original: ghanasiniddhabhāvadassanatthaṃ.
translated: which is also called “fragrant oil.” The mention of perfumed oil is for the purpose of showing the thickness and compactness of the betel roll.🔽Just as a piece of cotton cloth, beaten a hundred times, becomes very soft when placed on a slab of ghee, so it is with the great man’s hands and feet.

original: Yathā satakkhattuṃ vihataṃ kappāsapaṭalaṃ sappimaṇḍe osāritaṃ ativiya mudu hoti, evaṃ mahāpurisassa hatthapādāti dassento “sappimaṇḍe”tiādimāha. Talunāti sukhumālā.🔽Cammenāti aṅgulantaraveṭhitacammena. Paṭibaddhaaṅgulantaroti ekato sambaddhaaṅgulantaro🔽na hoti. Ekappamāṇāti dīghato samānappamāṇā. Yavalakkhaṇanti abbhantarato aṅgulipabbe
analyzed: yathā sata kkhattum vihatam kappāsa paṭalam sappi maṇḍe osāritam ativiya mudu hoti evam mahā purisassa hattha pādā ati dassentaḥ sappi maṇḍa iti ādim āha  cammena ati aṅgula antara veṭhita cammena paṭibaddha aṅgula antaraḥ ti ekatas sambaddha aṅgula antaraḥ  na hoti eka ppamāṇā ati dīghataḥ samāna ppamāṇā yava lakkhaṇanti abbhantarataḥ aṅguli pabbe
translated: “Palate” : the soft palate.🔽“Skin” : the skin covering the fingers. “Not joined” : not joined together.🔽“Of equal size” : equal in length. “The size of a barley grain” : the size of a barley grain placed inside the finger joint.

original: ṭhitaṃ yavalakkhaṇaṃ. Paṭivijjhitvāti taṃtaṃpabbānaṃ samānadesatāya aṅgulīnaṃ pasāritakālepi
analyzed: ṭhitam yava lakkhaṇam paṭivijjhitvā ti taṃ taṃ pabbānam samāna desa tāya aṅgulīnam pasārita kāle pi
translated: “Penetrating” : when the fingers are extended, the joints are connected by the skin in such a way that they are not visible.

original: aññamaññaṃ vijjhitāni viya phusitvā tiṭṭhanti.🔽Saṅkhā vuccanti gopphakā, uddhaṃ saṅkhā etesanti ussaṅkhā, pādā. Piṭṭhipādeti piṭṭhipādasamīpe.
analyzed: aññam aññam vijjhitāni viya phusitvā tiṭṭhanti  saṅkhāḥ vuccanti gopphakāḥ uddham saṅkhāḥ etesanti ussaṅkhā pādā piṭṭhi pādā iti piṭṭhi pāda samīpe
translated: They stand as if piercing each other.🔽The heels are called the “anklets” . The feet are the “anklets above” . The “back of the foot” is the part near the back of the foot.

original: Tenāti piṭṭhipāde ṭhitagopphakabhāvena baddhā hontīti yojanā. Tayidaṃ “tenā”ti padaṃ
analyzed: tena ati piṭṭhi pāde ṭhita gopphaka bhāvena baddhāḥ honti iti yojanā tayā idam tena ati padam
translated: The construction is: “They are bound by the part of the heels that is established in the anklets.”

original: uparipadadvayepi yojetabbaṃ “tena baddhabhāvena na yathāsukhaṃ parivaṭṭanti, tena
analyzed: upari pada dvaye pi yojetabbam tena baddha bhāvena na yathāsukham parivaṭṭanti tena
translated: This word “tenā” should be construed in both passages. “They do not turn as they please by that binding.

original: yathāsukhaṃ naparivaṭṭanena gacchantānaṃ pādatalānipi na dissantī”ti. Uparīti piṭṭhipādato🔽dvitiaṅgulimattaṃ uddhaṃ, “caturaṅgulamatta”nti ca vadanti. Nigūḷhāni ca honti, na
analyzed: yathāsukham na parivaṭṭanena gacchantānam pāda talāni pi na dissanti iti upari iti piṭṭhi pādato  ca vadanti nigūḍhāni ca honti na
translated: By that non-turning as they please, the soles of the feet do not appear as they walk.”🔽“Above” means above the back of the foot,

original: aññesaṃ viya paññāyamānāni. Tenāti gopphakānaṃ upari patiṭṭhitabhāvena. Assāti mahāpurisassa.
analyzed: aññesam viya paññāyamānāni tena ati gopphakānam upari patiṭṭhita bhāvena assa āti mahāpurisassa
translated: “four fingerbreadths” . They are “covered” , not appearing like those of others. By that means by the part that is established above the anklets. “The Great Man’s” .

original: Satipi desantarappavattiyaṃ niccaloti dassanatthaṃ nābhiggahaṇaṃ. “Adhokāyova iñjatī”ti
analyzed: sati pi desa antara ppavattiyam niccalaḥ ti dassana attham nābhi ggahaṇam adhokāyaḥ uva iñjati iti
translated: Although they move to another place, in order to show that they are motionless, he does not mention the navel. “Only the lower body moves.”

original: idaṃ purimapadassa kāraṇavacanaṃ. Yasmā adhokāyova iñjati, tasmā nābhito…pe… niccalo
analyzed: idam purima padassa kāraṇa vacanam yasmai iñjati tasmai na abhitope niccalo
translated: This is a statement of the reason for the former term. Because only the lower part moves, therefore from the navel … unmoving.

original: hoti. “Sukhena pādā parivaṭṭantī”ti idaṃ pana purimassa, pacchimassa ca kāraṇavacanaṃ.
analyzed: hoti sukhena pādā parivaṭṭanti iti idam pana purimassa pacchimassa ca kāraṇa vacanam
translated: This is a statement of the reason for the former term. Because the lower part moves, the navel … and so on up to … the head is steady. “The feet turn with ease” is a statement of the reason for the former and the latter terms.

original: Yasmā sukhena pādā parivaṭṭanti, tasmā adhokāyova iñjati, yasmā sukhena pādā parivaṭṭanti,
analyzed: yasmai sukhena pādā parivaṭṭanti tasmai adhokāyā uva iñjati yasmai sukhena pādā parivaṭṭanti
translated: Because the feet turn with ease, the lower part moves. Because the feet turn with ease,

original: tasmā puratopi…pe… pacchatoyevāti.
analyzed: tasmai
translated: the head moves forward and back.

original: Yasmā eṇimigassa samantato ekasadisamaṃsā anukkamena uddhaṃ thūlā jaṅghā honti, tathā
analyzed: yasmai eṇi migassa samantataḥ eka sadisa maṃsāḥ anukkamena uddham thūlāḥ jaṅghāḥ honti tathā
translated: Because the deer’s thighs are gradually thicker above, all round, and in the same way,

original: mahāpurisassāpi, tasmā vuttaṃ “eṇimigasadisajaṅgho”ti. Paripuṇṇajaṅghoti samantato
analyzed: mahā purisassa api tasmai vuttam eṇi miga sadisa jaṅgho ti paripuṇṇa jaṅgho ti samantataḥ
translated: the Great Man’s thighs are also. Therefore it is said that he has thighs like the deer’s. He has well-rounded thighs,

original: maṃsūpacayena paripuṇṇajaṅgho. Tenāha “na ekato”tiādi.🔽Etenāti “anonamanto”tiādivacanena, jāṇuphāsubhāvadīpanenāti attho. Avasesajanāti
analyzed: tena āha na ekatas iti ādi  etena ati jāṇu phāsu bhāva dīpanena ati atthaḥ
translated: his thighs being well rounded with the accumulation of flesh all round. Therefore it is said that they are not one-sided.

original: iminā lakkhaṇena rahitajanā. Khujjā vā honti heṭṭhimakāyato uparimakāyassa rassatāya,
analyzed: iminā lakkhaṇena rahita janā khujjāḥ vā honti heṭṭhima kāyataḥ uparima kāyassa
translated: “By this” : by the statement “without bending down” and so on, which shows the excellence of the knees. “Other people” : people who are devoid of this characteristic. They are either bent or crooked, because the upper part of their body is short in comparison with the lower part.

original: vāmanā vā uparimakāyato heṭṭhimakāyassa rassatāya, etena ṭhapetvā sammāsambuddhaṃ,
analyzed: vāmanāḥ vā uparima kāyataḥ heṭṭhima kāyassa rassa tāya etena ṭhapetvā sammāsambuddham
translated: Or else, “dwarf” means “short” in the sense of “short in stature,” as in the expression “dwarf-like body.”

original: cakkavattinañca itare sattā khujjapakkhikā, vāmanapakkhikā cāti dasseti.
analyzed: cakkavattinaṃ ca itare sattā khujjapakkhikā vāmanapakkhikā ca ati dasseti
translated: By this phrase, the Exalted One shows that all beings are crooked and dwarfish except for the Perfectly Enlightened One and the Wheel-turning Monarch.

original: Kāmaṃ sabbāpi padumakaṇṇikā suvaṇṇavaṇṇāva, kañcanapadumakaṇṇikā pana pabhassarabhāvena
analyzed: kāmam sabbā api paduma kaṇṇikā suvaṇṇa vaṇṇā ava kañcana paduma kaṇṇikā pana pabhassara bhāvena
translated: Although all lotus-buds are golden in color, the golden lotus-bud is more radiant than the others.

original: tato sātisayāti āha “suvaṇṇapadumakaṇṇikasadisehī”ti. Ohitanti samohitaṃ antogadhaṃ.
analyzed: āha suvaṇṇa paduma kaṇṇika sadisehi iti ohitam ti samohitam
translated: Therefore, the Exalted One says, “like a golden lotus-bud.” “Covered” means concealed, hidden.

original: Tathābhūtaṃ pana taṃ tena channaṃ hotīti āha “paṭicchanna”nti.
analyzed: tathābhūtam pana tam tena channam hoti iti āha paṭicchannam iti
translated: But when it is in that condition, it is covered by it. Therefore, the Exalted One says, “concealed.”

original: Suvaṇṇavaṇṇoti suvaṇṇavaṇṇavaṇṇoti ayamettha atthoti āha “jātihiṅgulakenā”tiādi,
analyzed: suvaṇṇa vaṇṇo ti suvaṇṇa vaṇṇa vaṇṇo ti ayam ettha atthaḥ ti āha jāti hiṅgulakena atiādi
translated: “Golden in color” means “having the color of gold.” The meaning here is this: “having the color of gold.” Therefore, the Exalted One says, “with the golden hue of the birthmark.”

original: svāyamattho āvuttiñāyena ca veditabbo. Sarīrapariyāyo idha vaṇṇa-saddoti adhippāyo.
analyzed: svāyam atthaḥ āvutti ñāyena ca veditabbo sarīra pariyāyaḥ idha vaṇṇa saddo ti adhippāyaḥ
translated: This meaning should be understood by the method of word analysis. The intended meaning is that the word “color” here is a synonym for “body.”

original: Paṭhamavikappaṃ vatvā tathārūpāya pana ruḷhiyā abhāvaṃ manasi katvā vaṇṇadhātupariyāyameva
analyzed: paṭhama vikappam vatvā tathārūpāya pana ruḷhiyāḥ abhāvam manasi katvā vaṇṇa dhātu pariyāyam eva
translated: After stating the first interpretation, the Exalted One, thinking of the absence of such a condition,

original: vaṇṇa-saddaṃ gahetvā dutiyavikappo vutto. Tasmā padadvayenāpi suniddhantasuvaṇṇasadisachavivaṇṇoti vuttaṃ hoti.
analyzed: vaṇṇa saddam gahetvā dutiya vikappaḥ vuttaḥ tasmā pada dvayena api vuttam hoti
translated: The second description is given by taking the colour and sound. Therefore it is said by the two phrases: “like well-refined gold in colour” and “like the sound of a kettle-drum.”

original: Rajoti sukhumarajo. Jallanti malīnabhāvāvaho reṇusañcayo. Tenāha “malaṃ vā”ti. Yadi vivattati, kathaṃ nhānādīnīti āha “hatthadhovanādīnī”tiādi.
analyzed: rajaḥ iti sukhuma rajaḥ jallanti malīna bhāva āvahaḥ reṇu sañcayaḥ tena āha malam vāti yadi vivattati katham nhāna ādīni iti āha hattha dhovana ādīni itiādi
translated: “Dust” means fine dust. “Dirt” means a collection of particles that cause a soiled condition. Therefore it is said: “dirt.” If it turns away, how is it bathing, etc.? Therefore it is said: “washing the hands, etc.”

original: Āvaṭṭapariyosāneti padakkhiṇāvaṭṭanavasena pavattassa āvaṭṭassa ante.
analyzed: āvaṭṭa pariyosāne ti padakkhiṇa avaṭṭana vasena pavattassa āvaṭṭassa ante
translated: “At the end of the turning around” means at the end of the turning around that occurs by turning to the right.

original: Brahmuno sarīraṃ purato vā pacchato vā anonamitvā ujukameva uggatanti āha “brahmā
analyzed: brahmunā sarīram puratas vā pacchatas vā anonamitvā ujukam eva āha brahmā
translated: Brahmā’s body does not bend forward or backward, but it rises straight up. Therefore it is said: “straight like Brahmā’s body.”

original: viya ujugatto”ti. Sā panāyaṃ ujugattatā avayavesu buddhippattesu daṭṭhabbā, na daharakāleti
analyzed: viya uju gattaḥ ti sā pana ayam uju gatta tā avayavesu buddhippattesu daṭṭhabbā na dahara kāle iti
translated: This straightness should be seen in the limbs that have attained understanding, not in the tender limbs.

original: vuttaṃ “uggatadīghasarīro bhavissatī”ti. Itaresūti “khandhajāṇūsū”ti imesu dvīsu
analyzed: vuttam uggata dīgha sarīraḥ bhavissati iti itaresu iti khandha jāṇūsu iti imesu dvīsu
translated: Therefore it is said: “it will be a tall body with straight limbs.” “In the other two places” means in these two places: “at the shoulders and knees.”

original: ṭhānesu namantā purato namantīti ānetvā sambandho. Passavaṅkāti dakkhiṇapassena vā
analyzed: ṭhānesu namantā puratas namanti iti ānetvā sambandho passa vaṅkā ti dakkhiṇa passena vā
translated: “Bending forward” means bending forward, bringing forward. “The curve of the shoulder” means by the right shoulder.

original: vāmapassena vā vaṅkā. Sūlasadisāti potthakarūpakaraṇe ṭhapitasūlapādasadisā.
analyzed: vāma passena vā vaṅkā sūla sadisā ati potthaka rūpa karaṇe ṭhapita sūla pāda sadisā
translated: and the left side is bent. Like a post: like the post-base of a plough.

original: Hatthapiṭṭhiādivasena satta sarīrāvayavā ussadā upacitamaṃsā etassāti sattussado.
analyzed: hattha piṭṭhi ādi vasena satta sarīra avayavāḥ ussadāḥ upacita maṃsāḥ etassa ati sattussadaḥ
translated: Seven prominent parts of the body: the seven parts of the body that are prominent, that have accumulated flesh, namely, the two hands, the two feet, the two shoulders, and the nape of the neck.🔽The meaning is that the ends of the bones can be seen.

original: Aṭṭhikoṭiyo paññāyantīti yojanā. Nigūḷhasirājālehīti lakkhaṇavacanametanti tena nigūḷhaaṭṭhikoṭīhītipi🔽vuttameva hotīti. Hatthapiṭṭhādīhīti ettha ādi-saddena aṃsakūṭakhandhakūṭānaṃ saṅgahe
analyzed: aṭṭhi koṭiyo paññāyanti iti yojanā nigūḷha sirā jālehi iti lakkhaṇa vacanam etat ti tena nigūḷha aṭṭhi koṭīhi iti pi  vuttam eva hoti iti hattha piṭṭha ādīhi iti ettha ādi saddena aṃsakūṭa khandhakūṭānam saṅgahe
translated: The phrase “with hidden ankle-bones” is a description. Therefore it is said that he has hidden ankle-bones.🔽The phrase “with hands, feet, and so on” includes the shoulders and the nape of the neck.

original: siddhe taṃ ekadesena dassento “vaṭṭetvā…pe… khandhenā”ti āha. “Silārūpakaṃ viyā”tiādinā
analyzed: siddhe tam eka desena dassentaḥ vaṭṭetvā āpe khandhena iti āha silā rūpakam viyāti ādinā
translated: To show that by the word “and so on” in the phrase “with hands, feet, and so on” the shoulders and the nape of the neck are included, he says, “with rounded shoulders and a well-developed neck.”

original: vā nigūḷhaaṃsakūṭatāpi vibhāvitā yevāti daṭṭhabbaṃ.
analyzed: vā nigūḷha aṃsakūṭa tā api vibhāvitā yā iva ati daṭṭhabbam
translated: The phrase “with hidden shoulders” should be understood to mean that his shoulders are rounded.

original: Sīhassa pubbaddhaṃ sīhapubbaddhaṃ, paripuṇṇāvayavatāya sīhapubbaddhaṃ viya sakalo🔽kāyo assāti sīhapubbaddhakāyo. Tenāha “sīhassa pubbaddhakāyo viya sabbo kāyo paripuṇṇo”ti.
analyzed: sīhassa pubbaddham sīha pubbaddham paripuṇṇa avayava tāya sīha pubbaddham viya sakalaḥ 🔽kāyaḥ assa ati sīha pubbaddha kāyaḥ tena āha sīhassa pubbaddha kāyaḥ viya sabbaḥ kāyo paripuṇṇo ti
translated: With a chest like a lion’s: his whole body is like a lion’s body, complete with all its parts.

original: Sīhassevāti sīhassa viya. Dussaṇṭhitavisaṇṭhito na hotīti duṭṭhu saṇṭhito, virūpasaṇṭhito
analyzed: sīhassa iva ati sīhassa viya dussaṇṭhita visaṇṭhitaḥ na hoti iti duṭṭhu saṇṭhitaḥ virūpa saṇṭhitaḥ
translated: Like a lion: like a lion. He is not ill-formed or deformed: he is not ill-formed, not deformed.

original: ca na hoti, tesaṃ tesaṃ avayavānaṃ ayuttabhāvena, virūpabhāvena ca saṇṭhiti upagato
analyzed: ca na hoti tesam tesam avayavānam ayutta bhāvena virūpa bhāvena ca saṇṭhiti upagataḥ
translated: The meaning is that he is not formed by the coming together of limbs that are ugly and misshapen.

original: na hotīti attho. Saṇṭhantīti saṇṭhahanti. Dīghehīti aṅgulināsādīhi. Rassehīti gīvādīhi.
analyzed: na hoti iti attho saṇṭhanti iti saṇṭhahanti dīghehi iti aṅguli nāsā ādīhi rassehi iti gīvā ādīhi
translated: They form: they come together. Long: with fingers, nose, etc. Short: with neck, etc.🔽Thick: with thighs, arms, etc. Thin: with hair of the head and body, etc.

original: Thūlehīti ūrubāhuādīhi. Kisehīti kesalomamajjhādīhi. Puthulehīti akkhihatthatalādīhi.
analyzed: thūlehi iti ūru bāhu ādīhi kisehi iti kesa loma majjha ādīhi puthulehi iti akkhi hattha tala ādīhi
translated: Round: with eyes, palms of hands, etc.

original: Vaṭṭehīti jaṅghahatthādīhi.🔽Satapuññalakkhaṇatāya nānācittena puññacittena cittito sañjātacittabhāvo “īdiso eva
analyzed: vaṭṭehi iti jaṅgha hattha ādīhi  sata puñña lakkhaṇa tāya nānā cittena puñña cittena cittitaḥ sañjāta citta bhāvaḥ īdisaḥ eva
translated: Square: with shanks, hands, etc.

original: buddhānaṃ dhammakāyassa adhiṭṭhānaṃ bhavituṃ yutto”ti dasapāramīhi sajjito abhisaṅkhato,
analyzed: buddhānam dhammakāyassa adhiṭṭhānam bhavitum yuttaḥ iti dasa pāramīhi sajjitaḥ abhisaṅkhataḥ
translated: Because of the hundred merits: because of the various kinds of merit, because of the meritorious thought. Formed: arisen in the form of thought. “Such a one is fit to be the basis for the Dhamma-body of the Buddhas,” he is endowed with the ten perfections, he is formed by them.

original: “dānacittena puññacittenā”ti vā pāṭho, dānavasena, sīlādivasena ca pavattapuññacittenāti attho.
analyzed: dāna cittena puñña cittena ati vā pāṭhaḥ dāna vasena sīla ādi vasena ca pavatta puñña cittena ati atthaḥ
translated: Or the reading may be “dānacittena puññacittena,” in which case the meaning is: because of the meritorious thought that occurs as giving, virtue, etc.

original: Dvinnaṃ koṭṭānaṃ antaranti dvinnaṃ piṭṭhibāhānaṃ vemajjhaṃ piṭṭhimajjhassa uparibhāgo.
analyzed: dvinnam koṭṭānam dvinnam piṭṭhi bāhānam vemajjham piṭṭhi majjhassa upari bhāgaḥ
translated: In the middle of the two buttocks: in the middle of the two buttocks and the two upper arms, the upper part of the middle of the back.

original: Citaṃ paripuṇṇanti aninnabhāvena citaṃ, dvīhi koṭṭehi samatalatāya paripuṇṇaṃ. Uggammāti
analyzed: citam paripuṇṇanti aninna bhāvena citam dvīhi koṭṭehi sama tala tāya paripuṇṇam uggamma ati
translated: The navel is deep and full: it is deep because it does not bulge out; it is full because it is level with the two sides. It is like a clear deep pool of water,

original: uggantvā, aninnaṃ samatalaṃ hutvāti adhippāyo. Tenāha “suvaṇṇaphalakaṃ viyā”ti.🔽Nigrodho viya parimaṇḍaloti parimaṇḍalanigrodho viya parimaṇḍalo, “nigrodhaparimaṇḍalaparimaṇḍalo”ti
analyzed: uggantvā aninnam sama talam hutvā iti adhippāyaḥ tena āha suvaṇṇa phalakam viyā ti  nigrodhaḥ parimaṇḍalaḥ ati parimaṇḍala nigrodhaḥ viya parimaṇḍalaḥ nigrodha parimaṇḍala parimaṇḍalaḥ iti
translated: the surface of which is level with the surrounding land. The meaning is that it is not sunken or protruding but is level. Hence it is said, “like a golden plate.”

original: vattabbe ekassa parimaṇḍala-saddassa lopaṃ katvā “nigrodhaparimaṇḍalo”ti vutto. Tenāha
analyzed: vattabbe ekassa parimaṇḍala saddassa lopam katvā nigrodha parimaṇḍalaḥ ti vuttaḥ tena āha
translated: Round like a navel: round like a navel. “Round like a banyan-tree” should be said, but by the omission of one “round” it is said “round like a banyan-tree.” Therefore it is said,

original: “samakkhandhasākho nigrodho”tiādi. Na hi sabbo nigrodho parimaṇḍaloti, parimaṇḍalasaddasannidhānena
analyzed: sama khandha sākhaḥ nigrodhaḥ tiādi na hi sabbaḥ nigrodho parimaṇḍalo ti parimaṇḍala sadda sannidhānena
translated: “The banyan-tree has a round trunk and round branches.” For not all banyan-trees are round.

original: vā parimaṇḍalova nigrodho gayhatīti ekassa parimaṇḍalasaddassa lopena vināpi ayamattho
analyzed: vā parimaṇḍalaḥ uva nigrodhaḥ gayhati iti ekassa parimaṇḍala saddassa lopena vinā api ayam attho
translated: Or the meaning can be taken as “a banyan-tree is round,” since the word “round” is present.

original: labbhatīti āha “nigrodho viya parimaṇḍalo”ti. Yāvatako assāti yāvatakvassa o-kārassa va-kārādesaṃ katvā.
analyzed: labbhati iti āha nigrodhaḥ viya parimaṇḍalaḥ ti yāvatakaḥ assa ati okārassa vakāra ādesam katvā
translated: “As far as the letter o” means as far as the letter o in the word oja .🔽“His shoulders are well rounded” means that his shoulders are well rounded.🔽The explanation of the words “his neck is like a conch” is that his neck is like a white conch.🔽“His tongue is slender” means that his tongue is slender like a lotus petal.🔽“He has a brahmic voice” means that he has a voice like Brahmā’s.🔽“His teeth are even” means that his teeth are even and well set.🔽“His teeth are without gaps” means that his teeth are without gaps.🔽“His eyes are blue” means that his eyes are blue like the color of the blue lotus.🔽“His eyelashes are like a cow’s” means that his eyelashes are like a cow’s.

original: Samavaṭṭitakkhandhoti samaṃ suvaṭṭitakkhandho. Koñcā viya dīghagalā, bakā viya vaṅkagalā, varāhā viya puthulagalāti yojanā. Suvaṇṇāḷiṅgasadisoti suvaṇṇamayakhuddakamudiṅgasadiso.
analyzed: sama avaṭṭita khandho ti samam su vaṭṭita kkhandho koñcāḥ viya dīgha galāḥ bakāḥ viya vaṅka galāḥ varāhāḥ viya puthula galāḥ iti yojanā suvaṇṇa āḷiṅga sadisaḥ iti suvaṇṇa maya khuddaka mudiṅga sadisaḥ
translated: “His head is like a turban” means that his head is like a turban.🔽“He has the ushnisha mark” means that he has the ushnisha mark on his head.

original: Rasaggasaggīti madhurādibhedaṃ rasaṃ gasanti anto pavesantīti rasaggasā rasaggasānaṃ
analyzed: rasaggasaggī iti madhura ādi bhedam rasam gasanti antar pavesanti iti
translated: “He has the ushnisha protuberance” means that he has the ushnisha protuberance on his head.🔽“He has the ushnisha coil” means that he has the ushnisha coil on his head.🔽“He has the ushnisha crest” means that he has the ushnisha crest on his head.

original: aggā rasaggasaggā, tā etassa santīti rasaggasaggī. Tenāti ojāya apharaṇena hīnadhātukattā
analyzed: aggāḥ rasagga saggā tāḥ etassa santi iti rasagga saggī tena ati ojāya a pharaṇena hīna dhātuka ttā
translated: “He has the ushnisha peak” means that he has the ushnisha peak on his head.🔽“He has the ushnisha summit” means that he has the ushnisha summit on his head.

original: te bahvābādhā honti.
analyzed: te bahu ābādhāḥ honti
translated: “He has the ushnisha top” means that he has the ushnisha top on his head.🔽“He has the ushnisha crown” means that he has the ushnisha crown on his head.🔽“He has the ushnisha pinnacle” means that he has the ushnisha pinnacle on his head.🔽“He has the ushnisha spire” means that he has the ushnisha spire on his head.🔽“He has the ushnisha crest jewel” means that he has the ushnisha crest jewel on his head.

original: Hanūti sannissayadantādhārassa samaññā, taṃ bhagavato sīhassa hanu viya, tasmā bhagavā🔽sīhahanu. Tattha yasmā buddhānaṃ rūpakāyassa, dhammakāyassa ca upamā nāma hīnūpamāva,
analyzed: hanu iti sannissaya danta ādhārassa samaññā tam bhagavataḥ sīhassa hanu viya tasmai bhagavā 🔽sīha hanu tattha yasmā buddhānam rūpa kāyassa dhamma kāyassa ca upamā nāma hīna upamā ava
translated: “He has the ushnisha jewel” means that he

original: natthi samānūpamā, kuto adhikūpamā, tasmā ayampi hīnūpamāti dassetuṃ “tatthā”tiādi
analyzed: natthi sama anūpamā kutas adhikūpamā tasmā ayam pi hi inūpamā ti dassetum tattha atiādi
translated: There is no simile equal to it, much less one surpassing it. Therefore, in order to show that this is also a simile for what is inferior, it is said: “In that case, etc.”

original: vuttaṃ. Yasmā mahāpurisassa heṭṭhimānurūpavaseneva uparimampi saṇṭhitaṃ, tasmā vuttaṃ
analyzed: vuttam yasmā mahā purisassa heṭṭhima anurūpa vasena iva uparimam pi saṇṭhitam tasmā vuttam
translated: Since the Great Man’s upper teeth are arranged in the same way as the lower ones, it is said:

original: “dvepi paripuṇṇānī”ti, tañca kho na sabbaso parimaṇḍalatāya, atha kho tibhāgāvasesamaṇḍalatāyāti
analyzed: dve api paripuṇṇāni iti tat ca kho na sabbaso parimaṇḍala tāya atha kho ti bhāga avasesa maṇḍala tāya ati
translated: “Both are complete.” But this is not so in every respect by way of complete circularity; rather, it is by way of the circularity of the remaining three parts.🔽Therefore it is said: “They are like the moon on the fourteenth day of the lunar half-month.”

original: āha “dvādasiyā pakkhassa candasadisānī”ti. Sallakkhetvāti attano lakkhaṇasatthānusārena
analyzed: āha dvādasiyā pakkhassa canda sadisāni iti sallakkhetvā iti attanaḥ lakkhaṇa sattha anusārena
translated: “Having observed”: having considered by way of the characteristics of the teacher’s instruction.

original: upadhāretvā. Dantānaṃ uccanīcatā abbhantarabāhirapassavasenapi veditabbā, na aggavaseneva.
analyzed: upadhāretvā dantānam ucca nīca tā abbhantara bāhira passa vasena api veditabbā na agga vasena iva
translated: The height and shortness of the teeth should be understood by way of the inner and outer surfaces, not by way of the tips.

original: Tenāha “ayapaṭṭakena chinnasaṅkhapaṭalaṃ viyā”ti. Ayapaṭṭakanti kakacaṃ adhippetaṃ.
analyzed: tena āha aya paṭṭakena chinna saṅkha paṭalam viyāti aya paṭṭakam ti ka kacam adhippetam
translated: Therefore it is said: “Like a section of shell cut by a saw.” “A saw” is intended for “a saw-leaf.”

original: Samā bhavissanti, na visamā, samasaṇṭhānāti attho.
analyzed: samāḥ bhavissanti na visamā sama saṇṭhānā ti attho
translated: They will be even, not uneven; the meaning is, they will be arranged evenly.

original: Sātisayaṃ mududīghaputhulatādippakāraguṇā hutvā bhūtā jātāti pabhūtā, bha-kārassa ha-kāraṃ katvā pahūtā jivhā etassāti pahūtajivho.🔽Vicchinditvā vicchinditvā pavattasaratāya chinnassarāpi. Anekākāratāya bhinnassarāpi.🔽Kākassa viya amanuññasaratāya kākassarāpi. Apalibuddhattāti anupaddutavatthukattā,
analyzed: sa atisayam mudu dīgha puthula tā ādi ppakāra guṇāḥ hutvā bhūtā jātā ati pabhūtā bhakārassa hakāram katvā pahūtā jivhā etassa ati pahūta jivhaḥ  vicchinditvā vicchinditvā pavatta saratāya chinna ssarā api aneka ākāra tāya bhinna ssarā api  kākassa viya a manuñña sara tāya kākassarā api a palibuddha ttā ati an upadduta vatthuka ttā
translated: They are “abundant” because they have become elements by being born with the special qualities of softness, length, thickness, etc., and the letter bha is changed to ha, thus they are “abundant tongue” .🔽They are “with split ends” because they occur by splitting and dividing. They are “with divided ends” because they have many modes.🔽They are “with crow’s ends” because they have the mode of a crow’s disfavour. “Unimpeded” means “with unimpeded object.”

original: vatthūti ca akkharuppattiṭṭhānaṃ veditabbaṃ. Aṭṭhaṅgasamannāgatoti ettha aṅgāni parato
analyzed: vatthu uti ca akkhara uppatti ṭṭhānam veditabbam aṭṭhaṅga samannāgataḥ ti ettha aṅgāni paratas
translated: It is “abundant” because it has become a being by being endowed with the special qualities of softness, length, thickness, etc., or because it is “abundant” in the sense of “abundant tongue” since it is “abundant” in the sense of “having much” .

original: āgamissanti. Mañjughosoti madhurassaro.
analyzed: āgamissanti mañjughosaḥ uti madhurassaro
translated: It is “with a sweet voice” because it has a pleasant sound.🔽It is “with a voice like Brahmā’s” because it has a voice like Brahmā’s.

original: Abhinīlanettoti adhikanīlanetto, adhikatā ca sātisayaṃ nīlabhāvena veditabbā, na
analyzed: abhinīla netto ti adhika nīla netto adhika tā ca sa atisayam nīla bhāvena veditabbā na
translated: It is “with a voice like the cuckoo’s” because it has a voice like the cuckoo’s.

original: nettanīlabhāvasseva adhikabhāvatoti āha “na sakalanīlanetto”tiādi. Pītalohitavaṇṇā
analyzed: netta nīla bhāvassa iva adhika bhāvato ti āha na sakala nīla nettā itiādi pīta lohita vaṇṇā
translated: It is “with a voice like the kalaviṅka’s” because it has a voice like the kalaviṅka’s.🔽It is “with a voice like the crane’s” because it has a voice like the crane’s.🔽It is “with a voice like the drum’s” because it has a voice like the drum’s.

original: setamaṇḍalagatarājivasena. Nīlasetakāḷavaṇṇā pana taṃtaṃmaṇḍalavaseneva veditabbā.
analyzed: seta maṇḍala gata rāji vasena nīla seta kāḷa vaṇṇā pana tat tat maṇḍala vasena iva veditabbā
translated: It is “with a voice like the kettledrum’s” because it has a voice like the kettledrum’s.🔽It is “with a voice like the conch’s” because it has a voice like the conch’s.🔽It is “with a voice like the thunder’s” because it has a voice like the thunder’s.

original: “Cakkhubhaṇḍanti akkhidala”nti keci. “Akkhidalavaṭuma”nti aññe. Akkhidalehi pana🔽saddhiṃ akkhibimbanti veditabbaṃ. Evañhi viniggatagambhīrajotanāpi yuttā hoti. “Adhippeta”nti🔽iminā ayamettha adhippāyo ekadesena samudāyupalakkhaṇañāyenāti dasseti. Yasmā pakhuma-saddo
analyzed: cakkhubhaṇḍanti akkhidalanti keci akkhidala vaṭumanti aññe akkhidalehi pana  saddhim akkhibimbanti veditabbam evam hi viniggata gambhīra jotanā api yuttā hoti adhippetanti  iminā ayam ettha adhippāyaḥ ekadesena samudāya upalakkhaṇa ñāyena ati dasseti yasmā pakhuma saddaḥ
translated: ‘Eye-ointment’ is the eye-ball, some say. Others say it is the eye-ball and the eye-lid. But it should be understood as the eye-ball together with the eye-lids, for then the expression ‘deep and clear’ is appropriate. ‘What is intended’ : by this he shows that the intention here is to point out the characteristic of the collection in part, since the word ‘pakhuma’ is a collective term.

original: loke akkhidalalomesu niruḷho, tenevāha “mudusiniddhanīlasukhumapakhumācitāni akkhīnī”ti.🔽Kiñcāpi uṇṇā-saddo loke avisesato lomapariyāyo, idha pana lomavisesavācakoti āha
analyzed: loke akkhi dala lomesu niruḷhaḥ tena iva āha akkhīni iti  kiñca api uṇṇā saddaḥ loke avisesataḥ loma pariyāyaḥ idha pana loma visesa vācakaḥ ti āha
translated: “Eye-membrane” is the eye’s film, say some. “The eye’s film and the eye’s film-sack,” say others. But the eye’s film should be understood together with the eye’s film-sack, for then the expression “deep and hard to see” is appropriate. “The intended” : by this he shows that the intention here is to point out by the method of a part the whole, namely, the eye. Since the word “hair” is current in the world for the hairs of the eye’s film, he says “the eyes are covered with a fine, smooth, black hair-net.”

original: “uṇṇā loma”nti. Nalāṭavemajjhe jātāti nalāṭamajjhagatā jātā. Odātatāya upamā, na
analyzed: uṇṇāḥ nalāṭa vemajjhe nalāṭa vemajjhe jātāḥ ati nalāṭa majjha gatāḥ jātāḥ odāta tāya upamāḥ na
translated: And although the word “hair” is current in the world without distinction for any kind of hair, here it is a term for a particular kind of hair, so he says “hair is a kind of hair.” “Arisen in the middle of the forehead” : arisen in the middle of the forehead. The simile is in respect of whiteness, not in respect of softness,

original: mudutāya. Uṇṇā hi tatopi sātisayaṃ mudutarā. Tenāha“sappi maṇḍe”tiādi. Rajatapubbuḷakanti🔽rajatamayatārakamāha.
analyzed: mudu tāya uṇṇā hi tatas api sa atisayam mudutarā tena āha sappi maṇḍa itiādi rajata pubbuḷakanti 🔽rajata maya tārakam āha
translated: for the hair is softer than that. That is why he says “like a butter-lump,” etc. “Silver bubble” : he says this referring to a silver star.

original: Dve atthavase paṭicca vuttanti yasmā buddhā, cakkavattino ca paripuṇṇanalāṭatāya,
analyzed: dve attha vase paṭicca vuttanti yasmai buddhā cakkavattino ca paripuṇṇa nalāṭa tāya
translated: Two reasons are given for the head being shaped like a turban,🔽since Buddhas and Universal Monarchs are said to have “turban-shaped heads” because their foreheads are full and their heads are shaped like a full bowl.

original: paripuṇṇasīsabimbatāya ca “uṇhīsasīsā”ti vuccanti, tasmā te dve atthavase paṭicca
analyzed: paripuṇṇa sīsa bimba tāya ca uṇhīsa sīsā ati vuccanti tasmā te dve attha vase paṭicca
translated: “The head is shaped like a turban” is said for these two reasons.

original: “uṇhīsasīso”ti idaṃ vuttaṃ. Idāni taṃ atthadvayaṃ mahāpurise suppatiṭṭhitanti “mahāpurisassa
analyzed: idam vuttam idāni tam attha dvayam mahāpurise su patiṭṭhitanti mahāpurisassa
translated: Now, the two meanings are given in the Mahāpurisavagga with the words “The head of a great man is well set on his shoulders.”

original: hī”tiādi vuttaṃ. Saṇhatamatāya, suvaṇṇavaṇṇatāya, pabhassaratāya, paripuṇṇatāya ca
analyzed: hi itiādi vuttam saṇhatama tāya suvaṇṇa vaṇṇa tāya pabhassara tāya paripuṇṇa tāya ca
translated: It is well set on because it is compact, because it is golden-colored, because it is radiant, and because it is full.

original: rañño bandhauṇhīsapaṭṭo viya virocati. Kapisīsāti dvidhābhūtasīsā. Phalasīsāti phalitasīsā.
analyzed: raññaḥ bandha oṇhīsa paṭṭaḥ viya virocati kapi sīsā ati dvidhā bhūta sīsā phala sīsā ati phalita sīsā
translated: It shines like a turban-cloth on a king’s head. A “monkey-head” is a head that is divided in two. A “peaked head” is a head with a peak.

original: Aṭṭhisīsāti maṃsassa abhāvato ativiya aṭṭhitāya, patanubhāvato vā taconaddhaaṭṭhimattasīsā.🔽Tumbasīsāti lābusadisasīsā. Pabbhārasīsāti piṭṭhibhāgena olambamānasīsā. Purimanayenāti
analyzed: aṭṭhi sīsā ati maṃsassa abhāvataḥ ativiya aṭṭhitāya patanu bhāvataḥ vā taconaddha aṭṭhi matta sīsā  tumba sīsā ati lābu sadisa sīsā pabbhāra sīsā ati piṭṭhi bhāgena olambamāna sīsā purima nayena ati
translated: A “bone-head” is a head that is very bony because of the absence of flesh, or a head that is the size of a piece of bone wrapped in a cloth.🔽A “conch-head” is a head shaped like a conch. A “hanging-head” is a head that hangs down by the back.

original: paripuṇṇanalāṭatāpakkhena. Uṇhīsaveṭhitasīso viyāti uṇhīsapaṭṭena veṭhitasīsapadeso
analyzed: paripuṇṇa nalāṭa tā pakkhena uṇhīsa veṭhita sīsaḥ viyāti uṇhīsa paṭṭena veṭhita sīsa padesaḥ
translated: “In the same way” means by the method of the full forehead. “As if the head were wrapped in a turban” means that the place on the head where a turban would be wrapped

original: viya. Uṇhīsaṃ viyāti chekena sippinā viracitauṇhīsamaṇḍalaṃ viya.
analyzed: viya uṇhīsam viyāti chekena sippinā viracita oṇhīsa maṇḍalam
translated: like a turban.

original: Vipassīsamaññāvaṇṇanā
analyzed: vipassī samaññā vaṇṇanā
translated: The description of the “Vipassi” sign

original: 37. Tassa vitthāroti tassa lakkhaṇapariggaṇhane nemittakānaṃ santappanassa vitthāro🔽vitthārakathā. Gabbhokkantiyaṃ nimittabhūta supinapaṭiggāhakasantappane vuttoyeva.
analyzed: tassa vitthāraḥ ti tassa lakkhaṇa pariggaṇhane nemittakānam santappanassa vitthāraḥ  vitthāra kathā gabbhokkantiyam supina paṭiggāhaka santappane vuttā yā iva
translated: The “elaboration” of his delight in the discovery of the characteristic is the “elaboration” of the delight of the diviners in the discovery of the sign in the dream.🔽The “elaboration” is the explanation. The “sign in the womb” is the dream that was the sign for the diviners’ delight.

original: Niddosenāti khārikaloṇikādidosarahitena. Dhātiyoti thaññapāyikā dhātiyo. Tā hi dhāpenti
analyzed: niddosena ati khārika loṇika ādi dosa rahitena dhātiyo ti thaññapāyikāḥ dhātiyo tāḥ hi dhāpenti
translated: “Without the smell of milk” means without the smell of milk, curd, etc. “Nurses” are nurses who give milk. For they “nurse”

original: thaññaṃ pāyentīti dhātiyo. “Tathā”ti iminā “saṭṭhi”nti padaṃ upasaṃharati, sesāpīti🔽nhāpikā, dhārikā, parihārikāti imā tividhā. Tāpi dahanti vidahanti nhānaṃ dahanti🔽dhārentīti “dhātiyo” tveva vuccanti. Tattha dhāraṇaṃ urasā, ūrunā, hatthehi vā suciraṃ
analyzed: thaññam pāyenti iti dhātiyaḥ tathā ati iminā saṭṭhin ti padam upasaṃharati sesā api iti  nhāpikā dhārikā parihārikā ati imā tividhā dahanti vidahanti nhānam dahanti  dhārenti iti dhātiyaḥ tu eva vuccanti tattha dhāraṇam urasā ūrunā hatthehi vā su ciram
translated: by giving milk. By “so” he includes the word “sixty.” The rest are🔽the three kinds beginning with “bathed.” They too “nurse” by bathing, by nursing, and by carrying. They are called “nurses” because they “nurse” by bathing, by nursing, and by carrying. Herein, “nursing” is the long carrying on the breast, on the hip, or in the arms.

original: velaṃ sandhāraṇaṃ. Pariharaṇaṃ aññassa aṅkato attano aṅkaṃ, aññassa bāhuto attano
analyzed: velam sandhāraṇam pariharaṇam aññassa aṅkataḥ attanaḥ aṅkam aññassa bāhutaḥ attanaḥ
translated: “Carrying” is the carrying on the hip or in the arms.

original: bāhuṃ upasaṃharantehi haraṇaṃ sampāpanaṃ.
analyzed: bāhum haraṇam sampāpanam
translated: The meaning is: the bringing about of the carrying away by those who are taking hold of the arm.

original: 38. Mañjussaroti saṇhassaro. Yo hi saṇho, so kharo na hotīti āha “akharassaro”ti.🔽Vaggussaroti manorammassaro, manorammatā cassa cāturiyane puññayogatoti āha “chekanipuṇassaro”ti.
analyzed: mañju ssaraḥ ti saṇha ssaraḥ yaḥ hi saṇhaḥ saḥ kharaḥ na hoti iti āha akhara ssaraḥ ti  vaggu ssaraḥ ti manoramma ssaraḥ manoramma tā ca ssa cāturiyane puñña yogato ti āha cheka nipuṇa ssaraḥ ti
translated: Sweet-voiced: soft-voiced. For one who is soft is not harsh. Thus it is said: “Not harsh-voiced.”🔽  Fine-voiced: charming-voiced. The meaning is: his charm is due to the performance of merit in the fourfold manner. Thus it is said: “Skilful in the fourfold manner.”

original: Madhurassaroti sotasukhassaro, sotasukhatā cassa ativiya iṭṭhabhāvenāti āha “sātassaro”ti.
analyzed: madhura ssaro ti sota sukha ssaro sota sukha tā ca ssa ativiya iṭṭha bhāvena ati āha sāta ssaro ti
translated: Honey-voiced: pleasant-to-hear-voiced. The meaning is: his pleasantness is due to the extreme desirability of his voice. Thus it is said: “Delightful-voiced.”

original: Pemanīyassaroti piyāyitabbassaro, piyāyitabbatā cassa suṇantānaṃ attani bhattisamuppādanenāti🔽āha “pemajanakassaro”ti. Karavīkassaroti. Karavīkasaddo yesaṃ sattānaṃ sotapathaṃ
analyzed: pemanīya ssaraḥ ti piyāyitabba ssaraḥ piyāyitabba tā ca suṇantānam attani bhatti samuppādanena ati  āha pemajanaka ssaro ti karavīka ssaro ti karavīka saddaḥ yesam sattānam sota patham
translated: Loveable-voiced: lovable-to-hear-voiced. The meaning is: his lovableness is due to the production of devotion in those who hear him. Thus it is said: “Voice-producing-love.”

original: upagacchati, te attano sarasampattiyā pakatiṃ jahāpetvā avase karonto attano vase
analyzed: upagacchati te attanaḥ sara sampattiyāḥ pakatim jahāpetvā avase karontaḥ attanaḥ vase
translated: Coo-like-voiced: the meaning is: the voice of those beings who have come within the range of hearing of the cooing of the cuckoo bird, being made to abandon its natural state, is made to serve his own purpose by making them come under his control. Showing that his voice is so sweet, he said “Therein.”

original: vatteti, evaṃ madhuroti dassento “tatrida”ntiādimāha. Tattha “karavīkasakuṇe”tiādi
analyzed: vattā iti evam madhurā iti dassentaḥ tatridanti ādim āha tattha karavīka sakuṇa itiādi
translated: Therein, “the cuckoo bird” and so on.

original: tassa sabhāvakathanaṃ. Laḷitanti pītivegasamuṭṭhitaṃ līḷaṃ. Chaḍḍetvāti “saṅkharaṇampi🔽madhurasaddasavanantarāyakara”nti tiṇāni apanetvā. Anikkhipitvāti bhūmiyaṃ anikkhipitvā
analyzed: tassa sabhāva kathanam laḷitanti pīti vega samuṭṭhitam līḷam chaḍḍetvā ati saṅkharaṇam pi  tiṇāni apanetvā a nikkhipitvā ati bhūmiyam a nikkhipitvā
translated: The rest is the description of the nature of the assembly. “Playful”: play arising from the flood of joy. “Having cast off”: having removed the grass, thinking “Even the sound of the grass being crushed will be an obstacle to hearing the sweet sound.” “Without laying down”: without laying down on the ground.

original: ākāsagatameva katvā. Anubaddhamigā vāḷamigehi. Tato maraṇabhayaṃ hitvā. Pakkhe pasāretvāti🔽pakkhe yathāpasārite katvā apatantā tiṭṭhanti.🔽Suvaṇṇapañjaraṃ vissajjesi yojanappamāṇe ākāse attano āṇāya pavattanato. Tenāha “so
analyzed: ākāsa gatam eva katvā anubaddha migāḥ vāḷa migehi tatas maraṇa bhayam hitvā pakkhe pasāretvā ati  pakkhe yathā apasārite katvā a patantā tiṭṭhanti  suvaṇṇa pañjaram vissajjesi yojana ppamāṇe ākāse attanaḥ āṇāya pavattanato tena āha so
translated: “In the air”: having made it to be in the air. “The deer that followed”: the deer that followed. “Having abandoned the fear of death”: having abandoned the fear of death. “Having extended their wings”: having extended their wings. “They stood without flying away.”

original: rājāṇāyā”tiādi. Laḷiṃsūti laḷitaṃ kātuṃ ārabhiṃsu. Taṃ pītinti taṃ buddhaguṇārammaṇaṃ🔽pītiṃ teneva nīhārena punappunaṃ pavattaṃ pītiṃ avijahitvā vikkhambhitakilesā therānaṃ
analyzed: rājāṇāya ati ādi laḷitam kātum ārabhiṃsu tam tam buddha guṇa ārammaṇam  pītim tena iva nīhārena punappunam pavattam pītim a vijahitvā vikkhambhita kilesā
translated: “The golden cage”: the golden cage. “He released”: he let go. “In the space of a league”: in the space of a league. “By his own power”: by his own power. Therefore he said “The king by his own power” and so on. “They played”: they began to play. “That joy”: that joy having the Buddha’s qualities as its object.

original: santike laddhadhammassavanasappāyā upanissayasampattiyā paripakkañāṇatāya sattahi…pe…
analyzed: santike laddha dhamma ssavana sappāyāḥ upanissaya sampattiyāḥ paripakka ñāṇa tāya satta hipe
translated: “Without abandoning”: without abandoning. “The defilements that had been suppressed”: the defilements that had been suppressed. “The elders”: the elders. “Having heard the Dhamma”: having heard the Dhamma. “The condition for the ripening of their knowledge”: the condition for the ripening of their knowledge. “The seven factors of enlightenment”: the seven factors of enlightenment.

original: patiṭṭhāsi. Sattasatamattena orodhajanena saddhiṃ padasāva therānaṃ santikaṃ upagatattā
analyzed: patiṭṭhāsi satta sata mattena orodha janena saddhim padasāva therānam santikam upagata ttā
translated: and it was established. Because he had gone to the elder’s presence on foot with a retinue of seven hundred men,

original: “sattahi jaṅghasatehi saddhi”nti vuttaṃ. Tatoti karavīkasaddato. Satabhāgena…pe…
analyzed: sattahi jaṅgha satehi saddhinti vuttam tatas ti
translated: it is said that he went “with seven hundred legs.” “From the sound of the plover” : from the sound of the plover’s cry. “By a hundredth part” : by a part that is a hundredth part of the sound of the plover’s cry.

original: veditabbo anekakappakoṭisatasambhūtapuññasambhārasamudāgatavatthusampattibhāvato.
analyzed: veditabbaḥ aneka kappa koṭi sata sambhūta puñña sambhāra samudāgata vatthu sampatti bhāvato
translated: It should be understood that it is so because it is the result of the accumulation of the requisites of merit arisen over a hundred thousand eons.

original: 39. Kammavipākajanti sātisayasucaritakammanibbattaṃ pittasemharuhirādīhi apalibuddhaṃ
analyzed: kamma vipāka janti sa atisaya su carita kamma nibbattam pitta semha ruhira ādīhi apalibuddham
translated: “The result of kamma” : it is the eye-sensitivity produced by the kamma of a very high degree of goodness, not affected by bile, phlegm, blood, etc.,

original: dūrepi ārammaṇaṃ sampaṭicchanasamatthaṃ kammavipākena sahajātaṃ, kammassa vā vipākabhāvena
analyzed: dūre pi ārammaṇam sampaṭicchana samattham kamma vipākena sahajātam kammassa vā vipāka bhāvena
translated: and capable of apprehending an object even at a distance, which is the result of kamma, arisen together with kamma, or

original: jātaṃ pasādacakkhu. Duvidhañhi dibbacakkhuṃ kammamayaṃ, bhāvanāmayanti. Tatridaṃ
analyzed: jātam pasādacakkhu duvidham hi dibba cakkhum kamma mayam bhāvanām ayanti tatra idam
translated: born as the result of kamma. There are two kinds of divine eye: that which is the result of kamma and that which is the result of development.

original: kammamayanti āha “na bhāvanāmaya”nti. Bhāvanāmayaṃ pana bodhimūle uppajjissati. Ayaṃ
analyzed: kamma mayan ti āha na bhāvanā mayan ti bhāvanā mayam pana bodhi mūle uppajjissati ayaṃ
translated: Herein, the divine eye that is the result of kamma is what is referred to here. “It is not the result of development” . But the divine eye that is the result of development will arise at the foot of the Bodhi Tree.

original: “so”ti sallakkhaṇaṃ kāmaṃ manoviññāṇena hoti, cakkhuviññāṇena pana tassa tathā vibhāvitattā
analyzed: so ti sat lakkhaṇam kāmam manaḥ viññāṇena hoti cakkhu viññāṇena pana tassa tathā vibhāvita ttā
translated: “That” : the discerning is, of course, by mind-consciousness. But because it is discerned in that way by eye-consciousness,

original: manoviññāṇassa tattha tathāpavattīti āha “yena nimittaṃ…pe… sakkotī”ti.
analyzed: manaḥ viññāṇassa tattha tathā pavatti iti āha yena sakkoti iti
translated: He says “he can bear up with the sign” because of the occurrence of the corresponding consciousness in the eye door.

original: 40. Vacanatthoti saddattho. Nimīlananti nimīlanadassanaṃ navisuddhaṃ, tathā ca akkhīni
analyzed: vacana atthaḥ ti sadda atthaḥ nimīlanam ti nimīlana dassanam na visuddham tathā ca akkhīni
translated: “Word meaning” is the meaning of the sound. “Closing” is the seeing of closing, which is not purified. So too, the eyes

original: avivaṭāni nimīladassanassa na visuddhibhāvato. Tabbipariyāyato pana dassanaṃ visuddhaṃ,
analyzed: nimīla dassanassa na visuddhi bhāvataḥ tad bipariyāyato pana dassanam visuddham
translated: are not purified because of the unpurifiedness of the seeing of closing. But the seeing that is the opposite of that is purified,

original: vivaṭañcāti āha “antarantarā”tiādi.
analyzed: āha antar antara ati ādi
translated: and it is open. Therefore he said “from time to time.”

original: 41. Nī-iti – jānanatthaṃ dhātuṃ gahetvā āha “panayati jānātī”ti. Yato vuttaṃ “animittā🔽na nāyare”ti, “vidūbhi neyyaṃ naravarassā”ti ca. Nī-iti pana pavattanatthaṃ dhātuṃ
analyzed: ni iti jānana attham dhātum gahetvā āha panayati jānāti iti yatas vuttam animittā  na nāyara iti neyyam nara varassa ati ca pana pavattana attham dhātum
translated: “Nī” : taking the element in the sense of knowing, he said “he leads, he knows.” For it is said, “He does not lead the sign away” ,

original: gahetvā “nayati pavattetī”ti. Appamatto ahosi tesu tesu kiccakaraṇīyesu.🔽42. Vassāvāso vassaṃ uttarapadalopena, tasmā vassaṃ, vasse vā, sannivāsaphāsutāya
analyzed: gahetvā nayati pavatteti iti appamattaḥ ahosi tesu tesu kicca karaṇīyesu  vassāvāsaḥ vassam uttara pada lopena tasmai vassam vasse vā sannivāsa phāsu tāya
translated: and “The wise man should lead the object to himself” . But taking the element in the sense of occurrence, he said “he leads, he causes to occur.” He was heedful in the performance of the various duties.

original: arahatīti vassiko, pāsādo. Māsā pana vasse utumhi bhavāti vassikā. Itaresūti hemantikaṃ
analyzed: arahati iti vassikaḥ pāsādaḥ māsā pana vasse utumhi bhavāti vassikā itaresu iti hemantikam
translated: “The rains” : the rains are so called because of the rain that falls in the rains. Therefore “in the rains” is the same as “in the rains, in the rainy season.” One who is worthy of the rains, of the rainy season, because of the opportunity for living together, is a “vassika” . But the months are called “vassika” because they exist in the rainy season, in the rains. “The others” : the winter months.

original: gimhikanti imesu. Eseva nayoti uttarapadalopena niddesaṃ atidisati.
analyzed: imesu esā iva uttara pada lopena niddesam atidisati
translated: ‘In the cold weather’ means in these. ‘Just so’ : he shows the description by omitting the second part of the compound.

original: Nātiucco hoti nātinīcoti gimhiko viya ucco, hemantiko viya nīco na hoti, atha kho
analyzed: na ati uccaḥ hoti na ati nīcaḥ iti gimhikaḥ viya uccaḥ hemantikaḥ viya nīcaḥ na hoti atha kho
translated: ‘Not too high, not too low’: it is not high like the one for the cold weather, and it is not low like the one for the hot weather. But

original: tadubhayavemajjhalakkhaṇatāya nātiucco hoti, nātinīco. Assāti pāsādassa. Nātibahūnīti🔽gimhikassa viya na atibahūni. Nātitanūnīti hemantikassa viya na khuddakāni, tanutarajālāni
analyzed: tad ubhaya vemajjha lakkhaṇa tāya na ati uccaḥ hoti na ati nīcaḥ assa ati pāsādassa na ati bahūni iti  gimhikassa viya na atibahūni na ati tanūni iti hemantikassa viya na khuddakāni tanutara jālāni
translated: it is not too high, not too low because of the characteristic of being in the middle of the two. ‘Assa’ : of the stilt house. ‘Not too many’:🔽not too many like the one for the hot weather. ‘Not too few’: not small, not fine-meshed like the one for the cold weather.

original: ca. Missakānevāti hemantike viya na uṇhaniyāneva, gimhike viya ca na sītaniyāneva,
analyzed: ca hemantike viya na uṇha niyānā iva gimhike viya ca na sīta niyānā iva
translated: ‘Mixed’: not only for the heat like the one for the cold weather, and not only for the cold like the one for the hot weather,

original: atha kho ubhayamissakāneva. Tanukānīti na puthulāni. Uṇhappavesanatthāyāti sūriyasantāpānuppavesāya.
analyzed: atha kho ubhaya missakāni eva tanukāni iti na puthulāni uṇha pavesana atthāya ati sūriya santāpa anuppavesāya
translated: but mixed with both. ‘Fine’: not thick. ‘For the entry of heat’: for the entry of the heat of the sun.

original: Bhittiniyūhānīti dakkhiṇapasse bhittīsu niyūhāni. Siniddhanti sinehavantaṃ, siniddhaggahaṇeneva
analyzed: bhitti niyūhāni iti dakkhiṇa passe bhittīsu niyūhāni siniddham ti sinehavantam siniddha ggahaṇena iva
translated: ‘Attached to the walls’: attached to the walls on the right side. ‘Smooth’: with oil, and by the mention of the smoothness

original: cassa garukatāpi vuttā eva. Kaṭukasannissitanti tikaṭukādikaṭukadrabbūpasañhitaṃ.
analyzed: cassa garuka tā api vuttā eva kaṭuka sannissitanti tikaṭuka ādi kaṭuka drabba upasañhitam
translated: its heaviness is also mentioned. ‘Attached to the sharp’: attached to the sharp, the very sharp, the rough.

original: Udakayantānīti udakadhārāvissandayantāni. Yathā jalayantāni, evaṃ himayantānipi tattha
analyzed: udaka yantāni iti udaka dhārā vissanda yantāni yathā jala yantāni evam hima yantāni pi tattha
translated: ‘Water-dripping’ means dripping with water-streams. As they do with water, so they do with ice.

original: karonti eva. Tasmā hemante viya himāni patantāniyeva hontīti ca veditabbaṃ.
analyzed: karonti eva tasmā hemante viya himāni patantāniyā iva honti iti ca veditabbam
translated: Therefore it should be understood that they fall in the cold season as though it were winter.

original: Sabbaṭṭhānānipīti sabbāni paṭikiriyānhānabhojanakīḷāsañcaraṇādiṭṭhānānipi, na nivāsaṭṭhānāniyeva. Tenāha “dovārikāpī”tiādi. Tattha kāraṇamāha “rājā kirā”tiādi.
analyzed: sabba ṭṭhānāni pi iti sabbāni na nivāsa ṭṭhānāni iva tena āha dovārikā api itiādi tattha kāraṇam āha rājā kirāti ādi
translated: ‘All places’ means all places for the performance of duties, for bathing, for meals, for play, for walking, and so on. They are not only places of residence. Hence he said ‘even the watchmen’s posts’ and so on. Herein, the reason is given with ‘The king, it seems’ and so on.

original: Paṭhamabhāṇavāravaṇṇanā niṭṭhitā.
analyzed: paṭhama bhāṇa vāra vaṇṇanā niṭṭhitā
translated: The commentary on the first recitation section is ended.

original: Jiṇṇapurisavaṇṇanā
analyzed: jiṇṇa purisa vaṇṇanā
translated: The description of the old man

original: 44. Gopānasivaṅkanti vaṅkagopānasī viya. Vaṅkānañhi vaṅkabhāvassa nidassanatthaṃ🔽avaṅkagopānasīpi gayhati. Ābhoggavaṅkanti ādito paṭṭhāya abbhuggatāya kuṭilasarīratāya
analyzed: gopānasi vaṅkanti vaṅka gopānasī viya vaṅkānam hi vaṅka bhāvassa nidassana attham  a vaṅka gopānasīpi gayhati ābhogga vaṅkanti āditaḥ paṭṭhāya abbhugga tāya kuṭila sarīra tāya
translated: ‘Crooked as a cow’s knee’ means like a cow’s knee-bone. For the purpose of showing the crookedness of the crooked,🔽he mentions the straight cow’s knee-bone. ‘Crooked as a hook’ means crooked by being bent from the beginning,

original: vaṅkaṃ. Tenāha “khandhe”tiādi. Daṇḍaparaṃ daṇḍaggahaṇaparaṃ ayanaṃ gamanaṃ etassāti
analyzed: vaṅkam tena āha khandha itiādi daṇḍa param daṇḍa ggahaṇa param ayanam gamanam etassa iti
translated: crooked by having a crooked body. Hence he said ‘limbs’ and so on. ‘Going to the end of the stick’ means going to the end of the stick’s grasp.

original: daṇḍaparāyanaṃ, daṇḍo vā paraṃ āyanaṃ gamanakāraṇaṃ etassāti daṇḍaparāyanaṃ. Ṭhānādīsu
analyzed: daṇḍa parāyanam daṇḍaḥ vā param āyanam gamana kāraṇam etassa ati daṇḍa parāyanam ṭhāna ādīsu
translated: The last refuge is that which has the staff as its last refuge, or the staff is the last refuge, the going, the cause of going, of it.

original: daṇḍo gati avassayo etassa tena vinā appavattanatoti daṇḍagatikaṃ, gacchati etenāti
analyzed: daṇḍaḥ gati avassayaḥ etassa tena vinā a pavattanato ti daṇḍagatikam gacchati etena ati
translated: The staff is the going, the support, of it, because it does not go without it.

original: vā gati, daṇḍo gati gamanakāraṇaṃ etassāti daṇḍagatikaṃ. Daṇḍapaṭisaraṇanti etthāpi🔽eseva nayo. Jarāturanti jarāya kilantaṃ assavasaṃ. Yadā ratho purato hotīti dvedhāpathe
analyzed: vā gati daṇḍaḥ gati gamana kāraṇam etassa ati daṇḍa gatikam daṇḍa paṭisaraṇam ti ettha api  esā iva nayaḥ jarāya kilantam assavasam yadā rathaḥ puratas hoti iti dvedhāpathe
translated: Or the staff is the going, the cause of going, of it.🔽The same method of explanation applies in the case of the last refuge as a staff.🔽The worn-out horse is one worn out by old age, exhausted.

original: sampatte purato gacchante balakāye tattha ekaṃ saṇṭhānaṃ āruḷho majjhe gacchanto
analyzed: sampatte puratas gacchante balakāye tattha ekam saṇṭhānam āruḍhaḥ majjhe gacchantaḥ
translated: When the chariot was in front: when the army was going in front on the two-fold path,🔽one who was riding in the middle of the formation,

original: bodhisattena āruḷho ratho itaraṃ saṇṭhānaṃ gacchanto yadā purato hoti. Pacchā balakāyoti
analyzed: bodhisattena āruḷhaḥ rathaḥ itaram saṇṭhānam gacchantaḥ yadā puratas hoti pacchā
translated: the chariot on which the Bodhisatta was riding, was going in front of the other formation.🔽The army was behind: at that time the whole army was behind.

original: tadā pacchā hoti sabbo balakāyo. Tādise okāseti tādise vuttappakāre maggappadese.
analyzed: tadā pacchā hoti sabbaḥ balakāyo tādise okāse ti tādise vutta ppakāre magga ppadese
translated: In such a place: in such a place of that kind, in such a region of the path.🔽That man: that old man.

original: Taṃ purisanti taṃ jiṇṇapurisaṃ. Suddhāvāsāti siddhatthādīnaṃ tiṇṇaṃ sammāsambuddhānaṃ
analyzed: tam purisanti tam jiṇṇa purisam suddha āvāsā ati siddhattha ādīnam tiṇṇam sammāsambuddhānam
translated: The Pure Abodes: the three Perfectly Awakened Ones, Siddhattha, etc.

original: sāsane brahmacariyaṃ caritvā suddhāvāsabhūmiyaṃ nibbattabrahmāno. Te hi tadā tattha🔽tiṭṭhanti. “Kiṃ paneso jiṇṇo nāmā”ti eso tayā vuccamāno kiṃ atthato, taṃ me niddhāretvā
analyzed: sāsane brahmacariyam caritvā suddhāvāsa bhūmiyam nibbatta brahmānaḥ te hi tadā tattha  tiṭṭhanti kim pana eso jiṇṇaḥ nāma ati esaḥ tayā vuccamāno kim atthataḥ tam me niddhāretvā
translated: and the Brahmas who have been reborn in the Suddhāvāsa planes after living the holy life under the dispensation of the Buddha Kassapa. For they were standing there at that time.

original: kathehīti dasseti. Aniddhāritasarūpattā hi tassa attano bodhisatto liṅgasabbanāmena🔽taṃ vadanto “ki”nti āha. “Yathā kiṃ te jāta”nti dvayameva hi loke yebhuyyato jāyati
analyzed: kathehi iti dassa iti a niddhārita sarūpa ttā hi tassa attanaḥ bodhisattaḥ liṅga sabba nāmena  tam āha yathā kim te dvayam eva hi loke yebhuyyataḥ jāyati
translated: “But what is this ‘old age’ that you speak of?” He shows that he wants the Bodhisatta to explain to him the meaning of the word. For the Bodhisatta, not understanding the word,

original: itthī vā puriso vā, tathāpi taṃ liṅgasabbanāmena vuccati, evaṃ sampadamidaṃ veditabbaṃ.
analyzed: itthī vā purisaḥ vā tathā api tam liṅga sabba nāmena vuccati evam sampadam idam veditabbam
translated: said “ki” . “What is it like?” he said, “How did it come about?” For in the world, generally, it is said that “one is born either as a woman or as a man.” But the word should be understood in the same way as the word “ki.”

original: “Kiṃ vuttaṃ hotī”tiādi tassa aniddhāritasarūpataṃyeva vibhāveti.
analyzed: kim vuttam hoti itiādi tassa a niddhārita sarūpa taṃyā iva vibhāveti
translated: “What is meant?” etc. He explains the same fact, that the Bodhisatta did not understand the word.

original: “Tena hī”tiādi “ayañca jiṇṇabhāvo sabbasādhāraṇattā mayhampi upari āpattito evā”ti
analyzed: tena hi itiādi ayam ca jiṇṇa bhāvo sabba sādhāraṇa ttā mayham pi upari āpattitaḥ eva ati
translated: “Then,” etc. He shows that the Bodhisatta understood that “this old age is common to all, and it will come upon me too.”

original: mahāsattassa saṃvijjanākāravibhāvanaṃ. Rathaṃ sāretīti sārathi. Kīḷāvihāratthaṃ uyyuttā
analyzed: mahāsattassa saṃvid jana ākāra vibhāvanam ratham sāreti iti sārathi kīḷā vihāra attham uyyuttā
translated: “He drove the chariot” : a charioteer is one who drives a chariot. He was eager to go out for the purpose of sport.

original: yanti upagacchanti etanti uyyānaṃ. Alanti paṭikkhepavacanaṃ. Nāmāti garahaṇe nipāto
analyzed: yanti upagacchanti etanti uyyānam alanti paṭikkhepa vacanam nāma ati garahaṇe nipātaḥ
translated: The word “garden” is derived from the verb uyyāyati, which means “to go to” or “to approach.” The prefix upa is a particle of prohibition.🔽The word “name” is a particle of interrogation, like the words “how” and “what.”

original: “kathañhināmā”tiādīsu viya. Jātiyā ādīnavadassanatthaṃ taṃmūlassa ummūlanaṃ viya
analyzed: katham hi nāma ati ādīsu viya jātiyāḥ ādīnava dassana attham tad mūlassa ummūlanam viya
translated: The purpose of the simile is to show the danger in birth. The man sits down to dig up the root of the tree,🔽just as one would dig up the root of a tree in order to destroy it.

original: hotīti, tassa ca avassitabhāvato “jātiyā mūlaṃ khaṇanto nisīdī”ti āha. Siddhe hi
analyzed: hoti iti tassa ca avassita bhāvataḥ jātiyāḥ mūlam khaṇantaḥ nisīdi iti āha siddhe hi
translated: And since the root of birth is the craving for existence, the Buddha says: “Dig up the root of birth.”

original: kāraṇe phalaṃ siddhameva hotīti. Pīḷaṃ janetvā antotudanavasena sabbapaṭhamaṃ hadayaṃ
analyzed: kāraṇe phalam siddham eva hoti iti pīḷam janetvā antotudana vasena sabba paṭhamam hadayam
translated: For when the cause is accomplished, the effect is accomplished too.

original: anupavissa ṭhitattā paṭhamena sallena hadaye viddho viya nisīdīti yojanā.
analyzed: anupavissa ṭhita ttā paṭhamena sallena hadaye viddhaḥ viya nisīdi iti yojanā
translated: Having generated the pain, the man sits down as if he were pierced by the first arrow, because he is sitting right next to the heart, having entered it with the inner breath.

original: Byādhipurisavaṇṇanā
analyzed: byādhipurisa vaṇṇanā
translated: The description of the sick man

original: 47. Pubbe vuttanayenevāti “suddhāvāsā kirā”tiādinā pubbe vutteneva nayena. Ābādhikanti ābādhavantaṃ. Dukkhitanti sañjātadukkhaṃ. Ajātanti ajātabhāvo, nibbānaṃ vā.
analyzed: pubbe vutta nayena iva āti suddhāvāsā kirāti ādinā pubbe vuttena iva nayena ābādhikam ti ābādhavantam dukkhitam ti sañjāta dukkham ajātam ti ajāta bhāvaḥ nibbānam vā

With what as condition is there aging-and-death? ” he saw that aging-and-death occurs when there is birth, that it does not occur when there is not, and that therefore birth is its cause.

original: jātipaccayā jarāmaraṇa”nti yā jarāmaraṇassa kāraṇapariggāhikā paññā uppajjati, tāya🔽uppajjantiyā samāgamo ahosīti. Sabbapadānīti “kimhi nu kho sati jāti hotī”tiādinā
analyzed: jāti paccayā jarā maraṇanti yā jarā maraṇassa kāraṇa pariggāhikā paññā uppajjati tāya  uppajjantiyā samāgamaḥ ahosi iti sabba padāni iti kimhi nu kho sati jāti hoti itiādinā
translated: When he had thus discerned the invariable mark of the cause, the knowledge that arose in him discerning the cause of aging-and-death was as follows: “With birth as condition there is aging-and-death; aging-and-death has birth as its condition.”🔽The meeting with this knowledge was the meeting with the third knowledge.

original: āgatāni jātiādīni viññāṇapariyosānāni nava padāni.
analyzed: āgatāni jāti ādīni viññāṇa pariyosānāni nava padāni
translated: “All the terms”: the nine terms beginning with birth and ending with consciousness, which are stated in the passage beginning, “When what exists does birth come to be? ”

original: Dvādasapadike paṭiccasamuppāde idha yāni dve padāni aggahitāni, tesaṃ aggahaṇe kāraṇaṃ
analyzed: dvādasa padike paṭiccasamuppāde idha yāni dve padāni aggahitāni tesam aggahaṇe kāraṇam
translated: In the twelve-factored dependent origination, the reason for not taking up the two terms is this:

original: pucchitvā vissajjetukāmo tesaṃ gahetabbākāraṃ tāva dassento “ettha panā”tiādimāha.
analyzed: pucchitvā vissajjetu kāmo tesam gahetabba ākāram tāva dassentaḥ ettha pana ati ādim āha
translated: Now, in order to show the way in which they are to be taken, he says, “Herein, however, ” etc.

original: Paccakkhabhūtaṃ paccuppannabhavaṃ paṭhamaṃ gahetvā tadanantaraṃ anāgataṃ “dutiya”nti
analyzed: paccakkha bhūtam paccuppanna bhavam paṭhamam gahetvā tad anantaram anāgatam
translated: Having first taken the present becoming, which is the opposite of the past and future, he then takes the future, calling it the second.

original: gahaṇe atīto tatiyo hotīti āha “avijjā saṅkhārā hi atīto bhavo”ti. Nanu cettha anāgatassāpi
analyzed: gahaṇe atītaḥ tatiyaḥ hoti iti āha avijjā saṅkhārā hi atītaḥ nanu ca ittha anāgatassa api
translated: In the taking of the future, the past becomes the third, thus he says, “Ignorance and formations are the past becoming” .🔽But is it not impossible to take the future here, since the insistence on the present is demonstrated?

original: bhavassa gahaṇaṃ na sambhavati paccuppannavasena abhinivesassa jotitattāti? Saccametaṃ,
analyzed: bhavassa gahaṇam na sambhavati paccuppanna vasena abhinivesassa jotita ttā ati saccam etam
translated: That is true, but

original: kāraṇe pana gahite phalaṃ gahitameva hotīti tathā vuttanti daṭṭhabbaṃ. Api cettha
analyzed: kāraṇe pana gahite phalam gahitam eva hoti iti tathā vuttan ti daṭṭhabbam api ca ittha
translated: it should be regarded as said in this way because when the cause is taken the fruit is taken too.

original: anāgatopi addhā atthato saṅgahito eva, yato parato “nāmarūpapaccayā saḷāyatana”ntiādinā
analyzed: anāgataḥ api addhā atthataḥ saṅgahitaḥ eva yatas paratas nāma rūpa paccayā
translated: And here the future is included in the sense too, since the teaching that follows beginning with “With mentality-materiality as condition, the sixfold base”🔽is a teaching that includes the future.

original: anāgataddhasaṅgahikā desanā pavattā. Tehīti avijjāsaṅkhārehi ārammaṇabhūtehi. Na
analyzed: anāgata ddha saṅgahikā desanā pavattā tehi iti avijjā saṅkhārehi ārammaṇa bhūtehi na
translated: By those, i.e. by the ignorance and formations that are the objects.

original: ghaṭiyati na sambajjhati. Mahāpuriso hi paccuppannavasena abhiniviṭṭhoti aghaṭane
analyzed: na sambajjhati mahāpurisaḥ hi paccuppanna vasena abhiniviṭṭhaḥ ti a ghaṭane
translated: It does not come together, it does not meet. For the great man is insistent on the present.

original: kāraṇamāha. Adiṭṭhehīti anavabuddhehi, itthambhūtalakkhaṇe cetaṃ karaṇavacanaṃ. Sati
analyzed: kāraṇam āha adiṭṭhehi iti anavabuddhehi ittham bhūta lakkhaṇe ca itam karaṇa vacanam sati
translated: He gives the reason: “By those who have not seen” means by those who have not understood. This is a gerundive expression in the sense of “having the nature of that.”

original: anubodhe paṭivedhena bhavitabbanti āha “na sakkā buddhena bhavitu”nti. Imināti mahāsattena.
analyzed: anubodhe paṭivedhena bhavitabbanti āha na sakkā buddhena bhavitunti iminā ati mahāsattena
translated: When there is understanding, there must be penetration. Therefore he says, “It is not possible for the Buddha to exist.” “By this” means by the Great Being.

original: Teti avijjāsaṅkhārā. Bhavaupādānataṇhāvasenevāti bhavaupādānataṇhādassanavaseneva.
analyzed: te iti avijjā saṅkhārāḥ bhava aupādāna taṇhā vasena iva ati bhava aupādāna taṇhā dassana vasena iva
translated: “Those” means ignorance and formations. “By the method of craving for becoming and attachment to becoming” means by the method of seeing craving for becoming and attachment to becoming.

original: Diṭṭhā taṃsabhāvataṃsahagatehi tehi samānayogakkhamattā. Visuddhimagge kathitāva,
analyzed: diṭṭhā taṃsa bhāva taṃsa hagatehi tehi samāna yogakkhama ttā visuddhi magge kathitā ava
translated: Because they are brought together by the mere fact of having the same association with that nature which has been seen. It has been explained in the Visuddhimagga,

original: tasmā na idha kathetabbāti adhippāyo.🔽58. Paccayatoti hetuto, saṅkhāratoti attho. “Kimhi nu kho sati jarāmaraṇaṃ hotī”tiādinā🔽hi hetuparamparāvasena phalaparamparāya vuccamānāya “kimhi nu kho sati viññāṇaṃ hotī”ti
analyzed: tasmā na idha kathetabbā ati adhippāyaḥ  paccayato ti hetutaḥ saṅkhārato ti attho kimhi nu kho sati jarā maraṇam hoti itiādinā  hi hetu paramparā vasena phala paramparāya vuccamānāya kimhi nu kho sati viññāṇam hoti iti
translated: therefore it is not necessary to explain it here. This is the intention.🔽“By way of condition” means by way of cause; the meaning is “by way of formations.” For in the passage beginning, “With what as condition does aging-death occur?”🔽the succession of fruits is stated by way of the succession of causes. And when the succession of fruits is stated in this way, the investigation “With what as condition does consciousness occur?”

original: vicāraṇāya “saṅkhāre kho sati viññāṇaṃ hotī”ti viññāṇassa visesakāraṇabhūte saṅkhāre
analyzed: vicāraṇāya saṅkhāre kho sati viññāṇam hoti iti viññāṇassa visesa kāraṇa bhūte saṅkhāre
translated: leads to the conclusion that formations, which are the specific cause of consciousness,

original: aggahite tato viññāṇaṃ paṭinivattati nāma, na sabbapaccayato. Tenevāha “nāmarūpe
analyzed: aggahite tatas viññāṇam paṭinivattati nāma na sabba paccayato tena iva āha nāma rūpe
translated: and consciousness turns back from the objective field, not from all conditions. Hence it is said: “With mentality-materiality present, consciousness comes to be” .

original: kho sati viññāṇaṃ hotī”ti, nāmampi cettha sahajātādivaseneva paccayabhūtaṃ adhippetaṃ,
analyzed: kho sati viññāṇam hoti iti nāmam pi ca ittha sahajāta ādi vasena iva paccaya bhūtam adhippetam
translated: And here “mentality” is intended as a condition in the way stated thus: “With the arising of ignorance there is the arising of mentality” ,

original: na kammūpanissayavasena paccuppannavasena abhinivisassa jotitattā. Ārammaṇatoti avijjāsaṅkhārasaṅkhātaārammaṇato,
analyzed: na kamma upanissaya vasena paccuppanna vasena abhinivisassa jotita ttā ārammaṇato ti avijjā saṅkhāra saṅkhāta ārammaṇato
translated: and not as a condition in the way stated thus: “With the arising of ignorance there is the arising of formations” , because the latter is intended to show the proximate condition.🔽From the objective field: from the objective field called ignorance and formations,

original: atītabhavasaṅkhātaārammaṇato vā. Atītaddhapariyāpannā hi avijjāsaṅkhārā. Yato paṭinivattamānaṃ
analyzed: atīta bhava saṅkhāta ārammaṇataḥ vā atīta ddha pariyāpannāḥ hi avijjā saṅkhārāḥ yatas paṭinivattamānam
translated: or from the objective field called past becoming. For ignorance and formations are included in the past.🔽And so it is said that consciousness turns back from the past becoming as well.

original: viññāṇaṃ atītabhavatopi paṭinivattati nāma. Ubhayampīti paṭisandhiviññāṇampi vipassanāviññāṇampi.🔽Nāmarūpaṃ nātikkamatīti paccayabhūtaṃ, ārammaṇabhūtañca nāmarūpaṃ nātikkamati tena
analyzed: viññāṇam atīta bhavataḥ api paṭinivattati nāma ubhayam pi iti paṭisandhi viññāṇam pi vipassanā viññāṇam pi  nāma rūpam na atikkamati iti paccaya bhūtam ārammaṇa bhūtam ca nāma rūpam na atikkamati tena
translated: Both: rebirth-linking consciousness and insight consciousness.

original: vinā avattanato. Tenāha “nāmarūpato paraṃ na gacchatī”ti.
analyzed: vinā tena āha nāma rūpataḥ param na gacchati iti
translated: It does not overstep mentality-materiality: it does not overstep the mentality-materiality that is a condition and the mentality-materiality that is an object, because it does not occur without them. Hence it is said: “It does not go beyond mentality-materiality” .

original: Viññāṇe nāmarūpassa paccaye honteti viññāṇe nāmassa, rūpassa, nāmarūpassa ca paccaye
analyzed: viññāṇe nāma rūpassa paccaye hontā iti viññāṇe nāmassa rūpassa nāma rūpassa ca paccaye
translated: When the condition for mentality-materiality is present in consciousness, the condition for mentality is present in consciousness, the condition for materiality is present in consciousness, the condition for mentality-materiality is present in consciousness.

original: honte. Nāmarūpe ca viññāṇassa paccaye honteti tathā nāme, rūpe, nāmarūpe ca viññāṇassa
analyzed: honte nāma rūpe ca viññāṇassa paccaye honte iti tathā nāme rūpe nāma rūpe ca viññāṇassa
translated: When the condition for consciousness is present in mentality-materiality, the condition for consciousness is present in mentality, the condition for consciousness is present in materiality, the condition for consciousness is present in mentality-materiality.

original: paccaye honteti catuvokāraekavokārapañcavokārabhavavasena yathārahaṃ yojanā veditabbā,
analyzed: paccaye hontā iti catuvokāra ekavokāra pañcavokāra bhava vasena yathāraham yojanā veditabbā
translated: The application should be understood according to the fourfold, twofold, and fivefold kinds of becoming respectively.🔽But when the condition is present in each of the two, it is only according to the fivefold kind of becoming.

original: dvīsupi aññamaññapaccayesu hontesūti pana pañcavokārabhavavaseneva. Ettakenāti evaṃ🔽viññāṇa nāmarūpānaṃ aññamaññaṃ upatthambhanavasena pavattiyā. Jāyetha vā…pe… upapajjetha
analyzed: dvīsu pi aññamañña paccayesu hontesu iti pana pañcavokāra bhava vasena iva ettakena ati evam  viññāṇa nāma rūpānam aññamaññam upatthambhana vasena pavattiyāḥ jāyetha vāpe upapajjetha
translated: To this extent: to this extent, that is,🔽with the occurrence of consciousness and mentality-materiality as mutual support.

original: vāti “satto jāyati…pe… upapajjati vā”ti samaññā hoti viññāṇanāmarūpavinimuttassa
analyzed: vā ati sattaḥ jāyati pe upapajjati vā ati samaññā hoti viññāṇa nāma rūpa vinimuttassa
translated: Would be born … would reappear: the convention “a being is born … reappears” is due to the non-existence of any other state of being that might be apprehended as a being apart from consciousness and mentality-materiality.

original: sattapaññattiyā upādānabhūtassa dhammassa abhāvato. Tenāha “ito hī”tiādi. Etadevāti
analyzed: satta paññattiyāḥ upādāna bhūtassa dhammassa abhāvato tena āha itas hi itiādi etat eva ati
translated: Therefore he said, “For from here” , etc.

original: viññāṇaṃ, nāmarūpanti etaṃ dvayameva.
analyzed: viññāṇam etam dvayam eva
translated: This very: this very pair, namely, consciousness and mentality-materiality.

original: Pañca padānīti “jāyetha vā”tiādīni pañca padāni. Nanu tattha paṭhamatatiyehi catutthapañcamāni🔽atthato abhinnānīti āha “saddhiṃ aparāparaṃ cutipaṭisandhīhī”ti. Puna taṃ ettāvatāti🔽vuttamatthanti yo “ettāvatā”ti padena pubbe vutto, tameva yathāvuttamatthaṃ “yadida”ntiādinā🔽niyyātento nidassento puna vatvā. Anulomapaccayākāravasenāti paccayadhammadassanapubbakaṃ
analyzed: pañca padāni iti jāyetha vāti ādīni pañca padāni nanu tattha paṭhama tatiyehi catuttha pañcamāni  atthataḥ abhinnāni iti āha saddhim apara aparam cuti paṭisandhīhi iti puna tam ettāvatā ati  vutta mattham ti yaḥ ettāvatā ati padena pubbe vuttaḥ tam eva yathā vuttam attham yat idam iti ādinā  niyyātentaḥ nidassentaḥ puna vatvā anuloma paccaya ākāra vasena ati paccaya dhamma dassana pubbakam
translated: The five terms are the five terms beginning with “be born”. But are not the fourth and fifth terms the same in meaning as the first and third? —“Together with the death and rebirth-linking that are successive to that” . Again, the meaning stated thus: “As far as this goes” , etc., is the meaning stated previously by the words “as far as this goes” . Having stated that meaning again, he “expounded” it, “showed” it, by the words “that is to say” , etc., “in forward order” . “By the mode of condition” : by the mode of condition that is preceded by the seeing of the states that are conditions.

original: paccayuppannadhammadassanavasena. Paccayadhammānañhi attano paccayuppannassa paccayabhāvo🔽idappaccayatā paccayākāro, so ca “avijjāpaccayā saṅkhārā”tiādinā vutto. Saṃsārappavattiyā🔽anulomanato anulomapaccayākāro. Jātiādikaṃ sabbaṃ vaṭṭadukkhaṃ cittena samihitena
analyzed: paccaya uppanna dhamma dassana vasena paccaya dhammānam hi attanaḥ paccaya uppannassa paccaya bhāvaḥ 🔽idappaccaya tā paccaya ākāraḥ saḥ ca avijjā paccayā saṅkhārā ti ādinā vutto saṃsāra ppavattiyā 🔽anulomanataḥ anuloma paccaya ākāraḥ jāti ādikam sabbam vaṭṭa dukkham cittena samihitena
translated: The five terms are the five terms beginning with “be born”. But are not the fourth and fifth terms the same in meaning as the first and third? “Together with the successive kinds of death and rebirth-linking” . Again, the meaning he stated thus: “To this extent” , he stated again, showing, pointing out, that same meaning stated thus with the words “To this extent” by the words beginning with “That is to say” . By the method of conditions as a forward process: by the method of conditions as a forward process consisting in the seeing of the states that are conditions followed by the seeing of the states that are conditionally arisen. For the states that are conditions have the state that is conditionally arisen as their own state’s condition, and that is the manner of conditionality. And that is stated in the way beginning, “With ignorance as condition there are formations” . It is a forward process because it forwards, promotes, the occurrence of the round of rebirths. All the suffering of the round of rebirths beginning with birth is brought together, collected, by consciousness.

original: kataṃ samūhavasena gahetvā pāḷiyaṃ “dukkhakkhandhassā”ti vuttanti āha “jāti…pe… dukkharāsissā”ti.
analyzed: katam samūha vasena gahetvā pāḷiyam dukkha kkhandhassa ati vuttanti āha jātipe dukkha rāsissa ati
translated: He said: “Birth, aging, death, sorrow, lamentation, pain, grief, and despair are the mass of suffering.”

analyzed: dukkha kkhandhassa aneka vāram samudaya dassana vasena viññāṇassa pavatta ttā samudayo  avoca atha vai evam samudayaḥ iti idam na kevalam  nibbatti nidassana padam atha kho paṭiccasamuppāda saddaḥ viya samuppāda mukhena idha
translated: Since consciousness occurs many times in the sense of the seeing of the origin of the mass of suffering, he said: “Origin, origin,”

original: samudaya-saddo nibbattimukhena paccayattaṃ vadati. Viññāṇādayo bhavantā idha paccayadhammā
analyzed: samudaya saddaḥ nibbatti mukhena paccaya ttam vadati viññāṇa ādayaḥ bhavantā idha paccaya dhammā

translated: are indicated by the word “origin.” Taking them by way of the desire to explain them in the manner of the first truth, he said: “Origin, origin.”🔽And thus, the statement: “The mere knowledge of conditionality, ‘When this exists, that comes to be,’ is stated,”

original: taṃ samatthitaṃ hoti. Yadi evaṃ “udayadassanapaññā vesā”ti idaṃ kathanti? Nāyaṃ doso
analyzed: tat samatthitam hoti yadi evam udaya dassana paññā idam kathanti na ayam doso
