translated: As emerging: as emerging by way of the emergence of the

original: samudayasabhāvapaṭicchādanakassa mohandhakārassa ca kilesandhakārassa ca vidhamanavasena avabhāsakabhāvena.🔽Idāni yathāvuttamatthaṃ paṭipāṭiyā vibhāvetuṃ “yathāhā”tiādi vuttaṃ. Tattha cakkhuṃ🔽udapādīti pāḷiyaṃ paduddhāro. Kathaṃ udapādīti ceti āha “dassanaṭṭhenā”ti. “Samudayassa
analyzed: samudaya sabhāva paṭicchādanakassa moha ndhakārassa ca kilesa ndhakārassa ca vidhamana vasena avabhāsaka bhāvena  idāni yathāvuttam attham paṭipāṭiyā vibhāvetum yathā āha atiādi vuttam tattha cakkhuṃ  udapādi iti pāḷiyam paduddhāro katham udapādi iti ca iti āha dassana ṭṭhena ati samudayassa
translated: And it is illuminating in the sense of illuminating the darkness of ignorance and the darkness of defilement by the removal of the concealment of the individual essences of the origin, etc.,

original: paccakkhato dassanabhāvenāti vutto vāyamattho. Iminā nayena sesapadesupi attho veditabbo.🔽Cakkhudhammoti cakkhūti pāḷidhammo. Dassanaṭṭho atthoti dassanasabhāvo tena pakāsetabbo🔽attho. Sesesupi eseva nayo. Ettakehi padehīti imehi pañcahi padehi. “Kiṃ kathita”nti
analyzed: paccakkhataḥ dassana bhāvena ati vuttaḥ vā ayam atthaḥ iminā nayena sesa padesu pi atthaḥ veditabbaḥ  cakkhu dhammo ti cakkhu uti pāḷi dhammaḥ dassana ṭṭhaḥ attho ti dassana sabhāvaḥ tena pakāsetabbaḥ  attho sesesu pi esa iva nayaḥ ettakehi padehi iti imehi pañcahi padehi kim kathitan ti
translated: Now, in order to illustrate the meaning stated in the way already given by means of a regular sequence, the text goes on: “As it is said” , etc. Herein, the words “The eye arose” are a verbal derivation. If it is asked, “How did it arise? ” he says, “In the sense of seeing” . The meaning is that it arose by means of the seeing of the origin as it actually is. The same method applies in the case of the other terms.

original: piṇḍatthaṃ pucchati. Paccayasañjānanamattanti viññāṇādīnaṃ paccayadhammānaṃ nāmarūpādipaccayuppannassa
analyzed: piṇḍa attham pucchati viññāṇa ādīnam paccaya dhammānam nāma rūpa ādi paccaya uppannassa
translated: The eye is a term in the text. The meaning is the meaning of seeing. The meaning that should be elucidated by that is the individual essence of seeing. The same method applies in the case of the rest. By these five terms: by these five terms beginning with “the eye arose.” What is stated? He asks for the overall meaning. The mere discerning of conditions: the mere discerning of the states that are conditions for consciousness, etc., and of the states that are produced by the conditions beginning with mentality-materiality.

original: paccayasabhāvasañjānanamattaṃ kathitaṃ avisesato paccayasabhāvasallakkhaṇassa jotitattā.
analyzed: paccaya sabhāva sañjānana mattam kathitam avisesato paccaya sabhāva sat lakkhaṇassa jotita ttā
translated: and it is said that the mere discerning of the state of condition is stated without distinction because the discerning of the state of condition is revealed.

original: Saṅkhārānaṃ sammadeva udayadassanassa jotitattā “vīthipaṭipannā taruṇavipassanā kathitā”ti ca vuttaṃ.🔽61. Attanā adhigatattā āsannapaccakkhatāya “aya”nti vuttaṃ, ariyamaggādīnaṃ magganaṭṭhena
analyzed: saṅkhārānam sammat eva udaya dassanassa jotita ttā vīthi paṭipannā taruṇa vipassanā kathitā iti ca vuttam  attanā adhigata ttā āsanna paccakkha tāya ayan ti vuttam ariya magga ādīnam maggana ṭṭhena
translated: And it is said that the insight that has entered the stream is stated because the rise of formations is seen correctly.🔽It is said “this” because it is attained by oneself and because it is a proximate perception. The noble path, etc., are called “the path” in the sense of path.

original: maggoti. Pubbabhāgavipassanā hesā. Tenāha “bodhāyā”ti. Bodhapadassa bhāvasādhanataṃ
analyzed: maggaḥ ti pubba bhāga vipassanā ha isā tena āha bodhāya iti bodha padassa bhāva sādhana tam
translated: This is insight in the preliminary stage. Therefore it is said “for the purpose of enlightenment.”

original: sandhāyāha “catusaccabujjhanatthāyā”ti. Pariññāpahānabhāvanābhisamayā yāvadeva sacchikiriyābhisamayatthā🔽nibbānādhigamatthattā brahmacariyavāsassāti vuttaṃ “nibbānabujjhanatthāya eva vā”ti.
analyzed: sandhāya āha catu sacca bujjhana tthāya iti pariññā apahāna bhāvanā abhisamayāḥ yāvat eva sacchikiriyā abhisamaya tthā  nibbāna adhigama ttha ttā brahmacariya vāsassa iti vuttam nibbāna bujjhana tthāya eva vā ti
translated: With reference to the state of being a means to the state of enlightenment, it is said “for the purpose of the discovery of the four truths.”🔽The discovery of the four truths is for the purpose of the discovery of Nibbāna, which is the supreme bliss.

original: “Nibbānaṃ paramaṃ sukha”nti hi vuttaṃ. Bujjhatīti cattāri ariyasaccāni ekapaṭivedhena
analyzed: nibbānam paramam sukhanti hi vuttam bujjhati iti cattāri ariya saccāni eka paṭivedhena
translated: “Nibbāna is the supreme bliss” is said. “It discovers” means that the four noble truths are discovered by a single penetration.

original: paṭivijjhati, tena bodha-saddassa kattusādhanattamāha. Paccattapadehīti paṭhamāvibhattidīpakehi
analyzed: paṭivijjhati tena bodha saddassa kattu sādhana ttam āha paccatta padehi iti paṭhamā vibhatti dīpakehi
translated: He penetrates, thus he says that the word bodha is a verbal noun.🔽With the words beginning with “in oneself” he says that it is taught with the words beginning with the first case

original: padehi. Nibbānameva kathitaṃ viññāṇādi nirujjhati etthāti katvā. Anibbattinirodhanti
analyzed: padehi nibbānam eva kathitam viññāṇa ādi nirujjhati ettha iti katvā anibbatti nirodhanti
translated: ending, “eye”, etc. Nibbana is called “in oneself” because consciousness, etc., cease there.

original: sabbaso paccayanirodhena anuppādanirodhaṃ accantanirodhaṃ.
analyzed: sabbaso paccaya nirodhena anuppāda nirodham accanta nirodham
translated: The cessation of non-rebirth is the cessation of non-arising through the cessation of conditions, the ultimate cessation.

original: 62. Sabbeheva etehi padehīti “cakkhū”tiādīhi pañcahi padehi. Nirodhasañjānanamattamevāti
analyzed: sabbehi eva etehi padehi iti cakkhu uti ādīhi pañcahi padehi nirodha sañjānana mattam eva ati
translated: With all these words beginning with “eye” he says that it is taught with the five words beginning with “eye”, etc.🔽The mere recognition of cessation is taught

original: “nirodho nirodhoti kho”tiādinā nirodhassa sañjānanamattameva kathitaṃ pubbārambhabhāvato,
analyzed: nirodhaḥ nirodho ti kho ti ādinā nirodhassa sañjānana mattam eva kathitam pubba ārambha bhāvato
translated: with the words beginning with “Cessation, cessation”, etc., because it is the first step,

original: na tassa paṭivijjhanavasena paccakkhato dassanaṃ ariyamaggassa anadhigatattā. Saṅkhārānaṃ🔽sammadeva nirodhadassanaṃ nāma sikhāppattāya vipassanāya vasena icchitabbanti “vuṭṭhānagāminī
analyzed: na tassa paṭivijjhana vasena paccakkhataḥ dassanam ariya maggassa anadhigata ttā saṅkhārānaṃ  sammat eva nirodhadassanam nāma sikhāppattāya vipassanāya vasena icchitabbanti vuṭṭhāna gāminī
translated: but not the seeing of it by penetrating it and thus making it evident to oneself, because the noble path has not yet been reached.🔽The seeing of the cessation of formations🔽should be understood as the insight that has reached its culmination.🔽Thus it is said that the powerful insight that leads to the emergence

original: balavavipassanā kathitā”ti ca vuttaṃ.
analyzed: balava vipassanā kathitā iti ca vuttam
translated: of the path is taught.

original: 63. Viditvāti pubbabhāgiyena ñāṇena jānitvā. Tato aparabhāgeti vuttanayena paccayanirodhajānanato🔽pacchābhāge. Upādānassa paccayabhūtesūti catubbidhassapi upādānassa ārammaṇapaccayādinā
analyzed: viditvā ti pubbabhāgiyena ñāṇena jānitvā tatas aparabhāge iti vutta nayena paccaya nirodha jānanato  pacchābhāge upādānassa paccaya bhūtesu iti catubbidhassa api upādānassa ārammaṇa paccaya ādinā
translated: “Having known”: having known by means of the knowledge of the prior stage. “Afterwards”: in the subsequent stage, after the knowledge of the cessation of conditions has arisen in the way stated.

original: paccayabhūtesu, upādāniyesūti attho. Vahantoti pavattento. Idanti “aparena samayenā”tiādi🔽vacanaṃ. Kasmā vuttanti “yāya paṭipattiyā sabbepi mahābodhisattā carimabhave bodhāya🔽paṭipajjanti, vipassanāya mahābodhisattena tatheva paṭipanna”nti kathetukamyatāvasena🔽pucchāvacanaṃ. Tenāha “sabbeyeva hī”tiādi. Tattha puttassa jātadivase mahābhinikkhamanaṃ,
analyzed: paccaya bhūtesu upādāniyesu uti atthaḥ vahantaḥ iti pavattentaḥ idam ti aparena samayena atiādi  vacanam kasmā vuttan ti yāya paṭipattiyā sabbe api mahā bodhisattā carima bhave bodhāya  paṭipajjanti vipassanāya mahā bodhisattena tathā iva paṭipannanti kathetu kamya tā vasena  pucchā vacanam tena āha hi itiādi tattha puttassa jāta divase mahā abhinikkhamanam
translated: “In regard to the conditions for assuming”: in regard to the objects that are conditions for the four kinds of assuming. The meaning is: in regard to what is to be assumed. “Bearing in mind”: giving attention to. “This”: the statement beginning, “On another occasion.”

original: padhānānuyogo ca dhammatāvasena veditabbo, itaraṃ itikattabbatāvasena. Tatthāpi cirakālaparibhāvanāya
analyzed: padhāna anuyogaḥ ca dhamma tā vasena veditabbaḥ itaram itikattabba tā vasena tattha api cira kāla paribhāvanāya
translated: “Why was it said?”: the question is asked out of a desire to relate the way in which the great bodhisattva practices the way in his last birth in order to attain enlightenment, and the way in which the great bodhisattva Vipassi practiced in the same way. Therefore he says, “For all great bodhisattvas,” etc. Herein, the great renunciation on the day of the son’s birth and the practice of austerities should be understood as natural laws, the rest as things to be done. And here too the former should be understood as the result of the long-term development of the latter.

original: laddhāsevanāya mahākaruṇāya sañcoditamānasattā “kicchaṃ vatāyaṃ loko āpanno”tiādinā
analyzed: laddha āsevanāya mahā karuṇāya sañcodita māna sattā kiccham vata ayam lokaḥ āpannaḥ iti ādinā
translated: And it is natural that he should also review the causal relations beginning with aging-and-death when he is thus desirous of delivering the world of beings from suffering in the round of rebirths, since he has been urged by his great compassion, which has been developed by practice, and since he has seen that the world has fallen upon trouble, saying to himself, “Alas! This world has fallen upon trouble.”

original: saṃsāradukkhato mocetuṃ icchitassa sattalokassa kicchāpattidassanamukhena jarāmaraṇato
analyzed: saṃsāra dukkhataḥ mocetum icchitassa satta lokassa kicchā āpatti dassana mukhena jarā maraṇato
translated: And it is natural that he should review the meditation subject of mindfulness of breathing, since that is the subject he has been practicing when he was desirous of attaining distinction in the dispensation of this Blessed One, and since he has not yet attained his goal.

original: paṭṭhāya paccayākārasammasanampi dhammatāva. Tathā attādhīnatāya, kenaci anupakhatattā,🔽asecanakasukhavihāratāya, catutthajjhānikatāya ca ānāpānakammaṭṭhānānuyogo. Pañcasu
analyzed: paṭṭhāya paccaya ākāra sammasanam pi dhamma tā va tathā atta adhīna tāya kenaci an upakhata ttā  asecanaka sukha vihāra tāya catuttha jhānika tāya ca āna apāna kammaṭṭhāna anuyogo pañcasu
translated: And it is natural that he should review the five aggregates as they really are, since he has already attained distinction in the dispensation of this Blessed One, and since he has attained his goal.🔽And it is natural that he should review the five aggregates as subject to affliction, since he has seen the danger in the five aggregates as they really are.🔽And it is natural that he should review the six internal and external bases, since he has seen the danger in the aggregates.🔽And it is natural that he should review the six internal and external bases as subject to affliction, since he has seen the danger in the bases as they really are.

original: khandhesu abhinivisitvāti viññāṇanāmarūpādipariyāyena gahitesu pañcasu upādānakkhandhesu🔽vipassanābhinivesavasena abhinivisitvā paṭipattiṃ ārabhitvā. Anukkamanti anu anu
analyzed: khandhesu abhinivisitvā ti viññāṇa nāma rūpa ādi pariyāyena gahitesu pañcasu upādānakkhandhesu  vipassanā abhinivesa vasena abhinivisitvā paṭipattim ārabhitvā anukkamanti anu anu
translated: And it is natural that he should review the six internal and external bases as subject to affliction by reviewing the three kinds of feeling, since he has seen the danger in the bases as they really are.🔽And it is natural that he should review the three kinds of feeling as subject to affliction, since he has seen the danger in the bases as they really are.🔽And it is natural that he should review the three kinds of feeling as subject to affliction by reviewing the six groups of craving, since he has seen the danger in the three kinds of feeling as they really are.🔽And it is natural that he should review the six groups of craving as subject to affliction, since he has seen the danger in the three kinds of feeling as they really are.🔽And it is natural that he should review the six groups of craving as subject to affliction by reviewing the six groups of craving for the six internal and external bases, since he has seen the danger in the six groups of craving as they really are.

original: gāmitabbato paṭipajjitabbato “anukkama”nti laddhanāmaṃ anupubbapaṭipattiṃ. Katvāti paṭipajjitvā.🔽Iti rūpanti ettha dutiyo iti-saddo nidassanattho, tena paṭhamo iti-saddo sarūpassa,
analyzed: gāmitabbataḥ paṭipajjitabbataḥ anukkamanti laddha nāmam anupubba paṭipattim katvā ati paṭipajjitvā 🔽iti rūpam ti ettha dutiyaḥ iti saddo nidassana ttho tena paṭhamaḥ iti saddo sarūpassa
translated: And it is natural that he should review the six groups of craving for the six internal and external bases as subject to affliction, since he has seen the danger in the six groups of craving as they really are.

original: parimāṇassa ca bodhako anekatthattā nipātānaṃ,āvuttiādivasena vāyamattho veditabbo.🔽Antogadhāvadhāraṇañca vākyaṃ dassento “idaṃ rūpaṃ, ettakaṃ rūpaṃ, ito uddhaṃ rūpaṃ
analyzed: parimāṇassa ca bodhakaḥ aneka attha ttā nipātānam āvutti ādi vasena vā ayam atthaḥ veditabbaḥ  vākyam dassentaḥ idam rūpam ettakam rūpam itas uddham rūpam
translated: And the word “only” indicates the measure of matter, since indeclinables have many meanings, or else the meaning should be understood as “no more than this.”

original: natthī”tiādimāha. Tattha “ruppanasabhāva”nti iminā sāmaññato rūpassa sabhāvo dassito,
analyzed: natthi itiādim āha tattha ruppana sabhāvanti iminā sāmaññataḥ rūpassa sabhāvaḥ dassito
translated: And showing that the sentence is inclusive, he says, “This is matter, matter is so much, there is no matter beyond this.” Herein, by the words “The individual essence of matter is the act of causing to be” he shows the general individual essence of matter.

original: “bhūtupādāyabheda”ntiādinā visesato, tadubhayenapi “idaṃ rūpa”nti padassa attho niddiṭṭho.🔽Tattha lakkhaṇaṃ nāma tassa tassa rūpavisesassa anaññasādhāraṇo sabhāvo. Raso tasseva🔽attano phalaṃ pati paccayabhāvo. Paccupaṭṭhānaṃ tassa paramatthato vijjamānattā yāthāvato
analyzed: bhūta upādāya bheda nti ādinā visesataḥ tad ubhayena api idam rūpanti padassa atthaḥ niddiṭṭho  tattha lakkhaṇam nāma tassa tassa rūpa visesassa anañña sādhāraṇaḥ sabhāvaḥ raso tassa iva  attanaḥ phalam pati paccaya bhāvaḥ paccupaṭṭhānam tassa paramatthataḥ vijjamāna ttā yāthāvato
translated: By the words “The classification of matter is by way of the four great primaries and the derived matter” he shows the particular individual essence. By both he shows the meaning of the words “This is matter.”🔽Herein, the characteristic is the individual essence of each particular kind of matter, which is not common to anything else. The taste is the state of being a condition for its own fruit. The manifestation is the state of being the domain of knowledge of the way things are, since it exists in the ultimate sense.

original: ñāṇassa gocarabhāvo. Padaṭṭhānaṃ āsannakāraṇaṃ, tenassa paccayāyattavuttitā dassitā.
analyzed: ñāṇassa gocara bhāvaḥ padaṭṭhānam āsanna kāraṇam tena ssa paccaya āyatta vutti tā dassitā
translated: The proximate cause is the near cause, by which its dependence on conditions is shown.

original: “Anavasesarūpapariggaho”ti iminā pana “ettakaṃ rūpaṃ, ito uddhaṃ” rūpaṃ natthīti
analyzed: anavasesa rūpa pariggaho ti iminā pana ettakam rūpam itas uddham rūpam natthi iti
translated: By the words “The delimitation of matter is the delimitation of its individual essence” he shows that the words “Matter is so much” mean that there is no matter beyond this.

original: padadvayassāpi attho niddiṭṭho rūpassa sabbaso pariyādānavasena niyāmanato. “Iti🔽rūpassa samudayo”ti ettha pana iti-saddo “iti kho bhikkhave sappaṭibhayo bālo”tiādīsu
analyzed: pada dvayassa api atthaḥ niddiṭṭhaḥ rūpassa sabbaso pariyādāna vasena niyāmanataḥ iti  rūpassa samudayo ti ettha pana iti saddaḥ iti kho bhikkhave sa paṭibhayaḥ bālaḥ ti ādīsu
translated: The meaning of the two phrases is stated by the words “by the complete perishing of lust, etc., for materiality.”🔽As regards the words “Thus there is an origin of materiality,” the word “thus” has the meaning of “in this way,” as in the passage, “Thus, bhikkhus, the fool is of this world, born of this world, created by this world, and he returns to this world” .

original: viya pakāratthoti āha “itīti eva”nti.
analyzed: viya pakāra attho ti āha iti iti evam ti
translated: The meaning is “in this way.”

original: Avijjāsamudayāti avijjāya uppādā, atthibhāvāti attho. Nirodhanirodhī hi uppādo atthibhāvavācakopi
analyzed: avijjā samudayā ati avijjāya uppādāḥ atthi bhāvā ti atthaḥ nirodha nirodhī hi uppādaḥ atthi bhāva vācakaḥ api
translated: “With the arising of ignorance”: with the arising of ignorance, with the coming into existence of ignorance. For arising is also a term for the coming into existence of what is present.

original: hoti, tasmā purimabhavasiddhāya avijjāya sati imasmiṃ bhave rūpasamudayo, rūpassa🔽uppādo hotīti attho. “Taṇhāsamudayā”tiādīsupi eseva nayo. Āhārasamudayāti ettha pana
analyzed: hoti tasmai purima bhava siddhāya avijjāya sati imasmin bhave rūpa samudayaḥ rūpassa  uppādaḥ hoti iti attho taṇhā samudayā ti ādīsu pi esa iva nayaḥ āhāra samudayā ti ettha pana
translated: Therefore the meaning here is this: “With the existence of ignorance established in a previous becoming, there is the arising of materiality, the coming into existence of materiality, in this present becoming.”🔽The same method of explanation applies in the case of the words “with the arising of craving,” etc.🔽As regards the words “with the arising of nutriment,” among the conditions for the process of becoming, material food is stated because it is the most powerful.

original: pavattipaccayesu kabaḷīkārāhārassa balavatāya so eva gahito. Tasmiṃ pana gahite pavattipaccayatāsāmaññena
analyzed: pavatti paccayesu kabaḷīkāra āhārassa balava tāya saḥ eva gahitaḥ tasmin pana gahite pavatti paccaya tā sāmaññena
translated: But when that is stated, temperature and mental volition are also stated, since they are similar to it as conditions for the process of becoming.

original: utucittāni gahitāneva hontīti catusamuṭṭhānikarūpassa paccayato udayadassanaṃ vibhāvitamevāti
analyzed: utu cittāni gahitāni eva honti iti catu samuṭṭhānika rūpassa paccayataḥ udaya dassanam vibhāvitam eva ati
translated: Thus the seeing of the origin of materiality that arises from the four primaries is made clear by the words “with the arising of nutriment.”

original: daṭṭhabbaṃ. “Nibbattilakkhaṇa”ntiādinā kālavasena udayadassanamāha. Tattha nibbattilakkhaṇanti🔽rūpassa uppādasaṅkhātaṃ saṅkhatalakkhaṇaṃ. Passantopīti na kevalaṃ paccayasamudayameva,🔽atha kho khaṇato udayaṃ passantopi. Addhāvasena hi paṭhamaṃ udayaṃ passitvā ṭhito🔽puna santativasena disvā anukkamena khaṇavasena passati. Avijjānirodhā rūpanirodhoti🔽aggamaggena avijjāya anuppādanirodhato anāgatassa rūpassa anuppādanirodho hoti paccayābhāve🔽abhāvato. Taṇhānirodhā kammanirodhoti etthāpi eseva nayo. Āhāranirodhāti pavattipaccayassa🔽kabaḷīkārāhārassa abhāvena. Rūpanirodhoti taṃsamuṭṭhānarūpassa abhāvo hoti. Sesaṃ

translated: “The characteristic of arising” is the arising of materiality, that is, the characteristic of the formed. “Seeing”: not only the arising of conditions,🔽but also the arising of the moment. analyzed: sama paññāsa lakkhaṇa vasena ati paccayataḥ vīsati khaṇataḥ pañca ati pañcavīsatiyā udaya lakkhaṇānaṃ
translated: As to the characteristic of the fifty: as to the characteristic of the fifty kinds of rise and fall, that is to say,

analyzed: udaya vaya lakkhaṇānam vasena tattha pañcannam khandhānam udayaḥ lakkhīyati etehi iti  lakkhaṇāni iti vuccanti avijjā ādi samudayaḥ ti tathā tesam anuppāda nirodhaḥ lakkhīyati

analyzed: etehi iti lakkhaṇāni iti vuccanti avijjā ādīnam accanta nirodhaḥ nibbatti vipariṇāma lakkhaṇāni
translated: so they are called characteristics. But the characteristics of generation and alteration are the characteristics of the formed.

original: pana saṅkhatalakkhaṇamevāti. Evaṃ etāni samapaññāsalakkhaṇāni sarūpato veditabbāni.🔽Yathānukkamena vaḍḍhiteti yathāvuttaudayabbayañāṇe tikkhe sūre pasanne hutvā vahante
analyzed: pana saṅkhata lakkhaṇam eva ati evam etāni sama paññāsa lakkhaṇāni sarūpataḥ veditabbāni  yathā anukkamena vaḍḍhitā iti yathā vutta udaya bbaya ñāṇe tikkhe sūre pasanne hutvā vahante
translated: So these characteristics should be understood as fifty in all in their individual essences.🔽As to the order in which they are extended: when the aforesaid knowledge of rise and fall is extended, it does so in the order stated, and it does so with keenness, with directness, with ease.

original: tato paraṃ vattabbānaṃ bhaṅgañāṇādīnaṃ uppattipaṭipāṭiyā buddhippatte paramukkaṃsagate
analyzed: tatas param vattabbānam bhaṅga ñāṇa ādīnam uppatti paṭipāṭiyā buddhi ppatte param ukkaṃsa gate
translated: After that, the order in which the knowledge of fall, etc., which have still to be told about, arise is as follows. The knowledge of fall is the first of the remaining kinds of knowledge.

original: vipassanāñāṇe. Pageva hi chattiṃsakoṭisatasahassamukhena pavattena sabbaññutaññāṇānucchavikena🔽mahāvajirañāṇasaṅkhātena sammasanañāṇena sambhatānubhāvaṃ gabbhaṃ gaṇhantaṃ paripākaṃ
analyzed: vipassanā ñāṇe pagā iva hi chattiṃsa koṭi sata sahassa mukhena pavattena sabbaññuta ññāṇa ānucchavikena  mahā vajira ñāṇa saṅkhātena sammasana ñāṇena sambhata anubhāvam gabbham gaṇhantam paripākam
translated: and in the knowledge of insight. For the knowledge of purification of the way, which is the first of the three kinds of knowledge called “purification” , is the proximate cause for the knowledge of the supramundane path.🔽It is the knowledge of purification of the way that takes up the embryo of the supramundane path, which is the fruit of the development of insight, and carries it to maturity.

original: gacchantaṃ paṭipadāvisuddhiñāṇaṃ aparimitakāle sambhatāya paññāpāramiyā ānubhāvena🔽ukkaṃsapāramippattaṃ anukkamena vuṭṭhānagāminibhāvaṃ upagantvā yadā ariyamaggena
analyzed: gacchantam paṭipadā visuddhi ñāṇam aparimita kāle sambhatāya paññāpāramiyā ānubhāvena  ukkaṃsa pārami pattam anukkamena vuṭṭhāna gāmini bhāvam upagantvā yadā ariya maggena
translated: This knowledge of purification of the way is the proximate cause for the knowledge of the supramundane path.

original: ghaṭeti, tadā ariyamaggacittaṃ sabbakilesehi maggapaṭipāṭiyā vimuccati, vimuccantañca
analyzed: ghaṭeti tadā ariya magga cittam sabba kilesehi magga paṭipāṭiyā vimuccati vimuccantam ca
translated: When the path is being generated, the mind of the supramundane path is liberated from the defilements in the order in which the path appears.

original: tathā vimuccati, yathā sabbañeyyāvaraṇappahānaṃ hoti. Yaṃ kilesānaṃ “savāsanappahāna”nti
analyzed: tathā vimuccati yathā sabba ñeyya āvaraṇa pahānam hoti yam kilesānam sa vāsanā ppahānam ti
translated: And as it is liberated, it is liberated in such a way that the abandoning of the known obstacles is effected.

original: vuccati, tayidaṃ pahānaṃ atthato anuppattinirodhoti āha “anuppādanirodhenā”ti. Āsavasaṅkhātehi
analyzed: vuccati tayā idam pahānam atthataḥ anuppatti nirodhaḥ ti āha anuppāda nirodhena āti āsava saṅkhātehi
translated: This abandoning is in fact the attainment of cessation. Therefore it is said: “by the cessation of arising.”🔽The knowledge of the supramundane path is the proximate cause for the knowledge of reviewing.

original: kilesehīti bhavato ābhavaggaṃ, dhammato āgotrabhuṃ savanato pavattanato āsavasaññitehi
analyzed: kilesehi iti bhavataḥ ā bha vaggam dhammataḥ ā gotrabhum savanataḥ pavattanataḥ āsava saññitehi
translated: “From defilements” : from existence, from the higher realms, from the state of non-restraint, from the state of non-possession of the noble states, from the state of non-possession of the path, from the state of non-possession of the fruit, from the state of non-possession of Nibbana.

original: rāgo, diṭṭhi, mohoti imehi kilesehi. Lakkhaṇavacanañcetaṃ, pāḷiyaṃ yadidaṃ “āsavehī”ti,
analyzed: rāgaḥ diṭṭhi moho ti imehi kilesehi lakkhaṇa vacanam ca itam pāḷiyam yat idam āsavehi iti
translated: “From the taints” : from the taints called lust, hatred, and delusion. This is a characteristic statement, for in the text it is said: “from the taints.”

original: tadekaṭṭhatāya pana sabbehipi kilesehi sabbehipi pāpadhammehi cittaṃ vimuccati. Aggahetvāti
analyzed: tad ekaṭṭhatāya pana sabbehi pi kilesehi sabbehi pi pāpa dhammehi cittam vimuccati aggahetvā ati
translated: But the mind is liberated from all defilements, from all evil states, by the single fact of its being liberated.

original: tesaṃ kilesānaṃ lesamattampi aggahetvā.
analyzed: tesam kilesānam lesa mattam pi aggahetvā
translated: “Without grasping” : without grasping even a trace of those defilements.

original: Maggakkhaṇe vimuccati nāma taṃtaṃmaggavajjhakilesehi phalakkhaṇe vimuttaṃ nāma. Maggakkhaṇe
analyzed: magga kkhaṇe vimuccati nāma taṃ taṃ magga vajjha kilesehi phala kkhaṇe vimuttam nāma magga kkhaṇe
translated: “Is liberated” : at the moment of the path, the mind is liberated from the defilements abandoned by that path at the moment of the fruit.

original: vā vimuttañceva vimuccati cāti uparimaggakkhaṇe heṭṭhimamaggavajjhehi vimuttañceva
analyzed: vā vimuttam ca iva vimuccati ca ati upari magga kkhaṇe heṭṭhima magga vajjhehi vimuttam ca iva
translated: Or, at the moment of the path, the mind is both liberated and is liberated from the defilements abandoned by the lower path at the moment of the higher path.🔽At the moment of the fruit, the mind is liberated from the defilements to be abandoned by each path.

original: yathāsakaṃ pahātabbehi vimuccati ca. Phalakkhaṇe vimuttamevāti sabbasmimpi phalakkhaṇe
analyzed: yathāsakam pahātabbehi vimuccati ca phala kkhaṇe vimuttam eva ati sabbasmim pi phala kkhaṇe
translated: At the moment of all the fruits,

original: vimuttameva, na vimuccati nāma.
analyzed: vimuttam eva na vimuccati nāma
translated: the mind is liberated, not liberated.

original: Sabbabandhanāti orambhāgiyuddhambhāgiyasaṅgahitā sabbasmāpi bhavasaññojanā, vippamutto
analyzed: sabba bandhanā ti orambhāgiya uddhambhāgiya saṅgahitā sabbasma api bhava saññojanā vippamutto
translated: “From all bonds” : from all the fetters included in the lower and higher fetters, from all the bonds of existence,

original: visesato pakārehi mutto. Suvikasitacittasantānoti sātisayaṃ ñāṇarasmisamphassena
analyzed: visesataḥ pakārehi muttaḥ su vikasita citta santānaḥ ti sa atisayam ñāṇa rasmi samphassena
translated: and especially by the kinds of knowledge. His mind-continuum is well-blossomed: by the contact of the rays of the knowledge of the four paths,

original: suṭṭhu sammadeva samphullacittasantāno. “Cattāri maggañāṇānī”tiādi yehi ñāṇehi suvikasitacittasantāno,
analyzed: suṭṭhu sammad eva samphulla citta santāno cattāri magga ñāṇāni itiādi yehi ñāṇehi su vikasita citta santāno
translated: his mind-continuum is well-blossomed, well-expanded, well-developed. “The four paths of knowledge” and so on are the kinds of knowledge by which his mind-continuum is well-blossomed.

original: tesaṃ ekadesena dassanaṃ. Nippadesato dassanaṃ pana parato āgamissati, tasmā tattheva
analyzed: tesam ekadesena dassanam nippadesataḥ dassanam pana paratas āgamissati tasmā tattha eva
translated: The seeing of a part of them is shown here. But the seeing of the whole will come later,

original: tāni vibhajissāma. Sakale ca buddhaguṇeti atītaṃse appaṭihatañāṇādike sabbepi buddhaguṇe.
analyzed: tāni vibhajissāma sakale ca buddha guṇe iti atīta ṃse appaṭihata ñāṇa ādike sabbe pi buddha guṇe
translated: and there we will analyze them. And all the qualities of a Buddha: the entire mass of qualities of a Buddha, such as the knowledge that is unobstructed with regard to the past, etc.

original: Yadā hi lokanātho aggamaggaṃ adhigacchati, tadā sabbe guṇe hatthagate karoti nāma.
analyzed: yadā hi loka nāthaḥ aggamaggam adhigacchati tadā sabbe guṇe hattha gate karoti nāma
translated: For when the Lord of the World attains the supreme path, then he takes all the qualities into his hand, so to speak.

original: Tato paraṃ “hatthagate katvā ṭhito”ti vuccati.
analyzed: tato param hattha gate katvā ṭhitaḥ iti vuccati
translated: From then on he is said to stand having taken them into his hand.

original: “Paripuṇṇasaṅkappo”ti vatvā paripuṇṇasaṅkappatāparidīpanaṃ udānaṃ dassetuṃ “anekajātisaṃsāra”ntiādi
analyzed: paripuṇṇa saṅkappo ti vatvā paripuṇṇa saṅkappa tā paridīpanam udānam dassetum aneka jāti saṃsāra nti ādi
translated: After saying “his intention is fulfilled,” the Udana is stated in order to illustrate the fulfillment of his intention. “Having gone through birth and death so many times” is said.

original: vuttaṃ. Tattha ādito dvinnaṃ gāthānamattho heṭṭhā brahmajālanidānavaṇṇanāyaṃ vutto
analyzed: vuttam tattha āditaḥ dvinnam gāthānam attho heṭṭhā brahmajālanidāna vaṇṇanāyam vutto
translated: Herein, the meaning of the first two stanzas is stated in the commentary on the Brahmajala Sutta below.

original: eva. Parato pana ayoghanahatassāti ayo haññati etenāti ayoghanaṃ, kammārānaṃ ayokūṭaṃ,
analyzed: eva paratas pana ayoghana hatassa ati ayaḥ haññati etena ati ayoghanam kammārānam ayokūṭam
translated: “And from another”: from an iron hammer. The meaning is: from an iron hammer, a blacksmith’s iron hammer, an iron fist.

original: ayomuṭṭhi ca, tena ayoghanena hatassa pahatassa. Eva-saddo cettha nipātamattaṃ. Jalato
analyzed: ayaḥ muṭṭhi ca tena ayaḥ ghanena hatassa pahatassa eva saddaḥ ca ittha nipāta mattam jalataḥ
translated: “Struck” means beaten. The word “even” is merely a particle. “From fire” means

original: jātavedasoti jalayamānassa aggissa, anādare vā etaṃ sāmivacanaṃ. Anupubbūpasantassāti
analyzed: jātavedasaḥ iti jalayamānassa aggissa anādare vai etam sāmi vacanam anupubbūpasantassa ati
translated: from burning fire. Or it is a term of respect. “Gradually subsiding” means

original: anukkamena upasantassa vikkhambhantassa niruddhassa. Yathā na ñāyate gatīti yathā
analyzed: anukkamena upasantassa vikkhambhantassa niruddhassa yathā na ñāyate gatī iti yathā
translated: subsiding, ceasing, gradually. “Its going is not known” means

original: tassa gati na ñāyati. Idaṃ vuttaṃ hoti – ayomuṭṭhikūṭādinā pahatattā ayoghanena hatassa🔽pahatassa ayogatassa, kaṃsabhājanādigatassa vā jalamānassa aggissa anukkamena upasantassa
analyzed: tassa gati na ñāyati idam vuttam hoti ayaḥ muṭṭhi kūṭa ādinā pahata ttā ayaḥ ghanena hatassa  pahatassa ayaḥ gatassa kaṃsa bhājana ādi gatassa vā jalamānassa aggissa anukkamena upasantassa
translated: its going is not known. This is the meaning: the going of the iron hammer, etc.,

original: dasasu disāsu na katthaci gati paññāyati paccayanirodhena appaṭisandhikaniruddhattāti.
analyzed: dasasu disāsu na katthaci gati paññāyati paccaya nirodhena appaṭisandhika niruddha ttā ati
translated: is not known anywhere in the ten directions, because it has ceased without reappearing through the cessation of its conditions.

original: Evaṃ sammāvimuttānanti sammā hetunā ñāyena tadaṅgavikkhambhanavimuttipubbaṅgamāya
analyzed: evam sammā vimuttānam ti sammā hetunā ñāyena tad aṅga vikkhambhana vimutti pubbaṅgamāya
translated: “So too, of those who are rightly freed”: of those who are rightly freed by the right cause, by the right method, by the prior stage of liberation through the suppression of the defilements,

original: samucchedavimuttiyā ariyamaggena catūhipi upādānehi, āsavehi ca muttattā sammā vimuttānaṃ,🔽tato eva kāmabandhanasaṅkhātaṃ kāmoghabhavoghādibhedaṃ avasiṭṭhaoghañca taritvā ṭhitattā
analyzed: samuccheda vimuttiyāḥ ariya maggena catūhi pi upādānehi āsavehi ca mutta ttā sammā vimuttānam  tatas eva kāma bandhana saṅkhātam kāma ogha bhava ogha ādi bhedam avasiṭṭha ogham ca taritvā
translated: And because they are liberated by the noble path of eradication from the four kinds of clinging and from the taints,

original: kāmabandhoghatārīnaṃ suṭṭhu paṭipassambhitasabbakilesavipphanditattā kilesābhisaṅkhāravātehi🔽akampanīyatāya acalaṃ nibbānasaṅkhātaṃ saṅkhārūpasamaṃ sukhaṃ pattānaṃ adhigatānaṃ
analyzed: kāma bandha ughatārīnam suṭṭhu paṭipassambhita sabba kilesa vipphandita ttā kilesa abhisaṅkhāra vātehi  a kampanīya tāya acalam nibbāna saṅkhātam saṅkhā rūpa samam sukham pattānam adhigatānam
translated: they are “fully liberated.” And because they have crossed over the remaining flood, which is called the bond of sense desire, and which is divided into the flood of sense desire, the flood of becoming, etc.,🔽they are “crossers of the flood.” And because they have attained the bliss of the stilling of formations called Nibbāna, which is unshakable by the winds of the formations called defilements,

original: khīṇāsavānaṃ gati devamanussādibhedāsu gatīsu “ayaṃ nāmā”ti paññāpetabbatāya abhāvato
analyzed: khīṇāsavānam gati deva manussa ādi bhedāsu gatīsu ayam nāma ati paññāpetabba tāya abhāvato
translated: they are “attainers of bliss.” And because they have no destination that can be pointed to as “this” in the various destinations of gods, humans, etc.,

original: paññāpetuṃ natthi na upalabbhati, yathāvuttajātavedo viya apaññattikabhāvameva te
analyzed: paññāpetum natthi na upalabbhati yathā vutta jātavedaḥ viya a paññattika bhāvam eva te
translated: they are “undirected.” The meaning is that they are like the fire of the past, which cannot be pointed to as “this” and is not found, and they go to the state of being unspecifiable, as explained above.

original: gacchantīti attho. Evaṃ manasi karontoti “evaṃ anekajātisaṃsāra”ntiādinā attano katakiccattaṃ
analyzed: gacchanti iti attho evam manasi karonto ti evam aneka jāti saṃsāranti ādinā
translated: “Thinking thus”: thinking thus about his own task, namely, “Thus for a long time I have wandered on,” etc.,

original: manasi karonto bodhipallaṅke nisinnova virocitthāti yojanā.

translated: The second recitation section is finished.

original: na pallaṅkasattāhassa viya aṭṭhamassa nāma sattāhassa vavatthitassa labbhamānattā.
analyzed: na pallaṅka sattāhassa viya aṭṭhamassa nāma sattāhassa vavatthitassa labbhamāna ttā
translated: not as the seventh week is distinguished from the eighth week.

original: Anantaroti “adhigato kho myāyaṃ dhammo”tiādiko vitakko.
analyzed: anantaraḥ ti adhigataḥ kho myā ayam dhammo ti ādikaḥ vitakko
translated: “The next stage” is the thought beginning, “This Dhamma that I have attained is deep, hard to see, hard to understand, peaceful, excellent, beyond the sphere of logic, profound, understandable (only) by the wise” .

original: Paṭividdhoti sayambhuñāṇena “idaṃ dukkha”ntiādinā paṭimukhaṃ paṭivijjhanavasena pavatto,
analyzed: paṭividdhaḥ ti sayambhu ñāṇena idam dukkham ti ādinā paṭimukham paṭivijjhana vasena pavatto
translated: “Penetrated” : penetrated by means of the knowledge of the self-awakened one, by way of the direct experience of the four truths beginning with “This is suffering” .

original: yathābhūtaṃ avabuddhoti attho. Dhammoti catusaccadhammo tabbinimuttassa paṭivijjhitabbadhammassa
analyzed: yathābhūtam avabuddhaḥ ti atthaḥ dhammo ti catu sacca dhammo tad vinimuttassa paṭivijjhitabba dhammassa
translated: “The Dhamma” : the Dhamma of the four truths.

original: abhāvato. Gambhīroti mahāsamuddo viya makasatuṇḍasūciyā aññatra samupacitaparipakkañāṇasambhārehi
analyzed: abhāvataḥ gambhīraḥ ti mahā samuddaḥ viya makasa tuṇḍa sūciyā aññatra samupacita paripakka ñāṇa sambhārehi
translated: “Deep” : like the great ocean, it is not to be fathomed by anyone except by one who has accumulated the requisites of knowledge and has developed it.

original: aññesaṃ ñāṇena alabbhaneyyappatiṭṭho. Tenāha “uttānabhāvapaṭikkhepavacanameta”nti.
analyzed: aññesam ñāṇena a labbhaneyya patiṭṭho tena āha uttāna bhāva paṭikkhepa vacanam etat ti
translated: Therefore it is said: “This is a statement that rejects the idea of superficiality.”

original: Alabbhaneyyappatiṭṭho ogāhituṃ asakkuṇeyyatāya sarūpato visesato ca passituṃ na sakkāti
analyzed: ogāhitum a sakkuṇeyya tāya sarūpataḥ visesataḥ ca passitum na sakkā ati
translated: It is not to be fathomed because it cannot be grasped by the knowledge of others. It cannot be seen in its own form and in its specific nature.🔽Therefore it is said: “It is hard to see because of its profundity.”

original: āha “gambhīrattāva duddaso”ti. Dukkhena daṭṭhabboti kicchena kenaci kadācideva daṭṭhabbo.
analyzed: āha gambhīra ttā ava duddasaḥ ti dukkhena daṭṭhabbo ti kicchena kenaci kadācid eva daṭṭhabbo
translated: It is to be seen with difficulty, with great effort, by some at some time.

original: Yaṃ pana daṭṭhumeva na sakkā, tassa ogāhetvā anu anu bujjhane kathā eva natthīti
analyzed: yam pana daṭṭhum eva na sakkā tassa ogāhetvā anu anu bujjhane kathā eva natthi iti
translated: But that which cannot be seen at all is not even a matter for discussion as to whether it can be penetrated or not.

original: āha “duddasattāva duranubodho”ti. Dukkhena avabujjhitabbo avabodhassa dukkarabhāvato.
analyzed: āha duddasa ttā va duranubodhaḥ ti dukkhena avabujjhitabbaḥ avabodhassa dukkara bhāvato
translated: So it is said, “Hard to see, hard to sound” . It is hard to sound because it is hard to penetrate by understanding.

original: Imasmiṃ ṭhāne “taṃ kiṃ maññatha bhikkhave dukkarataraṃ vā durabhisambhavataraṃ vā”ti
analyzed: imasmim ṭhāne tam kim maññatha bhikkhave dukkarataram vā durabhisambhavataram vā ati
translated: Herein, the passage from the sutta beginning, “What do you think, bhikkhus? Which is more difficult to do or to attain, the more difficult or the more hard to do or to attain of these two things?”

original: suttapadaṃ vattabbaṃ. Santārammaṇatāya vā santo. Nibbutasabbapariḷāhatāya nibbuto.
analyzed: sutta padam vattabbam santa ārammaṇa tāya vā santaḥ nibbuta sabba pariḷāha tāya nibbutaḥ
translated: is applicable. It is peaceful because it is the object of peace, or it is peaceful because it is itself peaceful with the stilling of all the defilements and the formations’ occurrence in tranquillity.

original: Padhānabhāvaṃ nītoti vā paṇīto. Atittikaraṭṭhena atappako sādurasabhojanaṃ viya.
analyzed: padhāna bhāvam nītaḥ iti vā paṇītaḥ a tittika raṭṭhena a tappakaḥ sādu rasa bhojanam viya
translated: It is sublime because it has reached the state of being the highest, and it is unsurpassed because it is not surpassed by anything higher, like a meal of rice and curry.

original: Ettha ca nirodhasaccaṃ santaṃ ārammaṇanti santārammaṇaṃ, maggasaccaṃ santaṃ, santārammaṇañcāti
analyzed: ettha ca nirodha saccam santam ārammaṇanti santa ārammaṇam magga saccam santam santa ārammaṇam ca ati
translated: And here the truth of cessation is the object of peace because it is the object of the peaceful supramundane path; the truth of the path is both peaceful and the object of peace.

original: santārammaṇaṃ anupasantasabhāvānaṃ kilesānaṃ, saṅkhārānañca abhāvato santo nibbutasabbapariḷāhattā🔽nibbuto, santapaṇītabhāveneva tadatthāya asecanakatāya atappakatā daṭṭhabbā. Tenāha
analyzed: santa ārammaṇam kilesānam saṅkhārānam ca abhāvataḥ santaḥ nibbuta sabba pariḷāha ttā 🔽nibbutaḥ santa paṇīta bhāvena iva tad atthāya asecanakatāya atappaka tā daṭṭhabbā tena āha
translated: It is peaceful because it is itself peaceful with the stilling of all the defilements and the formations’ occurrence in tranquillity; it is the object of peace because it is the object of the peaceful supramundane path.🔽And the state of being unsurpassed should be understood as the state of being not to be desired even by those seeking the peaceful state of the fine-material and immaterial spheres, since it is not to be desired by those who seek the bliss of jhāna and the attainments.

original: “idaṃ dvayaṃ lokuttarameva sandhāya vutta”nti. Uttamañāṇassa visayattā na takkena
analyzed: idam dvayam lokuttaram eva sandhāya vuttan ti uttama ñāṇassa visaya ttā na takkena
translated: Because it is the domain of the highest knowledge, it is not to be entered upon by a mere logician.

original: avacaritabbo, tato eva nipuṇañāṇagocaratāya, saṇhasukhumasabhāvattā ca nipuṇo. Bālānaṃ
analyzed: avacaritabbo tatas eva nipuṇa ñāṇa gocara tāya saṇha sukhuma sabhāvattā ca nipuṇaḥ bālānam
translated: Because it is the domain of subtle knowledge and because it has a subtle and refined nature, it is subtle.

original: avisayattā paṇḍitehi eva veditabboti paṇḍitavedanīyo. Ālīyanti abhiramitabbaṭṭhena
analyzed: avisaya ttā paṇḍitehi eva veditabbaḥ ti paṇḍita vedanīyaḥ ālīyanti abhiramitabba ṭṭhena
translated: Because it is the domain of the wise alone, it is to be known by the wise.🔽The five strands of sense pleasure are called “attachments” because one clings to them by way of delighting in them.

original: sevīyantīti ālayā, pañca kāmaguṇā. Ālayanti abhiramaṇavasena sevantīti ālayā, taṇhāvicaritāni.
analyzed: pañca kāmaguṇāḥ ālayanti abhiramaṇa vasena sevanti iti ālayanti taṇhā vicaritāni
translated: The activities of craving are called “attachments” because one delights in them by way of delighting in them.🔽“Attached to attachments” means attached to the attachments.

original: Ālayaratāti ālayaniratā. Suṭṭhu muditā ativiya muditā anukkaṇṭhanato. Ramatīti ratiṃ
analyzed: ālaya ratā ati ālaya niratā suṭṭhu muditā ativiya muditā an ukkaṇṭhanataḥ ramati iti ratim
translated: “Delighting” means finding delight, enjoying, and playing.

original: vindati kīḷati laḷati. Ime sattā yathā kāmaguṇe, evaṃ rāgampi assādenti abhinandanti
analyzed: vindati kīḷati laḷati ime sattāḥ yathā kāma guṇe evam rāgam pi assādenti abhinandanti
translated: Just as beings delight in the strands of sense pleasure, so too they enjoy and delight in craving.

original: yevāti vuttaṃ “duvidhampī”tiādi.
analyzed: yā iva ati vuttam duvidham pi itiādi
translated: Thus it is said, “Both kinds . . . ”

original: Ṭhānaṃ sandhāyāti ṭhāna-saddaṃ sandhāya. Atthato pana “ṭhāna”nti ca paṭiccasamuppādo
analyzed: ṭhānam sandhāya ati ṭhāna saddam sandhāya atthato pana ṭhānam ti ca paṭiccasamuppādaḥ
translated: “With reference to the word ‘ground’ ”: with reference to the word “ground.” But in the sense of the word “ground,” dependent origination is meant.

original: eva adhippeto. Tiṭṭhati ettha phalaṃ tadāyattavuttitāyāti ṭhānaṃ, saṅkhārādīnaṃ paccayabhūtā
analyzed: eva adhippetaḥ tiṭṭhati ettha phalam tad āyatta vutti tāya ati ṭhānam saṅkhāra ādīnam paccaya bhūtā
translated: The state is the condition, for the fruit is present there in the sense that it exists in dependence on it.🔽The conditions are ignorance, etc.,🔽which are the conditions for formations, and so on.

original: avijjādayo. Imesaṃ saṅkhārādīnaṃ paccayāti idappaccayā, avijjādayova. Idappaccayā
analyzed: avijjā ādayaḥ imesam saṅkhāra ādīnam paccayā ati idappaccayā avijjā ādayaḥ idappaccayā
translated: The state of being a condition is the state of being a condition for these, for formations, and so on.

original: eva idappaccayatā yathā devo eva devatā, idappaccayānaṃ vā avijjādīnaṃ attano phalaṃ
analyzed: eva idappaccaya tā yathā devaḥ eva devatā idappaccayānam vā avijjā ādīnam attanaḥ phalam
translated: The state of being a condition is the state of being a condition for the fruit, which is dependent on ignorance, etc.,

original: paṭicca paccayabhāvo uppādanasamatthatā idappaccayatā, tena paramatthapaccayalakkhaṇo
analyzed: paṭicca paccaya bhāvaḥ uppādana samattha tā idappaccaya tā tena paramattha paccaya lakkhaṇo
translated: for the state of being able to bring about the fruit. Thus the characteristic of a condition in the ultimate sense is shown.

original: paṭiccasamuppādo dassito hoti. Paṭicca samuppajjati phalaṃ etasmāti paṭiccasamuppādo.🔽Padadvayenāpi dhammānaṃ paccayaṭṭho eva vibhāvito. Tenāha “saṅkhārādipaccayānaṃ avijjādīnametaṃ
analyzed: paṭiccasamuppādaḥ dassitaḥ hoti paṭicca samuppajjati phalam etasma ati paṭiccasamuppādaḥ  pada dvayena api dhammānam paccaya ṭṭhaḥ eva vibhāvito tena āha saṅkhāra ādi paccayānam avijjā ādīnam etam
translated: The dependent origination is so called because the fruit originates in dependence on a condition.

original: adhivacana”nti. Ayamettha saṅkhepo, vitthāro pana visuddhimaggasaṃvaṇṇanāsu vuttanayena veditabbo.
analyzed: adhivacanam ti ayam ettha saṅkhepaḥ vitthāraḥ pana visuddhi magga saṃvaṇṇanāsu vutta nayena veditabbo
translated: And by the two terms “state of being a condition” and “dependent origination” the fact that states are conditions is also demonstrated. Hence it is said: “This is a designation for ignorance, and so on, which are the conditions for formations, and so on” . This, in brief, is the explanation of the dependent origination. The detailed explanation should be understood in the way given in the commentaries on the Visuddhimagga.

original: Sabbasaṅkhārasamathotiādi sabbanti sabbasaṅkhārasamathādipadābhidheyyaṃ sabbaṃ, atthato
analyzed: sabba saṅkhāra samatha uti ādi sabbanti sabba saṅkhāra samatha ādi pada abhidheyyam sabbam atthataḥ
translated: “The stilling of all formations” and so on: “all” is all that is signified by the terms “stilling of all formations” and so on. In meaning it is

original: nibbānameva. Idāni tassa nibbānabhāvaṃ dassetuṃ “yasmā hī”tiādi vuttaṃ. Tanti nibbānaṃ.
analyzed: nibbānam eva idāni tassa nibbāna bhāvam dassetum yasmā hi itiādi vuttam tat ti nibbānam
translated: Nibbana. Now, in order to show that it is Nibbana, the following is said: “because” and so on. “That” is Nibbana.

original: Āgammāti paṭicca ariyamaggassa ārammaṇapaccayahetu. Sammantīti appaṭisandhikūpasamavasena🔽sammanti. Tathā santā ca savisesaṃ upasantā nāma hontīti āha “vūpasammantī”ti, etena🔽sabbe saṅkhārā sammanti etthāti sabbasaṅkhārasamatho, nibbānanti dasseti. Sabbasaṅkhāravisaṃyutte🔽hi nibbāne sabbasaṅkhāravūpasamapariyāyo ñāyāgato yevāti. Sesepadesupi eseva nayo.🔽Upadhīyati ettha dukkhanti upadhi, khandhādayo. Paṭinissaṭṭhāti samucchedavasena
analyzed: āgamma ti paṭicca ariya maggassa ārammaṇa paccaya hetu sammanti iti appaṭisandhi kūpa sama vasena  sammanti tathā santā ca savisesam upasantāḥ nāma honti iti āha vūpasammanti iti etena  sabbe saṅkhārā ettha ati sabba saṅkhāra samathaḥ nibbānam ti dasseti sabba saṅkhāra visaṃyutte  hi nibbāne sabba saṅkhāra vūpasama pariyāyaḥ ñāya āgataḥ yeva ati sese padesu pi esa iva nayaḥ  upadhīyati ettha dukkhanti upadhi khandha ādayo paṭinissaṭṭhā ati samuccheda vasena
