analyzed: tesam pi lakkhaṇa saṇṭhānam viya satthu sarīra saṇṭhānam tesam kevalam paññāyati eva ati  na api āmukka maṇi kuṇḍalaḥ bhagavā hoti iti yojanā chinnaḥ sarā ati dvidhā bhūtaḥ sarā gaggaraḥ sarā ati
translated: as in the passage beginning ‘ Their characteristics and shape, like the Master’s body, are only discerned ‘ .

original: jajjaritassarā. Bhāsantaranti tesaṃ sattānaṃ bhāsato aññaṃ bhāsaṃ. Vīmaṃsāti cintanā.🔽“Kimatthaṃ…pe… desetī”ti idaṃ nanu attānaṃ jānāpetvā dhamme kathite tesaṃ sātisayo🔽pasādo hotīti iminā adhippāyena vuttaṃ? Yesaṃ attānaṃ ajānāpetvāva dhamme kathite
analyzed: tesam sattānam bhāsataḥ aññam bhāsam vīmaṃsāti cintanā  deseti iti idam nanu attānam jānāpetvā dhamme kathite tesam sa atisayaḥ  pasādaḥ hoti iti iminā adhippāyena vuttam yesam attānam a jānāpetvā ava dhamme kathite
translated: Nor is the Blessed One a man with earrings, is the construction. Split-tongued : with a tongue split in two. Fork-tongued : with a tongue that is forked. Speaking a different language : a language different from that of those creatures. Thinking : pondering.🔽‘ Why does he teach the True Idea after making known his own name? ‘—is this not said with the intention that when the True Idea is taught after making known his own name, their confidence in him is very great?

original: pasādo hoti, na jānāpetvā, tādise sandhāya satthā tathā karoti. Tattha payojanamāha
analyzed: pasādaḥ hoti na tādise sandhāya satthā tathā karoti tattha payojanam āha
translated: But when the True Idea is taught without making known his own name, confidence in him is not so great, and so the Master acts in this way with reference to those who are of that kind. Herein, the purpose is this:

original: “vāsanatthāyā”ti. Evaṃ sutopīti evaṃ aviññātadesako aviññātāgamanopi suto dhammo
analyzed: vāsana tthāya ati evam sutaḥ api iti evam aviññāta desakaḥ aviññāta āgamanaḥ api sutaḥ dhammo
translated: The Dhamma that is well heard in this way, that is, the Dhamma that is taught without confusion and that is understood without confusion,

original: attano dhammasudhammatāyeva anāgate paccayo hoti suṇantassa.
analyzed: attanaḥ dhamma su dhamma tāya iva anāgate paccayaḥ hoti suṇantassa
translated: is a condition for the future only by virtue of its own special quality of being the Dhamma.

original: “Ānandā”tiādiko saṅgītianāruḷho pāḷidhammo eva tathā dassito. Esa nayo ito paresupi evarūpesu ṭhānesu.
analyzed: ānanda ati ādiko saṅgīti anāruḷho pāḷi dhammo eva tathā dassitaḥ esa nayaḥ itas paresu pi evarūpesu ṭhānesu
translated: The Dhamma that is recited in the texts beginning with “Ānanda” is shown in the same way. The same method applies to other such passages.

original: Aṭṭhaabhibhāyatanavaṇṇanā🔽173. Abhibhavatīti abhibhu, parikammaṃ, ñāṇaṃ vā. Abhibhu āyatanaṃ etassāti abhibhāyatanaṃ,
analyzed: aṭṭha abhibhāyatana vaṇṇanā  abhibhavati iti abhibhu parikammam ñāṇam vā abhibhu āyatanam etassa ati abhibhāyatanam
translated: The explanation of the eight spheres of mastery🔽. “Mastery” is the act of mastering or the knowledge that masters. The sphere of mastery is that which has mastery.🔽It is a jhāna. Or alternatively, the sphere of mastery is that which is to be mastered, that is, the object consisting in a sign.

original: jhānaṃ. Abhibhavitabbaṃ vā ārammaṇasaṅkhātaṃ āyatanaṃ etassāti abhibhāyatanaṃ. Ārammaṇābhibhavanato
analyzed: jhānam abhibhavitabbam vā ārammaṇa saṅkhātam āyatanam etassa ati abhibhāyatanam ārammaṇa abhibhavanato
translated: Because of the mastering of the object,

original: abhibhu ca taṃ āyatanañca yogino sukhavisesānaṃ adhiṭṭhānabhāvato, manāyatanadhammāyatanabhāvato
analyzed: abhibhu ca tam āyatanam ca yogino sukha visesānam adhiṭṭhāna bhāvataḥ manāyatana dhammāyatana bhāvataḥ
translated: and because it is the basis for the yogin’s mastery of the special kinds of pleasantness, and because it is the mind and mental-data base,

original: vātipi sasampayuttaṃ jhānaṃ abhibhāyatanaṃ. Tenāha “abhibhavanakāraṇānī”tiādi. Tāni
analyzed: sa sampayuttam jhānam abhibhāyatanam tena āha abhibhavana kāraṇāni itiādi tāni
translated: the jhāna together with its associated states is a sphere of mastery. Hence it is said: “The reasons for the name are ‘because of the act of mastering’ and so on.”

original: hīti abhibhāyatanasaññitāni jhānāni. “Puggalassa ñāṇuttariyatāyā”ti idaṃ ubhayatthāpi
analyzed: hi iti abhibhāyatana saññitāni jhānāni puggalassa ñāṇuttariya tāya ati idam ubhayattha api
translated: “Hī” is the jhānas called the “bases of mastery.” “For the purpose of surpassing knowledge in a person” should be construed in both

original: yojetabbaṃ. Kathaṃ? Paṭipakkhabhāvena paccanīkadhamme abhibhavanti puggalassa ñāṇuttariyatāya
analyzed: yojetabbam katham paṭipakkha bhāvena paccanīka dhamme abhibhavanti puggalassa ñāṇuttariya tāya
translated: places. How? They master the opposing states by way of the opposite, and they master the objects by way of surpassing knowledge in a person.

original: ārammaṇāni abhibhavanti. Ñāṇabaleneva hi ārammaṇābhibhavanaṃ viya paṭipakkhābhibhavo pīti.🔽Parikammavasena ajjhattaṃ rūpasaññī, na appanāvasena. Na hi paṭibhāganimittārammaṇā
analyzed: ārammaṇāni abhibhavanti ñāṇa balena iva hi ārammaṇa abhibhavanam viya paṭipakkha abhibhavaḥ pi iti  parikamma vasena ajjhattam rūpa saññī na appanā vasena na hi paṭibhāga nimitta ārammaṇā
translated: For just as the object is mastered by the power of knowledge, so too the opposite is mastered by the power of knowledge.🔽He has the perception of a visible form internally, not by way of absorption but by way of the preliminary work. For the absorption perception of the counterpart sign as object

original: appanā ajjhattavisayā sambhavati, taṃ pana ajjhattaparikammavasena laddhaṃ kasiṇanimittaṃ
analyzed: appanā ajjhatta visayā sambhavati tam pana ajjhatta parikamma vasena laddham kasiṇa nimittam
translated: cannot have an internal object. But the kasiṇa as object acquired by way of the internal preliminary work

original: avisuddhameva hoti, na bahiddhāparikammavasena laddhaṃ viya visuddhaṃ.🔽Parittānīti yathāladdhāni suppasarāvamattāni. Tenāha “avaḍḍhitānī”ti. Parittavasenevāti
analyzed: a visuddham eva hoti na bahiddhā parikamma vasena laddham viya visuddham  parittāni iti yathā laddhāni suppasara avamattāni tena āha avaḍḍhitāni iti paritta vasena iva iti
translated: is not purified, unlike that acquired by way of the external preliminary work.🔽“Limited” means the size of a mere thumb-print, acquired as already described. Hence it is said, “not extended.” This base of mastery is called “limited”

original: vaṇṇavasena ābhoge vijjamānepi parittavaseneva idaṃ abhibhāyatanaṃ vuttaṃ. Parittatā
analyzed: vaṇṇa vasena ābhoge vijjamāne pi paritta vasena iva idam abhibhāyatanam vuttam paritta tā
translated: because it is limited in extent, not because it is limited in development, for it is developed by being extended as far as one likes.

original: hettha abhibhavanassa kāraṇaṃ. Vaṇṇābhoge satipi asatipi abhibhāyatanabhāvanā nāma
analyzed: ha ittha abhibhavanassa kāraṇam vaṇṇa ābhoge sati pi a sati pi abhibhāyatanabhāvanā nāma
translated: The reason for the mastery is this. The development of the bases of mastery is called🔽

original: tikkhapaññasseva sambhavati, na itarassāti āha “ñāṇuttariko puggalo”ti. Abhibhavitvā
analyzed: tikkha paññassa iva sambhavati na itarassa ati āha ñāṇuttarikaḥ puggalo ti abhibhavitvā
translated: The reason for the mastery is this. The development of the bases of mastery is possible only for one of quick understanding, not for another, even though he may have mastery in colour and form, and so he said “a person of superior knowledge.”

original: samāpajjatīti ettha abhibhavanaṃ, samāpajjanañca upacārajjhānādhigamasamanantarameva
analyzed: samāpajjati iti ettha abhibhavanam samāpajjanam ca upacāra jhāna adhigama samanantaram eva
translated: Having mastered: here the mastering and the attaining of absorption are the production of absorption immediately on the acquisition of access concentration.

original: appanājhānuppādananti āha “saha nimittuppādenevettha appanaṃ pāpetī”ti. Saha nimittuppādenāti
analyzed: appanā jhāna uppādananti āha saha nimitta uppādena iva ittha appanam pāpeti iti saha nimitta uppādena ati
translated: That is why he said “he brings it to absorption by the mere arising of the sign.”

original: ca appanāparivāsābhāvassa lakkhaṇaṃ vacanametaṃ. Yo “khippābhiñño”ti vuccati, tatopi
analyzed: ca appanā parivāsa abhāvassa lakkhaṇam vacanam etam yaḥ khippābhiñño ti vuccati tatas pi
translated: And the words “by the mere arising of the sign” are a description of the absence of access concentration in between.🔽The development of the bases of mastery is only for one described as “of quick understanding” and “of superior knowledge.”

original: ñāṇuttarasseva abhibhāyatanabhāvanā. Etthāti etasmiṃ nimitte. Appanaṃ pāpetīti bhāvanaṃ appanaṃ neti.
analyzed: abhibhāyatana bhāvanā ettha ati etasmin nimitte appanam pāpeti iti bhāvanam appanam na iti
translated: Herein, he brings it to absorption: he leads the development to absorption.

original: Ettha ca keci “uppanne upacārajjhāne taṃ ārabbha ye heṭṭhimantena dve tayo javanavārā
analyzed: ettha ca keci uppanne upacāra jjhāne tam ārabbha ye heṭṭhimantena dve tayaḥ javana vārā
translated: And here some say that when access concentration has arisen, the two or three impulsions that occur next to it are access concentration, and the rest is absorption.

original: pavattanti, te upacārajjhānapakkhikā eva, tadanantarañca bhavaṅgaparivāsena, upacārāsevanāya
analyzed: pavattanti te upacāra jhāna pakkhikāḥ eva tad anantarañca bhavaṅga parivāsena upacāra āsevanāya
translated: They are only the factors of access jhāna, and after that they are the factors of the life-continuum, and they are the factors of the access that is renewed.

original: ca vinā appanā hoti, saha nimittuppādeneva appanaṃ pāpetī”ti vadanti, taṃ tesaṃ matimattaṃ.🔽Na hi parivāsitaparikammena appanāvāro icchito, nāpi mahaggatappamāṇajjhānesu viya
analyzed: ca vinā appanā hoti saha nimitta uppādena iva appanam pāpeti iti vadanti tam tesam matimattam  na hi parivāsita parikammena appanāvāraḥ icchitaḥ na api mahaggata ppamāṇa jhānesu viya
translated: They are only the access jhāna factors. And absorption comes about without the interval of the life-continuum and without the repetition of the access jhāna. He brings absorption to pass with the arising of the sign itself. ’ This is their opinion, but it is mere opinion.🔽For the absorption level is not intended here as it is in the case of the exalted jhānas,

original: upacārajjhāne ekantato paccavekkhaṇā icchitabbā, tasmā upacārajjhānādhigamanato paraṃ
analyzed: upacāra jhāne ekantataḥ paccavekkhaṇā icchitabbā tasmai upacāra jhāna adhigamanataḥ param
translated: nor is the reviewing of the sign intended here as it is in the case of the access jhāna. So after the attainment of the access jhāna,

original: katipayabhavaṅgacittāvasāne appanaṃ pāpuṇanto “saha nimittuppādenevettha appanaṃ
analyzed: katipaya bhavaṅga citta avasāne appanam pāpuṇantaḥ saha nimitta uppādena iva ittha appanam
translated: when he reaches absorption at the end of the life-continuum consciousnesses that intervene, it is said that he ‘brings absorption to pass with the arising of the sign itself. ’

original: pāpetī”ti vutto. Saha nimittuppādenevāti ca adhippāyikamidaṃ vacanaṃ, na nītatthaṃ,
analyzed: pāpā iti iti vuttaḥ saha nimitta uppādena iva ati ca adhippāyikam idam vacanam na nīta ttham
translated: And this statement is intended figuratively, not in the primary sense,

original: adhippāyo vuttanayeneva veditabbo, na antosamāpattiyaṃ tadā tathārūpassa ābhogassa
analyzed: adhippāyaḥ vutta nayena iva veditabbaḥ na antosamāpattiyam tadā tathārūpassa ābhogassa
translated: and the intention can be understood in the way already stated. And it is not possible for such an exercise of reviewing to be present in the absorption itself,

original: asambhavato. Samāpattito vuṭṭhitassa ābhogo pubbabhāgabhāvanāyavasena jhānakkhaṇe
analyzed: asambhavataḥ samāpattitaḥ vuṭṭhitassa ābhogaḥ pubbabhāga bhāvanāya vasena jhāna kkhaṇe
translated: because there is no reviewing in the way stated in the case of the jhāna at the moment of absorption.

original: pavattaṃ abhibhavanākāraṃ gahetvā pavattoti daṭṭhabbaṃ. Abhidhammaṭṭhakathāyaṃ pana
analyzed: pavattam abhibhavana ākāram gahetvā pavattaḥ ti daṭṭhabbam abhidhamma ṭṭhakathāyam pana
translated: It should be regarded as occurring by taking the mode of impulsion as object. But in the Abhidhamma Commentary🔽it is said: “This is the impulsion of the prior stage.”

original: “iminā tassa pubbābhogo kathito”ti vuttaṃ. Antosamāpattiyaṃ tathā ābhogābhāve kasmā
analyzed: iminā tassa pubba ābhogo kathito ti vuttam antosamāpattiyam tathā ābhoga abhāve kasmā
translated: Why is it said “in the same way” here, since there is no impulsion in the central process?

original: “jhānasaññāyapī”ti vuttanti āha “abhibhavana…pe… atthī”ti.
analyzed: jhāna saññāya api iti vuttanti āha abhibhavana pe atthi iti
translated: He said “because there is impulsion in the overcoming” in order to show that.

original: Vaḍḍhitappamāṇānīti vipulappamāṇānīti attho, na ekaṅguladvaṅgulādivasena vaḍḍhiṃ
analyzed: vaḍḍhita ppamāṇāni iti vipula ppamāṇāni iti atthaḥ na ekaṅgula dvaṅgula ādi vasena vaḍḍhim
translated: “The size is increased”: the meaning is that the size is extended. For there is no increase here in the sense of one or two inches, etc.,

original: pāpitānīti tathā vaḍḍhanassevettha asambhavato. Tenāha “mahantānī”ti. Bhattavaḍḍhitakanti
analyzed: pāpitāni iti tathā vaḍḍhanassa iva ittha asambhavataḥ tena āha mahantāni iti bhatta vaḍḍhitakam ti
translated: being added. That is why he said “large.”

original: bhuñjanabhājanaṃ vaḍḍhetvā dinnabhattaṃ, ekāsane purisena bhuñjitabbabhattato upaḍḍhabhattanti attho.
analyzed: bhuñjana bhājanam vaḍḍhetvā dinna bhattam eka āsane purisena bhuñjitabba bhattataḥ upaḍḍha bhattam ti atthaḥ
translated: “The food is increased”: the meaning is that the food is given after increasing the eating vessel, since it is the amount of food that one man can eat from one sitting.

original: Rūpe saññā rūpasaññā, sā assa atthīti rūpasaññī, na rūpasaññī arūpasaññī, saññāsīsena jhānaṃ vadati. Rūpasaññāya anuppādanaṃ evettha alābhitā.
analyzed: rūpe saññā rūpa saññā sā assa atthi iti rūpa saññī na rūpa saññī a rūpa saññī saññā sīsena jhānam vadati rūpa saññāya anuppādanam eva ittha alābhi tā
translated: Perception of form is perception of visible forms. He has that, thus he is “percipient of form” . He is “percipient of the formless” who is percipient of the formless jhāna. He is speaking of jhāna by way of perception. The non-arising of perception of form is the non-obtainment of it here.

original: Bahiddhāva uppannanti bahiddhā vatthusmiṃyeva uppannaṃ. Abhidhamme pana “ajjhattaṃ
analyzed: bahiddhā ava uppannanti bahiddhā vatthusmiṃ yeva uppannam abhidhamme pana ajjhattam
translated: Arisen externally: arisen only in an external object.

original: arūpasaññī bahiddhā rūpāni passati parittāni suvaṇṇadubbaṇṇāni…pe… appamāṇāni suvaṇṇadubbaṇṇānī”ti🔽evaṃ catunnaṃ abhibhāyatanānaṃ āgatattā abhidhammaṭṭhakathāyaṃ “kasmā pana ‘yathā
analyzed: arūpa saññī bahiddhā rūpāni passati parittāni suvaṇṇa dubbaṇṇāni pe appamāṇāni suvaṇṇa dubbaṇṇāni iti  evam catunnam āgata ttā abhidhamma ṭṭhakathā ayam kasmā pana yathā
translated: Arisen externally means arisen only in external objects. But in the Abhidhamma it is said thus: “One percipient of the mental body internally sees forms externally limited, beautiful and ugly … and so on as in § 11 up to … unlimited, beautiful and ugly” .

original: suttante ajjhattaṃ rūpasaññī eko bahiddhā rūpāni passati parittānītiādi vuttaṃ, evaṃ
analyzed: suttante ajjhattam rūpa saññī ekaḥ bahiddhā rūpāni passati parittāni itiādi vuttam evam
translated: This is said in the four bases for transcendence . Therefore in the Abhidhamma Commentary, after the question has been asked, “Why is it said in the sutta thus, ‘One percipient of the mental body internally sees forms externally limited, beautiful and ugly, and so on as in § 11 up to … unlimited, beautiful and ugly’ ,

original: avatvā idha catūsupi abhibhāyatanesu ajjhattaṃ arūpasaññitāva vuttā’ti codanaṃ katvā
analyzed: avatvā idha catūsu pi abhibhāyatanesu ajjhattam arūpa saññi tā ava vuttā ati codanam katvā
translated: and why is it said here in the four bases for transcendence only that one is percipient of the immaterial internally?” ,

original: ‘ajjhattarūpānaṃ anabhibhavanīyato’ti kāraṇaṃ vatvā, tattha vā hi idha vā bahiddhā
analyzed: kāraṇam vatvā tattha vā hi idha vā bahiddhā
translated: the answer is given: “Because of the non-transcendence of internal forms” .

original: rūpāneva abhibhavitabbāni, tasmā tāni niyamato vattabbānīti tatrāpi idhāpi vuttāni.
analyzed: rūpān eva abhibhavitabbāni tasmā tāni niyamataḥ vattabbāni iti tatra api idha api vuttāni
translated: And there it is said: “Either there or here forms are to be transcended externally. Therefore they must be stated as such. So they are stated there and here.

original: ‘Ajjhattaṃ rūpasaññī’ti idaṃ pana satthu desanāvilāsamattamevā”ti vuttaṃ. Ettha ca
analyzed: ajjhattam rūpa saññī iti idam pana satthu desanā vilāsa mattam evā ti vuttam ettha ca
translated: But this, ‘One percipient of the mental body internally,’ is only the Teacher’s manner of teaching” .🔽And here

original: vaṇṇābhogarahitāni, sahitāni ca sabbāni parittāni “parittāni suvaṇṇadubbaṇṇānī”ti
analyzed: vaṇṇa ābhoga rahitāni sahitāni ca sabbāni parittāni parittāni suvaṇṇa dubbaṇṇāni iti
translated: and all the small ones, which are without colour and nourishment, are together.🔽

original: vuttāni, tathā appamāṇāni “appamāṇāni suvaṇṇadubbaṇṇānī”ti. Atthi hi so pariyāyo🔽parittāni abhibhuyya tāni ce kadāci vaṇṇavasena ābhujitāni honti, suvaṇṇadubbaṇṇāni
analyzed: vuttāni tathā appamāṇāni appamāṇāni suvaṇṇa dubbaṇṇāni iti atthi hi so pariyāyo  parittāni abhibhuyya tāni ce kadāci vaṇṇa vasena ābhujitāni honti suvaṇṇa dubbaṇṇāni
translated: and all the limited ones, which are devoid of both colour and pleasurableness, and all the measureless ones, which are devoid of colour but have pleasurableness, are called “limited and measureless, beautiful and ugly” respectively.🔽For there is a method of exposition

original: abhibhuyyāti. Pariyāyakathā hi suttantadesanāti. Abhidhamme pana nippariyāyadesanattā
analyzed: abhibhuyya ati pariyāya kathā hi suttanta desanā ati abhidhamme pana nippariyāya desana ttā
translated: in the Suttas according to which the limited are called “beautiful” and the measureless “ugly” when they are respectively dominated by the beautiful and the ugly.🔽But in the Abhidhamma the exposition is not according to the method of domination,

original: vaṇṇābhogarahitāni visuṃ vuttāni, tathā sahitāni. Atthi hi ubhayattha abhibhavanavisesoti.🔽Tathā idha pariyāyadesanattā vimokkhānampi abhibhavanapariyāyo atthīti “ajjhattaṃ🔽rūpasaññī”tiādinā paṭhamadutiyaabhibhāyatanesu paṭhamavimokkho, tatiyacatutthaabhibhāyatanesu
analyzed: vaṇṇa ābhoga rahitāni visum vuttāni tathā sahitāni atthi hi ubhayattha abhibhavana viseso ti  tathā idha pariyāya desana ttā vimokkhānam pi abhibhavana pariyāyaḥ atthi iti ajjhattam  rūpa saññī iti ādinā paṭhama dutiya abhibha āyatanesu paṭhama vimokkho tatiya catuttha abhibha āyatanesu
translated: so they are stated separately as devoid of both colour and pleasurableness, and also as having pleasurableness but devoid of colour. For there is a difference in the domination in both cases.🔽And likewise here, since the exposition is according to the method of domination, there is a method of exposition according to which the first jhāna is included in the first emancipation, the second jhāna in the second, and the third and fourth jhānas in the third emancipation,

original: dutiyavimokkho, vaṇṇābhibhāyatanesu tatiyavimokkho ca abhibhavanappavattito saṅgahito.
analyzed: dutiya vimokkhaḥ vaṇṇa abhibhā āyatanesu tatiya vimokkho ca abhibhavana ppavattitaḥ saṅgahito
translated: because they occur in the domination of perception of matter.

original: Abhidhamme pana nippariyāyadesanattā vimokkhābhibhāyatanāni asaṅkarato dassetuṃ vimokkhe
analyzed: abhidhamme pana nippariyāya desana ttā vimokkha abhibhā āyatanāni asaṅkarataḥ dassetum vimokkhe
translated: But in the Abhidhamma the bases of mastery are stated without confusion, omitting the liberations, in order to show them in the ultimate sense.

original: vajjetvā abhibhāyatanāni kathitāni; sabbāni ca vimokkhakiccāni jhānāni vimokkhadesanāyaṃ
analyzed: vajjetvā abhibhā āyatanāni kathitāni sabbāni ca vimokkha kiccāni jhānāni vimokkha desanā ayam
translated: And all the jhānas that have the function of liberations are stated in the description of the liberations.

original: vuttāni. Tadetaṃ “ajjhattaṃ rūpasaññī”ti āgatassa abhibhāyatanadvayassa abhidhamme
analyzed: vuttāni tat etam ajjhattam rūpa saññī iti āgatassa abhibha āyatana dvayassa abhidhamme
translated: This is evident from the fact that the two bases of mastery stated in the way beginning, “One percipient of form internally sees forms externally” are not stated in the Abhidhamma,

original: abhibhāyatanesu avacanato “rūpī rūpāni passatī”tiādīnañca sabbavimokkhakiccasādhāraṇavacanabhāvato🔽vavatthānaṃ katanti viññāyati. “Ajjhattarūpānaṃ anabhibhavanīyato”ti idaṃ katthacipi
analyzed: abhi bhā āyatanesu avacanato rūpī rūpāni passati iti ādīnam ca sabba vimokkha kicca sādhāraṇa vacana bhāvato  vavatthānam katanti viññāyati ajjhatta rūpānam an abhibhavanīya to ti idam katthacipi
translated: and from the fact that the words “percipient of form sees forms” and so on are common to all those that have the function of liberations.

original: “ajjhattaṃ rūpāni passatī”ti avatvā sabbattha yaṃ vuttaṃ “bahiddhā rūpāni passatī”ti,
analyzed: ajjhattam rūpāni passati iti avatvā sabbattha yat vuttam bahiddhā rūpāni passati iti
translated: “Because of the non-mastery of internal forms” is said in all instances where the words “seeing forms internally” are not used,🔽in order to explain the reason for the words “seeing forms externally” that are used instead.

original: tassa kāraṇavacanaṃ, tena yaṃ aññahetukaṃ, taṃ tena hetunā vuttaṃ. Yaṃ pana desanāvilāsahetukaṃ
analyzed: tassa kāraṇa vacanam tena yam añña hetukam tam tena hetunā vuttam yam pana desanā vilāsa hetukam
translated: So what is due to another reason is stated by that reason. But what is due to the skill in teaching is stated by the skill in teaching.

original: ajjhattaṃ arūpasaññitāya eva abhidhamme vacanaṃ, na tassa aññaṃ kāraṇaṃ maggitabbanti
analyzed: ajjhattam arūpa saññitāya eva abhidhamme vacanam na tassa aññam kāraṇam maggitabbanti
translated: The words in the Abhidhamma are only to show that the internal is not overwhelmed by the external, and there is no other reason to be sought.

original: dasseti. Ajjhattarūpānaṃ anabhibhavanīyatā ca tesaṃ bahiddhā rūpānaṃ viya abhūtattā.
analyzed: dassa iti ajjhatta rūpānam an abhibhavanīya tā ca tesam bahiddhā rūpānam viya a bhūta ttā
translated: And the reason why the internal is not overwhelmed is that it is not as the external is.

original: Desanāvilāso ca yathāvuttavavatthānavasena veditabbo veneyyajjhāsayavasena vijjamānapariyāyakathābhāvato.
analyzed: desanā vilāsaḥ ca yathā vutta vavatthāna vasena veditabbaḥ veneyya jhāsaya vasena vijjamāna pariyāya kathā bhāvato
translated: And the radiance of the teaching should be understood as follows. It is not a matter of teaching by way of a method that exists in the scriptures, but rather by way of the inclination of the disciples.

original: “Suvaṇṇadubbaṇṇānī”ti eteneva siddhattā na nīlādi abhibhāyatanāni vattabbānīti ce?
analyzed: suvaṇṇa dubbaṇṇāni iti etena iva siddha ttā na nīla ādi abhibhāyatanāni vattabbāni iti ce
translated: If it be said: “Since the words ‘beautiful and ugly’ are enough, the spheres of mastery beginning with the blue should not be mentioned.”

original: Taṃ na, nīlādīsu katādhikārānaṃ nīlādibhāvasseva abhibhavanakāraṇattā. Na hi tesaṃ
analyzed: tam na nīla ādīsu kata adhikārānam nīla ādi bhāvassa iva abhibhavana kāraṇa ttā na hi tesam
translated: That is not so, because the cause of the overwhelming is only the state of blue, etc., for those who have had practice in blue, etc. For the cause of the overwhelming is not

original: parisuddhāparisuddhavaṇṇānaṃ parittatā, appamāṇatā vā abhibhavanakāraṇaṃ, atha kho
analyzed: parisuddha aparisuddha vaṇṇānam paritta tā appamāṇa tā vā abhibhavana kāraṇam atha kho
translated: the purity or impurity of the colour, nor its limitedness or illimitability, but rather

original: nīlādibhāvo evāti. Etesu ca parittādikasiṇarūpesu yaṃ yaṃ caritassa imāni abhibhāyatanāni
analyzed: nīla ādi bhāvaḥ eva ati etesu ca paritta ādi kasiṇa rūpesu yam yam caritassa imāni
translated: the state of blue, etc. And of these kasiṇa materialities beginning with the limited one, whichever spheres of mastery are suitable

original: ijjhanti, taṃ dassetuṃ “imesu panā”tiādi vuttaṃ.
analyzed: ijjhanti tam dassetum imesu pana atiādi vuttam
translated: for a temperament are indicated by the words “In these, etc.”

original: Sabbasaṅgāhakavasenāti sakalanīlavaṇṇanīlanidassananīlanibhāsānaṃ sādhāraṇavasena.🔽Vaṇṇavasenāti sabhāvavaṇṇavasena. Nidassanavasenāti passitabbatāvasena cakkhuviññāṇādiviññāṇavīthiyā
analyzed: sabba saṅgāhaka vasena ati sakala nīla vaṇṇa nīla nidassana nīla nibhāsānam sādhāraṇa vasena  vaṇṇa vasena ati sabhāva vaṇṇa vasena nidassana vasena ati passitabba tā vasena cakkhu viññāṇa ādi viññāṇa vīthiyā
translated: By way of all-embracing: by way of the common characteristic of all that is blue in colour, blue in appearance, and blue in hue.🔽By way of colour: by way of the individual essence of the colour. By way of appearance: by way of visibility, by way of being apprehensible by the eye-consciousness and the consciousness of the cognitive series.

original: gahetabbatāvasena. Obhāsavasenāti sappabhāsatāya avabhāsanavasena. Umāpupphanti atasipupphaṃ.
analyzed: gahetabba tā vasena obhāsa vasena ati sa pabhāsa tāya avabhāsana vasena umāpupphanti atasi puppham
translated: By way of radiance: by way of illumination by means of luminosity. The umā flower is the atasī flower.

original: Nīlameva hoti vaṇṇasaṅkarābhāvato. Bārāṇasisambhavanti bārāṇasiyaṃ samuṭṭhitaṃ.
analyzed: nīlam eva hoti vaṇṇa saṅkara abhāvataḥ bārāṇasi sambhavanti bārāṇasiyam samuṭṭhitam
translated: It is only blue, because there is no mixture of colours. The one from Bārāṇasī: the one that originated in Bārāṇasī.

original: Ekaccassa ito bāhirakassa appamāṇaṃ ativitthāritaṃ kasiṇanimittaṃ olokentassa bhayaṃ
analyzed: ekaccassa itas bāhirakassa appamāṇam ati vitthāritam kasiṇa nimittam olokentassa bhayaṃ
translated: When one who is not a Tathāgata looks at the kasiṇa sign, which is measureless and extended to infinity, fear may arise in him,

original: uppajjeyya “kiṃ nu kho idaṃ sakalaṃ lokaṃ abhibhavitvā ajjhottharitvā gaṇhātī”ti,
analyzed: uppajjeyya kim nu kho idam sakalam lokam abhibhavitvā ajjhottharitvā gaṇhāti iti
translated: thinking: “What is this that has taken possession of the whole world and is overwhelming it?”

original: tathāgatassa pana tādisaṃ bhayaṃ vā sārajjaṃ vā natthīti abhītabhāvadassanatthameva ānītāni.🔽Aṭṭhavimokkhavaṇṇanā
analyzed: tathāgatassa pana tādisam bhayam vā sārajjam vā natthi iti abhīta bhāva dassana tham eva ānītāni 🔽aṭṭha vimokkha vaṇṇanā
translated: But the Tathāgata has no such fear or timidity. The kasiṇa signs were brought in only to show that he is fearless.

original: 174. Uttānatthāyeva heṭṭhā atthato vibhattattā. Ekaccassa vimokkhoti ghosopi bhayāvaho
analyzed: uttāna atthāya iva heṭṭhā atthataḥ vibhatta ttā ekaccassa vimokkhaḥ ti ghosaḥ api bhaya āvahaḥ
translated: The meaning is stated in the first line, and so it is not stated in the second line. “Some people’s deliverance” is deliverance that is fearful because of the fear of Mara.

original: vaṭṭābhiratabhāvato, tathāgatassa pana vimokkhe upasampajja viharatopi taṃ natthīti
analyzed: vaṭṭa abhirata bhāvato tathāgatassa pana vimokkhe upasampajja viharataḥ pi tam natthi iti
translated: But the Tathagata’s deliverance is not like that, even when he enters and abides in it.

original: abhītabhāvadassanatthameva ānītāni.
analyzed: abhīta bhāva dassana ttham eva ānītāni
translated: Therefore it is brought in here to show that he is fearless.

original: Ānandayācanakathāvaṇṇanā
analyzed: ānanda yācana kathā vaṇṇanā
translated: The story of Ananda’s request🔽“Enlightenment” is the knowledge of omniscience. For that is called “the penetration of the knowledge of the four paths” .

original: 178. Bodhīti sabbaññutaññāṇaṃ. Tañhi “catumaggañāṇapaṭivedha”ntveva vuttaṃ sabbaññutaññāṇappaṭivedhassa
analyzed: bodhi iti sabbaññu taññāṇam tat hi catu magga ñāṇa paṭivedha tu eva vuttam sabbaññu taññāṇa ppaṭivedhassa
translated: The penetration of the knowledge of omniscience is based on that.

original: taṃmūlakattā. Evaṃ vuttabhāvanti “ākaṅkhamāno ānanda tathāgato kappaṃ vā tiṭṭheyyā”ti evaṃ vuttabhāvaṃ.
analyzed: tad mūlaka ttā evam vutta bhāvanti ākaṅkhamānaḥ ānanda tathāgato kappam vā tiṭṭheyya ati evam vutta bhāvam
translated: “The state of being thus described” is the state of being described thus: “If he so wished, Ananda, the Tathagata could remain living for a kappa or for what was left of the kappa” .

original: 179. Tampi oḷārikanimittaṃ kataṃ tassa mārena pariyuṭṭhitacetaso na paṭividdhaṃ na sallakkhitaṃ.
analyzed: tat pi oḷārika nimittam katam tassa mārena pariyuṭṭhita cetasaḥ na paṭividdham na sallakkhitam
translated: That gross object was made by Mara, but it was not penetrated or discerned by him, whose mind was obsessed by Mara.🔽“By friends, etc.,” etc.

original: 183. Ādikehīti evamādīhi mittāmaccasuhajjāhi. Piyāyitabbato piyehi. Manavaḍḍhanato
analyzed: ādikehi iti evamādīhi mitta amacca suhajjāhi piyāyitabbataḥ piyehi mana vaḍḍhanataḥ
translated: “By the dear” : because of being dear. “By the agreeable” : because of increasing the mind.

original: manāpehi. Jātiyāti jātianurūpagamanena. Nānābhāvo visuṃbhāvo asambaddhabhāvo. Maraṇena
analyzed: manāpehi jāti yāti jāti anurūpa gamanena nānābhāvaḥ visuṃbhāvaḥ asambaddha bhāvaḥ maraṇena
translated: “By birth” : by going according to birth. “Separation” : being separate, being unconnected. “By death” :

original: vinābhāvoti cutiyā tenattabhāvena apunarāvattanato vippayogo. Bhavena aññathābhāvoti
analyzed: vinābhāvaḥ ti cutiyā tenatta bhāvena a punarāvattanataḥ vippayogaḥ bhavena aññathābhāvaḥ ti
translated: ‘Disappearance’ is the disjoining of the death-state from that individual existence by its not occurring again. ‘Alteration of what is due to kamma’ is the alteration of the kamma-originated materiality, etc.,

original: bhavantaraggahaṇena purimākārato aññākāratā “kāmāvacarasatto rūpāvacaro hotī”tiādinā,🔽tatthāpi “manusso devo hotī”tiādināpi yojetabbo. Kutettha labbhāti kuto kuhiṃ kismiṃ
analyzed: bhavantara ggahaṇena purima ākārataḥ añña ākāra tā kāmāvacara satto rūpāvacaraḥ hoti itiādinā  tattha api manusso devaḥ hoti iti ādinā api yojetabbo kuta ittha labbhāti kutas kuhim kismin
translated: ‘Non-existence’ is the disjunction of the death of that being from that individual essence by non-recurrence. ‘Alterity through becoming’ is the alteration of the former mode by the taking up of another becoming, as when a being of the sense sphere becomes one of the form sphere,

original: nāma ṭhāne ettha etasmiṃ khandhappavatte “yaṃ taṃ jātaṃ…pe… mā palujjī”ti laddhuṃ
analyzed: nāma ṭhāne ettha etasmin khandha ppavatte yam tam jātaṃpe mā palujji iti laddhum
translated: and so on. And in the case of the latter, it can be illustrated as when a human becomes a god, and so on. ‘Where is it found?’ is ‘Where, how, in what place, in this occurrence of aggregates, is it possible to find that which is born … let it not perish?’

original: sakkā. Na sakkā eva tādisassa kāraṇassa abhāvatoti āha “netaṃ ṭhānaṃ vijjatī”ti.
analyzed: sakkā na sakkā eva tādisassa kāraṇassa abhāvato ti āha na etam ṭhānam vijjati iti
translated: It is not possible, because there is no such cause. That is why he said ‘This is impossible.’

original: Evaṃ acchariyabbhutadhammaṃ tathāgatassāpi sarīraṃ, kimaṅgaṃ pana aññesanti adhippāyo.
analyzed: evam acchariya bhuta dhammam tathāgatassa api sarīram kimaṅgam pana aññesanti adhippāyo
translated: The meaning is that if the body of the Tathāgata, which has such wonderful and marvellous qualities, is subject to destruction, how much more so are other beings.

original: “Paccāvamissatī”ti netaṃ ṭhānaṃ vijjati satiṃ sūpaṭṭhitaṃ katvā ñāṇena paricchinditvā
analyzed: paccāvamissati iti na etam ṭhānam vijjati satim su upaṭṭhitam katvā ñāṇena paricchinditvā
translated: ‘It is impossible that he should be forgotten’ because he has established mindfulness well and discerned it with knowledge.

original: āyusaṅkhārānaṃ ossaṭṭhattā, buddhakiccassa ca pariyosāpitattā. Na hettha māsattayato
analyzed: āyu saṅkhārānaṃ ossaṭṭha ttā buddha kiccassa ca pariyosāpita ttā na ha ittha māsattayato
translated: Because his life-continuum has been interrupted and because he has completed his task as a Buddha. For it is not possible for him to remain🔽for more than three months.

original: paraṃ buddhaveneyyā labbhantīti.🔽184. Sāsanassa ciraṭṭhiti nāma sasambhārehi ariyamaggadhammehi kevalehīti āha “sabbaṃ
analyzed: param buddha veneyyāḥ labbhanti iti  sāsanassa ciraṭṭhiti nāma sa sambhārehi ariya magga dhammehi kevalehi iti āha sabbam
translated: and the disciples to be trained by the Buddha are available.🔽and the duration of the Dispensation is due to the noble path dhammas that are its requisites.

original: lokiyalokuttaravaseneva kathita”nti lokiyāhi sīlasamādhipaññāhi vinā lokuttaradhammasamadhigamassa asambhavato.
analyzed: lokiya lokuttara vasena iva kathitam ti lokiyāhi sīla samādhi paññāhi vinā lokuttara dhamma samadhigamassa asambhavato
translated: It is said that the whole of the Dispensation is taught by way of the mundane and supramundane.

original: Tatiyabhāṇavāravaṇṇanā niṭṭhitā.
analyzed: tatiya bhāṇa vāra vaṇṇanā niṭṭhitā
translated: The commentary on the third recitation section is finished.

original: Nāgāpalokitavaṇṇanā
analyzed: nāgāpalokita vaṇṇanā
translated: The explanation of the looking back like an elephant

original: 186. Nāgāpalokitanti nāgassa viya apalokitaṃ, hatthināgassa apalokanasadisaṃ apalokananti
analyzed: nāga apalokitanti nāgassa viya apalokitam hatthi nāgassa apalokana sadisam apalokananti
translated: Looking back like an elephant: looking back like an elephant, looking back like a royal tusker.

original: attho. Āhaccāti phusitvā. Aṅkusakalaggāni viyāti aṅkusakāni viya aññamaññasmiṃ laggāni
analyzed: attho āhacca ati phusitvā aṅkusaka laggāni viya ati aṅkusakāni viya aññam aññasmin laggāni
translated: The meaning is: looking back.🔽It is said: “Having touched, having stuck together like goads.”

original: āsattāni hutvā ṭhitāni. Ekābaddhānīti aññamaññaṃ ekato ābaddhāni. Tasmāti gīvaṭṭhīnaṃ
analyzed: āsattāni hutvā ṭhitāni eka ābaddhāni iti aññam aññam ekatas ābaddhāni tasmā iti gīvaṭṭhīnam
translated: They are stuck together, stuck to each other,🔽having become attached. They are bound together as one.

original: ekagghanānaṃ viya ekābaddhabhāvena, na kevalaṃ gīvaṭṭhīnaṃyeva, atha kho sabbānipi
analyzed: ekaggha nānam viya eka ābaddha bhāvena na kevalam atha kho sabbāni pi
translated: Thus, not only the neck bones, but all the bones

original: tāni buddhānaṃ ṭhapetvā bāhusandhiādikā dvādasa mahāsandhiyo, aṅgulisandhiyo ca itarasandhīsu
analyzed: tāni buddhānam ṭhapetvā bāhu sandhi ādikāḥ dvādasa mahā sandhiyaḥ ca itara sandhīsu
translated: Except for those of the Buddhas, the other great joints, such as the shoulder-joints, and the joints of the fingers and toes, are all connected together.

original: ekābaddhāni hutvā ṭhitāni, yato nesaṃ pakatihatthīnaṃ koṭisahassabalappamāṇaṃ kāyabalaṃ
analyzed: eka ābaddhāni hutvā ṭhitāni yatas na isam pakati hatthīnam koṭi sahassa bala ppamāṇam kāya balam
translated: For the natural elephants have a bodily strength equal to that of a koṭi of men.

original: hoti. Vesālinagarābhimukhaṃ akāsi kaṇṭakaparivattane viya kapilanagarābhimukhaṃ.
analyzed: hoti vesāli nagara abhimukham kāsi kaṇṭaka parivattane kapila nagara abhimukham
translated: He turned his face towards the city of Vesālī, as if he were turning the Kaṇṭaka mountain towards the city of Kapilavatthu.

original: Yadi evaṃ kathaṃ taṃ nāgāpalokitaṃ nāma jātaṃ? Tadajjhāsayaṃ upādāya. Bhagavā hi
analyzed: yadi evam katham tam nāgāpalokitam nāma jātam upādāya bhagavā hi
translated: If it was so, how did it come to be called the “Nāga-look”? It was so called because of his intention. The Blessed One

original: nāgāpalokitavaseneva apaloketukāmo jāto, puññānubhāvena panassa patiṭṭhitaṭṭhānaṃ
analyzed: nāga apalokita vasena iva apaloketu kāmo jātaḥ puñña anubhāvena panassa patiṭṭhita ṭṭhānam
translated: wished to look at Vesālī by means of the “Nāga-look.” But by the power of his merit the place where he stood turned round.

original: parivatti, tena taṃ “nāgāpalokitaṃ” tveva vuccati.🔽“Idaṃ pacchimakaṃ ānanda tathāgatassa vesāliyā dassana”nti nayidaṃ vesāliyā apalokanassa
analyzed: tena tam nāga apalokitam tu eva vuccati  idam pacchimakam ānanda tathāgatassa vesāliyāḥ dassanan ti na idam vesāliyāḥ apalokanassa
translated: Therefore it is called the “Nāga-look.”

original: kāraṇavacanaṃ anekantikattā, bhūtakathanamattaṃ panetaṃ. Maggasodhanavasena taṃ dassetvā
analyzed: kāraṇa vacanam anekantika ttā bhūta kathana mattam pana itam magga sodhana vasena tam dassetvā
translated: “This, Ānanda, is the last time that the Tathāgata will look at Vesālī” — this is not a statement of the reason for looking at Vesālī. It is merely a statement of fact, for the purpose of purifying the path. Having shown it by means of the “Nāga-look,”

original: aññadevettha apalokanakāraṇaṃ dassetukāmo “nanu cā”tiādimāha. Taṃ taṃ sabbaṃ pacchimadassanameva🔽anukkamena kusināraṃ gantvā parinibbātukāmatāya tato tato nikkhantattā. “Anacchariyattā”ti
analyzed: aññat evā ittha apalokana kāraṇam dassetu kāmaḥ nanu ca ati ādim āha tam tam sabbam pacchima dassanam eva  anukkamena kusināram gantvā parinibbātu kāma tāya tatas tatas nikkhanta ttā an acchariya ttā ati
translated: Desiring to show the reason for looking back, he says, “But did not the Exalted One look back?” All that is just a later view.🔽The reason for looking back is the fact that, after going to Kusinārā in due course, he looked back from there, there being no other reason for looking back.

original: iminā yathāvuttaṃ anekantikattaṃ pariharati, tayidaṃ sodhanamattaṃ. Idaṃ panettha
analyzed: iminā yathāvuttam anekantika ttam pariharati tayā idam idam pana ittha
translated: By the words “because it is not extraordinary” he avoids the fallacy of over-extension of the reason. This is merely a refutation.

original: aviparītaṃ kāraṇanti dassetuṃ “apicā”tiādi vuttaṃ. Na hi bhagavā sāpekkho vesāliṃ🔽apalokesi, “idaṃ pana me gamanaṃ apunarāgamana”nti dassanamukhena bahujanahitāya
analyzed: aviparītam kāraṇanti dassetum api ca itiādi vuttam na hi bhagavā sa apekkhaḥ vesālim  apalokesi idam pana me gamanam apunarāgamanam ti dassana mukhena bahu jana hitāya
translated: But in order to show the correct reason here, he says, “Moreover, the Exalted One did not look back with expectation.”

original: bahujanasukhāya lokānukampāya apalokesi. Tenāha “apica vesālirājāno”tiādi.
analyzed: bahu jana sukhāya loka anukampāya tena āha apica vesāli rājānaḥ tiādi
translated: The Exalted One did not look back with expectation, thinking, “This is my last journey, I will not return.” He looked back with compassion for the world, for the benefit and happiness of the multitude. Therefore he says, “Moreover, the kings of Vesālī.”

original: Antakaroti sakalavaṭṭadukkhassa sakasantāne, parasantāne ca vināsakaro abhāvakaro.
analyzed: anta karoti sakala vaṭṭa dukkhassa saka santāne para santāne ca vināsa karo abhāva karo
translated: “Destroyer”: he who destroys and makes non-existent all suffering in his own and others’ continua, in the entire round of existence.

original: Buddhacakkhudhammacakkhudibbacakkhumaṃsacakkhusamantacakkhusaṅkhātehi pañcahi cakkhūhi
analyzed: buddha cakkhu dhamma cakkhu dibba cakkhu maṃsa cakkhu samanta cakkhu saṅkhātehi pañcahi cakkhūhi
translated: With the five eyes, which are the Buddha-eye, the Dhamma-eye, the divine-eye, the fleshly-eye, and the universal eye.

original: cakkhumā. Savāsanānaṃ kilesānaṃ samucchinnattā sātisayaṃ kilesaparinibbānena parinibbuto.
analyzed: cakkhumā sa vāsanānam kilesānam samucchinna ttā sa atisayam kilesa parinibbānena parinibbutaḥ
translated: He is the one with eyes, because he has destroyed the defilements together with their residues by means of the supreme destruction of defilements.

original: Catumahāpadesavaṇṇanā
analyzed: catu mahā padesa vaṇṇanā
translated: The four great authorities

original: 187. Mahāokāseti mahante okāse. Mahantāni dhammassa patiṭṭhāpanaṭṭhānāni. Yesu patiṭṭhāpito
analyzed: mahā okāse ti mahante okāse mahantāni dhammassa patiṭṭhāpana ṭṭhānāni yesu patiṭṭhāpitaḥ
translated: In a great place: in a great situation, in great situations for establishing the True Idea. In which,

original: dhammo nicchīyati asandehato, kāni pana tāni? Āgamanavisiṭṭhāni suttotaraṇādīni.
analyzed: dhammaḥ nicchīyati asandehato kāni pana tāni āgamana visiṭṭhāni sutta utaraṇa ādīni
translated: when the True Idea is established, it is settled without doubt. But what are they? They are the coming, the pre- eminence, the entering upon the course, and so on.

original: Dutiyavikappe apadisantīti apadesā, “sammukhā metaṃ āvuso bhagavato suta”ntiādinā
analyzed: dutiya vikappe apadisanti iti apadesā sammukhā mā etam āvuso bhagavataḥ su tanti ādinā
translated: In the second analysis, apadisantī = apadesā. “This has been heard by me face to face, friends” ,

original: kenaci ābhatassa “dhammo”ti vinicchinane kāraṇaṃ. Kiṃ pana tanti? Tassa yathābhatassa
analyzed: kenaci ābhatassa dhammoti vinicchinane kāraṇam kim pana tanti tassa yathā ābhatassa
translated: is the reason for the decision that “this is the True Idea” when something is brought by someone. But what is that?

original: suttotaraṇādi eva. Yadi evaṃ kathaṃ cattāroti? Yasmā dhammassa dve samparāyā satthā,
analyzed: eva yadi evam katham cattāro ti yasmā dhammassa dve samparāyā satthā
translated: It is only the entering upon the course, and so on, of that which is brought as it is. If that is so, then how four? Because there are two successions of the True Idea, namely🔽the Master and the disciples. And among the disciples there are three kinds according to whether they are a Community, a group, or an individual. So it is said: “What has been

original: sāvakā ca, tesu ca sāvakā saṅghagaṇapuggalavasena tividhā, evaṃ “tumhākaṃ mayā yaṃ
analyzed: sāvakā ca tesu ca sāvakā saṅgha gaṇa puggala vasena tividhāḥ evam tumhākam mayā yaṃ
translated: brought by you to me

original: dhammo paṭiggahito”ti apadisitabbānaṃ bhedena cattāro. Tenāha “sammukhā me taṃ āvuso
analyzed: dhammaḥ paṭiggahito ti a padisitabbānam bhedena cattāro tena āha sammukhā me tam āvuso
translated: “I have heard that from the Blessed One himself, friends,🔽in such and such a place, in such and such a region,” etc.

original: bhagavato suta”ntiādi. Tathā ca vuttaṃ nettiyaṃ “cattāro mahāpadesā buddhāpadeso
analyzed: bhagavato suta nti ādi tathā ca vuttam nettiyam cattāro mahāpadesāḥ buddhāpadeso
translated: And it is said in the Netti: “There are four great authorities: the authority of the Enlightened One,🔽the authority of the Dhamma, the authority of the Saṅgha, and the authority of a learned and competent person.

original: saṅghāpadeso sambahulattherāpadeso ekattherāpadeso. Ime cattāro mahāpadesā”ti buddho
analyzed: saṅgha apadeso sambahula therāpadeso eka therāpadeso ime cattāro mahā padesā ati buddhaḥ
translated: These are the four great authorities.”🔽The authority of the Enlightened One is that which has the Enlightened One as its authority. So too with the rest.

original: apadeso etassāti buddhāpadeso. Esa nayo sesesupi. Tenāha “buddhādayo…pe… mahākāraṇānī”ti.
analyzed: apadesaḥ etassa ati buddha apadesaḥ esa nayo sesesu pi tena āha mahā kāraṇāni iti
translated: Hence it is said: “The Enlightened One, etc., are the great reasons” .🔽Nor should one rejoice in it: one should not assent to it.

original: 188. Neva abhinanditabbanti na sampaṭicchitabbaṃ. Ganthassa sampaṭicchanaṃ nāma savananti
analyzed: na iva abhinanditabbanti na sampaṭicchitabbam ganthassa sampaṭicchanam nāma savananti
translated: Assent to a text is hearing it.🔽Hence it is said: “It should not be listened to.”

original: āha “na sotabba”nti. Padabyañjanānīti padāni ca byañjanāni ca, atthapadāni, byañjanapadāni
analyzed: āha na sotabbanti pada byañjanāni iti padāni ca byañjanāni ca attha padāni byañjana padāni
translated: The syllables and the words: the syllables and the words, the words for the meaning, and the words for the phrasing.

original: cāti attho. Pajjati attho etehīti padāni, akkharādīni byañjanapadāni. Pajjitabbato
analyzed: ca ati attho pajjati attho etehi iti padāni akkhara ādīni byañjana padāni pajjitabbataḥ
translated: The meaning is expressed by these, thus they are words ; the letters, etc., are words for syllables.🔽They are words because the meaning is expressed by them.🔽The words for the meaning are the words for the prompting, etc.

original: padāni, saṅkāsanādīni atthapadāni. Aṭṭhakathāyaṃpana “‘padasaṅkhātāni byañjanānī’ti
analyzed: padāni saṅkāsana ādīni attha padāni pada saṅkhātāni byañjanāni iti
translated: In the commentary too it is said: “The syllables called ‘words’ ” .

original: byañjanapadāneva vuttānī”ti keci, taṃ na, atthaṃ byañjentīti byañjanāni, byañjanapadāni,🔽tehi byañjitabbato byañjanāni, atthapadānīti ubhayasaṅgahato. Imasmiṃ ṭhāneti tenābhatasuttassa🔽imasmiṃ padese. Pāḷi vuttāti kevalo pāḷidhammo pavatto. Attho vuttoti pāḷiyā attho🔽pavatto niddiṭṭho. Anusandhi kathitoti yathāraddhadesanāya, upari desanāya ca anusandhānaṃ
analyzed: byañjana padāni iva vuttāni iti keci tam na attham byañjenti iti byañjanāni byañjana padāni  tehi byañjitabbataḥ byañjanāni attha padāni iti ubhaya saṅgahataḥ imasmim ṭhāne iti tena ābhata suttassa  imasmin padese pāḷi vuttā ati kevalo pāḷi dhammo pavattaḥ atthaḥ vuttaḥ ti pāḷiyā attho  pavattaḥ niddiṭṭhaḥ anusandhi kathito ti yathā āraddha desanāya upari desanāya ca anusandhānam
translated: Some say that only the words are stated. But that is not so. For the words are called “distinctions” because they distinguish the meaning, and they are “word-states” because they are states consisting of words.🔽And they are “distinctions” because the meaning is distinguished by them, and they are “meaning-states” because the meaning is stated by them. So they are included in both.🔽In this context: in this place in the Ten Abbreviated Statements Discourse.🔽The words are stated: only the words as dhammas occur. The meaning is stated: the meaning of the words🔽occurs, is demonstrated. The connection is stated: the connection between the teaching as given and the teaching above is stated.

original: kathitaṃ sambandho kathito. Pubbāparaṃ kathitanti pubbenāparaṃ avirujjhanañceva visesādhānañca🔽kathitaṃ pakāsitaṃ. Evaṃ pāḷidhammādīni sammadeva sallakkhetvā gahaṇaṃ sādhukaṃ uggahaṇanti🔽āha “suṭṭhu gahetvā”ti. Sutte otāretabbānīti ñāṇena sutte ogāhetvā tāretabbāni, taṃ
analyzed: kathitam sambandhaḥ kathitaḥ pubba aparam kathitanti pubbena aparam a virujjhanam ca iva visesa ādhānam ca 🔽kathitam pakāsitam evam pāḷi dhamma ādīni sammat eva sallakkhetvā gahaṇam sādhukam uggahaṇanti 🔽āha suṭṭhu gahetvā iti sutte otāretabbāni iti ñāṇena sutte ogāhetvā tāretabbāni taṃ
translated: Some say that the words are only the syllables, but that is not so. For the words are the syllables because they distinguish the meaning, and the words are the syllables because they are what is distinguished by the syllables. And the words are the sentences because they are what is distinguished by the sentences, and the sentences are the words because they are what distinguishes the words. Thus they are included in both ways. In this place: in this part of the sutta. The words are stated: the mere words of the teaching are stated. The meaning is stated: the meaning of the words is stated. The connection is stated: the connection between the teaching as given and the teaching that follows is stated. The sequence is stated: the non-contradiction of the earlier and the later and the establishment of the distinction between them are stated. Thus the proper investigation of the words of the teaching, etc., and the grasping of them is the proper learning. Therefore it is said: “having learned them well.” They should be brought into the sutta: they should be brought into the sutta by means of knowledge.

original: pana ogāhetvā taraṇaṃ tattha otaraṇaṃ anuppavesanaṃ hotīti vuttaṃ “sutte otāretabbānī”ti.
analyzed: pana ogāhetvā taraṇam tattha otaraṇam anuppavesanam hoti iti vuttam sutte otāretabbāni iti
translated: But the meaning of the passage is that the questions should be brought down into the Suttas and the doubts should be resolved in the Vinaya.

original: Saṃsandetvā dassanaṃ sandassananti āha “vinaye saṃsandetabbānī”ti.
analyzed: saṃsandetvā dassanam sandassananti āha vinaye saṃsandetabbāni iti
translated: “In the Vinaya” means in the Khandhaka texts.🔽But what is the Sutta? What is the Vinaya?

original: Kiṃ pana taṃ suttaṃ, ko vā vinayoti vicāraṇāya ācariyānaṃ matibhedamukhena tamatthaṃ🔽dassetuṃ “ettha cā”tiādi vuttaṃ. Vinayoti vibhaṅgapāṭhamāha. So hi mātikāsaññitassa
analyzed: kim pana tam suttam kaḥ vā vinayo ti vicāraṇāya mati bheda mukhena tam attham  dassetum ettha ca atiādi vuttam vinayaḥ iti vibhaṅga pāṭham āha saḥ hi mātikā saññitassa
translated: In order to show the meaning of this question by means of the difference of opinion among the teachers,🔽“And here” is said. “Vinaya” refers to the text of the Vibhanga. For that is worthy to be called “Sutta” because it indicates the meaning of the “Mātikā” .

original: suttassa atthasūcanato “sutta”nti vattabbataṃ arahati. Vividhanayattā, visiṭṭhanayattā🔽ca vinayo, khandhakapāṭho. Evanti evaṃ suttavinayesu pariggayhamānesu vinayapiṭakampi
analyzed: suttassa attha sūcanataḥ sutta nti vattabba tam arahati vividha naya tā visiṭṭha naya tā  ca vinayaḥ khandhaka pāṭhaḥ evam ti evam sutta vinayesu pariggayhamānesu vinaya piṭakam pi
translated: The Vinaya is “Vinaya” because of the various methods and the special methods .🔽The Khandhaka text is also “Vinaya” . Thus, when the Sutta and the Vinaya are being defined in this way, the Vinaya Piṭaka is not included because it is not included in the Parivāra text.

original: na pariyādīyati parivārapāḷiyā asaṅgahitattā. Suttantābhidhammapiṭakāni vā suttaṃ
analyzed: na pariyādīyati parivāra pāḷiyāḥ a saṅgahita ttā suttanta abhidhamma piṭakāni vā suttam
translated: Or the Sutta and the Abhidhamma Piṭakas are the Sutta because of the possibility of the meaning being indicated by the meaning .

original: atthasūcanādiatthasambhavato. Evampīti “suttantābhidhammapiṭakāni suttaṃ, vinayapiṭakaṃ
analyzed: attha sūcana ādi attha sambhavataḥ evam pi iti suttanta abhidhamma piṭakāni suttam vinaya piṭakam
translated: Thus, the Sutta and the Abhidhamma Piṭakas are the Sutta and the Vinaya Piṭaka is the Vinaya.

original: vinayo”ti evaṃ suttavinayavibhāge vuccamānepi. Na tāva pariyādīyantīti na tāva anavasesato
analyzed: vinayo ti evam sutta vinaya vibhāge vuccamāne pi na tāva anavasesato
translated: they are not yet completed. They are not yet collected without remainder.

original: pariggayhanti, kasmāti āha “asuttanāmakañhī”tiādi. Yasmā “sutta”nti imaṃ nāmaṃ anāropetvā
analyzed: pariggayhanti kasmā iti āha asuttanāmakam hi itiādi yasmā imam nāmam an āropetvā
translated: Why? He says, “The Buddha-word without the name of Sutta, etc.” Because there is Buddha-word such as the Jātaka, etc., which was recited without being given the name of Sutta,

original: saṅgītampi jātakādibuddhavacanaṃ atthi, tasmā vuttanayena tīṇi piṭakāni na pariyādiṇṇānīti.
analyzed: saṅgītam pi jātaka ādi buddha vacanam atthi tasmā vutta nayena tīṇi piṭakāni na pariyādiṇṇāni iti
translated: therefore the three Piṭakas are not yet completed in the way stated.

original: Suttanipātaudānaitivuttakādīni dīghanikāyādayo viya suttanāmaṃ āropetvā asaṅgītānīti🔽adhippāye panettha jātakādīhi saddhiṃ tānipi gahitāni. Buddhavaṃsacariyāpiṭakānaṃ
analyzed: sutta nipāta audāna etivuttaka ādīni dīgha nikāya ādayaḥ sutta nāmam āropetvā a saṅgītāni iti  adhippāye pana ittha jātaka ādīhi saddhim tāni api gahitāni buddha vaṃsa cariyā piṭakānam
translated: The Suttanipāta, Udāna, Itivuttaka, etc., are not recited after being given the name of Sutta, like the Dīgha Nikāya, etc.🔽But in the intention here, they are also included together with the Jātaka, etc.

original: panettha aggahaṇe kāraṇaṃ maggitabbaṃ, kiṃ vā tena magganena? Sabbopāyaṃ vaṇṇanānayo
analyzed: pana ittha aggahaṇe kāraṇam maggitabbam kim vā tena magganena sabba upāyam vaṇṇanā anayo
translated: The reason for not including the Buddhavamsa and Cariyāpiṭaka here should be sought. Or what is the use of seeking? All this method of explanation

original: theravādaṃ dassanamukhena paṭikkhitto evāti.
analyzed: thera vādam dassana mukhena paṭikkhittaḥ eva ati
translated: is rejected by the Theravāda from the point of view of the doctrine.

original: Atthīti kiṃ atthi, asuttanāmakaṃ buddhavacanaṃ natthi evāti dasseti. Tathā hi nidānavaṇṇanāyaṃ
analyzed: atthi iti kim atthi asutta nāmakam buddha vacanam na atthi eva ati dasseti tathā hi nidāna vaṇṇanā ayam
translated: What is there? He shows that there is no Buddha-word without the name of Sutta. Thus in the Nidāna-explanation,

original: amhehi vuttaṃ “suttanti sāmaññavidhi, visesavidhayo pare”ti. Taṃ sabbaṃ paṭikkhipitvā
analyzed: amhehi vuttam suttanti sāmañña vidhi visesa vidhayaḥ pare ti tam sabbam paṭikkhipitvā
translated: We said that the Suttas are the general method of the monks’ rules, and the others are the special methods. He rejects all that,

original: “suttanti vinayo”tiādinā vuttaṃ saṃvaṇṇanānayaṃ “nāyamattho idhādhippeto”ti paṭisodhetvā.
analyzed: suttam ti vinaya uti ādinā vuttam saṃvaṇṇanā nayam na ayam atthaḥ idha adhippetaḥ ti paṭisodhetvā
translated: and what is said in the commentary in the passage beginning, “The Sutta is the Vinaya” he clears up by saying, “This is not the meaning intended here.”

original: Vineti etena kileseti vinayo, kilesavinayanūpāyo, so eva ca naṃ karotīti kāraṇanti
analyzed: vinā iti etena kilesa iti vinayaḥ saḥ eva ca nam karoti iti
translated: “The Vinaya is the cause” : it is the Vinaya because it disciplines , that is, because it disciplines defilements. It is the cause because it is the means of disciplining defilements and because it makes that happen.

original: āha “vinayo pana kāraṇa”nti.
analyzed: āha
translated: So he says, “But the Vinaya is the cause.”

original: Dhammeti pariyattidhamme. Sarāgāyāti sarāgabhāvāya kāmarāgabhavarāgaparibrūhanāya.🔽Saññogāyāti bhavasaṃyojanāya. Ācayāyāti vaṭṭassa vaḍḍhanatthāya. Mahicchatāyāti mahicchabhāvāya.🔽Asantuṭṭhiyāti asantuṭṭhibhāvāya. Saṅgaṇikāyāti kilesasaṅgaṇagaṇasaṅgaṇavihārāya.
analyzed: dhamme iti pariyatti dhamme sa rāgāya ati sa rāga bhāvāya kāma rāga bhava rāga paribrūhanāya  saññogāya ati bhava saṃyojanāya ācayāya ati vaṭṭassa vaḍḍhana tthāya mahiccha tāya ati mahiccha bhāvāya  asantuṭṭhiyā ati asantuṭṭhi bhāvāya saṅgaṇikāya ati kilesa saṅgaṇa gaṇa saṅgaṇa vihārāya
translated: “The Dhamma” : the Dhamma as text. “For the increase of lust” : for the state of lust, for the increase of sensual lust and lust for the existence of the form and formless worlds.🔽“For the increase of affection” : for the fetter of existence. “For the increase of craving” : for the increase of the round of rebirths. “For the state of being difficult to support” : for the state of being difficult to maintain. “For the state of discontent” : for the state of discontent. “For the state of being in a crowd” : for the state of living in a crowd of defilements and in a crowd of people.

original: Kosajjāyāti kusītabhāvāya. Dubbharatāyāti dupposatāya. Virāgāyāti sakalavaṭṭato virajjanatthāya.
analyzed: kosajjāya ati kusīta bhāvāya dubbharatāya ati dupposatāya virāgāya ati sakala vaṭṭataḥ virajjana tthāya
translated: “For the state of idleness” : for the state of laziness. “For the state of being difficult to support” : for the state of being difficult to maintain. “For the fading away of lust” : for the fading away of the whole round of rebirths.

original: Visaññogāyāti kāmabhavādīhi visaṃyujjanatthāya. Apacayāyāti sabbassāpi vaṭṭassa apacayanāya,
analyzed: visaññogāya ati kāma bhava ādīhi visaṃyujjana tthāya apacayāya ati sabbassa api vaṭṭassa apacayanāya
translated: For disengagement: for the purpose of disengaging from sense-desire existence, etc. For fading away: for the purpose of fading away of the whole round of suffering.

original: nibbānāyāti attho. Appicchatāyāti paccayappicchatādivasena sabbaso icchāpagamāya.
analyzed: nibbānāya ati atthaḥ appiccha tāya ati paccaya appiccha tā ādi vasena sabbaso icchā apagamāya
translated: The meaning is: for nibbana. For fewness of wishes: for the purpose of the complete abandonment of wishes in the form of fewness of wishes, etc.

original: Santuṭṭhiyāti dvādasavidhasantuṭṭhibhāvāya. Pavivekāyāti pavivittabhāvāya, kāyavivekāditadaṅgavivekādivivekasiddhiyā.
analyzed: santuṭṭhiyā ati dvādasavidha santuṭṭhi bhāvāya pavivekāya ati pavivitta bhāvāya kāya viveka ādi tad aṅga viveka ādi viveka siddhiyā
translated: For contentment: for the purpose of the twelve kinds of contentment. For seclusion: for the purpose of seclusion, for the purpose of accomplishing the seclusion consisting in the separation of body and the rest, the seclusion of the jhana factors, etc.

original: Vīriyārambhāyāti kāyikassa ceva, cetasikassa ca vīriyassa paggahaṇatthāya. Subharatāyāti
analyzed: vīriya ārambhāya ati kāyikassa ca iva cetasikassa ca vīriyassa paggahaṇa atthāya subhara tāya ati
translated: For the arousal of energy: for the purpose of exerting the bodily and mental energy. For being easy to support:

original: sukhaposanatthāya. Evaṃ yo pariyattidhammo uggahaṇadhāraṇaparipucchāmanasikāravasena
analyzed: sukha posana tthāya evam yaḥ pariyatti dhammo uggahaṇa dhāraṇa paripucchā manasikāra vasena
translated: for the purpose of being easy to nourish. Thus this is the one-sided teaching, which, as the cause for avoiding the states of lust, etc.,

original: yoniso paṭipajjantassa sarāgādibhāvaparivajjanassa kāraṇaṃ hutvā virāgādibhāvāya
analyzed: yonisaḥ paṭipajjantassa sa rāga ādi bhāva parivajjanassa kāraṇam hutvā virāga ādi bhāvāya
translated: leads to the states of non-lust, etc., in one who practices rightly by way of learning, memorizing, questioning, and attention.

original: saṃvattati, ekaṃsato eso dhammo. Eso vinayo, sammadeva apāyādīsu apatanavasena dhāraṇato,
analyzed: saṃvattati ekaṃsataḥ esaḥ dhammaḥ esaḥ vinayo sammat eva apāya ādīsu apatana vasena dhāraṇato
translated: This is the discipline, because it holds one back from falling into the states of loss, etc., in the true sense.

original: kilesānaṃ vinayanato, satthu sammāsambuddhassa ovādānusiṭṭhibhāvato etaṃ satthusāsananti
analyzed: kilesānam vinayanataḥ satthu sammāsambuddhassa ovāda anusiṭṭhi bhāvataḥ etam satthu sāsanam ti
translated: Because of the defilements’ being subdued, and because of the Teacher’s being the Fully Enlightened One who gives advice and instruction, it is the Teacher’s Dispensation.

original: dhāreyyāsi jāneyyāsi, avabujjheyyāsīti attho. Catusaccassa sūcanaṃ suttanti āha “sutteti
analyzed: dhāreyyāsi jāneyyāsi avabujjheyyāsi iti attho catu saccassa sūcanam suttan ti āha sutta iti
translated: You should bear it in mind, you should know it, you should understand it, is the meaning. He said ‘in the Discourses’ because the Four Truths are indicated in the Discourses.

original: tepiṭake buddhavacane”ti. Tepiṭakañhi buddhavacanaṃ saccavinimuttaṃ natthi. Rāgādivinayanakāraṇaṃ
analyzed: tepiṭake buddha vacane iti tepiṭakam hi buddha vacanam sacca vinimuttam natthi rāga ādi vinayana kāraṇam
translated: For there is no Buddha-word in the three Piṭakas that is not concerned with the Truths.🔽Because of the cause of the subduing of greed, etc.,

original: tathāgatena suttapadena pakāsitanti āha “vinayeti etasmiṃ rāgādivinayakāraṇe”ti.
analyzed: tathāgatena sutta padena pakāsitanti āha vinaya iti etasmin rāga ādi vinaya kāraṇā iti
translated: it is shown by the Tathāgata with the Thread, is what is said.

original: Sutte osaraṇañcettha tepiṭake buddhavacane pariyāpannatāvaseneva veditabbaṃ, na aññathāti
analyzed: sutte osaraṇam ca ittha tepiṭake buddha vacane pariyāpanna tā vasena iva veditabbam na aññathā ti
translated: Herein, the ‘falling into line with the Discourses’ should be understood as inclusion in the Buddha-word in the three Piṭakas, not otherwise.

original: āha “suttapaṭipāṭiyā katthaci anāgantvā”ti. Challiṃ uṭṭhapetvāti arogassa mahato
analyzed: āha sutta paṭipāṭiyā katthaci an āgantvā ati challim uṭṭhapetvā ati arogassa mahato
translated: That is why he said ‘without coming into the sequence of the Discourses anywhere’ .

original: rukkhassa tiṭṭhato upakkamena challiyā sakalikāya, papaṭikāya vā uṭṭhapanaṃ viya
analyzed: rukkhassa tiṭṭhataḥ upakkamena challiyā sakalikāya papaṭikāya vā uṭṭhapanam viya
translated: Just as when a man attacks a big healthy tree and fells it by cutting away the bark,

original: arogassa sāsanadhammassa tiṭṭhato byañjanamattena tappariyāpannaṃ viya hutvā challisadisaṃ
analyzed: arogassa sāsana dhammassa tiṭṭhataḥ byañjana mattena tat pariyāpannam viya hutvā challi sadisam
translated: so too, when the Dispensation-tree is healthy, he makes it as if it were barkless by making it included in the mere letter.

original: pubbāparaviruddhatādidosaṃ uṭṭhapetvā paridīpetvā, tādisāni pana ekaṃsato guḷhavessantarādipariyāpannāni
analyzed: pubba apara viruddha tā ādi dosam uṭṭhapetvā paridīpetvā tādisāni pana ekaṃsataḥ guḷha vessantara ādi pariyāpannāni
translated: and he shows that they are faulty by pointing out the contradiction between the earlier and later statements. But such statements are to be taken literally as in the case of the “sugar-cane simile” .🔽The meaning is that they are to be understood in the way stated.

original: hontīti āha “guḷhavessantara…pe…paññāyantīti attho”ti. Rāgādivinayeti rāgādīnaṃ vinayanatthe.
analyzed: honti iti āha rāga ādi vinaya iti rāga ādīnam vinayana atthe
translated: In the training of the faculties: in the training of the faculties in the overcoming of lust, etc.

original: Tadākāratāya na paññāyamānāni na dissamānāni chaḍḍetabbāni vajjitabbāni na gahetabbāni.
analyzed: tad ākāra tāya na paññāyamānāni na dissamānāni chaḍḍetabbāni vajjitabbāni na gahetabbāni
translated: They are to be rejected, to be avoided, not to be taken up, because they are not evident in that way, because they are not seen in that way.

original: Sabbatthāti sabbavāresu.
analyzed: sabbattha āti sabba vāresu
translated: In all cases: in all instances.🔽In this place: in this place where the Great Authorities are being demonstrated.

original: Imasmiṃ pana ṭhāneti imasmiṃ mahāpadesaniddesaṭṭhāne. “Sutte cattāro mahāpadesā”tiādinā
analyzed: imasmim pana ṭhāne iti imasmim mahāpadesa niddesa ṭṭhāne sutte cattāro mahāpadesa ati ādinā
translated: The four great authorities in the Suttas, etc.,

original: vuttampi avuttena saddhiṃ gahetvā pakiṇṇakakathāya mātikaṃ uddisati. Ñātuṃ icchito
analyzed: vuttam api a vuttena saddhim gahetvā pakiṇṇaka kathāya mātikam uddisati ñātum icchitaḥ
translated: are stated. But he includes them with what is not stated and he announces the mātikā of the miscellaneous discussion thus:

original: attho pañho, tassa vissajjanāni pañhābyākaraṇāni, atthasūcanādiatthena suttaṃ, pāḷi,
analyzed: atthaḥ pañho tassa vissajjanāni pañha abyākaraṇāni attha sūcana ādi atthena suttam
translated: The meaning that is wished to be known is a question. The answers to that are the answers to questions. The Thread is a sutta, a text, in the sense of showing a meaning, etc.

original: taṃ suttaṃ anulometi anukūletīti suttānulomaṃ, mahāpadeso. Ācariyā vadanti saṃvaṇṇenti
analyzed: tam suttam anulomā iti anukūlā iti iti sutta anulomam mahā padesaḥ ācariyāḥ vadanti saṃvaṇṇenti
translated: That sutta is in conformity with, is favourable to, the Great Authorities. The teachers say, declare,

original: pāḷiṃ etenāti ācariyavādo aṭṭhakathā. Tassa tassa therassa attano eva mati adhippāyoti
analyzed: pāḷim etena ati ācariya vādaḥ aṭṭhakathā tassa tassa therassa attano eva mati adhippāyo ti
translated: The Teacher’s opinion is the opinion of each of the elders.

original: attanomati. Dhammavinicchaye patteti dhamme vinicchinitabbe upaṭṭhite. Imeti anantaraṃ
analyzed: attanomati dhamma vinicchaye pattā iti dhamme vinicchinitabbe upaṭṭhite ime iti anantaram
translated: When the matter of the True Idea has been settled, when the matter of the True Idea has been decided,🔽these four Great Authorities are what have been mentioned next.

original: vuttā cattāro mahāpadesā. Pamīyati dhammo paricchijjati vinicchīyati etenāti pamāṇaṃ.🔽Tenāha “yaṃ ettha sametī”tiādi. Itaranti mahāpadesesu asamentaṃ. Puna itaranti akappiyaṃ
analyzed: vuttā cattāro mahā padesā pamīyati dhammo paricchijjati vinicchīyati etena ati pamāṇam  tena āha yam ettha sameti itiādi itaranti mahā apadesesu a samentam punar itaranti akappiyam
translated: The measure is what measures, what defines, what decides, the True Idea.🔽Hence he said ‘what is agreed upon here’ and so on.🔽The other is what is not agreed upon in the Great Authorities.

original: anulomentaṃ kappiyaṃ paṭibāhantaṃ sandhāyāha.🔽Ekaṃseneva byākātabbo vissajjetabboti ekaṃsabyākaraṇīyo. Vibhajjāti pucchitamatthaṃ
analyzed: anulomentam kappiyam paṭibāhantam sandhāya āha  ekaṃsena iva byākātabbaḥ vissajjetabbaḥ iti ekaṃsa byākaraṇīyaḥ vibhajja ati pucchitam attham
translated: Again, the other is what is not allowable, which contradicts what is allowable.🔽It should be answered categorically, it should be answered by a decision.🔽It should be answered analytically, after analysing the meaning of the question according to the distinction of definition, and so on.

original: avadhāraṇādibhedena vibhajitvā. Paṭipucchāti pucchantaṃ puggalaṃ paṭipucchitvā. Ṭhapanīyoti
analyzed: avadhāraṇa ādi bhedena vibhajitvā paṭipucchāti pucchantam puggalam paṭipucchitvā
translated: It should be answered by asking a question in return of the person who asks the question.🔽It should be set aside because it cannot be answered in any of the three ways. It should be set aside without answering it.

original: tidhāpi avissajjanīyattā ṭhapanīyo byākaraṇaṃ akatvā ṭhapetabbo. “Cakkhuṃ anicca”nti
analyzed: tidhā api a vissajjanīya ttā ṭhapanīyaḥ byākaraṇam a katvā ṭhapetabbaḥ cakkhum aniccanti
translated: ‘Is the eye impermanent?’

original: pañhe uttarapadāvadhāraṇaṃ sandhāya “ekaṃseneva byākātabba”nti vuttaṃ niccatāya lesassāpi
analyzed: pañhe uttara pada avadhāraṇam sandhāya ekaṃsena iva byākātabbam ti vuttam niccatāya lesassa api
translated: The words “must be answered categorically” are said with reference to the last term in the question. For the eye faculty is not a condition for the eye element in the sense of decisive support,

original: tattha abhāvato. Purimapadāvadhāraṇe pana vibhajjabyākaraṇīyatā cakkhusotesu visesatthasāmaññatthānaṃ🔽asādhāraṇabhāvato. Dvinnaṃ tesaṃ sadisatācodanā paṭipucchanamukheneva byākaraṇīyā
analyzed: tattha abhāvato purima pada avadhāraṇe pana vibhajja byākaraṇīya tā cakkhu sotesu visesa attha sāmañña tthānam  asādhāraṇa bhāvataḥ dvinnam tesam sadisa tā codanā paṭipucchana mukhena iva byākaraṇīyā
translated: because the latter does not exist. But the words “must be answered after making a distinction” are said with reference to the first term in the question. For the eye and ear faculties are similar in meaning in that they are both faculties,🔽but they differ in meaning in that they are not common to all. The question, “Are the eye and ear faculties the same or different?” must be answered by way of a counter-question,

original: paṭikkhepavasena, anuññātavasena ca vissajjitabbatoti āha “yathā cakkhu, tathā sotaṃ…pe…
analyzed: paṭikkhepa vasena anuññāta vasena ca vissajjitabbato ti āha yathā cakkhu tathā sotaṃpe
translated: because it must be answered by way of a denial and an affirmation. Therefore it is said: “As is the eye faculty, so is the ear faculty …

original: ayaṃ paṭipucchābyākaraṇīyo pañho”ti. Taṃ jīvaṃ taṃ sarīranti jīvasarīrānaṃ anaññatāpañho.
analyzed: ayam paṭipucchā byākaraṇīyaḥ pañho ti tam jīvam tam sarīram ti jīva sarīrānam anañña tā pañho
translated: This is a question to be answered by way of a counter-question.” The question, “Is the living being the same as the body or different from the body?” is a question about the non-difference of the living being and the body.

original: Yassa yena anaññatācoditā, so eva paramatthato nupalabbhatīti vañjhātanayassa matteyyatākittanasadisoti
analyzed: yassa yena anañña tā coditā saḥ eva paramatthataḥ na upalabbhati iti vañjhā tanayassa matteyya tā kittana sadisaḥ ti
translated: The question is asked in the form of a counter-question because the living being and the body are not different in the ultimate sense, and because the question is similar to the statement of a fool.

original: abyākātabbatāya ṭhapanīyo vuttoti. Imāni cattāri pañhabyākaraṇāni pamāṇaṃ teneva
analyzed: a byākātabba tāya ṭhapanīyaḥ vutto ti imāni cattāri pañha byākaraṇāni pamāṇam tena iva
translated: Therefore it is said to be a question to be set aside because it is unanswerable. These four ways of answering questions are the standard,

original: nayena tesaṃ pañhānaṃ byākātabbato.
analyzed: nayena tesam pañhānam byākātabbataḥ
translated: because the questions are to be answered in accordance with this method.

original: Vinayamahāpadeso kappiyānulomavidhānato nippariyāyato anulomakappiyaṃ nāma, mahāpadesabhāvena
analyzed: vinaya mahā padesaḥ kappiya anuloma vidhānataḥ nippariyāyataḥ anulomakappiyam nāma mahā padesa bhāvena
translated: The Great Authorities on Discipline are called “in conformity with what is allowable” because they are in conformity with the rules for what is allowable.

original: pana taṃsadisatāya suttantamahāpadesesupi “anulomakappiya”nti ayaṃ aṭṭhakathāvohāro.
analyzed: pana tad sadisa tāya suttanta mahā padesesu pi anuloma kappiyanti ayam aṭṭhakathā vohāro
translated: But because they are like the Great Authorities on the Suttas in being great authorities, the commentaries use the expression “in conformity with what is allowable” .

analyzed: yadi api tattha tattha bhagavatā pavattita pakiṇṇaka desanā va aṭṭhakathā sā pana dhamma saṅgāhakehi

analyzed: paṭhamam tīṇi piṭakāni saṅgāyitvā tassa attha vaṇṇanā anurūpena iva vācanā maggam āropita ttā

analyzed: siyā so na gahetabbaḥ ti dassentaḥ āha ācariya vādaḥ api suttena samentaḥ yeva gahetabbaḥ ti
translated: siyā, so na gahetabboti dassento āha “ācariyavādopi suttena samentoyeva gahetabbo”ti |

original: Sabbadubbalā puggalassa sayaṃ paṭibhānabhāvato. Tathā ca sāpi gahetabbā, kīdisī?
analyzed: sabba dubbalā puggalassa sayam paṭibhāna bhāvataḥ tathā ca sā api gahetabbā kīdisī
translated: sabbadubbalā puggalassa sayaṃ paṭibhānabhāvato | tathā ca sāpi gahetabbā, kīdisī?

original: Suttena samentā yevāti yojanā. Tāsūti tīsu saṅgītīsu. “Āgatameva pamāṇa”nti iminā
analyzed: suttena samentā yeva ati yojanā tāsu iti tīsu saṅgītīsu āgatam eva pamāṇam ti iminā
translated: The construction is: “They should be taken as Sutta only when they are in conformity with the Sutta.”

original: mahākassapādīhi saṅgītameva “sutta”nti idhādhippetanti tadaññassa suttabhāvameva
analyzed: mahākassapa ādīhi saṅgītam eva suttanti idha adhippetanti tad aññassa sutta bhāvam eva
translated: “The measure has already been stated”: by this he shows that the Sutta referred to here is that recited by the Elders Kassapa and others.🔽He rejects the idea that any other Sutta is the Sutta here referred to.🔽For the three Councils had only that Sutta as their object.

original: paṭikkhipati. Tadatthā eva hi tisso saṅgītiyo. Tatthāti gārayhasutte. Na ceva sutte
analyzed: paṭikkhipati tad atthāḥ eva hi tissaḥ saṅgītiyaḥ tattha ati gārayha sutte na ca iva sutte
translated: “There” means in the “Discourse on Blame.”🔽They should be understood as not to be accepted as Sutta,

original: osaranti, na ca vinaye sandissantīti veditabbāni tassa asuttabhāvato tena “anulomakappiyaṃ
analyzed: osaranti na ca vinaye sandissanti iti veditabbāni tassa a sutta bhāvataḥ tena anuloma kappiyam
translated: and as not to be in conformity with the Vinaya.

original: suttena samentameva gahetabba”nti vuttaṃ evatthaṃ nigamanavasena nidasseti. Sabbattha
analyzed: suttena samentam eva gahetabban ti vuttam evattham nigamana vasena nidasseti sabbattha
translated: “What is in conformity with the Sutta should be accepted.”🔽The meaning of this is shown by the conclusion: “Not the other.”

original: “na itara”nti vacanaṃ tattha tattha gahitāvadhāraṇaphaladassanaṃ daṭṭhabbaṃ.
analyzed: na itaran ti vacanam tattha tattha gahita avadhāraṇa phala dassanam daṭṭhabbam
translated: The fruit of the limitation is shown by the words “not the other” in each case.

original: Kammāraputtacundavatthuvaṇṇanā
analyzed: kammāra putta cunda vatthu vaṇṇanā
translated: The story of Cunda the Smith🔽“Tender pork”: the tender meat of a wild boar.

original: 189. Sūkaramaddavanti vanavarāhassa mudumaṃsaṃ. Yasmā cundo ariyasāvako sotāpanno,
analyzed: sūkara maddavanti vana varāhassa mudu maṃsam yasmā cundaḥ ariya sāvakaḥ sotāpanno
translated: Since Cunda the Noble Disciple was a Stream-Enterer,

original: aññe ca bhagavato, bhikkhusaṅghassa ca āhāraṃ paṭiyādentā anavajjameva paṭiyādenti,
analyzed: aññe ca bhagavataḥ bhikkhu saṅghassa ca āhāram paṭiyādentā anavajjam eva paṭiyādenti
translated: and others prepared blameless food for the Blessed One and the Community of Bhikkhus,

original: tasmā vuttaṃ “pavattamaṃsa”nti. Taṃ kirāti “nātitaruṇassā”tiādinā vuttavisesaṃ. Tathā
analyzed: tasmā vuttam tam kirāti na ati taruṇassa ati ādinā vutta visesam tathā
translated: So it is said to be “meat that is in process of formation.” It is “not too young” and so on.

original: hi taṃ “mudu ceva siniddhañcā”ti vuttaṃ. Mudumaṃsabhāvato hi abhisaṅkharaṇavisesena
analyzed: hi tam mudu ca iva siniddham ca ati vuttam mudu maṃsa bhāvataḥ hi abhisaṅkharaṇa visesena
translated: For it is said to be “soft and tender.” And because it is soft meat, it is said to be “tender” by a special formation of the word.

original: ca “maddava”nti vuttaṃ. Ojaṃ pakkhipiṃsu “ayaṃ bhagavato pacchimako āhāro”ti puññavisesāpekkhāya,
analyzed: ca maddavanti vuttam ojam pakkhipiṃsu ayam bhagavataḥ pacchimakaḥ āhāraḥ ti puñña visesa apekkhāya
translated: They put the essence in it, thinking: “This will be the Blessed One’s last meal,” expecting a special merit.

original: taṃ pana tathāpakkhittadibbojatāya garutaraṃ jātaṃ.
analyzed: tam pana tathā apakkhitta dibboja tāya garutaram jātam
translated: But it became more indigestible because of the essence put in it.

original: Aññe yaṃ dujjīraṃ, taṃ ajānantā “kassaci adatvā vināsita”nti upavadeyyunti parūpavādamocanatthaṃ bhagavā “nāhaṃ ta”ntiādinā sīhanādaṃ nadati.
analyzed: aññe yam dujjīram tam a jānantā kassaci a datvā upavadeyyunti parūpavāda mocana attham bhagavā na aham tanti ādinā sīha nādam nadati
translated: Others, not knowing that it was indigestible, would accuse him, saying: “He has wasted it without giving it to anyone.” So the Blessed One roars his lion’s roar with the words “I do not say” in order to avoid such accusations by others.

original: 190. Kathaṃ panāyaṃ sīhanādo nanu taṃ bhagavatopi sammāpariṇāmaṃ na gatanti? Nayidaṃ
analyzed: katham pana ayam sīha nādaḥ nanu tam bhagavataḥ api sammā pariṇāmam na
translated: But how can this be a lion’s roar? Has it not turned out badly for the Blessed One?

original: evaṃ daṭṭhabbaṃ, yasmā “sammadeva taṃ bhagavato pariṇāmaṃ gata”nti vattuṃ arahati
analyzed: evam daṭṭhabbam yasmā sammat eva tam bhagavataḥ pariṇāmam gatanti vattum arahati
translated: This should not be regarded as

original: tappaccayā uppannassa vikārassa abhāvato, aññapaccayassa ca vikārassa mudubhāvaṃ🔽āpāditattā. Tenāha “na pana bhuttappaccayā”tiādi. Na hi bhagavā, aññe vā pana khīṇāsavā
analyzed: tad paccayāḥ uppannassa vikārassa abhāvataḥ añña paccayassa ca vikārassa mudu bhāvam  āpādita ttā tena āha na pana bhutta paccayā tiādi na hi bhagavā aññe vā pana khīṇa āsavā
translated: because there is no change in him due to that condition, and because any other condition that might bring about change has been rendered pliable by his attainment of suppleness. Hence he said, “not due to the condition of eating.”

original: navavedanuppādanavasena āhāraṃ paribhuñjanti aṭṭhaṅgasamannāgatameva katvā āhārassa
analyzed: nava vedanā uppādana vasena āhāram paribhuñjanti aṭṭhaṅga samannāgatam eva katvā āhārassa
translated: For the Blessed One, or any other arahat, does not consume nutriment in order to produce the nine kinds of consciousness beginning with eye-consciousness. He consumes it only

original: upabhuñjanato. Yadi evaṃ kasmā pāḷiyaṃ “bhattaṃ bhuttāvissa kharo ābādho uppajjī”tiādi
analyzed: upabhuñjanataḥ yadi evam kasmā pāḷiyam bhattam bhutta avissa kharaḥ ābādhaḥ uppajji itiādi
translated: because it is necessary for the maintenance of this personality. If that is so, why is it said in the texts, “After he had eaten his meal, a violent sickness came upon him”?

original: vuttaṃ? Taṃ bhojanuttarakālaṃ uppannattā vuttaṃ. “Na pana bhuttapaccayā”ti vutto🔽vāyamattho aṭṭhakathāyaṃ. Katupacitassa laddhokāsassa kammassa vasena balavatipi
analyzed: vuttam tam bhojana uttara kālam uppanna ttā vuttam na pana bhutta paccayā ati vuttaḥ  vā ayam attho aṭṭhakathāyam kata upacitassa laddha ukāsassa kammassa vasena balavati pi
translated: This was said because the sickness arose after the meal. But the meaning of the words “not due to the condition of eating” is stated in the commentary:

original: roge uppanne garusiniddhabhojanappaccayā vedanāniggaho jāto, tenāha “yadi hī”tiādi.
analyzed: roge uppanne vedanā niggahaḥ jātaḥ tena āha yadi hi itiādi
translated: “Even when a strong disease arises due to the influence of kamma that has already obtained an opportunity to bear fruit, the Blessed One is able to control the pain by means of his strong mindfulness and understanding.

original: Patthitaṭṭhāneti icchitaṭṭhāne, icchā cassa tattha gantvā vinetabbaveneyyāpekkhā
analyzed: patthita ṭṭhāne ti icchita ṭṭhāne icchā ca ssa tattha gantvā vinetabba veneyya apekkhā
translated: ” “In the place he desires”: in the place he wishes. His wish is to go there in order to discipline those who are capable of being disciplined.

original: daṭṭhabbā. Gāthāyampi “suta”nti iminā sutamattaṃ, paresaṃ vacanamattametaṃ, na pana
analyzed: daṭṭhabbā gāthāyam pi sutam ti iminā suta mattam paresam vacana mattam etam na pana
translated: should be seen. And in the verse too, by the word “heard” he shows that it is mere hearsay, mere talk of others,

original: bhojanappaccayā ābādhaṃ phusi dhīroti dasseti.
analyzed: bhojana ppaccayā ābādham phusi dhīraḥ iti dasseti
translated: and that it is not the case that he has had experience of the fact that “sickness is due to over-eating.”
