translated: Therefore, in order to show the summary of it in its individual nature, he said: “For I have laid down for you,” etc. Herein, by way of the seven classes of offenses means by way of the seven classes of offenses.

original: avītikkamanīyatāvasena. Satthukiccaṃ sādhessati “idaṃ vo kattabbaṃ, idaṃ vo na kattabba”nti🔽kattabbākattabbassa vibhāgena anusāsanato.🔽Tena tenākārenāti tena tena veneyyānaṃ ajjhāsayānurūpena pakārena. Ime dhammeti ime
analyzed: avītikkamanīya tā vasena satthu kiccam sādhessati idam vaḥ kattabbam idam vaḥ na kattabbanti  kattabba a kattabbassa vibhāgena anusāsanataḥ  tena tena ākārena ati tena tena veneyyānam ajjhāsayā anurūpena pakārena ime dhammā iti ime
translated: in the sense of not being transgressed. It will fulfil the Teacher’s task in that it instructs by distinguishing what should and should not be done thus “This should be done by you, this should not be done by you.”🔽In that way, in that way, in the way appropriate to the dispositions of those requiring training. These ideas,

original: sattatiṃsabodhipakkhiyadhamme. Tappadhānattā suttantadesanāya “suttantapiṭakaṃ desita”nti
analyzed: sattatiṃsa bodhi pakkhiya dhamme tad padhāna ttā suttanta desanāya suttanta piṭakam desitanti
translated: these ideas that are the thirty-seven ideas that are the limbs of enlightenment. Because of the predominance of that, the teaching of the sutta-collection is called “the sutta-collection taught.”

original: vuttaṃ. Satthukiccaṃ sādhessati taṃtaṃcariyānurūpaṃ sammāpaṭipattiyā anusāsanato.
analyzed: vuttam satthu kiccam sādhessati tad tad cariyā anurūpam sammā paṭipattiyāḥ anusāsanato
translated: It will fulfil the Teacher’s task in that it instructs by means of right practice in accordance with the various characters of those requiring training.

original: Kusalākusalābyākatavasena nava hetū. “Satta phassā”tiādi sattaviññāṇadhātusampayogavasena
analyzed: kusala akusala abyākata vasena nava hetū satta phassa ati ādi satta viññāṇa dhātu sampayoga vasena
translated: There are nine causes in the sense of profitable, unprofitable, and indeterminate. “Seven contacts” is said in the sense of the seven consciousness-elements’ association .

original: vuttaṃ. Dhammānulome tikapaṭṭhānādayo cha, tathā dhammapaccanīye, dhammānulomapaccanīye,
analyzed: vuttam dhamma anulome tika paṭṭhāna ādayaḥ cha tathā dhamma paccanīye dhamma anuloma paccanīye
translated: In the case of the conformity and non-conformity ideas, there are six kinds of pervasion, etc., and likewise in the case of the non-conformity and conformity ideas,

original: dhammapaccanīyānulometi catuvīsati samantapaṭṭhānāni etassāti catuvīsatisamantapaṭṭhānaṃ,
analyzed: dhamma paccanīya anulomā iti catuvīsati samanta paṭṭhānāni etassa ati catuvīsati samanta paṭṭhānam
translated: and in the case of the non-conformity and conformity ideas. The one that has twenty-four kinds of pervasion is the one that has twenty-four kinds of pervasion.

original: taṃ pana paccayānulomādivasena vibhajiyamānaṃ aparimāṇanayaṃ evāti āha “anantanayamahāpaṭṭhānapaṭimaṇḍita”nti.🔽Satthukiccaṃ sādhessatīti khandhādivibhāgena ñāyamānaṃ catusaccasambodhāvahattā satthārā
analyzed: tam pana paccaya anuloma ādi vasena vibhajiyamānam aparimāṇa nayam eva iti āha ananta naya mahā paṭṭhāna paṭimaṇḍitan ti  satthu kiccam sādhessati iti khandha ādi vibhāgena ñāyamānam catu sacca sambodha āvahattā satthārā
translated: But when it is analysed according to the order of the conditions, etc., it has an infinite number of methods, and so it is said to be “adorned with the great method of the infinite number of methods.”🔽It will fulfil the task of a teacher: when it is taught by analysis into the categories, etc., it will fulfil the task that has to be done by a teacher, a Perfectly Enlightened One,

original: sammāsambuddhena kātabbakiccaṃ nipphādessati.
analyzed: sammāsambuddhena kātabba kiccam nipphādessati
translated: in order to bring about the enlightenment of the four noble truths.

original: Ovadissanti anusāsissanti ovādānusāsanīkiccanipphādanato.🔽Cārittanti samudācārā, navesu piyālāpaṃ vuḍḍhesu gāravālāpanti attho. Tenāha “bhanteti
analyzed: ovadissanti anusāsissanti ovāda anusāsanī kicca nipphādanato  cārittam ti samudācārāḥ navesu piya ālāpam vuḍḍhesu gārava ālāpam ti attho tena āha bhante iti
translated: They will admonish and instruct: because they will fulfil the task of admonishing and instructing.🔽Conduct: practice. The meaning is, they will speak affectionately to the young and respectfully to the old. Hence he said: “Venerable sir” or “venerable” .

original: vā āyasmāti vā”ti. Gāravavacanaṃ hetaṃ yadidaṃ bhanteti vā āyasmāti vā, loke pana
analyzed: vā āyasma ati vā ati gārava vacanam yat idam bhanta iti vā loke
translated: For this is a respectful form of address: “Venerable sir” or “venerable.” But in the world

original: “tatra bhava”nti, “devānaṃ piyā”ti ca gāravavacanameva.🔽“Ākaṅkhamāno samūhanatū”ti vutte “na ākaṅkhamāno na samūhanatū”tipi vuttameva hotīti
analyzed: tatra bhavanti ca gārava vacanam eva  ākaṅkhamānaḥ samūhanatu iti vutte na ākaṅkhamānaḥ na vuttam eva hoti iti
translated: “there” means “in that” and “dear to the gods” is also a respectful form of address.🔽When it is said, “If he wishes, he can abolish it,” it is as if it were said, “If he does not wish, he need not abolish it.”

original: āha “vikappavacaneneva ṭhapesī”ti. Balanti ñāṇabalaṃ. Yadi asamūhananaṃ diṭṭhaṃ,
analyzed: āha vikappa vacanena iva ṭhapesi iti balam ti ñāṇa balam yadi a samūhananam diṭṭham
translated: So he said, “He established it with a conditional statement.” Power: the power of knowledge. If the non-abolition is seen,

original: tadeva ca icchitaṃ, atha kasmā bhagavā “ākaṅkhamāno samūhanatū”ti avocāti? Tathārūpapuggalajjhāsayavasena.
analyzed: tat eva ca icchitam atha kasmai bhagavā ākaṅkhamānaḥ avoca ati tathārūpa puggala jjhāsaya vasena
translated: Because of the disposition of the kind of person he was referring to.

original: Santi hi keci khuddānukhuddakāni sikkhāpadāni samādāya saṃvattituṃ anicchantā, tesaṃ🔽tathā avuccamāne bhagavati vighāto uppajjeyya, taṃ tesaṃ bhavissati dīgharattaṃ ahitāya
analyzed: santi hi keci khuddānukhuddakāni sikkhāpadāni samādāya saṃvattitum an icchantā tesam  tathā a vuccamāne bhagavati vighātaḥ uppajjeyya tam tesam bhavissati dīgharattam ahitāya
translated: For there are some who, not wanting to undertake and observe the training rules,🔽would be upset if they were told, “If he wishes, he may abolish it.” That would be for their harm and suffering for a long time.

original: dukkhāya, tathā pana vutte tesaṃ vighāto na uppajjeyya “amhākaṃ evāyaṃ doso, yato
analyzed: dukkhāya tathā pana vutte tesam vighātaḥ na uppajjeyya amhākam eva ayam dosaḥ yatas
translated: But if they were told, “If he wishes, he may abolish it,” they would not be upset, thinking, “The fault is ours, since we are not able to observe the training rules.”

original: amhesu eva keci samūhananaṃ na icchantī”ti. Keci “sakalassa pana sāsanassa saṅghāyattabhāvakaraṇatthaṃ
analyzed: eva keci samūhananam na icchanti iti keci sakalassa pana sāsanassa saṅgha āyatta bhāva karaṇa attham
translated: Some say that the Blessed One said this in order to make the whole dispensation subject to the Sangha.

original: tathā vutta”nti vadanti. Yañca kiñci satthārā sikkhāpadaṃ paññattaṃ, taṃ samaṇā sakyaputtiyā
analyzed: tathā vuttam ti vadanti yat ca kiñci satthārā sikkhāpadam paññattam tam samaṇā sakyaputtiyā
translated: Whatever training rules the Teacher laid down, the ascetics, the Sakyan’s sons,🔽accepted them on their heads and observed them as they would their life.

original: sirasā sampaṭicchitvā jīvitaṃ viya rakkhanti. Tathā hi te “khuddānukhuddakāni sikkhāpadāni
analyzed: sirasā sampaṭicchitvā jīvitam viya rakkhanti tathā hi te khuddānukhuddakāni sikkhāpadāni
translated: For they observed even the minor training rules

original: ākaṅkhamāno saṅgho samūhanatū”ti vuttepi na samūhaniṃsu, aññadatthu “purato viya
analyzed: ākaṅkhamānaḥ saṅghaḥ samūhanatu uti vutte api na samūhaniṃsu puratas viya
translated: and the Sangha, if it wishes, can abolish it.” But they did not abolish it. On the contrary, they protected it even after his death, just as they had done before.

original: tassa accayepi rakkhiṃsu evā”ti satthusāsanassa, saṅghassa ca mahantabhāvadassanatthampi
analyzed: tassa accaye pi rakkhiṃsu evā ti satthu sāsanassa saṅghassa ca mahanta bhāva dassana attham pi
translated: This is how it should be understood that the Blessed One said this in order to show the greatness of the Teacher and the greatness of the Sangha.

original: tathā vuttanti daṭṭhabbaṃ. Tathā hi āyasmā ānando, aññepi vā bhikkhū “katamaṃ pana
analyzed: tathā vuttanti daṭṭhabbam tathā hi āyasmā ānandaḥ aññe pi vā bhikkhū katamam pana
translated: For neither the venerable Ananda nor any other bhikkhu asked, “But which is the lesser and which the greater? “

original: bhante khuddakaṃ, katamaṃ anukhuddaka”nti na pucchiṃsu samūhanajjhāsayasseva abhāvato.
analyzed: bhante khuddakam katamam anukhuddakam ti na pucchiṃsu samūhana jhāsayassa iva abhāvato
translated: because they had no intention of abolishing it.

original: Na taṃ evaṃ gahetabbanti “nāgasenatthero khuddānukhuddakaṃ jānātī”tiādinā vuttaṃ
analyzed: na tam evam gahetabbanti nāgasena theraḥ khuddānukhuddakam jānāti iti ādinā vuttam
translated: “It should not be taken in that way” means that what was said, “The Elder Nagasena knows the lesser and the greater,”

original: taṃ nesaṃ vacanaṃ iminā vuttākārena na gahetabbaṃ adhippāyassa aviditattā. Idāni
analyzed: tat na īsam vacanam iminā vutta ākārena na gahetabbam adhippāyassa a vidita ttā idāni
translated: should not be taken as stated by them in that way, because their intention is not understood. Now, in order to make that intention clear,🔽it was said, “The Elder Nagasena, however,” and so on. Since the Elder Nagasena

original: taṃ adhippāyaṃ vibhāvetuṃ “nāgasenatthero hī”tiādi vuttaṃ. Yasmā nāgasenatthero (milindapañhe
analyzed: tam adhippāyam vibhāvetum nāgasena theraḥ hi itiādi vuttam yasmā nāgasena theraḥ milindapañhe
translated: (see Milinda’s Questions, Chapter V, “On the Unbroken Continuity of the Community”)

original: abhejjavagge vitthāro) paresaṃ vādapathopacchedanatthaṃ saṅgītikāle dhammasaṅgāhakamahātherehi
analyzed: abhejja vagge vitthāro paresam vāda patha upacchedana attham saṅgīti kāle dhamma saṅgāhaka mahā therehi
translated: at the time of the rehearsal of the Dhamma by the great elders who were the compilers of the Dhamma, for the purpose of cutting off the opportunity for others to speak,

original: gahitakoṭṭhāsesu ca antimakoṭṭhāsameva gahetvā milindarājānaṃ paññāpesi. Mahākassapatthero🔽pana ekasikkhāpadampi asamūhanitukāmatāya tathā kammavācaṃ sāveti, tasmā taṃ tesaṃ
analyzed: gahita koṭṭhāsesu ca antima koṭṭhāsam eva gahetvā milinda rājānam paññāpesi mahākassapa thero  pana eka sikkhāpadam pi a samūhanitu kāma tāya tathā kamma vācam sāveti tasmā tam tesam
translated: and in the case of the sections that had been taken, he took only the last section and made it the subject of the discussion with King Milinda.

original: vacanaṃ tathā na gahetabbaṃ.
analyzed: vacanam tathā na gahetabbam
translated: But the Elder Kassapa the Great, not wanting to omit even one training precept, recited the Monastic Law in such a way that he did not omit any of the words of the Monastic Law. Therefore that statement of his should not be taken in the same way as the other two.🔽“Two-pronged” means twofold, double-sided. “Doubt” is the state of being doubtful. Hence it is said, “inability to decide.”

original: 217. Dveḷhakanti dvidhāgāho, anekaṃsaggāhoti attho. Vimatīti saṃsayāpatti. Tenāha “vinicchituṃ asamatthatā”ti. Taṃ vo vadāmīti taṃ saṃsayavantaṃ bhikkhuṃ sandhāya vo tumhe vadāmi.🔽Nikkaṅkhabhāvapaccakkhakaraṇañāṇaṃ yevāti buddhādīsu tesaṃ bhikkhūnaṃ nikkaṅkhabhāvassa🔽paccakkhakāriyābhāvato tamatthaṃ paṭivijjhitvā ṭhitaṃ sabbaññutaññāṇameva. Ettha etasmiṃ atthe.
analyzed: dveḷhakam ti dvidhā gāhaḥ aneka aṃsaggāhaḥ ti atthaḥ vimati iti saṃsaya āpatti tena āha vinicchitum asamattha tā ati tam vaḥ vadāmi iti tam saṃsayavantam bhikkhum sandhāya vaḥ tumhe vadāmi  nikkaṅkha bhāva paccakkha karaṇa ñāṇam yeva āti buddha ādīsu tesam bhikkhūnam nikkaṅkha bhāvassa  paccakkha kāriyā abhāvataḥ tam attham paṭivijjhitvā ṭhitam sabbaññu ta ññāṇam eva ettha etasmin atthe
translated: “I tell you” : I tell you, monks, who are doubtful.🔽“The knowledge that is the means of verifying the state of being free from doubt” is the knowledge of omniscience, which is established by penetrating that meaning, because there is no need for those monks to verify the state of being free from doubt in regard to the Buddha, etc. “Here” : in this matter.

original: 218. Appamajjanaṃ appamādo, so pana atthato ñāṇūpasañhitā sati. Yasmā tattha satiyā
analyzed: appamajjanam appamādo so pana atthataḥ sati yasmā tattha satiyā
translated: “Conscientiousness” is heedfulness. But this is, in fact, mindfulness associated with knowledge, because

original: byāpāro sātisayo, tasmā “satiavippavāsenā”ti vuttaṃ. Appamādapadeyeva pakkhipitvā
analyzed: byāpāraḥ sa atisayaḥ tasmā sati a vippavāsena ati vuttam appamāda padeyā iva pakkhipitvā
translated: and he included it in the section on heedfulness.🔽and he gave it, in meaning,

original: adāsi taṃ atthato, tassa sakalassa buddhavacanassa saṅgaṇhanato ca.
analyzed: adāsi tam atthataḥ tassa sakalassa buddha vacanassa saṅgaṇhanataḥ ca
translated: because it includes the whole of the Buddha’s word.

original: Parinibbutakathāvaṇṇanā🔽219. Jhānādīsu, citte ca paramukkaṃsagatavasībhāvatāya “ettake kāle ettakā samāpattiyo
analyzed: parinibbuta kathā vaṇṇanā  jhāna ādīsu citte ca ettake kāle ettakā samāpattiyaḥ
translated: The description of the parinibbāna🔽. Since he had the highest mastery over the jhānas, etc., and over the mind, he had fixed the time, saying: “At such a time I shall attain Nibbāna after having entered into so many attainments.”

original: samāpajjitvā parinibbāyissāmī”ti kālaparicchedaṃ katvā samāpatti samāpajjanaṃ “parinibbānaparikamma”nti
analyzed: samāpajjitvā parinibbāyissāmi iti kāla paricchedam katvā samāpatti samāpajjanam parinibbāna parikamman ti
translated: The entering into the attainments is called “the preliminary work for Nibbāna.”

original: adhippetaṃ. Theroti anuruddhatthero.
analyzed: adhippetam thero ti anuruddha thero
translated: The Elder: the Elder Anuruddha.

original: Ayampi cāti yathāvuttapañcasaṭṭhiyā jhānānaṃ samāpannabhāvakathāpi saṅkhepakathā
analyzed: ayam pi ca ati yathā vutta pañca saṭṭhiyāḥ jhānānam samāpanna bhāva kathā api saṅkhepa kathā
translated: This too is a brief statement: the statement about the Elder’s attainment of the sixty-five jhānas.

original: eva, kasmā? Yasmā bhagavā tadāpi devasikaṃ vaḷañjanasamāpattiyo sabbāpi aparihāpetvā
analyzed: eva kasmai yasmai bhagavā tadā api devasikam vaḷañjana samāpattiyaḥ sabbāḥ api a parihāpetvā
translated: Why? Because the Blessed One, even then, attained all the jhānas and measureless states without omitting any, day after day.

original: samāpajji evāti dassento “nibbānapuraṃ pavisanto”tiādimāha.
analyzed: samāpajji eva iti dassentaḥ nibbāna puram pavisantaḥ itiādim āha
translated: Showing this, the commentator says: “Entering the city of Nibbāna.”

original: Imāni dvepi samanantarāneva paccavekkhaṇāyapi yebhuyyenānantariyakatāya jhānapakkhikabhāvato,
analyzed: imāni dve pi yebhuyyena ānantariyaka tāya jhāna pakkhika bhāvato
translated: These two are only to be reviewed in immediate succession.

original: yasmā bhavaṅgacittaṃ sabbapacchimaṃ, tato bhavato cavanato “cutī”ti vuccati, tasmā
analyzed: yasmā bhavaṅga cittam sabba pacchimam tatas bhavataḥ cavanataḥ cutī iti vuccati tasmā
translated: Since the life-continuum consciousness is the last of all, it is called “death” because of passing away from existence.🔽Therefore,

original: na kevalaṃ ayameva bhagavā, atha kho sabbepi sattā bhavaṅgacitteneva cavantīti dassetuṃ
analyzed: na kevalam ayam eva bhagavā atha kho sabbe pi sattāḥ bhavaṅga cittena iva cavanti iti dassetuṃ
translated: in order to show that not only this Blessed One but all beings pass away with the life-continuum consciousness,

original: “ye hi kecī”tiādi vuttaṃ.
analyzed: ye hi keci itiādi vuttam
translated: “Whoever” is said, etc.

original: 220. Paṭibhāgapuggalavirahitoti sīlādiguṇehi asadisatāya sadisapuggalarahito.
analyzed: paṭibhāga puggala virahitaḥ ti sīla ādi guṇehi asadisa tāya sadisa puggala rahitaḥ
translated: Devoid of a counterpart person: devoid of a person similar to him in virtue, etc.

original: 221. Saṅkhārā vūpasamanti etthāti vūpasamoti evaṃsaṅkhātaṃ ñātaṃ kathitaṃ nibbānaṃ.
analyzed: saṅkhārāḥ vūpasamanti ettha ati vūpasamaḥ ti evaṃsaṅkhātam ñātam kathitam nibbānam
translated: The state called “cessation” is the Nibbāna that is known and spoken of thus: “Here formations cease.”

original: 222. Yanti paccatte upayogavacananti āha “yo kālaṃ akarī”ti.
analyzed: yanti paccatte upayoga vacananti āha yaḥ kālam akari iti
translated: “They go” is a word for utilization in the individual .

original: Suvikasitenevāti pītisomanassayogato suṭṭhu vikasitena muditena. Vedanaṃ adhivāsesi abhāvasamudayo kato suṭṭhu pariññātattā. Anāvaraṇavimokkho sabbaso nibbutabhāvato.
analyzed: su vikasitena iva āti pīti somanassa yogato suṭṭhu vikasitena muditena vedanam adhivāsesi abhāva samudayo kataḥ suṭṭhu pariññāta ttā anāvaraṇa vimokkho sabbaso nibbuta bhāvato
translated: He endured the feeling with a well-developed mind: with a mind well developed by joy and gladness. He made the origination of non-being : he fully understood by means of full understanding as exhaustion. The unhindered deliverance : the complete Nibbāna.

original: 223. Ākaronti attano phalāni samānākāre karontīti ākārā, kāraṇāni. Sabbākāravarūpeteti sabbehi ākāravarehi uttamakāraṇehi sīlādiguṇehi samannāgateti attho.
analyzed: ākaronti attanaḥ phalāni samāna ākāre karonti iti ākārā kāraṇāni sabbehi ākāra varehi uttama kāraṇehi sīla ādi guṇehi samannāgatā iti attho
translated: 223. They make their own fruits have the same appearance as themselves, thus they are “aspects” , i.e. reasons. The meaning is that he is endowed with the special qualities of virtue, etc., which are the best reasons in that they have the best aspects.

original: 225. Kathaṃbhūtāti kīdisābhūtā.
analyzed: kathaṃbhūtā ati kīdisābhūtā
translated: How? What kind?

original: Cullakaddhānanti parittaṃ kālaṃ dvattināḍikāmattaṃ velaṃ.
analyzed: parittam kālam dvatti nāḍikā mattam velam
translated: A short time: a short period, the length of two watches.

original: Buddhasarīrapūjāvaṇṇanā
analyzed: buddha sarīra pūjā vaṇṇanā
translated: The description of the worship of the Buddha’s bodily remains

original: 227. Kaṃsatāḷādi tāḷaṃ avacarati etthāti “tāḷāvacara”nti vuccati ātatāditūriyabhaṇḍaṃ. Tenāha “sabbaṃ tūriyabhaṇḍa”nti.
analyzed: kaṃsa tāḷa ādi tāḷam avacarati ettha ati tāḷa avacaranti vuccati ātata ādi tūriya bhaṇḍam tena āha sabbam tūriya bhaṇḍanti
translated: The place where the musical instruments such as cymbals are played is called “the place for cymbals” . He says, “all musical instruments.”

original: Dakkhiṇadisābhāgenevāti aññena disābhāgena anāharitvā yamakasālānaṃ ṭhānato dakkhiṇadisābhāgeneva, tatopi dakkhiṇadisābhāgaṃ haritvā netvā.
analyzed: dakkhiṇa disā bhāgena iva ati aññena disā bhāgena an āharitvā yamaka sālānam ṭhānataḥ dakkhiṇa disā bhāgena iva tatas api dakkhiṇa disā bhāgam haritvā netvā
translated: In the direction of the south: without bringing it in any other direction, only in the direction of the south from the place of the twin sal trees, and from there, having brought it in the direction of the south, he carried it.

original: Jetavanasadiseti sāvatthiyā jetavanasadise ṭhāne, “jetavanasadise ṭhāne”tipi pāṭho.
analyzed: jetavana sadisā iti sāvatthiyāḥ jetavana sadise ṭhāne jetavana sadise ṭhāna itipi pāṭhaḥ
translated: In a place like Jeta’s Wood: in a place like Jeta’s Wood in Sāvatthī. There is also the reading “in a place like Jeta’s Wood.”

original: 228. Pasādhanamaṅgalasālāyāti abhisekakāle alaṅkaraṇamaṅgalasālāya.
analyzed: ati abhiseka kāle alaṅkaraṇa maṅgala sālāya
translated: In the hall of the consecration ceremony: in the hall of the consecration ceremony, the hall of decoration at the time of the consecration.

original: 229. Devadāniyoti tassa corassa nāmaṃ.
analyzed: tassa corassa nāmaṃ
translated: Devadāni is the name of the robber.

original: Mahākassapattheravatthuvaṇṇanā🔽231. Pāvāyāti pāvā nagarato. Āvajjanapaṭibaddhattā jānanassa anāvajjitattā satthu🔽parinibbānaṃ ajānanto “dasabalaṃ passissāmī”ti thero cintesi, satthu sarīre vā satthusaññaṃ🔽uppādento tathā cintesi. Tenevāha “atha bhagavantaṃ ukkhipitvā”ti. “Dhuvaṃ parinibbuto
analyzed: mahā kassapatthera vatthu vaṇṇanā  pāvāya ati pāvā nagarataḥ āvajjana paṭibaddha ttā jānanassa an āvajjita ttā satthu  parinibbānam a jānantaḥ dasabalam passissāmi iti thero cintesi satthu sarīre vā satthu saññam  uppādentaḥ tathā cintesi tena iva āha atha bhagavantam ukkhipitvā ati dhuvam parinibbutaḥ
translated: The story of the Elder Maha Kassapa🔽At Pava: from the town of Pava.

original: bhavissatī”ti cintesi pārisesañāyena. Jānantopi thero ājīvakaṃ pucchiyeva, pucchane
analyzed: bhavissati iti cintesi pārisesa ñāyena jānantaḥ api theraḥ ājīvakam pucchiya iva pucchane
translated: Because of the connection between the act of adverting and the act of knowing, the Elder did not know of the Master’s Parinibbana because he had not adverted to it. He thought, “I shall see the One of Ten Powers,” and he thought thus because he had aroused the perception of the Master in regard to the Master’s body. That is why it is said, “Then, taking the Blessed One up” . He thought, “He must have attained final Nibbana” by inference.

original: pana kāraṇaṃ sayameva pakāsetuṃ “kiṃ panā”tiādi āraddhaṃ.
analyzed: kāraṇam sayam eva pakāsetum kim āraddham
translated: Though he knew, the Elder asked the Ajivaka, and the reason for the asking he himself made clear by saying, “But why?”

original: Ajja sattāhaparinibbutoti ajja divasato paṭilomato sattame ahani parinibbuto.
analyzed: ajja satta aha parinibbuto ti ajja divasataḥ paṭilomataḥ sattame ahani parinibbuto
translated: Today, a week after his final Nibbana: he attained final Nibbana on the seventh day after that day.

original: 232. Nāḷiyā vāpakenāti nāḷiyā ceva thavikāya ca.
analyzed: nāḷiyā vāpakena ati nāḷiyā ca iva thavikāya ca
translated: With a bamboo tube and a carrying pole: with a bamboo tube and a carrying pole.

original: Mañjuketi mañjubhāṇine madhurassare. Paṭibhāneyyaketi paṭibhānavante. Bhuñjitvā pātabbayāgūti paṭhamaṃ bhuñjitvā pivitabbayāgu.🔽Tassāti subhaddassa vuḍḍhapabbajitassa.🔽Ārādhitasāsaneti samāhitasāsane. Alanti samattho. Pāpoti pāpapuggalo. Osakkāpetunti hāpetuṃ antaradhāpetuṃ.
analyzed: mañjukā iti mañjubhāṇine madhurassare paṭibhāneyyakā iti paṭibhānavante bhuñjitvā pātabba yāgū iti paṭhamam bhuñjitvā pivitabba yāgu  tassa ati subhaddassa vuḍḍha pabbajitassa  ārādhita sāsane iti samāhita sāsane alanti samattho pāpo ti pāpa puggalo osakkāpetum ti hāpetum antaradhāpetum
translated: To the sweet-voiced, sweet-voiced Mañjuka, to the eloquent one, to the one with eloquence. He is able: he is capable. The bad person: the bad person. To be removed: to be taken away, to be made to disappear.

analyzed: naṭṭhā iti pisācena kira rukkha gaccha ādīnam kañcid eva mūlam chinditvā attano puttassa  dinnam yāva tam tassa hatthataḥ na vigacchati tāva saḥ tam padesam a dissamāna rūpaḥ
translated: “It is lost” : it seems that a spirit cut down the root of a tree or something else and gave it to his son.

original: vicarati. Yadā pana tasmiṃ kenaci acchinnabhāvena vā sativippavāsavasena vā naṭṭhe
analyzed: vicarati yadā pana tasmin kenacid acchinna bhāvena vā sati vippavāsa vasena vā naṭṭhe
translated: As long as it did not leave his son’s hand, he wandered about invisible in that place. But when it was lost either through someone’s cutting it down or through the son’s forgetting it,

analyzed: manussānam pi dissamāna rūpaḥ vicarati tam sandhāya āha mūle naṭṭhe pisāca sadisāḥ bhavissāma ati
translated: he wandered about visible even to human beings. With reference to this, it is said: “When the root is lost, we shall be like a spirit.”

original: Maṃ kāyasakkhiṃ katvāti taṃ paṭipadaṃ kāyena sacchikatavantaṃ tasmā tassā desanāya sakkhibhūtaṃ maṃ katvā. Paṭicchāpesi taṃ paṭicchāpanaṃ kassapasuttena dīpetabbaṃ.
analyzed: mam kāya sakkhim katvā ati tam paṭipadam kāyena sacchikatavantam tasmā tassā desanāya sakkhi bhūtam mam katvā paṭicchāpesi tam paṭicchāpanam kassapa suttena dīpetabbam
translated: “Making me a witness with my body” : making me a witness to that practice by experiencing it with my body, making me a witness to that teaching. The concealing should be illustrated by the Kassapa Sutta.

original: 233. Candanaghaṭikābāhullato candanacitakā.
analyzed: candana citakā
translated: The funeral pyre of sandalwood is called “sandalwood” because of the abundance of sandalwood.

original: Taṃ sutvāti taṃ āyasmatā anuruddhattherena vuttaṃ devatānaṃ adhippāyaṃ sutvā.
analyzed: tam sutvā iti tam āyasmatā anuruddhattherena vuttam devatānam adhippāyam sutvā
translated: “Having heard that” : having heard the intention of the deities spoken of by the venerable Anuruddha.

original: 234. Dasikatantaṃ vāti paliveṭhitaahatakāsikavatthānaṃ dasaṭhānena tantumattampi vā. Dārukkhandhaṃ vāti candanādicitakadārukkhandhaṃ vā.
analyzed: dasika tantam vāti paliveṭhita ahata kāsika vatthānam dasa ṭhānena tantumattam pi vā dāru khandham vāti candana ādi citaka dāru khandham vā
translated: The grass-rope: a rope made of ten strands of grass, or of grass-cloth strips. The log: a log of sandalwood, etc.

original: 235. Samudāyesu pavattavohārānaṃ avayavesu dissanato sarīrassa avayavabhūtāni aṭṭhīni “sarīrānī”ti vuttāni.
analyzed: samudāyesu pavatta vohārānam avayavesu dissanato sarīrassa avayava bhūtāni aṭṭhīni sarīrāni iti vuttāni
translated: The bones are called “the body” because they are found in the body as its parts, and because the conventional expression “body” is used for the parts in the case of wholes.

original: Na vippakiriṃsūti sarūpeneva ṭhitāti attho. “Sesā vippakiriṃsū”ti vatvā yathā pana tā vippakiṇṇā ahesuṃ, taṃ dassetuṃ “tatthā”tiādi vuttaṃ.
analyzed: na vippakiriṃsu iti sarūpena iva ṭhitā ati attho sesāḥ vippakiriṃsu iti vatvā yathā pana tāḥ vippakiṇṇāḥ ahesum tam dassetum tattha atiādi vuttam
translated: They did not scatter: the meaning is that they remained as they were. After saying “the rest scattered,” in order to show how they scattered, he said “therein,” etc.

original: Udakadhārā nikkhamitvā nibbāpesunti devatānubhāvena. Evaṃ mahatiyo bahū udakadhārā
analyzed: udaka dhārāḥ nikkhamitvā nibbāpesunti devatā anubhāvena evam mahatiyaḥ bahū udaka dhārā
translated: They extinguished it by issuing forth a stream of water: by the power of the deities.

original: kimatthāyāti āha “bhagavato citako mahanto”ti. Mahā hi so vīsaratanasatiko. Aṭṭhadantakehīti
analyzed: kim atthāya ati āha bhagavato citakaḥ mahanto ti mahā hi so aṭṭha dantakehi iti
translated: For what purpose? He said, “The Blessed One’s funeral pyre was large.” For it was fifty cubits in size.

original: naṅgalehi aṭṭheva hi nesaṃ dantasadisāni potthāni honti, tasmā “aṭṭhadantakānī”ti vuccati.
analyzed: naṅgalehi aṭṭha iva hi nesam danta sadisāni potthāni honti tasmā aṭṭhadantakāni iti vuccati
translated: With eight tusks: for they had eight tusks like those of an elephant.

original: Dhammakathāva pamāṇanti ativiya acchariyabbhutabhāvato passantānaṃ, suṇantānañca🔽sātisayaṃ pasādāvahabhāvato, savisesaṃ buddhānubhāvadīpanato. Parinibbutassa hi buddhassa
analyzed: dhamma kathā va pamāṇanti ativiya acchariya bhuta bhāvataḥ passantānam suṇantānam ca  sa atisayam pasāda āvaha bhāvataḥ sa visesam buddha anubhāva dīpanato parinibbutassa hi buddhassa
translated: Seeing that it is extremely wonderful and marvelous, and that it produces an abundance of faith in those who hear and understand it,🔽and that it reveals the Buddha’s power in a special way,🔽for the Buddha, the Blessed One, who has attained final Nibbana,

original: bhagavato evarūpo ānubhāvoti taṃ pavattiṃ kathentānaṃ dhammakathikānaṃ attano ñāṇabalānurūpaṃ
analyzed: bhagavataḥ evarūpaḥ ānubhāvaḥ ti tam pavattim kathentānam dhamma kathikānam attanaḥ ñāṇa bala anurūpam
translated: has such power. The discourse on the Dhamma, which is given by the preachers of the Dhamma in accordance with their own knowledge and ability,

original: pavattiyamānā dhammakathā evettha pamāṇaṃ vaṇṇetabbassa atthassa mahāvisayattā, tasmā
analyzed: pavattiyamānā dhammakathā eva ittha pamāṇam vaṇṇetabbassa atthassa mahā visaya ttā tasmā
translated: is the measure here in the description of that event, because the subject to be described is of great scope. Therefore🔽the intention is that the name of the chapter is “The Description.”🔽Having made a fragrant garland of four kinds of flowers,

original: vaṇṇanābhūmi nāmesāti adhippāyo. Catujjātiyagandhaparibhaṇḍaṃ kāretvāti tagarakuṅkumayavanapupphatamālapattāni
analyzed: vaṇṇanā bhūmi nāma isā ati adhippāyo catur jātiya gandha paribhaṇḍam kāretvā iti tagara kuṅkuma yavana puppha tamāla pattāni
translated: having ground together the fragrant wood, namely, agarwood, yellow sandalwood, and yavanapuppha, and having made a fragrant garland,

original: pisitvā katagandhena paribhaṇḍaṃ kāretvā. Khacitvāti tattha tattha olambanavasena
analyzed: pisitvā kata gandhena paribhaṇḍam kāretvā khacitvā ati tattha tattha olambana vasena
translated: having arranged it here and there in a hanging fashion,

original: racetvā, gandhavatthūni gahetvā ganthitamālā gandhadāmāni ratanāvaḷiyo ratanadāmāni.
analyzed: racetvā gandha vatthūni gahetvā ganthita mālāḥ gandha dāmāni ratana āvaḷiyaḥ ratana dāmāni
translated: having taken the fragrant materials, the fragrant garlands, the fragrant wreaths, the jeweled garlands, and the jeweled wreaths,

original: Bahikilañjaparikkhepassa, antosāṇiparikkhepassa karaṇena sāṇikilañjaparikkhepaṃ kāretvā.
analyzed: bahi kilañja parikkhepassa antosāṇi parikkhepassa karaṇena sāṇi kilañja parikkhepam kāretvā
translated: He had a bedstead made with a frame of bamboo and a mattress of jute, by making a frame of outer bamboo and a mattress of inner jute.

original: Vātaggāhiniyo paṭākā vātapaṭākā. Sarabharūpapādako pallaṅko sarabhamayapallaṅko,
analyzed: vātaggāhiniyaḥ paṭākā vātapaṭākā sarabha rūpa pādako pallaṅko sarabha maya pallaṅko
translated: The wind-catching banners are banners for catching the wind. A couch of tiger skin is a couch made of tiger skin.

original: tasmiṃ sarabhamayapallaṅke.🔽Sattihatthā purisā sattiyo taṃsahacaraṇato yathā “kuntā pacarantī”ti, tehi samantato
analyzed: tasmin sarabha maya pallaṅke  satti hatthā purisā sattiyaḥ yathā kuntā pacaranti iti tehi samantataḥ
translated: On that couch of tiger skin.🔽Men with spears are men with spears in their hands. As it is said, “spears are thrust in all around” , they are to be guarded by men with spears in their hands.

original: rakkhāpanaṃ pañcakaraṇanti āha “sattihatthehi purisehi parikkhipāpetvā”ti. Dhanūhīti🔽etthāpi eseva nayo. Sannāhagavacchikaṃ viya katvā nirantarāvaṭṭhitaārakkhasannāhena
analyzed: rakkhāpanam pañcakaraṇanti āha satti hatthehi purisehi parikkhipāpetvā ati dhanūhi iti  ettha api esā iva nayaḥ sannāha gavacchikam viya katvā nirantara avaṭṭhita ārakkha sannāhena
translated: With bows means🔽the same method applies here. With a net of bows means

original: gavacchijālaṃ viya katvā.
analyzed: gavacchijālam katvā
translated: like a net of cow’s hair, with a net of guards standing all around without a gap.

original: Sādhukīḷitanti saparahitaṃ sādhanaṭṭhena sādhū, tesaṃ kīḷitaṃ uḷārapuññapasavanato, samparāyikatthāvirodhikaṃ kīḷāvihāranti attho.
analyzed: sādhu kīḷitanti sa para hitam sādhana ṭṭhena sādhu tesam kīḷitam uḷāra puñña pasavanato samparāyika attha avirodhikam kīḷā vihāranti attho
translated: Well-played means well-played by them in the sense of accomplishment, being without hindrance, because of the great merit that is heard, it is a play-residence that does not conflict with the purpose of the next world.

original: Sarīradhātuvibhajanavaṇṇanā
analyzed: sarīra dhātu vibhajana vaṇṇanā
translated: The Description of the Distribution of the Relics

original: 236. Imināva niyāmenāti yena nīhārena mahātale nisinno kañci parihāraṃ akatvā kevalaṃ
analyzed: iminā ava niyāmena ati yena nīhārena mahā tale kañci parihāram a katvā kevalam
translated: “In this very way”: in this very manner, without making any excuses,

original: iminā niyāmeneva. Supinakoti dussupinako. Dukūladupaṭṭaṃ nivāsetvāti dve dukūlavatthāni
analyzed: iminā niyāmena iva supinakaḥ uti dussupinakaḥ dukūla dupaṭṭam nivāsetvā ati dve dukūla vatthāni
translated: just in this very way. “Bad dream”: a bad dream. “Having put on a double-cloth under robe”: having made two cloth-pieces of dukūla cloth

original: ekajjhaṃ katvā nivāsetvā. Evañhi tāni sokasamappitassāpi abhassitvā tiṭṭhanti.
analyzed: ekajjham katvā nivāsetvā evam hi tāni soka samappitassa api a bhassitvā tiṭṭhanti
translated: into one and put it on. For in this way they would shine even on one who is overcome with grief.

original: Abhisekasiñcakoti rajjābhiseke abhisekamaṅgalasiñcako uttamamaṅgalabhāvato. Visaññī
analyzed: abhiseka siñcako ti rajjā abhiseke abhiseka maṅgala siñcako uttama maṅgala bhāvataḥ visaññī
translated: “Anointing with the royal consecration”: the anointing with auspicious water at the consecration for kingship, because of its being the supreme auspicious thing. “Unconscious”

original: jāto yathā taṃ bhagavato guṇavisesāmatarasaññutāya avaṭṭhitapemo pothujjanikasaddhāya
analyzed: jātaḥ yathā tam bhagavataḥ guṇa visesa amatara saññu tāya avaṭṭhita pemaḥ pothujjanika saddhāya
translated: because his love, which had not been fixed on the taste of the Blessed One’s special qualities, was established in the faith of an ordinary person,

original: patiṭṭhitapasādo katūpakāratāya sañjanitacittamaddavo.
analyzed: patiṭṭhita pasādaḥ katu upakāra tāya sañjanita citta maddavaḥ
translated: and because of the pride of mind that had arisen in him through his gratitude.

original: Suvaṇṇabimbisakavaṇṇanti suviracita apassenasadisaṃ.
analyzed: suvaṇṇa bimbisaka vaṇṇam ti
translated: “The colour of gold or a bimba fruit”: like a well-fashioned mirror.

original: Kasmā panettha pāveyyakā pāḷiyaṃ sabbapacchato gahitā, kiṃ te kusinārāya āsannatarāpi sabbapacchato uṭṭhitā? Āma, sabbapacchato uṭṭhitāti dassetuṃ “tattha pāveyyakā”tiādi vuttaṃ.🔽Dhātupāsanatthanti satthu dhātūnaṃ payirupāsanāya. Nesaṃ pakkhā ahesuṃ “ñāyena tesaṃ santakā dhātuyo”ti.
analyzed: kasmā pana ittha pāveyyakā pāḷiyam sabba pacchataḥ gahitā kim te kusinārāya āsannatarā api sabba pacchataḥ uṭṭhitā āma sabba pacchataḥ uṭṭhitā iti dassetum tattha pāveyyaka iti ādi vuttaṃ  dhātu pāsana atthanti satthu dhātūnam payirupāsanāya nesam pakkhāḥ ahesum ñāyena tesam santakāḥ dhātuyaḥ ti
translated: Why are the Pāvā folk mentioned last in the text? Were they the last to rise up? —Yes, they were the last to rise up. —In order to show this, the text says: “There the Pāvā folk” .🔽For the worship of the relics: for the purpose of worshipping the relics of the Teacher. They were on their side, saying: “The relics are ours by right.”

original: 237. Doṇagajjitaṃ nāma avoca satthu avatthattayūpasaṃhitaṃ. Etadatthameva hi bhagavā🔽maggaṃ gacchanto “pacchato āgacchanto doṇo brāhmaṇo yāva me padavaḷañjaṃ passati,
analyzed: doṇagajjitam nāma avoca satthu etad attham eva hi bhagavā  maggam gacchanto pacchataḥ āgacchantaḥ doṇaḥ brāhmaṇaḥ yāva me pada vaḷañjam passati
translated: The “clatter of the bowl” was the sound of the bowl when it was struck by the Teacher’s staff. For this very purpose the Blessed One,

original: tāva mā vigacchatū”ti adhiṭṭhāya aññatarasmiṃ rukkhamūle nisīdi. Doṇopi kho brāhmaṇo
analyzed: tāva mā vigacchatu iti adhiṭṭhāya aññatarasmim rukkha mūle nisīdi doṇo api kho brāhmaṇaḥ

analyzed: imāni sa devake loke agga puggalassa padāni iti sallakkhento pada anusārena satthu santikam
translated: ” Doṇa, too, thinking: “These are the footprints of the foremost person in the world, with the wheel-mark,” following the footprints,

original: upagacchi, satthāpissa dhammaṃ desesi, tenapi so bhagavati niviṭṭhasaddho ahosi.
analyzed: upagacchi satthā api ssa dhammam desesi tena api so bhagavati niviṭṭha saddhaḥ ahosi
translated: He approached the Teacher, who taught him the Dhamma. He too became a faithful lay disciple of the Blessed One.

original: Etadavoca, kiṃ avocāti āha “suṇantu…pe… avocā”ti.
analyzed: etat avoca kim avoca iti āha avoca iti
translated: He said this: What did he say? He said: “Listen, friends, to me as I tell you.

original: Kāyena ekasannipātā vācāya ekavacanā abhinnavacanā evaṃ samaggā hotha. Tassa panidaṃ kāraṇanti āha “sammodamānā”ti. Tenāha “cittenāpi aññamaññaṃ sammodamānā hothā”ti.
analyzed: kāyena eka sannipātāḥ vācāya eka vacanāḥ abhinna vacanāḥ evam samaggāḥ hotha tassa pana idam kāraṇanti āha sammodamānā iti tena āha cittena api aññamaññam sammodamānāḥ hotha ati
translated: Be united in body, united in speech, united in thought. And the reason for this is that you are united in body, united in speech, united in thought. Therefore he said: “Be united in mind also.”

original: 238. Tato tato samāgatasaṅghānanti tato tato attano vasanaṭṭhānato samāgantvā sannipatitabhāvena
analyzed: tatas tatas tatas tatas tatas attanaḥ vasanaṭṭhānato samāgantvā sannipatita bhāvena
translated: From here and there, a united Sangha: from here and there, from their own dwelling places, they have come together, assembled,

original: samāgatasaṅghānaṃ. Tathā samāpatitasamūhabhāvena samāgatagaṇānaṃ. Vacanasampaṭicchanena paṭissuṇitvā.
analyzed: samāgata saṅghānam tathā samāpatita samūha bhāvena samāgata gaṇānam vacana sampaṭicchanena paṭissuṇitvā
translated: a united Sangha. In the same way, a united group, a united multitude. Having assented by word of mouth,

original: Dhātuthūpapūjāvaṇṇanā
analyzed: dhātu thūpa pūjā vaṇṇanā
translated: The Description of the Worship of the Relics and the Cetiyas

original: 239. Yakkhaggāho devatāveso. Khipitakaṃ dhātukkhobhaṃ uppādetvā khipitakarogo. Arocako āhārassa aruccanarogo.
analyzed: yakkha ggāhaḥ devatā vesaḥ khipitakam dhātu kkhobham uppādetvā khipitaka rogaḥ arocakaḥ āhārassa aruccana rogo
translated: The seizure of the yakkha, the possession by the devatā, the throwing out, the disturbance of the relics, the arising of the throwing out disease, the anorexia, the disease of not wanting food,

original: Sattamadivaseti sattavassasattamāsato parato sattame divase. Balānurūpenāti vibhavabalānurūpena.
analyzed: sattama divasa iti paratas sattame divase bala anurūpena ati vibhava bala anurūpena
translated: On the seventh day means after seven years and seven months, on the seventh day. According to their strength means according to their wealth and power.

original: Pacchā saṅgītikārakāti dutiyaṃ tatiyaṃ saṅgītikārakā. Dhātūnaṃ antarāyaṃ disvāti
analyzed: pacchā saṅgīti kārakā ati dutiyam tatiyam saṅgīti kārakā antarāyam
translated: Afterwards means after the second and third councils. Seeing the danger to the relics means

original: tattha tattha cetiye yathāpatiṭṭhāpitabhāveneva ṭhitānaṃ dhātūnaṃ micchādiṭṭhikānaṃ🔽vasena antarāyaṃ disvā, mahādhātunidhānena sammadeva rakkhitānaṃ anāgate asokena
analyzed: tattha tattha cetiye yathā patiṭṭhāpita bhāvena iva ṭhitānam dhātūnam micchādiṭṭhikānam  vasena antarāyam disvā mahādhātu nidhānena sammad eva rakkhitānam anāgate asokena
translated: seeing the danger to the relics placed here and there in the shrines, through the wrong views of the people.

original: dhammaraññā tato uddharitvā vitthāritabhāve kate sadevakassa lokassa hitasukhāvahabhāvañca
analyzed: dhammaraññā tatas uddharitvā vitthārita bhāve kate sa devakassa lokassa hita sukha āvaha bhāvañca
translated: Seeing that they were well protected by the great treasure of relics, and that in the future they would be taken out by King Asoka, the righteous, and spread about, and that they would be for the welfare and happiness of the world with its gods,

original: disvāti adhippāyo. Paricaraṇamattamevāti gahetvā paricaritabbadhātumattameva. Rājūnaṃ
analyzed: disvā iti adhippāyaḥ paricaraṇa mattam eva ati gahetvā paricaritabba dhātumattam eva
translated: this is the intention. Only the service means only the relics to be taken and served. The kings

original: hatthe ṭhapetvā, na cetiyesu. Tathā hi pacchā asokamahārājā cetiyesu dhātūnaṃ na labhati.
analyzed: hatthe ṭhapetvā na cetiyesu tathā hi pacchā asoka mahā rājā cetiyesu dhātūnam na labhati
translated: placed them in their hands, not in the shrines. For this reason, later, King Asoka the Great did not get the relics from the shrines.

original: Purimaṃ purimaṃ katassa gaṇhanayogyaṃ pacchimaṃ pacchimaṃ kārento aṭṭha aṭṭha haricandanādimaye
analyzed: purimam purimam katassa gaṇhana yogyam pacchimam pacchimam kārentaḥ aṭṭha aṭṭha haricandana ādi maye
translated: He made eight of them of yellow sandal-wood, and so on.🔽In the case of the ruby, etc., the same method was followed.

original: karaṇḍe ca thūpe ca kāresi. Lohitacandanamayādīsupi eseva nayo. Maṇikaraṇḍesūti lohitaṅkamasāragallaphalikamaye🔽ṭhapetvā avasesamaṇivicittakesu karaṇḍesu.
analyzed: karaṇḍe ca thūpe ca lohita candana maya ādīsupi eṣa iva nayaḥ maṇi karaṇḍesu iti  ṭhapetvā avasesa maṇi vicittakesu karaṇḍesu
translated: In the case of the jewel caskets, he made eight of them of ruby, of sapphire, of crystal, of emerald, of silver, of gold, of pearl, and of coral.

original: Thūpārāmacetiyappamāṇanti devānaṃpiyatissamahārājena kāritacetiyappamāṇaṃ.🔽Mālā mā milāyantūti “yāva asoko dhammarājā bahi cetiyāni kāretuṃ ito dhātuyo uddharissati,
analyzed: thūpa ārāma cetiya ppamāṇam ti devānaṃpiya tissa mahārājena kārita cetiya ppamāṇam  mālāḥ mā milāyantu uti yāva asokaḥ dhamma rājā bahi cetiyāni kāretuṃ itas dhātuyaḥ uddharissati
translated: The size of the shrines was that of the Thūpārāma Shrine built by King Devānaṃpiya Tissa.🔽The garlands were not allowed to fade until King Asoka had taken out relics from the shrines and had built shrines outside the city.

original: tāva mālā mā milāyantū”ti adhiṭṭhahitvā. Āviñchanarajjuyanti aggaḷāviñchanarajjuyaṃ.
analyzed: tāva mālāḥ mā milāyantu iti adhiṭṭhahitvā āviñchana rajjuyanti aggaḷa āviñchana rajjuyan
translated: The bolts were the bolts for opening the doors.

original: Kuñcikamuddikanti dvāravivaraṇatthaṃ kuñcikañceva muddikañca.
analyzed: kuñcika muddikanti dvāra vivaraṇa attham kuñcikam ca iva muddikam ca
translated: The keys and the labels were the keys and the labels for opening the doors.

original: Vāḷasaṅghātayantanti kukkulaṃ paṭibhayadassanaṃ aññamaññapaṭibaddhagamanāditāya saṅghāṭitarūpakayantaṃ
analyzed: vāḷa saṅghāta yantam ti kukkulam paṭibhaya dassanam aññamañña paṭibaddha gamana āditāya saṅghāṭita rūpaka yantam
translated: The iron fence was a fence of iron spikes, terrible to behold, with the spikes fastened together in such a way that they could be moved only by being pushed from one side to the other.

original: yojesi. Tenāha “kaṭṭharūpakānī”tiādi. Āṇiyā bandhitvāti anekakaṭṭharūpavicittayantaṃ
analyzed: yojesi tena āha kaṭṭharūpakāni itiādi āṇiyā bandhitvā iti
translated: He yoked them. Hence he said “the ploughs, etc.”🔽Having fastened them with the yoke-strap, etc.

original: attano devānubhāvena ekāya eva āṇiyā bandhitvā vissakammo devalokameva gato. “Samantato”tiādi
analyzed: attanaḥ deva anubhāvena ekāya eva āṇiyā bandhitvā vissakammaḥ deva lokam eva gataḥ samantataḥ tiādi
translated: He had it done. Hence he said: “The wooden figures” , etc. Having bound it with a single iron chain, he went to the deva-world. “All round” , etc.

original: pana tasmiṃ dhātunidāne ajātasattuno kiccavisesānuṭṭhānadassanaṃ.
analyzed: pana tasmim dhātu nidāne ajāta sattuno kicca visesa anuṭṭhāna dassanam
translated: is the showing of the special work done by Ajātasattu in the case of the treasure.

original: “Asukaṭṭhāne nāma dhātunidhāna”nti raññā pucchite “tasmiṃ sannipāte visesalābhino🔽nāhesu”nti keci. “Attānaṃ nigūhitvā tassa vuḍḍhatarassa vacanaṃ nissāya vīmaṃsanto
analyzed: asuka ṭṭhāne nāma dhātu nidhānan ti raññā pucchite tasmin sannipāte visesa lābhino  na ahesun ti keci attānam nigūhitvā tassa vuḍḍhatarassa vacanam nissāya vīmaṃsantaḥ
translated: When the king asked: “In such and such a place, the treasure is hidden,” some said: “In that assembly, there were those who had attained distinction.🔽Having concealed themselves, they will know, relying on the words of the elder who is older than they are.

original: jānissatīti na kathesu”nti apare. Yakkhadāsaketi upahārādividhinā devatāvesanake bhūtāviggāhake.

analyzed: dvinnam dvinnam antare ekekā hutvā ṭhitā
translated: ‘Between the walls’: between the two walls. They stood there as single palm-trees.

original: Chekoti paṭu suvisado, so cassa paṭubhāvo manosāroti āha “sundaro”ti. Rañjetunti
analyzed: cheko ti paṭu su visadaḥ saḥ ca sassa paṭu bhāvaḥ manosāro ti āha sundaraḥ ti rañjetunti
translated: ‘Clever’: skilled, very clever. His skill is ‘beautiful’ as ‘mind-born’.

original: rāgaṃ uppādetuṃ. Khamatevāti rocateva. Na bībhacchetīti na tajjeti, sotasukhabhāvato
analyzed: rāgam uppādetum khamatā iva ati rocatā iva na bībhaccheti iti na tad jā iti
translated: ‘To delight’: to arouse passion. ‘He approved’: he liked it. ‘He was not afraid’: he was not frightened. Because of the pleasure of hearing,

original: piyāyitabbo ca hoti. Kumbhathuṇadaddarikādi ekatalaṃ tūriyaṃ. Ubhayatalaṃ pākaṭameva.
analyzed: ca hoti kumbha thuṇa daddarika ādi eka talam tūriyam ubhaya talam pākaṭam eva
translated: he became fond of it. A drum, a tabor, a flute, etc., are one-sided instruments. Two-sided instruments are obvious.

original: Sabbato pariyonaddhaṃ caturassaambaṇakaṃ, paṇavādi ca. Vaṃsādīti ādi-saddena saṅkhādikaṃ
analyzed: sabbatas pariyonaddham catu rassa ambaṇakam paṇava ādi ca vaṃsa ādi iti ādi saddena saṅkhā ādikam
translated: A four-sided instrument is completely enclosed, like a paṇava drum, etc. ‘Bamboo instruments, etc.’: the word ‘etc.’ includes conch shells, etc.

original: saṅgaṇhāti. Sumucchitassāti suṭṭhu pariyattassa. Pamāṇeti nātidaḷhanātisithilatāsaṅkhāte
analyzed: saṅgaṇhāti su mucchitassa ati suṭṭhu pariyattassa pamāṇe iti na ati daḷhana ati sithila tā saṅkhāte
translated: ‘Well-tuned’: well-regulated. ‘In measure’: not too tight or too loose,

original: majjhime mucchanappamāṇe. Hatthaṃ vā pādaṃ vā cāletvāti hatthalayapādalaye sajjetvā.
analyzed: majjhime mucchana ppamāṇe hattham vā pādam vā cāletvā ati hattha laya pāda laye sajjetvā
translated: but in the middle measure called ‘slackening’. ‘Having moved his hand or foot’: having prepared the hand-movement or foot-movement.

original: Naccantāti sākhānaccaṃ naccantā.
analyzed: naccantā ati sākhā anaccam naccantā
translated: ‘They danced’: they danced the branch dance.

original: Cakkaratanavaṇṇanā
translated: The Description of the Wheel Treasure

original: 243. Uposathaṃ vuccati aṭṭhaṅgasamannāgataṃ sabbadivasesu gahaṭṭhehi rakkhitabbasīlaṃ,
analyzed: uposatham vuccati aṭṭhaṅga samannāgatam sabba divasesu gaha ṭṭhehi rakkhitabba sīlam
translated: Uposatha is the virtue to be observed on all days by householders, consisting in the eight precepts with the addition of abstinence from high beds, etc.,

original: samādānavasena taṃ tassa atthīti uposathiko, tassa uposathikassa. Tenāha “samādinnauposathaṅgassā”ti.
analyzed: samādāna vasena tam tassa atthi iti uposathikaḥ tassa uposathikassa tena āha samādinna auposathaṅgassa iti
translated: and he who has undertaken it is called “one who observes the uposatha” .

original: Tadāti tasmiṃ kāle. Kasmiṃ pana kāleti? Yasmiṃ kāle cakkavattibhāvasaṃvattaniyadānasīlādipuññasambhārasamudāgamasampanno
analyzed: tadā ati tasmin kāle kasmin pana kāle iti yasmin kāle cakkavatti bhāva saṃvattaniya dāna sīla ādi puñña sambhāra samudāgama sampannaḥ
translated: “At that time”: at that time when a being who is endowed with the requisites of merit consisting in giving, virtue, etc., which lead to the state of a wheel-turning monarch,

original: pūritacakkavattivatto kāladīpadesavisesapaccājātiyā ceva kularūpabhogādhipateyyādiguṇavisesasampattiyā🔽ca tadanurūpe attabhāve ṭhito hoti, tasmiṃ kāle. Tādise hi kāle cakkavattibhāvī purisaviseso
analyzed: pūrita cakkavatti vatto ca iva kula rūpa bhoga ādhipateyya ādi guṇa visesa sampattiyā  ca tad anurūpe attabhāve ṭhitaḥ hoti tasmin kāle tādise hi kāle cakkavatti bhāvī purisa visesaḥ
translated: and who has fulfilled the duties of a wheel-turning monarch, is established in a suitable existence endowed with the special qualities of time, country, family, physical appearance, wealth, sovereignty, etc.,

original: yathāvuttaguṇasamannāgato rājā khattiyo muddhāvasitto visuddhasīlo anuposathaṃ satasahassavissajjanādinā
analyzed: yathāvutta guṇa samannāgataḥ rājā khattiyaḥ muddhāvasittaḥ visuddha sīlaḥ anuposatham sata sahassa vissajjana ādinā
translated: for at that time a being who is destined to become a wheel-turning monarch, and who is endowed with the special qualities mentioned above, is a king, a warrior, a consecrated nobleman, a person of pure virtue, who practices the right way of life by giving away a hundred thousand pieces of gold, etc., on the uposatha day,

original: sammāpaṭipattiṃ paṭipajjati, na yadā cakkaratanaṃ uppajjati, tadā eva. Ime ca visesā
analyzed: sammāpaṭipattim paṭipajjati na yadā cakka ratanam uppajjati tadā eva ime ca visesā
translated: and not only when the wheel-gem appears.

original: sabbacakkavattīnaṃ sādhāraṇavasena vuttā. Tenāha “pātova…pe… dhammatā”ti. Bodhisattānaṃ
analyzed: sabba cakkavattīnam sādhāraṇa vasena vuttā tena āha pātovape dhamma tā iti bodhisattānam
translated: and it is said that this is the common lot of all Wheel-turning Monarchs. That is why it is said, ‘From the very first … the nature of things that it should be so’ .

original: pana cakkavattibhāvāvahaguṇāpi cakkavattiguṇāpi sātisayāva honti.
analyzed: pana cakkavatti bhāvāvaha guṇā api cakkavatti guṇā api sa atisayā ava honti
translated: But the qualities that bring about the state of a Wheel-turning Monarch and the qualities of a Wheel-turning Monarch are quite exceptional in the case of Bodhisattas.

original: Vuttappakārapuññakammapaccayanti cakkavattibhāvāvahadānadamasaṃyamādipuññakammahetukaṃ.
analyzed: vutta ppakāra puñña kamma paccayanti cakkavatti bhāva āvaha dāna dama saṃyama ādi puñña kamma hetukam
translated: Due to the kind of kamma already described: due to the kamma consisting in the giving, taming, restraint, etc., that brings about the state of a Wheel-turning Monarch.

original: Nīlamaṇisaṅghātasadisanti indanīlamaṇisañcayasamānaṃ. Dibbānubhāvayuttattāti dassaneyyatā,
analyzed: nīla maṇi saṅghāta sadisanti inda nīla maṇi sañcaya samānam dibba anubhāva yutta tā ati dassaneyya tā
translated: Like a mass of sapphires: like a heap of indanīla sapphires. Endowed with divine properties: it is lovely to look at,

original: manuññaghosatā, ākāsagāmitā, obhāsavissajjanā, appaṭighātatā, rañño icchitatthanipphattikāraṇatāti
analyzed: manuñña ghosa tā ākāsa gāmi tā obhāsa vissajjanā appaṭighāta tā rañño icchitattha nipphatti kāraṇa tā ati
translated: it has a pleasant sound, it travels through the air, it emits light, it is unobstructed, and it fulfills the king’s wishes.

original: evamādīhi dibbasadisehi ānubhāvehi samannāgatattā, etena dibbaṃ viyāti dibbanti dasseti.
analyzed: evamādīhi dibba sadisehi ānubhāvehi samannāgata ttā etena dibbam viyāti dibbanti dasseti
translated: It is called divine because it is endowed with properties similar to those of the divine.🔽For it is not included in the divine world.

original: Na hi taṃ devalokapariyāpannaṃ. Sahassaṃ arā etassāti vā sahassāraṃ. Sabbehi ākārehīti
analyzed: na hi tam deva loka pariyāpannam sahassam arāḥ etassa ati vā sahassa aram sabbehi ākārehi iti
translated: With a thousand spokes: with a thousand rims.

original: sabbehi sundarehi paripuṇṇāvayave lakkhaṇasampanne cakke icchitabbehi ākārehi. Paripūranti
analyzed: sabbehi sundarehi paripuṇṇa avayave lakkhaṇa sampanne cakke icchitabbehi ākārehi paripūranti
translated: With all its aspects: with all its aspects that are lovely, complete in all its parts, endowed with the characteristics, and desirable in a wheel.

original: paripuṇṇaṃ, sā cassā pāripūriṃ idāneva vitthāressati.🔽Panāḷīti chiddaṃ. Suddhasiniddhadantapantiyā nibbivarāyāti adhippāyo. Tassā pana
analyzed: paripuṇṇam sā ca assā pāripūrim idānā iva vitthāressati  panāḷī iti chiddam suddha siniddha danta pantiyā nibbivarāya ati adhippāyaḥ tassā pana
translated: If it is complete, she will now explain the complete one.🔽The meaning intended is: a hole, a pure, clean, and bright one.

original: panāḷiyā samantato passassa rajatamayattā sārarajatamayā vuttā. Yasmā cassa cakkassa
analyzed: panāḷiyā samantataḥ passassa rajata maya ttā sāra rajata mayā vuttā yasmā ca ssa cakkassa
translated: But because it is made of silver all round, it is said to be made of solid silver.

original: rathacakkassa viya antobhāvo nāma natthi, tasmā vuttaṃ “ubhosupi bāhirantesū”ti.🔽Kataparikkhepā hoti panāḷīti yojanā. Nābhipanāḷiparikkhepapaṭṭesūti nābhiparikkhepapaṭṭe
analyzed: ratha cakkassa viya antobhāvaḥ nāma natthi tasmā vuttam ubhosu pi bāhirantesu iti  kata parikkhepā hoti panāḷī iti yojanā nābhi panāḷi parikkhepa paṭṭesu iti nābhi parikkhepa paṭṭe
translated: But because there is no hollow space inside it like a chariot wheel, it is said, “on both the outside and the inside.”🔽The construction is: the hole is bounded by the rim.

original: ceva nābhiyā panāḷiparikkhepapaṭṭe ca.🔽Tesanti arānaṃ. Ghaṭakā nāma alaṅkārabhūtā khuddakapuṇṇaghaṭā. Tathā maṇikā nāma
analyzed: ca iva nābhiyā panāḷi parikkhepa paṭṭe ca  ghaṭakā nāma alaṅkāra bhūtā khuddaka puṇṇa ghaṭā tathā maṇikā nāma
translated: On the rim that bounds the navel and on the rim that bounds the hole.🔽The spokes are the spokes of the wheel.🔽The knobs are small ornamental jars. So too, the jewels are strings of pearls.

original: muttāvaḷikā. Paricchedalekhā tassa tassa paricchedadassanavasena ṭhitā paricchinnalekhā.
analyzed: muttāvaḷikā pariccheda lekhā tassa tassa pariccheda dassana vasena ṭhitā paricchinna lekhā
translated: The lines are the lines that stand as the delimitation of each part.🔽The word “etc.” includes the garland work, etc.

original: Ādi-saddena mālākammādiṃ saṅgaṇhāti. Suvibhattānevāti aññamaññaṃ asaṃkiṇṇattā suṭṭhu vibhattāni.
analyzed: ādi saddena mālā kamma ādim saṅgaṇhāti su vibhattāni eva ati aññamaññam a saṃkiṇṇa ttā suṭṭhu vibhattāni
translated: Very well divided: well divided because they are not mixed up with each other.

original: “Surattā”tiādīsu surattaggahaṇena mahānāmavaṇṇataṃ paṭikkhipati, suddhaggahaṇena🔽saṃṅkiliṭṭhataṃ, siniddhaggahaṇena lūkhataṃ. Kāmaṃ tassa cakkaratanassa nemimaṇḍalaṃ
analyzed: su ratta ati ādīsu su ratta ggahaṇena mahānāma vaṇṇa tam paṭikkhipati suddha ggahaṇena  siniddha gahaṇena lūkha tam kāmam tassa cakka ratanassa nemi maṇḍalam
translated: In the passage beginning “smooth” , the word “smooth” excludes the description of the wheel-gem given by Mahānāma,🔽the word “pure” excludes its being defiled, and the word “polished” excludes its being rough.🔽Although the rim-circle of that wheel-gem is born without joints,

original: asandhikameva nibbattaṃ, sabbatthakameva pana kevalaṃ pavāḷavaṇṇena ca sobhatīti
analyzed: asandhikam eva nibbattam sabbatthakam eva pana kevalam pavāḷa vaṇṇena ca sobhati iti
translated: it is nevertheless beautiful with the colour of coral everywhere.🔽Therefore, in the place where the joints would be in an ordinary wheel,

original: pakaticakkassa sandhiyuttaṭṭhāne surattasuvaṇṇapaṭṭādimayāhi vaṭṭaparicchedalekhāhi
analyzed: pakati cakkassa sandhi yutta ṭṭhāne su ratta suvaṇṇa paṭṭa ādi mayāhi vaṭṭa pariccheda lekhāhi
translated: it appears as if it has joints because of the lines that form the rim, which are made of smooth gold, etc.

original: paññāyamānāhi sasandhikā viya dissantīti āha “sandhīsu panassā”tiādi.
analyzed: paññāyamānāhi sa sandhikāḥ viya dissanti iti āha sandhīsu panassa atiādi
translated: That is why the commentator says, “But in the joints, etc.”

original: Nemimaṇḍalapiṭṭhiyanti nemimaṇḍalassa piṭṭhipadese. Ākāsacāribhāvato hissa tattha
analyzed: nemi maṇḍala piṭṭhiyanti nemi maṇḍalassa piṭṭhi padese ākāsa cāri bhāvataḥ hissa tattha
translated: On the back of the rim-circle : on the back of the rim-circle. For the coral staff that holds the wind🔽is there because it moves through the air.

original: vātaggāhī pavāḷadaṇḍo hoti. Dasannaṃ dasannaṃ arānaṃ antareti dasannaṃ dasannaṃ arānaṃ
analyzed: vātaggāhī pavāḷa daṇḍaḥ hoti dasannam dasannam arānam antareti dasannam dasannam arānam
translated: Between each ten spokes: in the place between each ten spokes.

original: antare samīpe padese. Chiddamaṇḍalakhacitoti maṇḍalasaṇṭhānachiddavicitto. Sukusalasamannāhatassāti
analyzed: antare samīpe padese chidda maṇḍala khacito ti maṇḍala saṇṭhāna chidda vicittaḥ su kusala samannāhatassa ati
translated: Studded with the designs of stars: marked with the designs of stars in the form of holes arranged in the shape of circles.🔽Well-fashioned: well-made.

original: suṭṭhu kusalena sippinā pahatassa, vāditassāti attho. Vaggūti manoramo. Rajanīyoti
analyzed: suṭṭhu kusalena sippinā pahatassa vāditassa ati atthaḥ vaggu iti manoramaḥ rajanīyaḥ ti
translated: Delightful, is the meaning.🔽Delight-producing, is the meaning.🔽Delightful to the ear, is the meaning.

original: suṇantānaṃ rāguppādako. Kamanīyoti kanto. Samosaritakusumadāmāti olambitasugandhakusumadāmā.
analyzed: rāga uppādako kamanīyaḥ ti kanto samosarita kusuma dāmā ati olambita sugandha kusuma dāmā
translated: A garland of flowers hanging down, is the meaning.🔽At the edge of the rim, is the meaning.

original: Nemiparikkhepassāti nemipariyantaparikkhepassa. Nābhipanāḷiyā dvinnaṃ passānaṃ vasena
analyzed: nemi parikkhepassa ati nemi pariyanta parikkhepassa nābhi panāḷiyāḥ dvinnam passānam vasena
translated: The navel-pole has two sides,🔽thus it is said ‘the two navel-poles’.🔽For it is only one navel-pole.🔽By which two mouths,

original: “dvinnampi nābhipanāḷīna”nti vuttaṃ. Ekā eva hi sā panāḷi. Yehīti yehi dvīhi mukhehi.🔽Puna yehīti yehi muttakalāpehi.
analyzed: dvinnam pi nābhi panāḷīnam ti vuttam ekā eva hi sā panāḷi yehi iti yehi dvīhi mukhehi  puna yehi iti yehi mutta kalāpehi
translated: and by which two urine-ducts,

original: Odhāpayamānanti sotuṃ avahitāni kurumānaṃ.
analyzed: odhāpayamānanti sotum avahitāni kurumānam
translated: it was causing to be heard, making them attentive to hear.🔽The moon in front, the Wheel-Treasure behind,

original: Cando purato cakkaratanaṃ pacchāti evaṃ pubbāpariyena pubbāparabhāvena.
analyzed: cando puratas cakkaratanam pacchā ati evam pubbāpariyena pubba apara bhāvena
translated: thus by the east and west, by the eastern and western parts.🔽In the royal compound, is the meaning.🔽In the city of Anurādhapura, is the meaning.🔽Like the northern lion-protector, is the meaning.

original: Antepurassāti anurādhapure rañño antepurassa. Uttarasīhapañjarasadiseti tadā rañño🔽pāsāde tādisassa uttaradisāya sīhapañjarassa labbhamānattā vuttaṃ. Sukhena sakkāti
analyzed: antepurassa ati anurādhapure raññaḥ antepurassa uttara sīha pañjara sadisā iti tadā raññaḥ 🔽pāsāde tādisassa uttara disāya sīha pañjarassa labbhamāna ttā vuttam sukhena sakkā iti
translated: For at that time in the king’s palace there was a lion-protector like that in the northern direction,

original: kiñci anāruhitvā, sarīrañca anullaṅghitvā yathāṭhiteneva hatthena pupphamuṭṭhiyo🔽khipitvā sukhena sakkā hoti pūjetuṃ.
analyzed: kiñci an āruhitvā sarīrañca an ullaṅghitvā yathā aṭhitena iva hatthena puppha muṭṭhiyaḥ  khipitvā sukhena sakkā hoti pūjetum
translated: Without climbing up anything or jumping down from anything, he can easily worship by throwing handfuls of flowers with his hand as it is.

original: Nānāvirāgaratanappabhāsamujjalanti nānāvidhavicittavaṇṇaratanobhāsapabhassaraṃ. Ākāsaṃ abbhuggantvā pavatteti āgantvā ṭhitaṭṭhānato upari ākāsaṃ abbhuggantvā pavatte.
analyzed: nānā virāga ratana ppabhāsam ujjalanti nānāvidha vicitta vaṇṇa ratana ubhāsa pabhassaram ākāsam abbhut gantvā pavatteti āgantvā ṭhita ṭṭhānataḥ upari ākāsam abbhut gantvā pavatte
translated: It shines with the radiance of various gems and jewels. It shines with the radiance of various beautiful gems and jewels. It moves about in the sky. It moves about in the sky after rising up from the place where it was standing.

original: 244. Rājāyuttāti rañño kicce āyuttakapurisā.
analyzed: rāja āyuttā ati rañño kicce āyuttaka purisā
translated: The king’s men are the men who are employed in the king’s work.

original: Sineruṃ vāmapassena katvā tassa dhurataraṃ gacchanto “vāmapassena sineruṃ pahāyā”ti vuttaṃ.
analyzed: sinerum vāma passena katvā tassa dhurataram gacchantaḥ vāma passena sinerum pahāya iti vuttam
translated: Having made Sineru to his left, he goes further away from it, “having left Sineru to his left.”

original: Vinibbedhenāti tiriyaṃ vinivijjhanavasena. Sannivesakkhamoti khandhāvārasannivesayogyo. Sulabhāhārupakaraṇoti sukheneva laddhabbadhaññagorasadārutiṇādibhojanasādhano.
analyzed: vinibbedhena ati tiriyam vinivijjhana vasena sannivesa kkhamaḥ ti khandhāvāra sannivesa yogyaḥ sulabha āhāra upakaraṇaḥ ti sukhena iva laddhabba dhañña gorasa dāru tiṇa ādi bhojana sādhanaḥ
translated: It is penetrable by going through it. It is capable of being occupied by the occupation of the region of the body. It is easy to get the requisites of life. It is easy to get the requisites of life such as rice, barley, meat, vegetables, and so on.

original: Paracakkanti parassa rañño senā, āṇā vā.
analyzed: paracakkanti parassa rañño senāḥ āṇāḥ vā
translated: The army of another is the army of another king or his command.

original: Āgamananandanoti āgamanena nandijanano. Gamanena socetīti gamanasocano. Upakappethāti
analyzed: āgamana nandano ti āgamanena nandi jananaḥ gamanena soceti iti gamana socanaḥ upakappetha ati
translated: “Delighting in coming” : delighting in coming. “Grieving at going” : grieving at going. “They should be brought together” :

original: uparūpari kappetha, saṃvidahatha upanethāti attho. Upaparikkhitvāti hetutopi sabhāvatopi🔽phalatopi diṭṭhadhammikasamparāyikādiādīnavatopi vīmaṃsitvā. Vibhāventi paññāya atthaṃ
analyzed: upari upari kappetha saṃvidahatha upanetha ati atthaḥ upaparikkhitvā ti hetutaḥ pi sabhāvataḥ pi  phalataḥ api diṭṭhadhammika samparāyika ādi ādīnavataḥ api vīmaṃsitvā vibhāventi paññāya atthaṃ
translated: they should be brought together in succession, they should be brought together in combination, is the meaning. “Having investigated” : having investigated by way of cause, by way of individual essence,

original: vibhūtaṃ karontīti vibhāvino, paññavanto. Anuyantāti anuvattakā, anuvattakabhāveneva,🔽pana rañño ca mahānubhāvena te jigucchanavasena pāpato anoramantāpi ekacce ottappavasena
analyzed: vibhūtam karonti iti vibhāvino paññavantaḥ anuyantā ati anuvattakāḥ anuvattaka bhāvena iva  pana raññaḥ ca mahā anubhāvena te jigucchana vasena pāpataḥ anoramantā api ekacce ottappa vasena
translated: by way of fruit, by way of the danger in this world and the world beyond, etc. “They are called the wise” : they are called the wise because they make the meaning clear by means of wisdom. “The followers” : the followers, the followers by way of following,

original: oramantīti veditabbaṃ.
analyzed: oramanti iti veditabbam
translated: but it should be understood that some of them, out of disgust for evil, do not transgress out of fear of the king’s great power, while others do so out of fear of the evil states themselves.

original: Ogacchamānanti osīdantaṃ. Yojanamattanti vitthārato yojanamattaṃ padesaṃ. Gambhīrabhāvena
analyzed: ogacchamānanti osīdantam vitthārataḥ yojana mattam padesam gambhīra bhāvena
translated: “Sinking” : sinking down. “A distance of a league” : a distance of a league in breadth. But in depth it sinks down as far as the earth is visible.

original: pana yathā bhūmi dissati, evaṃ ogacchati. Tenāha “mahāsamuddatala”ntiādi. Ante cakkaratanaṃ
analyzed: pana yathā bhūmi dissati evam ogacchati tena āha mahā samudda talanti ādi ante cakka ratanam
translated: Therefore it is said, “the bottom of the ocean,” etc. “The wheel-treasure at the end” :

original: udakena senāya anajjhottharaṇatthaṃ. Puratthimo mahāsamuddo pariyanto etassāti puratthimamahāsamuddapariyanto,
analyzed: udakena senāya an ajjhottharaṇa attham puratthimaḥ mahā samuddaḥ pariyantaḥ etassa ati puratthima mahā samudda pariyantaḥ
translated: The eastern ocean is the limit of this, thus it is the eastern ocean limit.

original: taṃ puratthimamahāsamuddapariyantaṃ, puratthimamahāsamuddaṃ pariyantaṃ katvāti attho.
analyzed: tam puratthima mahā samudda pariyantam puratthima mahā samuddam pariyantam katvā iti attho
translated: That eastern ocean limit, the eastern ocean being the limit, thus is the meaning.

original: Cāturantāyāti catusamuddantāya, puratthimadisādicatukoṭṭhāsantāya vā. Sobhayamānaṃ
analyzed: cāturantāya ati catu samuddantāya puratthima disā ādi catu koṭṭhāsantāya vā
translated: The four continents: the four oceans’ continents, or the four quarters beginning with the eastern direction.🔽Shining:

original: viyāti viya-saddo nipātamattaṃ. Attano acchariyaguṇehi sobhantameva hi taṃ tiṭṭhati.
analyzed: viyāti viya saddaḥ nipātam attam attanaḥ acchariya guṇehi sobhantam eva hi tam tiṭṭhati
translated: the word viya is merely a particle. For it stands shining with its own wonderful qualities.

original: Pāḷiyampi hi “upasobhayamānaṃ” tveva vuttaṃ.
analyzed: pāḷiyam pi hi upasobhayamānam tu eva vuttam
translated: For in the text too it is said, “upasobhamānaṃ.”

original: Hatthiratanavaṇṇanā
analyzed: hatthi ratana vaṇṇanā
translated: The description of the elephant treasure🔽The word “etc.” includes the fourfold noble solid perfume, etc.

original: 246. Haricandanādīhīti ādi-saddena catujjātiyagandhādiṃ saṅgaṇhāti. Āgamanaṃ cintethāti
analyzed: haricandana ādīhi iti ādi saddena catur jātiya gandha ādim saṅgaṇhāti āgamanam cintetha iti
translated: They say that he thinks of his coming🔽because he has fulfilled and practiced the duties of a universal monarch.

original: vadanti cakkavattivattassa pūritatāya paricitattā. Kāḷatilakādīnaṃ abhāvena visuddhasetasarīro.
analyzed: vadanti cakkavatti vattassa pūrita tāya paricita ttā kāḷa tilaka ādīnam abhāvena visuddha seta sarīraḥ
translated: He has a pure white body because he has no black moles, etc.

original: Sattapatiṭṭhoti bhūmiphusanakehi vāladhi, varaṅgaṃ, hatthoti imehi ca tīhi, catūhi
analyzed: satta patiṭṭho ti bhūmiphusanakehi vāladhi varaṅgam hattho ti imehi ca tīhi catūhi
translated: He has seven supports: with the three, namely, the tuft, the forelock, and the hand, and with the four, namely, the two feet, the two knees, and the two shoulders,

original: pādehi cāti sattahi avayavehi patiṭṭhitattā sattapatiṭṭho. Sabbakaniṭṭhoti sabbehi🔽chaddantakulahatthīhi hīno. Uposathakulā sabbajeṭṭhoti uposathakulato āgacchanto
analyzed: pādehi ca ati sattahi avayavehi patiṭṭhita ttā sattapatiṭṭhaḥ sabbakaniṭṭhaḥ ti sabbehi  chaddanta kula hatthīhi hīnaḥ uposatha kulā sabbajeṭṭho ti uposatha kulataḥ āgacchantaḥ
translated: and with his feet, he is ‘ seven-footed ’ because he is established with seven parts. ‘ Lowest of all ’ means inferior to all the six-tusked noble elephants. ‘ Highest of all in the Uposatha clan ’ means that he comes from the Uposatha clan.

original: tattha sabbappadhāno āgacchatīti yojanā. Vuttanayenāti “mahādānaṃ datvā”tiādinā vuttena
analyzed: tattha sabba ppadhānaḥ āgacchati iti yojanā vutta nayena ati mahādānam da tvā atiādinā vuttena
translated: He is “supported on seven” because he is supported on seven parts, namely, the two feet. “The youngest of all” means inferior to all the other elephants of the six tusk families. “The eldest of all in the Uposatha family” means that when he comes from the Uposatha family he comes as the eldest of all there. The construction is: “he comes as the chief of all there.” “In the way stated” means in the way stated in the passage beginning, “Having given a great gift” .

original: nayena. Cakkavattīnaṃ, cakkavattiputtānañca cakkavattiṃ uddissa cintayantānaṃ āgacchati.
analyzed: nayena cakkavattīnam cakkavatti puttānam ca cakkavattim uddissa cintayantānam āgacchati
translated: It comes to the wheel-turning kings and to the sons of the wheel-turning kings who are thinking of the wheel-turning kings.

original: Apanetvāti attano ānubhāvena apanetvā. Gandhameva hi tassa itare hatthī na sahanti.
analyzed: apanetvā ati attanaḥ ānubhāvena apanetvā gandham eva hi tassa itare hatthī na sahanti
translated: “Having removed” means having removed by his own power. For the other elephants cannot endure his smell.

original: Gharadhenuvacchako viyāti ghare paricitadhenuyā tattheva jātasaṃvaddhavacchako viya. Sakalapathavinti sakalaṃ jambudīpasaññitaṃ pathaviṃ.
analyzed: ghara dhenu vat śakaḥ viyā ti ghare paricita dhenuyā tattha iva jāta saṃvaddha vat śakaḥ sakala pathavinti sakalam jambudīpa saññitam pathavim
translated: “Like a calf of a cow familiar in the house” means like a calf born and reared there of a cow familiar in the house. “The whole path” means the whole earth called Jambudīpa.

original: Assaratanavaṇṇanā
analyzed: assa ratana vaṇṇanā
translated: The description of the elephant treasure

original: 247. Sindhavakulatoti sindhavassājānīyakulato.
analyzed: sindhava kulataḥ ti sindhavassājānīya kulataḥ
translated: “From the Sīhaļa breed” means from the breed of Sīhaļa elephants.

original: Maṇiratanavaṇṇanā
translated: The description of the jewel treasure

original: 248. Sakaṭanābhisamapariṇāhanti pariṇāhato mahāsakaṭassa nābhiyā samappamāṇaṃ. Ubhosu
analyzed: sakaṭa nābhi sama pariṇāhanti pariṇāhataḥ mahā sakaṭassa nābhiyā samappamāṇam ubhosu
translated: The size of the hub of a chariot wheel: the size of the hub of a great chariot wheel.🔽In both ends: below and above.

original: antesūti heṭṭhā, upari cāti dvīsu antesu. Kaṇṇikapariyantatoti dvinnaṃ kañcanapadumānaṃ
analyzed: antesu iti heṭṭhā upari ca ati dvīsu antesu dvinnam
translated: From the edge of the petals: from the edge of the petals of the two golden lotuses.

original: kaṇṇikāya pariyantato. Muttājālake ṭhapetvāti suvisuddhe muttamaye jālake patiṭṭhāpetvā.
analyzed: kaṇṇikāya pariyantataḥ muttā jālake ṭhapetvā ati su visuddhe mutta maye jālake patiṭṭhāpetvā
translated: Having placed in a net of pearls: having placed in a net of very pure pearls.

original: Aruṇuggamanavelā viyāti aruṇuggamanasīsena sūriyaudayakkhaṇaṃ upalakkheti.
analyzed: aruṇuggamana velā viyāti aruṇuggamana sīsena sūriya udaya kkhaṇam upalakkheti
translated: Like the time of sunrise: he points out the time of sunrise by the time of the rising of the dawn.

original: Itthiratanavaṇṇanā
analyzed: itthi ratana vaṇṇanā
translated: The description of the gem of a woman

original: 249. “Itthiratanaṃ pātubhavatī”ti vatvā kutassā pātubhāvoti dassetuṃ “maddarājakulato”tiādi

original: Saṇṭhānapāripūriyāti hatthapādādisarīrāvayavānaṃ susaṇṭhitāya. Avayavapāripūriyā🔽hi samudāyapāripūrisiddhi. Rūpanti sarīraṃ “rūpaṃ tveva saṅkhaṃ gacchatī”tiādīsu

original: Dhammapāsādapokkharaṇivaṇṇanā🔽253. Janarāsiṃ kāretvā tena janarāsinā khaṇitvā na māpesi. Kiñcarahīti āha “rañño

analyzed: paricāra vasena ati taṅkhaṇika paricāra vasena idam ca paṭhamam paṭṭhapita niyāmena iva

translated: It steals away: it steals away the eyes by its excessive brilliance, and it steals away the vision by its indistinctness, as if it were removing it. But that stealing away is by its flashing about. That is why it is said, “It flashes about.”

analyzed: paṭhama bhāṇa vāra vaṇṇanā niṭṭhitā
translated: The first recitation section is finished.

original: Jhānasampattivaṇṇanā
analyzed: jhāna sampatti vaṇṇanā
translated: The description of the attainment of jhāna

original: 260. Mahatiyā iddhiyāti mahantena icchitatthasamijjhanena. Tesaṃyeva icchiticchitatthānaṃ.
analyzed: mahatiyā iddhiyā ti mahantena icchita attha samijjhanena tesam yeva icchita icchita tthānam
translated: With great psychic power: with great success in the fulfilment of his wishes, in the accomplishment of what he wishes for.

original: “Anubhavitabbāna”nti iminā ānubhāva-saddassa kammasādhanataṃ dasseti. Pubbe sampannaṃ
analyzed: anubhavitabbānam ti iminā ānubhāva saddassa kamma sādhana tam dasseti pubbe sampannam
translated: “To be experienced”: this shows that the word “experience” is a gerund.

original: katvā deyyadhammapariccāgassa katabhāvaṃ dassento “sampattipariccāgassā”ti āha. Attānaṃ
analyzed: katvā deyya dhamma pariccāgassa kata bhāvam dassento sampatti pariccāgassa iti āha attānam
translated: Having previously made the gift of requisites perfect, he gave the gift of his attainment.

original: dameti etenāti damo.
analyzed: dama iti etena ati
translated: “Having tamed himself”: he tamed himself with this.

original: Bodhisattapubbayogavaṇṇanā
analyzed: bodhisatta pubba yoga vaṇṇanā
translated: The description of the bodhisattva’s previous practice🔽“The king”: Mahāsudassana.

original: Assāti mahāsudassanarañño. Eko theroti appaññāto nāmagottato aññataro puthujjano🔽thero. Theraṃ disvāti aññatarasmiṃ rukkhamūle nisinnaṃ disvā. Kaṭṭhattharaṇanti kaṭṭhamayaṃ
analyzed: assa ati mahāsudassana raññaḥ eko thero ti appaññātaḥ nāma gottataḥ aññataraḥ puthujjano  theraḥ theram disvā ti aññatarasmim rukkha mūle nisinnam disvā kaṭṭhattharaṇam ti kaṭṭha mayam
translated: “A little-known elder”: an ordinary elder, known neither by his name nor his clan.🔽“Having seen the elder”: having seen him sitting at the foot of a tree.

original: attharaṇaṃ, dāruphalakanti attho.
analyzed: attharaṇam dāru phalakanti
translated: “A wooden bedstead”: a bedstead made of wood. The meaning is: a wooden plank.

original: Paribhogabhājananti pānīyaparibhojanīyādiparibhogayogyaṃ bhājanaṃ. Ārakaṇṭakanti sūcivijjhanakakaṇṭakaṃ. Pipphalikanti khuddakasatthakaṃ. Udakatumbakanti kuṇḍikaṃ.
analyzed: paribhoga bhājanam ti pānīya paribhojanīya ādi paribhoga yogyam bhājanam ārakaṇṭakanti sūci vijjhanaka kaṇṭakam pipphalikanti khuddaka satthakam udaka tumbakanti kuṇḍikam
translated: “A vessel for use” is a vessel suitable for use in drinking water, etc. “Without thorns” means without thorns and needles. “A jujube fruit” is a small fruit. “A water pot” is a water-jar.

original: Kūṭāgāradvāreyeva nivattesīti kūṭāgāraṃ paviṭṭhakālato paṭṭhāya tesaṃ micchāvitakkānaṃ pavattiyā okāsaṃ nādāsi.
analyzed: kūṭāgāra dvāreya iva nivattesi iti kūṭāgāram paviṭṭha kālataḥ paṭṭhāya tesam micchā vitakkānam pavattiyā okāsam na adāsi
translated: “He turned back at the door of the stilt-wattle house” means that from the time he entered the stilt-wattle house he did not give an opportunity for the arising of those wrong thoughts.

original: 261. Kasiṇameva paññāyati mahāpurisassa tattha tattha katādhikārattā, tesañca padesānaṃ suparikammakatakasiṇasadisattā.
analyzed: kasiṇam eva paññāyati mahāpurisassa tattha tattha kata adhikāra ttā tesam ca padesānam su parikamma kata kasiṇa sadisa ttā
translated: The kasiṇa only appeared because the Great Man had practiced it there in the past, and because those places were like a well-prepared kasiṇa.

original: 262. Cattāri jhānānīti cattāri kasiṇajjhānāni. Kasiṇajjhānappamaññānaṃyeva vacanaṃ🔽tāsaṃ tadā ādaragāravavasena nibbattitattā. Mahābodhisattānañhi arūpajjhānesu ādaro
analyzed: cattāri jhānāni iti cattāri kasiṇajjhānāni vacanam  tāsam tadā ādara gārava vasena nibbattita ttā mahā bodhisattānam hi arūpa jhānesu ādaraḥ
translated: “The four jhānas” are the four kasiṇa jhānas. The statement “the kasiṇa jhānas and the measureless states”🔽is because they were produced by his respect and reverence for them at that time. For the great bodhisattvas do not have respect for the formless jhānas,

original: natthi, abhiññāpadaṭṭhānataṃ pana sandhāya tānipi nibbattenti, tasmā mahāsatto tāpasaparibbājakakāle
analyzed: natthi abhiññā pada ṭṭhāna tam pana sandhāya tāni api nibbattenti tasmā mahāsatto tāpasa paribbājaka kāle
translated: but they produce them as a basis for the higher knowledge. Therefore, when the Great Being was a wandering ascetic,

original: yattake lokiyaguṇe nibbatteti, te sabbepi tadā nibbattesiyeva. Tenāha “mahāpuriso panā”tiādi.
analyzed: yattake lokiya guṇe nibbatteti te sabbe pi tadā tena āha mahā purisaḥ pana atiādi
translated: and whatever mundane qualities he produced, all these were produced then. Hence it is said: “But the Great Man” and so on.

original: Caturāsītinagarasahassādivaṇṇanā🔽263. Abhiharitabbabhattanti upanetabbabhattaṃ.
analyzed: catur āsīti nagara sahassa ādi vaṇṇanā  abhiharitabba bhattanti upanetabba bhattam
translated: The description of the eighty-four thousand cities and so on🔽“Food to be brought in” : food to be brought up.

original: 264. Nibaddhavattanti pubbe upanibaddhaṃ pākavattaṃ.
analyzed: nibaddha vattanti pubbe upanibaddham pākavattam
translated: “Regular allowance” : the allowance that had been fixed before.

original: Subhaddādeviupasaṅkamanavaṇṇanā
analyzed: subhaddā devī upasaṅkamana vaṇṇanā
translated: The description of Queen Subhadda’s approach

original: 265. Āvaṭṭetvāti ativisitvā. Yaṃ yaṃ rañño icchitaṃ dānūpakaraṇañceva bhogūpakaraṇañca, tassa tassa tatheva samiddhabhāvaṃ vitthavati.
analyzed: āvaṭṭetvā ati ativisitvā yam yam raññaḥ icchitam dānu upakaraṇam ca iva bhogu upakaraṇam ca tassa tassa tathā iva samiddha bhāvam
translated: “Having turned it over” : having extended it very much. Whatever the king desired, whether it was a gift or an enjoyment, that very thing became abundant and extensive.

original: 266. Sace pana rājā jīvite chandaṃ janeyya, ito parampi ciraṃ kālaṃ tiṭṭheyya mahiddhiko
analyzed: sace pana rājā jīvite chandam janeyya ito param pi ciram kālam tiṭṭheyya mahiddhikaḥ
translated: But if the king had generated desire for life, he would have lived for a long time. He was one of great power

original: mahānubhāvoti evaṃ mahajjhāsayā devī bhogesu, jīvite ca rājānaṃ sāpekkhaṃ kātuṃ vāyami.
analyzed: mahā anubhāvā iti evam mahajjhāsayā devī bhogesu jīvite ca rājānam sa apekkham kātum vā āyami
translated: and great influence. Thus the queen, who had great desires for wealth and for life, tried to make the king hopeful.

original: Tena vuttaṃ “mā heva kho rājā”tiādi. Tenevāha “tassa kālaṅkiriyaṃ anicchamānā”tiādi.
analyzed: tena vuttam mā ha iva kho rājā itiādi tena iva āha tassa kālaṅkiriyam an icchamāna atiādi
translated: Therefore it is said: “Let not the king” and so on. Therefore it is said: “not desiring his death” and so on.

original: Chandaṃ janehīti ettha chanda-saddo taṇhāpariyāyoti āha “pemaṃ uppādehī”ti. Apekkhati
analyzed: chandam janehi iti ettha chanda saddo taṇhā pariyāyo ti āha uppādehi iti apekkhati
translated: “Generate desire” : the word “desire” here is a synonym for craving. That is why he said “give rise to love” .

original: ārammaṇaṃ etāya na vissajjetīti apekkhā, taṇhā.
analyzed: ārammaṇam etāya na vissajjeti iti apekkhā taṇhā
translated: He looks on , he does not let go of the object, thus it is looking on ; it is craving.

original: 267. Garahitāti ettha kehi garahitā, kasmā ca garahitāti antolīnaṃ codanaṃ vissajjento🔽“buddhehī”tiādimāha, tena viññugarahitattā, duggatisaṃvattaniyato ca sāpekkhakālakiriyā
analyzed: garahitā ati ettha kehi garahitā kasmā ca garahitā ati antolīnam codanam vissajjento  buddhehi iti ādim āha tena ca sa apekkha kāla kiriyā
