translated: “Blameworthy” : here, by whom are they blamed? And why are they blamed?

original: parivajjetabbāti dasseti.
analyzed: parivajjetabbā ati dasseti
translated: He answers the question that is implied, “By the wise,” etc. By that he shows that they are to be avoided because they are blamed by the wise and because they lead to a bad destination.

original: 268. Ekamantaṃ gantvāti rañño cakkhupathaṃ vijahitvā.
analyzed: ekamantam gantvā ati rañño cakkhu patham vijahitvā
translated: “Having gone to one side” : having left the range of the king’s sight.

original: Brahmalokūpagamanavaṇṇanā
analyzed: brahma loka upagamana vaṇṇanā
translated: The description of the going to the Brahma-world

original: 269. Soṇassāti koḷivīsassa soṇassa. Ekā bhattapātīti ekaṃ bhattavaḍḍhitakaṃ. Tādisaṃ bhattanti tathārūpaṃ garuṃ madhuraṃ siniddhaṃ bhattaṃ. Bhuttānanti bhuttavantānaṃ.
analyzed: soṇassa ati koḷivīsassa soṇassa ekā bhattapātī iti ekam bhattavaḍḍhitakam tādisam bhattam ti tathārūpam garum madhuram siniddham bhattam bhuttānam iti bhuttavantānam
translated: “Soṇa” : the Koḷivisa Soṇa. “One meal-offering” : one meal-offering-portion. “Such a meal” : such a heavy, sweet, soft meal. “Those who have eaten” : those who have eaten.

original: 271. Dāsamanussāti dāsā ceva āyuttakamanussā ca.
analyzed: dāsa manussā ati dāsā ca iva āyuttaka manussā ca
translated: “Slave and human” : slaves and human beings who are not slaves.

original: Idāni yathāvuttāya rañño mahāsudassanassa bhogasampattiyā kammasarikkhataṃ uddharanto “etāni panā”tiādimāha, taṃ suviññeyyameva.
analyzed: idāni yathā vuttāya raññaḥ mahāsudassanassa bhoga sampattiyā uddharantaḥ etāni pana ati ādim āha tam su viññeyyam eva
translated: Now, in order to show the similarity of the deed to the prosperity of King Mahāsudassana as described, he said, “But these,” etc., which is quite clear.

original: 272. Ādito paṭṭhāyāti samudāgamanato paṭṭhāya. Yattha taṃ puññaṃ āyūhitaṃ, yato sā
analyzed: āditas paṭṭhāya ati samudāgamanataḥ paṭṭhāya yattha tam puññam āyūhitam yatas sā
translated: From the beginning: from the time of its arising. Where that merit was accumulated, from which

original: sampatti nibbattā, tato tatiyattabhāvato pabhuti. Mahāsudassanassa jātakadesanā hi
analyzed: sampatti nibbattā tatas mahāsudassanassa jātaka desanā hi
translated: that prosperity arose, from the time of the third generation. For the teaching of the Jātaka of Mahāsudassana

original: tadā samudāgamanato paṭṭhāya bhagavatā desitāti. Paṃsvāgārakīḷaṃ viyāti yathā nāma
analyzed: tadā samudāgamanataḥ paṭṭhāya bhagavatā desitā ati paṃsu āgārakīḷam viyāti yathā nāma
translated: was given by the Exalted One from the time of its arising.

original: dārakā paṃsūhi vāpigehabhojanādīni dassentā yathāruci kīḷitvā gamanakāle sabbaṃ taṃ🔽vidhaṃsentā gacchanti, evameva bhagavā mahāsudassanakāle attanā anubhūtaṃ dibbasampattisadisaṃ
analyzed: dārakā paṃsūhi vāpi geha bhojana ādīni dassentā yathāruci kīḷitvā gamana kāle sabbam tam  vidhaṃsentā gacchanti evam eva bhagavā mahāsudassana kāle attanā anubhūtam dibba sampatti sadisam
translated: Like a game of sand: just as boys, showing houses, food, etc., made of sand, play as they like, and when it is time to go, they destroy all that

original: acinteyyānubhāvasampattiṃ vitthārato dassetvā puna attano desanaṃ ādīnavanissaraṇadassanavasena
analyzed: acinteyya anubhāva sampattim vitthārataḥ dassetvā puna attanaḥ desanam ādīnava nissaraṇa dassana vasena
translated: and go, so too, the Exalted One, after showing in detail the prosperity of the divine life, similar to the prosperity of the divine life he himself experienced in the time of Mahāsudassana, with its inconceivable power, again his teaching by showing its danger and escape.

original: vivaṭṭābhimukhaṃ viparivattento “sabbā sā sampatti aniccatāya vipariṇatā vidhaṃsitā”ti🔽dassento “passānandā”tiādimāha. Vipariṇatāti vipariṇāmaṃ sabhāvavigamaṃ gatā. Tenāha🔽“pakativijahanenā”tiādi. Pakatīti sabhāvadhammānaṃ udayavayaparicchinno kakkhaḷaphusanādisabhāvo,
analyzed: vivaṭṭa abhimukham viparivattento sabbā sā sampatti anicca tāya vipariṇatā vidhaṃsitā ati  dassentaḥ passa ānanda ati ādim āha vipariṇatā iti vipariṇāmam sa bhāva vigamam gatā tena āha  pakati vijahanena atiādi pakati iti sabhāva dhammānam udaya vaya paricchinno kakkhaḷa phusana ādi sabhāvaḥ
translated: He said, “You have seen, Ānanda,” etc., showing that all that prosperity had changed and perished through impermanence. “Changed” : gone to change, to the loss of its individual essence. Hence he said, “By the loss of its individual essence” , etc. The individual essence is the individual essence of hardness, softness, etc., which is limited by rise and fall in things that have an individual essence.

original: so bhaṅgakkhaṇato paṭṭhāya jahito, pariccajanto sabbaso nattheva. Tenāha “nibbutapadīpo🔽viya apaññattikabhāvaṃ gatā”ti.🔽Ettāvatāti ādito paṭṭhāya pavattena ettakena desanāmaggena. Anekāni vassakoṭisatasahassāniyeva🔽ubbedho etissāti anekavassakoṭisatasahassubbedhā. Aniccalakkhaṇaṃ ādāyāti taṃ sampattigataṃ
analyzed: so bhaṅga kkhaṇato paṭṭhāya jahitaḥ pariccajanto sabbaso nattha iva tena āha nibbuta padīpo  viya a paññattika bhāvam gatā ati  ettāvatā ti āditaḥ paṭṭhāya pavattena ettakena desanā maggena anekāni  ubbedhaḥ etissa ati aneka vassa koṭi sata sahassa ubbedhā anicca lakkhaṇam ādāya ati tam sampatti gatam
translated: That is lost, given up, completely non-existent, from the moment of its dissolution. Hence he said, “Like a lamp that is extinguished” , etc.🔽“To that extent” : by that much of the method of teaching that has been expounded from the beginning. For it is only after many hundreds of thousands of koṭis of years

original: aniccalakkhaṇaṃ desanāya gahetvā vibhāvetvā. Yathā nisseṇimuccane tādisaṃ satahatthubbedhaṃ
analyzed: anicca lakkhaṇam desanāya gahetvā vibhāvetvā yathā nisseṇi muccane tādisam sata hatthu bbedham
translated: that the world contracts. “To that extent” : to the extent of many hundreds of thousands of koṭis of years. “Taking the characteristic of impermanence” : taking, making known, the characteristic of impermanence in that prosperity by means of the teaching. As a man might climb a mountain of salt, or a mountain of rock candy, and eat into it, and then after a long time his descendants would appear in the same place, and so on.

original: rukkhaṃ pakatipurisena ārohituṃ na sakkā, evaṃ aniccatāvibhāvanena tassā sampattiyā
analyzed: rukkham pakati purisena ārohitum na sakkā evam anicca tā vibhāvanena tassā sampattiyā
translated: It is impossible for an ordinary man to climb that tree.🔽So too, it is impossible for an ordinary man to attain that kind of distinction by developing insight into impermanence.

original: apekkhānisseṇimuccane kenaci ārohituṃ na sakkāti āha “aniccalakkhaṇaṃ ādāya nisseṇiṃ
analyzed: apekkhā nisseṇi muccane kenaci ārohitum na sakkā iti āha anicca lakkhaṇam ādāya nisseṇim
translated: It is impossible for an ordinary man to climb a tree, and so it is impossible for anyone to climb the ladder of the contemplation of impermanence🔽and let go of his attachment to the excellence of the jhānas.

original: muñcanto viyā”ti. Tenevāti yathāvuttakāraṇeneva, ādito sātisayaṃ kāmesu assādaṃ dassetvāpi
analyzed: muñcantaḥ viyā ti tena iva ati yathā vutta kāraṇena iva āditas sa atisayam kāmesu assādam dassetvā api
translated: Therefore, after showing the excessive gratification in sensual pleasures at the beginning,

original: upari nesaṃ “passānandā”tiādinā ādīnavaṃ, okāraṃ, saṃkilesaṃ, nekkhamme ānisaṃsañca
analyzed: upari nesam passa ānanda ati ādinā ādīnavam okāram saṃkilesam nekkhamme ānisaṃsam ca
translated: he concluded the teaching by showing the danger, the drawbacks, the defilement, and the benefit in renunciation,🔽starting with the words: “Seeing danger in sensual pleasures” (Sn 102).🔽In the past: in the past time.

original: vibhāvetvā desanāya niṭṭhāpitattā. Pubbeti atītakāle. Vasabharājāti vasabhanāmako sīhaḷamahārājā.
analyzed: vibhāvetvā desanāya niṭṭhāpita ttā pubba iti atīta kāle vasabha rājā ati vasabha nāmako sīhaḷa mahā rājā
translated: King Vasabha: the great king of the Sinhalese named Vasabha.

original: Udakapupphuḷādayoti ādi-saddena tiṇagge ussāvabinduādike saṅgaṇhāti.
analyzed: udaka pupphuḷa ādayaḥ ti ādi saddena tiṇagge ussāva bindu ādike saṅgaṇhāti
translated: The dewdrop on the tip of a blade of grass, etc.: the word “etc.” includes the water-bubble, the mirage, etc.

original: Mahāsudassanassa panāti pana-saddo visesatthajotano, tena mahāsudassanamahārājā jhānābhiññāsamāpattiyo
analyzed: mahāsudassanassa pana ati pana saddo visesa attha jotanaḥ tena mahāsudassana mahārājāḥ jhāna abhiññā samāpattiyaḥ
translated: But the great king Mahāsudassana: the word “but” indicates a distinction. The great king Mahāsudassana attained the jhānas, direct knowledges, and liberations,

original: nibbattesi, tadaggena parisuddhe ca samaṇabhāve patiṭṭhito, yato vidhuya eva kāmavitakkādisamaṇabhāvasaṃkilesaṃ🔽suññāgāraṃ pāvisi, evaṃbhūtassāpi tassa kālaṃ kiriyato sattame divase sabbā cakkavattisampatti
analyzed: nibbattesi tad aggena parisuddhe ca samaṇa bhāve patiṭṭhitaḥ yatas vidhuya eva kāma vitakka ādi samaṇa bhāva saṃkilesam  suññāgāram pāvisi evaṃbhūtassa api tassa kālam kiriyato sattame divase sabbā cakkavatti sampatti
translated: and he was established in the purity of the state of a monk. When he had thus removed the defilements of the state of a monk, such as thoughts of sensual desire,

original: antarahitā, na tato paraṃ, aho acchariyamanusso anaññasādhāraṇaguṇavisesoti imaṃ visesaṃ dasseti.
analyzed: antara hitā na tatas param aho acchariya manussaḥ anañña sādhāraṇa guṇa viseso ti imam visesam dasseti
translated: and entered an empty house, then, on the seventh day after his death, all the glory of a universal monarch disappeared, and no more. Oh, what an extraordinary man, with special qualities not shared by others! This is the distinction shown.

original: Anāruḷhanti “rājā kira pubbe gahapatikule nibbattī”tiādinā, “puna theraṃ āmantesī”tiādinā🔽ca vuttamatthaṃ sandhāyāha. So hi imasmiṃ sutte saṅgītiṃ anāruḷho, aññattha pana
analyzed: rājā kira pubbe gahapati kule nibbattī itiādinā puna theram āmantesi itiādinā  ca vutta mattham sandhāya āha saḥ hi imasmin sutte saṅgītim anāruḷhaḥ aññattha pana
translated: Not yet mounted: “The king was reborn in the family of a householder” and so on, and “again he addressed the Elder” and so on.🔽The meaning stated is referred to. For he has not yet mounted the recitation in this sutta, but elsewhere

original: āgato imissā desanāya piṭṭhivattakabhāvena. Yaṃ panettha atthato na vibhattaṃ, taṃ suviññeyyaṃ evāti.
analyzed: āgataḥ imissā desanāya piṭṭhivattaka bhāvena yam pana ittha atthataḥ na vibhattam tam su viññeyyam eva ati
translated: he has come as the back-bone of this teaching. But what has not been explained in meaning here is very easy to understand.

original: Mahāsudassanasuttavaṇṇanāya līnatthappakāsanā.
translated: The explanation of the Mahāsudassana Sutta is ended.

original: 5. Janavasabhasuttavaṇṇanā
analyzed: janavasabha sutta vaṇṇanā
translated: The explanation of the Janavasabha Sutta

original: Nātikiyādibyākaraṇavaṇṇanā
analyzed: na ati kiyā ādi byākaraṇa vaṇṇanā
translated: The explanation of the Nāti and other replies

original: 273-275. “Parito”ti padaṃ yathā samantatthavācako, evaṃ samīpatthavācakopi hotīti
analyzed: paritas ti padam yathā samanta attha vācakaḥ evam samīpa attha vācakaḥ api hoti iti
translated: The word “around” is used to mean “all round” as well as “near” .

original: samantā sāmantāti attho vutto. Āmeḍitena pana samantattho jotito. Yassa pana sāmantā
analyzed: samantā sāmantā ti atthaḥ vuttaḥ āmeḍitena pana samanta atthaḥ jotitaḥ yassa pana sāmantā
translated: So the meaning is “all round, in the vicinity.” But the meaning “all round” is also suggested by the word “in the vicinity.”

original: janapadesu “nātike viharatī”ti vuttattā nātikassāti viññāto yamattho. Yassa parito
analyzed: janapadesu na atike viharati iti vutta ttā na atikassa ati viññātaḥ yamatthaḥ yassa paritas
translated: The meaning of the word “Nātika” is known from the expression “he was living at Nātika” as a place name in the vicinity of the city.🔽The meaning of the word “around” is known from the expression “in the vicinity of the city.”

original: janapadesu byākaroti, tattha paricārakārakānaṃ byākaraṇaṃ avuttasiddhaṃ, nidassanavasena
analyzed: janapadesu byākaroti tattha paricāra kārakānam byākaraṇam a vutta siddham nidassana vasena
translated: The people who live in the vicinity of the city are the attendants.🔽Or it may be taken as said in order to show them, since they are already established as such.

original: vā tassa vakkhamānattā “parito parito janapadesu” icceva vuttaṃ. Paricāraketi upāsake.
analyzed: vā tassa vakkhamānattā paritas paritas janapadesu iccā iva vuttam paricāraka iti upāsake
translated: The word “attendants” refers to lay followers.🔽Hence it is said: “attendants of the Buddha, the Dhamma, and the Saṅgha.”

original: Tenāha “buddhadhammasaṅghānaṃ paricārake”ti. Upapattīsūti nibbattīsu. Ñāṇagatipuññānaṃ
analyzed: tena āha buddha dhamma saṅghānam paricāraka iti upapattīsu iti nibbattīsu ñāṇa gati puññānam
translated: The word “births” refers to rebirths.

original: upapattīsūti ettha ñāṇagatūpapatti nāma tassa tassa maggañāṇagamanassa nibbatti.
analyzed: upapattīsu iti ettha ñāṇa gatūpapatti nāma tassa tassa magga ñāṇa gamanassa nibbatti
translated: The word “births” in the phrase “of knowledge, of destiny, and of merit” refers to the rebirth of the knowledge of the path, etc.

original: Yaṃ sandhāya vuttaṃ “pañcannaṃ orambhāgiyānaṃ parikkhayā”tiādi. Puññūpapatti nāma
analyzed: yam sandhāya vuttam pañcannam orambhāgiyānam parikkhaya ati ādi puññūpapatti nāma
translated: With reference to this it is said: “With the destruction of the five lower fetters” , and so on.🔽The word “births” in the phrase “of merit” refers to the rebirth of the merit of the four kinds of nutriment.

original: taṃtaṃdevanikāyūpapatti. Sabbatthāti “vajjimallesū”tiādike sabbattha catūsupi padesu.
analyzed: sabbattha ati vajji mallesu uti ādike sabbattha catūsu pi padesu
translated: Everywhere: in all the four places beginning with “Vajji and Malla”.🔽In the first: he says this referring to what is stated in the text.

original: Purimesūti pāḷiyaṃ vutte sandhāyāha. Dasasuyevāti tesu eva dasasu janapadesu. Paricārake
analyzed: purimesu iti pāḷiyam vutte sandhāya āha tesu eva dasasu janapadesu paricārake
translated: In the ten: in those very ten countries.🔽He declares the attendants because there are many to be declared there.

original: byākaroti byakātabbānaṃ bahūnaṃ tattha labbhanato. Nātike bhavā nātikiyā.
analyzed: byākaroti bya kātabbānam bahūnam tattha labbhanataḥ na atike bhavā na atikiyā
translated: The people of Natika are the Natika people.

original: Niṭṭhaṅgatāti niṭṭhaṃ nicchayaṃ upagatā.
analyzed: niṭṭhaṅga tā ati niṭṭham nicchayam upagatā
translated: They have reached the end: they have reached the end, the conclusion.

original: Ānandaparikathāvaṇṇanā
analyzed: ānanda parikathā vaṇṇanā
translated: The explanation of the discourse on Ānanda.

original: 276. Yasmā saṅghasuppaṭipatti nāma dhammasudhammatāya, dhammasudhammatā ca buddhasubuddhatāya,🔽tasmā “aho dhammo, aho saṅgho”ti dhammasaṅghaguṇakittanāpi atthato buddhaguṇakittanā
analyzed: yasmai saṅgha suppaṭipatti nāma dhamma su dhamma tāya dhamma su dhamma tā ca buddha su buddha tāya  tasmai aho dhammaḥ aho saṅgho ti dhamma saṅgha guṇa kittanā api atthataḥ buddha guṇa kittanā
translated: Because the Sangha’s good practice is due to the rightness of the Dhamma, and the rightness of the Dhamma is due to the Buddha’s perfect enlightenment,🔽therefore the praise of the qualities of the Dhamma and the Sangha, “How excellent the Dhamma! How excellent the Sangha!” is in fact a praise of the Buddha’s qualities.

original: eva hotīti “bhagavantaṃ kittayamānarūpā”ti padassa “aho dhammo”tiādināpi attho vutto.
analyzed: eva hoti iti bhagavantam kittayamāna rūpā ti padassa aho dhammaḥ ti ādinā api atthaḥ vutto
translated: Thus the meaning of the words “glorifying the Blessed One” is also stated by “How excellent the Dhamma!”🔽The course of knowledge: the course of knowledge stated thus:

original: 278. Ñāṇagatīti “pañcannaṃ orambhāgiyānaṃ saṃyojanānaṃ parikkhayā”tiādinā āgataṃ
analyzed: ñāṇa gatī iti pañcannam orambhāgiyānam saṃyojanānam parikkhaya ati ādinā āgatam
translated: “With the destruction of the five lower fetters he becomes an attainer of Nibbana in the interval” ,

original: pahātabbapahānavasena pavattaṃ maggañāṇagamanaṃ. Yasmā tassā eva ñāṇagatiyā vasena🔽tassa tassa ariyapuggalassa opapātikatādiviseso, tasmā taṃ tādisaṃ tassa abhisamparāyaṃ
analyzed: pahātabba pahāna vasena pavattam magga ñāṇa gamanam yasmā tassāḥ eva ñāṇa gatiyāḥ vasena  tassa tassa ariya puggalassa opapātika tā ādi viseso tasmā tam tādisam tassa abhisamparāyam
translated: the noble person is reborn spontaneously, and so on. Therefore, with reference to that kind of knowledge,🔽he said: “The future state is by knowledge.”

original: sandhāyāha “ñāṇābhisamparāyamevā”ti.
analyzed: sandhāya āha ñāṇa abhisamparāyam eva iti
translated: “The future state is by knowledge” means: “The future state is by the kind of knowledge that occurs as the abandoning of what should be abandoned.”🔽“The future state is by knowledge” means: “The future state is by the kind of knowledge that occurs as the abandoning of what should be abandoned.”🔽“The future state is by knowledge” means: “The future state is by the kind of knowledge that occurs as the abandoning of what should be abandoned.”🔽“The future state is by knowledge” means: “The future state is by the kind of knowledge that occurs as the abandoning of what should be abandoned.”

original: 279. Upasantaṃ pati sammati ālokīyatīti upasantapatiso. Upasantadassano upasantaussanno. Bhātirivāti ettha ra-kāro padasandhikaro, iva-saddo bhusatthoti āha “ativiya bhātī”ti.🔽Janavasabhayakkhavaṇṇanā
analyzed: upasantam pati sammati ālokīyati iti upasantapatisaḥ upasantadassanaḥ upasantaussannaḥ bhātiḥ iva ati ettha rakāraḥ pada sandhi karaḥ iva saddaḥ bhu sattho ti āha ativiya bhāti iti
translated: “The future state is by knowledge” means: “The future state is by the kind of knowledge that occurs as the abandoning of what should be abandoned.”🔽“The future state is by knowledge” means: “The future state is by the kind of knowledge that occurs as the abandoning of what should be abandoned.”

original: 280. Jeṭṭhakabhāvena jane vasabhasadisoti janavasabhoti assa devaputtassa nāmaṃ ahosi.🔽Ito devalokā cavitvā sattakkhattuṃ manussaloke rājabhūtassa. Manussalokā cavitvā
analyzed: jeṭṭhaka bhāvena jane vasabha sadisaḥ iti janavasabhaḥ iti assa devaputtassa nāmam ahosi  itas deva lokā cavitvā sattakkhattum manussa loke rāja bhūtassa manussa lokā cavitvā
translated: “The future state is by knowledge” means: “The future state is by the kind of knowledge that occurs as the abandoning of what should be abandoned.”🔽“The future state is by knowledge” means: “The future state is by the kind of knowledge that occurs as the abandoning of what should be abandoned.”🔽“The future state is by knowledge” means: “The future state is by the kind of knowledge that occurs as the abandoning of what should be abandoned.”🔽“The future state is by knowledge” means: “The future state is by the kind of knowledge that occurs as the abandoning of what should be abandoned.”🔽“The future state is by knowledge” means: “The future state is by the kind of knowledge that occurs as the abandoning of what should be abandoned.”🔽“The future state is by knowledge” means: “The future state is by the kind of knowledge that occurs as the abandoning of what should be abandoned.”🔽“The future state is by knowledge” means: “The future state is by the kind of knowledge that occurs as the abandoning of what should be abandoned.”

original: sattakkhattuṃ devabhūtassa. Etthevāti etasmiṃyeva cātumahārājikabhave, etthāpi vessavaṇassa sahabyatāvasena.
analyzed: sattakkhattum deva bhūtassa ettha iva ati etasmin yeva cātumahārājika bhave ettha api vessavaṇassa sahabya tā vasena
translated: “The future state is by knowledge” means: “The future state is by the kind of knowledge that occurs as the abandoning of

original: 281. Āsisanaṃ āsā, patthanā. Āsāsīsena cettha kattukamyatākusalacchandaṃ vadati.🔽Tenevāha “sakadāgāmimaggatthāyā”tiādi. Yadaggeti ettha agga-saddo ādipariyāyoti āha🔽“taṃ divasaṃ ādiṃ katvā”ti. “Purimaṃ…pe… avinipāto”ti idaṃ yathā tattakaṃ kālaṃ sugatito
analyzed: āsisanam āsā patthanā āsā sīsena ca ittha kattu kamya tā kusala chandam vadati  tena iva āha sakadāgāmi magga atthāya atiādi yat aggā iti ettha agga saddo ādi pariyāyo ti āha  tam divasam ādim katvā ati idam yathā tattakam kālam sugatitaḥ
translated: “Hope” is hopefulness, aspiration. Herein, he is speaking of the kind of desire called “unprofitable desire to do” .

original: sugatūpapattiyeva ahosi, tathā katūpacitakusalakammattā. Phussassa sammāsambuddhassa
analyzed: sugata upapattiyā iva ahosi tathā katu upacita kusala kammattā phussassa sammāsambuddhassa
translated: That is why he says “for the purpose of the once-returner’s path” and so on. As to “from that time on”: the word “beginning” is a word for “first” . That is why he says “beginning from that day” . As to “he was never again subject to destruction” , this was because he had stored up profitable action in such a way that he was assured of rebirth in a happy destination for as long as he was a worldling.

original: kālato pabhuti hi sambhatavivaṭṭūpanissayakusalasambhāro esa devaputto. Anacchariyanti
analyzed: kālataḥ pabhuti hi esa devaputto
translated: For this god had stored up the requisites of merit that ripen in the bliss of the gods and the bliss of the human world from the time of the Perfect Buddha Phussa onwards.

original: anu anu acchariyaṃ. Tenāha “punappunaṃ acchariyamevā”ti. Sayaṃparisāyāti sakāya parisāya.
analyzed: anu anu acchariyam tena āha punappunam acchariyam eva ati sayaṃparisāya ati sakāya parisāya
translated: “Not surprising” : not surprising again and again. That is why he says “it is not surprising” . “To his own assembly” : to his own following.

original: Bhagavato diṭṭhasadisamevāti āvajjanasamanantaraṃ yathā te bhagavato catuvīsatisatasahassamattā
analyzed: bhagavataḥ diṭṭha sadisam eva ati āvajjana samanantaram yathā te bhagavataḥ catuvīsati sata sahassa mattā
translated: “Just as if he had seen the Blessed One” : immediately after the adverting, just as if he had seen the Blessed One with his own eyes, he saw the Blessed One surrounded by a company of many thousands of bhikkhus.

original: sattā ñāṇagatito diṭṭhā, evaṃ tumhehi diṭṭhasadisameva. Vessavaṇassa sammukhā sutaṃ mayāti vadati.
analyzed: sattāḥ ñāṇa gatitaḥ diṭṭhāḥ evam tumhehi diṭṭha sadisam eva vessavaṇassa sammukhā sutam mayā iti vadati
translated: “Beings are seen to have gone by the way of knowledge” : it is just as you have seen them. He says that he heard it directly from Vessavaṇa.

original: Devasabhāvaṇṇanā
analyzed: deva sabhā vaṇṇanā
translated: The description of the divine assembly

original: 282. Vassūpanāyikasaṅgahatthanti vassūpanāyikāya ārakkhāsaṃvidhānavasena bhikkhūnaṃ
analyzed: vassūpanāyika saṅgahattham ti vassūpanāyikāya ārakkhā saṃvidhāna vasena bhikkhūnam
translated: “For the sake of the support of the Uposatha” : for the purpose of supporting the bhikkhus by making arrangements for their protection during the rains.

original: saṅgahaṇatthaṃ “vassūpagatā bhikkhū evaṃ sukhena samaṇadhammaṃ karontī”ti, pavāraṇasaṅgaho
analyzed: saṅgahaṇa attham vassu upagatāḥ bhikkhū evam sukhena samaṇa dhammam karonti iti pavāraṇa saṅgaho
translated: “The bhikkhus who have entered upon the rains are doing the ascetic practice happily” : the support of the Pavarana.

original: panassa pavāretvā satthu santikaṃ gacchantānaṃ bhikkhūnaṃ antarāmagge parissayapariharaṇatthaṃ.
analyzed: panassa pavāretvā satthu santikam gacchantānam bhikkhūnam antarāmagge parissaya pariharaṇa attham
translated: “For the purpose of warding off dangers on the way for the bhikkhus who, after the Pavarana, are going to the Teacher” .🔽The same method applies to those who go to a distant place for the purpose of hearing the Dhamma. He himself also assembles

original: Dhammassavanatthaṃ dūraṭṭhānaṃ gacchantesupi eseva nayo. Attanāpi āgantvā dhammassavanatthaṃ
analyzed: dhamma ssavana attham dūra ṭṭhānam gacchantesu pi esa iva nayaḥ attanā api āgantvā dhamma ssavana attham
translated: for the purpose of hearing the Dhamma after coming .

original: sannipatiyeva. Etthetthāti ettha ettha ayyānaṃ vasanaṭṭhāne.
analyzed: sannipatiyā iva ettha itthā ati ettha ettha vasanaṭṭhāne
translated: “Here and there” : in the dwelling places of the venerable ones.

original: Tadāpīti “purimāni bhante divasānī”ti vuttakālepi. Eteneva kāraṇenāti vassūpanāyikanimittameva.
analyzed: tadā api iti purimāni bhante divasāni iti vutta kāle pi etena iva kāraṇena ati vassūpanāyika nimittam eva
translated: “Even then” : at the time referred to by the words “in the past few days” . “For this reason” : for the reason of the Uposatha.

original: Tenāha pāḷiyaṃ “tadahuposathe pannarase vassūpanāyikāyā”tiādi. Āsanepi nisajjāya🔽sudhammāya devasabhāya paṭhamaṃ devesu tāvatiṃsesu nisinnesu tassā catūsu dvāresu
analyzed: tena āha pāḷiyam tadahu uposathe pannarase āsane pi nisajjāya  sudhammāya deva sabhāya paṭhamam devesu tāvatiṃsesu nisinnesu tassā catūsu dvāresu
translated: Hence it is said in the text: “On the Uposatha day of the fifteenth, the day for the observance of the Uposatha and for the commencement of the Rains” .🔽In the case of the seats, the sitting is

original: cattāro mahārājāno nisīdanti, idaṃ nesaṃ āsane nisajjāya cārittaṃ hoti.
analyzed: cattāraḥ mahā rājānaḥ nisīdanti idam na īsam āsane nisajjāya cārittam hoti
translated: in the Sudhamma Assembly Hall. When the Thirty-three Gods have first sat down there, the Four Great Kings sit down at the four doors. This is their conduct in sitting down on their seats.

original: Yenatthenāti yena kiccena yena payojanena. Ārakkhatthanti ārakkhabhūtamatthaṃ. Vuttaṃ vacanaṃ etesanti vuttavacanā, mahārājāno.
analyzed: yena atthena ati yena kiccena yena payojanena ārakkha attham ti ārakkha bhūtam attham vuttam vacanam etesan ti vutta vacanāḥ mahā rājāno
translated: “For the sake of which”: for the sake of which purpose, for the sake of which object. “For the sake of protection”: for the sake of the object of protection. “Those who have the speech”: those who have the speech “Vuttavacanā.”

original: 283. Atikkamitvāti abhibhavitvā.
analyzed: atikkamitvā iti abhibhavitvā
translated: “Having surpassed”: having overcome.

original: Sanaṅkumārakathāvaṇṇanā
translated: The Story of Sanaṅkumāra

original: 284. Abhisambhavituṃ adhigantuṃ asakkuṇeyyo anabhisambhavanīyo. Tenāha “appattabbo”tiādi.
analyzed: abhisambhavitum adhigantum a sakkuṇeyyaḥ an abhisambhavanīyaḥ tena āha appattabba utiādi
translated: is not to be attained. Therefore it is said: “not to be reached.”

original: Cakkhuyeva patho rūpadassanassa maggo upāyoti cakkhupatho, tasmiṃ cakkhupathasminti
analyzed: cakkhuyā iva pathaḥ rūpa dassanassa maggaḥ upāyaḥ ti cakkhu pathaḥ tasmin cakkhu pathasmin ti
translated: The path of the eye is the way, the path, of seeing visible forms. In that path of the eye,

original: āha “cakkhupasāde”ti, cakkhussa gocarayoggo vā cakkhupathoti āha “āpāthe vā”ti. Nābhibhavatīti
analyzed: āha cakkhu pasāde ti cakkhussa gocara yoggaḥ vā cakkhu pathaḥ ti āha āpāthe vāti na abhibhavati iti
translated: he said: “in the eye-sensitivity.” Or the path of the eye is the range of the eye. Therefore he said: “in the range.” He does not surpass

original: na abhibhavati, gocarabhāvaṃ na gacchatīti attho. Heṭṭhā heṭṭhāti tāvatiṃsato paṭṭhāya
analyzed: na abhibhavati gocara bhāvam na gacchati iti atthaḥ heṭṭhā heṭṭhā ti paṭṭhāya
translated: does not overpower him, does not become his domain. The meaning is that he does not come under its sway. Below, below: from the Tāvatiṃsa heaven downwards,

original: heṭṭhā heṭṭhā, na cātumahārājikato paṭṭhāya, nāpi brahmapārisajjato paṭṭhāya. “Cātumahārājikā
analyzed: heṭṭhā heṭṭhā na cātumahārājikataḥ paṭṭhāya na api brahmapārisajjataḥ paṭṭhāya cātumahārājikā
translated: not from the Cātumahārājika heaven downwards, nor from the Brahmā-pārisajya heaven downwards.

original: hi tāvatiṃsānaṃ yathā jātirūpāni passituṃ sakkonti, tathā brahmāno heṭṭhimā uparimāna”nti
analyzed: hi tāvatiṃsānam yathā jāti rūpāni passitum sakkonti tathā brahmānaḥ heṭṭhimāḥ uparimānanti
translated: “For the Cātumahārājika gods are able to see the forms of the Tāvatiṃsa gods, and the Brahmā gods are able to see those of the lower gods.”

original: keci, taṃ na yuttaṃ. Na hi heṭṭhimā brahmāno uparimānaṃ mūlapaṭisandhirūpaṃ passituṃ
analyzed: keci tam na yuttam na hi heṭṭhimāḥ brahmānaḥ uparimānam mūla paṭisandhi rūpam passitum
translated: Some say this, but it is not correct. For the Brahmā gods of the lower planes are not able to see the material form of the rebirth-linking of the gods of the higher planes.

original: sakkonti, māpitameva passituṃ sakkontīti daṭṭhabbaṃ.
analyzed: sakkonti māpitam eva passitum sakkonti iti daṭṭhabbam
translated: It should be understood that they are able to see only the created form.🔽As he was listening, he fell asleep: while he was discerning the destinies, his mind became contracted through the interruption of his discursive thought that had spread out externally.

original: Suṇantova niddaṃ okkamīti gatiyo upadhārento bahi visaṭavitakkavicchedena saṅkocaṃ āpannacittatāya. Mayhaṃ ayyakassāti bhagavantaṃ sandhāya vadati.
analyzed: suṇantaḥ iva niddam okkamīti gatiyaḥ upadhārentaḥ bahi visaṭa vitakka vicchedena saṅkocam āpanna citta tāya mayham ayyakassa ati bhagavantam sandhāya vadati
translated: My venerable sir: he speaks with reference to the Exalted One.🔽He has five crests: he is called “Pañcasikha” because he has five crests, like the Pañcasikha gandhabba.

original: Pañca sikhā etassāti pañcasikho, pañcasikho viya pañcasikhoti āha “pañcasikhagandhabbasadiso”ti. Mamāyantīti piyāyanti.
analyzed: pañca sikhāḥ etassa ati pañca sikho pañca sikhaḥ viya pañca sikhaḥ iti āha pañca sikha gandhabba sadisaḥ iti mamāyanti iti piyāyanti
translated: They are dear to me: they are pleasing to me.

original: 285. Sumuttoti saradosehi suṭṭhu mutto. Yehi pittasemhādīhi palibuddhattā saro avissaṭṭho
analyzed: su muttaḥ ti sara dosehi suṭṭhu muttaḥ yehi pitta semha ādīhi palibuddha ttā saraḥ a vissaṭṭhaḥ
translated: “Well-released” : well-released from the faults of the rainy season. When the rain is obstructed by bile, phlegm, etc., it may be uneven;

original: siyā, tadabhāvato vissaṭṭhoti dassento āha “apalibuddho”ti. Viññāpetīti viññeyyo,
analyzed: siyā tad abhāvataḥ vissaṭṭhaḥ ti dassentaḥ āha apalibuddhaḥ ti viññāpeti iti viññeyyaḥ
translated: but because of the absence of those, it is even. Showing this, he said “unobstructed.” “To be cognized” : viññeyyo.

original: antogadhahetuattho kattusādhano esa viññeyyasaddoti āha “atthaviññāpano”ti. Sarassa🔽madhuratā nāma maddavanti āha “madhuro mudū”ti. Savanaṃ arahatīti savanīyo. Savanārahatāya
analyzed: antar gadha hetu attho kattu sādhano esa viññeyya saddo ti āha attha viññāpanaḥ ti sarassa  madhuratā nāma āha madhuraḥ savanam arahati iti savanīyaḥ savana arahatāya
translated: This word viññeyya is a verbal noun formed from the root √vijñā, “to know.” Thus he said “indicating the meaning.”🔽The sweetness of the rain is its softness. Thus he said “sweet and soft.”🔽“Worth hearing” : savanīyo. And because it is worth hearing, it is pleasant to hear.🔽Thus he said “pleasant to the ear.”

original: ca āpāthasukhatāyāti āha “kaṇṇasukho”ti. Bindūti piṇḍito. Ākoṭitabhinnakaṃsasaddo🔽viya anekāvayavo ahutvā niravayavo, ekabhāvoti attho. Tenāha “ekagghano”ti, etenevassa
analyzed: ca āpātha sukhatāya iti āha kaṇṇa sukho ti bindu iti piṇḍitaḥ ākoṭita bhinna kaṃsa saddaḥ  aneka avayavaḥ a hutvā niravayavaḥ eka bhāvaḥ ti attho tena āha ekagghanaḥ ti etena iva assa
translated: “A drop” : a lump.🔽Not being a collection of many parts like the sound of a gong struck with a drumstick, it is partless, he said “compact.”

original: avisāritā saṃvaṇṇitā daṭṭhabbā. Gambhīruppattiṭṭhānatāya cassa gambhīratāti āha “nābhimūlato”tiādi.
analyzed: a visāritā saṃvaṇṇitā daṭṭhabbā gambhīra uppatti ṭṭhāna tāya ca ssa gambhīra tā iti āha nābhi mūlataḥ tiādi
translated: By this he has praised its non-diffusion. And because it has a deep origination-base, it is deep. Thus he said “from the navel” , etc.

original: Evaṃ samuṭṭhitoti jīvhādippahāramattasamuṭṭhito. Amadhuro ca hoti uppattiṭṭhānānaṃ
analyzed: evam samuṭṭhitaḥ ti jīvhā ādi ppahāra matta samuṭṭhitaḥ amadhuraḥ ca hoti uppatti ṭṭhānānam
translated: “Arisen thus” : arisen merely by the impact of the tongue, etc. It is not sweet,

original: parilahubhāvato. Na ca dūraṃ sāveti vīrabhāvābhāvato. Ninnādī suvipulabhāvato savisesaṃ
analyzed: parilahu bhāvataḥ na ca dūram vīra bhāva abhāvataḥ ninna ādī su vipula bhāvataḥ sa visesam
translated: and because of its lightness, it is not far-reaching, because of the absence of heroism.

original: ninnādo, pāsaṃsaninnādo vā. Tenāha “mahāmegha…pe… yutto”ti.
analyzed: ninnādaḥ pāsaṃsa ninnādaḥ vā tena āha mahā meghape yuttā iti
translated: It is resonant because of its great extent, and it is resonant with praise. Hence it is said, “accompanied by the great cloud-masses of the thirty-two aspects of a Buddha’s voice.”

original: Pacchimaṃ pacchimanti dutiyaṃ, catutthaṃ, chaṭṭhaṃ, aṭṭhamañca padaṃ. Purimassa purimassāti🔽yathākkamaṃ paṭhamassa, tatiyassa, pañcamassa, sattamassa ca. Atthoyevāti atthaniddeso🔽eva. Vissaṭṭhatā hissa viññeyyatāya veditabbā, mañjubhāvo savanīyatāya, bindubhāvo
analyzed: pacchimam pacchimanti dutiyam catuttham chaṭṭham aṭṭhamam ca padam purimassa purimassa ati  yathākkamam paṭhamassa tatiyassa pañcamassa sattamassa ca attho yeva ati attha niddeso  eva vissaṭṭha tā hissa viññeyya tāya veditabbā mañju bhāvaḥ savanīya tāya bindu bhāvaḥ
translated: The last of the last: the second, fourth, sixth, and eighth terms. The first of the first:🔽the first, third, fifth, and seventh terms. The meaning is:🔽The quality of being easily understood should be known as the quality of being easily heard. The quality of being pleasant should be known as the quality of being worth hearing. The quality of being unbroken should be known as the quality of being uninterrupted. The quality of being resonant should be known as the quality of being praiseworthy.

original: avisāritāya, gambhīrabhāvo ninnāditāyāti. Yathāparisanti ettha yathā-saddo parimāṇavācī,
analyzed: a visāritāya gambhīra bhāvaḥ ninnāditāya ati ettha yathā saddaḥ parimāṇa vācī
translated: The word yathā in the phrase yathā parisā means “in accordance with the extent of the assembly.”

original: na pakārādivācīti āha “yattakā parisā”ti, tena parisappamāṇaṃ evassa saro niccharati,
analyzed: na pakāra ādi vāci iti āha yattakā parisāti tena parisappamāṇam evassa saraḥ niccharati
translated: It does not mean “in accordance with the number of the assembly.” Hence it is said, “in accordance with the extent of the assembly.” Thus the sound issues forth in accordance with the extent of the assembly.

original: ayamassa dhammatāti dasseti. Tenāha “tattakamevā”tiādi.
analyzed: ayam assa dhamma tā ti dasseti tena āha tattakam eva atiādi
translated: This is the nature of the Buddha’s voice. Hence it is said, “in accordance with the extent of the assembly.”

original: “Ye hi kecī”tiādi “yāvañca so bhagavā”tiādinā vuttassa atthassa hetukittanavasena
analyzed: ye hi keci itiādi yāvat ca saḥ bhagavā ati ādinā vuttassa atthassa hetu kittana vasena
translated: It is the cause of praise.

original: samatthanaṃ saraṇesu nesaṃ niccasevanena, sīlesu ca patiṭṭhāpanena chakāmasaggasampattianuppādanato.
analyzed: samatthanam saraṇesu nesam nicca sevanena sīlesu ca patiṭṭhāpanena cha kāma sagga sampatti an uppādanato
translated: By constantly attending to the refuges and by establishing them in virtue, he causes them to attain the six kinds of success in the sense-desire world.🔽Therefore he says, “Whoever” and so on.🔽They are called “those who have gone for refuge by way of the path” because they have gone for refuge by means of the path.

original: Tenāha “ye hi keci…pe… vadatī”ti. Nibbematikagahitasaraṇeti maggenāgatasaraṇagamane.🔽Te hi sabbaso samugghātitavicikicchatāya ratanattaye aveccappasādena samannāgatāyeva,
analyzed: tena āha ye hi vadati iti maggena āgata saraṇa gamane  te hi sabbaso samugghātita vicikicchatāya rata nattaye avecca ppasādena samannāgatāya iva
translated: For they have gone for refuge by means of the path, having gone for refuge by means of the fruit.🔽They are called “those who have gone for refuge by way of the path” because they have gone for refuge by means of the path.🔽For they have gone for refuge by means of the path, having gone for refuge by means of the fruit.🔽They are called “those who have gone for refuge by way of the path” because they have gone for refuge by means of the path.🔽For they have gone for refuge by means of the path, having gone for refuge by means of the fruit.🔽They are called “those who have gone for refuge by way of the path” because they have gone for refuge by means of the path.

original: pothujjanikasaddhāya vasena buddhādīnaṃ guṇe ogāhetvā jānanti, aparaneyyabuddhino
analyzed: pothujjanika saddhāya vasena buddha ādīnam guṇe ogāhetvā jānanti aparaneyya buddhinaḥ
translated: For they have gone for refuge by means of the path, having gone for refuge by means of the fruit.🔽They are called “those who have gone for refuge by way of the path” because they have gone for refuge by means of the path.🔽For they have gone for refuge by means of the path, having gone for refuge by means of the fruit.

original: te pariyāyato nibbematikagahitasaraṇā veditabbā. Gandhabbadevagaṇanti gandhabbadevasamūhaṃ.
analyzed: te pariyāyataḥ nibbematika gahita saraṇāḥ veditabbāḥ gandhabba deva gaṇanti gandhabba deva samūham
translated: They are called “those who have gone for refuge by way of the path” because they have gone for refuge by means of the path.🔽For they have gone for refuge by means of the path, having gone for refuge by means of the fruit.

original: Tukā vuccati khīriṇī yā tukātipi vuccati. Tassā cuṇṇaṃ tukāpiṭṭhaṃ. Taṃ koṭṭetvā
analyzed: tukā vuccati khīriṇī yā tukā atipi vuccati tassā cuṇṇam tukā piṭṭham tam koṭṭetvā
translated: They are called “those who have gone for refuge by way of the path” because they have gone for refuge by means of the path.

original: pakkhittaṃ ghanaṃ nirantaracitaṃ hutvā tiṭṭhati.
analyzed: pakkhittam ghanam nirantara citam hutvā tiṭṭhati
translated: For they have gone for refuge by means of the path, having gone for refuge by means of the fruit.🔽They are called “those who have gone for refuge by way of the path” because they have gone for refuge by means of the path.🔽For they have gone for refuge by means of the path, having gone for refuge by means of the fruit.

original: Bhāvitaiddhipādavaṇṇanā
analyzed: bhāvita aiddhipāda vaṇṇanā
translated: They are called “those who have gone for refuge by way of the path” because

original: 287. Supaññattāti suṭṭhu pakārehi ñāpitā bodhitā, asaṅkarato vā ṭhapitā, taṃ pana🔽bodhanaṃ, asaṅkarato ṭhapanañca atthato desanā evāti āha “sukathitā”ti. Ijjhanaṭṭhenāti
analyzed: su paññattā ati suṭṭhu pakārehi ñāpitā bodhitā asaṅkarataḥ vā ṭhapitā tam pana  bodhanam asaṅkarato ṭhapanam ca atthataḥ desanā eva ati āha su kathitā ti ijjhan aṭṭhena ati
translated: Well-proclaimed: well-announced, well-made known, by means of the modes of statement, or else well-established without confusion. But that announcing and that establishing without confusion are in fact teaching. That is why he said “well-expounded” . As to the meaning of “success”:

original: samijjhanaṭṭhena, nippajjanassa kāraṇabhāvenāti attho. Patiṭṭhānaṭṭhenāti adhiṭṭhānaṭṭhena.🔽Iddhiyā pādoti iddhipādo, iddhiyā adhigamupāyoti attho. Tena hi yasmā uparūpari visesasaṅkhātaṃ🔽iddhiṃ pajjanti pāpuṇanti, tasmā “pādo”ti vuccati. Ijjhatīti iddhi, samijjhati nippajjatīti
analyzed: samijjhana ṭṭhena nippajjanassa kāraṇa bhāvena ati attho patiṭṭhāna ṭṭhena ati adhiṭṭhāna ṭṭhena  iddhiyā pādo ti iddhipādaḥ iddhiyā adhigama upāyo ti attho tena hi yasmai upari upari visesa saṅkhātam  iddhim pajjanti pāpuṇanti tasmā pādo ti vuccati ijjhati iti iddhi samijjhati nippajjati iti
translated: Well-proclaimed: well-announced, well-made known, by means of the modes of statement, or else well-established without confusion. But that announcing and that establishing without confusion are in fact teaching, so he said “well-expounded” . As the basis for success: as the cause for the occurrence of success, is the meaning. As the foundation: as the footing.

original: attho. Iddhi eva pādo iddhipādo, iddhikoṭṭhāsoti attho. Evaṃ tāva “cattāro iddhipādā”ti
analyzed: attho iddhi eva pādaḥ iddhipādo iddhi koṭṭhāso ti attho evam tāva cattāro iddhipādā ti
translated: Foot of success: basis of success; means of attaining success, is what is said. Because by means of it one succeeds in, reaches, higher and higher kinds of success called “special qualities” , therefore it is called “foot” . Success is what succeeds, what occurs, is the meaning. The foot of success is a basis of success; means the source of success, is what is said. This, in the first place, is how the meaning should be understood of the words four bases of success.

original: ettha attho veditabbo. Iddhipahonakatāyāti iddhiyā nipphādane samatthabhāvāya. Iddhivisavitāyāti
analyzed: ettha atthaḥ veditabbaḥ iddhi pahonaka tāya ati iddhiyāḥ nipphādane samattha bhāvāya iddhi visavi tāya ati
translated: For the production of success: for the state of being able to bring about success. For the manifestation of success:

original: iddhiyā nipphādane yogyabhāvāya. Anekatthattā hi dhātūnaṃ yogyattho vi-pubbo su-saddo,
analyzed: iddhiyāḥ nipphādane yogya bhāvāya aneka attha ttā hi dhātūnam yogya tthaḥ vipubbaḥ su saddaḥ
translated: for the purpose of fitness for the production of success. For the meaning of the root vi-pu- is fitness, since roots have many meanings, and the word su- means good.

original: visavanaṃ vā pajjanaṃ visavitā, tattha kāmakāritā visavitā. Tenāha “punappuna”ntiādi.
analyzed: visavanam vā pajjanam visavitā tattha kāma kāri tā visavitā tena āha punappunantiādi
translated: Or else, the meaning of the root vi-pu- is the act of spreading out, the spreading, and the fitness for that is the spreading out. Hence it is said, “again and again” and so on.

original: Iddhivikubbanatāyāti vikubbaniddhiyā vividharūpakaraṇāya. Tenāha “nānappakārato katvā dassanatthāyā”ti.
analyzed: iddhi vikubbana tāya ati vikubba niddhiyāḥ vividha rūpa karaṇāya tena āha nānā pakārataḥ katvā dassana tthāya ati
translated: For the purpose of success in the various transformations: for the purpose of the success in the various transformations, that is to say, for the purpose of the success in the various kinds of form. Hence it is said, “for the purpose of showing the various kinds of form” .

original: “Chandañca bhikkhu adhipatiṃ karitvā labhati samādhiṃ, labhati cittassekaggataṃ,
analyzed: chandam ca bhikkhu adhipatim karitvā labhati samādhim labhati cittassa ekagga tam
translated: “When a bhikkhu, by making predominance of will, obtains concentration, obtains one-pointedness of mind,🔽this is called concentration due to will” .

original: ayaṃ vuccati chandasamādhī”ti imāya pāḷiyā chandādhipati samādhi chandasamādhīti
analyzed: ayam vuccati chanda samādhi iti imāya pāḷiyā chanda adhipati samādhi chanda samādhi iti
translated: It is evident that the compound chandasamādhi is made by omitting the word adhipati in the text, taking it as “concentration due to will” .

original: adhipatisaddalopaṃ katvā samāso vuttoti viññāyati, adhipatisaddatthadassanavasena
analyzed: adhipati sadda lopam katvā samāsaḥ vuttaḥ ti viññāyati adhipati sadda ttha dassana vasena
translated: But it should be understood that in the commentary the word is given in the sense of “predominance” .

original: pana “chandahetuko, chandādhiko vā samādhi chandasasamādhī”ti aṭṭhakathāyaṃvuttanti
analyzed: pana chanda hetuko chanda adhikaḥ vā samādhi chanda sasamādhi iti aṭṭhakathā ayam vuttanti
translated: “Concentration due to will” is concentration caused by will or having will as its predominance.

original: veditabbaṃ. “Padhānabhūtāti vīriyabhūtā”ti keci vadanti. Saṅkhatasaṅkhārādinivattanatthañhi
analyzed: veditabbam padhāna bhūtā ati vīriya bhūtā ati keci vadanti saṅkhata saṅkhāra ādi nivattana attham hi
translated: Some say that the word padhāna is a synonym for energy . For the purpose of the cessation of formations that are formed, that is, for the purpose of the cessation of the formations that are formed by the will, etc.,

original: padhānaggahaṇanti. Atha vā taṃ taṃ visesaṃ saṅkharotīti saṅkhāro, sabbampi vīriyaṃ.🔽Tattha catukiccasādhakato aññassa nivattanatthaṃ padhānaggahaṇanti padhānabhūtā seṭṭhabhūtāti
analyzed: padhāna ggahaṇanti atha vā tam tam visesam saṅkharoti iti saṅkhāraḥ sabbam pi vīriyam  tattha catu kicca sādhakataḥ aññassa nivattana attham padhāna ggahaṇam ti padhāna bhūtā seṭṭha bhūtā ati
translated: Or alternatively, ‘forming’ is ‘forming this or that distinction’, and ‘effort’ is all energy.🔽Herein, the words ‘grasping of predominance’ are said in order to prevent any other than that which accomplishes the fourfold task. The meaning is that it is predominant, chief.🔽But because the fourfold effort is intended, the demonstrative ‘this’ is stated in the plural.

original: attho. Catubbidhassa pana vīriyassa adhippetattā bahuvacananiddeso kato. Visuṃ samāsayojanavasena🔽yo pubbe iddhipādattho pādassa upāyatthataṃ, koṭṭhāsatthatañca gahetvā yathāyogavasena🔽idha vutto, so vakkhamānānaṃ paṭilābhapubbabhāgānaṃ kattukaraṇiddhibhāvaṃ, uttaracūḷabhājanīye🔽vā vuttehi chandādīhi iddhipādehi sādhetabbāya iddhiyā kattiddhibhāvaṃ, chandādīnañca
analyzed: attho catubbidhassa pana vīriyassa adhippeta ttā bahuvacana niddeso kataḥ visum samāsa yojana vasena  yaḥ pubbe iddhipāda attho pādassa upāya ttha tam koṭṭhāsa ttha tam ca gahetvā yathā yoga vasena  idha vuttaḥ saḥ vakkhamānānam paṭilābha pubbabhāgānam kattu karaṇa iddhi bhāvam uttaracūḷa bhājanīye  vā vuttehi chanda ādīhi iddhipādehi sādhetabbāya iddhiyā kattiddhi bhāvam chanda ādīnam ca
translated: And the words ‘grasping of predominance’ are said in order to show that it is energy that is the condition for the kinds of direct-knowledge, and so on, in the way stated in the Paṭisambhidā, as follows: ‘What is the condition for the kinds of direct-knowledge? Energy is the condition for the kinds of direct-knowledge.🔽What is the condition for the supernormal powers? Energy is the condition for the supernormal powers. What is the condition for the fruits of the life of purity? Energy is the condition for the fruits of the life of purity. What is the condition for the attainment of the further-side? Energy is the condition for the attainment of the further-side’ .🔽And the words ‘grasping of predominance’ are said in order to show that it is energy that is the condition for the kinds of direct-knowledge, and so on, in the way stated in the Paṭisambhidā, as follows: ‘What is the condition for the kinds of direct-knowledge? Energy is the condition for the kinds of direct-knowledge. What is the condition for the supernormal powers? Energy is the condition for the supernormal powers. What is the condition for the fruits of the life of purity? Energy is the condition for the fruits of the life of purity. What is the condition for the attainment of the further-side? Energy is the condition for the attainment of the further-side’ .

original: karaṇiddhibhāvaṃ sandhāya vuttoti veditabbo, tasmā “ijjhanaṭṭhena iddhī”ti ettha
analyzed: karaṇa iddhi bhāvam sandhāya vuttaḥ ti veditabbaḥ tasmai ijjhan aṭṭhena iddhi iti ettha
translated: And the words ‘grasping of predominance’ are said in order to show that it is energy that is the condition for the kinds of direct-knowledge, and so on, in the way stated in the Paṭisambhidā, as follows: ‘What is the condition for the kinds of direct-knowledge? Energy is the condition for the kinds of direct-knowledge. What is the condition for the supernormal powers? Energy is the condition for the supernormal powers. What is the condition for the fruits of the life of purity? Energy

original: kattuattho, karaṇattho ca ekajjhaṃ gahetvā vuttoti kattuatthaṃ tāva dassetuṃ “nipphattipariyāyena
analyzed: kattu attho karaṇa ttho ca ekajjham gahetvā vuttaḥ iti kattu attham tāva dassetum nipphatti pariyāyena
translated: The meaning of the agent and the meaning of the instrument are taken together and spoken of as one. In order to show the meaning of the agent first, he says, “by way of the result”

original: ijjhanaṭṭhena vā”ti vatvā itaraṃ dassento “ijjhanti etāyā”tiādimāha. Vuttanti kattha🔽vuttaṃ? Iddhipādavibhaṅgapāṭhe. tathābhūtassāti tenākārena bhūtassa, te chandādidhamme
analyzed: ijjhan aṭṭhena vā ti vatvā itaram dassentaḥ ijjhan ti etāya atiādim āha vuttam ti kattha  vuttam iddhipāda vibhaṅga pāṭhe tathābhūtassa ati tena ākārena bhūtassa te chanda ādi dhamme
translated: and “by way of the mode of activity.” In order to show the other, he says, “they are inclined by this.” Where is this said? In the text of the exposition of the bases of success.

original: paṭilabhitvā ṭhitassāti attho. “Vedanākkhandho”tiādīhi chandādayo antokatvā cattāropi
analyzed: paṭilabhitvā ṭhitassa ti atthaḥ vedanā khandhaḥ ti ādīhi chanda ādayaḥ antokatvā cattāro pi
translated: “Having become such”: having become such by that mode; having obtained the states of desire, etc., and being established, is the meaning. By the words “the aggregate of feeling,” etc., desire, etc., are included and the four aggregates are spoken of.

original: khandhā kathitā. Sesesūti sesiddhipādesu.
analyzed: khandhā kathitā sesesu uti se siddhipādesu
translated: “In the rest”: in the remaining bases of success.

original: Vīriyiddhipādaniddese “vīriyasamādhipadhānasaṅkhārasamannāgata”nti dvikkhattuṃ vīriyaṃ
analyzed: vīriya iddhipāda niddese vīriya samādhi padhāna saṅkhāra samannāgatanti dvikkhattum vīriyam
translated: In the description of the basis of success that is energy, “accompanied by concentration due to energy and by the will to strive” energy is mentioned twice.

original: āgataṃ. Tattha purimaṃ samādhivisesanaṃ “vīriyādhipati samādhi vīriyasamādhī”ti,
analyzed: āgatam tattha purimam samādhi visesanam vīriya adhipati samādhi vīriya samādhi iti
translated: Herein, the first energy is a distinguishing of concentration: “concentration due to energy is concentration by energy.”

original: dutiyaṃ samannāgamaṅgadassanaṃ. Dveyeva hi sabbattha samannāgamaṅgāni, samādhi, padhānasaṅkhāro
analyzed: dutiyam samannāgam aṅga dassanam dveyā iva hi sabbattha samannāgam aṅgāni samādhi padhāna saṅkhāro
translated: The second is the showing of the factor of possession. For there are only two factors of possession everywhere: concentration and the will to strive.

original: ca. Chandādayo hi samādhivisesanāni, padhānasaṅkhāro pana padhānavacaneneva visesito,
analyzed: ca chanda ādayaḥ hi samādhi visesanāni padhāna saṅkhāraḥ pana padhāna vacanena iva visesitaḥ
translated: For zeal, etc., are the special qualities of concentration, but the faculty of energy is distinguished by the word “endeavour” .

original: na chandādīhīti na idha vīriyādhipatitā padhānasaṅkhārassa vuttā hoti. Vīriyañca
analyzed: na chanda ādīhi iti na idha vīriya adhipati tā padhāna saṅkhārassa vuttā hoti vīriyam ca
translated: So it is not said here of the faculty of energy that it is the basis of success.

original: samādhiṃ visesetvā ṭhitameva, samannāgamaṅgavasena pana padhānasaṅkhāravacanena vuttanti
analyzed: samādhim visesetvā ṭhitam eva samannāgam aṅga vasena pana padhāna saṅkhāra vacanena vuttanti
translated: And energy is established as distinguishing concentration, but it is said of the faculty of concentration that it is the basis of success by the word “endeavour” in the sense of the factor of right concentration.

original: nāpi dvīhi vīriyehi samannāgamo vutto hoti. Yasmā pana chandādīhi visiṭṭho samādhi,
analyzed: na api dvīhi vīriyehi samannāgamaḥ vuttaḥ hoti yasmā pana chanda ādīhi visiṭṭhaḥ samādhi
translated: So it is not said that there is possession of the two kinds of energy.🔽But since concentration is distinguished by zeal, etc.,

original: tathāvisiṭṭheneva ca tena sampayutto padhānasaṅkhāro, sesadhammā ca, tasmā samādhivisesanānaṃ
analyzed: tathā visiṭṭhena iva ca tena sampayuttaḥ padhāna saṅkhāro sesa dhammā ca tasmā samādhi visesa nānam
translated: and the basis of success is associated with it as distinguished in this way, and the other states are too,🔽the four bases for success are stated as the special qualities of concentration.

original: vasena cattāro iddhipādā vuttā, visesanabhāvo ca chandādīnaṃ taṃtaṃavassayadassanavasena🔽hotīti “chandasamādhi…pe… iddhipāda”nti ettha nissayatthepi pāda-sadde upāyatthena
analyzed: vasena cattāro iddhipādāḥ vuttāḥ visesana bhāvaḥ ca chanda ādīnam taṃ taṃ avassaya dassana vasena  hoti iti ettha nissaya tthe pi pāda sadde upāya tthena
translated: And the special quality of zeal, etc., is stated as the basis of success in the sense of cause, though the word “basis” is also in the sense of support,🔽in the passage, “Concentration through zeal as a basis” , etc., because zeal, etc., are the cause of the bases for success.🔽That is why it is said that zeal, etc., are the bases for success in the sense of cause.

original: chandādīnaṃ iddhipādatā vuttā hoti. Teneva hi abhidhamme uttaracūḷabhājanīye “cattāro
analyzed: chanda ādīnam iddhipāda tā vuttā hoti tena iva hi abhidhamme uttaracūḷabhājanīye cattāro
translated: And that is why in the Abhidhamma the following is said in the Uttarādhyayana: “What is the basis for success as zeal?

original: iddhipādā chandiddhipādo”tiādinā chandādīnameva iddhipādatā vuttā. Pañhapucchake
analyzed: iddhipādā chandā iddhipādā iti ādinā chanda ādīnam eva iddhipāda tā vuttā pañha pucchake
translated: And in the Questions of Nāḷādana:

original: “cattāro iddhipādā idha bhikkhu chandasamādhī”tiādinā ca uddesaṃ katvāpi puna chandādīnaṃyeva
analyzed: cattāro iddhipādāḥ idha bhikkhu chanda samādhi iti ādinā ca uddesam katvā api puna
translated: “The four bases of success: here a bhikkhu, having entered upon and abides in the first jhāna, which is … born of seclusion, on that occasion his will-concentration is will- concentration based on renunciation” , etc.,🔽and after the summary, the profitable, etc., state of will, etc., is again distinguished.

original: kusalādibhāvo vibhatto. Upāyiddhipādadassanatthameva hi nissayiddhipādadassanaṃ kataṃ,
analyzed: kusala ādi bhāvaḥ vibhattaḥ upāya iddhipāda dassana attham eva hi nissaya iddhipāda dassanam katam
translated: For the demonstration of the bases of success as a means is given only in order to show the bases of success as a support.

original: aññathā catubbidhatā na siyāti. Ayamettha pāḷivasena atthavinicchayo veditabbo. Idāni🔽paṭilābhapubbabhāgānaṃ vasena iddhipāde vibhajitvā dassetuṃ “apicā”tiādi vuttaṃ,
analyzed: aññathā catubbidha tā na siyāti ayam ettha pāḷi vasena attha vinicchayaḥ veditabbaḥ idāni  paṭilābha pubbabhāgānam vasena iddhipāde vibhajitvā dassetum api ca itiādi vuttam
translated: Otherwise the fourfoldness would not be established. This is how the exposition should be understood here as to the text.🔽Now, in order to show the bases of success by distinguishing them as to acquisition and prior state, the words “Besides, the four bases of success” are stated.

original: taṃ suviññeyyameva. Idha iddhipādakathā saṅkhepeneva vuttāti āha “vitthārena pana…pe… vuttā”ti.🔽Kecīti abhayagirivāsino. Tesu hi ekacce “iddhi nāma anipphannā”ti vadanti, ekacce
analyzed: tam su viññeyyam eva idha iddhipāda kathā saṅkhepena iva vuttā iti āha vitthārena pana pe vuttā iti  keci iti abhayagiri vāsino tesu hi ekacce id hi nāma anipphannā ati vadanti ekacce
translated: That is sufficiently clear. Herein, the explanation of the bases of success is given in brief, so it is said, “But in the Paṭisambhidā they are given in detail.”🔽“Some” are the residents of the Abhayagiri Monastery. For some of them say that success is unarisen, while others say that the base of success is unarisen.

original: “iddhipādo pana anipphanno”ti vadanti, anipphannoti ca paramatthato asiddho, natthīti
analyzed: iddhipādaḥ pana anipphannaḥ ti vadanti anipphannaḥ ti ca paramatthataḥ asiddhaḥ natthi iti
translated: And by “unarisen” they mean non-existent in the ultimate sense.

original: attho. Ābhatoti abhidhammapāṭhato dīghanikāyaṭṭhakathāyaṃ ānīto purimanayato aññenākārena
analyzed: atthaḥ ābhato ti abhidhamma pāṭhataḥ dīgha nikāya ṭṭhakathāyam ānītaḥ purima nayataḥ aññena ākārena
translated: Meaning. Brought: brought from the Abhidhamma Piṭaka into the Commentary on the Dīgha Nikāya by a different method from that used above.

original: desanāya pavattattā. Chando eva iddhipādo chandiddhipādo. Eseva nayo sesesupi. Ime
analyzed: desanāya pavattattā chando eva iddhipādo chanda iddhipādo esa iva nayo sesesu pi ime
translated: Will-power is the basis for success, thus will-power is a basis for success. So too with the rest.

original: panāti imasmiṃ sutte āgatā iddhipādā. Raṭṭhapālatthero “chande sati kathaṃ nānujānissantī”ti
analyzed: pana ati imasmin sutte āgatāḥ iddhipādāḥ raṭṭhapāla thero chande sati katham na anujānissanti iti
translated: These: the bases for success stated in this sutta. The Elder Raṭṭhapāla, thinking “If there is will-power, why should they not allow it?”

original: sattāhaṃ bhattāni abhuñjitvā mātāpitaro anujānāpetvā pabbajitvā chandameva avassāya🔽lokuttaraṃ dhammaṃ nibbattesīti āha “raṭṭhapālatthero…pe… nibbattesī”ti. Soṇatthero
analyzed: sattāham bhattāni a bhuñjitvā mātā pitaraḥ anujānāpetvā pabbajitvā chandam eva avassāya  lokuttaram dhammam nibbattesi iti āha nibbattesi iti soṇa tthero
translated: refused to eat for seven days, and after getting his parents’ permission to go forth he produced the supramundane state by depending on will-power alone.

original: bhāvanamanuyutto āraddhavīriyo paramasukhumālo pādesu phoṭesu jātesupi vīriyaṃ nappaṭipassambhesīti
analyzed: bhāvanam anuyuttaḥ āraddha vīriyo parama sukhu mālo pādesu phoṭesu jātesu pi vīriyam na paṭipassambhesi iti
translated: The Elder Soṇa, devoted to meditation, did not slacken his energy even when a very fine hair grew on his feet.

original: āha “soṇatthero vīriyaṃ dhuraṃ katvā”ti. Sambhūtatthero “cittavato kiṃ nāma na sijjhatī”ti
analyzed: āha soṇa ttheraḥ vīriyam dhuram katvā ati sambhūta ttheraḥ cittavataḥ kim nāma na sijjhati iti
translated: The Elder Sambhūta, thinking “What is not successful for one who has mental development?”

original: cittaṃ pubbaṅgamaṃ katvā bhāvanaṃ ārādhesīti āha “sambhūtatthero cittaṃ dhuraṃ katvā”ti.🔽Moghatthero vīmaṃsaṃ avassayi, tasmā tassa bhagavā “suññato lokaṃ avekkhassū”ti suññatākathaṃ
analyzed: cittam pubbaṅgamam katvā bhāvanam ārādhesi iti āha sambhūta theraḥ cittam dhuram katvā iti  moghattheraḥ vīmaṃsam tasmā tassa bhagavā suññataḥ lokam avekkhassu iti suññatā katham
translated: He has fulfilled development by making cognizance the forerunner.🔽The Blessed One spoke the discourse on emptiness to the venerable Mogharāja, saying, “Contemplate the world as empty,” in order to restrain conceit based on understanding and to make him understand understanding.

original: kathesi, paññānissitamānaniggahatthaṃ, paññāya pariggahatthañca dvikkhattuṃ pucchito🔽samāno pañhaṃ kathesi. Tenāha “āyasmā mogharājā vīmaṃsaṃ dhuraṃ katvā”ti.
analyzed: kathesi paññā nissita māna niggaha ttham paññāya pariggaha ttham ca dvi kkhattum pucchitaḥ  samāno pañham kathesi tena āha āyasman mogha rājā vīmaṃsam dhuram katvā ati
translated: When asked twice, he answered the question. Therefore it was said: “The venerable Mogharāja, making investigation the forerunner, … .”

original: Punappunaṃ chanduppādanaṃ pesanaṃ viya hotīti chandassa upaṭṭhānasadisatā vuttā.
analyzed: punappunam chanda uppādanam pesanam viya hoti iti chandassa upaṭṭhāna sadisa tā vuttā
translated: The arousing of desire again and again is like sending, so the simile of desire’s being like a messenger is stated.

original: Parakkamenāti parakkamasīsena sūrabhāvaṃ vadati. Thāmabhāvato ca vīriyassa sūrabhāvasadisatā daṭṭhabbā.
analyzed: parakkamena ati parakkama sīsena sūra bhāvam vadati thāma bhāvato ca vīriyassa sūra bhāva sadisa tā daṭṭhabbā
translated: “By endeavour” : he says that it is like a scent that is spread by the wind. And the simile of endeavour’s being like a scent should be regarded as follows. Since it is the state of firmness, endeavour is like a scent.

original: Cintanappadhānattā cittassa mantasaṃvidhānasadisatā vuttā.
analyzed: cintana ppadhāna ttā cittassa manta saṃvidhāna sadisa tā vuttā
translated: “By cognizance” : the simile of cognizance’s being like a spell is stated because of cognizance’s pre-eminence in thinking.

original: Jātisampatti nāma visiṭṭhajātitā. “Sabbadhammesu ca paññā seṭṭhā”ti vīmaṃsāya jātisampattisadisatā
analyzed: jāti sampatti nāma visiṭṭha jāti tā sabba dhammesu ca paññā seṭṭhā ati vīmaṃsāya jāti sampatti sadisa tā
translated: “The excellence of birth” is the state of being of a distinguished kind. And since understanding is the best of all ideas, investigation’s being like the excellence of birth should be regarded as follows.

original: vuttā. Sammohavinodaniyaṃ pana cittiddhipādassa jātisampattisadisatā, vīmaṃsiddhipādassa
analyzed: vuttā sammoha vinodaniyam pana citta iddhipādassa jāti sampatti sadisa tā vīmaṃsiddhipādassa
translated: and in the Sammohavinodani the perfection of his birth is likened to the basis of success consisting of desire,

original: mantabalasadisatā ca yojitā.
analyzed: ca yojitā
translated: and his strength of thought to the basis of success consisting of inquiry.

original: Anekaṃ vihitaṃ vidhaṃ etassāti anekavihitanti āha “anekavidha”nti. Vidha-saddo koṭṭhāsapariyāyo “ekavidhena ñāṇavatthū”tiādīsu viyāti āha “iddhividhanti iddhikoṭṭhāsa”nti.
analyzed: anekam vihitam vidham etassa ati aneka vihitanti āha anekavidhanti vidha saddo koṭṭhāsa pariyāyaḥ ekavidhena ñāṇa vatthu uti ādīsu viyā iti āha iddhi vidhanti iddhi koṭṭhāsanti
translated: “Of many kinds”: “of many kinds” means “of many sorts.” The word vidha is a synonym for koṭṭhāsa . It is used in the sense of “section” in such passages as “ekavidhena ñāṇavatthū” .

original: Tividhaokāsādhigamavaṇṇanā
analyzed: tividha okāsa adhigama vaṇṇanā
translated: The explanation of the attainment of the triple clear-vision

original: 288. “Sukhassā”ti idaṃ tiṇṇampi sukhānaṃ sādhāraṇavacananti āha “jhānasukhassa maggasukhassa
analyzed: sukhassa ati idam tiṇṇam pi sukhānam sādhāraṇa vacanan ti āha jhāna sukhassa magga sukhassa
translated: “For the happiness”: this is a general term for the three kinds of happiness. Therefore the commentator says: “for the happiness of jhāna, for the happiness of the path,

original: phalasukhassā”ti. Nānappanāpattatāya pana appadhānattā upacārajjhānasukhassa, vipassanāsukhassa
analyzed: phala sukhassa ati nānā appanā patta tāya pana appadhāna ttā upacāra jhāna sukhassa vipassanā sukhassa
translated: for the happiness of fruition.” But the happiness of access concentration and the happiness of insight are not mentioned because they are not the chief kinds of happiness.

original: cettha aggahaṇaṃ. Purimesu tāva dvīsu okāsādhigamesu tīṇipi sukhāni labbhanti, tatiye
analyzed: ca ittha aggahaṇam purimesu tāva dvīsu okāsa adhigamesu sukhāni labbhanti tatiye
translated: In the first two kinds of attainment of clear-vision, all three kinds of happiness are found. But in the third kind,

original: pana kathanti? Tattha kāmaṃ tīṇi na labbhanti, dve pana labbhantiyeva. Yathālābhavasena
analyzed: pana kathanti tattha kāmam tīṇi na labbhanti dve pana yathā lābha vasena
translated: how is it? There, of course, the three kinds of happiness are not found, but the other two are found.

original: hetaṃ vuttaṃ. “Sakkharakathalampi macchagumbampi carantampi tiṭṭhantampī”tiādīsu🔽viya. Saṃsaṭṭhoti saṃsaggaṃ upagato samaṅgībhūto, so pana tehi samannāgatacittopi
analyzed: vuttam sakkhara kathalam pi maccha gumbam pi carantam pi tiṭṭhantam pi iti ādīsu  viya saṃsaṭṭhaḥ ti saṃsaggam upagato samaṅgībhūto saḥ pana tehi samannāgata cittaḥ api
translated: As in the passage beginning, “Whether walking or standing, whether sitting or lying” .🔽“Associates with” : he has gone to the association, he has become a companion. It is said that he has a mind associated with them.🔽“The Dispensation of the Noble Ones” : the Dhamma that brings about the state of an ariya.

original: hotīti vuttaṃ “sampayuttacitto”ti. Ariyadhammanti ariyabhāvakaraṃ dhammaṃ. Upāyatoti
analyzed: hoti iti vuttam sampayutta cittaḥ ti ariya dhammanti ariya bhāva karam dhammam upāyatas ti
translated: “By the right method” : by the prescribed method.🔽“By the path” : by the path.🔽“By the reason” : by the cause.

original: vidhito. Pathatoti maggato. Kāraṇatoti hetuto. Yena hi vidhinā dhammānudhammapaṭipatti🔽hoti, so upeti etenāti upāyo, so tadadhigamassa maggabhāvato patho, tassa karaṇato
analyzed: vidhitaḥ pathataḥ ti maggataḥ kāraṇataḥ ti hetutaḥ yena hi vidhinā dhamma anudhamma paṭipatti  hoti saḥ upeti etena ati upāyaḥ saḥ tad adhigamassa magga bhāvataḥ patho tassa karaṇato
translated: For the practice in conformity with the Dhamma is the method by which one approaches the attainment of the goal.

original: kāraṇanti ca vuccati.
analyzed: kāraṇanti ca vuccati
translated: It is the path because it has the nature of a path to the attainment of the goal. It is called the reason because it is the cause of the attainment of the goal.

original: “Aniccantiādivasena manasi karotī”ti saṅkhepato vuttamatthaṃ vivarituṃ “yoniso manasikāro
analyzed: manasi karoti iti saṅkhepataḥ vuttam attham vivaritum yonisaḥ manasikāro
translated: “He gives attention to it by way of the impermanence, etc., of the aggregates” .🔽In order to explain the meaning stated in brief, it is said, “The right reflection is called the right reflection on the right occasion, etc.” .

original: nāmā”tiādi vuttaṃ. Tattha upāyamanasikāroti kusaladhammappavattiyā kāraṇabhūto manasikāro.
analyzed: nāma atiādi vuttam tattha upāya manasikāro ti kusala dhamma ppavattiyā kāraṇa bhūtaḥ manasikāro
translated: Therein, “right reflection” is the reflection that is the cause for the occurrence of wholesome dhammas.

original: Pathamanasikāroti tassa eva maggabhūto manasikāro. Anicceti ādiantavantatāya, anaccantikatāya
analyzed: patha manasikāro ti tassa eva magga bhūtaḥ manasikāraḥ anicca iti ādi antavanta tāya an accantika tāya
translated: The first attention is the attention that is the path. The impermanent: the formations of the three planes are impermanent because they are not permanent,

original: ca anicce tebhūmake saṅkhāre “anicca”nti manasikāroti yojanā. Eseva nayo sesesupi.
analyzed: ca anicce tebhūmake saṅkhāre yojanā esā iva nayo sesesu pi
translated: because they are not lasting, because they are not eternal. The contemplation of impermanence is the attention given to the formations of the three planes as impermanent. The same method applies to the rest.

original: Ayaṃ pana viseso tasmiṃyeva udayabbayapaṭipīḷanatāya dukkhanato, dukkhamato ca dukkhe,
analyzed: ayam pana visesaḥ tasmin yeva udaya bbaya paṭipīḍana tāya dukkha nataḥ dukkha mataḥ ca dukkhe
translated: But there is this difference: in the case of suffering, the formations of the three planes are suffering because they are oppressed by rise and fall, and because they are the basis for suffering.

original: avasavattanatthena, anattasabhāvatāya ca anattani, asucisabhāvatāya asubhe. Sabbampi
analyzed: avasavattana atthena anatta sabhāvatāya ca anattani asuci sabhāvatāya asubhe sabbam pi
translated: In the case of non-self, they are non-self because they are not the self, because they are not one’s own, because they are not under one’s control.

original: hi tebhūmakaṃ saṅkhataṃ kilesāsucipaggharaṇato “asubha”ntveva vattuṃ arahati. Saccānulomikena🔽vāti saccābhisamayassa anulomanavasena. “Cittassa āvaṭṭanā”tiādinā āvajjanāya paccayabhūtā
analyzed: hi tebhūmakam saṅkhatam vattum arahati sat ca ānulomikena  vāti sacca abhisamayassa anulomana vasena cittassa āvaṭṭana ati ādinā āvajjanāya paccaya bhūtā
translated: In the case of foulness, they are foul because they are the source of the foul-smelling impurities of defilement.🔽Or alternatively, the contemplation of impermanence, etc., is in conformity with the truths because it is a condition for the penetration of the truths.🔽The “turning of the mind” is the wholesome impulsion of the mind-door process that is a condition for the adverting.

original: tato purimuppannā manodvārikā kusalajavanappavatti phalavohāreneva tathā vuttā. Tassā
analyzed: tato purima uppannā manodvārikā kusala javana ppavatti phala vohārena iva tathā vuttā tassā
translated: It is called “fruit” because it arises immediately next to the adverting.

original: hi vasena sā kusaluppattiyā upanissayo hotīti. Āvajjanā hi bhavaṅgacittaṃ āvaṭṭetīti
analyzed: hi vasena sā kusala uppattiyāḥ upanissayaḥ hoti iti āvajjanā hi bhavaṅga cittam āvaṭṭeti iti
translated: for it is a decisive support for the arising of profitable states by means of that.🔽Because it turns the life-continuum consciousness over to the object, it is “turning over of consciousness.”

original: cittassa āvaṭṭanā, anu anu āvaṭṭetīti anvāvaṭṭanā. Bhavaṅgārammaṇato aññaṃ ābhujatīti
analyzed: cittassa āvaṭṭanā anu anu āvaṭṭeti iti anvāvaṭṭanā bhavaṅga ārammaṇato aññam ābhujati iti
translated: It turns over again and again, thus it is “repeated turning over.”🔽It is “application” because it applies to the object other than that of the life-continuum.🔽It is “attention” because it attends to the object.

original: ābhogo. Samannāharatīti samannāhāro. Tadevārammaṇaṃ attānaṃ anubandhitvā anubandhitvā🔽uppajjamāne manasi karoti ṭhapetīti manasikāro. Ayaṃ vuccatīti ayaṃ upāyamanasikāralakkhaṇo
analyzed: ābhogo samannāharati iti samannāhāro tat eva ārammaṇam attānam anubandhitvā anubandhitvā  uppajjamāne manasi karoti ṭhapeti iti manasikāraḥ ayam vuccati iti ayam upāya manasikāra lakkhaṇo
translated: It is “adverting” because it adverts to the object.🔽It is “mindfulness” because it makes the object present to mind and keeps it present.

original: yonisomanasikāro nāma vuccati, yassa vasena puggalo dukkhādīni saccāni āvajjituṃ sakkoti.
analyzed: yonisomanasikāraḥ nāma vuccati yassa vasena puggalaḥ dukkha ādīni saccāni āvajjitum sakkoti
translated: This is called right thinking: this right thinking that has the characteristic of directing the means is called right thinking, by means of which a man is able to advert to the truths of suffering, and so on.

original: Asaṃsaṭṭhoti na saṃsaṭṭho kāmādīhi vivitto vinābhūto. Kāmādivisaṃsaggahetu uppajjanakasukhaṃ
analyzed: asaṃsaṭṭho ti na saṃsaṭṭhaḥ kāma ādīhi vivittaḥ vinābhūtaḥ kāma ādi visaṃsagga hetu uppajjanaka sukham
translated: Unassociated: not associated with sense desire, etc., secluded, secluded from, dissociated from, sense desire, and so on. The pleasure that arises as the cause for the relinquishment of sense desire, and so on,

original: nāma vivekajaṃ pītisukhanti āha “paṭhamajjhānasukha”nti. Kāmaṃ paṭhamajjhānasukhampi
analyzed: nāma viveka jam pīti sukham iti āha paṭhamajjhāna sukham ti kāmam paṭhamajjhāna sukham pi
translated: is called “the pleasure of seclusion” and “the pleasure of happiness and bliss born of seclusion.” So it is said that “the pleasure of the first jhāna” is meant.

original: somanassameva, suttesu pana taṃ kāyikasukhassāpi paccayabhāvato visesato “sukha”ntveva
analyzed: somanassam eva suttesu pana tam kāyika sukhassa api paccaya bhāvataḥ visesataḥ
translated: But in the Suttas it is called “happiness” in the sense of being a condition for bodily happiness too.

original: vuccatīti idhāpi jhānabhūtaṃ somanassaṃ sukhanti, itaraṃ somanassaṃ. Tena vuttaṃ
analyzed: vuccati iti idha api jhāna bhūtam somanassam sukhanti itaram somanassam tena vuttam
translated: So here too the happiness that is a jhāna is called “happiness” and the other is “joy.” Hence it was said above🔽“happiness” is said in the sense of the happiness that is a jhāna.

original: “sukhā”ti. Hetumhi nissakkavacananti āha “jhānasukhapaccayā”ti. Aparāparaṃ somanassanti
analyzed: sukhā ti hetumhi nissakka vacananti āha jhāna sukha paccayā ti apara aparam somanassa nti
translated: “The cause of happiness” is the cause of the happiness that is a jhāna.

original: jhānādhigamahetu paccavekkhaṇādivasena punappunaṃ uppajjanakasomanassaṃ.
analyzed: jhāna adhigama hetu paccavekkhaṇa ādi vasena punappunam uppajjanaka somanassam
translated: “Repeated joy” is the joy that arises again and again through reviewing the attainment of the jhāna and so on.

original: Pamodanaṃ pamudo, taruṇapīti, tato pamudā. “Pāmojjaṃ pītatthāyā”tiādīsu taruṇapīti🔽“pāmojja”nti vuccati, idha pana pakaṭṭho mudo pamudo pāmojjanti adhippetaṃ, tañca
analyzed: pamodanam pamudaḥ taruṇa pīti tatas pamudā pāmojjam pītatthāya ati ādīsu taruṇa pīti  pāmojjanti vuccati idha pana pakaṭṭhaḥ mudaḥ pamudaḥ pāmojjanti adhippetam tat ca
translated: “Gladness” is the young of joy. In such passages as “Gladness is a condition for the state of happiness” , “gladness” is said to be young joy.

original: somanassarahitaṃ natthīti avinābhāvitāya “balavataraṃ pītisomanassa”nti vuttaṃ. Jhānassa
analyzed: somanassa rahitam na atthi iti avinābhāvitāya balavataram pīti somanassan ti vuttam jhānassa
translated: But here what is intended is the mature gladness called “gladness,” “joy,” and “rapture.” And that is never without happiness. So because it is invariably conjoined with happiness it is said to be “strong happiness and joy.”

original: ujuvipaccanīkataṃ sandhāya “pañca nīvaraṇāni vikkhambhetvā”ti vuttaṃ. Jhānaṃ pana
analyzed: uju vipaccanīka tam sandhāya pañca nīvaraṇāni vikkhambhetvā iti vuttam jhānam pana
translated: The words “after abandoning the five hindrances” are said with reference to the fact that the jhāna is entered upon by completely surmounting the hindrances.🔽But the jhāna itself is not entered upon by the surmounting of the hindrances.

original: tadekaṭṭhe sabbepi kilese, sabbepi akusale dhamme vikkhambhetiyeva, attano okāsaṃ
analyzed: tad ekaṭṭhe sabbe api kilese sabbe api akusale dhamme vikkhambhetiya iva attanaḥ okāsam
translated: and all defilements and all unprofitable things are suppressed in the one who has entered upon it, and it stands in its own place,

original: gahetvā tiṭṭhati paṭipakkhadhammehi anabhibhavanīyato. Tasmāti okāsaggahaṇato, laddhokāsatāyāti
analyzed: gahetvā tiṭṭhati paṭipakkha dhammehi an abhibhavanīyato tasmā ati okāsa ggahaṇataḥ laddha ukāsa tāya ati
translated: unconquered by opposing states. So it is because it takes a place that it is called “having reached the place” .

original: attho. Maggaphalasukhādhigamāya okāsabhāvato vā okāso, assa adhigamo okāsādhigamo.
analyzed: atthaḥ magga phala sukha adhigamāya okāsa bhāvataḥ vā okāsaḥ assa adhigamaḥ okāsa adhigamaḥ
translated: Or alternatively, it is a place because it is a means to the attainment of the bliss of the path and fruition. The reaching of that is “the reaching of the place” .

original: Purimapakkhe pana okāsaṃ avasaraṃ adhigacchati etenāti okāsādhigamo.
analyzed: purima pakkhe pana okāsam avasaram adhigacchati etena ati okāsa adhigamaḥ
translated: But in the former case it is the reaching of a place, a chance, by means of this, thus it is “the reaching of the place” .

original: Rūpasabhāvatāya, ekantarūpādhīnavuttitāya, savipphārikatāya ca ānāpānavitakkavicārānaṃ
analyzed: rūpa sabhāva tāya ekanta rūpa adhīna vutti tāya sa vipphārika tāya ca
translated: because of the grossness of the in-breaths and out-breaths, which are a single materiality, which have a mode of existence dependent on a single materiality, and which are extended.

original: thūlabhāvaṃ anujānanto “kāyavacīsaṅkhārā tāva oḷārikā hontū”ti āha. Tabbidhuratāya🔽pana ekaccānaṃ vedanāsaññānaṃ thūlataṃ ananujānanto “cittasaṅkhārā kathaṃ oḷārikā”ti
analyzed: thūla bhāvam anujānantaḥ kāya vacī saṅkhārā tāvat oḷārikāḥ hontu iti āha tad bidhura tāya  pana ekaccānam vedanā saññānam thūlatam an anujānanto citta saṅkhārā katham oḷārikā ati
translated: He says, “Let bodily and verbal formations be gross,”🔽but he does not allow that certain feelings and perceptions are gross because of their subtlety.

original: āha. Itaro “appahīnattā”ti kāraṇaṃ vatvā “kāyasaṅkhārā hī”tiādinā tamatthaṃ vivarati.
analyzed: āha itaraḥ kāraṇam vatvā kāya saṅkhārāḥ hi iti ādinā tam attham vivarati
translated: He says, “How can mental formations be gross?” The other replies, “Because they are unabandoned,” and he explains the meaning of that, “Bodily formations are abandoned,” and so on.

original: Teti cittasaṅkhārā. Appahīnā saṅkhārā labbhamānasaṅkhāranimittatāya “oḷārikā”ti vattuṃ
analyzed: tā iti citta saṅkhārāḥ appahīnā saṅkhārāḥ labbhamāna saṅkhāra nimitta tāya oḷārikā iti vattum
translated: The “volitions” are the mental volitions. The volitions that have not been abandoned are called “gross” because they are the sign of the occurrence of volitions.

original: arahanti, pahīnā pana tadabhāvato “sukhumā”ti āha “pahīne upādāya appahīnattā oḷārikā
analyzed: arahanti pahīnā pana tad abhāvato sukhumā iti āha pahīne upādāya appahīna ttā oḷārikā
translated: The abandoned ones are called “subtle” because they are not that.

original: nāma jātā”ti. Pāḷiyaṃ “kāyasaṅkhārānaṃ paṭippassaddhiyā”ti vuttattā “sukhanti catutthajjhānikaphalasamāpattisukha”nti
analyzed: nāma jātā ati pāḷiyam kāya saṅkhārānam paṭippassaddhiyā ati vutta ttā sukhanti catuttha jhānika phala samāpatti sukhanti
translated: “The happiness is the happiness of the fourth jhāna and of the attainment of fruition” is said because of the words “with the stilling of applied and sustained thought” in the text.

original: vuttaṃ. “Cittasaṅkhārānaṃ paṭippassaddhiyā”ti pana vuttattā “nirodhā vuṭṭhahantassā”ti
analyzed: vuttam citta saṅkhārānam paṭippassaddhiyā iti pana vutta ttā nirodhā vuṭṭhahantassa ati
translated: “When he emerges from cessation” is said because of the words “with the stilling of all the volitional formations” in the text.

original: vuttaṃ. Vacīsaṅkhārapaṭippassaddhi kāyasaṅkhārapaṭippassaddhiyāva siddhāti veditabbā.
analyzed: vuttam vacī saṅkhāra paṭippassaddhi kāya saṅkhāra paṭippassaddhiyā ava siddhā iti veditabbā
translated: The stilling of the verbal formations should be understood as included in the stilling of the bodily formations.

original: Tenevāha “dutiya…pe… visuṃ na vuttānī”ti. Pāḷiyaṃ pana atthato siddhāpi supākaṭabhāvena
analyzed: tena iva āha dutiya pe visum na vuttāni iti pāḷiyam pana atthataḥ siddhā api su pākaṭa bhāvena
translated: That is why it is said: “The second jhāna … is not mentioned separately” .🔽But in the text they are taken literally in order to make the meaning clear, although it is established by the meaning.

original: vibhāvetuṃ sarūpato gaṇhāti. Na hi ariyavinaye atthāpattivibhāvanā abhidhammadesanāya
analyzed: vibhāvetum sarūpataḥ gaṇhāti na hi ariya vinaye atthāpatti vibhāvanā abhidhamma desanāya
translated: For in the Noble One’s Discipline the elucidation of the meaning is not by Abhidhamma teaching,

original: pakatīti. Yathā nīvaraṇavikkhambhanañca paṭhamassa jhānassa adhigamāya upāyo, evaṃ🔽sukhadukkhavikkhambhanaṃ catutthassa jhānassa adhigamāya upāyoti “catutthajjhānaṃ
