translated: ‘Having well entrusted’: having well handed over, having given over, by way of that very respect. ‘He sees that matter’: he is a giver of the benefit.🔽‘Bhavamatthū’ is said by way of the affixing of the ma- vowel and the substitution of the a- vowel for the o- vowel. ‘Bhavamatthū’ means ‘he is the cause of increase’, ‘increase’ being ‘bhavana’ (increase), ‘bhavo’ (becoming) because of the affixing of the sandhi vowel, or ‘bhavo’ (becoming) because of ‘he becomes by this’.

original: pana sāmiatthe upayogavacananti āha “bhoto”ti. Mā paccabyāhāsīti mā paṭikkhipīti🔽attho. So pana paṭikkhepo paṭivacanaṃ hotīti āha “mā paṭibyāhāsī”ti. Abhisambhosīti
analyzed: pana sāmi atthe upayoga vacananti āha bhoto ti mā paccabyāhāsi iti mā paṭikkhipi iti  atthaḥ saḥ pana paṭikkhepaḥ paṭivacanam hoti iti āha mā paṭibyāhāsi iti abhisambhosi iti
translated: ‘Bhoto jotipālassa’ is said by way of the use of the word ‘bhava’ (lord) in the sense of ‘master’. ‘Do not refuse’: the meaning is ‘do not reject’.

original: kammantānaṃ saṃvidhāne samattho hotīti āha “saṃvidahitvā”ti. Bhavābhavaṃ, paññañca
analyzed: kammantānam saṃvidhāne samatthaḥ hoti iti āha saṃvidahitvā iti bhava abhavam paññam ca
translated: But that rejection is a reply, therefore he said ‘do not reply’. ‘Having consulted’: he is able in the distribution of work, therefore he said ‘having consulted’. ‘Becoming and non-becoming, and wisdom’:

original: vindi paṭilabhīti govindo, mahanto govindo mahāgovindo. “Go”ti hi paññāyetaṃ adhivacanaṃ
analyzed: vindi paṭilabhi iti govindaḥ mahantaḥ govindaḥ mahāgovindaḥ go ti hi paññāyetam adhivacanam
translated: Govinda found, obtained, the great, the mighty, the great and mighty, the great and mighty one: for the word go is a designation for wisdom,

original: gacchati atthe bujjhatīti.
analyzed: gacchati atthe bujjhati iti
translated: since it goes and awakens to the meaning.

original: Rajjasaṃvibhajanavaṇṇanā🔽306. Ekapitikā vemātukā kaniṭṭhabhātaro. Ayaṃ abhisittoti ayaṃ reṇu rājakumāro pitu accayena rajje abhisitto. Rājakārakāti rājaputtaṃ rajje patiṭṭhāpetāro.
analyzed: rajja saṃvibhajana vaṇṇanā  eka pitikā vemātukā kaniṭṭha bhātaraḥ ayam abhisittaḥ iti ayam reṇu rāja kumāro pitu accayena rajje abhisittaḥ rāja kārakā ati rāja puttam rajje patiṭṭhāpetāro
translated: The Description of the Distribution of the Robe-Fund

original: 307. Madentīti madanīyāti kattusādhanataṃ dassento “madakarā”ti āha. Madakaraṇaṃ pana pamādassa visesakāraṇanti vuttaṃ “pamādakarā”ti.🔽308. Reṇussa rajjasamīpe dasagāvutamattavitthatāni hutvā aparabhāge tiyojanasataṃ vitthatattā sabbāni cha rajjāni sakaṭamukhāni paṭṭhapesi. Vitānasadisaṃ caturassabhāvato.🔽310. Sahāti gāthāya padaparipūraṇatthaṃ vuttaṃ. Tassa atthaṃ dassento “teneva sahā”ti
analyzed: madenti iti madanīyā ati kattu sādhanatam dassentaḥ mada karā iti āha mada karaṇam pana pamādassa visesa kāraṇanti vuttam pamāda karā ti 🔽reṇussa rajja samīpe dasa gāvuta matta vitthatāni hutvā apara bhāge ti yojana satam vitthata ttā sabbāni cha rajjāni sakaṭa mukhāni paṭṭhapesi vitāna sadisam catur assa bhāvato 🔽saha iti gāthāya pada paripūraṇa attham vuttam tassa attham dassento tena iva saha iti
translated: The brothers of the same parents as the king, the king’s brothers, the king’s brothers-in-law, the king’s nephews, the king’s councillors, the king’s messengers, the king’s army officers, the king’s door-keepers, the king’s bodyguards, the king’s slaves, the king’s sons, the king’s ministers, the king’s attendants, the king’s relatives, the king’s friends, the king’s acquaintances, the king’s blood-relations, the king’s kinsmen, the king’s countrymen, the king’s companions, the king’s followers, the king’s supporters, the king’s retainers, the king’s servants, the king’s men, the king’s people, the king’s subjects, the king’s retinue, the king’s court, the king’s assembly, the king’s company, the king’s entourage, the king’s followers, the king’s retinue, the king’s court, the king’s assembly, the king’s company, the king’s entourage, the king’s followers, the king’s retinue, the king’s court, the king’s assembly, the king’s company, the king’s entourage, the king’s followers, the king’s retinue, the king’s court, the king’s assembly, the king’s company, the king’s entourage, the king’s followers, the king’s retinue, the king’s court, the king’s assembly, the king’s company, the king’s entourage, the king’s followers, the king’s retinue, the king’s court, the king’s assembly, the king’s company, the king’s entourage, the king’s followers, the king’s retinue, the king’s court, the king’s assembly, the king’s company, the king’s entourage, the king’s followers, the king’s retinue, the king’s court, the king’s assembly, the

original: āha. Sahāti vā avinābhāvatthe nipāto, so saha āsuṃ satta bhāradhāti yojetabbo, tena
analyzed: āha saha iti vā a vinābhāva atthe nipātaḥ saḥ saha āsum satta bhāradhā ti yojetabbaḥ tena
translated: He says: The particle saha is in the sense of inseparable. It should be construed with the seven Bhāradvājas who were together with him. By that🔽he shows that they were inseparable, co-existent with him in mind. They

original: te desantare vasantā vicittena sahabhāvino avinābhāvinoti dīpeti. Rajjabhāraṃ dhārenti
analyzed: te desantare vasantā vicittena sahabhāvinaḥ avinābhāvinaḥ iti dīpe iti rajja bhāram dhārenti
translated: bore the burden of the king,

original: attani āropenti vahantīti bhāradhā.
analyzed: āropenti vahanti iti bhāradhā
translated: they took it on themselves, they carried it, thus they were Bhāradvājas.

original: Paṭhamabhāṇavāravaṇṇanā niṭṭhitā.
analyzed: paṭhama bhāṇa vāra vaṇṇanā niṭṭhitā
translated: The commentary on the first recitation section is finished.

original: Kittisaddaabbhuggamanavaṇṇanā
translated: The description of the spreading of the fame

original: 311. Anupurohite ṭhapesīti anupurohite katvā ṭhapesi, anupurohite vā ṭhāne ṭhapesi.
analyzed: anupurohite ṭhapesi iti anupurohite katvā ṭhapesi anupurohite vā ṭhāne ṭhapesi
translated: He appointed as his chaplain: he appointed after making him a chaplain, or he appointed him in the place of chaplain.

original: Tisavanaṃ karonte sandhāya “divasassa tikkhattu”nti vuttaṃ. Dvīsu sandhīsu savanaṃ
analyzed: ti savanam karonte sandhāya divasassa tikkhattum ti vuttam dvīsu sandhīsu savanam
translated: “Three times a day” is said with reference to those who make the recitation twice a day.🔽“In the evening or in the morning” is said with reference to those who make the recitation at the two junctions.

original: karonte sandhāya “sāyaṃ, pāto vā”ti vuttaṃ. Tato paṭṭhāyāti vatacariyaṃ matthakaṃ🔽pāpetvā nhātakālato pabhuti.
analyzed: karonte sandhāya sāyam pāto vā ti vuttam tatas paṭṭhāya āti vata cariyam matthakam  nhāta kālataḥ
translated: From then on: from the time of bathing after bringing the practice to its culmination.

original: 312. Abhiuggacchīti uṭṭhahi udapādi. Acintetvāti “kathaṃ kho ahaṃ brahmunā saddhiṃ
analyzed: abhiuggacchi iti uṭṭhahi udapādi a cintetvā iti katham khalu aham brahmunā saddhim
translated: It spread: it arose, it appeared. Without thinking: without thinking “How can I

original: manteyya”nti acintetvā evaṃ cittampi anuppādetvā. Tena samāgamanasseva abhāvato amantetvā.
analyzed: manteyyanti a cintetvā evam cittam pi an uppādetvā tena samāgamanassa iva abhāvataḥ a mantetvā
translated: Without inviting: because there is no meeting with him.

original: Taṃ disvāti taṃ karuṇābrahmavihārabhāvanaṃ brahmadassanūpāyaṃ disvā ñāṇacakkhunā.
analyzed: tam disvā ati tam karuṇā brahmavihāra bhāvanam brahma dassana upāyam disvā ñāṇa cakkhunā
translated: Having seen: having seen that meditation on the divine abidings of compassion is the means to see the Brahmā world with the eye of knowledge.

original: 313. Evanti evaṃ rañño ārocetvā paṭisallānaṃ upagate. Sabbatthāti sabbesu channaṃ
analyzed: evam ti evam raññaḥ ārocetvā paṭisallānam upagate sabbattha ati sabbesu channam
translated: Thus: having thus informed the king, and having gone to his own lodging.

original: khattiyānaṃ, sattannaṃ brāhmaṇamahāsālānaṃ, sattannaṃ nāṭakasatānaṃ, cattārīsāya🔽ca bhariyānaṃ āpucchanavāresu.
analyzed: khattiyānam sattannam brāhmaṇa mahāsālānam sattannam nāṭaka satānam cattārīsāya  ca bhariyānam āpucchana vāresu
translated: Everywhere: in all the six royal clans, the seven great clans of brahmins, the seven hundred clans of actors, and the forty-four clans of his wives.

original: 316. Sādisiyoti jātiyā sādisiyoti āha “samavaṇṇā samajātikā”ti.
analyzed: sādisiyā iti jātiyā sādisiyā iti āha sama vaṇṇā sama jātikā iti
translated: In the case of those who are similar: he said, “of the same colour and the same caste,” meaning those who are similar in birth.

original: 317. Santhāgāranti jhānamanasikārena bahi visaṭavitakkavūpasamanena cittassa santhambhanaṃ
analyzed: jhāna manasikārena bahi cittassa santhambhanam
translated: The abode of peace: the abode of the mind, the “house” of the mind, is the quieting of the mind by the attention given to jhāna and by the stilling of distracting thoughts.🔽The abode of jhāna is what is meant.

original: agāraṃ, jhānasālanti attho. Gahitāvāti bhāvanānuyogena mahāsattena attano cittasantāne
analyzed: agāram jhāna sālanti atthaḥ bhāvanā anuyogena mahāsattena citta santāne
translated: Taken up: taken up by the Great Being by arousing it in his own mental continuity by practice of development.🔽There is none: because it has been suppressed by jhāna.

original: uppādanavasena gahitā eva. Natthi jhāneneva vikkhambhitattā. Visesato hissa karuṇāya
analyzed: uppādana vasena gahitā eva natthi jhānena iva vikkhambhita ttā visesataḥ hi ssa karuṇāya
translated: For he has no compassion for them, especially.

original: bhāvitattā anabhirati ukkaṇṭhanā natthi, mettāya bhāvitattā bhayaparitassanā natthi.
analyzed: bhāvita ttā anabhirati ukkaṇṭhanā natthi mettāya bhāvita ttā bhaya paritassanā natthi
translated: Since he has developed loving-kindness, there is no dissatisfaction and no discontent. Since he has developed equanimity, there is no fear or terror.

original: Ukkaṇṭhanāti pana brahmadassane ussukkaṃ, paritassanāti tadabhipatthanāti āha “brahmuno panā”tiādi.
analyzed: ukkaṇṭhanā ati pana brahma dassane ussukkam paritassanā ati tad abhipatthanā ati āha brahmuno pana atiādi
translated: “Dissatisfaction” is eagerness to see Brahmā. “Terror” is the desire to reach him.

original: Brahmunāsākacchāvaṇṇanā
analyzed: brahmu nāsā kaccha vaṇṇanā
translated: The explanation of the discussion with Brahmā.

original: 318. Cittutrāsoti cittassa utrāsanamattaṃ. Kathanti sattanikāyanivāsaṭṭhānanāmagottādīnaṃ vasena kena pakārena. Tenāha “ki”ntiādi.
analyzed: citta utrāsaḥ ti cittassa kathanti satta nikāya nivāsa ṭhāna nāma gotta ādīnam vasena kena pakārena tena āha kintiādi
translated: “Mental agitation” is mere agitation of the mind. “How?” is by way of the name, clan, etc., of the place of residence of the seven brahmin seers. Therefore he says “What?” and so on.

original: Soti ye te panakanasanantabandhasatanasanaṅkumārakālanāmakā loke pākaṭā paññātā brahmāno, tesu sanaṅkumāro nāmāhanti dasseti.🔽Agghanti garuṭṭhāniyānaṃ dātabbaṃāhāraṃ. Madhusākanti madhurāhāraṃ, yaṃ kiñci atithino
analyzed: so ti ye te panakana sanantabandha satana sanaṅkumāra kāla nāmakā loke pākaṭā paññātā brahmāno tesu sanaṅkumāraḥ nāma ahanti dasseti  agghanti garuṭṭhā niyānam dātabbaṃāhāram madhusākanti madhura āhāram yam kiñci atithino
translated: “He” refers to Saṇhaṅkumāra, one of the five well-known and famous Brahmās in the world, the others being Pañcakaṅga, Sanu, Tissa, and Kaḷaṅka. He shows that Saṇhaṅkumāra is one of them.

original: dātabbaṃ āhāraṃ upacāravasena evaṃ vadati. Tenāha “madhusākaṃ panā”tiādi. Pucchāmāti
analyzed: dātabbam āhāram upacāra vasena evam vadati tena āha madhu sākam pucchāma ati
translated: “The best” is the food to be given to those who are worthy of respect. “Honey-mixture” is sweet food, any food to be given to the guest. He speaks thus by way of courtesy. Therefore he says “Honey-mixture,” and so on. “We ask”

original: nimantanavasena pucchāma.
analyzed: nimantana vasena pucchāma
translated: means we ask by way of invitation.

original: 319. Mahāsatto cattāro brahmavihāre bhāvetvā ṭhitopi tesu “brahmasahabyatāya maggo”ti🔽anibbematikatāya “kaṅkhī”ti avoca. Keci pana “tapokammena parikkhīṇasarīratāya, brahmasamāgamena
analyzed: mahāsatto cattāraḥ brahmavihāre bhāvetvā ṭhitaḥ api tesu brahma sahabya tāya maggoti  a nibbematika tāya avoca keci pana tapo kammena parikkhīṇa sarīra tāya brahma samāgamena
translated: Although the Great Being was standing there having developed the four divine abodes, he said, “I am doubtful” because he was not certain that they were “the path to companionship with Brahma.”🔽But some say that he had lost the divine abodes that he had acquired through the fear of being reborn in the Brahma-world because his body had been exhausted by the austerities, and that he had lost them also through his association with Brahma.

original: bhayādisamuppattiyā ca paṭiladdhamattehi brahmavihārehi parihīno ahosi, tasmā avikkhambhitavicikicchatāya
analyzed: bhaya ādi samuppattiyā ca paṭiladdha mattehi brahmavihārehi parihīnaḥ ahosi tasmai a vikkhambhita vicikiccha tāya
translated: Therefore, because his doubt had not been dispelled, he said, “I am doubtful.”

original: ‘kaṅkhī’ti avocā”ti vadanti. Parassa vediyā viditā paravediyā, te pana tassa pākaṭā
analyzed: kaṅkhi iti avoca ati vadanti parassa vediyā viditā paravediyā te pana tassa pākaṭā
translated: “The other’s perception” is the perception of another. But they were evident to him,

original: vibhūtāti āha “parassa pākaṭesu paravediyesū”ti. Tattha kāraṇamāha “parena sayaṃ
analyzed: vibhūtā iti āha parassa pākaṭesu para vediyesu iti tattha kāraṇam āha parena sayam
translated: so he said, “The other’s perception that is evident to the other.” Herein, he gives the reason: “because it is conceived by the other himself.”

original: abhisaṅkhatattā”ti. Mamāti kammaṃ mamaṃkāro, mamattanti āha “idaṃ mama…pe… taṇha”nti.
analyzed: mama ati kammam mamaṃkāraḥ āha idam mamape taṇhanti
translated: “Mine” is the action of the conceit “I am,” the state of “I am.” So he said, “This is mine … Craving is the ‘I am’ maker.”🔽For it is through the conceit “I am” that one makes the “I am” . Craving occurs in that way.

original: “Mama”nti karoti etenāti hi mamaṃkāro, tathāpavattā taṇhā. Manujesūti niddhāraṇe
analyzed: karoti etena ati hi mamaṃkāro tathā pavattā taṇhā manujesu iti niddhāraṇe
translated: “Among men” is a specification.

original: bhummaṃ, na visayeti āha “manujesu yo kocī”ti. “Ekodibhūto”ti padassa bhāvatthaṃ
analyzed: bhummam na visaya iti āha manujesu yaḥ koci iti eka udi bhūtaḥ iti padassa bhāva attham
translated: He says “any man” in order to show that it is not a particular person.

original: tāva dassento “ekībhūto”ti vatvā puna taṃ vivaranto “eko tiṭṭhanto eko nisīdanto”ti
analyzed: tāva dassento ekībhūto ti vatvā puna tam vivaranto ekaḥ tiṭṭhanto ekaḥ nisīdanto ti
translated: He shows the meaning of the word “alone” by saying “alone” and then explains it by saying “standing alone, sitting alone.”

original: āha. Tādisoti eko hutvā pavattanako. Bhūtoti jāto. Jhāne adhimutti nāma tasmiṃ nibbattite,🔽anibbattite kuto adhimuttīti āha “jhānaṃ nibbattetvāti attho”ti. Vissagandho nāma
analyzed: āha tādisaḥ iti ekaḥ hutvā pavattanakaḥ bhūtoti jātaḥ jhāne adhimutti nāma tasmin nibbattite  a nibbattite kutas adhimutti iti āha jhānam nibbattetvā ati attho ti vissagandhaḥ nāma
translated: “Such” means having become one, he lives alone. “Alone” means born. “Intentness upon jhāna” is the state of being intent upon jhāna, which is produced when jhāna is produced.

original: kodhādikilesaparibhāvanāti tesaṃ vikkhambhanena vissagandhavirahito. Etesu dhammesūti
analyzed: kodha ādi kilesa paribhāvanā ati tesam vikkhambhanena vissa gandha virahitaḥ etesu dhammesu
translated: “Odourless” means free from the odour of the defilements such as anger, by suppressing them. “In these things”

original: pabbajjānaṃ vivekavāsakaruṇābrahmavihārādidhammesu.
analyzed: pabbajjānam viveka vāsa karuṇā brahmavihāra ādi dhammesu
translated: means in the things such as the going forth, the dwelling in a secluded place, and the divine abidings.

original: 320. Avidvāti na viditavā. Āvaritāti kusalānaṃ uttarimanussadhammānaṃ uppattinivāraṇena
analyzed: avidvā iti na viditavā āvaritā ati kusalānam uttari manussa dhammānam uppatti nivāraṇena
translated: “Unwise” means not knowing. “Covered” means covered by the prevention of the arising of profitable things that are higher than the human level.

original: āvaritā. Pūtikāti byāpannacittatādinā pūtibhūtā. Kilesavasena duggandhaṃ vissagandhaṃ
analyzed: āvaritā pūtikā ati byāpanna citta tā ādinā pūti bhūtā kilesa vasena duggandham vissa gandham
translated: “Rotten” means rotten with hate and the other evil thoughts. “Odourless” means free from the bad smell of the defilements.

original: vāyati. Nirayādiapāyesu nibbattanasīlatāya āpāyikāti āha “apāyūpagā”ti. Corādīhi
analyzed: vāyati niraya ādi apāyesu nibbattana sīla tāya āpāyikā iti āha apāyu upagā iti cora ādīhi
translated: and blows. He is called “one who goes to the lower realms” because of his habit of being reborn in the lower realms such as the hells, etc. He says “to the world of the gods” because of his habit of being reborn in the heavenly worlds. He says “to the Brahma-world” because of his habit of being reborn in the Brahma-world. He says “to the world of men” because of his habit of being reborn in the human world. He says “to the world of ghosts” because of his habit of being reborn in the ghost realm. He says “to the animal realm” because of his habit of being reborn in the animal realm. He says “to the hells” because of his habit of being reborn in the hells. He says “to the lower realms” because of his habit of being reborn in the lower realms such as the hells, etc.

original: upaddutassa pavisitukāmassa pākārakavāṭaparikhādīhi viya nagaraṃ kodhādīhi nivuto
analyzed: upaddutassa pavisitu kāmassa pākāra kavāṭa parikhā ādīhi viya nagaram kodha ādīhi
translated: Just as a city is surrounded by a wall, a gate, a moat, etc., so the Brahma-world is surrounded by anger, etc., and is inaccessible to one who is afflicted by thieves, etc., and who wishes to enter it.

original: pihito brahmaloko assāti nivutabrahmaloko. Pucchati “kenāvaṭā”ti vadanto.🔽Musāvādova mosavajjaṃ yathā bhisakkameva bhesajjaṃ. Kujjhanaṃ dussanaṃ. Diṭṭhādīsu🔽adiṭṭhādivāditāvasena paresaṃ visaṃvādanaṃ paravisaṃvādanaṃ. Sadisaṃ patirūpaṃ dassetvā🔽palobhanaṃ sadisaṃ dassetvā vañcanaṃ. Mittānaṃ vihiṃsanaṃ mettibhedo mittadubbhanaṃ.🔽Daḷhamaccharitā thaddhamacchariyaṃ. Attani vijjamānaṃ nihīnataṃ, sadisataṃ vā atikkamitvā
analyzed: pihitaḥ brahmaloko assa ati nivuta brahmaloko pucchati vadanto  musāvādaḥ uva mosavajjam yathā bhisakkam eva bhesajjam kujjhanam dussanam diṭṭha ādīsu  a diṭṭha ādi vādi tā vasena paresam visaṃvādanam para visaṃvādanam sadisam patirūpam dassetvā  palobhanam sadisam dassetvā vañcanam mittānam vihiṃsanam metti bhedaḥ mitta dubbhanam  daḷhamaccharitā thaddhamacchariyam attani vijjamānam nihīna tam sadisa tam vai atikkamitvā
translated: He asks: “By what means is it shut off?”

original: maññanaṃ. Paresaṃ sampattiyā asahanaṃ khīyanaṃ. Attasampattiyā nigūhanavasena, parehi
analyzed: maññanam paresam sampattiyāḥ asahanam khīyanam atta sampattiyāḥ nigūhana vasena parehi
translated: Lying is a lie. Just as a medicine is a remedy. To be angry is to be displeased. To be displeased is to be angry. To be angry is to be displeased. To be displeased is to be angry. To be angry is to be displeased. To be displeased is to be angry. To be angry is to be displeased. To be displeased is to be angry. To be angry is to be displeased. To be displeased is to be angry. To be angry is to be displeased. To be displeased is to be angry. To be angry is to be displeased. To be displeased is to be angry. To be angry is to be displeased. To be displeased is to be angry. To be angry is to be displeased. To be displeased is to be angry. To be angry is to be displeased. To be displeased is to be angry. To be angry is to be displeased. To be displeased is to be angry. To be angry is to be displeased. To be displeased is to be angry. To be angry is to be displeased. To be displeased is to be angry. To be angry is to be displeased. To be displeased is to be angry. To be angry is to be displeased. To be displeased is to be angry. To be angry is to be displeased

original: sādhāraṇabhāvāsahanavasena ca vividhā icchā ruci etassāti vivicchā. Kadariyatāya
analyzed: ca vividhā icchā ruci vivicchā kadariya tāya
translated: And because of the inability to bear the state of being shared, there is the various desire, wish, in him, thus he is vivicchā.🔽Stinginess is soft miserliness.

original: mudukaṃ macchariyaṃ. Yattha katthacīti sakasantake, parasantake, hīnātike cāti yattha
analyzed: mudukam macchariyam yattha katthaci iti saka santake para santake hīna atike ca ati yattha
translated: Anywhere means in one’s own property, in another’s property, and in what is neither, thus anywhere.

original: katthaci ārammaṇe. Lubbhanaṃ ārammaṇassa gahaṇaṃ abhigijjhanaṃ. Majjanaṃ seyyādivasena
analyzed: katthaci ārammaṇe lubbhanam ārammaṇassa gahaṇam abhigijjhanam majjanam seyyā ādi vasena
translated: The seizing of an object, the over-apprehending of it, is the grasping of it. The enjoyment of it by means of a couch, etc., is the relishing of it.

original: madanaṃ sampaggaho. Muyhanaṃ ārammaṇassa anavabodho. Etesūti etesu yathāvuttesu kodhādīsu
analyzed: madanam sampaggahaḥ muyhanam ārammaṇassa anavabodhaḥ etesu iti etesu yathā vuttesu kodha ādīsu
translated: The non-understanding of the object is the delusion about it.

original: sattasantānassa kilissanato vibādhanato, upatāpanato ca kilesasaññitesu pāpadhammesu.
analyzed: satta santānassa kilissanataḥ vibādhanataḥ upatāpanataḥ ca kilesa saññitesu pāpa dhammesu
translated: In these, in these bad states called defilements, which defile, afflict, and torment the mental continuity.

original: Yuttā payuttā sampayuttā avirahitā.
analyzed: yuttā payuttā sampayuttā avirahitā
translated: They are occupied, engaged, associated, not separated from them.

original: Ettha cāyaṃ brahmā mahāsattena āmagandhe supuṭṭho attano yathāupaṭṭhite pāpadhamme
analyzed: ettha ca ayam brahmā mahāsattena āmagandhe su puṭṭhaḥ attanaḥ yathā upaṭṭhite pāpa dhamme
translated: And here the Great Being asked the Brahmā about the foul-smelling things, and the Brahmā, having divided up his own bad states as they appeared to him

original: cuddasahi padehi vibhajitvā kathesi, te pana tādisaṃ pavattivisesaṃ upādāya vuttāpi
analyzed: padehi vibhajitvā kathesi te pana tādisam pavatti visesam upādāya vuttā api
translated: into fourteen parts, spoke about them. But these bad states were spoken of in this way🔽because of the particular way in which they occurred.

original: keci puna vuttā, āmagandhasutte pana vuttāpi keci idha sabbaso na vuttā, evaṃ santepi
analyzed: keci puna vuttā āmagandha sutte pana vuttā api keci idha sabbaso na vuttā evam sante pi
translated: Some are mentioned in the Āmagandhā Sutta but not mentioned here at all.

original: lakkhaṇahāranayena, tadekaṭṭhatāya vā tesaṃ pettha saṅgaho daṭṭhabbo. Tenāha “idaṃ
analyzed: lakkhaṇa hāra nayena tad ekaṭṭha tāya vā tesam pa ittha saṅgahaḥ daṭṭhabbo tena āha idam
translated: Nevertheless, they should be regarded as included here, either by the method of characteristic, or because they are of the same nature as those mentioned here.

original: pana sutta”ntiādi. Tattha āmagandhasuttena dīpetvāti idha sarūpato avutte āmagandhepi🔽vuttehi ekalakkhaṇatādinā āmagandhasuttena pakāsetvā kathetabbaṃ tattha nesaṃ sarūpato🔽kathitattā. Āmagandhasuttampi iminā dīpetabbaṃ idha vuttānampi kesañci āmagandhānaṃ
analyzed: pana sutta nti ādi tattha āma gandha suttena dīpetvā iti idha sarūpataḥ a vutte āma gandhe pi  vuttehi eka lakkhaṇa tā ādinā āmagandha suttena pakāsetvā kathetabbam tattha na īsam sarūpato  kathita ttā āmagandha suttam pi iminā dīpetabbam idha vuttānam pi kesañci āma gandhānam
translated: That is why he says, “But this sutta …🔽” Herein, he should expound the unmentioned bad odours by the method of the Āmagandhā Sutta, which is as follows.🔽The bad odours mentioned there are to be expounded by this sutta, because some of the bad odours mentioned here are not mentioned in the Āmagandhā Sutta.

original: tattha avuttabhāvato. Yasmā āmagandhasutte vuttāpi āmagandhā atthato idha saṅgahaṃ
analyzed: tattha avutta bhāvataḥ yasmai āmagandha sutte vuttā api āmagandhā atthataḥ idha saṅgaham
translated: The bad odours mentioned in the Āmagandhā Sutta come under the same heading as those mentioned here, because they are the same in meaning.

original: samosaraṇaṃ gacchanti, tasmā idha vutte pariharaṇavasena dassentena yasmā cettha
analyzed: samosaraṇam gacchanti tasmai idha vutte pariharaṇa vasena dassentena yasmai ca ittha
translated: Therefore, in showing the avoidance of them, he should show the avoidance of those mentioned in the Āmagandhā Sutta too.

original: keci abhidhammanayena akilesasabhāvāpi sattasantānassa vibādhanaṭṭhena “kilesā”ti
analyzed: keci abhidhamma nayena akilesa sabhāvā api satta santānassa vibādhana ṭṭhena kilesā ti
translated: For although some of the bad odours mentioned there are not of the nature of defilements according to the Abhidhamma method, still they are “defilements” in the sense of being a nuisance to the mental body.

original: vattabbataṃ arahanti, tasmā “cuddasasu kilesesū”ti vuttaṃ.
analyzed: vattabbatam arahanti tasmā cuddasasu kilesesu iti vuttam
translated: “They are fit to be spoken of” means they are fit to be mentioned.🔽“They are to be destroyed” means they are to be abandoned.

original: Nimmādaṃ milāpanaṃ khepananti āha “nimmādetabbā pahātabbā”ti. Buddhatantīti buddhabhāvīnaṃ
analyzed: nimmādam milāpanam khepananti āha nimmādetabbā pahātabbā iti buddha tantī iti buddha bhāvīnam
translated: “The Buddha’s line” is the lineage of those who will become Buddhas.

original: paveṇī, buddhabhāvinopi “buddhā”ti vuccanti yathā “agamā rājagahaṃ buddho”ti. Mahāpurisassa
analyzed: paveṇī buddha bhāvinaḥ api buddhā ati vuccanti yathā agamā rājagaham buddhaḥ ti mahā purisassa
translated: Those who will become Buddhas are called “Buddhas” just as it is said, “The Buddha went to Rājagaha.”

original: daḷhīkammaṃ katvāti mahāpurisassa “pabbajissāmaha”nti pavattacittuppādassa daḷhīkammaṃ katvā.
analyzed: daḷhīkammam katvā ati mahā purisassa pabbajissāmahanti pavatta cittuppādassa daḷhīkammam katvā
translated: “Having made firm the great man’s resolve” means having made firm the great man’s thought of going forth.

original: Reṇurājaāmantanāvaṇṇanā
translated: The Description of the Request of King Reṇu

original: 321. Mama manaṃ haritvāti mama cittaṃ apanetvā tassa vasena avattitvā.
analyzed: mama manam haritvā iti mama cittam apanetvā tassa vasena avattitvā
translated: “Having carried off my mind” means having taken away my mind, having made it turn away from him.

original: Ekībhāvaṃ upagantvā vutthassāti kāyavivekaparibrūhanena ekībhāvaṃ upagantvā tapokammavasena🔽vutthassa. Kusapattehi paritthatoti barihisehi vediyā samantato santharito. Akācoti
analyzed: ekībhāvam upagantvā vutthassa ati kāya viveka paribrūhanena ekībhāvam upagantvā tapo kamma vasena  vutthassa kusa pattehi barihisehi vediyā samantataḥ santharitaḥ akācaḥ iti
translated: “Having arisen after attaining unity” means having attained unity by increasing the seclusion of the body, having arisen after the ascetic practice.🔽“Surrounded by kusagrass” means covered all around by kusagrass.

original: vaṇo vaṇasadisakhaṇḍiccavirahito. Tenāha “akakkaso”ti.
analyzed: vaṇaḥ tena āha akakkasaḥ iti
translated: “Without a wound” means without a wound or a piece of wood that looks like a wound. Therefore it is said, “without a crack.”

original: Chakhattiyaāmantanāvaṇṇanā
analyzed: cha khattiya āmantanā vaṇṇanā
translated: The Description of the Request of the Six Nobles

original: 322. Sikkheyyāmāti sikkhāpeyyāma, sikkhāpanañcettha atthibhāvāpādananti āha “upalāpeyyāmā”ti.🔽323. Yassa vīriyārambhassa, khantibalassa ca abhāvena pabbajitānaṃ samaṇadhammo paripuṇṇo,
analyzed: sikkheyyāma ati sikkhāpeyyāma sikkhāpanam ca ittha atthi bhāva āpādananti āha upalāpeyyāma ati  yassa vīriya ārambhassa khanti balassa ca abhāvena pabbajitānam samaṇa dhammo paripuṇṇo
translated: ‘I would train’: I would cause to train. Here training is the bringing about of existence. Hence he said ‘I would make them understand’.

original: parisuddho ca na hoti, tesu vīriyārambhakhantibalesu te te niyojetuṃ “ārambhavho”tiādi vuttaṃ.
analyzed: parisuddhaḥ ca na hoti tesu vīriya ārambha khanti balesu te te niyojetum ārambha vho ti ādi vuttaṃ
translated: Since the recluse’s state is not fulfilled and is not purified in those who have gone forth but who lack the energy to make effort and the patience to endure, he said ‘Make effort’ and so on in order to induce them to have the energy to make effort and the patience to endure.

original: Karuṇājhānamaggoti karuṇājhānasaṅkhāto maggo. Ujumaggoti brahmalokagamane ujubhūto
analyzed: karuṇā jhāna maggo ti karuṇā jhāna saṅkhātaḥ maggaḥ uju maggo iti brahma loka gamane uju bhūtaḥ
translated: ‘The path of jhana with compassion’: the path called jhana with compassion. ‘The straight path’: the path that is straight in going to the Brahmā-world.

original: maggo. Anuttaroti seṭṭho brahmavihārasabhāvato. Tenāha “uttamamaggo nāmā”ti. Sabbhi
analyzed: maggaḥ anuttaro ti seṭṭhaḥ brahmavihāra sabhāvataḥ tena āha uttama maggaḥ nāma ati sabbhi
translated: ‘The unsurpassed’: the best, because of its being a divine abiding. Hence he said ‘called the supreme path’.

original: rakkhito sādhūhi yathā parihāni na hoti, evaṃ paṭipakkhadūrīkaraṇena rakkhito gopito.🔽“Saddhammo sabbhi vakkhito”ti keci paṭhanti, tesaṃ saparahitasādhanena sādhūhi buddhādīhi
analyzed: rakkhitaḥ sādhūhi yathā na hoti evam paṭipakkha dūrīkaraṇena rakkhitaḥ gopitaḥ  saddhammo sabbhi vakkhitoti keci paṭhanti tesam sa para hita sādhanena sādhūhi buddha ādīhi
translated: ‘Guarded by the good’: guarded and protected by the good, who keep it from decline by keeping it far from opposition.

original: kathito paveditoti attho.
analyzed: kathito pavedito ti attho
translated: Some read ‘The good have told the true ideal to all’ . The meaning of that is: it is told and proclaimed by the good, the Enlightened One, etc., by means of the accomplishment of what is beneficial to others.🔽‘

original: Taṅkhaṇaviddhaṃsanadhammanti yasmiṃ khaṇe virodhidhammasamāyogo, tasmiṃyeva khaṇe🔽vinassanasabhāvaṃ, yo vā so gamanassādānaṃ devaputtānaṃ heṭṭhupariyena paṭimukhaṃ
analyzed: yasmin khaṇe virodhi dhamma samāyogo tasmin yeva khaṇe  vinassana sabhāvam yaḥ vā saḥ gamanassa ādānam deva puttānam heṭṭhupariyena paṭimukham
translated: ‘Subject to destruction at the very moment it comes into existence’: it is of the nature to be destroyed at the very moment when it comes into existence through the combination of opposing factors.

original: dhāvantānaṃ sirasi, pāde ca baddhakhuradhārāsamāgamanatopi sīghataratāya atiittaro
analyzed: sirasi pāde ca baddha khura dhārā samāgamanataḥ upi sīghatara tāya
translated: Or else, the very moment of arising is more rapid than the rapid meeting of the tips of two arrows shot simultaneously by expert archers at each other’s chest.

original: pavattikkhaṇo, teneva vinassanasabhāvaṃ. Tassa jīvitassa. Gatinti niṭṭhaṃ. Mantāyanti🔽manteyyanti vuttaṃ hotīti āha “mantetabba”nti. Karaṇatthe vā bhummanti “mantāya”nti
analyzed: pavatti kkhaṇo tena iva vinassana sabhāvam tassa jīvitassa gatiḥ niṭṭham mantāyanti  manteyyam iti vuttam hoti iti āha mantetabbanti karaṇa atthe vā bhummanti mantāyanti
translated: That is the nature of the life span. ‘End’: final limit.🔽‘To be considered’ : what is meant is ‘to be considered by the wise.’🔽Or else, the locative in ‘to be considered’ should be taken as meaning ‘by means of’ , as in the expression ‘by the known’ .

original: idaṃ bhummaṃ karaṇatthe daṭṭhabbaṃ yathā “ñātāya”nti. Sabbapalibodheti sabbepi kusalakiriyāya vibandhe uparodhe.
analyzed: idam bhummam karaṇa atthe daṭṭhabbam yathā ñātāyanti sabba palibodhā iti sabbe api kusala kiriyāya vibandhe uparodhe
translated: ‘All impediments’: all hindrances to the performance of profitable action.

original: Brāhmaṇamahāsālādīnaṃ āmantanāvaṇṇanā
analyzed: brāhmaṇa mahāsāla ādīnam āmantanā vaṇṇanā
translated: The explanation of the address to the magnanimous brahmans, etc.

original: 324. Appesakkhāti appānubhāvāti āha “pabbajitakālato paṭṭhāyā”tiādi.
analyzed: appesakkhā iti appa anubhāvā ti āha pabbajita kālataḥ paṭṭhāya atiādi
translated: ‘Of little influence’: of little power. ‘From the time of his going forth’ means from the time of his going forth.

original: Cakkavatti rājā viya sambhāvito.
analyzed: cakkavatti rājā viya sambhāvito
translated: He was honoured like a universal monarch.

original: Mahāgovindapabbajjāvaṇṇanā
translated: The explanation of the Great Steward’s going forth

original: 328. Samāpattīnaṃ ājānanaṃ nāma attapaccakkhatā, sacchikiriyāti āha “na sakkhiṃsu nibbattetu”nti.
analyzed: samāpattīnam ājānanam nāma atta paccakkha tā sacchikiriyā iti āha na sakkhiṃsu nibbattetun ti
translated: The “understanding of attainments” is the state of being one’s own witness, the state of having verified them for oneself. That is why it is said, “they were unable to produce them.”

original: 329. Imināti “sarāmaha”nti iminā padena. “Sarāmaha”nti hi vadantena bhagavato mahābrahmunā🔽kathitaṃ “tatheva ta”nti bhagavatā paṭiññātameva jātanti. Na vaṭṭe nibbindanatthāya
analyzed: iminā ati iminā padena hi vadantena bhagavataḥ mahābrahmunā  kathitam tathā iva tanti bhagavatā paṭiññātam eva jāta nti na vaṭṭe nibbindana tthāya
translated: “By this”: by the word “remember.” For by saying “I remember,” the Great Brahmā is saying, “It was affirmed by the Blessed One that it is just as I have said.”🔽Not for the purpose of causing disenchantment with the round of rebirths,

original: catusaccakammaṭṭhānakathāya abhāvato. Asati pana vaṭṭe nibbidāya virāgānaṃ asambhavo🔽evāti āha “na virāgāyā”tiādi. Ekantameva vaṭṭe nibbindanatthāya anekākāravokāravaṭṭe ādīnavavibhāvanato.🔽“Nibbidāyā”ti iminā padena vipassanā vuttā. Esa nayo sesesupi. Vavatthānakathāti
analyzed: catu sacca kammaṭṭhāna kathāya abhāvataḥ asati pana vaṭṭe nibbidāya virāgānam asambhavaḥ  eva iti āha na virāgāya atiādi ekantam eva vaṭṭe nibbindana tthāya aneka ākāra vokāra vaṭṭe ādīnava vibhāvanato  nibbidāya ati iminā padena vipassanā vuttā esa nayo sesesu pi vavatthāna kathā ati
translated: because the discourse on the four noble truths does not deal with the round of rebirths. But if there were no round of rebirths, there could be no disenchantment with it, and without disenchantment there could be no fading away of lust.🔽That is why it is said, “not for the fading away of lust.” It is for the purpose of causing disenchantment with the round of rebirths in all its aspects, since it reveals the dangers in the round of rebirths in its various aspects.

original: vipassanāmagganibbānānaṃ taṃtaṃpadehi vavatthapetvā kathā. Ayamettha nippariyāyakathāti
analyzed: vipassanā magga nibbānānam tat tat padehi vavatthapetvā kathā ayam ettha nippariyāya kathā ti
translated: By the word “disenchantment” insight is meant. The same method applies to the rest. The “exposition” is the discourse that defines insight and the path and Nibbāna by means of the various terms. This is the literal meaning.

original: āha “pariyāyena panā”tiādi.
analyzed: āha pariyāyena
translated: “But by the method” and so on.

original: 330. Paripūretunti bhāvanāpāripūrivasena paripuṇṇe kātuṃ, nibbattetunti attho. Brahmacariyaciṇṇakulaputtānanti
analyzed: paripūretum ti bhāvanā pāripūri vasena paripuṇṇe kātum nibbattetum ti atthaḥ brahmacariya ciṇṇa kula puttānam ti
translated: “To fulfil”: to make them complete by fulfilling the development; the meaning is, to bring them into being. “To sons of good family who have lived the life of chastity”:

original: ciṇṇamaggabrahmacariyānaṃ kulaputtānanti ukkaṭṭhaniddesena arahattanikūṭena desanaṃ niṭṭhapesi.
analyzed: ciṇṇa magga brahmacariyānam kula puttānam ti ukkaṭṭha niddesena arahatta nikūṭena desanam niṭṭhapesi
translated: he concluded the teaching with the peak of arahatship, the highest point, by the expression “sons of good family who have lived the life of chastity.”

original: Abhinandanaṃ nāma sampaṭicchanaṃ “abhinandanti āgata”ntiādīsu viya, tañcettha atthato🔽cittassa attamanatāti āha “cittena sampaṭicchanto abhinanditvā”ti. “Sādhu sādhū”ti
analyzed: abhinandanam nāma sampaṭicchanam abhinandanti āgata nti ādīsu viya tat ca ittha atthato  cittassa atta manatā iti āha cittena sampaṭicchantaḥ abhinanditvā ati sādhu sādhu iti
translated: “Appreciation” is approval, as in the passages beginning, “They appreciate the comeliness” . Here the meaning is

original: vācāya sampahaṃsanā anumodanāti āha “vācāya sampahaṃsamāno anumoditvā”ti.
analyzed: vācāya sampahaṃsanā anumodanā iti āha vācāya sampahaṃsamānaḥ anumoditvā iti
translated: the satisfaction of the mind. “By approving with his mind he appreciated” means: by approving with his mind he appreciated. “By applauding with his speech he rejoiced” means: by applauding with his speech he rejoiced.

original: Mahāgovindasuttavaṇṇanāya līnatthappakāsanā.
translated: The explanation of the meaning of the Mahāgovinda Sutta is ended.

original: 7. Mahāsamayasuttavaṇṇanā🔽Nidānavaṇṇanā
analyzed: nidāna vaṇṇanā
translated: The Great Discourse on the Assembly🔽The Introduction

original: 331. Udānanti raññā okkākena jātisambhedaparihāranimittaṃ pavattitaṃ udānaṃ paṭicca.
analyzed: udānan ti raññā okkākena jāti sambheda parihāra nimittam pavattitam udānam paṭicca
translated: “Udan” : in dependence on the utterance made by King Okkāka for the purpose of preventing the division of the clans.

original: Ekopi janapado ruḷhisaddena “sakkā”ti vuccatīti ettha yaṃ vattabbaṃ, taṃ mahānidānavaṇṇanāyaṃ
analyzed: ekaḥ api janapadaḥ ruḷhi saddena sakkā ati vuccati iti ettha yat vattabbam tat mahānidāna vaṇṇanāyam
translated: As to the single country called “Sakka” because of the sound of the word “ruḷhi” there, what should be said has been said in the Mahānidāna Commentary.

original: vuttanayena veditabbaṃ. Aropiteti kenaci aropite.
analyzed: vutta nayena veditabbam aropita iti kenaci aropite
translated: “When a dispute has been brought” means when a dispute has been brought by someone.🔽“By means of a fence” means by means of a dam.

original: Āvaraṇenāti setunā. Bandhāpetvāti paṃsupalāsapāsāṇamattikākhaṇḍādīhi āḷiṃ thiraṃ kārāpetvā.
analyzed: āvaraṇena ati setunā bandhāpetvā ati paṃsu palāsa pāsāṇa mattikā khaṇḍa ādīhi āḷim thiram kārāpetvā
translated: “Having had it enclosed” means having had a dyke made firm with earth, grass, sticks, stones, and lumps of clay.

original: “Jātiṃ ghaṭṭetvā kalahaṃ vaḍḍhayiṃsū”ti saṅkhepena vuttamatthaṃ pākaṭataraṃ kātuṃ “koliyakammakarā vadantī”tiādi vuttaṃ.
analyzed: jātim ghaṭṭetvā kalaham vaḍḍhayiṃsu iti saṅkhepena vuttam attham pākaṭataram kātum koliya kammakarāḥ vadanti itiādi vuttam
translated: “Having struck the birth-place, they increased the quarrel” is said in brief. In order to make the meaning clear, “the weavers said” is said.

original: Tīṇi jātakānīti phandanajātakapathavīundriyajātakalaṭukikajātakāni dve jātakānīti rukkhadhamma vaṭṭakajātakāni.
analyzed: tīṇi jātakāni iti phandana jātaka pathavī indriya jātaka laṭukika jātakāni dve jātakāni iti rukkhadhamma vaṭṭaka jātakāni
translated: “Three birth-stories” means the Phandana Jātaka, the Pathavī-undurī Jātaka, and the Laṭukikā Jātaka. “Two birth-stories” means the Rukkha-dhamma Jātaka and the Vaṭṭaka Jātaka.

original: Tenāti bhagavatā. Kalahakāraṇabhāvoti kalahakāraṇassa atthibhāvo.
analyzed: tena ati bhagavatā kalaha kāraṇa bhāvaḥ ti kalaha kāraṇassa atthi bhāvaḥ
translated: “By him” means by the Blessed One. “The existence of a cause for a dispute” means the existence of a cause for a dispute.

original: Aṭṭhāneti akāraṇe. Veraṃ katvāti virodhaṃ uppādetvā. “Kuṭhārihattho puriso”tiādinā
analyzed: aṭṭhāna iti akāraṇe veram katvā ati virodham uppādetvā kuṭhāri hatthaḥ puriso ti ādinā
translated: “Without reason” means without cause. “Having made an enemy” means having created an opponent. “A man with an axe in his hand” is said.

original: phandanajātakaṃ kathesi. “Duddubhāyati bhaddante”tiādinā pathavīundriyajātakaṃ kathesi.
analyzed: phandana jātakam kathesi duddubhāyati bhaddanta iti ādinā pathavī undriya jātakam kathesi
translated: and told the story of the Stag. “The earth trembles, Blessed One,” and so on; and told the story of the Earth-Worm.

original: “Vandāmi taṃ kuñjarā”tiādinā laṭukikajātakaṃ kathesi.
analyzed: vandāmi tam kuñjarāti ādinā laṭukika jātakam kathesi
translated: “I pay homage to you, O elephant,” and so on; and told the story of the Hare.

original: “Sādhū sambahulā ñātī; api rukkhā araññajā;
analyzed: sādhū sambahulā ñātī api rukkhā arañña jā
translated: “How good are many kinsmen! Even trees in the forest are kinsmen.

original: Vāto vahati ekaṭṭhaṃ, brahantampi vanappati”nti. –
analyzed: vātaḥ vahati ekaṭṭham brahantam pi vanappatinti
translated: The wind blows on a single tree, but not on the forest’s lord.”

original: Ādinā rukkhadhammajātakaṃ kathesi.
analyzed: ādinā rukkhadhamma jātakam kathesi
translated: And told the story of the Tree-Spirit.

original: “Sammodamānā gacchanti, jālaṃ ādāya pakkhino;
analyzed: sammodamānāḥ gacchanti jālam ādāya pakkhinaḥ
translated: “The birds go along in harmony, carrying the net.

original: Yadā te vivadissanti, tadā ehinti me vasa”nti. –
analyzed: yadā te vivadissanti tadā ehinti me vasanti
translated: When they quarrel, then come to me.”

original: Ādinā vaṭṭakajātakaṃ kathesi.
analyzed: ādinā vaṭṭaka jātakam kathesi
translated: And told the story of the Kite.

original: “Attadaṇḍā bhayaṃ jātaṃ, janaṃ passatha medhagaṃ;
analyzed: atta daṇḍāḥ bhayam jātam janam passatha medha gam
translated: “Fear has arisen from self-punishment. Look at the people, O wise one!

original: Saṃvegaṃ kittayissāmi, yathā saṃvijitaṃ mayā”ti. ;
analyzed: saṃvegam kittayissāmi yathā saṃvijitam mayā ati
translated: I will proclaim the inspiration that I have gained.”

original: Ādinā attadaṇḍasuttaṃ kathesi.
analyzed: ādinā attadaṇḍa suttam kathesi
translated: And told the story of the Self-Punishment.

original: Taṃtaṃpalobhanakiriyā kāyavācāhi parakkamantiyo “ukkaṇṭhantū”ti sāsanaṃ pesenti.
analyzed: taṃtaṃpalobhana kiriyā kāya vācāhi parakkamantiyaḥ ukkaṇṭhantu iti sāsanam pesenti
translated: They send a message, “Let them be discontented,” by means of the body and speech, which are the means of instigating them.

original: Kuṇāladaheti kuṇāladahatīre patiṭṭhāya. Pucchitapucchitaṃ kathesi “anukkamena kuṇālasakuṇarājassa
analyzed: kuṇāla daha iti kuṇāla daha tīre patiṭṭhāya pucchita pucchitam kathesi anukkamena kuṇāla sakuṇa rājassa
translated: Kuṇāladahe means on the bank of the Kuṇāladaha. He told them what they asked him. “In due course, in the context of the questions of the bird king Kuṇāla,

original: pucchanappasaṅgena kuṇālajātakaṃ kathessāmī”ti. Anabhiratiṃ vinodesi itthīnaṃ dosadassanamukhena
analyzed: pucchana ppasaṅgena kuṇāla jātakam kathessāmi iti anabhiratim vinodesi itthīnam dosa dassana mukhena
translated: I will tell the Kuṇāla Birth Story.” He removed their dissatisfaction by showing the faults of women

original: kāmānaṃ ādīnavokārasaṃkilesavibhāvanena.
analyzed: kāmānam ādīnava ukāra saṃkilesa vibhāvanena
translated: and by explaining the danger and corruption of sensual pleasures.

original: Kosajjaṃ vidhamitvā purisathāmaparibrūhanena “uttamapurisasadisehi no bhavituṃ vaṭṭatī”ti uppannacittā.
analyzed: kosajjam vidhamitvā purisa thāma paribrūhanena uttama purisa sadisehi no bhavitum vaṭṭati iti uppanna cittā
translated: Having removed their laziness by increasing their manly strength, thinking “It is not right for us to be like the best of men,” they aroused their minds.

original: Avissaṭṭhakammantāti arativinodanato paṭṭhāya avissaṭṭhasamaṇakammantā, aparicattakammaṭṭhānāti attho. Nisīdituṃ vaṭṭatīti bhagavā cintesīti yojanā.
analyzed: a vissaṭṭha kammantā ati arati vinodanataḥ paṭṭhāya a vissaṭṭha samaṇa kammantā a paricatta kammaṭṭhānā ti attho nisīditum vaṭṭati iti bhagavā cintesi iti yojanā
translated: “They did not neglect their duties” means that from the time of removing their dissatisfaction they did not neglect their duties as ascetics, their meditation subjects, that is the meaning. The Blessed One thought “It is proper for them to sit down.”

original: Paduminiyanti padumassare. Vikasiṃsu guṇagaṇavibodhena. “Ayaṃ imassa…pe… na kathesī”ti
analyzed: guṇa gaṇa vibodhena ayam na kathesi iti
translated: In the Padumini means in the Padumini lotus pond. They blossomed by the development of the multitude of virtues. “This one … and so on … did not tell it.”

original: iminā sabbepi te bhikkhū tāvadeva paṭipāṭiyā āgatattā aññamaññassa lajjamānā attanā
analyzed: iminā sabbe pi te bhikkhū tāvat eva paṭipāṭiyā āgata ttā aññamaññassa lajjamānāḥ attanā
translated: By this, all those monks, having come in turn, were ashamed of each other.

original: paṭividdhavisesaṃ bhagavato nārocesunti dasseti. “Khīṇāsavāna”ntiādinā tattha kāraṇamāha.
analyzed: paṭividdha visesam bhagavataḥ na arocesun ti dasseti khīṇāsavānam ti ādinā tattha kāraṇam āha
translated: He shows that he did not report the distinction to the Blessed One until he had verified it. He gives the reason for that in the words ‘who had destroyed the cankers’ .

original: Osīdamatteti bhagavato santikaṃ upagatamatte. Ariyamaṇḍaleti ariyasamūhe. Pācīnayugandharaparikkhepatoti
analyzed: osīda matta iti bhagavato santikam upagata matte ariya maṇḍala iti ariya samūhe pācīna yugandhara parikkhepato ti
translated: As soon as they had approached the Blessed One: as soon as they had gone into the Blessed One’s presence. In the circle of the Noble Ones: in the assembly of Noble Ones. From the eastern side of the Yugandhara range:

original: yugandharapabbatassa pācīnaparikkhepato, na bāhirakehi uccamānaudayapabbatato. Rāmaṇeyyakadassanatthanti
analyzed: yugandhara pabbatassa pācīna parikkhepataḥ na bāhirakehi uccamāna audaya pabbatato rāmaṇeyyaka dassana tthanti
translated: from the eastern side of the Yugandhara mountain range, not from the outer range of the Udaya mountain. In order to see the delightful:

original: buddhuppādapaṭimaṇḍitattā visesato ramaṇīyassa lokassa ramaṇīyabhāvadassanatthaṃ.🔽Ullaṅghitvāti uṭṭhahitvā. Evarūpe khaṇe laye muhutteti yathāvutte candamaṇḍalassa
analyzed: buddhuppāda paṭimaṇḍita ttā visesataḥ ramaṇīyassa lokassa ramaṇīya bhāva dassana attham  ullaṅghitvā iti uṭṭhahitvā evarūpe khaṇe laye muhutta iti yathā vutte canda maṇḍalassa
translated: in order to see the delightful state of the delightful world, which is especially delightful because of the Buddha’s appearance.🔽Having risen: having got up. At such a time, at such an instant, at such a moment: at the time, at the hour, at the instant when the moon’s disk had risen,

original: uṭṭhitakkhaṇe uṭṭhitavelāyaṃ uṭṭhitamuhutteti uparūpari kālassa vaḍḍhitabhāvadassanatthaṃ vuttaṃ.
analyzed: uṭṭhita khaṇe uṭṭhita velāyam uṭṭhita muhutta iti upari upari kālassa vaḍḍhita bhāva dassana attham vuttam
translated: he says this in order to show that the time had gone on increasing in this way, ‘at such a time,’ ‘at such an instant,’ ‘at such a moment.’

original: Tathā tesaṃ bhikkhūnaṃ jātiādivasena bhagavato anurūpaparivāritaṃ dassento “tatthā”ti ādimāha.
analyzed: tathā tesam bhikkhūnam jāti ādi vasena bhagavataḥ anurūpa parivāritam dassentaḥ tattha iti ādim āha
translated: And in order to show that the Blessed One’s retinue was suitable to him in respect of birth, etc., he said ‘There the Blessed One was accompanied by … ’ .

original: Samāpannadevatāti āsannaṭṭhāne jhānasamāpatti samāpannadevatā. Caliṃsūti uṭṭhahiṃsu.
analyzed: samāpanna devatā ati āsanna ṭṭhāne jhāna samāpatti samāpanna devatā caliṃsu iti uṭṭhahiṃsu
translated: “Deities who had attained jhāna” are deities who had attained jhāna in a nearby place. “They shook” means they rose up.

original: Kosamattaṃ ṭhānaṃ saddantaraṃ. Jambudīpe kira ādito tesaṭṭhimattāni nagarasahassāni
analyzed: kosa mattam ṭhānam sadda antaram jambudīpe kira āditas tesaṭṭhi mattāni nagara sahassāni
translated: The distance of a shout is the distance a person can cover with a shout. In the Rose-Apple Island, it is said, there were originally thirty-six thousand cities,

original: uppannāni, tathā dutiyaṃ, tathā tatiyaṃ, taṃ sandhāyāha “tikkhattuṃ tesaṭṭhiyā nagarasahassesū”ti.
analyzed: uppannāni tathā dutiyam tathā tatiyam tam sandhāya āha tikkhattum nagara sahassesu iti
translated: and then a second time thirty-six thousand, and then a third time thirty-six thousand. With reference to this, it is said: “in thirty-six thousand cities three times over.”

original: Te pana sampiṇḍetvā satasahassato paraṃ asītisahassāni, navasahassāni ca honti. Navanavutiyā
analyzed: te pana sampiṇḍetvā sata sahassataḥ param asīti sahassāni nava sahassāni ca honti nava navutiyā
translated: These, when combined, are more than a hundred thousand, namely eighty-four thousand. In the nine hundred thousand

original: doṇamukhasatasahassesūti navasatasahassādhikesu navutisatasahassesu doṇamukhesu.
analyzed: doṇa mukha sata sahassesu uti nava sata sahassa adhikesu navuti sata sahassesu doṇa mukhesu
translated: “mouths of doṇas” means in nine hundred thousand mouths of doṇas plus one hundred thousand.

original: Doṇamukhanti ca mahānagarassa āyuppattiṭṭhānabhūtaṃ pādanagaraṃ vuccati. Channavutiyā
analyzed: doṇamukhanti ca mahā nagarassa āyu ppatti ṭṭhāna bhūtam pādanagaram vuccati channavutiyā
translated: And a mouth of a doṇa is said to be a subsidiary city that is the source of the life of a great city. In the ninety-six hundred thousand

original: paṭṭanakoṭisatasahassesūti chakoṭiadhikanavutikoṭisatasahassapaṭṭanesu. Tambapaṇṇidīpādīsu
analyzed: paṭṭana koṭi sata sahassesu iti cha koṭi adhika navuti koṭi sata sahassa paṭṭanesu tamba paṇṇi dīpa ādīsu
translated: “mouths of rivers” means in ninety-six hundred thousand mouths of rivers plus six hundred thousand. In the Rose-Apple Island, etc.,

original: chapaṇṇāsāya ratanākaresu. Evaṃ pana nagaradoṇimukhapaṭṭanaratanākarādivibhāgena
analyzed: rata nākaresu evam pana nagara doṇi mukha paṭṭana rata nākara ādi vibhāgena
translated: in the fifty-six hundred thousand “jewels.” But in this way, by the division into cities, mouths of doṇas, rivers, jewels, etc.,

original: kathanaṃ taṃtaṃadhivatthāya vasantīnaṃ devatānaṃ bahubhāvadassanatthaṃ. Yadi dasasahassacakkavāḷesu
analyzed: kathanam taṃ taṃ adhivatthāya vasantīnam devatānam bahu bhāva dassana attham yadi dasa sahassa cakkavāḷesu
translated: The reason for the statement is to show the multitude of deities who dwell in the various realms.

original: devatā sannipatitā, atha kasmā pāḷiyaṃ “dasahi ca lokadhātūhī”ti vuttanti āha “dasasahassa…pe…
analyzed: devatā sannipatitā atha kasmā pāḷiyam dasahi ca lokadhātūhi iti vuttan ti āha dasa sahassape
translated: If deities from the ten-thousandfold world-system assemble, then why is it said in the text, “from the ten world-systems”?

original: adhippetā”ti, tena sahassilokadhātu idha “ekā lokadhātū”ti vuttāti veditabbaṃ.
analyzed: adhippetā ti tena sahassi lokadhātu idha ekā lokadhātu uti vuttā iti veditabbam
translated: The ten-thousandfold world-system is referred to here as “one world-system.”

original: Lohapāsādeti ādito kate lohapāsāde. Brahmaloketi heṭṭhime brahmaloke. Yadi tā devatā
analyzed: loha pāsāda iti āditas kate loha pāsāde brahma loka iti heṭṭhime brahma loke yadi tāḥ devatāḥ
translated: The “iron palace” is the iron palace built at the beginning. The “Brahma world” is the lower Brahma world.🔽If the deities are so closely packed together, then there would be no room for those who come later.

original: evaṃ nirantarā, pacchā āgatānaṃ okāso eva na bhaveyyāti codanaṃ sandhāyāha “yathā🔽kho panā”tiādi. Suddhāvāsakāyaṃ upapannā suddhāvāsakāyikā, tāsaṃ pana yasmā suddhāvāsabhūmi
analyzed: evam nirantarā pacchā āgatānam okāsaḥ eva na bhaveyya iti codanam sandhāya āha yathā  kho pana atiādi suddhāvāsa kāyam upapannā suddhāvāsa kāyikā tāsam pana yasmā suddhāvāsa bhūmi
translated: The passage beginning with “But just as” is in response to this objection.🔽Those who are reborn in the Suddhāvāsa realm are called Suddhāvāsika. But since the Suddhāvāsa plane is their dwelling place,🔽it is said, “those who dwell in the Suddhāvāsa.”

original: nivāsaṭṭhānaṃ, tasmā vuttaṃ “suddhāvāsavāsīna”nti. Āvāsāti āvāsanaṭṭhānabhūtā, devatā
analyzed: nivāsa ṭṭhānam tasmā vuttam suddhāvāsa vāsīnam ti āvāsā ati āvāsana ṭṭhāna bhūtā devatā
translated: Dwelling place means the place where they dwell.

original: pana orambhāgiyānaṃ, itaresañca saṃyojanānaṃ samucchindanena suddho āvāso etesanti suddhāvāsā.
analyzed: pana orambhāgiyānam itaresam ca saṃyojanānam samucchindanena suddhaḥ āvāsaḥ etesanti suddha āvāsā
translated: But the Pure Abodes are so called because they are the abode of those who are pure by the cutting off of all the fetters belonging to the lower world and of the other fetters as well.

original: 332. Puratthimacakkavāḷamukhavaṭṭiyaṃ otari aññattha okāsaṃ alabhamāno. Evaṃ sesāpi.
analyzed: puratthima cakkavāḷa mukha vaṭṭiyam otari aññattha okāsam a labhamāno evam sesā api
translated: He descends to the eastern rim of the world-sphere and finds no way through. So too the others.

original: Buddhānaṃ abhimukhamaggo buddhavīthi. Yāva cakkavāḷā ottharituṃ ovarituṃ na sakkā.
analyzed: buddhānam abhimukha maggaḥ buddha vīthi yāva cakkavāḷāḥ ottharitum ovaritum na sakkā
translated: The Buddhas’ path is the Buddhas’ way. It cannot be traversed or crossed over as far as the rim of the world.

original: Pahaṭabuddhavīthiyāvāti buddhānaṃ santikaṃ upasaṅkamantehi tehi devabrahmehi vaḷañjitavīthiyāva.
analyzed: pahaṭa buddha vīthiyā ava ati buddhānam santikam upasaṅkamantehi tehi devabrahmehi vaḷañjita vīthiyā ava
translated: As far as the Buddhas’ way that has been traversed: as far as the way that has been traversed by the gods and brahmas who have approached the Buddhas.

original: Samiti saṅgati sannipāto samayo, mahanto samayo mahāsamayoti āha “mahāsamūho”ti.
analyzed: samiti saṅgati sannipātaḥ samayaḥ mahantaḥ samayaḥ mahā samayaḥ iti āha mahā samūhaḥ iti
translated: An assembly, a gathering, a concourse, a company, is a gathering together, a coming together, a meeting together, a concurrence, a concourse, a company.

original: Pavaddhaṃ vanaṃ pavananti āha “vanasaṇḍo”ti. Devaghaṭāti devasamūhā.
analyzed: āha deva ghaṭā ati deva samūhā
translated: A forest grove is a wood.

original: Samādahaṃsūti samādahitaṃ lokuttarasamādhinā suṭṭhu appitaṃ akaṃsu, yathāsamāhitaṃ
analyzed: samādahaṃsu iti samādahitam lokuttara samādhinā suṭṭhu appitam akaṃsu yathā samāhitam
translated: They set it alight: they set it alight with the supramundane concentration, they lit it well.🔽But it is said that it is called “yoked by concentration” when it is yoked by the concentration that is attained thus.

original: pana samādhinā yojitaṃ nāma hotīti vuttaṃ “samādhinā yojesu”nti. Sabbesaṃ gomuttavaṅkādīnaṃ
analyzed: pana samādhinā yojitam nāma hoti iti vuttam samādhinā yojesuḥ ti sabbesam gomutta vaṅka ādīnam
translated: Of all the cow’s urine, etc.,

original: dūrasamūhanitattā sabbe…pe… akariṃsu. Nayati asse etehīti nettāni, yottāni. Avīthipaṭipannānaṃ
analyzed: dūra samūha nita ttā nayati asse etehi iti nettāni yottāni a vīthi paṭipannānam
translated: The horses are guided by the reins when they are on the wrong course.

original: assānaṃ vīthipaṭipādanaṃ rasmiggahaṇena pahotīti “sabbayottāni gahetvā acodento”ti
analyzed: assānam vīthi paṭipādanam rasmi gahaṇena pahoti iti sabba yottāni gahetvā a codentā iti
translated: Having taken hold of all the reins, he drove them on without beating them.

original: vatvā taṃ pana acodanaṃ avāraṇaṃ evāti āha “acodento avārento”ti.
analyzed: vatvā tam pana a codanam a vāraṇam eva ati āha a codentaḥ a vārentaḥ iti
translated: But that driving on without beating is the same as not beating, so he said “without beating, without driving them on.”🔽Just as a post driven into a wall or into the ground is hard to pull out,

original: Yathā khīlaṃ bhittiyaṃ vā bhūmiyaṃ vā ākoṭitaṃ dunnīharaṇaṃ, yathā ca palighaṃ nagarappavesanivāraṇaṃ,
analyzed: yathā khīlam bhittiyam vā bhūmiyam vā ākoṭitam dunnīharaṇam yathā ca paligham nagara ppavesa nivāraṇam
translated: and just as a bolt is hard to pull out when it has been inserted into a socket,🔽and just as an axle pin is hard to pull out when it has been deeply inserted into a socket,

original: yathā ca indakhīlaṃ gambhīranemi sunikhātaṃ dunnīharaṇaṃ, evaṃ rāgādayo sattasantānato
analyzed: yathā ca inda khīlam gambhīra nemi su nikhātam dunnīharaṇam evam rāga ādayaḥ satta santānataḥ
translated: so too, lust, etc., are hard to pull out from the continuity of beings.

original: dunnīharaṇā, nibbānanagarappavesanivāraṇā cāti te “khīlaṃ, palighaṃ, indakhīla”nti
analyzed: dunnīharaṇā nibbāna nagara pavesa nivāraṇā ca ati te khīlam paligham indakhīlanti
translated: They prevent entry into the city of Nibbāna, so they are called “post,” “bolt,” and “axle pin.”

original: ca vuttā. Taṇhāejāya abhāvena anejā paramasantuṭṭhabhāvena cātuddisattā appaṭihatacārikaṃ caranti.
analyzed: ca vuttā taṇhā ejāya abhāvena anejā parama santuṭṭha bhāvena cātuddisattāḥ appaṭihata cārikam caranti
translated: They are without lust because of the absence of the dart of lust, and they are satisfied with any kind of alms food because they are satisfied with the four requisites. They go on their way without seeking alms systematically.

original: Gatāseti gatā eva, na pana gamissanti pariniṭṭhitasaraṇagamanattāti. Lokuttarasaraṇagamanaṃ
analyzed: gatā ase iti gatāḥ eva na pana gamissanti pariniṭṭhita saraṇa gamana ttā ati lokuttara saraṇa gamanam
translated: “Gone to” : they have gone, but they will not go again, because they have completed the going for refuge.🔽The supramundane going for refuge is intended here.

original: adhippetanti āha “nibbematikasaraṇagamanena gatā”ti. Te hi niyamena apāyabhūmiṃ na🔽gamissanti, devakāyañca paripūressanti. Ye pana lokiyena saraṇagamanena buddhaṃ saraṇaṃ🔽gatāse, na te gamissanti apāyabhūmiṃ, sati ca paccayantarasamavāye pahāya mānusaṃ
analyzed: adhippetanti āha nibbematika saraṇa gamanena gatā ati te hi niyamena apāya bhūmim na  gamissanti deva kāyam ca paripūressanti ye pana lokiyena saraṇa gamanena buddham saraṇam  gatāse na te gamissanti apāya bhūmim sati ca paccaya antara samavāye pahāya mānusam
translated: “Gone to” by the going for refuge of one who is definitely liberated. For they will not go to the plane of misery, and they will fill the divine abodes.

original: dehaṃ, devakāyaṃ paripūressantīti ayamettha attho.
analyzed: deham deva kāyam paripūressanti iti ayam ettha attho
translated: But those who have gone for refuge to the Buddha by the mundane going for refuge will not go to the plane of misery, and if they meet with the requisite conditions, after abandoning the human body they will fill the divine abodes. This is the meaning here.

original: Devatāsannipātavaṇṇanā
analyzed: devatā sannipāta vaṇṇanā
translated: The Discourse on the Assemblage of Deities🔽“To these”: to the assemblage of deities.🔽“Now”: at this time.🔽“Buddhas”: because there are no other Buddhas.

original: 333. Etesanti devatāsannipātānaṃ. Idānīti imasmiṃ kāle. Buddhānanti aññesaṃ buddhānaṃ abhāvā. Cittakallatā cittamaddavaṃ.🔽Kiṃ pana bhagavatāva mahante devatāsamāgame tesaṃ nāmagottaṃ kathetuṃ sakkāti? Āma
analyzed: devatā sannipātānam idāni iti imasmin kāle buddhānam ti aññesam buddhānam abhāvā citta kalla tā citta maddavam 🔽kim pana bhagavatā ava mahante devatā samāgame tesam nāma gottam kathetum sakkā ati āma
translated: “Gentleness of mind”: softness of mind.

original: sakkāti dassetuṃ “buddhā nāma mahantā”tiādi vuttaṃ. Tattha diṭṭhanti rūpāyatanamāha,
analyzed: sakkā iti dassetum buddhāḥ nāma mahantā tiādi vuttam tattha diṭṭham ti rūpa āyatanam āha
translated: “Can be shown” is said in order to show that “Buddhas are great.” Herein, seen means the visible-form base.

original: sutanti saddāyatanaṃ, mutanti sampattaggāhiindriyavisayaṃ gandharasaphoṭṭhabbāyatanaṃ,
analyzed: sutanti sadda āyatanam mutanti sampattaggāhi indriya visayam gandha rasa phoṭṭhabba āyatanam
translated: Heard means the sound base. Sensed means the bases of odour, flavour, and tangible data, which are the objective fields of the faculties that apprehend what is contacted.

original: viññātanti vuttāvasesaṃ sabbaṃ ñeyyaṃ, pattanti pariyesitvā, apariyesitvā vā sampattaṃ,
analyzed: viññātanti vutta avasesam sabbam ñeyyam pattanti pariyesitvā a pariyesitvā vā sampattam
translated: Cognized means all the rest that is to be known. Experienced means what is reached by searching for it or what is reached without searching for it.🔽Searched for means what is reached by searching for it or what is not reached but is searched for.

original: pariyesitanti pattaṃ, appattaṃ vā pariyiṭṭhaṃ. Anuvicaritaṃ manasāti kevalaṃ manasā🔽ālocitaṃ. Katthaci nīlādivasena vibhattarūpārammaṇeti abhidhamme “nīlaṃ pītaka”ntiādinā
analyzed: pariyesitam ti pattam appattam vā pariyiṭṭham anuvicaritam manasā iti kevalam manasā  ālocitam katthaci nīla ādi vasena vibhatta rūpa ārammaṇā iti abhidhamme nīlam pīta kanti ādinā
translated: Contemplated with the mind means merely considered with the mind.🔽In some places the object of the visible-form is distinguished by way of blue, etc., and in the Abhidhamma it is distinguished by way of blue, yellow, etc.,

original: vibhatte yattha katthaci rūpārammaṇe kiñci rūpārammaṇaṃ vā na atthīti yojanā. Bherisaddādivasenāti
analyzed: vibhatte yattha katthaci rūpa ārammaṇe kiñci rūpa ārammaṇam vā na atthi iti yojanā bheri sadda ādi vasena ati
translated: and in some places the object of the visible-form is not any visible-form at all. The method is to be construed thus. By way of the sound of a drum, etc.,

original: etthāpi eseva nayo. Yanti yaṃ ārammaṇaṃ. Etesanti buddhānaṃ.
analyzed: ettha api esā iva nayaḥ yanti yam ārammaṇam buddhānam
translated: the same method applies here too. What means whatever object. Of these means of the Buddhas.

original: Idāni yathāvuttamatthaṃ pāḷiyā samatthetuṃ “yathāhā”tiādi vuttaṃ. Tadā jānanakiriyāya
analyzed: idāni yathāvuttam attham pāḷiyā samatthetum yathā āha atiādi vuttam tadā jānana kiriyāya
translated: Now, in order to establish the meaning stated by the texts, “As it is said” is said. At that time, the act of knowing

original: apariyositabhāvadassanatthaṃ “jānāmī”ti vatvā yasmā yaṃ kiñci neyyaṃ nāma, sabbaṃ
analyzed: a pariyosita bhāva dassana attham jānāmi iti vatvā yasmai yam kiñci na iyyam nāma sabbam
translated: “I know” is said in order to show that the matter is not exhausted.

original: taṃ bhagavatā aññātaṃ nāma natthi, tasmā vuttaṃ “tamahaṃ abbhaññāsi”nti.
analyzed: tam bhagavatā aññātam nāma na atthi tasmai vuttam tam aham abbhaññāsin ti
translated: “I know” is said to show that he has not finished speaking. Since there is nothing among the disciples that the Blessed One does not know, it is said: “I have directly known.”

original: Na olokenti payojanābhāvato. Viparītā “na kammāvaraṇena samannāgatā”tiādinā nayena🔽vuttā. “Yassa maṅgalā samūhatā”ti ārabhitvā “rāgaṃ vinayetha mānusesu dibbesu kāmesu🔽cā”tiādinā ca rāganiggahakathābāhullato sammāparibbājanīyasuttaṃ rāgacaritānaṃ sappāyaṃ,
analyzed: na payojana abhāvataḥ viparītāḥ na kamma āvaraṇena samannāgatā ati ādinā nayena  vuttā yassa maṅgalā ārabhitvā rāgam vinayetha mānusesu dibbesu kāmesu  ca ati ādinā ca rāga niggaha kathā bāhullato sammā paribbājanīya suttam rāga caritānam sappāyam
translated: They do not look at it because there is no purpose in doing so. The opposite is stated in the way beginning: “They are not hindered by the hindrance of action” .🔽Since the discourse abounds in statements that eliminate lust, beginning with “For whom the auspicious things are destroyed” and continuing with “Lust among human beings and among the divine sensual-happiness beings,

original: “piyamappiyabhūtā kalaha vivādā paridevasokā sahamaccharā cā”tiādinā kalahādayo yato
analyzed: kalaha vivādā parideva sokā ca ati ādinā kalaha ādayaḥ yatas
translated: you should eliminate” , the discourse called “The Right Way to Instruct” is suitable for those of lustful temperament.

original: dosato samuṭṭhahanti, so ca doso yato piyabhāvato, so ca piyabhāvo yato chandato
analyzed: dosataḥ samuṭṭhahanti saḥ ca dosaḥ yatas piya bhāvato saḥ ca piya bhāvaḥ yatas chandato
translated: Since quarrels, etc., arise from hate, and hate arises from affection, and affection arises from desire,

original: samuṭṭhahanti, iti phalato, kāraṇaparamparato ca dose ādīnavavibhāvanabāhullato kalahavivādasuttaṃ
analyzed: samuṭṭhahanti iti phalataḥ kāraṇa paramparataḥ ca dose ādīnava vibhāvana bāhullataḥ kalaha vivāda suttam
translated: the discourse called “Quarrel and Contention” is suitable for those of hating temperament, since it abounds in the revelation of the danger in hate, from the point of view of the fruit and of the succession of causes, beginning with “Quarrel and contention, lamentation and grief, despair and tribulation, and what is not wished for and not loved” .

original: dosacaritānaṃ sappāyaṃ –
analyzed: dosa caritānam sappāyam
translated: The Great Discourse on the Destruction of Craving

original: “Appañhi etaṃ na alaṃ samāya,
analyzed: etam na alam
translated: “This is a little thing, not worth a quarrel;

original: Duve vivādassa phalāni brūmi;
analyzed: duve vivādassa phalāni brūmi
translated: I declare these two fruits of wrangling:

original: Etampi disvā na vivādayetha,
analyzed: etam pi disvā na vivādayetha
translated: Seeing this, one should not quarrel;

original: Khemābhipassaṃ avivādabhūmi”nti. –
analyzed: khema abhipassam avivāda bhūminti
translated: One should seek the state free from quarrels, the safe state of peace.”

original: Ādinā nayena sammohavidhamanato, paññāparibrūhanato ca mahābyūhasuttaṃ mohacaritānaṃ sappāyaṃ –
analyzed: ādinā nayena sammoha vidhamanataḥ paññā paribrūhanataḥ ca mahābyūhasuttam moha caritānam sappāyam
translated: The Great Discourse on the Destruction of Craving is suitable for those of deluded temperament because it dispels delusion and increases wisdom.

original: “Parassa ce dhammaṃ anānujānaṃ,
analyzed: parassa ce dhammam an ānujānam
translated: “If one does not assent to another’s view,

original: Bālo, mago hoti nihīnapañño;
analyzed: bālaḥ magaḥ hoti nihīna paññaḥ
translated: The fool is of low wisdom;

original: Sabbeva bālā sunihīnapaññā,
analyzed: sabbā iva bālā su nihīna paññā
translated: All are fools of low wisdom,

original: Sabbevime diṭṭhiparibbasānā”ti. –
analyzed: sabbe u ime diṭṭhi paribbasānā ti
translated: All are submerged in views.”

original: Ādinā nayena sandiṭṭhiparāmāsitāpanayanamukhena savisayesu diṭṭhiggahaṇesu visaṭavitakkavicchindanavasena pavattattā cūḷabyūhasuttaṃ vitakkacaritānaṃ sappāyaṃ –
analyzed: ādinā nayena sandiṭṭhi parāmāsita apanayana mukhena sa visayesu diṭṭhi ggahaṇesu visaṭa vitakka vicchindana vasena pavatta ttā cūḷabyūha suttam sappāyam
translated: The Shorter Discourse on the Destruction of Craving is suitable for those of discursive temperament because it occurs by way of the removal of the adherence to views together with their objects, and by way of the cutting off of the scattered thoughts in the various views.

original: “Mūlaṃ papañcasaṅkhāya (iti bhagavā),
analyzed: mūlam iti bhagavā
translated: “The root of mental proliferation,

original: Mantā asmīti sabbaṃ uparundhe;
analyzed: mantā asmi iti sabbam uparundhe
translated: I say, is the thought ‘I am’;

original: Yā kāci taṇhā ajjhattaṃ,
analyzed: yā kāci taṇhā ajjhattam
translated: Whatever craving there is,

original: Tāsaṃ vinayā sadā sato sikkhe”ti. –
analyzed: tāsam vinayā sadā sataḥ sikkha iti
translated: One should always train in its removal.”

original: Papañcasaṅkhāya mūlaṃ avijjādikilesajātaṃ asmīti pavattamānañcāti sabbaṃ mantā paññāya
analyzed: mūlam avijjā ādi kilesa jātam asmi iti pavattamānam ca ati sabbam mantā paññāya
translated: The root of the proliferation of conceiving is the defilement-class beginning with ignorance and the occurrence of the conceit “I am.” All this the wise man should crush with wisdom.

original: uparundheyya. Yā kāci ajjhattaṃ rūpataṇhādibhedā taṇhā uppajjeyya, tāsaṃ vinayā vūpasamāya
analyzed: uparundheyya yā kāci ajjhattam rūpa taṇhā ādi bhedā taṇhā uppajjeyya tāsam vinayāḥ vūpasamāya
translated: Whatever craving there is, classed as craving for visible forms, etc., that has arisen in him, he should train himself to remove and allay

original: sadā sato upaṭṭhitassati hutvā sikkheyyāti evamādi upadesassa saddhova bhājanaṃ.
analyzed: sadā sataḥ upaṭṭhitaḥ sati hutvā sikkheyya ati evamādi upadesassa saddhā uva bhājanam
translated: by being ever mindful and ever aware. Such is the kind of person who is a fit vessel for the advice.

original: Tassa hi so atthāvahoti tuvaṭṭakasuttaṃ saddhācaritānaṃ sappāyaṃ –
analyzed: tassa hi so attha āvahaḥ ti tuvaṭṭaka suttam saddhā caritānam sappāyam
translated: For he is a bearer of the burden of the advice. The Tuvatakasutta is suitable for those who have faith as their dominant tendency:

original: “Vītataṇho purā bhedā (iti bhagavā),
analyzed: vīta taṇho purā bhedāḥ iti bhagavā
translated: “With craving fully ended, he is not set on the past;🔽He is not set on the future, nor does he hanker for the present.

original: Pubbamantamanissito;🔽Vemajjhe nupasaṅkheyyo,
analyzed: pubbam antam anissitaḥ  vemajjhe n upasaṅkheyyaḥ
translated: He is not reckoned in the middle;

original: Tassa natthi purakkhata”nti. –🔽Yo sarīrabhedato pubbeva pahīnataṇho, tato eva atītaddhasaññitaṃ purimakoṭṭhāsaṃ🔽taṇhānissayena anissito, vemajjhe paccuppannepi addhani “ratto”tiādinā upasaṅkhātabbo,
analyzed: tassa na atthi purakkhatanti  yaḥ sarīra bhedato pubbā iva pahīna taṇhaḥ tatas eva atīta ddha saññitam purima koṭṭhāsam  taṇhā nissayena anissitaḥ vemajjhe paccuppanne pi addhani rattaḥ ti ādinā upasaṅkhātabbaḥ
translated: He has no future, nor does he exist in the past.🔽One who has ended craving before the breakup of the body is called “one not set on the past” because he has already abandoned craving in the past.🔽He is not set on the future by the craving for existence, nor is he reckoned in the middle, in the present, as “one who is attached” , etc.

original: tassa arahato taṇhādiṭṭhipurakkhārānaṃ abhāvā anāgate addhani kiñci purakkhataṃ natthīti
analyzed: tassa arahataḥ taṇhā diṭṭhi purakkhārānaṃ abhāvā anāgate addhani kiñci purakkhatam natthi iti
translated: He has no future because he has no future rebirth due to the absence of craving and view that might precede it.

original: ādinā evaṃ gambhīrakathābāhullato pūrābhedasuttaṃ buddhicaritānaṃ sappāyanti katvā🔽vuttaṃ “atha nesaṃ sappāyaṃ …pe… vavatthapetvā”ti. Manasākāsīti evaṃ cariyāya vasena
analyzed: ādinā evam gambhīra kathā bāhullato pūrābheda suttam katvā  vuttam atha nesam sappāyam pe vavatthapetvā ati manasā akāsi iti evam cariyāya vasena
translated: The Pürabheda Sutta was spoken by the Blessed One in order to show the suitability of the Dhamma talk for those of the type of understanding that is inclined to the profound.🔽“Then, having determined what is suitable for them, he teaches them the Dhamma” .

original: manasi katvā puna taṃ sadisaṃ attano desanānikkhepayogyatāvasena manasi akāsi. Attajjhāsayena🔽nu kho jāneyyāti parajjhāsayādiṃ anapekkhitvā mayhaṃyeva ajjhāsayena āraddha desanaṃ
analyzed: manasi katvā puna tam sadisam attanaḥ desanā nikkhepa yogya tā vasena manasi akāsi  nu kho jāneyya iti para ajjhāsaya ādim an apekkhitvā mayhaṃyeva ajjhāsayena āraddha desanaṃ
translated: Having thus considered the type of understanding, he again considered the suitability of the Dhamma talk for the particular occasion, thinking, “Will they understand a talk that I have prepared in my own mind? ”🔽“Will they understand a talk that I have prepared in my own mind” means: will they understand a talk that I have prepared in my own mind without regard for the inclinations of others?

original: jāneyya nu kho. Parajjhāsayenāti sannipatitāya parisāya kassaci ajjhāsayena. Aṭṭhuppattikenāti🔽idha samuṭṭhitaaṭṭhuppattiyā. Pucchāvasenāti kassaci pucchantassa pucchāvasena. Āraddhadesanaṃ
analyzed: jāneyya nu kho para ajjhāsayena ati sannipatitāya parisāya kassaci ajjhāsayena aṭṭhuppattikena ati  idha samuṭṭhita aṭṭhuppattiyā pucchā vasena ati kassaci pucchantassa pucchā vasena āraddha desanam
translated: “Will they understand a talk that I have prepared in the minds of others” means: will they understand a talk that I have prepared in the minds of some member of the assembly?🔽“Will they understand a talk that has arisen through questioning” means: will they understand a talk that has arisen through questioning someone who asks a question?🔽“Will they understand a talk that I have prepared” means: “If he were a Paccekabuddha” .

original: jāneyyāti. “Sace paccekabuddho bhaveyyā”ti idaṃ imesaṃ suttānaṃ desanāya pucchā paccekabuddhānaṃ
analyzed: jāneyya iti sace paccekabuddhaḥ bhaveyya ati idam imesam suttānam desanāya pucchā paccekabuddhānam
translated: This is the method of teaching and questioning in these Suttas.

original: bhāriyā, avisayā cāti dassanatthaṃ vuttaṃ. Tenāha “sopi na sakkuṇeyyā”ti.
analyzed: bhāriyā avisayā ca ati dassana attham vuttam tena āha saḥ api na sakkuṇeyya iti
translated: and it is said for the purpose of showing that it is heavy and beyond their scope. Hence he said: “She would not be able to do so.”

original: Ettha ca yasmā na anumatipucchā, kathetukamyatāpucchā vā yuttā, atha kho diṭṭhasaṃsandanapucchāsadisī
analyzed: ettha ca yasmai na anumati pucchā kathā itu kamyatā pucchā vā yuttā atha kho diṭṭha saṃsandana pucchā sadisī
translated: And here it is not proper to ask for permission or to ask out of a desire to speak, but it is proper to ask as if to confirm what has been seen🔽or as if to decide a doubt.

original: vā vimaticchedanapucchāsadisī vā pucchā yuttā, tāva puggalajjhāsayavasena pavattitā🔽nāma honti, na yathādhammavasena, tattha yadi bhagavā tathā sayameva pucchitvā sayameva
analyzed: vā vimati chedana pucchā sadisī vā pucchā yuttā  nāma honti na yathā dhamma vasena yadi bhagavā tathā sayam eva pucchitvā sayam eva
translated: But such questions occur only according to the inclination of the person asking,

original: vissajjeyya, suṇantīnaṃ devatānaṃ sammoho bhaveyya “kiṃ nāmetaṃ bhagavā paṭhamaṃ🔽evamāha, punapi evamāhā”ti, andhakāraṃ paviṭṭhā viya honti, tasmā vuttaṃ “evaṃ petā
analyzed: vissajjeyya suṇantīnam devatānam sammohaḥ bhaveyya kim nāma etam bhagavā paṭhamam  evam āha puna api evam āha ati andhakāram paviṭṭhāḥ viya honti tasmā vuttam evam petā
translated: not according to the way things are. There, if the Blessed One were to ask in that way and then answer himself, the deities listening would be confused, thinking: “Why did the Blessed One say this first,🔽and why did he say this afterwards?” They would be as if plunged into darkness. That is why it was said: “The deities would not be able to penetrate it.”

original: devatā na sakkhissanti paṭivijjhitu”nti. Yathādhammadesanāyaṃ pana kathetukamyatāvasena
analyzed: devatāḥ na sakkhissanti paṭivijjhitunti yathā dhamma desanā ayam pana kathetu kamya tā vasena
translated: But if the question is asked out of a desire to speak according to the way things are, there is confusion.

original: pucchanena sammoho hotīti. Sūriyo uggatoti āha devasaṅgho āsannatarabhāvena obhāsassa
analyzed: pucchanena sammohaḥ hoti iti sūriyaḥ uggataḥ ti āha deva saṅghaḥ āsannatara bhāvena obhāsassa
translated: The sun has risen, the host of deities is near, the light

original: vipulauḷārabhāvato. Ekissā lokadhātuyāti sutte āgatanayena sabbattheva pana apubbaṃ
analyzed: vipula oḷāra bhāvataḥ ekissā lokadhātuyā ati sutte āgata nayena sabbattha iva pana apubbam
translated: And because of the greatness of the field.🔽In the Suttas, however, it is said that two Buddhas do not arise in one world-sphere.

original: acarimaṃ dve buddhā na honteva. Tenevāha – “anantāsu…pe… addasā”ti.
analyzed: acarimam dve buddhāḥ na honta iva tena iva āha
translated: That is why it is said, “In infinite world-spheres … saw.”

original: Gāthāyaṃ pucchāmīti nimmitabuddho bhagavantaṃ pucchituṃ okāsaṃ kārāpesi. Muninti🔽buddhamuniṃ. Pahūtapaññanti mahāpaññaṃ. Tiṇṇanti caturoghatiṇṇaṃ. Pāraṅgatanti nibbānappattaṃ,
analyzed: gāthāyam pucchāmi iti nimmita buddhaḥ bhagavantam pucchitum okāsam kārāpesi munin ti  buddha munim pahūta paññam ti mahā paññam tiṇṇam ti catur ogha tiṇṇam pāraṅgatam nibbāna ppattam
translated: In the verse, “I ask” : the created Buddha asked the Blessed One to give him an opportunity to ask. “Sage” :

original: sabbassa vā ñeyyassa pāraṃ pariyantaṃ gataṃ. Parinibbutaṃ saupādisesanibbānavasena.
analyzed: sabbassa vā ñeyyassa pāram pariyantam gatam parinibbutam sa aupādisesa nibbāna vasena
translated: Buddha-sage. “Rich in wisdom” : of great wisdom. “Crossed over” : crossed over the four floods . “Gone to the other shore” : reached Nibbāna, or gone to the end of all that is to be known. “Extinguished” : extinguished by the attainment of the Nibbāna element with residue remaining.

original: Ṭhitattanti avaṭṭhitacittaṃ lokadhammehi akampaneyyatāya. Nikkhamma gharā panujja
analyzed: ṭhitattam ti avaṭṭhita cittam loka dhammehi akampaneyya tāya nikkhamma gharā panujja
translated: “Abiding” : his mind not wavering, unshaken by mundane states. “Having gone forth from the house life” :🔽having abandoned sensual pleasures and gone forth from the house life.

original: kāmeti vatthukāme panūditvā gharāvāsā nikkhamma. Kathaṃ bhikkhu sammā so loke paribbajeyyāti
analyzed: kāmeti vatthu kāme panūditvā ghara āvāsā nikkhamma katham bhikkhu sammā saḥ loke paribbajeyya ati
translated: “How should a monk wander about rightly in the world?” :

original: so bhikkhu kathaṃ sammā paribbajeyya gaccheyya vihareyya, anupalitto hutvā lokaṃ🔽atikkameyyāti attho.
analyzed: so bhikkhu katham sammā paribbajeyya gaccheyya vihareyya an upalittaḥ hutvā lokaṃ 🔽atikkameyya ati attho
translated: how should a monk go, live, and overcome the world without being defiled?

original: 334. Silokaṃ anukassāmīti ettha siloko nāma pādasamudayo, isīhi vuccamānā gāthātipi
analyzed: silokam anukassāmi iti ettha silokaḥ nāma pāda samudayaḥ isīhi vuccamānā
translated: I shall recite the verse: here the verse is a collection of feet, and it is called a stanza when it is spoken by seers.

original: vuccati. Pādova niyatavaṇṇānupubbikānaṃ padānaṃ samūho, taṃ silokaṃ anukassāmi pavattayissāmīti🔽atthoti āha “akkhara…pe… pavattayissāmī”ti. Yatthāti adhikaraṇe bhummaṃ. Āmeḍitalopenāyaṃ
analyzed: vuccati pādaḥ uva niyata vaṇṇa ānupubbikānam padānam samūhaḥ tam silokam anukassāmi pavattayissāmi iti  atthaḥ iti āha akkharape pavattayissāmi iti yattha ati adhikaraṇe bhummam āma īḍita lopena ayam
translated: The collection of feet in the regular order is a verse. I shall recite that, I shall set it going, is what is said.🔽Where: the locative case is in the sense of basis.🔽The demonstration is in the sense of the place.

original: niddesoti āha “yesu yesu ṭhānesū”ti. Bhummāti bhūmipaṭibaddhanivāsā. Taṃ taṃ nissitā
analyzed: niddeso ti āha yesu yesu ṭhānesu iti bhummā ati bhūmi paṭibaddha nivāsā tam tam nissitā
