translated: The locative case is in the sense of the place.

original: taṃ taṃ ṭhānaṃ nissitavanto nissāya vasamānā, tehi saddhiṃ silokaṃ anukassāmīti adhippāyo.
analyzed: tam tam ṭhānam nissitavantaḥ nissāya vasamānā tehi saddhim si lokam anukassāmi iti adhippāyaḥ
translated: The meaning is: I shall recite the verse together with those who live in that place, who are dependent on that place, who live in dependence on that place.🔽“Those who live in mountain caves” : this shows that they live in seclusion.

original: “Ye sitā girigabbhara”nti iminā tesaṃ vivekavāsaṃ dasseti, “pahitattā samāhitā”ti
analyzed: ye sitāḥ iminā tesam viveka vāsam dasseti pahita ttā samāhitā ti
translated: “Who are ardent and attained to concentration” :

original: iminā bhāvanābhiyogaṃ.
analyzed: iminā bhāvanā abhiyogam
translated: this shows that they are devoted to development.🔽The many people are those numbered at five hundred.

original: Bahujanā pañcasatasaṅkhyattā. Paṭipakkhābhibhavanato, tejussadatāya ca sīhā viya
analyzed: bahujanā pañca sata saṅkhya tā paṭipakkha abhibhavanato tejussada tāya ca sīhāḥ
translated: Like lions, because they overpower their opposites and because of the abundance of their splendour.

original: pavivittatāya nilīnā. Ekattanti ekībhāvaṃ. Odātacittā hutvā suddhāti arahattamaggādhigamena
analyzed: nilīnāḥ ekattanti ekībhāvam odāta cittāḥ hutvā suddhā ati arahatta magga adhigamena
translated: They were secluded in the sense of being withdrawn from the hindrances. They were unified in the sense of being unified in the noble fruit. They were pure in the sense of being purified by the attainment of the path of arahantship.

original: pariyodātacittā hutvā suddhā, na kevalaṃ sarīrasuddhiyāva. Vippasannāti ariyamaggappasādena
analyzed: pariyodāta cittā hutvā suddhā na kevalam vippasannā ati ariya magga ppasādena
translated: They were pure not only in the sense of bodily purity. They were clear in the sense of being clear by the clarity of the noble path.

original: visesato pasannā. Cittassa āvilabhāvakarānaṃ kilesānaṃ abhāvena anāvilā.
analyzed: visesataḥ pasannā cittassa āvila bhāva karānam kilesānam abhāvena anāvilā
translated: They were untroubled in the sense of being untroubled by the defilements that cause the mind’s lucidity.

original: Bhikkhū jānitvāti bhinnakilese bhikkhū “ime dibbacakkhunā ete devakāye passantīti
analyzed: bhikkhū jānitvā ti bhinna kilese bhikkhū ime dibba cakkhunā ete deva kāye passanti iti
translated: The bhikkhus knew that they were seeing those deities in the Brahmā-world with the divine eye after they had attained the divine eye.

original: jānitvā. Savanante jātattāti dhammassavanapariyosāne ariyajātiyā jātattā. Idaṃ sabbanti
analyzed: jānitvā savana ante jāta ttā ati dhammassavana pariyosāne ariya jātiyā jāta ttā idam sabbanti
translated: They were born in the noble birth at the conclusion of the hearing of the Dhamma.

original: idaṃ “bhiyyo pañcasate”tiādikaṃ sabbaṃ.
analyzed: idam bhiyyo pañca sata iti ādikam sabbam
translated: This all: this all beginning with “more than five hundred.”

original: Tadatthāya vīriyaṃ kariṃsūti dibbacakkhuñāṇābhinīhāravasena vīriyaṃ ussāhaṃ akaṃsu.
analyzed: tad atthāya vīriyam kariṃsu iti dibba cakkhu ñāṇa abhinīhāra vasena vīriyam ussāham akaṃsu
translated: They exerted themselves for the attainment of that: they exerted themselves, they made an effort, for the attainment of the divine eye knowledge.

original: Tenāha “na taṃ tehī”tiādi. Sattarinti ta-kārassa ra-kārādesaṃ katvā vuttaṃ, sattatinti
analyzed: tena āha na tam tehi itiādi sattarin ti takārassa rakāra ādesam katvā vuttam sattatin ti
translated: Hence it is said: “Not by them” and so on. Seventy: the ta is replaced by ra.

original: attho. “Sahassa”nti pana anuvattati, sattatiyogena bahuvacanaṃ. Tenāha “eke sahassaṃ.
analyzed: attho sahassanti pana anuvattati sattati yogena bahuvacanam tena āha eke sahassam
translated: “Sahassa” is repeated, and the plural is used by way of the “satta” . Therefore he says: “Some one thousand .

original: Eke sattatisahassānī”ti.
analyzed: eke sattati sahassāni iti
translated: Some seven thousand .

original: Anantanti antarahitaṃ, taṃ pana ativiya mahantaṃ nāma hotīti āha “vipula”nti.
analyzed: ananta anti anta rahitam tam pana mahantam nāma hoti iti āha vipula nti
translated: “Ananta” means “without an end”, but that is a very great name, therefore he says “vipulā” .

original: Avekkhitvāti ñāṇacakkhunā visuṃ visuṃ avekkhitvā “vavatthitvānā”tipi paṭhanti, so
analyzed: avekkhitvā ti ñāṇa cakkhunā visum visum avekkhitvā paṭhanti so
translated: “Avekkhitvā” means “having surveyed” with the eye of knowledge, “having defined” is also read, that is the

original: evattho. Taṃ avekkhanaṃ nicchayakaraṇaṃ hotīti āha “vavatthapetvā”ti. Pubbe vuttagāthāsu
analyzed: evatthaḥ tam avekkhanam nicchaya karaṇam hoti iti āha vavatthapetvā ti pubbe vutta gāthāsu
translated: meaning. That survey is the making of a fixed idea, therefore he says “having defined” . In the verses stated previously

original: tatiyagāthāya pacchimaddhaṃ, catutthagāthāya purimaddhañca sandhāyāha “pubbe vuttagāthamevā”ti.
analyzed: tatiya gāthāya pacchimaddham catuttha gāthāya purimaddhañca sandhāya āha pubbe vutta gātham eva iti
translated: he says: “The latter half of the third verse and the former half of the fourth verse” .

original: Vijānanampi dassanaṃ evāti āha “passatha olokethā”ti. Vācāyatapavattitabhāvato “anupaṭipāṭiyāva kittayissāmī”ti vadati.
analyzed: vijānanam pi dassanam eva ati āha passatha oloketha ati vācā āyata pavattita bhāvataḥ anupaṭipāṭiya āva kittayissāmi iti vadati
translated: Vijānanampi is seeing, therefore he says: “Passatha olokethā” . Because of the state of being spoken of, he says: “I shall recite in no particular order” .

original: 335. Satta sahassāni saṅkhāyāti satta sahassā. Yakkhāyevāti yakkhajātikā eva. Ānubhāvasampannāti
analyzed: satta sahassāni saṅkhāya ati satta sahassā yakkhāya iva ati yakkha jātikā eva ānubhāva sampannā ati
translated: Satta sahassāni saṅkhāyāti satta sahassā. Yakkhāyevāti yakkhajātikā eva. Ānubhāvasampannāti

original: mahesakkhā. Iddhimantoti vā mahānubhāvā. Jutimantoti mahappabhā. Vaṇṇavantoti atikkantavaṇṇā.
analyzed: mahesakkhāḥ iddhimanto ti vā mahā anubhāvāḥ jutimanto ti mahappabhāḥ vaṇṇavanto ti atikkanta vaṇṇā
translated: Greatly powerful: either greatly successful in psychic power, or greatly successful in influence. Greatly radiant: greatly successful in radiance. Greatly famous: greatly successful in fame.

original: Yasassinoti mahāparivārā ceva patthaṭakittisaddā ca. Samiti-saddo samīpatthoti adhippāyenāha
analyzed: yasassino ti mahā parivārā ca iva patthaṭa kitti saddā ca samiti saddo samīpa tthaḥ ti adhippāyena āha
translated: Renowned: greatly successful in having a great retinue and in having their sound of fame spread. The word samiti is a near-synonym of santika.

original: “bhikkhūnaṃ santika”nti.
analyzed: bhikkhūnam santikam ti
translated: “In the presence of the bhikkhus” is said with the intention of showing this.

original: Hemavatapabbateti himavato samīpe ṭhitapabbate.
analyzed: hemavata pabbata iti himavataḥ samīpe ṭhita pabbate
translated: On the Himalayas: on the mountain standing near the Himalayas.

original: Ete sabbepīti ete sattasahassā kāpilavatthavā, chasahassā hemavatā, tisahassā sātāgirāti yathāvuttā sabbepi soḷasasahassā.
analyzed: ete sabbe api iti ete satta sahassā kāpilavatthavā cha sahassā hemavatā ti sahassā sātāgirā ati yathā vuttā sabbe api soḷasa sahassā
translated: All these: all these sixteen thousand, namely, the seven thousand from Kāpilavatthu, the six thousand from the Himalayas, and the three thousand from Sīta.

original: Rājagahanagareti rājagahanagarassa samīpe. Tanti kumbhīraṃ.
analyzed: rājagaha nagara iti rājagaha nagarassa samīpe kumbhīram
translated: In the vicinity of the city of Rājagaha: near the city of Rājagaha. Tanti: a water demon.

original: 336. Kāmaṃ pācīnadisaṃ pasāsati, tathāpi catūsupi disāsu saparivāradīpesu catūsupi
analyzed: kāmam pācīna disam tathā api catūsupi disāsu sa parivāra dīpesu catūsupi
translated: Although he rules over the eastern direction, so too in the four directions, in the four great continents together with the surrounding islands,

original: mahādīpesu gandhabbānaṃ jeṭṭhako, kathaṃ? Sabbe te tassa vase vattanti. Kumbhaṇḍānaṃ
analyzed: mahā dīpesu gandhabbānam jeṭṭhako katham sabbe te tassa vase vattanti kumbhaṇḍānam
translated: he is the chief of the gandhabbas. How? All of them are subject to his sway. He is the overlord of the kumbhaṇḍhas.

original: adhipatītiādīsupi eseva nayo.
analyzed: adhipati iti ādī supi esa iva nayoḥ
translated: The same method applies to the rest.

original: Tassāpi viruḷhassa. Tādisāyevāti dhataraṭṭhassa puttasadisā eva puthutthato, nāmato, balato, iddhiādivisesato ca.
analyzed: tassa api viruḷhassa tādisāya eva ati dhataraṭṭhassa putta sadisā eva puthutthataḥ nāmataḥ balataḥ iddhi ādi visesato ca
translated: and he too had a son like him, of the same name, of the same strength, and of the same special qualities of supernormal power, etc.

original: Sabbasaṅgāhikavasenāti dasasahassilokadhātuyā paccekaṃ cattāro cattāro mahārājānoti tesaṃ sabbesaṃ saṅgaṇhanavasena. Tenāha “ayañcetthā”tiādi.
analyzed: sabba saṅgāhika vasena āti dasa sahassi lokadhātuyā paccekam cattāro cattāro mahārājāno ti tesam sabbesam saṅgaṇhana vasena tena āha ayam ca itthā itiādi
translated: By way of the all-inclusive: by way of the inclusion of all of them, since each of the four great kings rules over the ten thousand world-element. Therefore he says, “Herein, the four kings” and so on.

original: Caturo disāti catūsu disāsu. Caturo disā jalamānā samujjalantā obhāsentā. Yadi evaṃ mahatiyā parisāya āgatānaṃ kathaṃ kāpilavatthave vane ṭhitāti āha “te panā”tiādi.
analyzed: caturaḥ disā ati catūsu disāsu caturaḥ disā jalamānā samujjalantā obhāsentā yadi evam mahatiyā parisāya āgatānam katham kāpilavatthave vane ṭhitā iti āha te pana atiādi
translated: The four directions: in the four directions. The four directions shine, blaze, and radiate. If so, how is it that they are said to be “standing in the forest at Kapilavatthu” among the great multitude that has come? He says, “But they” and so on.

original: Ettakā dāsāti ettakā kuṭeṇḍuādikā nighaṇḍupariyosānā aṭṭhamahārājānaṃ dāsā.

original: Devarājānoti devā hutvā taṃtaṃdevakāyassa rājāno. Citto ca seno ca cittaseno cāti tayo ete devaputtā pāḷiyaṃ ekasesanayena vuttāti āha “citto cā”tiādi.
analyzed: deva rājāno ti devāḥ hutvā taṃ taṃ deva kāyassa rājāno citto ca seno ca cittaseno ca ati tayo ete deva puttā pāḷiyam ekasesa nayena vuttā ati āha citto ca atiādi
translated: “Kings of the gods” : they are kings of the gods of such and such a divine world. Citta, Sena, and Cittasena, these three sons of gods are mentioned in the text in a single group. Therefore he said “Citta and so on.”

original: Bhikkhusaṅgho samito sannipatito etthāti bhikkhusaṅghasamiti, imaṃ vanaṃ.
analyzed: bhikkhu saṅghaḥ samitaḥ sannipatitaḥ ettha ati bhikkhu saṅgha samiti imam vanam
translated: “The assembly of the community of monks” : the assembly of the community of monks gathered here.

original: 338. Nāgasadahavāsikāti nāgasadahanivāsino. Tattheko kira nāgarājā, cirakālaṃ vasato tassa parisā mahatī paramparāgatā atthi, taṃ sandhāyāha “tacchakanāgaparisāyā”ti.
analyzed: nāgasadaha vāsikā ati nāgasadaha nivāsinaḥ tattha ekaḥ kira nāga rājā cira kālam vasataḥ tassa parisā mahatī paramparā gatā atthi tam sandhāya āha tacchaka nāga parisāya iti
translated: “The residents of Nāgasadha” : the residents of Nāgasadha. It is said that there was a king of the nāgas there, and that he had a great retinue that had come down to him through a long line of ancestors. With reference to that he said “the retinue of the nāgas of that place.”

original: Yamunavāsinoti yamunāyaṃ vasanakanāgā. Nāgavohārenāti hatthināgavohārena.
analyzed: yamuna vāsinaḥ iti vasanaka nāgāḥ nāga vohārena ati hatthi nāga vohārena
translated: “The residents of the Yamunā” : the nāgas living in the Yamunā. “By the term ‘nāga’” : by the term ‘elephant.’

original: Vuttappakāreti kambalassatare ṭhapetvā itare vuttappakāranāgā. Lobhābhibhūtāti āhāralobhena
analyzed: vutta ppakārā iti kambala ssatare ṭhapetvā itare vutta ppakāra nāgā lobha abhibhūtā ati āhāra lobhena
translated: “The nāgas of the kind mentioned” : the nāgas of the kind mentioned, except for the one called Kambala. “Overcome by greed” : overcome by greed for food.

original: abhibhūtā. Dibbānubhāvatāti dibbānubhāvato, dibbānubhāvahetu vā dibbā. “Citrasupaṇṇā”ti
analyzed: abhibhūtā dibba anubhāvatā ati dibba anubhāvataḥ dibba anubhāva hetu vā dibbā citra supaṇṇā ati
translated: and they were overcome. ‘By the power of the gods’ means by the power of the gods, or because of the power of the gods. ‘Supaṇṇas’

original: nāmaṃ vicitrasundarapattavantatāya.
analyzed: nāmam
translated: means ‘having variegated and beautiful wings’.

original: Upavhayantāti upecca kathentā. Kākolūkaahinakulādayo viya aññamaññaṃ jātisamudāgataverāpi🔽samānā mittā viya…pe… haṭṭhatuṭṭhacittā aññamaññasminti adhippāyo. Buddhaṃyeva te
analyzed: upavhayantā ati upecca kathentā kāka ulūka ahi nakula ādayaḥ aññam aññam jāti samudāgata verā api  samānāḥ mittāḥ viyape haṭṭha tuṭṭha cittāḥ aññam aññasmin ti adhippāyaḥ buddham yeva te
translated: ‘They spoke’ means they spoke after having approached each other. Although they had mutual enmity born of their different species, like crows, owls, and mongooses,

original: saraṇaṃ gatā “buddhānubhāveneva mayaṃ aññamaññasmiṃ mettiṃ paṭilabhimhā”ti.
analyzed: saraṇam gatāḥ buddha anubhāvena iva mayam aññam aññasmin mettim paṭilabhimha ati

original: 339. Bhātaroti methunabhātaro. Tenāha “sujāya asurakaññāya kāraṇā”ti.
analyzed: bhātaro ti methuna bhātaro tena āha sujāya asura kaññāya kāraṇā iti

original: Tesūti asuresu. Kālakañcāti evaṃ nāmā. Mahābhismāti bhiṃsanakamahāsarīrā. Abhabbāti sammattaniyāmaṃ okkamituṃ na bhabbā acchandikattā tādisassa chandasseva abhāvato.
analyzed: tesu iti asuresu kālakam ca ati evam nāmā mahā bhismā ati bhiṃsanaka mahā sarīrā abhabbā ati sammatta niyāmam okkamitum na bhabbā acchandika ttā tādisassa chandassa iva abhāvato
translated: ‘Among them’ means among the asuras. ‘Kālakañja’ is the name of one. ‘Greatly terrifying’ means having a terrifyingly large body. ‘Unable’ means unable to enter into the fixed course of rightness, because of the absence of such desire, because of the absence of desire.

original: Balino mahāasurassa abbhatītattā tassa putte eva kittento bhagavā “satañca baliputtāna”nti ādimāha. So kira sukhumaṃ attabhāvaṃ māpetvā upagacchi.
analyzed: balinaḥ mahā asurassa abbhatīta ttā tassa putte eva kittentaḥ bhagavā satam ca bali puttānam ti ādim āha saḥ kira sukhumam atta bhāvam māpetvā upagacchi
translated: The Blessed One said “the hundred and the thousand of Bali’s sons” because he was referring to the sons of the mighty asura king Bali who had been killed. It seems that he assumed a subtle material form and approached the Blessed One.

translated: Having been reborn in the Brahmā-world, he is established in the lower Brahmā-world, not in the Suddhāvāsa Brahmā-world. The Great Brahmā Tissa was an ordinary man,

original: yo aparabhāge manussesu nibbattitvā moggaliputtatissatthero jāto.🔽Sahassaṃ brahmalokānanti brahmaloko etesanti brahmalokā, brahmāno, tesaṃ brahmalokānaṃ🔽sahassaṃ sattalokapariyāyo cāyaṃ lokasaddoti āha “mahābrahmānaṃ sahassaṃ āgata”nti.
analyzed: yaḥ aparabhāge manussesu nibbattitvā moggaliputta tissa theraḥ jātaḥ  sahassam brahma lokānam ti brahma lokaḥ etesanti brahma lokāḥ brahmāno tesam brahma lokānam  sahassam satta loka pariyāyo ca ayam loka saddo ti āha mahābrahmānam sahassam āgatanti
translated: who later, after being reborn among humans, became the Elder Moggaliputtatissa.🔽“A thousand Brahmā-worlds” : the Brahmā-world is what is meant by “Brahmā-world” .🔽The word “world” is a term for the world of beings. Therefore it is said: “a thousand of the Great Brahmās came.”

original: Anantaragāthāyaṃ “āgatā”ti vuttapadameva atthavasena vadati. Yatthāti yasmiṃ brahmasahasse.
analyzed: anantara gāthāyam āgatā iti vutta padam eva attha vasena vadati yattha iti yasmim brahma sahasse
translated: In the next line, he explains the meaning of the word “came” that is used in the verse. “Where” means in which thousand of Brahmā-worlds.

original: Aññe brahmeti tadaññe brahmāno. Abhibhavitvā tiṭṭhati vaṇṇena, yasasā āyunā ca.
analyzed: aññe brahmā iti tat aññe brahmānaḥ abhibhavitvā tiṭṭhati vaṇṇena yasasā āyunā ca
translated: ‘Other Brahmas’: other Brahmas than he. ‘He stands out’: he stands out in beauty, fame and life-span.

original: Issarāti teneva vasapavattanena sesabrahmānaṃ adhipatino.
analyzed: tena iva vasa pavattanena sesa brahmānam adhipatinaḥ
translated: ‘Ruler’: by that very control of his own he is the overlord of the other Brahmas.

original: 342. Kāḷakadhammasamannāgato kāḷakassa pāpimassa mārassa bālabhāvaṃ passatha, yo attano avisaye niratthakaṃ parakkamituṃ vāyamati.
analyzed: kāḷaka dhamma samannāgataḥ kāḷakassa pāpimassa mārassa bāla bhāvam passatha yaḥ attanaḥ avisaye niratthakam parakkamitum vā āyamati
translated: ‘See the folly of the evil Mara, the Black One, who is possessed by the black states’: see the foolishness of the Black One, the evil Mara, who strives to attack what is not his province and is useless.

original: Vītarāgabhāvāvahassa dhammassavanassa antarāyakaraṇena avītarāgā rāgena baddhā eva nāma hontīti vuttaṃ “rāgena baddhaṃ hotū”ti.
analyzed: vīta rāga bhāva āvahassa dhamma ssavanassa antarāya karaṇena a vīta rāgāḥ rāgena baddhāḥ eva nāma honti iti vuttam rāgena baddham hotu uti
translated: ‘Let him be bound with passion’: they are said to be bound with passion because they are not free from passion by reason of their obstructing the hearing of the Dhamma which leads to the state of being free from passion.

original: Bhayānakaṃ sarañca katvāti bheravaṃ mahantaṃ saddaṃ samuṭṭhapetvā.🔽Idāni taṃ saddaṃ upamāya dassento “yathā”ti ādimāha. Kañcīti tasmiṃ samāgame kañci🔽devataṃ, mānusakaṃ vā attano vase vattetuṃ asakkonto asayaṃvase sayañca na attano
analyzed: bhayānakam sarañca katvā ati bheravam mahantam saddam samuṭṭhapetvā  idāni tam saddam upamāya dassentaḥ yathā iti ādim āha kañci iti tasmin samāgame kañci  devatam mānusakam vā attanaḥ vase vattetum a sakkontaḥ a sayaṃvase sayam ca na attanaḥ
translated: ‘Having made a fearful and terrible noise’: having made a loud and great noise.🔽Now, showing that noise by means of a simile, he said ‘As if’ and so on. ‘Anyone’: anyone in that assembly, whether a god or a human being.

original: vase ṭhito. Tenāha “asayaṃvasī”tiādi.
analyzed: tena āha asayaṃvasī itiādi
translated: ‘Unable to control himself’: unable to control himself, unable to stand in his own place. Therefore he said ‘unable to control himself’ and so on.

original: 343. “Vītarāgehī”ti desanāsīsametaṃ. Sabbāyapi hi tattha samāgataparisāya mārasenā
analyzed: vīta rāgehi iti hi tattha samāgata parisāya māra senā
translated: “Free from lust” is the climax of the teaching. For the whole of Māra’s army, which had assembled there,

original: apakkantāva. Nesaṃ lomampi iñjayuṃ tesaṃ lomamattampi na cālesuṃ, kuto antarāyakaraṇaṃ.
analyzed: nesam lomam iñjayum tesam loma mattam pi na kutas antarāya karaṇam
translated: had already departed. They did not even ruffle a hair of the Blessed One, to say nothing of doing any harm.

original: Iti yattakā tattha visesaṃ adhigacchiṃsu, tesaṃ sabbesampi antarāyākaraṇavasena attho
analyzed: iti yattakā tattha visesam tesam sabbesam pi antarāya akaraṇa vasena attho
translated: So the meaning should be illustrated by the fact that they did no harm to anyone there who had reached distinction,

original: vibhāvetabbo, vītarāgaggahaṇena vā sarāgavītarāgavibhāvino ca tattha saṅgahitāti
analyzed: vibhāvetabbaḥ vīta rāga ggahaṇena vā sa rāga vīta rāga vibhāvino ca tattha saṅgahitā ti
translated: or else by the fact that those who were distinguished as free from lust and those who were distinguished as possessing lust were both included in the phrase “free from lust.”

original: veditabbaṃ. Māro imaṃ gāthaṃ abhāsi acchariyabbhutacittajāto. Kathañhi nāma tāva
analyzed: veditabbam māraḥ imam gātham abhāsi acchariya bhuta citta jātaḥ katham hi nāma tāva
translated: Māra spoke this verse with his mind amazed and astonished. For how was it that, when he had done such a terrible and terrifying thing to them,

original: ghorataraṃ mahatiṃ vibhiṃsakaṃ mayi karontepi sabbe pime nibbikārā samāhitā eva.
analyzed: ghorataram mahatim vibhiṃsakam mayi karonte api sabbe pi me nibbikārā samāhitāḥ eva
translated: they all remained unmoved and composed?

original: Kasmā? Vijitāvino ime uttamapurisāti. Tenāha “sabbe”tiādi. Yādiso ariyānaṃ dhammanissito
analyzed: kasmā vijitāvinaḥ ime uttama purisā ti tena āha sabba itiādi yādisaḥ ariyānam dhamma nissito
translated: Why was that? Because they were the most excellent of men who had won the victory. That is why he said “all” .🔽The joy of the noble ones has the Dhamma as its object,

original: pamodo, na kadāci tādiso anariyānaṃ hotīti “sāsane bhūtehi ariyehi” iccetaṃ vuttaṃ.
analyzed: pamodaḥ na kadāci tādisaḥ anariyānam hoti iti sāsane bhūtehi ariyehi icca etam vuttam
translated: and never is the joy of the ignoble like that of the noble ones. That is why it was said “with noble ones, who are true to the Dhamma.”

original: Vi-saddena vinā kevalopi suta-saddo vikhyātatthavacano hoti “sutadhammassā”tiādīsu
analyzed: visaddena vinā kevalaḥ api suta saddaḥ vikhyāta attha vacanaḥ hoti suta dhammassa ati ādīsu
translated: Without the prefix vi, the word suta alone is a term for what is well known, as in the words sutadhammassa, etc.

original: viyāti āha “jane vissutā”ti.
analyzed: viyā iti āha jane vissutā ati
translated: He said “well known to people” .🔽Far: in a far place.

original: Dūreti dūre padese. Daharassa antarāyaṃ pariharantī “na sakkā bhante sakalaṃ kāyaṃ dassetu”nti avocāti.
analyzed: dūra iti dūre padese daharassa antarāyam pariharantī na sakkā bhante sakalam kāyam dassetunti avoca ati
translated: Avoiding an obstacle for the young man, he said: “Venerable Sir, it is not possible to show the whole body.”

original: Mahāsamayasuttavaṇṇanāya līnatthappakāsanā.
translated: The explanation of the meaning of the word līna is finished.

original: 8. Sakkapañhasuttavaṇṇanā
analyzed: sakka pañha sutta vaṇṇanā
translated: The explanation of the Sakkapañhasutta is finished.

original: Nidānavaṇṇanā
analyzed: nidāna vaṇṇanā
translated: The explanation of the nidāna is finished.

original: 344. Ambasaṇḍānaṃ adūrabhavattā ekopi so brāhmaṇagāmo “ambasaṇḍā”tveva bahuvacanavasena🔽vuccati, yathā “varaṇā nagara”nti. Vedi eva vediko, vediko eva vediyo ka-kārassa
analyzed: ambasaṇḍānam adūra bhavat tā ekaḥ api saḥ brāhmaṇa gāmaḥ bahuvacana vasena  vuccati yathā varaṇā eva vedikaḥ vedikaḥ eva vediyaḥ kakārassa
translated: Because Ambasaṇḍā is not far from the village, that single brāhmaṇa village is called “Ambasaṇḍā” in the plural,🔽just as “Varaṇā city” is called. A platform is a vedi, a vedi is a vediya.

original: ya-kāraṃ katvā, tasmiṃ vediyake. Tenāha “maṇivedikāsadisenā”tiādi, indanīlādimaṇimayavedikāsadisenāti
analyzed: yakāram katvā tasmin vediyake tena āha maṇi vedikā sadisena atiādi inda nīla ādi maṇi maya vedikā sadisena ati
translated: Having made the k- sound into a y- sound, in that vediya. Therefore he said “like a jewel platform” and so on. The meaning is: like a jewel platform made of sapphires, etc.

original: attho. Pubbepīti leṇakaraṇato pubbe, guhārūpena ṭhitā, dvāre indasālarukkhavatī ca,
analyzed: attho pubbe pi iti leṇa karaṇato pubbe guhā rūpena ṭhitā dvāre indasāla rukkhavatī ca
translated: Previously: before the cave was made, it stood in the form of a cave, and it had a door and Indasāla trees,

original: tasmā “indasālaguhā”ti vuttā purimavohārena.
analyzed: tasmai indasālaguhā ati vuttā purima vohārena
translated: therefore it is called “Indasāla cave” by the old name.

original: Ussukkaṃ vuccati abhiruci, taṃ pana buddhadassanakāmatāvasena, tathā ussāhanavasena
analyzed: ussukkam vuccati abhiruci tam pana buddha dassana kāma tā vasena tathā ussāhana vasena
translated: “Eager” is said to be “keen” . But that is said in the sense of the desire to see the Buddha, and in the sense of the occurrence of eagerness.

original: ca pavattiyā “dhammiko ussāho”ti vuttaṃ. Sakkena sadiso…pe… natthīti. Yathāha “appamādena
analyzed: ca pavattiyā dhammikaḥ ussāhaḥ ti vuttam sakkena natthi iti yathā āha appamādena
translated: “Dhammiko ussāho” is said. Sakka is like … there is not … . As it is said: “By diligence

original: maghavā, devānaṃ seṭṭhataṃ gato”ti. Parittakenāti aparāparaṃ bahuṃ puññakammaṃ akatvā
analyzed: maghavā devānam seṭṭha tam gataḥ iti parittakena ati apara aparam bahum puñña kammam a katvā
translated: Maghavā, gone to the best of the gods” . Parittakena means without doing much meritorious action one after the other,

original: appamattakeneva puññakammena.
analyzed: appamattakena iva puñña kammena
translated: by a small amount of meritorious action.

original: Sakkopi kāmaṃ mahāpuññakatabhīruttāno hoti, sātisayāya pana dibbasampattiyā viyogahetukena
analyzed: sakkaḥ api kāmam mahā puñña kata bhīru uttānaḥ hoti sa atisayāya pana dibba sampattiyā viyoga hetukena
translated: Sakka, indeed, is a great meritorious one, but he is frightened by the separation from the very special divine prosperity,

original: sokena diguṇitena maraṇabhayena saṃtajjito jāto. Tenāha “sakko pana maraṇabhayābhibhūto ahosī”ti.🔽Dibbacakkhunā devatānaṃ dassanaṃ nāma paṭivijjhanasadisanti āha “paṭivijjhī”ti. Pāṭiyekko
analyzed: sokena di guṇitena maraṇa bhayena saṃtajjitaḥ jātaḥ tena āha sakkaḥ pana maraṇa bhaya abhibhūtaḥ ahosi iti  dibba cakkhunā devatānam dassanam nāma paṭivijjhana sadisanti āha paṭivijjhi iti pāṭiyekkaḥ
translated: and by the fear of death, which is twice as much as that . Therefore it is said: “Sakka, however, was overcome by the fear of death” .

original: vohāroti āveṇiko piyasamudāhāro. Marisaniyasampattikāti mārisā. Tesañhi sampattiyo
analyzed: vohāraḥ ti āveṇikaḥ piya samudāhāraḥ marisa niya sampattikā ati mārisā tesam hi sampattiyaḥ
translated: The seeing of the deities by the divine eye is like the penetration . Therefore it is said: “He penetrated” . Pāṭiyekko vohāroti āveṇiko piyasamudāhāro. Marisaniyasampattikāti mārisā. Tesañhi sampattiyo

original: mahānubhāvatāya sahanti upaṭṭhahanti, aññe ayonisomanasikāratāya ceva appahukāya
analyzed: mahā anubhāva tāya sahanti upaṭṭhahanti aññe a yonisomanasikāra tāya ca iva appahukāya
translated: because of their great power they endure and serve them, others because of unwise attention and because of being ill-harnessed,

original: ca na sahantiyeva, sā pana nesaṃ marisaniyasampattikatā dukkhavirahitāyāti vuttaṃ🔽“niddukkhātipi vuttaṃ hotī”ti. Ekako vāti devaparisāya vinā āgatattā vuttaṃ, mātaliādayo
analyzed: ca na sahantiyā iva sā pana nesam marisaniya sampattikatā dukkha virahitāya ati vuttam  niddukkhā iti pi vuttam hoti iti ekakaḥ vā ati deva parisāya vinā āgata ttā vuttam mātali ādayo
translated: because of his greatness they bear it and serve him, but others, because of their lack of right reflection and their lack of service, do not bear it at all. But that is due to their lack of success in dying, and so it is said that it is “free from pain.”

original: pana tādisā sahāyā tadāpi ahesuṃyeva. Tathā hi vakkhati “api cāyaṃ āyasmato cakkanemisaddena🔽tamhā samādhimhā vuṭṭhito”ti. Okāsaṃ nākāsi sakkassa ñāṇaparipākaṃ āgamento, aññesañca
analyzed: pana tādisā sahāyā tadā api ahesuṃ yeva tathā hi vakkhati api ca ayam āyasmataḥ cakkanemi saddena  tamhā samādhimhā vuṭṭhito ti okāsam na akāsi sakkassa ñāṇa paripākam āgamento aññesam ca
translated: “Alone” is said because he came without a divine retinue. But such companions as Mātali and the rest were with him then too. For it is said: “And it was by the sound of the venerable one’s chariot wheel that he emerged from that concentration.”

original: bahūnaṃ devānaṃ dhammābhisamayaṃ upaparikkhamāno. Soti sakko.
analyzed: bahūnam devānam dhamma abhisamayam upaparikkhamāno saḥ ti sakko
translated: He did not make an opportunity for Sakka to come and complete his knowledge, and for many other gods to come and investigate the penetration of the Dhamma.🔽“He” is Sakka.

original: Evanti vacanasampaṭicchane nipātoti āha “evaṃ hotū”tiādi. Bhaddaṃtavāti pana sakkaṃ uddissa nesaṃ āsi vādo.
analyzed: evam ti vacana sampaṭicchane nipāto ti āha evam hotu utiādi bhaddaṃtavā ti pana sakkam uddissa na āsi vādo
translated: “Thus” is a particle expressing assent. Thus he said “Let it be so.” But “Good luck to you” is their blessing to Sakka.

original: 345. Vallabho…pe… dhammaṃ suṇātīti ayamattho govindasuttādīhi dīpetabbo. Iminā katokāseti iminā pañcasikhena katokāse bhagavati.
analyzed: vallabha upe dhammam suṇāti iti ayam atthaḥ govinda sutta ādīhi dīpetabbaḥ iminā kata ukāse iti iminā pañcasikhena kata ukāse bhagavati
translated: The meaning of the expression “he listens to the Dhamma” should be illustrated by the Govinda Sutta and the rest.

original: Anucariyanti anucaraṇabhāvaṃ, taṃ panassa anucaraṇaṃ nāma saddhiṃ gamanamevāti āha “sahacaraṇaṃ ekato gamana”nti.
analyzed: anucariyanti anucaraṇa bhāvam tam panassa anucaraṇam nāma saddhim gamanam eva ati āha sahacaraṇam ekatas gamanan ti
translated: “Attendance”: the state of attending. Since that attendance is called “going along with,” he said, “going along together, going in common.”

original: Sovaṇṇamayanti suvaṇṇamayaṃ. Pokkharanti vīṇāya doṇimāha. Daṇḍoti vīṇadaṇḍo. Veṭhakāti🔽tantīnaṃ bandhanāya ceva uppīḷanāya ca dhametabbā veṭhakā. Pattakanti pokkharaṃ.🔽Samapaññāsamucchanā mucchetvāti yathā samapaññāsamucchanā kamato tattha saṃmucchanaṃ
analyzed: sovaṇṇa mayanti suvaṇṇa mayam pokkharanti vīṇāya doṇim āha daṇḍo ti vīṇa daṇḍaḥ veṭhakā ati  tantīnam bandhanāya ca iva uppīḷanāya ca dhametabbā veṭhakā pattakanti pokkharam  sama paññā samucchanā mucchetvā ati yathā sama paññā samucchanā kamato tattha saṃmucchanam
translated: “Golden”: made of gold. “Lute”: he calls the lute’s body a “lute.” “Stick”: the lute’s stick. “Strings”:🔽the strings for binding and tightening the strings. “Picks”:

original: kātuṃ sakkā, evaṃ taṃ sajjetvāti attho. “Samapaññāsamucchanā saṃmucchetvā”ti ca idaṃ
analyzed: kātum sakkā evam tam sajjetvā ati sama paññā samucchanā saṃmucchetvā iti ca idam
translated: the picks for plucking the strings. “Tuning key”: the tuning key for tuning the strings. “Having tuned it to the right pitch”: having tuned it so that it can be played by tightening the strings to the right pitch. “Having tuned it to the right pitch”

original: devaloke niyataṃ vīṇāvādanavidhiṃ sandhāya vuttaṃ. Manussaloke pana ekavīsati mucchanā.
analyzed: deva loke niyatam vīṇā vādana vidhim sandhāya vuttam manussa loke pana ekavīsati mucchanā
translated: is said with reference to the fixed method of playing the lute in the deva world. But in the human world there are twenty-one tunings.

original: Tenevāha vīṇopamasuttavaṇṇanāyaṃ –
analyzed: tena iva āha vīṇā upama sutta vaṇṇanā ayam
translated: That is why it is said in the commentary to the Vīṇā Sutta:🔽Seven streams, three villages,🔽Twenty-one openings,

original: “Satta sarā tayo gāmā, mucchanā ekavīsati;
analyzed: satta sarā tayaḥ gāmā mucchanā ekavīsati
translated: Fifty-three in all:

original: Tānā cekūnapaññāsa, iccete saramaṇḍalā”ti. ;
analyzed: tānā cekūnapaññāsaḥ icca ete
translated: These are the stream-circles.

original: Tattha chajjo, usabho, gandhāro, majjhimo, pañcamo, dhevato, nisādoti ete satta sarā.🔽Chajjagāmo, majjhimagāmo, sādhāraṇagāmoti tayo gāmā, sarasamūhāti attho. Manussaloke
analyzed: tattha chajjaḥ usabhaḥ gandhāraḥ majjhimaḥ pañcamaḥ dhevataḥ nisādaḥ ti ete satta sarā  chajja gāmaḥ majjhima gāmaḥ sādhāraṇa gāmaḥ ti tayo gāmā sara samūhā ati atthaḥ manussa loke
translated: Herein, the seven streams are the Chajjā, the Usabha, the Gandhāra, the Majjhima, the Pañcama, the Dheva, and the Nisāda.🔽The three villages are the Chajjā village, the Majjhima village, and the common village. The meaning is that they are a collection of streams.

original: vādanavidhinā ekekasseva ca sarassa vasena tayo tayo mucchanā katvā ekavīsati mucchanā.
analyzed: vādana vidhinā ekekassa iva ca sarassa vasena tayo tayo mucchanā katvā ekavīsati mucchanā
translated: In the human world there are twenty-one openings made by taking each stream separately and dividing it into three according to the method of playing the instrument.

analyzed: ekekassa iva ca sarassa satta satta tāna bhedāḥ yatas sarassa mandatara vavatthānam hoti
translated: And there are fifty-three kinds of them, since each stream has seven divisions,🔽beginning with the one of less distinct sound.🔽There are twenty-two kinds of them, namely, three, two, four, four, three, two, four,

analyzed: te ekūnapaññāsa tānavisesā ati tissaḥ duve catasso catasso tissaḥ duve catasso tissaḥ duve catasso ti dvāvīsati 🔽suti bhedāḥ icchitāḥ ayam pana ekekassa sarassa vasena satta satta mucchanāḥ antara sarassa

original: ca ekāti samapaññāsāya mucchanānaṃ yogyabhāvena vīṇaṃ vajjesi. Tena vuttaṃ “samapaññāsa
analyzed: ca eka ati sama paññāsāya muccha nānam yogya bhāvena vīṇam vajjesi tena vuttam sama paññāsa
translated: and he played the lute with the fifty strings tuned in harmony.

original: mucchanā saṃmucchetvā”ti. Sesadeve jānāpento sakkassa gamanakālanti yojanā.
analyzed: mucchanā saṃmucchetvā ati sesa deve jānāpento sakkassa gamana kālanti yojanā
translated: The rest of the gods, in order to make Sakka go, knew that he was playing the lute.

original: 346. Atirivāti ra-kāro padasandhikaro, atīva ativiyāti vuttaṃ hoti. Pakati …pe… agamāsi maraṇabhayasaṃtajjitattā taramānarūpo. Tenevāha “nanu cā”tiādi.
analyzed: atiriva ati rakāro pada sandhi karo atīva ativiya iti vuttam hoti tena iva āha nanu ca atiādi
translated: “Very much”: the letter ra is a connector of words. “Very much” means “exceedingly, greatly.” He went in his natural form, but he went quickly, terrified by the fear of death. Therefore he said, “But didn’t I say to you,” and so on.

original: 347. Buddhā nāma mahākāruṇikā, sadevakassa lokassa hitasukhatthāya eva uppannā, te
analyzed: buddhāḥ nāma mahā kāruṇikā sa devakassa lokassa hita sukha tthāya eva uppannā te
translated: The Buddhas are greatly compassionate. They are born only for the welfare and happiness of the world with its gods.

original: kathaṃ atthikehi durupasaṅkamāti āha “ahaṃ sarāgo”tiādi. Tadantaraṃ paṭisallīnāti
analyzed: katham atthikehi durupasaṅkamā ti āha aham sa rāgā iti ādi tad antaram paṭisallīnā ti
translated: How is it that they are difficult to approach for those who need them? He said, “I am full of passion,” and so on.🔽“In that interval, secluded”:

original: yena antarena yena khaṇena upasaṅkameyya, tadantaraṃ paṭisallīnā jhānaṃ samāpannā.
analyzed: yena antarena yena khaṇena upasaṅkameyya tad antaram paṭisallīnā jhānam samāpannā
translated: in whatever interval, in whatever moment he would approach, in that interval he was secluded, absorbed in jhāna.

original: Tadantara-saddo vā “etarahī”ti iminā samānatthoti āha “sampati paṭisallīnā vā”ti.
analyzed: tad antara saddaḥ vā etarahi iti iminā samāna tthaḥ ti āha sampati paṭisallīnā vā ti
translated: Or the word “tadantara” has the same meaning as “etarahi.” Therefore he said, “now secluded.”

original: Pañcasikhagītagāthāvaṇṇanā
analyzed: pañcasikhagītagāthā vaṇṇanā
translated: The Explanation of the Verses of the Pañcasikha Song

original: 348. Sāvesīti yathādhippetamucchanaṃ paṭṭhapetvā vīṇaṃ vādento taṃtaṃṭhānuppattiyā🔽pākaṭībhūtamandatāvavatthaṃ dassento sumadhurakomalamadhupānamattamadhukāravirutāpahāsinilakkhaṇo
analyzed: sā avesi iti yathā adhippeta mucchanam paṭṭhapetvā vīṇam vādento taṃ taṃṭhāna uppattiyā  pākaṭībhūta manda tā vavattham dassento sumadhura komala madhu pāna matta madhukāra viruta apahāsi nilakkhaṇaḥ
translated: By the sound’s being manifest in the place where it arose, he showed the sound’s faintness.🔽He played the lute with a clear voice, with a sound of strings in harmony,

original: pasannabhānī samaravaṃ tantissaraṃ sāvesi.🔽“Sakyaputtova jhānena, ekodi nipako sato;
analyzed: pasanna bhānī sama ravam tantissaram sāvesi  sakya puttaḥ iva jhānena ekodi nipakaḥ sato
translated: Laughing with the blue note of a bee drunk with honey, as if with a drink of honey sweet and soft and delicious.🔽“The Sakyan’s son, with jhana,🔽One-pointed, mindful, and discreet,

original: Amataṃ muni jigīsāno….
analyzed: amatam muni jigīsānaḥ
translated: The sage who seeks the deathless state,🔽As if the sage would rejoice,

original: Yathāpi muni nandeyya, patvā sambodhiṃ uttama”nti. ;🔽Ca evaṃ buddhūpasañhitā. Buddhūpasañhitā pana buddhānaṃ dhammasarīraṃ ārabbha nissayaṃ
analyzed: yathā api muni patvā sambodhim uttamanti  ca evam buddha upasañhitā buddha upasañhitā pana buddhānam dhamma sarīram ārabbha nissayam
translated: Having attained the supreme enlightenment.”🔽So too, the Buddha is the subject of the verse. But the verse is said to be “about the Dhamma” because it occurs in dependence on the Dhamma body of the Buddhas.

original: katvā pavattitāti āha “dhammo arahatāṃ ivā”ti. Dhammūpasañhitā, arahattūpasañhitā ca veditabbā.
analyzed: katvā pavatti tā ti āha dhammaḥ arahatām iva ati dhamma upasañhitā arahatta upasañhitā ca veditabbā
translated: It is said to be “about the arahants” because it occurs in dependence on the arahants.

original: Sūriyasamānasarīrāti sūriyasamānappabhāsarīrā. Tenāha “tassā kirā”tiādi. Yasmā timbaruno
analyzed: sūriya samāna sarīrā ti sūriya samāna ppabhā sarīrā tena āha tassā kirāti ādi yasmā
translated: “With a body like the sun”: with a body like the sun in radiance. Hence he said “It is said that…” .🔽Since Timbaru

original: gandhabbadevarājassa sūriyavaccha sā aṅke jātā, tasmā āha “yaṃ timbaruṃ devarājānaṃ
analyzed: gandhabba devarājassa sūriya vaccha sā aṅke jātā tasmai āha yam timbarum devarājānam
translated: was born on the lap of the gandhabba king Suriya, he said “the timbaru tree deity king Suriya…” .

original: nissāya tvaṃ jātā”ti. Kalyāṇaṅgatāya “kalyāṇī”ti vuttāti āha “sabbaṅgasobhanā”ti.
analyzed: nissāya tvam jātā ati kalyāṇaṅgatāya kalyāṇī iti vuttā ati āha sabbaṅga sobhanā ti
translated: “You were born depending on her.” She was called “Kalyani” because of her all-round beauty.

original: Rāgāvesavasena pubbe vuttā gāthā idānipi tameva ārabbha purato ṭhitaṃ viya ālapanto vadati.
analyzed: rāga āvesa vasena pubbe vuttā gāthā idāni api tam eva ārabbha puratas ṭhitam viya ālapantaḥ vadati
translated: The verse spoken earlier by the king out of his infatuation for her is now repeated by the queen as if it were standing in front of her.

original: Thanudaranti payodharañca udarañca adhippetanti āha “thanavemajjhaṃ udarañcā”ti.
analyzed: thanudaranti payodharan ca udaran ca adhippetanti āha thana vemajjham udaran ca ati
translated: “Her breasts and belly”: her breasts and belly are meant.

original: Kiñci kāraṇanti kiñci pīḷaṃ.
analyzed: kiñci
translated: “Some reason”: some affliction.

original: Pakatiṃ jahitvā ṭhitaṃ abhirattabhāvena.
analyzed: pakatim jahitvā ṭhitam abhiratta bhāvena
translated: “Having abandoned her natural state”: having abandoned her natural state of mind.

original: Vāmūrūti ruciraūrū. Tenāha “vāmākārenā”tiādi. Vāmavikasitarucirasundarābhirūpacārusaddā
analyzed: rucira ūrū tena āha vāma ākārena ati ādi vāma vikasita rucira sundara abhirūpa cāru saddā
translated: “Her thighs”: her beautiful thighs. Hence he said “with a graceful gait,” etc. “Graceful,” “beautiful,” “lovely,” and “charming” are to be understood in the same sense.

original: hi ekatthā daṭṭhabbā. Na tikhiṇanti na tikkhaṃ na lūkhaṃ na kakkhaḷaṃ. Mandanti mudu siniddhaṃ.
analyzed: hi ekatthā daṭṭhabbā na tikhiṇanti na tikkham na lūkham na kakkhaḷam mandanti mudu siniddham
translated: “Not sharp”: not sharp, not rough, not harsh. “Gentle”: soft, smooth.

original: Anekabhāvoti anekasabhāvo, so pana bahuvidho nāma hotīti āha “anekavidho jāto”ti. Anekabhāgoti anekakoṭṭhāso.
analyzed: aneka bhāvo ti aneka sabhāvo saḥ pana bahuvidhaḥ nāma hoti iti āha anekavidhaḥ jātaḥ iti aneka bhāgaḥ ti aneka koṭṭhāso
translated: “Many-sided”: of many kinds. Hence he said “of many kinds.” “Many-faceted”: having many parts.

original: Tayā saddhiṃ vipaccatanti tayā sahitaṃyeva me taṃ kammaṃ vipaccatu, tayā saheva tassa
analyzed: tayā saddhim vipaccatanti tayā sahitaṃya iva me tam kammam vipaccatu tayā saha iva tassa
translated: ‘May it ripen with you’: may that kamma of mine ripen with you alone, may I experience the fruit of that kamma with you alone. The meaning is: ‘May it ripen with me and you alone.’

original: kammassa phalaṃ anubhaveyyanti adhippāyo. Tayā saddhimevāti yathā cakkavattisaṃvattaniyakammaṃ
analyzed: kammassa phalam anubhaveyyanti adhippāyaḥ tayā saddhim evā ti yathā cakkavatti saṃvattaniya kammam
translated: ‘Just as’: just as kamma that leads to becoming a Wheel-turning Monarch

original: tassa nissandaphalabhūtena itthiratanena saddhiṃyeva vipākaṃ deti, evaṃ taṃ me kammaṃ
analyzed: tassa nissanda phala bhūtena itthi ratanena saddhiṃyā iva vipākam deti evam tam me kammaṃ
translated: gives its fruit of kamma as a by-product in the form of a woman treasure, so may that kamma of mine

original: tayā saddhiṃyeva mayhaṃ vipākaṃ detu.
analyzed: tayā saddhiṃyā iva mayham vipākam detu
translated: give its fruit with you alone.

original: Ekodīti ekodibhāvaṃ gato, samāhitoti attho. Jigīsānoti jigīsamāno hoti. Tathābhūtova
analyzed: ekodī iti ekodi bhāvam gato samāhito ti attho jigīsāno ti jigīsamāno hoti tathābhūtaḥ uva
translated: ‘One-pointed’: gone to one-pointedness, concentrated, is the meaning. ‘Seeking’: seeking to win. One who is such

original: jigīsati nāmāti tathā paṭhamavikappo vutto. Dutiyavikappe pana “vicaratī”ti kiriyāpadaṃ
analyzed: jigīsati nāma ati tathā paṭhama vikappaḥ vuttaḥ dutiya vikappe pana vicarati iti kiriyā padam
translated: is called ‘seeking to win.’ Thus the first analysis is given. But in the second analysis the verb ‘wanders’

original: āharitvā attho vutto.🔽Nandeyyanti samāgamaṃ patthento vadati atisassirikarūpasobhāya.
analyzed: āharitvā atthaḥ vuttaḥ  nandeyya nti samāgamam patthentaḥ vadati ati sassirika rūpa sobhāya
translated: is brought in and the meaning is stated.🔽‘Would rejoice’: he speaks thus longing for union, because of the extreme beauty of her appearance.

original: 349. Saṃsandatīti sameti, yāya mucchanāya, yena ca ākārena tantissaro pavatto, taṃ
analyzed: saṃsandati iti sameti yāya mucchanāya yena ca ākārena tantissaraḥ pavatto tam
translated: ‘Comes together’: meets, in the way and manner in which the sound of the lute arose.

original: mucchanaṃ anativattento, teneva ca ākārena gītassaropi pavattoti attho. Yena ajjhāsayena
analyzed: mucchanam tena iva ca ākārena gīta ssaraḥ api pavatto ti atthaḥ yena ajjhāsayena
translated: and he did not avoid the swoon, but the sound of the song arose in that way.

original: bhagavā pañcasikhassa gandhabbe vaṇṇaṃ kathesi, yadatthañca kathesi, taṃ sabbaṃ vibhāvetuṃ
analyzed: bhagavā pañcasikhassa gandhabbe vaṇṇam kathesi yadattham ca kathesi tam sabbam vibhāvetum
translated: The intention with which the Blessed One praised Pañcasikha’s lute-playing, and the reason why he praised it, are all explained🔽by the question “Why?”

original: “kasmā”tiādimāha. Natthi bodhimūle eva samucchinnattā. Upekkhako bhagavā anupalittabhāvato.🔽Suvimuttacitto bhagavā chandarāgato, sabbasmā ca kilesā. Yadi evaṃ kasmā pañcasikhassa
analyzed: kasmā iti ādim āha natthi bodhi mūle eva samucchinna ttā upekkhakaḥ bhagavā an upalitta bhāvataḥ  su vimutta cittaḥ bhagavā chanda rāgato sabbasmā ca kilesāḥ yadi evam kasmā pañcasikhassa
translated: The Blessed One is impartial because he has cut off all attachment to self and others, and he is equanimous because he is free from resentment.🔽The Blessed One is well liberated in mind because he is free from desire and lust, and he is well liberated in wisdom because he is free from all defilements.

original: gandhabbe vaṇṇaṃ kathesīti āha “sace panā”tiādi.
analyzed: gandhabbe vaṇṇam kathesi iti āha sace pana atiādi
translated: If that is so, why did the Blessed One praise Pañcasikha’s lute-playing?🔽The Blessed One said, “If, bhikkhus, Pañcasikha were to die at this time and reappear in the next world, he would reappear right there in the brahma world.”🔽“Bound together” means fastened together. But they are spoken of as “heaped up” because they are spoken of without interval.

original: Ganthitāti sandahitā, tā pana nirantaraṃ kathiyamānā rāsikatā viya hontīti āha “piṇḍitā”ti. Vohāravacananti bhagavato, bhikkhūnañca purato vattabbaṃ upacāravacanaṃ.
analyzed: ganthitā ati sandahitā tāḥ pana nirantaram kathiyamānāḥ rāsikatāḥ viya honti iti āha piṇḍitā iti vohāra vacanan ti bhagavataḥ bhikkhūnam ca puratas vattabbam upacāra vacanam
translated: “Conversational expression” is the conventional expression that should be spoken in the presence of the Blessed One and the bhikkhus.

original: Upanaccantiyāti upagantvā naccantiyā.🔽Sakkūpasaṅkamanavaṇṇanā
analyzed: upanaccantiyā ati upagantvā naccantiyā 🔽sakkūpa saṅkamana vaṇṇanā
translated: “Dancing” means dancing after approaching.

original: 350. “Kadā saṃyūḷhā”tiādīni vadanto paṭisammodati. Vippakārampi dasseyyāti aḍḍhakatābhinayavasena naccampi dasseyya.
analyzed: kadā saṃyūḍha ati ādīni vadanto paṭisammodati vippakāram pi dasseyya ati aḍḍhaka tā abhinaya vasena naccam pi dasseyya
translated: “When were they composed?” etc., he is greeting him. He might show off his skill: he might show off his dancing by a half-performance.

original: 351. “Abhivadito sakko devānamindo”tiādīnaṃ “tena kho pana samayenā”tiādīnaṃ viya
analyzed: abhivaditaḥ sakkaḥ devānam indo ti ādīnam tena kho pana samayena ati ādīnam viya
translated: “Sakka, lord of the gods, has been greeted” is not a statement by the compilers, like “Then at that time” .

original: saṅgītikāravacanabhāve saṃsayo natthi, “evañca pana tathāgatā”ti idha pana siyā saṃsayoti
analyzed: saṅgīti kāravacana bhāve saṃsayaḥ natthi evam ca pana tathāgatā ati idha pana siyā saṃsayo ti
translated: But there might be a doubt here about “So too the Perfect Ones” .

original: “dhammasaṅgāhakattherehi ṭhapitavacana”nti vatvā itarassāpi tathābhāvaṃ dassetuṃ🔽“sabbameta”ntiādi vuttaṃ. Vuḍḍhivacanena vuttoti “sukhī hotu pañcasikha sakko devānaṃ
analyzed: dhammasaṅgāhaka therehi ṭhapita vacanan ti vatvā itarassa api tathābhāvam dassetum  sabbam etat tiādi vuttam vuḍḍhi vacanena vuttaḥ iti sukhī hotu pañcasikha sakkaḥ devānam
translated: So after saying “The words are those of the compilers of the Dhamma and the Vinaya”, he shows that the other is also like that,

original: indo”ti āsīsavādaṃ vutto. “Bhagavato pāde sirasā vandatī”ti vadanto abhivādeti nāma
analyzed: indo ti āsīsavādam vuttaḥ bhagavataḥ pāde sirasā vandati iti vadantaḥ abhivāda iti nāma
translated: saying “All this” . He is said to “speak a speech of blessing” when he says “May Sakka, lord of the gods, be happy, Pancasikha” . He is said to “greet” when he says “He pays homage with his head at the Blessed One’s feet” .

original: “sukhī hotū”ti āsīsavādassa vadāpanato. Tathā pana āsīsavādaṃ vadanto abhivadati
analyzed: sukhī hotu uti āsīsa vādassa vadāpanataḥ tathā pana āsīsa vādam vadantaḥ abhivadati
translated: Because he has spoken a speech of blessing with “May he be happy.” But he is said to “greet”

original: nāma sabbakālaṃ tatheva tiṭṭhanato.
analyzed: nāma sabbakālam tathā iva tiṭṭhanataḥ
translated: because he has spoken a speech of blessing and because he remains standing in that way all the time.

original: Uruṃ vepullaṃ dassati dakkhatīti urundā vibhattialopena. Vivaṭā aṅgaṇaṭṭhānaṃ. Yo
analyzed: urum vepullam dassati dakkhati iti urundā vibhatti a lopena vivaṭā aṅgaṇa ṭhānam
translated: “He will show the light, he will see the light” is uru-ndā, the uru being elided. The courtyard was opened up.🔽The darkness that was in the cave,

original: pakatiyā guhāyaṃ andhakāro, so antarahitoti yo tassaṃ guhāyaṃ satthu samantato asītihatthato
analyzed: pakatiyā guhā ayam andhakāro saḥ antarahitaḥ iti yaḥ tassam guhā ayam satthu samantataḥ asīti hatthataḥ
translated: which was eighty cubits all around the Teacher,

original: ayaṃ pākatiko andhakāro, so devānaṃ vatthābharaṇasarīrobhāsehi antarahito, āloko
analyzed: ayam pākatikaḥ andhakāro saḥ devānam vattha ābharaṇa sarīra ubhāsehi antarahitaḥ āloko
translated: was dispelled by the light of the garments, ornaments, and bodies of the gods. The light

original: sampajji. Asītihatthe pana buddhālokeneva andhakāro antarahito, na ca samattho devānaṃ
analyzed: sampajji asīti hatthe pana buddha ālokena iva andhakāraḥ antarahitaḥ na ca samatthaḥ devānam
translated: spread. But the darkness in the eighty cubits was dispelled only by the Buddha’s light, and the gods’

original: obhāso buddhānaṃ abhibhavituṃ.
analyzed: obhāsaḥ buddhānam abhibhavitum
translated: light was unable to overpower the Buddha’s light.

original: 352. Cirappaṭikāhanti cirappabhutiko ahaṃ. Aḍḍakaraṇaṃ nāma natthi avivādādhikaraṇaṭṭhāne nibbattattā. Kīḷādīnipīti ādi-saddena dhammassavanādiṃ saṅgaṇhāti.
analyzed: cirappaṭikāhanti cirappabhutikaḥ aham aḍḍakaraṇam nāma natthi avivāda adhikaraṇa ṭhāne nibbatta ttā kīḷa ādīni pi iti ādi saddena dhamma ssavana ādim saṅgaṇhāti
translated: “I have waited a long time” means “I have waited a long time.” There is no such thing as a “formal act of reconciliation,” because it arises in a place where there is no legal issue. “Play, etc.”: the word “etc.” includes listening to the Dhamma, and so on.

original: Salaḷamayagandhakuṭiyanti salaḷarukkhehi raññā pasenadinā kāritagandhakuṭiyaṃ. Tenassāti
analyzed: salaḷa maya gandhakuṭiyanti salaḷa rukkhehi raññā pasenadinā kārita gandhakuṭiyam tena assa ati
translated: “A fragrant chamber made of salaḷ wood”: a fragrant chamber built by King Pasenadi with salaḷ trees. “Because of that”:

original: tena phaladvayādhigamena pahīnaoḷārikakāmarāgatāya assā bhūjatiyā devaloke abhiratiyeva🔽natthi. Cakkanemisaddena tamhā samādhimhā vuṭṭhitoti ettha adhippāyaṃ ajānantā “ārammaṇassa🔽adhimattatāya samāpattito vuṭṭhānaṃ jāta”nti maññeyyunti taṃ paṭikkhipanto “samāpanno
analyzed: tena phala dvaya adhigamena pahīna oḷārika kāma rāga tāya assā deva loke  natthi cakkanemi saddena tamhā samādhimhā vuṭṭhitaḥ ti ettha adhippāyam a jānantāḥ ārammaṇassa  adhimatta tāya samāpattitaḥ vuṭṭhānam jātanti maññeyyunti tam paṭikkhipanto samāpanno
translated: Since she had attained the two fruits, and since she had abandoned sensual desire in its grosser forms, she had no delight in the heavenly world.🔽When he arose from that concentration by the sound of the chariot-wheels, some people, not knowing the intention, might think that he arose from concentration because the object had become excessive.🔽To forestall this, he said: “It is not right to say that he who has entered upon the jhāna hears the sound.”

original: saddaṃ suṇātīti no vata re vattabbe”ti āha. Sati ca ārammaṇasaṅghaṭṭanāyaṃ gahaṇenapi🔽bhavitabbanti adhippāyena “suṇātī”ti vuttaṃ, itaro “paṭhamaṃ jhānaṃ samāpannassa
analyzed: saddam suṇāti iti no vata re vattabbā iti āha sati ca ārammaṇa saṅghaṭṭana ayam gahaṇena api  bhavitabbanti adhippāyena suṇāti iti vuttam itaraḥ paṭhamam jhānam samāpannassa
translated: The intention is this: “He hears” is said because there is the apprehension of the impact of the object.

original: saddo kaṇṭako”ti vacanamattaṃ nissāya sabbassāpi jhānassa saddo kaṇṭakoti adhippāyena
analyzed: saddo kaṇṭako ti vacana mattam nissāya sabbassa api jhānassa saddo kaṇṭako ti adhippāyena
translated: But the other, taking the mere statement “Sound is an obstruction to one who has entered upon the first jhāna” as his reason, and intending that sound is an obstruction to all jhāna,

original: paṭikkhepaṃ asahanto “nanu bhagavā…pe… bhaṇatī”ti imameva suttapadaṃ uddhari. Tattha
analyzed: paṭikkhepam asahantaḥ nanu bhagavā āpe bhaṇati iti imam eva sutta padam tattha
translated: cannot accept the refutation and so quotes the sutta passage, “Does not the Exalted One say …?” Here

original: yathā dosadassanapaṭipakkhabhāvanāvasena paṭighasaññānaṃ suppahīnattā mahatāpi saddena
analyzed: yathā dosa dassana paṭipakkha bhāvanā vasena paṭigha saññānam su pahīna ttā mahatā api saddena
translated: just as, because of the development of the opposite of the seeing of hate, the perception of annoyance is well suppressed, and even by a great sound

original: arūpasamāpattito na vuṭṭhānaṃ, evaṃ “uppādo bhayaṃ, anuppādo khema”ntiādinā sammadeva
analyzed: arūpa samāpattitaḥ na vuṭṭhānam evam uppādaḥ bhayam anuppādaḥ khemanti ādinā sammat eva
translated: and the emergence from the formless attainments.🔽🔽Thus, “Arising is terror, non-arising is safety” , etc.

original: dosadassanapaṭipakkhabhāvanāvasena sabbāsampi lokiyasaññānaṃ aggamaggena samatikkantattā🔽ārammaṇādhigamatāya na kadāci phalasamāpattito vuṭṭhānaṃ hotīti. Tathā pana na suppahīnattā
analyzed: dosa dassana paṭipakkha bhāvanā vasena sabbāsam pi lokiya saññānam aggamaggena samatikkanta ttā  ārammaṇa adhigama tāya na kadāci phala samāpattitaḥ vuṭṭhānam hoti iti tathā pana na suppahīna ttā
translated: He does not emerge from the immaterial jhānas. So it is by seeing danger in arising and by developing the opposite of it, namely, non-arising, that he emerges from all mundane perceptions by the most excellent escape,

original: paṭighasaññānaṃ sabbarūpasamāpattito vuṭṭhānaṃ hoti, paṭhamajjhānaṃ pana appakampi🔽saddaṃ na sahatīti taṃsamāpannassa “saddo kaṇṭako”ti vuttaṃ. Yadi pana paṭighasaññānaṃ
analyzed: paṭigha saññānam sabba rūpa samāpattitaḥ vuṭṭhānam hoti paṭhama jhānam pana appakampi  saddam na sahati iti tad samāpannassa saddo kaṇṭako ti vuttam yadi pana paṭigha saññānam
translated: and he does not emerge from the fruition attainment because of the attainment of the object. But he emerges from all the fine-material jhānas because the perceptions of resistance have not been completely abandoned. But the first jhāna cannot endure the sound that is slight,

original: vikkhambhitattā mahatāpi saddena arūpasamāpattito na vuṭṭhānaṃ hoti, pageva maggaphalasamāpattito.
analyzed: vikkhambhita ttā mahatā api saddena arūpa samāpattitaḥ na vuṭṭhānam hoti pageva magga phala samāpattitaḥ
translated: so it is said of him who has entered upon it, “Sound is its danger” . But if he does not emerge from the immaterial jhānas even when there is a great sound because the perceptions of resistance have been completely suppressed, how much less will he emerge from the path and fruition attainments.

original: Tenāha “cakkanemisaddenā”tiādi. Cakkanemisaddenāti ca nayidaṃ karaṇavacanaṃ hetumhi,
analyzed: tena āha cakka nemi saddena atiādi cakka nemi saddena ati ca na idam karaṇa vacanam hetumhi
translated: That is why it is said, “By the sound of the chariot wheel” , etc. The words “By the sound of the chariot wheel” are not a locative of instrument;

original: karaṇe vā atha kho sahayoge. Imameva hi atthaṃ dassetuṃ “bhagavā panā”tiādi vuttaṃ.
analyzed: karaṇe vā atha kho saha yoge imam eva hi attham dassetum bhagavā pana atiādi vuttam
translated: or in the sense of the instrument, namely, the combination. In order to show this very meaning, the passage beginning “But the Blessed One” is stated.

original: Gopakavatthuvaṇṇanā🔽353. Paripūrakārinīti paripuṇṇāni, parisuddhāni ca katvā rakkhitavatī. “Itthitta”ntiādi🔽tattha virajjanākāradassanaṃ. Dhitthibhāvaṃitthibhāvassa dhikkāro hetūti attho. Alanti
analyzed: gopaka vatthu vaṇṇanā  paripūra kārinī iti paripuṇṇāni parisuddhāni ca katvā rakkhitavatī itthittanti ādi  tattha virajjana ākāra dassanam dhitthi bhāva itthi bhāvassa dhikkāraḥ hetu iti atthaḥ
translated: The explanation of the Gopaka-Moggallāna story

original: paṭikkhepavacanaṃ, payojanaṃ natthīti attho. Virājetīti jigucchati. Etā sampattiyoti
analyzed: paṭikkhepa vacanam payojanam na atthi iti atthaḥ virājeti iti jigucchati etā sampattiyo ti
translated: “She acted in a way that was fulfilling”: she protected them by making them complete and pure. “Itthitta” is the state of being a woman. The state of being a woman is the reason for the exclamation “Itthitta!” The exclamation is a sign of her disgust. “Alan” is a word of rejection; the meaning is that there is no purpose in it. “She was disgusted” means she was disgusted with it. “These perfections”

original: cakkavattisiriādikā etā yathāvuttasampattiyo. Tasmā pubbaparicayena upaṭṭhitanikantivasena.
analyzed: cakkavatti siri ādikāḥ etāḥ yathā vutta sampattiyaḥ tasmā pubba paricayena upaṭṭhita nikanti vasena
translated: are these perfections described above, such as the glory of a wheel-turning monarch. Therefore, by the force of her previous practice, she was inclined to attend upon the Buddha.

original: Upaṭṭhānasālanti sudhammadevasabhaṃ.
analyzed: sudhammadeva sabham
translated: “The place of attendance” is the Sudhamma Assembly Hall.

original: Soti gopakadevaputto. Vaṭṭetvā vaṭṭetvāti tomarādiṃ vattentena viya codanavacanaṃ parivaṭṭetvā parivaṭṭetvā. Gāḷhaṃ vijjhitabbāti gāḷhataraṃ ghaṭṭetabbā.
analyzed: saḥ ti gopaka deva puttaḥ vaṭṭetvā vaṭṭetvā ati tomara ādim vattentena viya codana vacanam parivaṭṭetvā parivaṭṭetvā gāḷham vijjhitabbā ati gāḷhataram ghaṭṭetabbā
translated: “He” is the god Gopaka. “Again and again” means that he turned the words of admonition around and around, as if he were spinning a spear. “He should be struck hard” means he should be struck even harder.

original: Kuto mukhāti kuto pavattañāṇamukhā. Tenāha “aññavihitakā”ti. Katapuññeti sammā katapuññe dhamme.
analyzed: kutas mukhā ati kutas pavatta ñāṇa mukhā tena āha añña vihitakā ati kata puññā iti sammā kata puññe dhamme
translated: “From where is the face?”: from where does the face of the knowledge that has arisen come? Therefore it is said: “from the other side.” “One who has made merit”: one who has made right merit.

original: Dāyoti lābho. So hi dīyati tehi dātabbattā dāyo, yesaṃ dīyati, tehi laddhattā lābhoti
analyzed: dāyo ti lābho saḥ hi dīyati tehi dātabba ttā dāyaḥ yesam dīyati tehi laddha ttā lābho ti
translated: “Gift”: gain. For that is a gift because it is given by them, and it is gain because it is obtained by them.

original: ca vuccati. Saṅkhāre…pe… patiṭṭhahiṃsu katādhikārattā. Tattha tāvatiṃsabhavane ṭhitānaṃyeva
analyzed: ca vuccati tattha tāvatiṃsa bhavane
translated: They were established in the world of the Thirty-three, not in the world of the gods of the Four Great Kings, because they had not done the requisite deeds.

original: nibbatto yathā sakkassa indasālaguhāyaṃ ṭhitasseva sakkattabhāvo.
analyzed: nibbattaḥ yathā sakkassa indasāla guhāyam ṭhitassa iva sakkatta bhāvaḥ
translated: Just as Sakka’s state as Sakka arose while he was standing in the Indasāla cave.

original: Nikantiṃ tasmiṃ gandhabbakāye ālayaṃ samucchindituṃ na sakkonto.
analyzed: nikantim tasmin gandhabba kāye ālayam samucchinditum na sakkontaḥ
translated: unable to cut off attachment to that gandhabba existence.

original: 354. Attanāva veditabboti attanāva adhigantvā veditabbo, na parappaccayikena. Tumhehi vuccamānānīti kevalaṃ tumhehi vuccamānāni.
analyzed: attanā va veditabbo ti attanā va adhigantvā veditabbo na parappaccayikena tumhehi vuccamānāni iti kevalam tumhehi vuccamānāni
translated: “To be known by oneself”: to be known by oneself, by attaining it, not by depending on another. “What is being said by you”: what is being said only by you.

original: Viyāyāmāti vissaṭṭhaṃ vīriyaṃ santāne pavattema. Pakatiyāti rūpāvacarabhāvena, “anussara”nti vā pāṭho.
analyzed: viyāyāma ati vissaṭṭham vīriyam santāne pavattema pakatiyā iti rūpāvacara bhāvena anussaranti vā
translated: “To strive”: to cause to occur in the continuum the effort that is separate. “By nature”: by the nature of the fine-material sphere. The reading is also “to recollect.”

original: Kāmarāgo eva “chando rāgo chandarāgo”tiādi pavattibhedena saṃyojanaṭṭhena “kāmarāgasaṃyojanānī”ti,
analyzed: kāma rāgaḥ eva chandaḥ rāgaḥ chanda rāgaḥ utiādi pavatti bhedena saṃyojana ṭṭhena kāma rāga saṃyojanāni iti
translated: Lust for sense desires is called “desire and lust” in the various ways of describing it. It is called “the fetter of lust for sense desires” in the sense of fettering.

original: yogaganthādipavattiākārabhedena “kāmabandhanānī”ti ca vutto. Pāpimayogānīti ettha
analyzed: yoga gantha ādi pavatti ākāra bhedena kāma bandhanāni iti ca vuttaḥ ettha
translated: It is called “the bond of lust for sense desires” in the sense of the various ways of describing the occurrence of the bond of lust.

original: pana sesayogaganthānampi vasena attho veditabbo.
analyzed: pana sesa yogaganthānam pi vasena atthaḥ veditabbo
translated: The meaning should be understood here in terms of the other bonds and fetters.

original: Duvidhānanti vatthukāmakilesakāmavasena duvidhānaṃ.
analyzed: duvidhānanti vatthu kāma kilesa kāma vasena duvidhānan
translated: Of two kinds: of two kinds as sense desires as object and sense desires as defilement.

original: “Ettha kiṃ, tattha ki”nti ca padadvaye kinti nipātamattaṃ. Cātuddisabhāveti tesaṃ🔽buddhādīnaṃ tiṇṇaṃ ratanānaṃ catuddisayogyabhāve appaṭihaṭabhāve. Buddharatanañhi🔽mahākāruṇikatāya, anāvaraṇañāṇatāya, paramasantuṭṭhatāya ca cātuddisaṃ, dhammaratanaṃ
analyzed: ettha kim tattha kinti ca pada dvaye kinti nipāta mattam tesam  buddha ādīnam tiṇṇam ratanānam catuddisa yogya bhāve appaṭihaṭa bhāve  mahā kāruṇika tāya anāvaraṇa ñāṇa tāya parama santuṭṭha tāya ca cātuddisam dhamma ratanam
translated: “Here what? There what?” are mere particles.🔽Of the four quarters: of the four quarters of the Buddha and the rest.

original: svākkhātatāya, saṅgharatanaṃ suppaṭipannatāya. Tenāha “sabbadisāsu asajjamāno”ti.
analyzed: su ākkhāta tāya saṅgha ratanam su paṭipanna tāya tena āha sabba disāsu a sajjamānaḥ iti
translated: The Buddha Jewel is of the four quarters because of his great compassion, his unobstructed knowledge, and his supreme contentment. The Dhamma Jewel is of the four quarters because of its well-expoundedness. The Sangha Jewel is of the four quarters because of its good practice. Therefore it is said: “Not clinging to any quarter” .

original: Majjhimassa paṭhamajjhānassa adhigatattā tāvadeva kāyaṃ brahmapurohitaṃ adhigantvā
analyzed: majjhimassa paṭhama jhānassa adhigata ttā tāvat eva kāyam brahma purohitam adhigantvā
translated: Having attained the first jhāna of the middle, he attained the body of the Brahmapurohita gods.

original: tāvadeva purimaṃ jhānasatiṃ paṭilabhitvā taṃ jhānaṃ pādakaṃ katvā vipassanaṃ vaḍḍhetvā
analyzed: tāvat eva purimam jhāna satim paṭilabhitvā tam jhānam pādakam katvā vipassanam vaḍḍhetvā
translated: and they attained the former jhāna mindfulness. Making that jhāna the footing, they increased insight,

original: orambhāgiyasaṃyojanasamucchindanena maggaphalavisesaṃ anāgāmiphalasaṅkhātaṃ visesaṃ
analyzed: orambhāgiya saṃyojana samucchindanena magga phala visesam anāgāmi phala saṅkhātam visesam
translated: and by the severing of the fetters of the lower world they reached the distinction of the path and fruition called the non-return fruition.

original: ajjhagaṃsu adhigacchiṃsu. Keci pana “kāmāvacarattabhāvena maggaphalāni adhigacchiṃsūti🔽adhippāyena pañcamassa jhānassa anadhigatattā suddhāvāsesu na uppajjiṃsu, paṭhamajjhānalābhitāya
analyzed: ajjhagaṃsu adhigacchiṃsu keci pana kāmāvacara tad bhāvena magga phalāni adhigacchiṃsu iti  adhippāyena pañcamassa jhānassa anadhigata ttā suddhāvāsesu na uppajjiṃsu paṭhama jhāna lābhi tāya
translated: But some say that they reached the path and fruition in the sense-desire world,

original: pana brahmapurohitesu nibbattiṃsū”ti vadanti.
analyzed: pana brahma purohitesu nibbattiṃsu iti vadanti
translated: and that they did not reappear in the Pure Abodes because they had not yet reached the fifth jhāna, but that they were reborn among the Brahma-underlings because they had reached the first jhāna.

original: Maghamāṇavavatthuvaṇṇanā
translated: The Story of the Youthful Magha

original: 355. Visuddhoti visuddhaajjhāsayo, upanissayasampannoti adhippāyo. Gāmakammakaraṇaṭṭhānanti
analyzed: visuddhaḥ ti visuddha ajjhāsayaḥ upanissaya sampanno ti adhippāyaḥ gāma kamma karaṇa ṭhānanti
translated: “Pure” : his intention is that he had a pure heart, he was possessed of the supporting conditions. “The place where the village work is done” :

original: gāmikānaṃ upaṭṭhānaṭṭhānaṃ vadati. Tāvatakenevāti attanā sodhitaṭṭhāneva aññassa
analyzed: gāmikānam upaṭṭhāna ṭṭhānam vadati tāvatakena iva ati attanā sodhita ṭṭhānā iva aññassa
translated: he says “the place where the villagers’ work is done”. “With just that much” : in the place he had himself cleaned,

original: āgantvā avaṭṭhāneneva. Satiṃ paṭilabhitvāti “aho mayā katakammaṃ saphalaṃ jāta”nti
analyzed: āgantvā avaṭṭhānena iva satim paṭilabhitvā ati aho mayā kata kammam sa phalam jātan ti
translated: by another’s coming and standing there. “He attained mindfulness” : “Oh, the work I have done has borne fruit” .

original: yoniso cittaṃ uppādetvā.
analyzed: yonisaḥ cittam uppādetvā
translated: and he should arouse his mind wisely.

original: Pāsāṇeti maggamajjhe uccatarabhāvena ṭhitapāsāṇe. Uccāletvāti uddharitvā. Etassa saggassa gamanamagganti etassa candādīnaṃ uppattiṭṭhānabhūtassa saggassa gamanamaggaṃ puññakammaṃ.
analyzed: pāsāṇa iti magga majjhe uccatara bhāvena ṭhita pāsāṇe uccāletvā ati uddharitvā etassa saggassa gamana maggam ti etassa canda ādīnam uppatti ṭṭhāna bhūtassa saggassa gamana maggam puñña kammam
translated: A stone: a stone standing high in the middle of the road. He should remove it: he should take it away. The path to heaven: the path to the heaven that is the place of origin of the moon, etc., is the meritorious deed.

original: Sugativasena laddhabbaṃ, kahāpaṇañcāti kahāpaṇaṃ, daṇḍavasena laddhabbaṃ bali daṇḍabali.🔽Gahapatikā kiṃ karissantīti gahapatikā nāma aṭavikā viya visamanissitā, te na kañci🔽anatthaṃ karissanti, evaṃ tayā jānamānena kasmā mayhaṃ na kathitanti yadipi pubbe🔽na kathitaṃ, etarahi pana bhayena kathitaṃ, mā mayhaṃ dosaṃ kareyyātha, ārocitakālato
analyzed: sugati vasena laddhabbam kahāpaṇam ca ati kahāpaṇam daṇḍa vasena laddhabbam bali daṇḍa bali  gahapatikā kim karissanti iti gahapatikā nāma aṭavikā viya visama nissitā te na kañci  anattham karissanti evam tayā jānamānena kasmai mayham na kathitan ti yadi pi pubbe  na kathitam etarahi pana bhayena kathitam mā dosam kareyyātha ārocita kālato
translated: The fine: the fine that should be imposed. The penalty: the penalty that should be imposed.

original: paṭṭhāya na mayhaṃ dosoti vadati.
analyzed: paṭṭhāya na mayham doso ti vadati
translated: What will the householders do? Householders are like forest-dwellers, they are dependent on the uneven. They will not do any harm. If you knew this, why didn’t you tell me? Even though you didn’t tell me before, you are telling me now out of fear. Don’t be angry with me. From the time I was informed, I am not to blame.

original: Nibaddhanti ekantikaṃ.
analyzed: nibaddha nti ekantikam
translated: Constantly: always.

original: Pisuṇesīti pisuṇakammamakāsi, tumhākaṃ antare mayhaṃ pesuññaṃ upasaṃharatīti attho.
analyzed: pisuṇesi iti tumhākam antare mayham pesuññam upasaṃharati iti attho
translated: Slander: he has done slanderous deeds. He is spreading malicious gossip about me among you.

original: Puna aharaṇīyaṃ brahmadeyyaṃ katvā. Mayhampīti mayhampi atthāya maṃ uddissa puññakammaṃ
analyzed: puna a haraṇīyam brahmadeyyam katvā mayham pi iti mayham pi atthāya mam uddissa puñña kammaṃ
translated: And again, “For the sake of my welfare” means “for my sake, for my benefit, do meritorious deeds.”

original: karotha. Nīluppalaṃ nāma vikasamānaṃ udakato uggantvāva vikasati, evaṃ ahutvā antoudake
analyzed: karotha nīluppalam nāma vikasamānam udakataḥ uggantvā ava vikasati evam a hutvā antoudake
translated: The blue lotus opens up by rising out of the water; it does not open up while still under the water.

original: pupphitaṃ nīluppalaṃ viya. Amhākaṃ panidaṃ puññakammaṃ bhavantarūpapattiyā vinā imasmiṃyeva
analyzed: pupphitam nīluppalam viya amhākam pan idam puñña kammam bhavantaru upapattiyā vinā imasmin yeva
translated: But this meritorious deed of ours will give its fruit in this very existence, not in a future existence.🔽“Even if I think” means “even if I am sad.”

original: attabhāve vipākaṃ detīti yojanā. Cintāmattakampīti domanassavasena cintāmattakampi.
analyzed: atta bhāve vipākam deti iti yojanā cintā matta kampi iti domanassa vasena cintā matta kampi
translated: “Early in the morning” means “very early in the morning.”🔽“The bedstead” is suitable for a bedstead. Having cut it and made it smooth, having finished all that is to be done with the bedstead,

original: Pagevāti kālasseva, ativiya pātoti attho. Kaṇṇikūpaganti kaṇṇikayogyaṃ. Tacchetvā maṭṭhaṃ katvā kaṇṇikāya kattabbaṃ sabbaṃ niṭṭhapetvā. Tathā hi sā vatthena veṭhetvā ṭhapitā.
analyzed: pageva iva ti kālassa iva ativiya pāto ti attho kaṇṇikūpaganti kaṇṇika yogyam tat śetvā maṭṭham katvā kaṇṇikāya kattabbam sabbam niṭṭhapetvā tathā hi sā vatthena veṭhetvā ṭhapitā
translated: for it is placed there covered with cloth.

original: Cayabandhanaṃ sālāya adhiṭṭhānasajjanaṃ. Kaṇṇikamañcabandhanaṃ kaṇṇikārohanakāle āruhitvā avaṭṭhānaaṭṭakaraṇaṃ.
analyzed: caya bandhanam sālāya adhiṭṭhāna sajjanam kaṇṇika mañca bandhanam kaṇṇikā ārohana kāle āruhitvā avaṭṭhāna aṭṭa karaṇam
translated: The bedstead is the person who is in charge of the hall. The bedstead-bed is the making of a bed when one has climbed up at the time of climbing up the bedstead.

original: Yassa atthate phalake yassa phalake atthateti yojanā.
analyzed: yassa atthate phalake yassa phalake atthata iti yojanā
translated: The interpretation is: “On which plank it is placed, on which plank it is not placed.”

original: Avidūreti sālāya, koviḷārarukkhassa ca avidūre. Sabbajeṭṭhikāti sabbāsaṃ tassa bhariyānaṃ jeṭṭhikā sujātā.
analyzed: avidūre ti sālāya koviḷāra rukkhassa ca avidūre sabbajeṭṭhikā ti sabbāsam tassa bhariyānam jeṭṭhikā sujātā
translated: Not far from the hall : not far from the Koviḷāra Tree. The chief wife : Sujātā, the chief of all his wives.

original: Tassevāti sakkasseva. Santiketi samīpe santikāvacarā hutvā nibbattā. Dhajena saddhiṃ sahassayojaniko pāsādo.
analyzed: tassa iva ati sakkassa iva santikā iti samīpe santika avacarā hutvā nibbattā dhajena saddhim sahassa yojanikaḥ pāsādaḥ
translated: To him : to the king. They were born : they were reborn in the vicinity of the king. The palace was a thousand leagues in height together with the flagstaff.

original: Kakkaṭakavijjhanasūlasadisanti kakkaṭake gaṇhituṃ tassa bilapariyantassa vijjhanasūcisadisaṃ.
analyzed: kakkaṭaka vijjhana sūla sadisanti kakkaṭake gaṇhitum tassa bila pariyantassa vijjhana sūci sadisam
translated: Like the piercing needle of a kakkaṭaka : like the piercing needle of a kakkaṭaka for catching fish, which has a hole at the end.

original: Maccharūpenāti matamaccharūpena. Osaratīti pilavanto gacchati. Tassāpi bakasakuṇikāya
analyzed: maccha rūpena ati mata maccha rūpena osarati iti pilavantaḥ gacchati tassa api baka sakuṇikāya
translated: With the appearance of a corpse : with the appearance of a dead corpse. It went away : it went away with a limp. The life of the female crane

original: pañca vassasatāni āyu ahosi devanerayikānaṃ viya manussapetatiracchānānaṃ āyuno aparicchinnattā.
analyzed: pañca vassa satāni āyu ahosi deva nerayikānam viya manussa peta tiracchānānam āyunaḥ aparicchinna ttā
translated: was five hundred years. Because the life of human beings, of petas, and of animals is not fixed, as it is in the case of devas and denizens of hell.

original: Ukkuṭṭhimakāsīti uccāsaddamakāsi.
analyzed: ukkuṭṭhi makāsi iti uccāsaddam akāsi
translated: She made a loud noise : she made a loud sound.

original: Pubbasannivāsenāti purimajātīsu cirasannivāsena. Evañhi ekaccānaṃ diṭṭhamattenapi sineho uppajjati. Tenāha bhagavā –
analyzed: pubba sannivāsena āti purima jātīsu cira sannivāsena evam hi ekaccānam diṭṭha mattena api sinehaḥ uppajjati tena āha bhagavā
translated: Because of former association : because of long association in former births. For affection arises in some in this way even through mere sight. Therefore the Blessed One said:🔽“Because of former association,

original: “Pubbeva sannivāsena, paccuppannahitena vā;
analyzed: pubbe iva sannivāsena paccuppanna hitena vā
translated: or because of present good,

original: Evaṃ taṃ jāyate pemaṃ, uppalaṃva yathodake”ti. ;
analyzed: evam tam jāyate uppalam va yathā udaka iti
translated: So love is born in him, As lotus in the water’s rim” .

original: Avasesesūti asure, sakkaṃ ṭhapetvā dvīsu devalokesu deveva sandhāya vadati.
analyzed: avasesesu iti asure sakkam ṭhapetvā dvīsu deva lokesu devā iva sandhāya vadati
translated: “In the rest” : in the two divine worlds, except for the devas of the Thirty-three.

original: Atthanissitanti attano, paresañca atthameva hitameva nissitaṃ, taṃ pana hitaṃ sukhassa nidānanti āha “kāraṇanissita”nti.
analyzed: attha nissitanti attanaḥ paresam ca attham eva hitam eva nissitam tam pana hitam sukhassa nidānanti āha kāraṇa nissitanti
translated: “In what is good” : in what is good for oneself and others, in what is beneficial. But that benefit is the source of happiness, so he says “in the cause.”

original: Pañhaveyyākaraṇavaṇṇanā
analyzed: pañha veyyākaraṇa vaṇṇanā
translated: The explanation of the question and answer

original: 357. Kiṃsaṃyojanāti kīdisasaṃyojanā. Satte anatthe saṃyojenti bandhantīti saṃyojanānīti🔽āha “kiṃbandhanā, kena bandhanena baddhā”ti. Puthukāyāti bahū sattakāyāti āha “bahū
analyzed: kiṃsaṃyojanā ati kīdisa saṃyojanā satte anatthe saṃyojenti bandhanti iti saṃyojanāni iti  āha kiṃbandhanā kena bandhanena baddhā ati puthukāya ati bahū sattakāya iti āha bahū
translated: “What fetter?” : what kind of fetter? They fetter beings to misfortune, they bind them, thus they are fetters.

original: janā”ti. Veraṃ vuccati dosoti āha “averāti appaṭighā”ti. Āvudhena sarīre daṇḍo āvudhadaṇḍo,
analyzed: janāti veram vuccati doso ti āha averā ati appaṭighā ati āvudhena sarīre daṇḍaḥ āvudha daṇḍaḥ
translated: He says “What bond?” : by what bond are they bound? “Many bodies” : many groups of beings. He says “many people” . “Enmity” is hate. He says “non-enmity” : non-resistance. “Weapon-bond” : a weapon is a blow with a sword, etc., on the body.

original: dhanassa dāpanatthena daṇḍo dhanadaṇḍo, tadubhayākaraṇena tato vinimutto adaṇḍo,
analyzed: dhanassa dāpana atthena daṇḍaḥ dhanadaṇḍo tad ubhaya akaraṇena tatas vinimuttaḥ adaṇḍo
translated: “Wealth-bond” : a fine is a penalty for the purpose of making one give up one’s wealth. “Free from bond” : free from both of those.

original: sampattiharaṇato, saha anatthuppattito ca sapatto, paṭisattūti āha “asapattāti apaccatthikā”ti.
analyzed: sampatti haraṇato saha anattha uppattito ca sapattaḥ paṭisattu iti āha a sapattā ati a paccatthikā ti
translated: He is an enemy because he takes away what is good and brings about what is not good.🔽Byāpajjhaṃ is mental suffering. They are free from that, thus they are abyāpajjhaṃ.

original: Byāpajjhaṃ vuccati cittadukkhaṃ, tabbirahitā abyāpajjhāti āha “vigatadomanassā”ti.🔽Pubbe “averā”ti padena sambaddhāghātakābhāvo vutto. Tenāha “appaṭighā”ti. “Averino”ti🔽pana imināpi kopamattassapi anuppādanaṃ. Tenāha “katthaci kopaṃ na uppādetvā”ti.🔽“Viharemū”ti ca padaṃ purimapadehipi yojetabbaṃ “averā viharemū”tiādinā. Ayañca averādibhāvo
analyzed: byāpajjham vuccati citta dukkham tad virahitā abyāpajjhā ti āha vigata domanassā ati  pubbe averā ti padena sambaddha āghātaka abhāvaḥ vuttaḥ tena āha appaṭighā ati averino ti  pana iminā api kopa mattassa api anuppādanam tena āha katthaci kopam na uppādetvā iti  viharemu iti ca padam averāḥ viharemu iti ādinā ayam ca avera ādi bhāvaḥ
translated: In the first verse the absence of ill will is stated by the word averā. Therefore he says “appaṭighā” .🔽But by the word averino the non-arising of mere anger is also stated. Therefore he says “without arousing anger anywhere” .

original: saṃvibhāgena pākaṭo hotīti dassetuṃ “accharāyā”ti ādiṃ vatvā “iti ce nesaṃ hotī”ti🔽vuttaṃ. Cittuppatti daḷhatarāpi hutvā pavattatīti dassetuṃ “dānaṃ datvā, pūjaṃ katvā
analyzed: saṃvibhāgena pākaṭaḥ hoti iti dassetum accharāya ati ādim vatvā iti ce na īsam hoti iti 🔽vuttam cittuppatti daḷhatarā api hutvā pavattati iti dassetum dānam da tvā pūjam katvā
translated: The word viharemū is to be construed with the preceding words also: “without ill will, let us live … without anger, let us live … without vexation, let us live … without hate, let us live … without envy, let us live … without miserliness, let us live … without deceit, let us live … without treachery, let us live … without conceit, let us live … without arrogance, let us live … without vanity, let us live … without hypocrisy, let us live … without obstinacy, let us live … without perverseness, let us live … without envy, let us live … without avarice, let us live … without guile, let us live … without maliciousness, let us live … without harmfulness, let us live … without anger, let us live … without revenge, let us live … without spite, let us live … without jealousy, let us live … without selfishness, let us live … without vanity, let us live … without haughtiness, let us live … without arrogance, let us live … without pride, let us live … without insolence, let us live … without conceit, let us live … without delusion, let us live … without confusion, let us live … without dullness, let us live … without sloth, let us live … without agitation, let us live … without fear, let us live … without worry, let us live … without grief, let us live … without sorrow, let us live … without lamentation, let us live … without despair, let us live … without perplexity, let us live … without doubt, let us live … without faithlessness, let us live … without lack of conscience, let us live … without lack of shame, let us live … without anger, let us live … without revenge, let us live … without spite, let us live … without jealousy, let us live … without selfishness, let us live … without vanity, let us live … without haughtiness,

original: ca patthayantī”ti vuttaṃ. Iti ceti ce-saddo anvayasaṃsaggena parikappetīti āha “evañca nesa”nti.
analyzed: ca patthayanti iti vuttam iti ca iti cesaddaḥ anvaya saṃsaggena parikappeti iti āha evam ca na īsanti
translated: The word “if” in the passage quoted above is a term of supposition.🔽It is the characteristic of envy that it is the inability to bear, the annoyance, the irritation, at the success of others in any way at all.

original: Yāya kāyaci paresaṃ sampattiyā khīyanaṃ usūyanaṃ asahanaṃ lakkhaṇaṃ etissāti parasampattikhīyanalakkhaṇā,🔽yadaggena attasampattiyā parehi sādhāraṇabhāvaṃ asahanalakkhaṇaṃ, tadaggenassa “nigūhanalakkhaṇa”ntipi
analyzed: yāya kāyaci paresam sampattiyā khīyanam usūyanam asahanam lakkhaṇam etissa ati para sampatti khīyana lakkhaṇā  yadaggena atta sampattiyā parehi sādhāraṇa bhāvam a sahana lakkhaṇam tadaggena assa nigūhana lakkhaṇam ti pi
translated: It is the characteristic of avarice that it is the inability to bear the fact that one’s own success is shared with others.🔽For the ancients said: “Let this wonder not be for others, let it be for me alone.”

original: vattabbaṃ. Tathā hissa porāṇā “mā idaṃ acchariyaṃ aññesaṃ hotu, mayhameva hotūti🔽macchariya”nti nibbacanaṃ vadanti. Abhidhamme “yā paralābhasakkāragarukāramānanavandanapūjanāsu
