analyzed: vattabbam tathā hissa porāṇāḥ mā idam acchariyam aññesam hotu mayham eva hotu uti  nibbacanam vadanti abhidhamme yā para lābha sakkāra garukāra mānana vandana pūjanāsu
translated: And in the Abhidhamma it is called “envy” in the Description of Terms: “What is envy? It is envy, enviousness, envy- ing, a state of envy, in one who envies those who have gain, honour, respect, esteem, reverence, worship, and in one who says ‘Let not others have gain … worship’ ” .

original: issā issāyanā”tiādinā nikkhepakaṇḍe, “yā etesu paresaṃ lābhādīsu kiṃ iminā imesa”ntiādinā
analyzed: issā issāyana ati ādinā nikkhepa kaṇḍe yā etesu paresam lābha ādīsu kim iminā imesanti ādinā
translated: And it is called “avarice” in the Description of Terms in the same place: “What is avarice? It is avarice, niggardliness, miserliness, a state of avarice, in one who is avaricious about robes, alms food, resting place, and the requisite of medicine as cure for the sick, and in one who does not give when asked for any of these, and in one who is unwilling to use anything himself and who does not wish others to use it, and in one who is unwilling to part with anything, and in one who is a slave to his own belongings” .

original: taṃsaṃvaṇṇanāyañca vuttāneva, tasmā tattha vuttanayeneva veditabbānīti adhippāyo.
analyzed: tad saṃvaṇṇanāyam ca tasmā tattha vutta nayena iva veditabbāni iti adhippāyaḥ
translated: So the meaning intended is that they should be understood in the way stated there.

original: Yasmā pana issāmacchariyāni bahvādīnavāni, tesaṃ vibhāvanā lokassa bahukārā, tasmā
analyzed: yasmā pana issā macchariyāni bahu ādīnavāni tesam vibhāvanā lokassa bahu kārā tasmā
translated: But since envy and avarice are of great harm and their abandonment is of great benefit to the world,

original: abhidhammaṭṭhakathāyaṃ vibhāvitānampi tesaṃ diṭṭhadhammikepi samparāyike piādīnave🔽dassento “āvāsamacchariyena panā”tiādimāha. Etthāti etesu issāmacchariyesu, etesu
analyzed: vibhāvitānam pi tesam diṭṭhadhammike pi samparāyike pi ādīnave  dassentaḥ āvāsamacchariyena pana ati ādim āha ettha iti etesu issāmacchariyesu etesu
translated: the Exalted One, in the Abhidhamma Commentary, after explaining envy and avarice,

original: vā āvāsamacchariyādīsu pañcasu macchariyesu. Saṅkāraṃ sīsena ukkhipitvāva vicarati🔽tattha laggacittatāya, nihīnajjhāsayatāya ca. Mamāti mayā, ayameva vā pāṭho. Lohitampi
analyzed: vā āvāsa macchariya ādīsu pañcasu macchariyesu saṅkāram sīsena ukkhipitvā ava vicarati  tattha lagga citta tāya ca mama ati mayā ayam eva vā pāṭhaḥ
translated: shows their harmfulness in this life and in the life to come, saying: “But through avarice regarding one’s dwelling place … “ Herein, among the two, envy and avarice, or among the five kinds of avarice beginning with avarice regarding one’s dwelling place.🔽He carries the rubbish on his head and goes about with his mind stuck there, because of his low disposition.🔽“My” : this is the reading. Blood also comes out of his mouth, because his heart is torn by grief.

original: mukhato uggacchati cittavighātena saṃtattahadayatāya. Kucchivirecanampi hoti atijalaggino.🔽Añño vibhavapaṭivedhadhammo ariyānaṃyeva hoti, te ca taṃ na maccharāyanti macchariyassa
analyzed: mukhataḥ uggacchati citta vighātena saṃtatta hadaya tāya kucchi virecanam pi hoti ati jalaggino  aññaḥ vibhava paṭivedha dhammo hoti te ca tam na mat śarāyanti mat śariyassa
translated: There is also purging of the bowels, because of the excess of bile and phlegm.🔽But the Dhamma of penetration of wealth is only for the Noble Ones, and they do not become avaricious, because they have completely abandoned avarice.

original: sabbaso pahīnattā. Paṭivedhadhamme macchariyassa asambhavo evāti āha “pariyattidhammamacchariyena
analyzed: sabbaso pahīna ttā paṭivedha dhamme macchariyassa asambhavaḥ evā ti āha pariyatti dhamma macchariyena
translated: The impossibility of avarice regarding the Dhamma of penetration is shown by the words: “Through avarice regarding the Dhamma of the scriptures … “

original: cā”ti. Vaṇṇamacchariyena dubbaṇṇo, dhammamacchariyena eḷamūgo duppañño hoti.
analyzed: ca ati vaṇṇa macchariyena dubbaṇṇaḥ dhamma macchariyena eḷamūgaḥ duppaññaḥ hoti
translated: and he is ugly through envy of beauty, dumb and witless through envy of the Dhamma.

original: “Apicā”tiādi pañcannaṃ macchariyānaṃ vasena kammasarikkhakavipākadassanaṃ. Āvāsamacchariyena
analyzed: apica atiādi pañcannam macchariyānam vasena kamma sarikkhaka vipāka dassanam āvāsa macchariyena
translated: “But still” : this is the showing of the ripening similar to the respective action by way of the five kinds of envy. Through envy of dwelling-place

original: lohagehe paccati paresaṃ āvāsapaccayahitasukhanisedhanato. Kulamacchariyena appalābho🔽hoti parehi kulesu laddhabbalābhanisedhanato, appalābhoti ca alābhoti attho. Lābhamacchariyena🔽gūthaniraye nibbattati lābhahetu parehi laddhabbassa assādanisedhanato. Sabbathāpi🔽nirassādo hi gūthanirayo. Vaṇṇo nāma na hotīti sarīravaṇṇo, guṇavaṇṇoti duvidhopi
analyzed: loha gehe paccati paresam āvāsa paccaya hita sukha nisedhanataḥ kula macchariyena appa lābhaḥ  hoti parehi kulesu laddhabba lābha nisedhanataḥ appalābho ti ca alābho ti atthaḥ lābha macchariyena  gūthaniraye nibbattati lābha hetu parehi laddhabbassa assāda nisedhanato sabbathā api  nirassādaḥ hi gūtha nirayaḥ vaṇṇaḥ nāma na hoti iti sarīra vaṇṇaḥ guṇa vaṇṇaḥ ti duvidhaḥ api
translated: he is cooked in the iron house, because of his obstruction of the dwelling-place, profit and happiness of others. Through envy of families🔽he has little gain, because of his obstruction of the gain that others have received in families. And “little gain” means “no gain.” Through envy of gain

original: vaṇṇo nāmamattenapi na hoti, tattha tattha nibbattamāno virūpo eva hoti. Sampattinigūhanasabhāvena
analyzed: vaṇṇaḥ nāma mattena api na hoti tattha tattha nibbattamānaḥ virūpaḥ eva hoti sampatti nigūhana sabhāvena
translated: he is reborn in the dung-hell, because of his obstruction of the enjoyment of the gain that others have received. For the dung-hell is completely without enjoyment. “No beauty” : there is no beauty of the body, and there is no beauty of qualities. There is no beauty of either kind. He is ugly wherever he is reborn. Through envy of praise

original: macchariyena virūpite santāne yebhuyyena guṇā patiṭṭhameva na labhanti, ye ca patiṭṭhaheyyuṃ,🔽tesampi vasenassa vaṇṇo na bhaveyya. Te hi tassa loke rattiṃ khittā sarā viya na
analyzed: macchariyena virūpite santāne yebhuyyena guṇāḥ patiṭṭham eva na labhanti ye ca patiṭṭhaheyyum  tesam pi vasenassa vaṇṇo na bhaveyya te hi tassa loke rattim khittā sarāḥ viya na
translated: and in a being whose continuity is distorted by miserliness, qualities generally do not even get established,

original: paññāyanti. Dhammamacchariyena kukkuḷaniraye. Sotāpattimaggena pahīyati apāyagamanīyabhāvato.
analyzed: paññāyanti dhamma macchariyena kukkuḷa niraye sotāpatti maggena pahīyati apāya gamanīya bhāvato
translated: and those that might get established do not shine forth under its sway. For they do not become manifest in the world as the rays of the sun do at night. By the obstruction of the True Idea, in the Kukkula hell. It is abandoned by the path of stream-entry, because of the impossibility of its going to states of loss.

original: Verādīhi na parimuccantiyeva tapparimuccanāya icchāya appattabbattā jātiādidhammānaṃ
analyzed: vera ādīhi na tad parimuccanāya icchāya a pattabba ttā jāti ādi dhammānam
translated: They do not get free from hate, etc., because they have not reached the desire for their getting free.

original: sattānaṃ jātiādīhi viya.
analyzed: sattānam jāti ādīhi viya
translated: Like beings’ births, etc., do not get free from the states of birth, etc.

original: Tiṇṇā mettha kaṅkhāti ma-kāro padasandhikaro. Etasmiṃ pañheti etasmiṃ “kiṃsaṃyojanā🔽nu kho”ti evaṃ ñātuṃ icchite atthe. Tumhākaṃ vacanaṃ sutvāti “issāmacchariyasaṃyojanā”ti
analyzed: tiṇṇām mā ittha kaṅkhā ati makāro pada sandhi karaḥ etasmin etasmin kiṃsaṃyojanā  nu kho ti evam ñātum icchite atthe tumhākam vacanam sutvā iti
translated: The three kinds of doubt here are the three kinds of doubt about the meaning of the question, namely, ‘What is the fetter of envy?🔽What is the fetter of avarice? ‘🔽Having heard your statement,

original: evaṃ pavattaṃ tumhākaṃ vissajjanavacanaṃ sutvā. Kaṅkhā tiṇṇāti yathāpucchite atthe
analyzed: evam pavattam tumhākam vissajjana vacanam sutvā kaṅkhā tiṇṇā ati yathā pucchite atthe
translated: having heard your answer stated thus, ‘The fetter of envy … the fetter of avarice’,🔽our doubt is resolved,

original: saṃsayo tarito vigato desanānussaraṇamattena, na samucchedavasenāti āha “na maggavasenā”tiādi.🔽Ayampi kathaṃkathā vigatāti kaṅkhāya vigatattā eva tassā pavattiākāravisesabhūtā
analyzed: saṃsayaḥ taritaḥ vigataḥ desanā anussaraṇa mattena na samuccheda vasena ati āha na magga vasena atiādi  ayam pi kathaṃkathā vigatā ati kaṅkhāya vigata ttā eva tassā pavatti ākāra visesa bhūtā
translated: Doubt is removed by the mere recollection of the teaching, not by the path.🔽This too is a kind of talk that is removed. Since it is removed, the mode of its occurrence, which is a special kind of talk,

original: “idaṃ katha idaṃ katha”nti ayampi kathaṃkathā vigatā apagatā.
analyzed: idam kathā idam kathanti ayam pi kathaṃkathā vigatā apagatā
translated: is also removed. Thus this kind of talk is removed, gone.🔽The origin, etc., are given the same explanation as in the Mahānidāna Sutta.

original: 358. Nidānādīni mahānidānasuttavaṇṇanāyaṃ vuttatthāneva. Piyānaṃ attano pariggahabhūtānaṃ
analyzed: nidāna ādīni mahānidāna sutta vaṇṇanāyam vutta tthāni iva piyānam attano pariggaha bhūtānam
translated: Because of the inability to bear the fact that what is dear, i.e., the aggregates that constitute one’s own possession,

original: sattasaṅkhārānaṃ parehi sādhāraṇabhāvāsahanavasena, nigūhanavasena ca pavattanato🔽piyasattasaṅkhāranidānaṃ macchariyaṃ, appiyānaṃ pariggahabhūtānaṃ sattānaṃ, saṅkhārānañca
analyzed: parehi sādhāraṇa bhāva asahana vasena nigūhana vasena ca pavattanato  piya satta saṅkhāra nidānam macchariyam appiyānam pariggaha bhūtānam sattānam saṅkhārānam ca
translated: are shared with others, and because of the concealment of this fact,🔽envy arises from the inability to bear the fact that what is not dear, i.e., other beings and their aggregates,

original: asahanavasena pavattiyā appiyasattasaṅkhāranidānā issā. Yañhi kiñci appiyasambandhaṃ
analyzed: a sahana vasena pavattiyā appiya satta saṅkhāra nidānā issā yat hi kiñci appiya sambandham
translated: is shared with others. For whatever is connected with what is not dear

original: bhaddakampi taṃ kodhanassa appiyamevāti. Ubhayanti macchariyaṃ, issā cāti ubhayaṃ.
analyzed: bhaddakam pi tam kodhanassa appiyam eva ati ubhayanti macchariyam issā ca ati ubhayam
translated: is not dear to the angry person. Both: both miserliness and envy.

original: Ubhayanidānanti piyanidānañceva appiyanidānañca. Piyāti iṭṭhā. Keḷāyitāti dhanāyitā.🔽Mamāyitāti mamattaṃ katvā pariggahitā. Issaṃ karotīti “kiṃ imassa iminā”ti tassa🔽piyasattalābhāsahanavasena ussūyati, tameva piyasattaṃ yācito. Aho vatassāti sādhu🔽vata assa. “Imassa puggalassa evarūpaṃ piyavatthu na bhaveyyā”ti issaṃ karoti usūyaṃ
analyzed: ubhaya nidānanti piya nidānañca iva appiya nidānañca piyā ati iṭṭhā keḷāyitā ati dhanāyitā  mamāyitā ati mamattam katvā pariggahitā issam karoti iti kim imassa tassa  piya satta lābha asahana vasena ussūyati tam eva piya sattam yācitaḥ aho vatassa iti sādhu  vata assa imassa puggalassa evarūpam piya vatthu na bhaveyyāti issam karoti usūyam
translated: The “both kinds of grounds” are grounds for the dear and grounds for the unde ar. The “dear” is the loved one. “He is fond of” means he is attached to.🔽“He is possessive of” means he has taken possession of it as “mine.” “He is envious” means he is jealous because of not getting the loved person.

original: uppādeti. Mamāyantāti keḷāyantā. Appiyeti appiye satte tesaṃ satāpato. Assāti puggalassa,
analyzed: uppāde iti appiye satte tesam assa ati puggalassa
translated: “He wishes” means he wishes that it might be well with him. “May this kind of loved object not be for this person” is how he is envious, how he arouses jealousy. “He is possessive” means he is fond of. “The unde ar” is the unde ar person. “Of them” is of those persons. “Of that” is of the person

original: yena te laddhā. Teti sattasaṅkhārā, sacepi amanāpā honti appiyehi samudāgatattā.🔽Viparītavuttitāyāti ayāthāvagāhitāya. Ko añño evarūpassa lābhīti tena attānaṃ sambhāvento
analyzed: yena te laddhā teti satta saṅkhārā sace pi amanāpāḥ honti appiyehi samudāgata ttā  viparīta vutti tāya āti ayāthāvagāhitāya kaḥ aññaḥ evarūpassa lābhī iti tena attānam sambhāvento
translated: by whom they are got. “Those” is the formations of beings, even though they may be unlovely, because they have come about through the unde ar.🔽“Because of pervertedness” is because of misapprehension. “Who else is there to get such?” is how he exalts himself.

original: issaṃ vā karoti. Aññassa tādisaṃ uppajjamānampi “aho vatassa evarūpaṃ na bhaveyyā”ti
analyzed: issam vā karoti aññassa tādisam uppajjamānam pi aho vata assa evarūpam na bhaveyya ati
translated: “He is envious” is how he is envious of another’s getting such. “May such not be for him” is how he is envious of another’s getting such.

original: issaṃ vā karoti, ayañca nayo heṭṭhā vuttanayattā na gahito.🔽Vatthukāmānaṃ pariyesanavasena pavatto chando pariyesanachando. Paṭilābhapaccayo🔽chando paṭilābhachando. Paribhuñjanavasena pavatto chando paribhogachando. Paṭiladdhānaṃ🔽sannidhāpanavasena, saṅgopanavasena ca pavatto chando sannidhichando. Diṭṭhadhammikameva
analyzed: issam vā karoti ayam ca nayaḥ heṭṭhā vutta naya ttā na gahitaḥ  vatthu kāmānam pariyesana vasena pavatto chando pariyesana chando paṭilābha paccayo  chando paṭilābha chando paribhuñjana vasena pavatto chando paribhoga chando paṭiladdhānam  sannidhāpana vasena saṅgopana vasena ca pavatto chando sannidhichandaḥ diṭṭhadhammikam eva
translated: and the same method applies to envy.

original: payojanaṃ cintetvā vissajjanavasena pavatto chando vissajjanachando. Tenāha “katamo”tiādi.
analyzed: payojanam cintetvā vissajjana vasena pavattaḥ chandaḥ vissajjanachando tena āha katamaḥ itiādi
translated: The desire that occurs as the seeking of objects of sense desire is the desire to seek. The desire that occurs as the condition for acquisition is the desire for acquisition. The desire that occurs as the enjoyment of what has been acquired is the desire for enjoyment. The desire that occurs as the storing up of what has been acquired and as the guarding of it is the desire for storing. The desire that occurs as the giving away of what has been acquired after considering the purpose for which it is needed in this very life is the desire for giving away. Hence he said, “What is the desire to seek? ” and so on.

original: Ayaṃ pañcavidhopi atthato taṇhāyanamevāti āha “taṇhāmattamevā”ti.🔽Evaṃ vutto “lābhaṃ paṭicca vinicchayo”ti evaṃ mahānidānasutte vutto vinicchayavitakko
analyzed: ayam pañcavidhaḥ pi atthato taṇhāyanam evā ti āha taṇhā mattam evā ti  evam vuttaḥ lābham paṭicca vinicchayaḥ ti evam mahānidāna sutte vuttaḥ vinicchaya vitakko
translated: And although this fivefold desire is in fact craving, he said, “It is craving only” in order to show that it is a form of craving.🔽The reflection called “reflection on acquisition” mentioned in the Mahānidāna Sutta in the passage, “With the arising of acquisition there is the arising of reflection” is not just any kind of reflection,

original: vitakko nāma, na yo koci vitakko. Idāni yathāvuttaṃ vinicchayavitakkaṃ atthuddhāranayena
analyzed: vitakkaḥ nāma na yaḥ koci vitakkaḥ idāni yathā vuttam vinicchaya vitakkam attha uddhāra nayena
translated: but the kind of reflection that occurs as the desire to seek, etc., as stated there. Now, in order to show the meaning of that reflection by way of the method of extracting the meaning, he said, “Herein, what is reflection on acquisition? ”

original: nīharitvā dassetuṃ “vinicchayo”tiādi vuttaṃ. Aṭṭhasatanti aṭṭhādhikaṃ sataṃ, tañca
analyzed: nīharitvā dassetum vinicchaya utiādi vuttam aṭṭha satanti aṭṭha adhikam satam tat ca
translated: and in order to show that it is the eighty-two that are so stated, “The eighty-two” is said.

original: kho taṇhāvicaritānaṃ sataṃ, na yassa kassacīti dassetuṃ “taṇhāvicarita”nti vuttaṃ.
analyzed: kho taṇhā vicaritānam satam na yassa kassaci iti dassetum taṇhā vicaritanti vuttam
translated: And in order to show that they are not the eighty-two of anyone at all but of those whose ideas are the eighty-two, “Whose ideas are the eighty-two” is said.

original: Taṇhāvinicchayo nāma taṇhāya vasena vakkhamānanayena ārammaṇassa vinicchinanato.
analyzed: taṇhāvinicchayaḥ nāma taṇhāya vasena vakkhamāna nayena ārammaṇassa vinicchinanato
translated: Craving-investigation is so called because of the investigating of an object by the method of describing it according to craving.

original: Diṭṭhidassanavasena “idameva saccaṃ, moghaṃ añña”nti vinicchinanato diṭṭhivinicchayo
analyzed: diṭṭhi dassana vasena idam eva saccam mogham aññanti vinicchinanataḥ diṭṭhi vinicchayaḥ
translated: View-investigation is so called because of the investigating of an object thus, “This alone is the truth, other statements are silly,” according to the view.

original: nāma. Iṭṭhaṃ paṇītaṃ, aniṭṭhaṃ appaṇītaṃ, piyāyitabbaṃ piyaṃ, appiyāyitabbaṃ appiyaṃ,🔽tesaṃ vavatthānaṃ taṇhāvasena na hoti. Taṇhāvasena hi ekacco kiñci vatthuṃ paṇītaṃ
analyzed: nāma iṭṭham paṇītam aniṭṭham appaṇītam piyāyitabbam piyam appiyāyitabbam appiyam  tesam vavatthānam taṇhā vasena na hoti taṇhā vasena hi ekacco kiñci vatthum paṇītam
translated: What is desirable, beautiful, and so on is agreeable, dear, and so on.

original: maññati, ekacco hīnaṃ, ekacco piyāyati, ekacco nappiyāyati. Tenāha “tadeva hī”tiādi.
analyzed: maññati ekaccaḥ hīnam ekaccaḥ piyāyati ekaccaḥ na piyāyati tena āha tat eva hi itiādi
translated: The delimitation of these is not according to craving. For according to craving, some conceive a thing as desirable and beautiful, some as undesirable and ugly, some as agreeable and dear, and some as disagreeable and not dear. That is why he said “The same thing” and so on.

original: “Dassāmī”ti idaṃ vissajjanachande vuttanayena ceva vaṭṭūpanissayadānavasena ca veditabbaṃ.
analyzed: dassāmi iti idam vissajjana chande vutta nayena ca iva vaṭṭu upanissaya dāna vasena ca veditabbam
translated: “I shall give” is to be understood in the way stated in the answer to the question about the will to give and in the way stated under the “support for conditions” .

original: Tampi hi taṇhāchandahetukanti.
analyzed: tat pi hi taṇhā chanda hetukan ti
translated: for that too has craving and will for its cause.

original: Yattha sayaṃ uppajjanti, taṃ santānaṃ saṃsāre papañcenti vitthārayantīti papañcā.
analyzed: yattha sayam uppajjanti tam santānam saṃsāre papañcenti vitthārayanti iti papañcā
translated: They proliferate that continuity in the round of rebirths where they themselves arise, thus they are proliferators.

original: Yassa ca uppannā, taṃ “ratto”ti vā “satto”ti vā “micchābhiniviṭṭho”ti vā papañcenti
analyzed: yassa ca uppannā tam ratto ti vā satto ti vā micchā abhiniviṭṭho ti vā papañcenti
translated: And they proliferate the person in whom they arise, calling him “one who is attached,” “one who is bound,” or “one who is misapprehending.”

original: byañjentīti papañcā. Yasmā taṇhādiṭṭhiyo adhimattā hutvā pavattamānā taṃsamaṅgīpuggalaṃ
analyzed: byañjenti iti yasmā taṇhā diṭṭhiyaḥ adhimattāḥ hutvā pavattamānā tad samaṅgī puggalam
translated: They proliferate him by making him out to be more than he is, thus they are proliferators.

original: pamattākāraṃ pāpenti, māno pana jātimadādi vasena mattākārampi, tasmā “mattapamattākārapāpanaṭṭhenā”ti
analyzed: pamatta ākāram vasena matta ākāram pi tasmā matta pamatta ākāra pāpana ṭṭhena ati
translated: Because craving and views, when they occur in excess, make the person in whom they arise fall into negligence, while conceit makes him fall into the conceit “I am” on account of his birth, etc.,🔽they are said to “cause him to fall into negligence and conceit.”

original: vuttaṃ. Saṅkhā vuccati koṭṭhāso bhāgaso saṅkhāyati upaṭṭhātīti. Yasmā papañcasaññā
analyzed: vuttam saṅkhā vuccati koṭṭhāsaḥ bhāgasaḥ saṅkhāyati upaṭṭhāti iti yasmā papañca saññā
translated: A “compartment” is a portion; it is reckoned as, it is evident as, a portion.

original: taṃtaṃdvāravasena, ārammaṇavasena ca bhāgaso vitakkassa paccayā honti, na kevalā,
analyzed: taṃ taṃ dvāra vasena ārammaṇa vasena ca bhāgasaḥ vitakkassa paccayāḥ honti na kevalā
translated: Because the perceptions of proliferation are conditions for applied thought by way of the various doors and objects, not by themselves alone,

original: tasmā papañcasaññāsaṅkhānidāno vitakko vutto, papañcasaññānaṃ vā anekabhedabhinnattā
analyzed: tasmā papañca saññā saṅkhā nidānaḥ vitakkaḥ vuttaḥ papañca saññānam vā aneka bheda bhinna ttā
translated: it is said that applied thought has the perceptions of proliferation and their concomitants for its source. Or alternatively, since the perceptions of proliferation are divided into many kinds,

original: taṃsamudāyo “papañcasaññāsaṅkhā”ti vutto. Papañcasaññāsaṅkhāggahaṇena ca anavaseso
analyzed: tad samudāyaḥ papañca saññā saṅkhā ti vuttaḥ papañca saññā saṅkhā ggahaṇena ca anavasesaḥ
translated: and the totality of these is called “the proliferation of perceptions and notions.” And by the expression “the proliferation of perceptions and notions” the whole field of formations is included.

original: dukkhasamudayo vutto taṃtaṃ nimittattā vaṭṭadukkhassāti.🔽Yo nirodho vūpasamoti nirodhasaccamāha. Tassa sāruppanti tassa papañcasaññāsaṅkhāya
analyzed: dukkha samudayaḥ vuttaḥ taṃ tam nimitta ttā vaṭṭa dukkhassa ti  yaḥ nirodhaḥ vūpasamaḥ ti nirodha saccam āha tassa sāruppam ti tassa papañca saññā saṅkhāya
translated: The totality of these is called ‘perceptions and categories of perception that proliferate’. And by the inclusion of ‘perceptions and categories of perception that proliferate’ the origin of suffering is stated without reserve,🔽since the suffering of the round is due to this or that sign.

original: nirodhassa vūpasamassa adhigamupāyatāya sāruppaṃ anucchavikaṃ, etena vipassanaṃ vadati.
analyzed: nirodhassa vūpasamassa adhigama upāya tāya sāruppam anucchavikam etena vipassanam vadati
translated: ‘The cessation, the allaying’ : he mentions the cessation truth. ‘The way that is appropriate to that’ : the way that is appropriate to the cessation of that proliferation of perceptions and categories of perception, that is appropriate to the allaying of that, is the way that is suitable, the way that is fitting. By this he mentions insight.

original: Tattha yathāvuttanirodhe ārammaṇakaraṇavasena gacchati pavattatīti tatthagāminī,
analyzed: tattha yathā vutta nirodhe ārammaṇa karaṇa vasena gacchati pavattati iti tattha gāminī
translated: ‘The way that goes to that’ : it goes, it occurs, by making that cessation mentioned in the way stated its object.

original: etena maggaṃ. Tenāha “saha vipassanāya maggaṃ pucchatī”ti.
analyzed: etena maggam tena āha saha vipassanāya maggam pucchati iti
translated: By this he mentions the path. Hence it is said: ‘He asks about the path together with insight’ .

original: Vedanākammaṭṭhānavaṇṇanā
analyzed: vedanā kammaṭṭhāna vaṇṇanā
translated: The Description of the Meditation Subject of Feeling

original: 359. Pucchitameva kathitaṃ. Yasmā sakkena devānaṃ indena papañcasaññāsaṅkhānirodhagāminipaṭipadā
analyzed: pucchitam eva kathitam yasmā sakkena devānam indena
translated: What was asked has been told. Since Sakka Ruler of Gods asked the way of practice that goes to the cessation of the proliferation of perceptions and categories of perception,

original: pucchitāva, bhagavā ca tadadhigamupāyaṃ arūpakammaṭṭhānaṃ tassa ajjhāsayavasena vedanāmukhena
analyzed: pucchitāva bhagavā ca tad adhigama upāyam arūpa kamma ṭṭhānam tassa ajjhāsaya vasena vedanā mukhena
translated: and since the Blessed One, in accordance with his inclination, told him the immaterial meditation subject, which is the way to attain that, by the means of feeling,

original: kathento tisso vedanā ārabhi, iti pucchitameva kathentena pucchānusandhivasena sānusandhimeva🔽ca kathitaṃ. Na hi buddhānaṃ ananusandhikā kathā nāma atthi. Idānissa vedanāmukhena
analyzed: kathentaḥ tissaḥ vedanāḥ ārabhi iti pucchitam eva kathentena puccha anusandhi vasena sa anusandhim eva  ca kathitam na hi buddhānam ananusandhikā kathā nāma atthi idāni ssa vedanā mukhena
translated: He began by speaking of the three kinds of feeling. Thus he answered the question that was asked, and he did so by a connected train of thought.

original: arūpakammaṭṭhānasseva kathane kāraṇaṃ dassetuṃ “devatānañhī”tiādi vuttaṃ. Karajakāyassa
analyzed: arūpa kammaṭṭhānassa iva kathane kāraṇam dassetum devatānam hi itiādi vuttam karaja kāyassa
translated: For the Buddhas have no disconnected way of speaking. Now, in order to show the reason for his speaking of the immaterial meditation subject by way of feeling, he said, “For the deities,” and so on.

original: sukhumatāvacaneneva accantamudusukhumālabhāvāpi vuttā evāti daṭṭhabbaṃ. Kammajanti
analyzed: sukhuma tā vacanena iva vuttāḥ eva iti daṭṭhabbam kamma janti
translated: The words “subtlety of the born-of-kamma body” imply the extreme softness and delicacy of the born-of-kamma body.

original: kammajatejaṃ. Tassa balavabhāvo uḷārapuññakammanibbattattā, ativiya garumadhurasiniddhasuddhāhārajīraṇato
analyzed: tassa balava bhāvaḥ uḷāra puñña kamma nibbatta ttā ativiya garu madhura siniddha suddha āhāra jīraṇato
translated: The “born-of-kamma fire” is the fire in the born-of-kamma body. Its strength is due to the fact that it is produced by a very powerful meritorious kamma, and also to the fact that it digests the extremely rich, sweet, and pure food.

original: ca. Ekāhārampīti ekāhāravārampi. “Vilīyantī”ti etena karajakāyassa mandatāya kammajatejassa
analyzed: ca ekāhāram pi iti eka āhāra vāram pi vilīyanti iti etena karaja kāyassa manda tāya kamma ja tejassa
translated: “Even in a single day” means even in a single period of twenty-four hours.

original: balavabhāvena āhāravelātikkamena nesaṃ balavatī dukkhavedanā uppajjamānā supākaṭā
analyzed: balava bhāvena āhāra velā atikkamena nesam balavatī dukkha vedanā uppajjamānā su pākaṭā
translated: By the words “dissolve” he shows that because the born-of-kamma body is weak and the born-of-kamma fire is strong, the food is digested very quickly. Thus the strong painful feeling that arises is very evident.

original: hotīti dasseti. Nidassanamattañcetaṃ, sukhavedanāpi pana nesaṃ uḷārapaṇītesu ārammaṇesu
analyzed: hoti iti dasseti sukha vedanā api pana nesam uḷāra paṇītesu ārammaṇesu
translated: He shows that it is. But this is only a way of showing. For pleasant feeling too, when it occurs in regard to very superior objects,

original: uparūpari aniggahaṇavasena pavattamānā supākaṭā hutvā upaṭṭhātiyeva. Upekkhāpi tesaṃ
analyzed: upari upari a niggahaṇa vasena pavattamānā su pākaṭā hutvā upaṭṭhātiyā iva upekkhā api tesam
translated: appears quite clearly, since it occurs without interruption. And equanimity too,

original: kadāci uppajjamānā santapaṇītarūpā eva iṭṭhamajjhatte eva ārammaṇe pavattanato. Tenevāha “tasmā”tiādi.
analyzed: kadāci uppajjamānā santa paṇīta rūpā eva iṭṭha majjhatte eva ārammaṇe pavattanato tena iva āha tasmā itiādi
translated: when it arises in them, is of a peaceful and sublime kind, since it occurs in regard to a desirable object that is neither pleasant nor unpleasant. That is why he said, “Therefore … ”

original: Rūpakammaṭṭhānanti rūpapariggahaṃ, rūpamukhena vipassanābhinivesanti attho. Arūpakammaṭṭhānanti🔽etthāpi eseva nayo. Tattha rūpakammaṭṭhānena samathābhinivesopi saṅgayhati, vipassanābhiniveso
analyzed: rūpa kammaṭṭhānam ti rūpa pariggaham rūpa mukhena vipassanā abhinivesanti attho arūpa kammaṭṭhānam ti  ettha api esā iva nayaḥ tattha rūpa kammaṭṭhānena samatha abhiniveso api saṅgayhati vipassanā abhiniveso
translated: Rūpa kasiṇa” is the apprehending of materiality; the meaning is, the devotion to insight by way of materiality. “Arūpa kasiṇa” is the apprehending of the immaterial.

original: pana idhādhippetoti dassento “rūpapariggaho arūpapariggahotipi etadeva vuccatī”ti
analyzed: pana idha adhippetaḥ iti dassentaḥ rūpa pariggahaḥ a rūpa pariggahaḥ ti pi etat eva vuccati iti
translated: Here too the same method applies. Herein, the devotion to serenity is included by the “rūpa kasiṇa,” but the devotion to insight is intended here. Showing this, he said, “This is also called the apprehending of materiality and the apprehending of the immaterial.”

original: āha. Catudhātuvavatthānanti ettha yebhuyyena catudhātuvavatthānaṃ vitthārento rūpakammaṭṭhānaṃ
analyzed: āha catu dhātu vavatthānam ti ettha yebhuyyena catu dhātu vavatthānam vitthārentaḥ rūpa kammaṭṭhānam
translated: “The defining of the four elements”: here, in the course of explaining the defining of the four elements, the meditation subject consisting of materiality is included.

original: kathetīti adhippāyo. Rūpakammaṭṭhānaṃ dassetvāva katheti “evaṃ rūpakammaṭṭhānaṃ vuccamānaṃ🔽suṭṭhu vibhūtaṃ pākaṭaṃ hutvā upaṭṭhātī”ti. “Etena idhāpi rūpakammaṭṭhānaṃ ekadesena
analyzed: kathā iti iti adhippāyaḥ rūpa kammaṭṭhānam dassetvā ava kathā iti evam rūpa kammaṭṭhānam vuccamānam  suṭṭhu vibhūtam pākaṭam hutvā upaṭṭhāti iti etena idha api rūpa kammaṭṭhānam eka desena
translated: The intention is that he should explain it. He explains it after showing the meditation subject of foulness, thinking: “When foulness as a meditation subject is being taught,

original: vibhāvitamevā”ti vadanti.
analyzed: vibhāvitam eva ati vadanti
translated: it appears quite clear and evident.” “So here too foulness as a meditation subject is partly demonstrated by this passage,” they say.

original: Kāmañcettha vedanāvasena arūpakammaṭṭhānaṃ āgataṃ, tadaññadhammavasenapi arūpakammaṭṭhānaṃ
analyzed: kāmam ca ittha vedanā vasena arūpa kammaṭṭhānam āgatam tad añña dhamma vasena api arūpa kammaṭṭhānam
translated: Although the meditation subject of the fine material is implied by the words “the sign of the fine material,” still, since the meditation subject of the immaterial is not implied by the words “the sign of the immaterial,”🔽it is shown by a classification of its own, thus: “The immaterial states are of three kinds.”

original: labbhatīti taṃ vibhāgena dassetuṃ “tividho hī”tiādi vuttaṃ. Tattha abhinivesoti anuppaveso,
analyzed: labbhati iti tam vibhāgena dassetum tividhaḥ hi itiādi vuttam tattha abhiniveso ti anuppaveso
translated: Herein, “insistence” is the entering upon ,

original: ārambhoti attho. Ārambhe eva hi ayaṃ vibhāgo, sammasanaṃ pana anavasesatova dhamme🔽pariggahetvā pavattatīti. “Pariggahite rūpakammaṭṭhāne”ti idaṃ rūpamukhena vipassanābhinivesaṃ
analyzed: ārambhaḥ ti atthaḥ ārambhe eva hi ayam vibhāgaḥ sammasanam pana anavasesataḥ va dhamme  pariggahetvā pavattati iti pariggahite rūpa kammaṭṭhāne iti idam rūpa mukhena vipassanā abhinivesam
translated: the meaning is “beginning.” For this is the classification in the beginning, but the surmounting is only by way of the whole of the states.

original: sandhāya vuttaṃ, arūpamukhena pana vipassanābhiniveso yebhuyyena samathayānikassa
analyzed: sandhāya vuttam arūpa mukhena pana vipassanā abhinivesaḥ yebhuyyena samatha yānikassa
translated: “When the meditation subject of foulness has been apprehended”: this is said with reference to insistence on insight by way of the material septad. But in the case of insistence on insight by way of the immaterial septad,🔽the method is mostly that of serenity.

original: icchitabbo, so ca paṭhamaṃ jhānaṅgāni pariggahetvā tato paraṃ sesadhamme pariggaṇhāti.
analyzed: icchitabbaḥ saḥ ca paṭhamam jhāna aṅgāni pariggahetvā tatas param sesa dhamme pariggaṇhāti
translated: He should wish for it, and he should discern the first jhāna’s factors first and then discern the remaining states.

original: Paṭhamābhinipātoti sabbe cetasikā cittāyattā cittakiriyābhāvena vuccantīti phasso
analyzed: paṭhama abhinipāto ti sabbe cetasikā citta āyattā citta kiriyā bhāvena vuccanti iti phasso
translated: The first impact: all the mental states are dependent on consciousness, and they are called “mental” because they are the activity of consciousness. So contact is said to be the first impact on consciousness.

original: cittassa paṭhamābhinipāto vutto. Taṃ ārammaṇanti yathāpariggahitaṃ rūpakammaṭṭhānasaññitaṃ🔽ārammaṇaṃ. Uppannaphasso puggalo, cittacetasikarāsi vā ārammaṇena phuṭṭho phassasahajātāya
analyzed: cittassa paṭhama abhinipātaḥ vutto tam ārammaṇam ti yathā pariggahitam rūpa kammaṭṭhāna saññitam  ārammaṇam uppanna phassaḥ puggalo vā ārammaṇena phuṭṭhaḥ phassa sahajātāya
translated: The object: the object is the sign of the material form as the meditation subject, which has been discerned as already described.🔽The person or the aggregate of consciousness and its concomitants that has contact arising is touched by the object. He feels with the feeling that is associated with the contact that arises simultaneously with the contact.

original: vedanāya taṃsamakālameva vedeti, phasso pana obhāsassa viya padīpo vedanādīnaṃ paccayaviseso
analyzed: vedanāya tad sama kālam eva vedeti phassaḥ pana obhāsassa viya padīpaḥ vedanā ādīnam paccaya viseso
translated: But contact is the specific condition for feeling, etc., as the flame is for the light,

original: hotīti purimakālo viya vuccati, yā tassa ārammaṇābhiniropanalakkhaṇatā vuccati. Phusantoti
analyzed: hoti iti purima kālaḥ viya vuccati yā tassa ārammaṇa abhiniropana lakkhaṇa tā vuccati phusanto ti
translated: and so it is said as if it were prior, and that is called the characteristic of its impingement on the object.

original: ārammaṇassa phusanākārena. Ayañhi arūpadhammattā ekadesena anallīyamānopi rūpaṃ viya
analyzed: ārammaṇassa phusana ākārena ayan hi arūpa dhamma ttā eka desena rūpam viya
translated: Touching: by the mode of touching the object. For this, being a formless state, does not adhere to the object part by part like material form,

original: cakkhuṃ, saddo viya ca sotaṃ, cittaṃ, ārammaṇañca phusanto viya, saṅghaṭṭento viya
analyzed: cakkhum saddaḥ viya ca sotam cittam ārammaṇam ca phusantaḥ viya saṅghaṭṭentaḥ viya
translated: and the eye is like the ear in regard to the visible-data, and the mind is like the body in regard to the mental data, and it occurs as though touching and striking the object.

original: ca pavattatīti. Tathā hesa “saṅghaṭṭanaraso”ti vuccati.🔽Ārammaṇaṃ anubhavantīti issaravatāya visavitāya sāmibhāvena ārammaṇarasaṃ saṃvedentī.
analyzed: ca pavattati iti tathā ha isa saṅghaṭṭana rasaḥ iti vuccati  ārammaṇam anubhavanti iti issaravatāya visavitāya sāmi bhāvena ārammaṇa rasam saṃvedentī
translated: That is why it is called “having the characteristic of striking” .🔽Experiencing the object: experiencing the object’s taste as master, as ruler, as owner.

original: Phassādīnañhi sampayuttadhammānaṃ ārammaṇe ekadeseneva pavatti phusanādimattabhāvato,
analyzed: phassa ādīnam hi sampayutta dhammānam ārammaṇe eka desena iva pavatti phusana ādi matta bhāvato
translated: For the associated states beginning with contact occur in regard to the object only to the extent of mere touching, and so on,

original: vedanāya pana iṭṭhākārasambhogādivasena pavattanato ārammaṇe nippadesato pavatti.
analyzed: vedanāya pana iṭṭha ākāra sambhoga ādi vasena pavattanataḥ ārammaṇe nippadesato pavatti
translated: but feeling occurs in regard to the object without distinction as to place, because it occurs by enjoying the aspect of agreeableness, and so on.

original: Phusanādibhāvena hi ārammaṇaggahaṇaṃ ekadesānubhavanaṃ, vedayitabhāvena gahaṇaṃ yathākāmaṃ🔽sabbānubhavanaṃ, evaṃsabhāvāneva tāni gahaṇānīti na vedanāya viya phassādīnampi yathā
analyzed: phusana ādi bhāvena hi ārammaṇa ggahaṇam eka desa anubhavanam vedayita bhāvena gahaṇam yathākāmam  tāni gahaṇāni iti na vedanāya phassa ādīnam pi yathā
translated: For the apprehension of the object as contact, and so on, is the experiencing of it in part, and the apprehension of it as feeling is the experiencing of it according to desire,🔽as all. These are the kinds of apprehension. So it cannot be objected that, as feeling does, so also contact, and so on, experience the object as owners by doing their several functions.

original: sakakiccakaraṇena sāmibhāvānubhavanaṃ codetabbaṃ. Vijānantanti paricchindanavasena
analyzed: saka kicca karaṇena sāmi bhāva anubhavanam codetabbam paricchindana vasena
translated: Cognizing: by discerning.

original: visesato jānantaṃ. Viññāṇañhi minitabbavatthuṃ nāḷiyā minanto puriso viya ārammaṇaṃ
analyzed: visesataḥ jānantam viññāṇam hi minitabba vatthum nāḷiyā minantaḥ purisaḥ viya ārammaṇam
translated: and especially one who knows. For consciousness is like a man who pierces a thing to be pierced with a gimlet by means of the gimlet’s point.

original: paricchijja vibhāventaṃ pavattati, na saññā viya sañjānanamattaṃ hutvā. Tathā hi🔽anena kadāci lakkhaṇattayavibhāvanāpi hoti, imesaṃ pana phassādīnaṃ tassa tassa pākaṭabhāvo
analyzed: paricchijja vibhāventam pavattati na saññā viya sañjānana mattam hutvā tathā hi  anena kadāci lakkhaṇa ttaya vibhāvanā api hoti imesam pana phassa ādīnam tassa tassa pākaṭa bhāvaḥ
translated: And especially one who knows. For consciousness occurs discerning and defining the object, as a man does a piece of wood by planing it with a plane, not merely discerning it as does perception. For this is why

original: paccayavisesasiddhassa pubbabhāgassa vasena veditabbo.🔽Evaṃ tassa tasseva pākaṭabhāvepi “sabbaṃ, bhikkhave, abhiññeyya”nti, “sabbañca kho,🔽bhikkhave, abhijāna”nti ca evamādi vacanato sabbe sammasanupagā dhammā pariggahetabbāti
analyzed: paccaya visesa siddhassa pubbabhāgassa vasena veditabbaḥ  evam tassa tassa iva pākaṭa bhāve pi sabbam bhikkhave abhiññeyyanti sabbam ca kho  bhikkhave abhijānanti ca evamādi vacanato sabbe sammasanupagāḥ dhammāḥ pariggahetabbā ati
translated: sometimes it defines the three characteristics. But the manifestation of these, contact, etc., should be understood as due to the predominance of the respective conditions in the prior stage.🔽And although it is their manifestation in this way, still all states that are to be penetrated should be discerned, since it is said: “Bhikkhus, all is to be directly known” , and “Bhikkhus, all is to be fully understood” , and so on.

original: dassento “tattha yassā”tiādimāha. Tattha phassapañcamakeyevāti avadhāraṇaṃ tadantogadhattā
analyzed: dassentaḥ tattha yassa ati ādim āha tattha avadhāraṇam
translated: So showing how all states that are to be penetrated should be discerned, he said, “Herein, of those beginning with contact” . Herein, the words “only those beginning with contact” are a restriction,

original: taggahaṇeneva gahitattā catunnaṃ arūpakkhandhānaṃ. Phassapañcamakaggahaṇañhi tassa
analyzed: tad gahaṇena iva gahita ttā catunnam arūpa kkhandhānam phassa pañcamaka ggahaṇam hi tassa
translated: because they include what is included by the word “those” . For the four immaterial aggregates are included by the word “those” .🔽For the words “only those beginning with contact”

original: sabbassa sabbacittuppādasādhāraṇabhāvato. Tattha ca phassacetanāggahaṇena sabbasaṅkhārakkhandhadhammasaṅgaho🔽cetanappadhānattā tesaṃ. Tathā hi suttantabhājanīye saṅkhārakkhandhavibhaṅge “cakkhusamphassajā
analyzed: sabbassa sabba cittuppāda sādhāraṇa bhāvato tattha ca phassa cetanā ggahaṇena sabba saṅkhāra kkhandha dhamma saṅgaho  cetanā padhāna ttā tesam tathā hi suttanta bhājanīye saṅkhāra kkhandha vibhaṅge cakkhu samphassa jā
translated: because it is common to all consciousness. And here, by the inclusion of contact and volition, all states of the formations aggregate are included,

original: cetanā”tiādinā cetanāva vibhattā, itare pana khandhā sarūpeneva gahitā.
analyzed: cetanā ati ādinā vibhattā itare pana khandhā sarūpena iva gahitā
translated: because volition is predominant among them. For in the exposition of the formations aggregate in the Suttantabhājanīya, volition alone is given in the passage beginning, “Volition born of eye-contact” (Vibh 1), while the other formations are included in the passage on the materiality aggregate.

original: Vatthunissitāti ettha vatthu-saddo karajakāyavisayo, na chabbatthuvisayoti. Kathamidaṃ🔽viññāyatīti āha “yaṃ sandhāya vutta”nti. Kattha pana vuttaṃ? Sāmaññaphalasutte. Soti
analyzed: vatthu nissitā ti ettha vatthu saddo karaja kāya visayaḥ na chabbatthu visayaḥ ti katham idam  viññāyati iti āha yam sandhāya vuttanti kattha pana vuttam sāmaññaphalasutte saḥ ti
translated: Herein, the word “basis” (vatthu) refers to the physical body, not to the six bases. How is this known?

original: karajakāyo. “Pañcakkhandhavinimuttaṃ nāmarūpaṃ natthī”ti idaṃ adhikāravasena vuttaṃ.
analyzed: karaja kāyo pañca kkhandha vinimuttam nāma rūpam natthi iti idam adhikāra vasena vuttam
translated: He says, “With reference to which it is said.” But where is it said? In the Sāmaññaphala Sutta. “That” refers to the physical body. “There is no mentality-materiality apart from the five aggregates” is said by way of the subject matter of the passage.🔽Otherwise, mentality would exist even apart from the aggregates.

original: Aññathā hi khandhavinimuttampi nāmaṃ atthevāti. Avijjādihetukāti avijjātaṇhupādānādihetukā.
analyzed: aññathā hi khandha vinimuttam pi nāmam attha iva ati avijjā ādi hetukā ati avijjā taṇhā upādāna ādi hetukā
translated: “With ignorance as their root” means with ignorance, craving, and attachment as their root.

original: “Vipassanāpaṭipāṭiyā aniccaṃ dukkhaṃ anattāti sammasanto vicaratī”ti iminā balavavipassanaṃ
analyzed: vipassanā paṭipāṭiyā aniccam dukkham anattā ati sammasantaḥ vicarati iti iminā balava vipassanam
translated: “He is one who, by the method of insight, is discerning and comprehending impermanence, suffering, and non-self” .

original: vatvā puna tassa ussukkāpanaṃ, visesādhigamañca dassento “so”tiādimāha.
analyzed: vatvā puna tassa ussukkāpanam visesa adhigamam ca dassento so ti ādim āha
translated: Having thus shown strong insight, the Exalted One again shows the way to strive for it and the attainment of distinction, saying “He” .

original: Idhāti imasmiṃ sakkapañhasutte. Vedanāvasena cettha arūpakammaṭṭhānakathane kāraṇaṃ
analyzed: idha ati imasmim sakkapañha sutte vedanā vasena ca ittha arūpa kammaṭṭhāna kathane kāraṇam
translated: “Here” in this sutta, the sutta of Sakka’s question. The reason for the teaching of the immaterial meditation subject by way of feeling is

original: heṭṭhā vuttanayameva. Yathāvuttesu ca tīsu kammaṭṭhānābhinivesesu vedanāvasena kammaṭṭhānābhiniveso
analyzed: heṭṭhā vutta nayam eva yathā vuttesu ca tīsu kammaṭṭhāna abhinivesesu vedanā vasena kammaṭṭhāna abhiniveso
translated: the same as the reason given above . And of the three ways of taking up a meditation subject mentioned above, the taking up of a meditation subject by way of feeling is

original: sukaro vedanānaṃ vibhūtabhāvatoti dassetuṃ “phassavasena hī”tiādi vuttaṃ. “Na pākaṭaṃ🔽hotī”ti idaṃ sakkapamukhānaṃ tesaṃ devānaṃ yathā vedanā vibhūtā hutvā upaṭṭhāti,
analyzed: sukaraḥ vedanānam vibhūta bhāvato ti dassetum phassa vasena hi itiādi vuttam na pākaṭam  hoti iti idam sakka pamukhānam tesam devānam yathā vedanā vibhūtā hutvā upaṭṭhāti
translated: easy because of the obviousness of the feelings. In order to show this, it is said: “For it is by way of contact” .

original: na evaṃ itaradvayanti katvā vuttaṃ. Vedanāya eva ca nesaṃ vibhūtabhāvo vedanāmukhenevettha
analyzed: na evam itarat vayanti katvā vuttam vedanāya eva ca na īsam vibhūta bhāvaḥ vedanā mukhena iva īttha
translated: “It is not obvious” . This is said because the way the feelings appear to those gods headed by Sakka is not the way the other two appear to them.

original: bhagavatā desanāya āraddhattā. “Vedanānaṃ uppattiyā pākaṭatāyā”ti idaṃ sukhadukkhavedanānaṃ
analyzed: bhagavatā desanāya āraddha ttā vedanānaṃ uppattiyā pākaṭa tāya ati idam sukha dukkha vedanānam
translated: And it is only the obviousness of the feelings to them that is shown by the Exalted One in this teaching, which he began with the words: “By way of the arising of feelings” .

original: vasena vuttaṃ. Tāsañhi pavatti oḷārikā, na itarāya. Tadubhayaggahaṇamukhena vā gahetabbattā🔽itarāyapi pavatti viññūnaṃ pākaṭā evāti sukhadukkhavedanānañhī”ti visesaggahaṇaṃ
analyzed: vasena vuttam tāsam hi pavatti oḷārikā na itarāya tad ubhaya ggahaṇa mukhena vā gahetabba ttā  pākaṭā eva ati sukha dukkha vedanānam hi iti visesa ggahaṇam
translated: Or else, the other should be regarded as stated in particular because the occurrence of both is obvious to the wise.

original: daṭṭhabbaṃ. “Yadā sukhaṃ uppajjatī”tiādi sukhavedanāya pākaṭabhāvavibhāvanaṃ, tayidaṃ
analyzed: daṭṭhabbam yadā sukham uppajjati itiādi sukha vedanāya pākaṭa bhāva vibhāvanam tayā idam
translated: The words “When pleasure arises” and so on are a way of showing that pleasant feeling is obvious.

original: asamāhitabhūmivasena veditabbaṃ. Tattha “sakalaṃ sarīraṃ kho bhante”ntiādinā kāmaṃ
analyzed: asamāhita bhūmi vasena veditabbam tattha sakalam sarīram kho bhante inti ādinā kāmam
translated: This should be understood as referring to the plane of the non-concentrated .

original: pavattioḷārikatāya avūpasantasabhāvametaṃ sukhaṃ, sātalakkhaṇatāya pana sampayuttadhamme,🔽nissayañca anuggaṇhantameva pavattatīti dasseti. “Yadā dukkhaṃ uppajjatī”tiādīsu
analyzed: pavatti oḷārika tāya a vūpasanta sabhāvam etam sukham sāta lakkhaṇa tāya pana sampayutta dhamme  nissayam ca anuggaṇhantam eva pavattati iti dasseti yadā dukkham uppajjati itiādīsu
translated: Here, the Blessed One shows that this pleasure, which is obvious because of the grossness of its occurrence, is not peaceful in its nature, but that it occurs supporting the associated states and the physical body by way of the characteristic of coolness.

original: vuttavipariyāyena attho veditabbo.
analyzed: vutta vipariyāyena atthaḥ veditabbaḥ
translated: In the passages beginning “When pain arises” the meaning should be understood in the opposite way.

original: Duddīpanāti ñāṇena dīpetuṃ asakkuṇeyyā, dubbiññeyyāti attho. Tenāha “andhakārā abhibhūtā”ti.
analyzed: duddīpanā iti ñāṇena dīpetum asakkuṇeyyā dubbiññeyyā ti attho tena āha andhakārā abhibhūtā iti
translated: Hard to discern: not to be discerned by knowledge. The meaning is, hard to understand. Hence he said, “overwhelmed by darkness.”

original: Andhakārāti andhakāragatasadisī, jānitukāme ca andhakārinī. Pubbāparaṃ samaṃ sukare
analyzed: andhakārā ati andhakāra gata sadisī jānitu kāme ca andhakārinī pubba aparam samam su kare
translated: “Darkness” is like that in darkness, and it is what makes one who wants to know dark.

original: supalakkhitamaggavasena pāsāṇatale migagatamaggo viya iṭṭhāniṭṭhārammaṇesu sukhadukkhānubhavanehi
analyzed: su upalakkhita magga vasena pāsāṇa tale miga gata maggaḥ viya iṭṭha aniṭṭha ārammaṇesu sukha dukkha anubhavanehi
translated: It is like the track of an animal on a rock, which is easy to see because the path is well defined.

original: majjhattārammaṇesu anuminitabbatāya vuttaṃ “sā sukhadukkhānaṃ…pe… pākaṭā hotī”ti.
analyzed: majjhatta ārammaṇesu anuminitabba tāya vuttam sā sukha dukkhānaṃ pe pākaṭā hoti iti
translated: It is said that it can be inferred in the case of a neutral object because it is the experiencing of pleasure and pain in regard to desirable and undesirable objects.

original: Tenāha “yathā”tiādi. Nayato gaṇhantassāti etthāyaṃ nayo – yasmā iṭṭhāniṭṭhavisayāya
analyzed: tena āha yathā iti ādi nayataḥ gaṇhantassa ati ettha ayam nayaḥ yasmai iṭṭha aniṭṭha visayāya
translated: Hence he said: “As, in the case of the track of an animal on a rock, etc.”

original: ārammaṇūpaladdhiyā anubhavanato niṭṭhāmajjhattavisayā ca upaladdhi, tasmā na tāya
analyzed: ārammaṇa upaladdhiyāḥ anubhavanataḥ ca upaladdhi tasmā na tāya
translated: The method here is this: since the experience of the object of the desirable and undesirable is the end, and the experience of the object of the neutral is the middle, therefore it must not be that which is not experienced.🔽That which is the experience there is neither-painful-nor-pleasant.

original: niranubhavanāya bhavitabbaṃ, yaṃ tatthānubhavanaṃ, sā adukkhamasukhā. Tathā anupalabbhamānaṃ🔽rūpādianubhuyyamānaṃ diṭṭhaṃ upalabbhati, yo pana majjhattārammaṇaṃ tabbisayassa
analyzed: niranubhavanāya bhavitabbam yam tattha anubhavanam sā adukkham asukhā tathā anupalabbhamānam  rūpa ādi anubhuyyamānam diṭṭham upalabbhati yaḥ pana majjhatta ārammaṇam tad visayassa
translated: So too, the visible object, etc., which are not experienced, are seen to be experienced.🔽But in the case of a neutral object, there is no occurrence of consciousness with that as its object.

original: viññāṇappavattiyaṃ, tasmā ananubhuyyamānena tena na bhavitabbaṃ. Sakkā hi vattuṃ
analyzed: viññāṇa ppavattiyam tasmai an anubhuyyamānena tena na bhavitabbam sakkā hi vattum
translated: Therefore it must not be that which is not experienced. It is possible to say:

original: anubhavamānā majjhattavisayupaladdhi upaladdhibhāvato. Iṭṭhāniṭṭhavisayupaladdhivisayaṃ
analyzed: anubhavamānā majjhatta visaya upaladdhi upaladdhi bhāvataḥ iṭṭha aniṭṭha visaya upaladdhi visayam
translated: The experience of the object of equanimity is seen as the state of mere experience.

original: pana niranubhavanaṃ taṃ anupaladdhisabhāvameva diṭṭhaṃ, taṃ yathārūpanti. Nivattetvāti🔽nīharitvā, “somanassaṃpāha”ntiādinā samānajātiyampi bhindanto aññehi arūpadhammehi
analyzed: pana niranubhavanam tam anupaladdhi sabhāvam eva diṭṭham tam yathārūpam ti nivattetvā ati  nīharitvā somanassaṃpāhanti ādinā samāna jātiyam pi bhindantaḥ aññehi arūpa dhammehi
translated: But the experience of the object of the desirable and the undesirable is seen as the state of non-experience, as the state of non-apprehending.

original: vivecetvā asaṃsaṭṭhaṃ katvāti attho.
analyzed: vivecetvā asaṃsaṭṭham katvā iti atthaḥ
translated: “Having turned away from” means having removed.🔽“And joy” and so on. By distinguishing the other immaterial states, he shows that they are not mixed up with the material states, but are separate from them.

original: Ayañca rūpakammaṭṭhānaṃ kathetvā arūpakammaṭṭhānaṃ vedanāvasena nivattetvā desanā
analyzed: ayam ca rūpa kammaṭṭhānam kathetvā arūpa kammaṭṭhānam vedanā vasena nivattetvā desanā
translated: This teaching, which is given after the material meditation subject has been explained and after the immaterial meditation subject has been turned to by way of feeling,

original: tathāvinetabbapuggalāpekkhāya suttantaresupi āgatā evāti dassento “na kevala”ntiādimāha.
analyzed: tathā vinetabba puggala apekkhāya sutta antaresu pi āgatāḥ eva ati dassentaḥ na kevalam ti ādim āha
translated: is given with reference to the kind of person who can be trained in that way. It is also found in other suttas.🔽The fact that it is found in the Mahāsatipaṭṭhāna Sutta will be evident in the next chapter.

original: Tattha mahāsatipaṭṭhāne tathā desanāya āgatabhāvo anantarameva āvi bhavissati, majjhimanikāye
analyzed: tattha mahāsati paṭṭhāne tathā desanāya āgata bhāvaḥ anantaram eva bhavissati majjhima nikāye
translated: The Satipaṭṭhāna Sutta of the Majjhima Nikāya is also of that kind.

original: satipaṭṭhānadesanāpi tādisī eva. Cūḷataṇhāsaṅkhaye “evaṃ cetaṃ, devānaṃ inda, bhikkhuno
analyzed: sati paṭṭhāna desanā api tādisī eva cūḷa taṇhā saṅkhaye evam ca itam devānam inda bhikkhuno
translated: In the Cūḷatanaṇsaṅkhaya Sutta the Blessed One says: “So it is, Devānaminda, for a bhikkhu

original: sutaṃ hoti ‘sabbe dhammā nālaṃ abhinivesāyā’ti, so sabbaṃ dhammaṃ abhijānāti, sabbaṃ
analyzed: sutam hoti sabbe dhammāḥ na alam abhinivesāya ati so sabbam dhammam abhijānāti sabbam
translated: “He has heard: ‘All things are unworthy of attachment,’ and he knows all things,

original: dhammaṃ abhiññāya sabbaṃ dhammaṃ parijānāti, sabbaṃ dhammaṃ pariññāya yaṃ kiñci vedanaṃ
analyzed: dhammaṃ abhiññāya sabbam dhammam parijānāti sabbam dhammam pariññāya yam kiñci vedanam
translated: knowing all things he fully understands all things, fully understanding all things whatever feeling he feels

original: vedeti sukhaṃ vā dukkhaṃ vā adukkhamasukhaṃ vā, so tāsu vedanāsu aniccānupassī viharati,
analyzed: vedeti sukham vā dukkham vā adukkham asukham vā so tāsu vedanāsu anicca anupassī viharati
translated: he is one who abides contemplating impermanence in those feelings,🔽contemplating fading away in those feelings, contemplating cessation in those feelings, contemplating relinquishment in those feelings.”

original: virāgānupassī”tiādinā āgataṃ. Tena vuttaṃ “arūpakammaṭṭhānaṃ vedanāvasena nivattetvā
analyzed: virāga anupassī iti ādinā āgatam tena vuttam arūpa kammaṭṭhānam vedanā vasena nivattetvā
translated: That is why it was said above: “He shows the formless meditation subject by turning it into the contemplation of feeling.”

original: dassesī”ti. Mahātaṇhāsaṅkhaye pana “so evaṃ anurodhavirodhavippahīno yaṃ kiñci vedanaṃ
analyzed: dassesi iti mahā taṇhā saṅkhaye pana saḥ evam anurodha virodha vippahīnaḥ yam kiñci vedanam
translated: But in the Great Book, in the passage beginning, “When he is thus devoid of compliance and opposition, whatever feeling he feels,

original: vedeti sukhaṃ vā dukkhaṃ vā adukkhamasukhaṃ vā, so taṃ vedanaṃ nābhinandati nābhivadati
analyzed: vedeti sukham vā dukkham vā adukkham asukham vā saḥ tam vedanam na abhinandati na abhivadati
translated: if he delights in that feeling, welcomes it, or remains holding to it,🔽then that delight is the source of the renewal of being” , it is given as follows: “When he is thus devoid of compliance and opposition, whatever feeling he feels,

original: nājjhosāya tiṭṭhati. Tassa taṃ vedanaṃ anabhinandato anabhivadato anajjhosāya tiṭṭhato
analyzed: na ajjhosāya tiṭṭhati tassa tam vedanam an abhinandataḥ an abhivadataḥ an ajjhosāya tiṭṭhataḥ
translated: if he delights in that feeling, welcomes it, or remains holding to it,

original: yā vedanāsu nandī sā nirujjhatī”tiādinā āgataṃ. Cūḷavedalle “kati panāyyevedanā”tiādinā
analyzed: yā vedanāsu nandī sā nirujjhati iti ādinā āgatam cūḷa vedalle kati panāyye vedanā iti ādinā
translated: then that delight in feeling ceases in him. In the Shorter Series of Questions it is given as follows: “Lady, how many kinds of feeling are there?”

original: āgataṃ. Mahāvedalle “vedanāti, āvuso, vuccati, kittāvatā nu kho, āvuso, ‘vedanā’ti
analyzed: āgatam mahāvedalle vedanā ati āvuso vuccati kittāvatā nu kho āvuso vedanā ati
translated: “Friends, ‘feeling’ is said. To what extent, friends, is there ‘feeling’ …

original: vuccatī”tiādinā āgataṃ. Evaṃ raṭṭhapālasuttādīsupi vedanākammaṭṭhānassa āgataṭṭhānaṃ🔽uddharitvā vattabbaṃ.
analyzed: vuccati iti ādinā āgatam evam raṭṭhapāla sutta ādīsu pi vedanā kammaṭṭhānassa āgata ṭṭhānam  uddharitvā vattabbam
translated: It is also found in the Mahāvedalla: “‘Feeling, friend Gotama, is said. To what extent, friend Gotama, is one said to be consummate in the matter of feeling?” and so on . And so too with the Ratthapala Sutta, and so on.🔽The place where the meditation subject of contemplation of feeling is found should be quoted in each case.

original: “Paṭhamaṃ rūpakammaṭṭhānaṃ kathetvā”ti vuttaṃ, kathaṃ tamettha kathitanti āha “rūpakammaṭṭhāna”ntiādi.
analyzed: paṭhamam rūpa kammaṭṭhānam kathetvā ati vuttam katham tam ettha kathitan ti āha rūpa kammaṭṭhāna ntiādi
translated: “Having taught the meditation subject of the kinds of materiality” : how was it taught here? He said: “The meditation subject of the kinds of materiality” .

original: Saṅkhittaṃ, kathaṃ saṅkhittaṃ? Vedanāya ārammaṇamattakaṃyeva, yebhuyyena vedanā rūpadhammārammaṇā
analyzed: saṅkhittam katham saṅkhittam vedanāya yebhuyyena vedanā rūpa dhamma ārammaṇā
translated: Briefly: only the object of contemplation of feeling is stated. For the most part feeling has material dhammas as its object,

original: pañcadvāravasena pavattanato. Tena cassā purimasiddhā eva ārammaṇanti vedanaṃ vadantena
analyzed: pañca dvāra vasena pavattanato tena ca ssā purima siddhā eva vedanam vadantena
translated: because it occurs by way of the five doors. Therefore those who say that its object is already accomplished🔽by the mere fact that it is called “feeling” are to be asked:🔽“What is the meaning of the word ‘feeling’?”

original: tassārammaṇadhammā atthato paṭhamataraṃ gahitā eva nāma hontīti imāya atthāpattiyā
analyzed: tassa ārammaṇa dhammāḥ atthataḥ paṭhamataram gahitāḥ eva nāma honti iti imāya attha āpattiyā
translated: So by this interpretation of the meaning

original: rūpakammaṭṭhānassevettha paṭhamaṃ gahitatā jotitā, na sarūpeneva gahitattā. Tenāha
analyzed: rūpa kammaṭṭhānassa iva ittha paṭhamam gahita tā jotitā na sarūpena iva gahita ttā tena āha
translated: it is shown that the meditation subject of the kinds of materiality is taken first here, not because it is actually mentioned first,🔽but because it is mentioned first in the text. Therefore he said:

original: “tasmā pāḷiyaṃ nāruḷhaṃ bhavissatī”ti.
analyzed: tasmā pāḷiyam na āruḷham bhavissati iti
translated: “so it will not be included in the text” .

original: 360. Dvīhi koṭṭhāsehīti sevitabbāsevitabbabhāgehi. Evarūpanti yaṃ akusalānaṃ abhibuddhiyā,🔽kusalānañca parihānāya saṃvattati, evarūpaṃ, taṃ pana kāmūpasañhitatāya “gehanissita”nti🔽vuccatīti āha “gehasitasomanassa”nti. Iṭṭhānanti piyānaṃ. Kantānanti kamanīyānaṃ.🔽Manāpānanti manavaḍḍhanakānaṃ. Tato eva mano ramentīti manoramānaṃ. Lokāmisapaṭisaṃyuttānanti
analyzed: dvīhi koṭṭhāsehi iti sevitabba asevitabba bhāgehi evarūpam ti yam akusalānam abhibuddhiyā  kusalānam ca parihānāya saṃvattati evarūpam tam pana kāma upasañhita tāya geha nissitanti  vuccati iti āha iṭṭhānam ti piyānam kantānam ti kamanīyānam  manāpānanti tatas eva manaḥ ramenti iti manoramānam loka āmisa paṭisaṃyuttānanti
translated: In the two sections: in the two sections of what should be cultivated and what should not be cultivated. Such as this: that which leads to the manifestation of the unwholesome and🔽to the decline of the wholesome is called “householder-based” because it is associated with sense desires.🔽Therefore it is said: “householder-based joy.” Desirable: dear. Lovely: charming.🔽Agreeable: pleasing. Delightful: delightful. Associated with worldly pleasures:🔽

original: taṇhāsannissitānaṃ kāmūpasañhitānaṃ. Paṭilābhato samanupassatoti “aho mayā imāni🔽laddhānī”ti yathāladdhāni rūpārammaṇādīni assādayato. Atītanti atikkantaṃ. Niruddhanti🔽nirodhappattaṃ. Vipariṇatanti sabhāvavigamena vigataṃ. Samanussaratoti assādanavasena🔽anucintayato. Gehasitanti kāmaguṇanissitaṃ. Kāmaguṇā hi kāmarāgassa gehasadisattā
analyzed: taṇhā sannissitānam kāma upasañhitānam paṭilābhataḥ samanupassato ti aho mayā imāni 🔽laddhāni iti yathā laddhāni rūpa ārammaṇa ādīni assādayataḥ atītanti atikkantam niruddhanti 🔽nirodha ppattam vipariṇatam ti sabhāva vigamena vigatam samanussarato ti assādana vasena 🔽anucintayataḥ geha sitam ti kāma guṇa nissitam kāma guṇāḥ hi kāma rāgassa geha sadisa ttā
translated: In the two sections: in the two sections dealing with what should be cultivated and what should not be cultivated. Such as these: such as lead to the manifestation of the unprofitable and to the disappearance of the profitable. That is called “based on the house life” because it is associated with sense desires. Hence it is said: “The joy based on the house life” . Dear: dear to the mind. Charming: delightful. Pleasing: enhancing the mind. Delightful: delightful to the mind. Associated with worldly material goods: associated with sense desires and dependent on craving. As gain: as “Oh, I have gained these” when enjoying visible forms, etc., as they are gained. Past: gone by. Ceased: reached cessation. Changed: departed through the loss of its individual essence. Recollecting: thinking over them by way of enjoyment. Based on the house life: dependent on the sense desires. For the sense desires are like a house for sensual desire.

original: idha “geha”nti adhippetā.
analyzed: idha adhippetā
translated: Herein, “home” is what is intended.

original: Evarūpanti yaṃ akusalānaṃ parihānāya, kusalānañca abhibuddhiyā saṃvattati, evarūpaṃ,🔽taṃ pana pabbajjādivasena pavattiyā nekkhammūpasañhitanti āha “nekkhammasitaṃ somanassa”nti.
analyzed: yam akusalānam parihānāya kusalānam ca abhibuddhiyā saṃvattati evarūpam  tam pana pabbajja ādi vasena pavattiyā nekkhamma upasañhitanti āha nekkhamma sitam somanassanti
translated: Such: such as leads to the abandoning of the unprofitable and to the arising of the profitable.🔽But that is called “associated with renunciation” because it occurs as renunciation of the home, etc., and so he said “gladness associated with renunciation.”

original: Idāni taṃ pāḷivaseneva dassetuṃ “tattha katamānī”tiādi vuttaṃ. Tattha vipassanālakkhaṇe
analyzed: idāni tam pāḷi vasena iva dassetum tattha katamāni itiādi vuttam tattha vipassanā lakkhaṇe
translated: Now, in order to show that by means of the text of the sutta itself, he said “Herein, what is the kind of happiness that is worldly? ” Herein, the kind of happiness that is worldly is shown by the words “when he is sensitive to the happiness of renunciation” .

original: nekkhamme dassite itarāni tassa kāraṇato, phalato, atthato ca dassitāneva hontīti🔽vipassanālakkhaṇameva taṃ dassento “rūpānantvevā”tiādimāha. Vipariṇāmavirāganirodhanti
analyzed: nekkhamme dassite itarāni tassa kāraṇato phalataḥ atthataḥ ca dassitāna eva honti iti  vipassanā lakkhaṇam eva tam dassentaḥ rūpa anantu eva iti ādim āha vipariṇāma virāga nirodha nti
translated: The other kinds of happiness are shown by the words “when he is sensitive to the happiness of seclusion” , etc., as being respectively the cause, the fruit, and the benefit of that kind of happiness that is worldly.🔽So he said “When he is sensitive to the happiness of renunciation” in order to show the characteristic of that kind of happiness that is worldly.🔽When he is sensitive to the happiness of seclusion, etc., is said in order to show the cause, the fruit, and the benefit of that kind of happiness that is worldly.🔽The words “When he is sensitive to the happiness of seclusion” show the cause of that kind of happiness that is worldly.

original: jarāya vipariṇāmetabbatañceva jarāmaraṇehi palujjanaṃ nirujjhanañca viditvāti yojanā.
analyzed: jarāya vipariṇāmetabbatam ca iva jarā maraṇehi palujjanam nirujjhanam ca viditvā ati yojanā
translated: The words “When he is sensitive to the happiness of the pentad of faculties” show the fruit of that kind of happiness that is worldly.🔽The words “When he is sensitive to the happiness of the stilling of the activities” show the benefit of that kind of happiness that is worldly.🔽The words “When he is sensitive to the happiness of the stilling of applied and sustained thought” show the cause of that kind of happiness that is worldly.

original: Uppajjati somanassanti vipassanāya vīthipaṭipattiyā kamena uppannānaṃ pāmojjapītipassaddhīnaṃ
analyzed: uppajjati somanassa nti vipassanāya vīthi paṭipattiyā kamena uppannānam pāmojja pīti passaddhīnam
translated: The words “When he is sensitive to the happiness of the enlightenment factors” show the fruit of that kind of happiness that is worldly.🔽The words “When he is sensitive to the happiness of the path” show the benefit of that kind of happiness that is worldly.

original: upari anappakaṃ somanassaṃ uppajjati. Yaṃ sandhāya vuttaṃ –
analyzed: upari anappakam somanassam uppajjati yam sandhāya vuttam
translated: and he experiences a measure of joy. It is with reference to this that it was said:🔽“When a monk has entered upon

analyzed: suññāgāram paviṭṭhassa santa cittassa bhikkhuno
translated: The bliss of the heart’s seclusion,🔽He finds delight that is divine

original: Amānusī rati hoti, sammā dhammaṃ vipassato.

translated: In contemplating the Dhamma rightly.

analyzed: nekkhamma vasena āti pabbajja ādi vasena vaṭṭa dukkhataḥ nittharissāmi iti pabbajitum bhikkhūnam

original: dhutaguṇe samādāya vattantassa, kasiṇaparikammādīni karontassa ca yā paṭipatti, sabbā
analyzed: dhuta guṇe samādāya vattantassa kasiṇa parikamma ādīni karontassa ca yā paṭipatti sabbā
translated: He sees it as a den of robbers,🔽As a flood and a hurricane,🔽As a forest thicket and a bramble,🔽As a mass of thorns and a crevasse.

analyzed: katvā anussati vasena āti vatvā paṭhama jhāna ādi vasena āti vuttam ettha ca yathā pabbajjā
translated: As a flood and a hurricane,🔽As a forest thicket and a bramble,🔽As a mass of thorns and a crevasse.🔽He sees it as a dream and a borrowed thing,🔽As a tree and a slaughter post,🔽As a stake and

analyzed: ghara bandhanato nikkhamana ṭṭhena nekkhammam evam vipassanā ādayaḥ api tad paṭipakkhato tena āha
translated: Renunciation is the going forth from the house life, and so on.

original: “Pabbajjā paṭhamaṃ jhānaṃ, nibbānañca vipassanā;
analyzed: pabbajjā paṭhamam jhānam nibbānam ca vipassanā
translated: “Going forth, and the first jhāna, And also Nibbāna, are insight;

analyzed: sabbe pi kusalāḥ dhammāḥ nekkhammanti pavuccara ti
translated: All profitable things are called Renunciation” .🔽And the word “and” in the phrase “renunciation and the first jhāna” is merely conjunctive; it is not meant that the first jhāna is renunciation too.

original: Yaṃ ceti ettha ceti nipātamattaṃ somanassassa adhippetattā. Catukkanayavaseneva ca🔽suttantesu jhānakathāti vuttaṃ “dutiyatatiyajjhānavasenā”ti. Dvīsūti “savitakkaṃ
analyzed: yam ca iti ettha ca iti nipāta mattam somanassassa catukka naya vasena iva ca  suttantesu jhāna kathā iti vuttam dutiya tatiya jhāna vasena ati dvīsu iti sa vitakkam
translated: And it is said in the texts that the jhāna is spoken of in the way it is in the verse because of the fourfold method of doing so.

original: savicāraṃ avitakkaṃ avicāra”nti vuttesu dvīsu somanassesu.
analyzed: sa vicāram a vitakkam a vicāranti vuttesu dvīsu somanassesu
translated: The two kinds of joy are the two kinds of joy spoken of as “accompanied by applied thought and accompanied by sustained thought” and “unaccompanied by applied thought and unaccompanied by sustained thought” .🔽The joy accompanied by applied thought and sustained thought is the joy in the limited sphere or that in the first jhāna.

original: Savitakkasavicāre somanasseti parittabhūmike, paṭhamajjhāne vā somanasse. Abhiniviṭṭhasomanassesūti🔽vipassanaṃ paṭṭhapitasomanassesu. Pi-saddena sammaṭṭhasomanassesu pīti imamatthaṃ
analyzed: sa vitakka sa vicāre somanasse ti paritta bhūmike paṭhamajjhāne vā somanasse abhiniviṭṭha somanassesu  vipassanam paṭṭhapita somanassesu pi saddena sammaṭṭha somanassesu pi iti imamattham
translated: The joy in which he is well established is the joy in which he is well established by insight.🔽The word “and” shows that the joy in which he is well established is the joy in which he is well established by insight.

original: dasseti. Somanassavipassanātopīti savitakkasavicārasomanassapavattivipassanātopi.
analyzed: dasseti somanassa vipassanātaḥ api iti sa vitakka sa vicāra somanassa pavatti vipassanātaḥ api
translated: The joy of insight is the insight that occurs as joy accompanied by applied thought and sustained thought.

original: Avitakkaavicāra vipassanā paṇītatarā sammasitadhammavasenapi vipassanāya visesasiddhito,🔽yato maggepi tathārūpā visesā ijjhanti. Ayaṃ panattho “ariyamagga bojjhaṅgādivisesaṃ
analyzed: avitakka avicāra vipassanā paṇītatarā sammasita dhamma vasena api vipassanāya visesa siddhito  yatas magge pi tathārūpāḥ visesāḥ ijjhanti ayam pana atthaḥ
translated: Insight without thinking and exploring is more excellent than that with thinking and exploring, because it is established as a special kind of insight even by virtue of the state of the dhammas being penetrated.🔽And because such a distinction is possible in the path too.

original: vipassanāya ārammaṇabhūtā khandhā niyamentī”ti evaṃ pavattena moravāpīvāsimahādattattheravādena dīpetabbo.
analyzed: vipassanāya ārammaṇa bhūtā khandhāḥ niyamenti iti evam pavattena mora vāpī vāsi mahādatta thera vādena dīpetabbo
translated: But this meaning should be illustrated by the Elder Mahādatta’s statement, a resident of the Moravāpi Monastery, who expounded it thus: “The aggregates that are the object of insight determine the distinction of the path’s factors of enlightenment, etc.”

original: 361. Gehasitadomanassaṃ nāma kāmaguṇānaṃ appaṭilābhanimittaṃ, vigatanimittañca uppajjanakadomanassaṃ.
analyzed: gehasita domanassam nāma kāma guṇānam appaṭilābha nimittam vigata nimittam ca uppajjanaka domanassam
translated: “Household-bred grief” is grief that arises with the sign of non-gain of the five strands of sense pleasure and with the sign of separation from them.

original: Appaṭilābhato samanupassatoti appaṭilābhena “ahameva na labhāmī”ti paritassanato.
analyzed: appaṭilābhataḥ samanupassato ti appaṭilābhena aham eva na labhāmi iti paritassanato
translated: “As he sees non-gain”: as he worries, “I alone do not get it,” through non-gain.

original: Samanussaratoti “ahu vata me taṃ vata natthī”tiādinā anussaraṇavasena cintayato.
analyzed: samanussarato ti ahu vata me tam vata na atthi iti ādinā anussaraṇa vasena cintayato
translated: “As he recollects”: as he thinks by way of recollecting, “I had it, but now it is not.”

original: Tenāha “evaṃ chasu dvāresū”tiādi.
analyzed: tena āha evam chasu dvāresu itiādi
translated: Hence it is said, “Thus in the six doors” and so on.🔽“In the unsurpassed liberations”: in the noble fruition-liberations beginning with the emptiness fruition.

original: Anuttaresu vimokkhesūti suññataphalādiariyaphalavimokkhesu. Pihanti apekkhaṃ, āsanti
analyzed: anuttaresu vimokkhesu ti suññata phala ādi ariya phala vimokkhesu pihanti apekkham āsanti
translated: He closes the doors: he looks on.

original: attho. Kathaṃ pana lokuttaradhamme ārabbha āsā uppajjatīti? Na kho panetaṃ evaṃ daṭṭhabbaṃ
analyzed: atthaḥ katham pana lokuttara dhamme ārabbha āsā uppajjati iti na kho pana etat evam daṭṭhabbam
translated: What is the meaning? But it should not be regarded in this way.

original: “yaṃ ārammaṇakaraṇavasena tattha pihā pavattatī”ti avisayattā, puggalassa ca anadhigatabhāvato.
analyzed: yam ārammaṇa karaṇa vasena tattha pihā pavattati iti avisaya ttā puggalassa ca anadhigata bhāvato
translated: Because it is not an object, and because the person has not yet acquired it.

original: Anussavūpaladdhe pana anuttaravimokkhe uddissa pihaṃ upaṭṭhapento “tattha pihaṃ upaṭṭhapetī”ti🔽vutto. Tenāha “kudāssu nāmāha”ntiādi. Chasu dvāresu iṭṭhārammaṇe āpāthagate aniccādivasena
analyzed: anussava upaladdhe pana anuttara vimokkhe uddissa piham upaṭṭhapento tattha piham upaṭṭhapeti iti  vuttaḥ tena āha chasu dvāresu iṭṭha ārammaṇe āpātha gate anicca ādi vasena
translated: But when he is establishing longing for the supramundane deliverance that is accepted on the evidence of the scriptures, he is said to be “establishing longing for that.”🔽That is why he says, “When shall I be …?”

original: vipassanaṃ paṭṭhapetvāti yojanā. “Iṭṭhārammaṇe”ti ca iminā nayidaṃ domanassaṃ sabhāvato
analyzed: vipassanam paṭṭhapetvā iti yojanā iṭṭha ārammaṇā iti ca iminā na idam domanassam sabhāvato
translated: The construction should be treated as follows: “When he has established insight by means of the contemplation of impermanence, etc., in a desirable object that has come into the focus of the six bases of contact.”🔽And by the words “in a desirable object” he shows that this grief is not only produced by a disagreeable thing in itself,

original: aniṭṭhadhammeyeva ārabbha uppajjanakaṃ, atha kho icchitālābhahetukaṃ icchābhighātavasena
analyzed: ārabbha uppajjanakam atha kho icchitā lābha hetukam icchā abhighāta vasena
translated: but that it is produced in any object at all by the frustration of desire, which is the cause of the desirable.

original: yattha katthaci ārammaṇe uppajjanakanti dasseti. Evaṃ “kudāssu nāmāha”nti vuttākārena
analyzed: yattha katthaci ārammaṇe uppajjanakanti dasseti evam kudāssu vutta ākārena
translated: So too with the words “When shall I be …?”

original: pihaṃ upaṭṭhapetvā evaṃ imampi pakkhaṃ…pe… nāsakkhinti anusocatoti yojanā. “Imasmiṃ🔽pakkhe, imasmiṃ māse, imasmiṃ saṃvacchare pabbajituṃ nāladdhaṃ, kasiṇaparikammaṃ🔽kātuṃ nāladdha”ntiādivasena pavattiṃ sandhāya “nekkhammavasenā”ti vuttaṃ. “Vipassanāvasenā”tiādīsupi🔽iminā nayena yojanā veditabbā.
analyzed: piham upaṭṭhapetvā evam imam pi pakkhaṃpe na asakkhinti anusocato ti yojanā imasmiṃ  pakkhe imasmin māse imasmin saṃvacchare pabbajitum na āladdham kasiṇa parikammam  kātum na aladdha nti ādi vasena pavattim sandhāya nekkhamma vasena ati vuttam vipassanā vasena ati ādīsu pi  iminā nayena yojanā veditabbā

original: savitakkasavicāraṃ, siyā avitakkaavicāraṃ. Savitakkasavicārasseva kāraṇabhūtaṃ domanassaṃ🔽savitakkasavicāradomanassaṃ. Kiṃ taṃ? Gehasitadomanassaṃ, yaṃ pana nekkhammādivasena
analyzed: sa vitakka sa vicāram siyā avitakka avicāram sa vitakka sa vicārassa iva kāraṇa bhūtam domanassam  sa vitakka sa vicāra domanassam kim tam gehasita domanassam yam pana nekkhamma ādi vasena
translated: and it may be accompanied by applied thought and sustained thought, and it may be without applied thought and sustained thought. The grief that is the cause of that accompanied by applied thought and sustained thought is🔽grief accompanied by applied thought and sustained thought. What is that? The grief that is rooted in the household life. But that which is rooted in renunciation, etc.,🔽🔽

original: uppannaṃ, taṃ avitakkaavicārassa kāraṇabhūtaṃ avitakkaavicāradomanassanti. Ayañca🔽nayo pariyāyavasena vuttoti āha “nippariyāyena panā”tiādi. Yadi evaṃ kasmā “yaṃ ce
analyzed: uppannam tam avitakka avicārassa kāraṇa bhūtam avitakka avicāra domanassanti ayam ca  nayo pariyāya vasena vutto ti āha nippariyāyena pana atiādi yadi evam kasmai yam ce
translated: and it is the cause of the first jhāna accompanied by applied thought and sustained thought, and it is the cause of the second jhāna free from applied thought and sustained thought. The grief that is the cause of the first jhāna accompanied by applied thought and sustained thought is called grief accompanied by applied thought and sustained thought. But that which arises through renunciation, etc., is the cause of the second jhāna free from applied thought and sustained thought and is called grief free from applied thought and sustained thought.

original: avitakkaṃ avicāra”nti pāḷiyaṃ vuttanti āha “etassa panā”tiādi. Maññanavasenāti parikappanavasena. Vuttaṃ pāḷiyaṃ.
analyzed: avitakkam avicāram ti pāḷiyam vuttanti āha etassa pana atiādi maññana vasena ati parikappana vasena vuttam pāḷiyam
translated: This method is stated by way of a roundabout way. That is why he says, “But in the direct way” , etc. If that is so, why is it said in the text, “What is free from applied thought and sustained thought”? That is why he says, “But in the case of this” , etc. By means of conceiving : by means of surmising. The text is quoted.

original: Tatrāti tasmiṃ maññane. Ayaṃ idāni vuccamāno nayo. Domanassapaccayabhūteti domanassassa
analyzed: tatra ati tasmim maññane ayam idāni vuccamānaḥ nayaḥ domanassa paccaya bhūta iti domanassassa
translated: There : in that conceiving. This is the method now being stated.

original: paccayabhūte. Upacārajjhānañhi paṭhamajjhānādīni vā pādakāni katvā maggaphalāni nibbattetukāmassa
analyzed: paccaya bhūte upacāra jhānam hi paṭhama jhāna ādīni vā pādakāni katvā magga phalāni nibbattetu kāmassa
translated: As a cause of grief : as a cause of grief. For the first jhāna, etc., are made the footing for the attainment of the paths and fruits.

original: tesaṃ alābhe domanassassa uppajjane tāni tassa paccayā nāma honti iti te dhammā phalūpacārena🔽“domanassa”nti vuttā. Yo pana tathā uppannadomanasso dhuranikkhepaṃ akatvā anukkamena
analyzed: tesam alābhe domanassassa uppajjane tāni tassa paccayāḥ nāma honti iti te dhammā phala upacārena  domanassanti vuttā yaḥ pana tathā uppanna domanassaḥ dhura nikkhepam a katvā anukkamena
translated: When they arise, they are called conditions for the arising of grief. Thus these states are called grief by way of the proximity of fruit.🔽But when one who has arisen grief does not give up the burden, but develops insight in due course,

original: vipassanaṃ ussukkāpetvā maggaphaladhamme nibbatteti, te kāraṇūpacārena “domanassa”nti
analyzed: vipassanam ussukkāpetvā magga phala dhamme nibbatteti te kāraṇa upacārena domanassanti
translated: and produces the states of the path and fruition, these states are called grief by way of the proximity of cause.

original: vuttāti imamatthaṃ dassento “idha bhikkhū”tiādimāha. Nanu etassa tadā domanassameva
analyzed: vuttā iti imam attham dassentaḥ idha bhikkhu iti ādim āha nanu etassa tadā domanassam eva
translated: The meaning of this is shown by the words “Here a bhikkhu” and so on.

original: uppannaṃ, na domanassahetukā vipassanāmaggaphaladhammā uppannā, tattha kathaṃ domanassasamaññaṃ
analyzed: uppannam na domanassa hetukāḥ vipassanā magga phala dhammāḥ uppannā tattha katham domanassa samaññam
translated: But is not grief itself arisen in him? Are not the states of insight, the path, and fruition arisen with grief as their cause? How then does the Exalted One speak of them as grief by way of the proximity of name?

original: āropetvā voharatīti āha “aññesaṃ paṭipattidassanavasena domanassanti gahetvā”tiādi.
analyzed: āropetvā voharati iti āha aññesam paṭipatti dassana vasena domanassanti gahetvā atiādi
translated: The Exalted One speaks of them in this way by way of showing the practice of others.

original: Savitakkasavicāradomanasseti savitakkasavicāranimitte domanasse. Tīhi māsehi nibbattetabbā
analyzed: sa vitakka sa vicāra domanasse ti sa vitakka sa vicāra nimitte domanasse tīhi māsehi nibbattetabbā
translated: In grief with applied and sustained thought: in grief with applied and sustained thought as object.

original: temāsikā, taṃ temāsikaṃ. Imā ca temāsikādayo paṭipadā tathāpavattaukkaṭṭhamajjhimamudindriyavasena
analyzed: temāsikā tam temāsikam imā ca temāsika ādayaḥ paṭipadā
translated: The three-month one is the three-month one. These three-month and other courses are🔽according to the kind of temperament, whether sharp, medium, or sluggish.

original: veditabbā, adhikamajjhimamudussāhavasena vā. Jaggatīti jāgarikaṃ anuyuñjati.
analyzed: veditabbāḥ adhika majjhimam udussāha vasena vā jaggati iti jāgarikam anuyuñjati
translated: The three-month period: that is three months. These three-month periods, etc., should be understood as the three kinds of conduct classed according to the predominance of the sharp, medium, and sluggish faculties, or according to the predominance of the great, medium, and slight effort. He is intent on the practice of wakefulness: he is intent on the practice of being awake.

original: Mahāsivattheravatthuvaṇṇanā
analyzed: mahāsivatthera vatthu vaṇṇanā
translated: The story of the Elder Mahā-Siva

original: Sahassadvisahassasaṅkhyattā mahāgaṇe.
analyzed: mahā gaṇe
translated: In a great assembly of a thousand or more.

original: Aṭṭhakathātherāti aṭṭhakathāya atthapaṭipucchanakatherā. Antarāmaggeti bhikkhaṃ gahetvā gāmato vihāraṃ paṭigamanamagge. Tayo…pe… gāhāpetvāti tīṇi cattāri uṇhāpanāni.
analyzed: aṭṭhakathā therā ati aṭṭhakathāya attha paṭipucchanaka therā antarāmagge iti bhikkham gahetvā gāmataḥ vihāram paṭigamana magge ta yope gāhāpetvā ati tīṇi cattāri uṇhāpanāni
