translated: The Elder of the Commentary: the elder who was questioned about the meaning of the Commentary. On the way back: on the way back from the village to the monastery after receiving alms. Three or four times: three or four times he heated it.

original: Kenaci papañcenāti kenaci sarīrakiccabhūtena papañcena. Saññaṃ akāsi rattiyaṃ pacchato gacchantaṃ asallakkhento.
analyzed: kenaci papañcena ati kenaci sarīra kicca bhūtena papañcena saññam akāsi rattiyam pacchatas gacchantam a sallakkhento
translated: With some trouble: with some trouble of bodily function. He made a sign to him, not noticing that he was walking behind him at night.

original: Kasmā pana thero antevāsikānaṃ anārocetvāva gatoti āha “thero kirā”tiādi. Arahattaṃ
analyzed: kasmā pana theraḥ antevāsikānam an ārocetvā ava gataḥ iti āha theraḥ kirāti ādi arahattam
translated: But why did the elder go without telling his pupils? “It seems that the elder,” etc.

original: nāma kinti tadadhigamassa adukkarabhāvaṃ sandhāya vadati. Catūhi iriyāpathehīti catūhipi
analyzed: nāma kinti tad adhigamassa adukkara bhāvam sandhāya vadati catūhi iriyāpathehi iti catūhi pi
translated: Attainment of arahatship: he says this because of the ease with which he attained it. In the four postures: in all four postures,

original: iriyāpathehi pavattamānassa, tasmā yāva arahattādhigamā sayanaṃ paṭikkhipāmīti adhippāyo.
analyzed: iriyāpathehi pavattamānassa tasmai yāva arahatta adhigamā sayanam paṭikkhipāmi iti adhippāyaḥ
translated: He had the intention, “I will give up lying down until I reach Arahantship.”

original: “Anucchavikaṃ nu kho te eta”nti saṃvegajāto vīriyaṃ samuttejento arahattaṃ aggahesi ettakaṃ kālaṃ vipassanāya suciṇṇabhāvato ñāṇassa paripākaṃ gatattā.
analyzed: anucchavikam nu kho te etat ti saṃvega jātaḥ vīriyam samuttejentaḥ arahattam aggahesi ettakam kālam vipassanāya su ciṇṇa bhāvataḥ ñāṇassa paripākam gata ttā
translated: “Is it suitable for you?” He aroused energy, thinking, “It is not suitable,” and he reached Arahantship.

original: Parimajjīti parimasi. Keci pana “parimajjīti parivattetvā therena dhoviyamānaṃ pariggahetvā dhovī”ti atthaṃ vadanti.
analyzed: parimajjī iti keci pana parimajjī iti parivattetvā therena dhoviyamānam pariggahetvā dhovī iti attham vadanti
translated: “He rubbed it” means he rubbed it. But some say that the meaning is: “He rubbed it, taking it after the Elder had washed it, turning it over.”

original: Vipassanāya ārammaṇaṃ nāma upacārajjhānapaṭhamajjhānādi.
analyzed: vipassanāyaḥ ārammaṇam nāma upacāra jhāna paṭhama jhāna ādi
translated: The object of insight is the access concentration, the first jhāna, and so on.

original: “Savitakkasavicāradomanasse”tiādīsu vattabbaṃ somanassesu vuttanayānusārena veditabbaṃ.
analyzed: sa vitakka sa vicāra domanassa iti ādīsu vattabbam somanassesu vutta naya anusārena veditabbam
translated: In the case of the words “with applied thought and sustained thought, with happiness and pleasure” and so on, the meaning should be understood in the way already stated under joy .

original: 362. Evarūpāti yā akusalānaṃ abhibuddhiyā, kusalānaṃ parihānāya ca saṃvattati, evarūpā,
analyzed: evarūpā ati yā akusalānam abhibuddhiyā kusalānam parihānāya ca saṃvattati evarūpā
translated: Such as this: such as leads to the manifestation of the unprofitable and to the disappearance of the profitable.🔽But that is called “householder’s equanimity” because it is associated with sense desire.

original: sā pana kāmūpasañhitatāya “gehasitā”ti vuccatīti āha “gehasitaupekkhā”ti. “Bālassā”tiādīsu
analyzed: sā pana kāma upasañhita tāya gehasitā ati vuccati iti āha gehasita aupekkhā ati bālassa ati ādīsu
translated: In the case of the words “of a fool” and so on,

original: bālakaradhammayogato bālassa attahitaparahitabyāmūḷhatāya mūḷhassa puthūnaṃ kilesādīnaṃ
analyzed: bāla kara dhamma yogataḥ bālassa atta hita para hita byāmūḷhatāya mūḍhassa puthūnam kilesa ādīnam
translated: Because of the condition of being a fool, he is a fool because of being confused about what is for his own and others’ welfare. Because of the condition of being confused, he is confused because of the many defilements, etc.,

original: jananādīhi kāraṇehi puthujjanassa kilesodhīnaṃ maggodhīhi ajitattā anodhijinassa,
analyzed: janana ādīhi kāraṇehi puthujjanassa kilesa udhīnam magga udhīhi ajita ttā anodhi jinassa
translated: that arise in him. Because of the condition of being a worldling, he is a worldling because of the condition of not having conquered the defilements and the path.

original: odhijino vāyapekkhā, odhiso ca kilesānaṃ jitattā, tenassa sekkhabhāvaṃ paṭikkhipati.
analyzed: odhijinaḥ ca kilesānam jita ttā tena assa sekkha bhāvam paṭikkhipati
translated: Or he is a worldling because of being one who looks for a conqueror of the defilements, and because of the condition of having conquered the defilements. Thus he denies his state of being a learner.

original: Sattamabhavādito uddhaṃ pavattanavipākassa ajitattā avipākajinassa, vipākajinā vā🔽arahanto appaṭisandhikattā, tenassa asekkhattaṃ paṭikkhipati. Anekādīnave sabbesampi
analyzed: sattama bhava āditas uddham pavattana vipākassa ajita ttā avipāka jinassa vipāka jināḥ vā  arahantaḥ appaṭisandhika ttā tena assa asekkha ttam paṭikkhipati aneka ādīnave sabbesam pi
translated: Because of the condition of not having conquered the ripening of the rebirth-process that occurs after the seventh existence, he is one who has not conquered the ripening. Or he is one who has conquered the ripening because of the condition of having conquered the ripening.🔽He is a perfected one because of the condition of having no more rebirth. Thus he denies his state of being a non-learner. Because of the condition of not seeing the danger in the many kinds of evil states,

original: pāpadhammānaṃ mūlabhūte sammohe ādīnavānaṃ adassanasīlatāya anādīnavadassāvino. Āgamādhigamābhāvā🔽assutavato. Ediso ekaṃsena andhaputhujjano nāma hotīti tassa andhaputhujjanabhāvaṃ
analyzed: pāpa dhammānam mūla bhūte sammohe ādīnavānam a dassana sīla tāya anādīnava dassāvinaḥ āgama adhigama abhāvā  assutavataḥ edisaḥ ekaṃsena andhaputhujjanaḥ nāma hoti iti tassa andhaputhujjana bhāvam
translated: he is one who does not see the danger. Because of the condition of not seeing the danger in the root of all evil states, namely, confusion, he is one who does not see the danger. Because of the condition of not having the knowledge that comes from the scriptures and from realization,🔽he is one who has not heard. Thus he is called a blind worldling in the sense of being one who is completely blind. In order to show that he is a blind worldling,

original: dassetuṃ punapi “puthujjanassā”ti vuttaṃ. Evarūpāti vuttappakārā sammohapubbikā.
analyzed: dassetum puna api puthujjanassa iti vuttam evarūpā ati vutta ppakārā sammoha pubbikā
translated: it is said again: “of the worldling.” Such a one is one who is confused in the way described above.

original: Rūpaṃ sā nātivattatīti rūpānaṃ samatikkamanāya kāraṇaṃ na hoti, rūpārammaṇe kilese🔽nātikkamatīti adhippāyo. Aññāṇāvibhūtatāya ārammaṇe ajjhupekkhanavasena pavattamānā🔽lobhasampayuttaupekkhā idhādhippetāti tassa lobhassa anucchavikameva ārammaṇaṃ dassento🔽“iṭṭhārammaṇe”ti āha. Anativattamānā anādīnavadassitāya. Tato eva assādānupassanato
analyzed: rūpam sā na ativattati iti rūpānam samatikkamanāya kāraṇam na hoti rūpa ārammaṇe kilese  na atikkamati iti adhippāyaḥ aññāṇa avibhūta tāya ārammaṇe ajjhupekkhana vasena pavattamānā  lobha sampayuttā aupekkhā idha adhippetā ti tassa lobhassa anucchavikam eva ārammaṇam dassento  iṭṭha ārammaṇā iti āha an ativattamānā anādīnava dassitāya tatas eva assāda anupassanato
translated: It does not transcend form: it is not a cause for the surmounting of form. The intention is that it does not transcend the defilements that have form as their object.🔽The equanimity associated with greed that occurs by way of looking on indifferently at the object because of the non-penetration of the object is intended here.🔽Thus, showing an object that is suitable to that greed, he said, “with regard to an agreeable object.” It does not transcend because of the non-seeing of danger.

original: tattheva laggā. Abhisaṅgassa lobhassa vasena, dummocanīyatāya ca tena laggitā viya hutvā uppannā.
analyzed: tattha iva laggā abhisaṅgassa lobhassa vasena dummocanīya tāya ca tena laggitā viya hutvā uppannā
translated: Because of that, it is attached to the object by way of contemplation of gratification.

original: Evarūpāti yā akusalānaṃ pahānāya, kusalānañca abhibuddhiyā saṃvattati, evarūpā, sā🔽pana pabbajjādivasena pavattiyā nekkhammūpasañhitāti āha “nekkhammasitā”ti. Idāni
analyzed: evarūpā ati yā akusalānam pahānāya kusalānam ca abhibuddhiyā saṃvattati evarūpā sā  pana pabbajja ādi vasena pavattiyā nekkhamma upasañhitā ti āha nekkhamma sitā ti idāni
translated: Such: such as leads to the abandoning of the unwholesome and the development of the wholesome.

original: taṃ pāḷivasena dassetuṃ “tattha katamā”tiādi vuttaṃ, tassattho heṭṭhā vuttanayānusārena
analyzed: tam pāḷi vasena dassetum tattha katamā tiādi vuttam tassa atthaḥ heṭṭhā vutta naya anusārena
translated: That renunciation is associated with renunciation because of its occurrence by way of going forth, etc. Thus he said, “associated with renunciation.” Now, in order to show that by way of the text, he said, “Herein, what is …?” The meaning of that should be understood by the method stated below.

original: veditabbo. Rūpaṃ sā ativattatīti rūpasmiṃ sammadeva ādīnavadassanato. Rūpaniyātāti🔽kilesehi anabhibhavanīyato. Iṭṭheti sabhāvato, saṅkappato ca iṭṭhe ārammaṇe. Arajjantassāti🔽na rajjantassa rāgaṃ anuppādentassa. Aniṭṭhe adussantassāti ettha vuttanayena attho
analyzed: veditabbaḥ rūpam sā ativattati iti rūpasmim sammat eva ādīnava dassanato rūpa niyātā ati  kilesehi an abhibhavanīyataḥ iṭṭhā iti sabhāvato saṅkappato ca iṭṭhe ārammaṇe a rajjantassa ati  na rajjantassa rāgam an uppādentassa aniṭṭhe a dussantassa ettha vutta nayena atthaḥ
translated: and should be understood. “She has gone beyond form”: she has seen the danger in it correctly. “She has reached the ending of form”:🔽because she is not overcome by defilements. “She is not excited by what is pleasing”: by a pleasing object as such and as a concept. “She does not hate what is unpleasing”:

original: veditabbo. Samaṃ sammā yoniso na pekkhanaṃ asamapekkhanaṃ, taṃ pana iṭṭhāniṭṭhamajjhatte🔽viya iṭṭhāniṭṭhesupi bālassa hotīti “iṭṭhāniṭṭhamajjhatte”ti avatvā “asamapekkhanena
analyzed: veditabbaḥ samam sammā yonisas na pekkhanam a sama pekkhanam tam pana iṭṭha aniṭṭha majjhatte  viya iṭṭha aniṭṭhesu pi bālassa hoti iti iṭṭha aniṭṭham ajjhatta iti avatvā a samapekkhanena
translated: the meaning should be understood as stated in the case of “what is pleasing.” “She does not look with dispassion”: she does not look with equanimity, correctly, properly, wisely. But this is found in the fool in regard to what is pleasing, unpleasing, and neutral,

original: asammuyhantassā”ti vuttaṃ, tividhepi ārammaṇe asamapekkhanavasena muyhantassāti attho.
analyzed: asammuyhantassa ati vuttam tividhe pi ārammaṇe asamapekkhana vasena muyhantassa ati attho
translated: so instead of saying “with dispassion in regard to what is pleasing, unpleasing, and neutral,” it is said “she does not become confused with dispassion.” The meaning is: she does not become confused by looking with dispassion at the three kinds of objects.

original: Vipassanāñāṇasampayuttā upekkhā. Nekkhammasitā upekkhā vedanāsabhāgāti udāsinākārena
analyzed: vipassanā ñāṇa sampayuttā upekkhā upekkhā vedanā sabhāgā ti udāsinā ākārena
translated: Equanimity associated with insight knowledge. Equanimity purified by non-greed is similar to the feeling of equanimity,

original: pavattiyā, upekkhā vedanāya ca sabhāgā. Ettha upekkhā vāti ettha etasmiṃ upekkhāniddese
analyzed: pavattiyā upekkhā vedanāya ca sabhāgā ettha upekkhā vāti ettha etasmin upekkhā niddese
translated: because it occurs in a neutral mode and because it is similar to the feeling of equanimity. “Herein, equanimity” : in this exposition of equanimity.

original: “upekkhā”ti gahitā eva. Tasmāti tatramajjhattupekkhāyapi idha upekkhāggahaṇena gahitattā.
analyzed: upekkhā ati gahitā eva tasmā iti idha upekkhā ggahaṇena
translated: and it is included in the word equanimity.

original: Tañhi sandhāya “paṭhamadutiyatatiyacatutthajjhānavasena uppajjanakaupekkhā”ti vuttaṃ.
analyzed: tat hi sandhāya paṭhama dutiya tatiya catuttha jjhāna vasena uppajjanakā aupekkhā iti vuttam
translated: That is why it is said that the equanimity that arises in the first, second, third, and fourth jhānas is included in the word equanimity.🔽The word “too” is a particle indicating inclusion.

original: Tāyapi nekkhammasitaupekkhāyāti niddhāraṇe bhummaṃ. “Yaṃ nekkhammavasenā”tiādi heṭṭhā vuttanayattā uttā natthameva.
analyzed: tāya api nekkhamma sita aupekkhāya ti niddhāraṇe bhummam yam nekkhamma vasena atiādi heṭṭhā vutta naya ttā uttā nattham eva
translated: “That which is due to renunciation” and so on is not stated because it is already stated below .

original: 363. Yadi sakkassa tadā sotāpattiphalapattiyāva upanissayo, atha kasmā bhagavā yāva
analyzed: yadi sakkassa tadā sotāpatti phala patti yāvā upanissayaḥ atha kasmai bhagavā yāvā
translated: If it is a condition for Sakka’s attainment of the fruit of stream-entry, why did the Exalted One extend his teaching to the attainment of arahatship?

original: arahattaṃ desanaṃ vaḍḍhesīti āha “buddhānañhī”tiādi. Taruṇasakkoti abhinavo adhunā
analyzed: arahattam desanam vaḍḍhesi iti āha abhinavaḥ adhunā
translated: “The Buddhas’ teaching of the Dhamma” and so on is said. “Young Sakka” is a new, recently arisen Sakka.

original: pātubhūto sakko. Sampati pātubhāvañhi sandhāya “taruṇasakko”ti vuttaṃ, na tassa kumāratā,
analyzed: pātubhūto sakko pātubhāvañ hi sandhāya taruṇa sakko iti vuttam na tassa kumāra tā
translated: “Young” is said with reference to his recent appearance, not because he is a youth,🔽for he is neither a youth nor an adult.

original: vuddhatā vā atthi. Gatāgataṭṭhānanti gamanāgamanakāraṇaṃ. Na paññāyati na upalabbhati.
analyzed: vuddha tā vā atthi gata āgata ṭṭhānan ti gamana āgamana kāraṇam na paññāyati na upalabbhati
translated: “The reason for his coming and going” is not known, is not evident.

original: Gabbhaseyyakānañhi cavantānaṃ kammajarūpaṃ vigacchati anudeva cittajaṃ, āhārajañca
analyzed: gabbhaseyyakānam hi cavantānam kamma ja rūpam vigacchati anudā iva citta jam āhāra jañca
translated: For when those who lie in wombs die, the materiality generated by kamma vanishes, and that generated by consciousness and that generated by nutriment vanish subsequently.

original: paccayābhāvato, utujaṃ pana sucirampi kālaṃ paveṇiṃ ghaṭṭentaṃ bhassantaṃ vā sosantaṃ🔽vā kilesantaṃ vā viṭṭhataṃ vā hoti, na evaṃ devānaṃ. Tesañhi opapātikattā kammajarūpe
analyzed: paccaya abhāvataḥ utu jam pana su ciram pi kālam paveṇim ghaṭṭentam bhassantam vā sosantam  vā kilesantam vā viṭṭhatam vā hoti na evam devānam tesam hi opapātika ttā kamma ja rūpe
translated: But that generated by temperature remains for a long time, even though the womb is being pressed, shaken, and heated,

original: antaradhāyante sesatisantatirūpampi tena saddhiṃ antaradhāyati. Tenāha “dīpasikhāgamanaṃ
analyzed: antaradhāyante tena saddhim antaradhāyati tena āha dīpa sikhā gamanam
translated: and even though it is being corrupted, dried up, and scattered. But not so with deities. For because they are spontaneously born, the materiality generated by kamma vanishes in them, and the rest of the continuity of materiality vanishes with it. That is why it is said, “It is like the disappearance of the flame.”

original: viya hotī”ti. Sesadevatā na jāniṃsu punapi sakkattabhāvena tasmiṃyeva ṭhāne nibbattattā.
analyzed: viya hoti iti sesa devatāḥ na jāniṃsu puna api sakkatta bhāvena tasmiṃ yeva ṭhāne nibbatta ttā
translated: The other deities did not know because they were reborn in the same place again with the same status as before.

original: Tīsu ṭhānesūti somanassadomanassaupekkhāvissajjanāvasānaṭṭhānesu. Nibbattitaphalamevāti
analyzed: tīsu ṭhānesu uti somanassa domanassa upekkhā vissajjana avasāna ṭhānesu nibbattita phalam eva ati
translated: In the three instances: in the three instances of the abandoning of joy, grief, and equanimity.

original: sappimhā sappimaṇḍo viya āgamanīyapaṭipadāya nibbattitaphalabhūtaṃ lokuttaramaggaphalameva
analyzed: sappimhā sappi maṇḍaḥ viya āgamanīya paṭipadāya nibbattita phala bhūtam lokuttara magga phalam eva
translated: The fruit that is born: the supramundane path and fruition that are the fruit born of the way of arrival like the butter that is the fruit of the milk.🔽Like a hen: like a hen on the eggs.

original: kathitaṃ. Sakuṇikāya viya kiñci gayhūpagaṃ uppatitvā uḍḍetvā ullaṅghitvā. Assāti
analyzed: kathitam sa kuṇikāya viya kiñci gayhūpagam uppatitvā uḍḍetvā ullaṅghitvā assa ati
translated: Has flown away: has flown away after rising up, after flying, after jumping.

original: maggaphalasaññitassa ariyassa dhammassa.
analyzed: magga phala saññitassa ariyassa dhammassa
translated: of the noble Dhamma called the path and the fruits of the path.

original: Pātimokkhasaṃvaravaṇṇanā
analyzed: pātimokkha saṃvara vaṇṇanā
translated: The virtue of restraint by the Patimokkha

original: 364. Pātimokkhasaṃvarāyāti pātimokkhabhūtasīlasaṃvarāyāti ayamettha atthoti āha “uttamajeṭṭhakasīlasaṃvarāyā”ti.
analyzed: pātimokkha saṃvarāya ati pātimokkha bhūta sīla saṃvarāya ati ayam ettha atthaḥ ti āha uttama jeṭṭhaka sīla saṃvarāya ati
translated: is the virtue of restraint by the Patimokkha, which is the virtue of the class of virtue consisting in restraint. The meaning here is this: “for the sake of the supreme, chief restraint of virtue.”

original: “Pātimokkhasīlañhi sabbasīlato jeṭṭhakasīla”nti dīghavāpīvihāravāsi sumatthero vadati,
analyzed: pātimokkha sīlam hi sabba sīlataḥ jeṭṭhaka sīlanti dīgha vāpīvihāra vāsi suma theraḥ vadati
translated: For the elder Sumana, resident at the Dīghavāpi monastery, said: “The virtue of the Patimokkha is the chief virtue of all kinds of virtue.”

original: antevāsiko panassa tepiṭakacūḷanāgatthero “pātimokkhasaṃvaro eva sīlaṃ, itarāni pana
analyzed: antevāsikaḥ pana assa tepiṭaka cūḷanāga thero pātimokkha saṃvaraḥ eva sīlam itarāni pana
translated: But his pupil, the elder Cūḷanāga, who also belonged to the Dīghavāpi monastery and was a master of the three Piṭakas, said: “Only the restraint of the Patimokkha is virtue. The other two kinds of virtue

original: ‘sīlanti vuttaṭṭhānaṃ nāma atthī’ti ananujānanto indriyasaṃvaro nāma chadvārarakkhāmattakaṃ,
analyzed: sīlanti vutta ṭṭhānam nāma atthi iti an anujānanto indriya saṃvaro nāma cha dvāra rakkhāmattakam
translated: are not admitted as virtue. The restraint of the faculties is merely the guarding of the six sense doors;

original: ājīvapārisuddhi dhammena samena paccayuppādanamattakaṃ, paccayasannissitaṃ paṭiladdhapaccaye
analyzed: ājīva pārisuddhi dhammena samena paccaya uppādana mattakam paccaya sannissitam paṭiladdha paccaye
translated: the purification of livelihood is merely the proper search for requisites;

original: ‘ida mattha’nti paccavekkhitvā paribhuñjanamattakaṃ, nippariyāyena pātimokkhasaṃvarova
analyzed: ida mattha nti paccavekkhitvā paribhuñjana mattakam nippariyāyena pātimokkha saṃvaraḥ uva
translated: the use of the requisites is merely the use of requisites obtained in such a way, after reviewing them thus: ‘This is allowable for me.’🔽In the strict sense of the word, only the restraint of the Patimokkha is virtue.

original: sīlaṃ. Tathā hi yassa so bhinno, so itarāni rakkhituṃ abhabbattā asīlo hoti. Yassa🔽pana sabbaso arogo sesānaṃ rakkhituṃ bhabbattā sampannasīlo”ti vadati, tasmā itaresaṃ
analyzed: sīlam tathā hi yassa so bhinno so itarāni rakkhitum abhabba ttā asīlaḥ hoti yassa  pana sabbasas arogaḥ sesānam rakkhitum bhabbattā sampanna sīlaḥ ti vadati tasmai itaresam
translated: For one whose virtue is broken is unable to guard the other three, and so he is one of bad virtue.🔽But one whose virtue is intact is able to guard the other three, and so he is one of perfect virtue.

original: tassa parivārabhāvato, sabbaso ekadesena ca tadantogadhabhāvato tadeva padhānasīlaṃ🔽nāmāti āha “uttamajeṭṭhakasīlasaṃvarāyā”ti. Tattha yathā heṭṭhā papañcasaññāsaṅkhānirodhasāruppagāminiṃ🔽paṭipadaṃ pucchitena bhagavatā papañcasaññānaṃ, paṭipadāya ca mūlabhūtaṃ vedanaṃ
analyzed: tassa parivāra bhāvato sabbasas ekadesena ca tad antogadha bhāvato tat eva padhāna sīlam  nāma iti āha uttama jeṭṭhaka sīla saṃvarāya ti tattha yathā heṭṭhā papañca saññā saṅkhā nirodha sāruppa gāminim  paṭipadam pucchitena bhagavatā papañca saññānam paṭipadāya ca mūla bhūtam vedanam
translated: Therefore, since the other three are its retinue, and since they are included within it either wholly or in part, virtue is called the principal.🔽Hence it is said, “for the restraint of the highest virtue.”

original: vibhajitvā paṭipadā desitā sakkassa ajjhāsayavasena saṃkilesadhammappahānamukhena
analyzed: vibhajitvā paṭipadā desitā sakkassa ajjhāsaya vasena saṃkilesa dhamma ppahāna mukhena
translated: Herein, just as when the Blessed One was asked about the way leading to the cessation of perception and attention, he expounded the way by analyzing feeling, which is the root of perception and attention, and the way was taught by him in terms of the abandoning of defiling things and the fulfilling of purifying things in accordance with the inclination of the questioner Sakka,

original: vodānadhammapāripūrīti, evaṃ tassā eva paṭipadāya mūlabhūtampi sīlasaṃvaraṃ pucchitena🔽bhagavatā yato so visujjhati, yathā ca visujjhati, tadubhayaṃ sakkassa ajjhāsayavasena
analyzed: vodāna dhamma pāripūrī iti evam tassaḥ eva paṭipadāya mūla bhūtam pi sīla saṃvaram pucchitena 🔽bhagavatā yatas saḥ visujjhati yathā ca visujjhati tat ubhayam sakkassa ajjhāsaya vasena
translated: so too, when he was asked about the restraint of virtue, which is the root of the way, he expounded the way by analyzing virtue, and the way was taught by him in terms of the abandoning of defiling things and the fulfilling of purifying things in accordance with the inclination of the questioner Sakka.

original: vibhajitvā dassetuṃ “kāyasamācārampī”tiādi vuttaṃ saṃkilesadhammappahānamukhena vodānadhammapāripūrīti
analyzed: vibhajitvā dassetum kāya samācāram pi itiādi vuttam saṃkilesa dhamma ppahāna mukhena vodāna dhamma pāripūrī ti
translated: and in order to show the division he says “wrong bodily conduct” and so on.🔽The fulfilment of the purification ideas is by way of abandoning the defilement ideas.🔽The reason for the teaching of the wrong bodily conduct, etc., in the discussion of virtue has already been given.

original: katvā. Sīlakathāyaṃ asevitabbakāyasamācārādikathane kāraṇaṃ vuttameva, tasmā kammapathavasenāti
analyzed: katvā sīla kathā ayam asevitabba kāya samācāra ādi kathane kāraṇam vuttam eva tasmai kamma patha vasena ati
translated: Therefore by way of the paths of action means

original: kusalākusalakammapathavasena.
analyzed: kusala akusala kammapatha vasena
translated: by way of the profitable and unprofitable paths of action.🔽And by way of the paths of action means by way of the investigation of the paths of action.

original: Kammapathavasenāti ca kammapathavicāravasena. Kammapathabhāvaṃ apattānampi hi kāyaduccaritādīnaṃ
analyzed: kammapatha vasena ati ca kammapatha vicāra vasena kammapatha bhāvam apattānam pi hi kāya duccarita ādīnam
translated: For although bodily misconduct, etc., do not reach the state of being a path of action,🔽their being wrong bodily conduct, etc., is mentioned here.

original: asevitabbakādīnaṃ asevitabbakāyasamācārādibhāvo idha vuccatīti. Paṇṇattivasenāti
analyzed: asevitabbaka ādīnam asevitabba kāyasamācāra ādi bhāvaḥ idha vuccati iti paṇṇatti vasena ati
translated: By way of the terms means🔽by way of the terms of the training precepts.

original: sikkhāpadapaṇṇattivasena. Yato yato hi yā yā veramaṇī, tadubhayepi vibhāvento paṇṇattivasena
analyzed: sikkhāpada paṇṇatti vasena yatas yatas hi yā yā veramaṇī tat ubhaye api vibhāventaḥ paṇṇatti vasena
translated: For whatever abstention is from whatever, when he distinguishes both, he is said to teach “by way of the terms.”

original: katheti nāma. Tenāha “kāyadvāre”tiādi. Sikkhāpadaṃ vītikkamati etenāti sikkhāpadavītikkamo,
analyzed: kathā iti nāma tena āha kāya dvāra itiādi sikkhāpadam vītikkamati etena ati sikkhāpada vītikkamaḥ
translated: Hence he said “in the door of the body” and so on.🔽The unprofitable idea that occurs in the mode of transgressing the training precepts is the wrong bodily conduct, etc.,

original: sikkhāpadassa vītikkamanākārena pavatto akusaladhammo yaṃ, tassa asevitabbakāyasamācārāditā.
analyzed: sikkhāpadassa vītikkamana ākārena pavattaḥ akusala dhammaḥ yam tassa a sevitabba kāya samācāra ādi tā
translated: which are the wrong bodily conduct, etc.

original: Vītikkamapaṭipakkho avītikkamo, na vītikkamati etenāti avītikkamo, sīlaṃ.
analyzed: vītikkama paṭipakkhaḥ a vītikkamaḥ na vītikkamati etena ati a vītikkamaḥ sīlam
translated: Non-transgression is the opposite of transgression. It is non-transgression because it does not transgress.🔽It is a search because it searches for what is right and wrong. It is a search for livelihood because it searches for requisites. It is a search for requisites because it searches for requisites. It is a search for requisites because it searches for requisites such as robes, etc., which are necessary for the endurance of one who has entered upon the way.

original: Micchā sammā ca pariyesati etāyāti pariyesanā, ājīvo, atthato paccayagavesanabyāpāro🔽kāyavacīdvāriko. Yadi evaṃ kasmā visuṃ gahaṇanti āha “yasmā”tiādi. Ariyā niddosā
analyzed: micchā sammā ca pariyesati etāya ati pariyesanā ājīvaḥ atthataḥ paccaya gavesana byāpāro  kāyavacī dvārikaḥ yadi evam kasmai āha ariyāḥ niddosā
translated: It is a search for requisites because it searches for requisites such as robes, etc., which are necessary for the endurance of one who has entered upon the way.🔽It is a search for requisites because it searches for requisites such as robes, etc., which are necessary for the endurance of one who has entered upon the way.

original: pariyesanā gavesanāti ariyapariyesanā, ariyehi sādhūhi pariyesitabbātipi ariyapariyesanāti.🔽Vuttavipariyāyato anariyapariyesanā veditabbā.🔽Jātidhammoti jāyanasabhāvo jāyanapakatiko. Jarādhammoti jīraṇasabhāvo. Byādhidhammoti
analyzed: pariyesanā gavesanā ati ariya pariyesanā ariyehi sādhūhi pariyesitabbā atipi ariya pariyesanā ati  vutta vipariyāyataḥ anariya pariyesanā veditabbā  jāti dhammo ti jāyana sabhāvaḥ jāyana pakatikaḥ jarā dhammo ti jīraṇa sabhāvaḥ byādhi dhammo ti
translated: It is a search for requisites because it searches for requisites such as robes, etc., which are necessary for the endurance of one who has entered upon the way.🔽It is a search for requisites because it searches for requisites such as robes, etc., which are necessary for the endurance of one who has entered upon the way.🔽It is a search for requisites because it searches for requisites such as robes, etc., which are necessary for the endurance of one who has entered upon the way.🔽It is a search for requisites because it searches for requisites such as robes, etc., which are necessary for the endurance of one who has entered upon the way.

original: byādhisabhāvo. Maraṇadhammoti mīyanasabhāvo. Sokadhammoti socanakasabhāvo. Saṃkilesadhammoti🔽saṃkilissanasabhāvo.
analyzed: byādhi sabhāvaḥ maraṇa dhammo ti mīyana sabhāvaḥ soka dhammo ti socanaka sabhāvaḥ saṃkilesa dhammo ti  saṃkilissana sabhāvaḥ
translated: It is a search for requisites because it searches for requisites such as robes, etc., which are necessary for the endurance of one who has entered upon the way.🔽It is a search for requisites because it searches for requisites such as robes, etc., which are necessary for the endurance of one who has entered upon the way.🔽It is a search for requisites because it searches for requisites such as robes, etc., which are necessary for the endurance of one who has entered upon the way.🔽It is a search for requisites because it searches for requisites such as robes, etc., which are necessary for the endurance of one who has entered upon the way.🔽It is a search for requisites because it searches for requisites such as robes, etc., which are necessary for the endurance of one who has entered upon the way.

original: Puttabhariyanti puttā ca bhariyā ca. Esa nayo sabbattha. Dvandekattavasena tesaṃ
analyzed: putta bhariyanti puttā ca bhariyā ca esa nayo sabbattha dvand ekatta vasena tesam
translated: It is a search for requisites because it searches for requisites such as robes, etc., which are necessary for the endurance of

original: niddeso. Jātarūparajatanti ettha pana yato vikāraṃ anāpajjitvā sabbaṃ jātarūpameva🔽hotīti jātarūpaṃ nāma suvaṇṇaṃ. Dhavalasabhāvatāya rajatīti rajataṃ, rūpiyaṃ. Idha🔽pana suvaṇṇaṃ ṭhapetvā yaṃ kiñci upabhogaparibhogārahaṃ “rajata”ntveva gahitaṃ vohārūpagamāsakādi.🔽Jātidhammā hete, bhikkhave, upadhayoti ete kāmaguṇūpadhayo nāma honti, te sabbepi🔽jātidhammāti dasseti.
analyzed: niddesaḥ jātarūpa rajatanti ettha pana yatas vikāram an āpajjitvā sabbam jātarūpam eva  hoti iti jātarūpam nāma suvaṇṇam dhavala sabhāvatāya rajati iti rajatam  pana suvaṇṇam ṭhapetvā yam kiñci upabhoga paribhoga araham gahitam  jāti dhammāḥ ha ete bhikkhave upadhayaḥ ti ete kāmaguṇūpadhayaḥ nāma honti te sabbe pi  jāti dhammā ati dasseti
translated: The exposition. As to ‘gold and silver’: here gold is the colour that is not subject to change,🔽and is called ‘gold’. Silver is the colour that is white by nature, and is called ‘silver’. But here🔽‘silver’ is taken to mean any kind of metal fit for use, such as copper, lead, tin, and so on,🔽except gold. ‘These acquisitions, bhikkhus, are subject to birth’: these are called ‘sensual-pleasure acquisitions’, and he shows that all of them are subject to birth.

original: Byādhidhammavārādīsu jātarūparajataṃ na gahitaṃ. Na hetassa sīsarogādayo byādhayo🔽nāma santi, na sattānaṃ viya cutisaṅkhātaṃ maraṇaṃ, na soke uppajjati, cutisaṅkhātaṃ
analyzed: byādhi dhamma vāra ādīsu jātarūpa rajatam na gahitam na sīsa roga ādayaḥ byādhayaḥ  nāma santi na sattānam viya cuti saṅkhātam maraṇam na soke uppajjati cuti saṅkhātam
translated: The exposition. As to ‘gold and silver’: here gold is the colour of the refined metal which is called ‘suvaṇṇa’ (lit. ‘well-burnt’); silver is the colour of the metal which is called ‘rajata’ because it ‘shines’ . But here ‘silver’ is taken as any metal fit for use and trade, such as ‘vohārūpa’ , ‘gamāsa’ , etc., leaving aside gold. ‘These, bhikkhus, are the properties that are subject to birth’: these are called the ‘properties of the five strands of sense pleasure’ . He shows that all of them are subject to birth. As to the section on ‘subject to sickness’ and so on, gold and silver are not included. For they have no sickness called ‘head-sickness’ , etc.,

original: maraṇanti ca ekabhavapariyāpannakhandhanirodho, so tassa natthi, khaṇikanirodho pana
analyzed: maraṇam ti ca eka bhava pariyāpanna khandha nirodho so tassa natthi khaṇika nirodho pana
translated: nor do they have death called ‘falling away’ , as living beings do. Nor does grief arise in them. ‘Death called falling away’ is the cessation of aggregates included in a single becoming. That does not exist in them. But there is momentary cessation.

original: khaṇe khaṇe labbhateva. Rāgādīhi pana saṃkilesehi saṃkilissatīti saṃkilesadhammavāre🔽gahitaṃ jātarūpaṃ, tathā utusamuṭṭhānattā jātidhammavāre, malaṃ gahetvā jīraṇato
analyzed: khaṇe khaṇe labbha tā iva rāga ādīhi pana saṃkilesehi saṃkilissati iti saṃkilesa dhamma vāre  gahitam jātarūpam tathā utu samuṭṭhāna ttā jāti dhamma vāre malam gahetvā jīraṇato
translated: It is available at every moment. But it is defiled by defilements such as greed, etc., and so it is included in the section on the states that are defiled.🔽The gold that is taken is like that. And because it arises by temperature it is included in the section on the states that are subject to birth. And because it is worn out by taking in dirt, it is included in the section on the states that are subject to ageing.

original: jarādhammavāre ca. Ariyehi na araṇīyā, pariyesanātipi anariyapariyesanā.
analyzed: jarā dhamma vāre ca ariyehi na araṇīyā anariya pariyesanā
translated: It is not to be sought by the noble ones, thus it is the wrong kind of search.

original: Idāni anesanāvasenāpi taṃ dassetuṃ “apicā”tiādi vuttaṃ. Iminā nayena sukkapakkhepi attho veditabbo.
analyzed: idāni anesanā vasena api tam dassetum api ca atiādi vuttam iminā nayena sukka pakkhe pi atthaḥ veditabbo
translated: Now, in order to show it also by way of the absence of search, etc., it is said: “Besides,” etc. The meaning should be understood in this way in the bright side too.

original: Sambhārapariyesanaṃ paharaṇavisādigavesanaṃ, payogavasena payogakaraṇaṃ tajjāvāyāmajananaṃ
analyzed: sambhāra pariyesanam paharaṇa visādi gavesanam payoga vasena payoga karaṇam tajjā āyāma jananam
translated: The search for requisites, the search for information about the directions, etc., the act of using, the act of making use, the arousing of the corresponding effort,

original: tādisaṃ upakkamanibbattanaṃ, pāṇātipātādiatthaṃ gamanaṃ, paccekaṃ kāla-saddo yojetabbo
analyzed: tādisam upakkama nibbattanam pāṇātipāta ādi attham gamanam paccekam kāla saddaḥ yojetabbaḥ
translated: the undertaking of such a search, the going for the purpose of killing breathing things, etc., the word “time” should be construed with each

original: “sambhārapariyesanakālato paṭṭhāya, payogakaraṇakālato paṭṭhāya, gamanakālato paṭṭhāyā”ti.
analyzed: sambhāra pariyesana kālataḥ paṭṭhāya payoga karaṇa kālataḥ paṭṭhāya gamana kālataḥ paṭṭhāya ati
translated: as “from the time of the search for requisites,” “from the time of the act of using,” “from the time of the going.”

original: Itaroti “sevitabbo”ti vuttakāyasamācārādiko. Cittampi uppādetabbaṃ. Tathā uppāditacitto
analyzed: itaraḥ ti sevitabbo ti vutta kāya samācāra ādiko cittam api uppādetabbam tathā uppādita cittaḥ
translated: The other is the bodily conduct, etc., described as “to be cultivated.” The mind too should be aroused. Having aroused the mind in this way,

original: hi sati paccayasamavāye tādisaṃ payogaṃ parakkamaṃ karonto paṭipattiyā matthakaṃ
analyzed: hi sati paccaya samavāye tādisam payogam parakkamam karonto paṭipattiyā matthakam
translated: When the conditions are present, one who makes such an effort and undertakes such a practice reaches the summit of the practice.

original: gaṇhāti. Tenāha “cittuppādampi kho ahaṃ, bhikkhave, kusalesu dhammesu bahupakāraṃ vadāmī”ti.
analyzed: gaṇhāti tena āha citta uppādam pi kho aham bhikkhave kusalesu dhammesu bahu pakāram vadāmi iti
translated: That is why it is said: “I say that the arising of a thought of sense desire is of great benefit in wholesome states” .

original: Idāni taṃ matthakappattaṃ asevitabbaṃ, sevitabbañca dassetuṃ “apicā”tiādi vuttaṃ.
analyzed: idāni tam matthaka ppattam asevitabbam sevitabbam ca dassetum api ca itiādi vuttam
translated: Now, in order to show that which has reached the summit and should be cultivated and that which should not be cultivated, the following is stated: “Besides, bhikkhus, there are these two kinds of search: the noble search and the ignoble search” .🔽By the word “etc.” in the phrase “the schism in the Sangha, etc.,” the causing of blood to flow from a Buddha, etc., is included.

original: Saṅghabhedādīnanti ādi-saddena lohituppādanādiṃ saṅgaṇhāti. Buddharatanasaṅgharatanupaṭṭhāneheva
analyzed: saṅgha bheda ādīn anti ādi saddena lohita uppādana ādim saṅgaṇhāti buddha ratana saṅgha ratana upaṭṭhānā iha iva
translated: The establishment of the Dhamma jewel is accomplished by the establishment of the Buddha jewel and the Sangha jewel.

original: dhammaratanupaṭṭhānasiddhīti āha “divasassa dvattikkhattuṃ tiṇṇaṃ ratanānaṃ upaṭṭhānagamanādivasenā”ti.
analyzed: dhamma rata nupaṭṭhāna siddhi iti āha divasassa dvatti khattum tiṇṇam ratanānam upaṭṭhāna gamana ādi vasena ati
translated: That is why it is said: “By going out to attend to the three jewels twenty-four times a day, etc.”

original: Dhanuggahapesanaṃ dhanuggahapurisānaṃ uyyojanaṃ. Ādi-saddena pañcavarayācanādiṃ saṅgaṇhāti.
analyzed: dhanuggaha pesanam dhanuggaha purisānam uyyojanam ādi saddena pañca vara yācanā ādim saṅgaṇhāti
translated: The dispatching of archers is the sending out of archers. By the word “etc.” the asking for the five favours, etc., is included.

original: “Ajātasattuṃ pasādetvā lābhuppādavasena parihīnalābhasakkārassa kulesu viññāpana”nti
analyzed: ajāta sattum pasādetvā lābha uppāda vasena parihīna lābha sakkārassa kulesu viññāpananti
translated: “Having satisfied Ajatasattu, the announcement to the families of one who has lost his gains and honour through the arising of gains” .

original: evamādiṃ anariyapariyesanaṃ pariyesantānaṃ.
analyzed: evamādim an ariya pariyesanam pariyesantānam
translated: The search for what is unbeneficial is the search of those who are seeking in this way.

original: Pāripūriyāti pāripūriatthaṃ. Aggamaggaphalavaseneva hi sevitabbānaṃ pāripūrīti tadatthaṃ
analyzed: pāripūriyā iti pāripūri attham agga magga phala vasena iva hi sevitabbānam pāripūrī iti tad attham
translated: For fulfilment: for the sake of fulfilment. For it is only by means of the noble path and fruition that the fulfilment of what should be cultivated comes about.

original: sabbā pubbabhāgapaṭipadā, pātimokkhasaṃvaropi aggamaggeneva paripuṇṇo hotīti tadatthaṃ
analyzed: sabbā pubbabhāga paṭipadā pātimokkha saṃvaraḥ api agga maggena iva paripuṇṇaḥ hoti iti tad attham
translated: So it is for the sake of that.

original: pubbabhāgapaṭipadaṃ vatvā nigamento “pātimokkho…pe… hotī”ti āha.
analyzed: pubbabhāga paṭipadam vatvā nigamento hoti iti āha
translated: Having stated the preliminary training, he concluded with the words “for the sake of restraint by the Pāṭimokkha” .

original: Indriyasaṃvaravaṇṇanā
analyzed: indriya saṃvara vaṇṇanā
translated: The explanation of restraint of the sense faculties

original: 365. Indriyānaṃ pidhānāyāti indriyānaṃ pidahanatthāya. Indriyāni ca cakkhādīni dvārāni,
analyzed: indriyānam pidhānāya ati indriyānam pidahana atthāya indriyāni ca cakkha ādīni dvārāni
translated: For the restraint of the faculties: for the purpose of restraining the faculties. And the faculties are the eye, etc., which are the doors,

original: tesaṃ pidhānaṃ saṃvaraṇaṃ akusaluppattito gopanāti āha “guttadvāratāyā”ti. Asevitabbarūpādivasena
analyzed: tesam pidhānam saṃvaraṇam akusala uppattitaḥ gopanā iti āha gutta dvāra tāya iti a sevitabba rūpa ādi vasena
translated: the restraint of them is the guarding of them by preventing the arising of unprofitable things. Hence he said “for the guarding of the doors of the sense faculties.”🔽The unguardedness of the faculties by way of the visible data, etc., that should not be seen, etc.,

original: indriyesu aguttadvāratā asaṃvaro, saṃkilesadhammavippahānavasena vodānadhammapārisuddhīti.🔽Kāmaṃ pāḷiyaṃ asevitabbampi rūpādi dassitaṃ, sakkena pana indriyasaṃvarāya paṭipatti
analyzed: indriyesu a gutta dvāra tā asaṃvaro saṃkilesa dhamma vippahāna vasena vodāna dhamma pārisuddhi iti 🔽kāmam pāḷiyam a sevitabbam pi rūpa ādi dassitam sakkena pana indriya saṃvarāya paṭipatti
translated: is unrestraint. The purification by cleansing is the abandoning of things that defile and the perfecting of things that cleanse.

original: pucchitāti tameva nivattetvā dassetuṃ aṭṭhakathāyaṃvuttaṃ “cakkhuviññeyyaṃ rūpampītiādi
analyzed: pucchitā ti tam eva nivattetvā dassetum aṭṭhakathā yaṃvuttam cakkhu viññeyyam rūpam pi itiādi
translated: “Asked” : this is said in the commentary to show that he turned back and pointed out the same object.🔽“The words ‘visible forms cognizable by the eye’ are said for the purpose of showing restraint of the faculties by way of the visible forms, etc., that should be cultivated.”

original: sevitabbarūpādivasena indriyasaṃvaradassanatthaṃ vutta”nti. “Tuṇhī ahosī”ti vatvā
analyzed: sevitabba rūpa ādi vasena indriya saṃvara dassana attham vuttanti tuṇhī ahosi iti vatvā
translated: After saying “he was silent,”🔽in order to show the reason for his silence by way of a supplementary explanation, it is said, “although desirous of speaking.”

original: tuṇhībhāvassa kāraṇaṃ byatirekamukhena vibhāvetuṃ “kathetukāmopī”tiādi vuttaṃ. Ayanti sakko devānaṃ indo.
analyzed: tuṇhībhāvassa kāraṇam byatireka mukhena vibhāvetum kathetu kāmaḥ api itiādi vuttaṃ ayanti sakkaḥ devānam indo
translated: “He” is Sakka, lord of the devas.

original: Rūpanti rūpāyatanaṃ, tassa asevanaṃ nāma adassanaṃ evāti āha “na sevitabbaṃ na daṭṭhabba”nti.
analyzed: rūpam ti rūpa āyatanam tassa asevanam nāma adassanam eva ati āha na sevitabbam na daṭṭhabbam ti
translated: “Visible forms” is the visible form base. The non-cultivation of it is the non-seeing of it. Thus it is said: “should not be cultivated, should not be seen.”

original: Yaṃ pana sattasantānagataṃ rūpaṃ passato paṭikūlamanasikāravasena, asubhasaññā vā
analyzed: yam pana satta santāna gatam rūpam passato paṭikūla manasikāra vasena asubha saññā vā
translated: But when one sees visible forms belonging to the life-continuum, the perception of foulness is established by way of the contemplation of the repulsive,

original: saṇṭhāti dassanānuttariyavasena. Atha vā kammaphalasaddahanavasena pasādo vā uppajjati.
analyzed: saṇṭhāti dassana anuttariya vasena atha vā kamma phala saddahana vasena pasādaḥ vā uppajjati
translated: or faith arises by way of the excellence of seeing, through the conviction that it is the result of kamma.

original: Hutvā abhāvākārasallakkhaṇena aniccasaññāpaṭilābho vā hoti.
analyzed: hutvā abhāva ākāra sallakkhaṇena anicca saññā paṭilābhaḥ vā hoti
translated: Or the acquisition of the perception of impermanence occurs through the characteristic of dissolution, which is the mode of destruction.

original: Pariyāyakkharaṇato akkharaṃ, vaṇṇo, so eva nirantaruppattiyā samuddito padavākyasaññito,
analyzed: pariyāya kharaṇataḥ akkharam vaṇṇo saḥ eva nirantara uppattiyā samudditaḥ pada vākya saññitaḥ
translated: “Syllable” is the sound that is articulated. “Word” is the sound that is uttered without interruption, which is known as a sentence.

original: adhippetamatthaṃ byañjetīti byañjanaṃ, tayidaṃ kābyanāṭakādigatavevacanavasena, uccāraṇavasena
analyzed: adhippetam attham byañjā iti iti byañjanam tayā idam kābya nāṭaka ādi gata vevacana vasena uccāraṇa vasena
translated: By means of the letters and the words it reveals the meaning intended, thus it is “expression” . This is said with reference to the letters and words occurring in poetry, drama, etc., and to the mode of utterance

original: ca vicittasannivesatāya tathāpavattavikappanavasena cittavicittabhāvena upatiṭṭhanakaṃ🔽sandhāyāha “yaṃ cittakkharaṃ cittabyañjanampi saddaṃ suṇato rāgādayo uppajjantī”ti.🔽Atthanissitanti samparāyikatthanissitaṃ. Dhammanissitanti vivaṭṭadhammanissitaṃ,
analyzed: ca vicitta sannivesa tāya tathā apavatta vikappana vasena citta vicitta bhāvena upatiṭṭhanakam  sandhāya āha yam citta kkharam citta byañjanam pi saddam suṇataḥ rāga ādayaḥ uppajjanti iti  attha nissitanti samparāyika attha nissitam dhamma nissitanti vivaṭṭa dhamma nissitam
translated: and to the mode of occurrence of the letters and words in the form of a variety of combinations, with reference to the letters and words that are the basis for the arising of lust, etc., when heard.

original: lokuttararatanattayadhammanissitaṃ vā. Pasādoti ratanattayasaddhā, kammaphalasaddhāpi.🔽Nibbidā vāti aniccasaññādivasena vaṭṭato ukkaṇṭhā vā.🔽Gandharasāviparodhādivasena seviyamānaṃ ayoniso paṭipannattā asevitabbaṃ nāma. Yoniso
analyzed: lokuttara ratana ttaya dhamma nissitam vā pasādaḥ ti ratana ttaya saddhā kamma phala saddhā api  nibbidā vā ti anicca saññā ādi vasena vaṭṭataḥ ukkaṇṭhā vā  gandha rasa a viparodha ādi vasena seviyamānam ayonisas paṭipanna ttā asevitabbam nāma yonisas
translated: “Based on meaning” : based on the meaning of the future life. “Based on the Dhamma” : based on the Dhamma of the round of rebirths or based on the supramundane Dhamma of the Three Jewels. “Confidence” : faith in the Three Jewels, and faith in the results of action.🔽“Disenchantment” : aversion to the round of rebirths through the perception of impermanence, etc.

original: paccavekkhitvā seviyamānaṃ sampajaññavasena gahaṇato sevitabbaṃ nāma. Tena vuttaṃ
analyzed: paccavekkhitvā seviyamānam sampajañña vasena gahaṇato sevitabbam nāma tena vuttam
translated: “Not to be cultivated” : not to be cultivated because of unwise practice, though it may be cultivated by the wise. “To be cultivated” : to be cultivated because of wise practice, through the understanding that arises from wise practice.

original: “yaṃ gandhaṃ ghāyato”tiādi.
analyzed: yam gandham ghāyata uti ādi
translated: Therefore it is said: “When a man smells an odour with the nose” , etc.

original: Yaṃ pana phusatoti yaṃ pana sevitabbaṃ phoṭṭhabbaṃ anipphannasseva phusato. Āsavakkhayo
analyzed: yam pana phusatoti yam pana sevitabbam phoṭṭhabbam anipphannassa iva phusataḥ āsava kkhayaḥ
translated: But when he touches what should be sought,🔽he will have the destruction of cankers,

original: ceva hoti jāgariyānuyogassa matthakappattito. Vīriyañca supaggahitaṃ hoti catutthassa
analyzed: ca iva hoti jāgariya anuyogassa matthaka ppattitaḥ vīriyam ca su paggahitam hoti catutthassa
translated: and his energy will be well exerted,🔽and the last will be confirmed,🔽and the last will be helped,

original: ariyavaṃsassa ukkaṃsanato. Pacchimā ca…pe… anuggahitā hoti sammāpaṭipattiyaṃ niyojanato.🔽Ye manoviññeyye dhamme iṭṭhādibhede samannāharantassa āvajjantassa āpāthaṃ āgacchanti.🔽“Manoviññeyyā dhammā”ti vibhatti vipariṇāmetabbā, mettādivasena samannāharantassa
analyzed: ariya vaṃsassa ukkaṃsanato pacchimā cape anuggahitā hoti sammāpaṭipattiyam niyojanato  ye manaḥ viññeyye dhamme iṭṭha ādi bhede samannāharantassa āvajjantassa āpātham āgacchanti  manaḥ viññeyyāḥ dhammā ti vibhatti vipariṇāmetabbā mettā ādi vasena samannāharantassa
translated: and the right way will be pointed out.🔽When he adverts to the kinds of mental object cognizable by the mind, that is, to the kinds of mental object classed as desirable, and so on, and they come into focus for him,

original: ye manoviññeyyā dhammā āpāthaṃ āgacchanti, evarūpā sevitabbāti yojanā. Ādi-saddena
analyzed: ye manaḥ viññeyyāḥ dhammāḥ āpātham āgacchanti evarūpā sevitabbā iti yojanā ādi saddena
translated: the words “cognizable by the mind” should be analysed thus: “cognizable by the mind” is the analysis;🔽the construction is “mental objects of this kind should be sought.” The word “and so on”

original: karuṇādīnañceva aniccādīnañca saṅgaho daṭṭhabbo. Tiṇṇaṃ therānaṃ dhammāti idāni vuccamānapaṭipattīnaṃ
analyzed: karuṇā ādīnam ca iva anicca ādīnam ca saṅgahaḥ daṭṭhabbo tiṇṇam therānam dhammā ti idāni vuccamāna paṭipattīnam
translated: should be understood to include compassion, and so on, and impermanence, and so on. The Dhamma of the three elders

original: tiṇṇaṃ therānaṃ manoviññeyyā dhammā. Bahi dhāvituṃ na adāsinti antopariveṇaṃ āgatameva
analyzed: tiṇṇam therānam manaḥ viññeyyāḥ dhammāḥ bahi dhāvitum na adāsinti antopariveṇam āgatam eva
translated: the three elders’ mental objects. “Did not allow to run outside” means that they came to the inner courtyard.

original: rūpādiṃ ārabbha imasmiṃ temāse kammaṭṭhānavinimuttaṃ cittaṃ kadāci uppannapubbaṃ,🔽antopariveṇe ca visabhāgarūpādīnaṃ asambhavo eva, tasmā visaṭavitakkavasena cittaṃ
analyzed: rūpa ādim ārabbha imasmin temāse kammaṭṭhāna vinimuttam cittam kadāci uppanna pubbam  ca eva tasmāt cittam
translated: The three elders’ mental objects. He did not allow his mind to run outside: he did not allow his mind to be distracted by meditation subjects during the three months, even though it might have been distracted by visible forms, etc., on entering the inner cloister.🔽And it is impossible for there to be visible forms, etc., of a kind to arouse lust, in the inner cloister. So he shows that he did not allow his mind to run outside by way of distracting thoughts.

original: bahi dhāvituṃ na adāsinti dasseti. Nivāsagehato nivāsanagabbhato. Niyakajjhattakhandhapañcakato
analyzed: bahi dhāvitum na adāsinti dassa iti nivāsa gehataḥ nivāsana gabbhataḥ niya kajjhatta khandha pañcakato
translated: From the house of the abode, from the room of the abode, from the five aggregates that are his own,

original: vipassanāgocarato. Thero kira sabbampi attanā kātabbakiriyaṃ kammaṭṭhānasīseneva paṭipajjati.
analyzed: vipassanā gocarataḥ thero kira sabbam pi attanā kātabba kiriyam kammaṭṭhāna sīsena iva paṭipajjati
translated: from the domain of insight. The elder, it seems, undertook all the duties to be done by himself with insight as his guide.

original: 366. Asammohasampajaññavasena advejjhābhāvato eko anto etassāti ekanto, ekanto vādo🔽etesanti ekantavādā. Tenāha “ekaṃyeva vadantī”ti, abhinnavādāti attho. Ekācārāti
analyzed: asammoha sampajañña vasena a dvejjha abhāvataḥ ekaḥ antaḥ etassa ati ekantaḥ ekantaḥ vādaḥ  etesanti ekantavādā tena āha ekaṃ yā iva vadanti iti abhinna vādā ati eka ācārā iti
translated: . He had no second within: he had no second within because he had no companion in the state of non-remorse due to his non-delusion and his clear comprehension.🔽He had no second in his view: he had no second in his view.🔽He had the same practice: he had the same practice.

original: samānācārā. Ekaladdhikāti samānaladdhikā. Ekapariyosānāti samānaniṭṭhānā.
analyzed: samāna ācārā eka laddhikā ati samāna laddhikā eka pariyosānā ati samāna niṭṭhānā
translated: He had the same aspiration: he had the same aspiration.🔽He had the same consummation: he had the same consummation.

original: Iti sakko pubbe attanā sutaṃ puthusamaṇabrāhmaṇānaṃ nānāvādā cāraladdhiniṭṭhānaṃ
analyzed: iti sakko pubbe attanā sutam puthu samaṇa brāhmaṇānam nānā vādāḥ cāra laddhi niṭṭhānam
translated: So Sakka, having heard the various views of the ordinary recluses and brahmans, which were the outcome of their surmising,

original: idāni saccapaṭivedhena asārato ñatvā ṭhito, tassa kāraṇaṃ ñātukāmo tameva tāva byatirekamukhena
analyzed: idāni sacca paṭivedhena asārataḥ ñatvā ṭhitaḥ tassa kāraṇam ñātu kāmo tam eva tāva byatireka mukhena
translated: now, having understood them to be worthless by his own penetration of the Truths, stood firm. Desiring to know the reason for this, he first asked him by way of an elaboration:

original: pucchati “sabbeva dhammā nu kho”tiādinā.
analyzed: pucchati sabbe iva dhammāḥ nu kho ti ādinā
translated: “Are all dhammas …?”

original: Dhātūti ajjhāsayadhātu uttarapadalopena vuttā, ajjhāsayadhātūti ca atthato ajjhāsayo
analyzed: dhātu uti ajjhāsaya dhātu uttara pada lopena vuttā ajjhāsaya dhātu uti ca atthataḥ ajjhāsayo
translated: “Elements” : the underlying tendencies are referred to by the word “elements” with the omission of the middle term . The underlying tendencies are in fact the underlying tendencies .

original: evāti āha “anekajjhāsayo nānajjhāsayo”ti. “Ekasmiṃ gantukāme eko ṭhātukāmo hotī”ti
analyzed: eva iti āha aneka ajjhāsayaḥ ekasmin gantu kāme ekaḥ ṭhātu kāmaḥ hoti iti
translated: Therefore it is said: “of many underlying tendencies, of various underlying tendencies” . “When one wants to go, another wants to stay”

original: idaṃ nidassanavasena vuttaṃ iriyāpathepi nāma sattā ekajjhāsayā dullabhā, pageva
analyzed: idam nidassana vasena vuttam iriyāpathe pi nāma sattā ekajjhāsayā dullabhā pagā iva
translated: is said by way of illustration. It is rare for beings to have the same underlying tendency even in postures,

original: laddhīsūti dassanatthaṃ. Yaṃ yadeva ajjhāsayanti yaṃ yameva sassatādiajjhāsayaṃ.
analyzed: laddhīsu iti dassana attham yam yat eva ajjhāsayanti yam yam eva sassata ādi ajjhāsayam
translated: to say nothing of the acquisition of views. The purpose of this statement is to show that. “Whatever underlying tendency” : whatever underlying tendency to eternalism, etc.

original: Abhinivisantīti taṃ taṃ laddhiṃ diṭṭhābhinivesavasena abhimukhā hutvā duppaṭinissaggibhāvena
analyzed: abhinivisanti iti tam tam laddhim diṭṭha abhinivesa vasena abhimukhāḥ hutvā duppaṭinissaggi bhāvena
translated: “Adhere to” : they adhere to the various views by way of the adherence to views. They are difficult to relinquish by way of the nature of being face to face with them.

original: nivisanti, ādānaggāhaṃ gaṇhanti. Thāmena ca parāmāsena cāti diṭṭhithāmena ca diṭṭhiparāmāsena
analyzed: nivisanti ādāna ggāham gaṇhanti thāmena ca parāmāsena ca ati diṭṭhi thāmena ca diṭṭhi parāmāsena
translated: They take up, they seize upon, they are attached to, they insist upon, they declare: ‘This alone is the truth, other ideas are worthless.’🔽With the conceit ‘I am’ and with the holding ‘I am’: with the conceit ‘I am’ and with the holding ‘I am’ that is a view.🔽Having well seized: having seized very firmly.

original: ca. Suṭṭhu gaṇhitvāti ativiya daḷhaggāhaṃ gaṇhitvā. Voharantīti yathābhiniviṭṭhaṃ
analyzed: ca suṭṭhu gaṇhitvā ati daḷha gāham gaṇhitvā voharanti iti yathā abhiniviṭṭham
translated: They proclaim: they make known the view-theory according to how they are obsessed.

original: diṭṭhivādaṃ paññāpenti pare hi gāhenti patiṭṭhapenti. Tenāha “kathenti dīpenti kittentī”ti, ugghosentīti attho.
analyzed: diṭṭhi vādam paññāpenti pare hi gāhenti patiṭṭhapenti tena āha kathenti dīpenti kittenti iti ugghosenti iti atthaḥ
translated: Others also they lead, they establish, they cause to enter into it. Hence it is said: ‘They speak, they proclaim, they announce’ . The meaning is: they make it well known.🔽The extreme, the uttermost, the final, is the extreme-final.

original: Antaṃ atītā accantā, accantā niṭṭhā etesanti accantaniṭṭhā. Sabbesanti sabbesaṃ samaṇabrāhmaṇānaṃ.
analyzed: antam atītāḥ accantāḥ accantāḥ niṭṭhāḥ etesanti accanta niṭṭhā sabbesanti sabbesam samaṇa brāhmaṇānam
translated: All: all the contemplatives and brahmans.

original: Yogakkhemotipi nibbānaṃ catūhipi yogehi anuppaduṭṭhattā. “Accantayogakkhemā”ti vattabbe🔽i-kārena niddesena “accantayogakkhemī”ti vuttaṃ, accantayogakkhemo vā etesaṃ atthīti
analyzed: yogakkhemaḥ ti pi nibbānam catūhi pi yogehi an uppaduṭṭha ttā accanta yogakkhemā ti vattabbe  ikārena niddesena accanta yogakkhemī iti vuttam accanta yogakkhemaḥ vā etesam atthi iti
translated: The safe and firm: Nibbāna is called ‘safe and firm’ because it is not affected by the four kinds of fear .🔽What should be said as ‘having the extreme safe and firm’ is said as ‘having the extreme safe and firm’ by the indication of the letter i .🔽Or they have the extreme safe and firm, thus they are ‘having the extreme safe and firm’ .

original: accantayogakkhemīti. Caranti upagacchanti, adhigacchantīti attho. Pariyassati parikkhissati
analyzed: accanta yogakkhemī iti caranti upagacchanti adhigacchanti iti attho pariyassati parikkhissati
translated: They go, they approach, they arrive at, is the meaning.

original: vaṭṭadukkhantaṃ āgammāti pariyosānantipi nibbānassa nāmaṃ.
analyzed: vaṭṭa dukkha antam āgamma iti nibbānassa nāmam
translated: and has come to the end of suffering and stress: this is a name for Nibbāna.

original: Saṅkhiṇātīti samucchindanena khepeti. Vināsetīti tato eva sabbaso adassanaṃ pāpeti. Vimuttāti vaṭṭadukkhato accantaniggamena visesena muttā.
analyzed: saṅkhiṇāti iti samucchindanena khepeti vināseti iti tatas eva sabbasas adassanam pāpā iti vimuttā ati vaṭṭa dukkhato accanta niggamena visesena muttā
translated: He crushes them: he crushes them by cutting them off. He destroys them: he causes them to disappear completely by that same cutting off. Liberated: liberated by the special quality of complete escape from suffering and stress.

original: “Issāmacchariyaṃ eko pañho”ti kasmā vuttaṃ, nanu issāmacchariyaṃ vissajjananti? Saccametaṃ,
analyzed: issāmacchariyam ekaḥ pañhaḥ ti kasmā vuttam nanu issāmacchariyam vissajjananti saccam etam
translated: Why is it said, “Envy and avarice are one question,” when envy and avarice are the answer? That is true.

original: yo pana ñātuṃ icchito attho, so pañho. So eva ca vissajjīyatīti nāyaṃ doso, aññathā
analyzed: yaḥ pana ñātum icchitaḥ attho so pañho so eva ca vissajjīyati iti na ayam doso aññathā
translated: But the meaning that is intended to be known is the question. And that is the answer. So there is no fault here. Otherwise

original: ambaṃ puṭṭhassa labujaṃ byākaraṇaṃ viya siyā, evaṃ pañhasīsena pañhabyākaraṇaṃ vadati.🔽Tathā hi “piyāppiya”ntiādinā vissajjanapadāneva gahitāni, “piyāppiyaṃ eko”tiādīsupi
analyzed: ambam puṭṭhassa labujam byākaraṇam viya siyā evam pañha sīsena pañha byākaraṇam vadati  tathā hi piya appiya nti ādinā gahitāni eka uti ādīsu pi
translated: it would be like the answer “a gourd” to the question “a mango.” So he answers the question by the method of the question.

original: eseva nayo. Papañcasaññāti saññāsīsena papañcā eva vuttāti āha “papañco eko”ti. Ettha
analyzed: esā iva nayo papañca saññā ti saññā sīsena papañcā eva vuttā ati āha papañcaḥ ekaḥ ti ettha
translated: For in the answer given in the passage beginning, “Dear and beloved” , only the answer is given. And so too in the passage beginning, “Dear and beloved are one” .🔽Herein,

original: ca yathā pātimokkhasaṃvarapucchā kāyasamācārādivibhāgena vissajjitattā tayo pañhā
analyzed: ca yathā pātimokkha saṃvara pucchā kāya samācāra ādi vibhāgena vissajjita ttā tayo pañhā
translated: And just as the questions on restraint by the Pāṭimokkha are three because of the answers given by analysis into bodily behaviour, etc.,

original: jātā, evaṃ indriyasaṃvarapucchā rūpādivibhāgena vissajjitattā cha pañhā siyuṃ. Tathā🔽sati ekūnavīsati pucchā siyuṃ, atha indriyasaṃvaratāsāmaññena ekova pañho kato, evaṃ
analyzed: jātāḥ evam indriya saṃvara pucchāḥ rūpa ādi vibhāgena cha pañhāḥ siyum tathā  sati ekūnavīsati pucchā siyuṃ atha indriya saṃvara tā sāmaññena ekaḥ iva pañho kataḥ evam
translated: so the questions on restraint by the faculties would be six because of the answers given by analysis into visible data, etc.🔽If that were so, there would be nineteen questions. But the questions are made one by the commonality of restraint by the faculties.

original: sati pātimokkhasaṃvarapucchābhāvasāmaññena tepi tayo ekova pañhoti sabbeva dvādaseva
analyzed: sati pātimokkha saṃvara pucchā bhāva sāmaññena te pi tayo ekaḥ iva pañho ti sabbe iva dvādasā iva
translated: And if that is so, then because of the commonality of the absence of questions on restraint by the Pāṭimokkha, those three are also made one. So all the questions would be twelve.

original: pañhā bhaveyyunti? Nayidamevaṃ. Yasmā kāyasamācārādīsu vibhajja vuccamānesu mahāvisayatāya
analyzed: na idam evam yasmā kāya samācāra ādīsu vibhajja vuccamānesu mahā visaya tāya
translated: But that is not so. Because when the answers are given by analysis into bodily behaviour, etc., the analysis is immeasurable because of its vast scope.

original: aparimāṇo vibhāgo sambhavati vissajjetuṃ. Sakalampi vinayapiṭakaṃ tassa niddeso.
analyzed: aparimāṇaḥ vibhāgaḥ sambhavati vissajjetum sakalam pi vinaya piṭakam tassa niddeso
translated: The whole of the Vinaya Piṭaka is its commentary.

original: Rūpādīsu pana vibhajja vuccamānesu appavisayatāya na tādiso vibhāgo sambhavati vissajjetuṃ.
analyzed: rūpa ādīsu pana vibhajja vuccamānesu appa visaya tāya na tādisaḥ vibhāgaḥ sambhavati vissajjetum
translated: But when the answers are given by analysis into visible data, etc., the analysis is not of that kind because of its limited scope.

original: Iti mahāvisayatāya pātimokkhasaṃvarapucchā tayo pañhā katā, indriyasaṃvarapucchā
analyzed: iti mahā visaya tāya pātimokkha saṃvara pucchā tayo pañhā katā indriya saṃvara pucchā
translated: So the questions on restraint by the Pāṭimokkha are made three because of their vast scope, and the questions on restraint by the faculties are made one because of their limited scope.

original: pana appavisayatāya ekova pañho kato. Tena vuttaṃ “cuddasa mahāpañhā”ti.
analyzed: pana appavisaya tāya ekaḥ iva pañho kato tena vuttam cuddasa mahāpañhā ti
translated: but because of the smallness of the scope of the latter, only one question is asked. Hence it was said above: “Fourteen great questions” .

original: 367. Calanaṭṭhenāti kampanaṭṭhena. Taṇhā hi kāmarāgarūparāgaarūparāgādivasena pavattiyā
analyzed: calana ṭṭhena ati kampana ṭṭhena taṇhā hi kāma rāga rūpa rāga arūpa rāga ādi vasena pavattiyā
translated: In the sense of shaking: in the sense of trembling. For craving, by occurring as sense-desire, desire for fine-material existence, desire for immaterial existence, etc.,

original: anavaṭṭhitatāya sayampi calati, yattha uppannā, tampi santānaṃ bhavādīsu parikaḍḍhanena🔽cāleti, tasmā calanaṭṭhena taṇhā ejā nāma. Pīḷanaṭṭhenāti vibādhanaṭṭhena tassa tassa🔽dukkhassa hetubhāvena. Padussanaṭṭhenāti adhammarāgādibhāvena, sammukhaparaṃmukhena,
analyzed: anavaṭṭhita tāya sayam pi calati yattha uppannā tam pi santānam bhava ādīsu parikaḍḍhanena  cālā iti tasmā calana ṭṭhena taṇhā ejā nāma pīḷana ṭṭhena ati vibādhana ṭṭhena tassa tassa  dukkhassa hetu bhāvena padussana ṭṭhena ati adhamma rāga ādi bhāvena sammukha paraṃmukhena
translated: is itself unsteady because of its lack of stability. And wherever it arises, it shakes the continuity by dragging it here and there among the kinds of becoming, etc.🔽Therefore it is called “the dart” in the sense of shaking. In the sense of afflicting: in the sense of oppressing, by being the cause of this or that suffering.🔽In the sense of festering: in the sense of festering by corruption, by being unrighteous greed, etc., by being turned towards what is in front and what is behind,

original: kilesāsucipaggharaṇena ca pakārato dussanaṭṭhena gaṇḍo. Anuppaviṭṭhaṭṭhenāti āsayassa🔽dunnīharaṇīyabhāvena anuppavisanaṭṭhena. Kaḍḍhati attano ca ruciyā upaneti. Uccāvacanti
analyzed: kilesa asuci paggharaṇena ca pakārataḥ dussana ṭṭhena gaṇḍaḥ anuppaviṭṭha ṭṭhena ati āsayassa  dunnīharaṇīya bhāvena an uppavisana ṭṭhena kaḍḍhati attanaḥ ca ruciyā upaneti uccāvacanti
translated: and by the discharge of the impurities of defilement. Therefore it is called “the boil” in the sense of festering. In the sense of lying hidden: in the sense of lying hidden by being hard to remove from its abode.

original: paṇītabhāvaṃ, nihīnabhāvañca. Yesu samaṇabrāhmaṇesu. “Yesāha”ntipi pāḷi, tassā keci
analyzed: paṇīta bhāvam nihīna bhāvam ca yesu samaṇa brāhmaṇesu keci
translated: It drags one along and brings one under its own control. High and low: the exalted and the lowly. In the case of those recluses and brahmins: the reading is “yesāha” , but some read “yesāhaṃ” .

original: “yesaṃ aha”nti atthaṃ vadanti. Evanti sutānurūpaṃ, uggahānurūpañca. “Ahaṃ kho pana
analyzed: yesam aham iti attham vadanti evam ti suta anurūpam uggaha anurūpam ca aham kho pana
translated: “Those of me” is the meaning they give. “Thus” is in accordance with what was heard and in accordance with what was grasped.

original: bhante aññesaṃ samaṇabrāhmaṇānaṃ dhammācariyo hontopi bhagavato sāvako…pe… sambodhiparāyaṇo”ti
analyzed: bhante aññesam samaṇa brāhmaṇānam dhamma ācariyo honto api bhagavato sāvaka ope sambodhi parāyaṇaḥ ti
translated: “I am one of those who have.” “Thus” means in accordance with what has been heard and in accordance with what has been grasped. “Venerable sir, although I am a teacher of Dhamma to other ascetics and brahmins, I am a disciple of the Blessed One in the Dispensation of the One Fully Enlightened.”

original: evaṃ attano sotāpannabhāvaṃ jānāpeti.
analyzed: evam sotāpanna bhāvam jānāpeti
translated: In this way he declares his own state of stream-entry.

original: Somanassapaṭilābhakathāvaṇṇanā🔽368. Samāpannoti samogāḷho pavattasampahāro viyātibyūḷho. Jiniṃsūti yathā asurā puna
analyzed: somanassa paṭilābha kathā vaṇṇanā  samāpannaḥ iti samogāḷhaḥ pavatta sampahāraḥ viyāti byūḍhaḥ jiniṃsu iti yathā asurā punar
translated: The Description of the Discussion of the Attainment of Happiness

original: sīsaṃ ukkhipituṃ nāsakkhiṃsu, evaṃ devā vijiniṃsuyevāti dassento āha “devā puna apaccāgamanāya🔽asure jiniṃsū”ti. Tādiso hissa jayo sātisayaṃ vedapaṭilābhāya ahosi. Duvidhampi ojanti🔽dibbaṃ, asuraṃ cāti dvippakārampi ojaṃ. Devāyeva paribhuñjissanti asurānaṃ pavesābhāvato.
analyzed: sīsam ukkhipitum na asakkhiṃsu evam devāḥ vijiniṃsu yeva ati dassentaḥ āha devāḥ puna a paccāgamanāya  asure jiniṃsu iti tādisaḥ hissa jayaḥ sa atisayam veda paṭilābhāya duvidham pi  dibbam asuram ca ati dvippakāram pi ojam devāya iva paribhuñjissanti asurānam pavesa abhāvato
translated: “The gods defeated the asuras and drove them off” : showing how the asuras were unable to raise their heads again, he says this in order to show that the gods defeated them. For such was the victory that it brought about the attainment of happiness in abundance.🔽“The gods enjoyed the two kinds of strength” : the two kinds of strength are divine strength and asura strength. The gods alone enjoyed them because the asuras were excluded.

original: Daṇḍassa avacaraṇaṃ āvaraṇaṃ daṇḍāvacaro, saha daṇḍāvacarenāti sadaṇḍāvacaro, daṇḍena
analyzed: daṇḍassa avacaraṇam āvaraṇam daṇḍa avacaro saha daṇḍa avacarena ati sa daṇḍa avacaraḥ daṇḍena
translated: “The gods enjoyed the two kinds of strength” : the two kinds of strength are divine strength and asura strength. The gods alone enjoyed them because the asuras were excluded.

original: paharitvā vā āvaritvā vā sādhetabbanti attho.
analyzed: paharitvā vā āvaritvā vā sādhetabbanti atthaḥ
translated: The meaning is: having struck it or having turned it over, it should be made to be cooked.

original: 369. Imasmiṃyeva okāseti imissameva indasālaguhāyaṃ. Devabhūtassa meti pubbepi devabhūtassa sakkasseva me bhūtassa. Satoti idānipi sakkasseva sato punarāyu ca me laddho.
analyzed: imasmin yeva okāse iti imissam eva inda sālaguhā ayam deva bhūtassa me iti pubbe pi deva bhūtassa sakkassa iva me bhūtassa sato ti idāni pi sakkassa iva sato punar āyu ca me laddhaḥ
translated: In this very place: in this very Indasāla Cave. Of me who was a god: of me who was a Sakka-god in the past. Of me who was mindful: of me who was mindful even now. Again life has been obtained by me.

original: Diviyā kāyāti dibbā, khandhapañcakasaṅkhātā kāyāti āha “dibbā attabhāvā”ti. “Amūḷho🔽gabbhaṃ essāmī”ti iminā ariyasāvakānaṃ andhaputhujjanānaṃ viya sammohamaraṇaṃ, asampajānagabbhokkamanañca
analyzed: diviyā kāyā iti dibbā khandha pañcaka saṅkhātā kāyā iti āha dibbā atta bhāvā ati amūḷhaḥ  gabbham essāmi iti iminā ariya sāvakānam andha puthujjanānam viya sammoha maraṇam asampajāna gabbha ukkamanam ca
translated: Divine: heavenly. Body: the five aggregates called body. Therefore it is said: “divine existence.”🔽I will enter the womb with full awareness: by this it is shown that there is no death of noble disciples with delusion, nor is there entry into the womb without full awareness,

original: natthi, atha kho asammohamaraṇañceva sampajānagabbhokkamanañca hotīti dasseti. Ariyasāvakā🔽niyatagatikattā sugatīsu eva uppajjanti, tatthāpi manussesu uppajjantā uḷāresu eva
analyzed: natthi atha kho asammoha maraṇam ca iva sampajāna gabbha ukkamanam ca hoti iti dasseti ariya sāvakā  niyata gatikattā su gatīsu eva uppajjanti tattha api manussesu uppajjantā uḷāresu eva
translated: as there is for blind worldlings. Rather, there is death with full awareness and entry into the womb with full awareness. Noble disciples🔽are reborn in the happy destinations because they have a fixed destiny. Even there, when they are reborn among humans, they will take rebirth in the highest families,

original: kulesu paṭisandhiṃ gaṇhissanti, sakkassāpi tādiso ajjhāsayo. Tena vuttaṃ pāḷiyaṃ
analyzed: kulesu paṭisandhim gaṇhissanti sakkassa api tādisaḥ ajjhāsayaḥ tena vuttam pāḷiyam
translated: in a family like Sakka’s. Therefore it is said in the text:

original: “yattha me ramatī mano”ti, taṃ sandhāyāha “yattha me”tiādi. Sakko pana attano dibbānubhāvenāpi🔽tādisaṃ jānituṃ sakkotiyeva.
analyzed: yattha me ramatī ti tam sandhāya āha yattha mā itiādi sakkaḥ pana attanaḥ dibba anubhāvena api  tādisam jānitum sakkotiyā iva
translated: “Where my mind finds delight” : he says this referring to the place where his mind finds delight. Sakka, however, is able to know such a place even through his divine power.

original: Kāraṇenāti yuttena ariyasāvakabhāvassa anucchavikena. Tenāha “samenā”ti.
analyzed: kāraṇena ati yuttena ariya sāvaka bhāvassa anucchavikena tena āha samena ati
translated: “With a reason” : with a suitable reason that is appropriate for one who is a noble disciple. Therefore, he says “with a reason” .

original: Sakadāgāmimaggaṃ sandhāya vadati chaṭṭhe atthavase anāgāmimaggassa vakkhamānattā.🔽Ājānitukāmoti appattaṃ visesaṃ paṭivijjhitukāmo. Manussaloke anto bhavissati puna
analyzed: sakadāgāmi maggam sandhāya vadati chaṭṭhe attha vase anāgāmi maggassa vakkhamāna ttā  ājānitu kāmaḥ ti appattam visesam paṭivijjhitu kāmaḥ manussa loke antar bhavissati puna
translated: He speaks with reference to the path of the once-returner, because the path of the non-returner will be mentioned in the sixth condition.

original: mānussūpapattiyā abhāvato.
analyzed: mā anussūpapattiyāḥ abhāvataḥ
translated: “Desiring to know” : desiring to penetrate the special quality that he has not yet attained. It will be within the human world, because there is no rebirth as a non-human being.

original: Punadevāti manussesu uppanno tato cavitvā punadeva. Imasmiṃ tāvatiṃsadevalokasmiṃ. Uttamo, kīdisoti āha “sakko”tiādi.🔽Antime bhaveti mama sabbabhavesu antime sabbapariyosāne bhave. “Āyunā”ti iminā ca
analyzed: punadeva ati manussesu uppanno tatas cavitvā punadeva imasmin tāvatiṃsa deva lokasmin uttamaḥ kīdisaḥ iti āha sakkaḥ tiādi  antime bhave ti mama sabba bhavesu antime sabba pariyosāne bhave āyunā ati iminā ca
translated: “Again” : having been reborn among humans and having passed away from there, he will be reborn again. “In this very deva world of the Thirty-three” . “Supreme” : what is he like? He says “Sakka” .

original: taṃsahabhāvino sabbepi vaṇṇādike saṅgaṇhāti. “Paññāyā”ti ca iminā sabbepi saddhāsativīriyādike.
analyzed: tad sahabhāvino sabbe api vaṇṇa ādike saṅgaṇhāti paññāyāti ca iminā sabbe api saddhā sati vīriya ādike
translated: “In his last existence” : in my last existence out of all my existences, in my last existence, which is the culmination of all. By “life span” he includes all the qualities of form, etc., that are concomitant with it. By “wisdom” he includes all the qualities of faith, mindfulness, energy, etc.

original: Tasmiṃ attabhāveti tasmiṃ sabbantime sakkattabhāve. Akaniṭṭhagāmī hutvāti antarāyaparinibbāyiādibhāvaṃ
analyzed: tasmin atta bhāve iti tasmin sabbantime sakkatta bhāve akaniṭṭha gāmī hutvā iti antarāya parinibbāyi ādi bhāvam
translated: In that existence: in that existence of Sakka, the existence in which he was Sakka.🔽Having become one who goes to the Akanittha realm: without going to the state of an arahat who attains final Nibbāna in the interval, or to any other state, he became one who goes to the Akanittha realm by the straight path.

original: anupagantvā ekaṃsato uddhaṃsoto akaniṭṭhagāmī eva hutvā. Tato eva anukkamena avihādīsu
analyzed: an upagantvā ekaṃsataḥ uddhaṃsotaḥ a kaniṭṭha gāmī eva hutvā tatas eva anukkamena a vihādīsu
translated: And he was reborn in the Aviha realm, etc., in due succession.

original: nibbattanto. Evamāhāti “so nivāso bhavissatī”ti evamāha. “Avihādīsu…pe… nibbattissatī”ti
analyzed: nibbattantaḥ evam āha ati saḥ nivāsaḥ bhavissati iti evam āha nibbattissati iti
translated: Thus he said: thus he said: “That will be my abode.” “He will be reborn in the Aviha realm, etc.”

original: saṅkhepato vuttamatthaṃ vivarituṃ “esa kirā”tiādi vuttaṃ. Ayañca nayo na kevalaṃ
analyzed: saṅkhepataḥ vuttam attham vivaritum esa kira ati ādi vuttam ayam ca nayaḥ na kevalam
translated: In order to explain the meaning stated in brief, it is said: “It is said that Sakka.”🔽And this method is not only for Sakka, but it is also for the great treasurer and the great female lay follower.

original: sakkasseva, atha kho mahāseṭṭhimahāupāsikānampi hotiyevāti dassento “sakko devarājā”tiādimāha.🔽370. Bhavasampattinibbānasampattīnaṃ vasena aparipuṇṇajjhāsayatāya aniṭṭhitamanoratho
analyzed: sakkassa iva atha kho mahā seṭṭhi mahā upāsikānam pi hotiyā iva ati dassentaḥ sakkaḥ devarājā iti ādim āha  bhava sampatti nibbāna sampattīnam vasena a paripuṇṇa ajjhāsaya tāya a niṭṭhita manorathaḥ
translated: Showing this, he said: “Sakka, the king of the gods.”🔽Because his desire was not fulfilled in the matter of the attainment of existence and the attainment of Nibbāna, he remained desirous of attaining this or that.

original: taṃ taṃ pattukāmoyeva hutvā ṭhito. Ye ca samaṇeti ye ca pabbajite. Pavivittavihārinoti
analyzed: tam tam hutvā ṭhitaḥ ye ca samaṇā iti ye ca pabbajite pavivitta vihārino ti
translated: Those who are ascetics: those who have gone forth.

original: “anekavivekattayaṃ paribrūhetvā viharantī”ti maññāmi.
analyzed: aneka viveka ttayam viharanti iti maññāmi
translated: Who dwell in solitude: I think that they dwell having reflected on the many kinds of solitude.

original: Sampādanāti maggassa upasampādanaṃ tassa sampāpanaṃ sammadeva pāpanaṃ. Virādhanāti🔽anārādhanā anupāyapaṭipatti. Na sambhontīti anabhisambhuṇanti. Yathāpucchite atthe
analyzed: sampādanā ati maggassa upasampādanaṃ tassa sampāpanam sammat eva pāpanam virādhanā ati  an ārādhanāḥ an upāya paṭipatti na sambhonti iti an abhisambhuṇanti yathā pucchite atthe
translated: Sampādananti means the accomplishment of the path, the fulfilment of it, the right accomplishment of it. Virādhanāti means🔽non-fulfilment, the practice of the wrong means. Na sambhontīti means they do not succeed. Yathāpucchite atthe

original: anabhisambhuṇanaṃ nāma sammā kathetuṃ asamatthatā evāti āha “sampādetvā kathetuṃ na sakkontī”ti.
analyzed: an abhisambhuṇanam nāma sammā kathetum asamattha tā eva ati āha sampādetvā kathetum na sakkonti iti
translated: means the inability to explain correctly. Therefore it is said: “they are unable to explain after having accomplished it.”

original: Tasmāti yasmā ādiccena samānagottatāya. Tenevāha “ādicca nāma gottenā”ti, tasmā.
analyzed: tasmā iti yasmai ādiccena samāna gotta tāya tena iva āha nāma gottena ati tasmā
translated: Tasmāti means because of the similarity of the clan with the sun. Therefore it is said: “the clan named Ādicca.” Therefore.

original: Ādicco bandhu etassāti ādiccabandhu, atha vā ādiccassa bandhūti ādiccabandhu, bhagavā,
analyzed: ādiccaḥ bandhu etassa ati ādiccabandhu atha vā ādiccassa bandhu iti ādiccabandhu bhagavā
translated: Ādicco bandhu etassāti means Ādiccabandhu. Or, Ādiccassa bandhūti means Ādiccabandhu, the Blessed One.

original: taṃ ādiccabandhunaṃ. Ādicco hi sotāpannatāya bhagavato orasaputto. Tenevāha –
analyzed: tam ādiccabandhunam ādiccaḥ hi sotāpanna tāya bhagavataḥ tena iva āha
translated: Taṃ Ādiccabandhunaṃ means that of the sun-kinsman. For the sun is the Blessed One’s paternal uncle by virtue of his being a stream-enterer. Therefore it is said:

original: “Yo andhakāre tamasi pabhaṅkaro,
analyzed: yaḥ andhakāre tamasi pabhaṅkaraḥ
translated: “The sun, the light-bringer in the darkness and gloom,

original: Verocano maṇḍalī uggatejo;🔽Mā rāhu gilī caraṃ antalikkhe,
analyzed: verocanaḥ maṇḍalī ugga tejaḥ  mā rāhu gilī caraṃ antalikkhe
translated: The sun, the orb, the one with radiant heat,🔽Do not swallow the sun as it moves across the sky,

original: Pajaṃ mamaṃ rāhu pamuñca sūriya”nti. ;
analyzed: pajam mamam rāhu pamuñca sūriyanti
translated: O Rāhu, release my sun!”

original: Sāmanti sāmaṃpayogaṃ, satthu pana sāvakassa sāmaṃpayogo nāma sanipāto evāti āha “namakkāraṃ karomā”ti.
analyzed: sāmanti sāmaṃpayogam satthu pana sāvakassa sāmaṃpayogaḥ nāma sa nipātaḥ eva ati āha namakkāram karoma iti
translated: “The earth” : the earth as a means of access. But the earth as a means of access for the Master’s disciples is a gathering. That is why he said “we pay homage” .

original: 371. Parāmasitvāti “imāya nāma pathaviyaṃ nisinnena mayā ayaṃ acchariyadhammo adhigato”ti
analyzed: parāmasitvā iti imāya nāma pathaviyam nisinnena mayā ayam acchariya dhammo adhigato ti
translated: “Taking hold of” : being glad, he took hold of the earth, thinking “Sitting on this earth I attained this wonder-working power” ,

original: somanassajāto, “imāya nāma pathaviyaṃ evaṃ acchariyabbhutaṃ buddharatanaṃ uppanna”nti
analyzed: somanassa jātaḥ imāya nāma pathaviyam evam acchariyabbhutam buddha ratanam uppannanti
translated: and being glad, he took hold of the earth, thinking “On this earth the wonder-working Buddha-Jewel arose in this way” .

original: acchariyabbhutacittajāto ca pathaviṃ parāmasitvā. Patthitapañhāti dīgharattānusayitasaṃsayasamugghātatthaṃ🔽“kadā nu kho bhagavantaṃ pucchituṃ labhāmī”ti evaṃ abhipatthitapañhā. Yaṃ panettha
analyzed: ca pathavim parāmasitvā patthita pañhāti dīgha ratta anusayita saṃsaya samugghāta ttham  kadā nu kho bhagavantam pucchitum labhāmi iti evam abhipatthita pañhā yam pana ittha
translated: “Question that he had long desired to ask” : in order to remove a doubt that had long lain latent in him,

original: atthato na vibhattaṃ, taṃ suviññeyyamevāti.
analyzed: atthataḥ na vibhattam tam su viññeyyam eva ati
translated: he had long desired to ask the question “When shall I get to ask the Blessed One?” . But what has not been explained here in the meaning can be understood easily enough.

original: Sakkapañhasuttavaṇṇanāya līnatthappakāsanā.
translated: The explanation of the Sakkapañhasutta is ended.

original: 9. Mahāsatipaṭṭhānasuttavaṇṇanā
translated: The Great Discourse on the Foundations of Mindfulness

original: Uddesavārakathāvaṇṇanā
analyzed: uddesa vāra kathā vaṇṇanā
translated: The Commentary on the Introduction

original: 373. “Kasmā bhagavā idaṃ suttamabhāsī”ti asādhāraṇaṃ samuṭṭhānaṃ pucchati, sādhāraṇaṃ
analyzed: kasmai bhagavā idam suttam abhāsi iti asādhāraṇam samuṭṭhānam pucchati sādhāraṇam
translated: “Why did the Blessed One speak this discourse?” He asks about the special reason for the delivery of the discourse. The general reason is this:

original: pana “pākaṭa”nti anāmasitvā “kururaṭṭhavāsīna”ntiādi vuttaṃ. Samuṭṭhānanti hi desanānidānaṃ,
analyzed: pana pākaṭam ti an āmasitvā kuru raṭṭha vāsīna ntiādi vuttam samuṭṭhānam ti hi desanā nidānam
translated: but without mentioning “clearly,” he said, “the resident of Kuraraṭṭha.”🔽For the origin is the reason for the teaching.

original: taṃ sādhāraṇāsādhāraṇabhedato duvidhaṃ, sādhāraṇampi ajjhattikabāhirabhedato duvidhaṃ.
analyzed: tam sādhāraṇa asādhāraṇa bhedataḥ duvidham sādhāraṇam pi ajjhattika bāhira bhedataḥ duvidham
translated: It is of two kinds, common and uncommon. The common is also of two kinds, internal and external.

original: Tattha sādhāraṇaṃ ajjhattikaṃ samuṭṭhānaṃ nāma bhagavato mahākaruṇā. Tāya hi samussāhitassa
analyzed: tattha sādhāraṇam ajjhattikam samuṭṭhānam nāma bhagavataḥ mahā karuṇā tāya hi samussāhitassa
translated: Herein, the internal common origin is the Blessed One’s great compassion. For it was owing to that being aroused in him

original: bhagavato veneyyānaṃ dhammadesanāya cittaṃ udapādi. Yathāha “sattesu ca kāruññataṃ
analyzed: bhagavataḥ veneyyānam dhamma desanāya cittam udapādi yathā āha sattesu ca kāruñña tam
translated: that the Blessed One’s mind inclined to teaching the True Idea to his disciples, as it is said: “And because of his compassion for beings
