analyzed: ca asubha ākārassa kāya iti ekavacanam tathā ārammaṇa ādi vibhāgena aneka bheda bhinnam pi 🔽cittam citta bhāva sāmaññena ekajjham gahetvā citta iti eka vacanam vedanā pana sukha ādi bheda bhinnā
translated: The word “body” is also used for the collection of the dhammas called head hairs, etc., and for the collection of the primary elements that are the material support of the dhammas called head hairs, etc.🔽The word “body” is also used for the collection of the dhammas called head hairs, etc., and for the collection of the primary elements that are the material support of the dhammas called head hairs, etc.🔽The word “body” is also used for the collection of the dhammas called head hairs, etc., and for the collection of the primary elements that are the material support of the dhammas called head hairs, etc.🔽The word “body” is also used for the collection of the dhammas called head hairs, etc., and for the collection of the primary elements that are the material support of the dhammas called head hairs, etc.🔽The word “body” is also used for the collection of the dhammas called head hairs, etc., and for the collection of the primary elements that are the material support of the dhammas called head hairs, etc.🔽The word “body” is also used for the collection of the dhammas called head hairs, etc., and for the collection of the primary elements that are the material support of the dhammas called head hairs, etc.🔽The word “body” is also used for the collection of the dhammas called head hairs, etc., and for the collection of the primary elements

original: visuṃ visuṃ anupassitabbāti dassentena “vedanāsū”ti bahuvacanena vuttā, tatheva ca
analyzed: visum visum anupassitabbā ti dassentena vedanāsu iti bahuvacanena vuttā tathā iva ca
translated: And the exposition is given in the same way.

original: niddeso pavattito, dhammā ca paropaṇṇāsabhedā, anupassitabbākārena ca anekabhedā
analyzed: niddeso pavattitaḥ dhammā ca paropaṇṇāsa bhedāḥ anupassitabba ākārena ca aneka bhedā
translated: And states are of over twenty kinds, and they are of many kinds according to the aspect of looking on.

original: evāti tepi bahuvacanavaseneva vuttā.🔽Avayavīgāhasamaññātidhāvanasārādānābhinivesanisedhanatthaṃ kāyaṃ aṅgapaccaṅgehi,🔽tāni ca kesādīhi, kesādike ca bhūtupādāyarūpehi vinibbhuñjanto “tathā na kāye”tiādimāha.
analyzed: eva iti te pi bahuvacana vasena iva vuttā  avayavī gāha samaññā ati dhāvana sāra ādāna abhinivesa nisedhana attham kāyam aṅga paccaṅgehi  tāni ca kesa ādīhi kesa ādike ca bhūta upādāya rūpehi tathā na kāya itiādim āha
translated: So they too are mentioned in the plural.🔽The purpose of the words “He defines the body by its parts” is to prevent the assumption of a unity in what is a collection of parts, and to prevent the assumption of a self in what is not a self.🔽The purpose of the words “He defines the head-hairs by the primary and secondary characteristics” is to prevent the assumption of a unity in what is a collection of elements and derived matter, and to prevent the assumption of a self in what is not a self.

original: Pāsādādinagarāvayavasamūhe avayavīvādinopi avayavīgāhaṃ na karonti, “nagaraṃ nāma
analyzed: pāsāda ādi nagara avayava samūhe avayavī vādinaḥ api avayavī gāham na karonti nagaram nāma
translated: The purpose of the words “He defines the body by the parts” is to prevent the assumption of a unity in what is a collection of parts, and to prevent the assumption of a self in what is not a self.🔽The purpose of the words “He defines the head-hairs by the primary and secondary characteristics” is to prevent the assumption of a unity in what is a collection of elements and derived matter, and to prevent the assumption of a self in what is not a self.

original: koci attho atthī”ti pana kesañci samaññātidhāvanaṃ siyāti itthipurisādisamaññātidhāvane
analyzed: koci atthaḥ atthi iti pana kesañci samaññā atidhāvanam siyāti itthi purisa ādi samaññā atidhāvane
translated: The purpose of the words “He defines the body by the parts” is to prevent the assumption of a unity in what is a collection of parts, and to prevent the assumption of a self in what is not a self.

original: nagaranidassanaṃ vuttaṃ. Aṅgapaccaṅgasamūho, kesalomādisamūho, bhūtupādāyasamūho
analyzed: nagara nidassanam vuttam aṅga paccaṅga samūhaḥ kesa loma ādi samūhaḥ bhūta upādāya samūhaḥ
translated: The purpose of the words “He defines the head-hairs by the primary and secondary characteristics” is to prevent the assumption of a unity in what is a collection of elements and derived matter, and to prevent the assumption of a self in what is not a self.

original: ca yathāvuttasamūho, tabbinimutto kāyopi nāma koci natthi, pageva itthiādayoti āha
analyzed: ca yathā vutta samūhaḥ tad vinimutto kāyaḥ api nāma koci natthi pageva itthi ādayaḥ ti āha
translated: And there is no such thing as a body, etc., apart from the collection of states described above, to say nothing of a woman or a man.

original: “kāyo vā itthī vā puriso vā añño vā koci dhammo dissatī”ti. “Koci dhammo”ti iminā
analyzed: kāyaḥ vā itthī vā purisaḥ vā aññaḥ vā koci dhammo dissati iti koci dhammo ti iminā
translated: “Is there any visible phenomenon called a body, or a woman, or a man, or anything else?”🔽By “any visible phenomenon” he rejects the soul, the living being, etc.,

original: sattajīvādiṃ paṭikkhipati, avayavī pana kāyapaṭikkhepeneva paṭikkhittoti. Yadi evaṃ
analyzed: satta jīva ādim paṭikkhipati avayavī pana kāya paṭikkhepena iva paṭikkhittaḥ ti yadi evam
translated: but the possessor of parts is rejected by the rejection of the body.🔽If that is so,🔽how is it that the terms “body,” etc., are used? He says, “The states described above … are seen,” etc.

original: kathaṃ kāyādisamaññātidhāvanānīti āha “yathāvuttadhamma…pe… karontī”ti. Tathā tathāti kāyādiākārena.
analyzed: katham kāya ādi samaññā ati dhāvanāni iti āha yathā vutta dhammape karonti iti tathā tathā iti kāya ādi ākārena
translated: “In such and such a way” means in the mode of a body, etc.🔽“What one sees”: what woman or man one sees.

original: Yaṃ passatīti yaṃ itthiṃ, purisaṃ vā passati. Nanu cakkhunā itthipurisadassanaṃ natthīti?
analyzed: yam passati iti yam itthim purisam vā passati nanu cakkhunā itthi purisa dassanam natthi iti
translated: But isn’t the seeing of a woman or a man done by the eye?

original: Saccametaṃ, “itthiṃ passāmi, purisaṃ passāmī”ti pana pavattasaññāya vasena “yaṃ passatī”ti
analyzed: saccam etam itthim passāmi purisam passāmi iti pana pavatta saññāya vasena yam passati iti
translated: That is true, but it is said that “what one sees” is seen by the perception that occurs in the form “I see a woman,” “I see a man.”

original: vuttaṃ micchādassanena vā diṭṭhiyā yaṃ passati, na taṃ diṭṭhaṃ taṃ rūpāyatanaṃ na
analyzed: vuttam micchā dassanena vā diṭṭhiyā yam passati na tat diṭṭham tam rūpa āyatanam na
translated: Or what one sees by wrong view is not seen, is not the visible-data base.

original: hotīti attho viparītaggāhavasena micchāparikappitarūpattā. Atha vā taṃ kesādibhūtupādāyasamūhasaṅkhātaṃ🔽diṭṭhaṃ na hoti, acakkhuviññāṇaviññeyyattā diṭṭhaṃ vā taṃ na hoti. Yaṃ diṭṭhaṃ, taṃ
analyzed: hoti iti atthaḥ viparīta ggāha vasena micchā parikappita rūpa ttā atha vā tam kesa ādi bhūta upādāya samūha saṅkhātam  diṭṭham na hoti a cakkhu viññāṇa viññeyya ttā diṭṭham vā tam na hoti yam diṭṭham tam
translated: The meaning is that it is not seen because of the misapprehension of it as form by the wrong assumption of a contrary mode. Or alternatively, what is called “seen” is not the visible-data base consisting of the head hairs, etc.,🔽as a collection of primary elements and derived matter; or what is seen is not that,

original: na passatīti yaṃ rūpāyatanaṃ kesādibhūtupādāyasamūhasaṅkhātaṃ diṭṭhaṃ, taṃ paññācakkhunā🔽bhūtato na passatīti attho. Apassaṃ bajjhateti imaṃ attabhāvaṃ yathābhūtaṃ paññācakkhunā
analyzed: na passati iti yam rūpa āyatanam kesa ādi bhūta upādāya samūha saṅkhātam diṭṭham tam paññā cakkhunā  bhūtataḥ na passati iti attho apassam bajjhata iti imam atta bhāvam yathābhūtam paññā cakkhunā
translated: because it is not cognizable by eye-consciousness. What is seen he does not see: the visible-data base consisting of the head hairs, etc., as a collection of primary elements and derived matter, which is called “seen,” he does not see with the eye of wisdom,

original: apassanto “etaṃ mama, eso hamasmi, eso me attā”ti kilesabandhanena bajjhati.
analyzed: a passantaḥ etam mama esaḥ ham asmi esaḥ me attā iti kilesa bandhanena bajjhati
translated: is the meaning. Not seeing, he is fettered: not seeing this individual form as it really is with the eye of wisdom, he is fettered by the defilements of craving and conceit in the three ways beginning with “This is mine … this I am … this is my self.”

original: Na aññadhammānupassīti na aññasabhāvānupassī, asubhādito aññākārānupassī na hotīti
analyzed: na añña dhamma anupassī iti na añña sabhāva anupassī asubha āditas añña ākāra anupassī na hoti iti
translated: Not contemplating another property: not contemplating a different nature; not contemplating another aspect, such as foulness, is the meaning.

original: attho. “Kiṃ vuttaṃ hotī”tiādinā taṃ evatthaṃ pākaṭaṃ karoti. Pathavīkāyanti kesādikoṭṭhāsaṃ
analyzed: atthaḥ kim vuttam hoti itiādinā tam evattham pākaṭam karoti pathavīkāyanti kesa ādi koṭṭhāsam
translated: “What is meant?” etc. He makes the meaning clear. The earth element: the head hairs, etc.,

original: pathaviṃ dhammasamūhattā “kāyo”ti vadati, lakkhaṇapathavimeva vā anekappabhedaṃ sakalasarīragataṃ,
analyzed: pathavim dhamma samūha ttā kāyaḥ iti vadati lakkhaṇa pathavim eva vā aneka ppabhedam sakala sarīra gatam
translated: He calls the earth element in the aggregate of material form “the body” because it is a collection of states, or else he calls the earth element in the aggregate of material form “the body” because it is of many kinds and is to be found throughout the whole physical frame.

original: pubbāpariyabhāvena ca pavattamānaṃ samūhavasena gahetvā “kāyo”ti vadati. “Āpokāya”ntiādīsupi eseva nayo.
analyzed: pubba apariya bhāvena ca pavattamānam samūha vasena gahetvā kāyo ti vadati esa iva nayo
translated: And he calls it “the body” when he takes it as a collection by passing over its particular parts.

original: Evaṃ gahetabbassāti “ahaṃ mama”nti evaṃ attattaniyabhāvena andhabālehi gahetabbassa.
analyzed: evam gahetabbassa ati aham mama nti evam atta ttaniya bhāvena andha bālehi gahetabbassa
translated: “Can be so apprehended”: can be apprehended by the foolish and the unlearned as self and self’s property.

original: Idāni sattannaṃ anupassanākārānampi vasena kāyānupassanaṃ dassetuṃ “apicā”tiādi āraddhaṃ.
analyzed: idāni sattannam anupassanā ākārānam pi vasena kāya anupassanam dassetum apica ati ādi āraddham
translated: Now, in order to show the contemplation of the body by means of the seven contemplations, the text is resumed with the words “Again, bhikkhus, a bhikkhu contemplates as impermanent” .

original: Tattha aniccato anupassatīti catusamuṭṭhānikaṃ kāyaṃ “anicca”nti anupassati, evaṃ
analyzed: tattha aniccataḥ anupassati iti catu samuṭṭhānikam kāyam aniccanti anupassati evam
translated: Herein, he contemplates the body, which is the four-cornered physical frame, as impermanent.🔽Contemplating it thus, he contemplates its aspect of impermanence as “impermanent.”

original: passanto evañcassa aniccākārampi “anupassatī”ti vuccati. Tathābhūtassa cassa niccaggāhassa🔽lesopi na hotīti vuttaṃ “no niccato”ti. Tathā hesa “niccasaññaṃ pajahatī”ti vutto.
analyzed: passantaḥ evam ca assa anicca ākāram pi anupassati iti vuccati tathābhūtassa ca ssa nicca ggāhassa 🔽lesaḥ api na hoti iti vuttam no niccataḥ ti tathā ha esa nicca saññam pajahati iti vutto
translated: And since he does so, he has no perception of permanence.

original: Ettha ca “aniccato eva anupassatī”ti eva-kāro luttaniddiṭṭhoti tena nivattitamatthaṃ
analyzed: ettha ca aniccataḥ eva anupassati iti evakāraḥ lutta niddiṭṭhaḥ ti tena nivattitam attham
translated: And here the word eva is a particle indicating a negative, so in order to show the meaning of the negative

original: dassetuṃ “no niccato”ti vuttaṃ. Na cettha dukkhato anupassanādinivattanaṃ āsaṅkitabbaṃ
analyzed: dassetum no niccatas ti vuttam na ca ittha dukkhataḥ anupassanā ādi nivattanam āsaṅkitabbam
translated: it is said, “not as permanent.” And here the negating of contemplation as painful, etc., should not be taken as implied by🔽the word eva, which is only a particle negating the opposite, and because those are included in the teaching above.

original: paṭiyogīnivattanaparattā eva-kārassa, upari desanāruḷhattā ca tāsaṃ. “Dukkhato anupassatī”tiādīsupi
analyzed: paṭiyogī nivattana parattā eva kārassa upari desanā ruḷha ttā ca tāsam dukkhataḥ anupassati iti ādīsu pi
translated: The same method applies in the case of the contemplation of what is impermanent as painful, etc.,

original: eseva nayo. Ayaṃ pana viseso – aniccassa dukkhattā tameva ca kāyaṃ dukkhato anupassati,
analyzed: esa iva nayaḥ ayam pana visesaḥ aniccassa dukkha ttā tam eva ca kāyam dukkhataḥ anupassati
translated: but there is this difference. He contemplates that same body as painful because what is impermanent is painful,

original: dukkhassa anattattā anattato anupassati. Yasmā pana yaṃ aniccaṃ dukkhaṃ anattā, na
analyzed: dukkhassa anatta ttā anattataḥ anupassati yasmā pana yam aniccam dukkham anattā na
translated: and he contemplates it as not-self because what is painful is not-self. But since what is impermanent, painful, and not-self

original: taṃ abhinanditabbaṃ, yañca na abhinanditabbaṃ, na tattha rañjitabbaṃ, tasmā vuttaṃ🔽“nibbindati, no nandati. Virajjati, no rajjatī”ti. So evaṃ arajjanto rāgaṃ nirodheti,
analyzed: tam abhinanditabbam yat ca na abhinanditabbam na tattha rañjitabbam tasmā vuttam  nibbindati no nandati virajjati no rajjati iti saḥ u evam a rajjantaḥ rāgam nirodha iti
translated: is not something to delight in, and what is not something to delight in is not something to be greedy for,🔽it is said that “he becomes dispassionate and does not delight, he becomes dispassionate and does not greedily delight.”🔽As he does not greedily delight thus, he stops greed and does not originate it; the meaning is that he does not cause it to arise.

original: no samudeti samudayaṃ na karotīti attho. Evaṃ paṭipanno ca paṭinissajjati, no ādiyati.
analyzed: no samudeti samudayam na karoti iti attho evam paṭipannaḥ ca paṭinissajjati no ādiyati
translated: And he who is practising thus abandons and does not take up.

original: Ayañhi aniccādianupassanā tadaṅgavasena saddhiṃ kāyaṃ tannissayakhandhābhisaṅkhārehi🔽kilesānaṃ pariccajanato, saṅkhatadosadassanena tabbiparīte nibbāne tanninnatāya pakkhandanato
analyzed: ayan hi anicca ādi anupassanā tad aṅga vasena saddhim kāyam tad nissaya khandha abhisaṅkhārehi  kilesānam pariccajanataḥ saṅkhata dosa dassanena tad biparīte nibbāne tad ninna tāya pakkhandanato
translated: For this contemplation of impermanence, etc., is the abandoning of defilements by the abandoning of the aggregates that are its concomitants, and by the formations that are its support.🔽And it is the entering into nibbāna by seeing the danger in what is formed and by inclining towards nibbāna, which is the opposite of what is formed.

original: “pariccāgapaṭinissaggo ceva pakkhandanapaṭinissaggo cā”ti vuccati, tasmā tāya samannāgato
analyzed: pariccāga paṭinissaggo ca iva pakkhandana paṭinissaggo ca ati vuccati tasmā tāya samannāgato
translated: For this contemplation of impermanence, etc., is called “surrender” and “penetration” in the sense of the abandoning of defilements by means of the jhāna that possesses that khandha as its object, and in the sense of the penetration of Nibbāna, which is the opposite of formed things, by inclining the mind to Nibbāna through seeing the danger in formed things.

original: bhikkhu vuttanayena kilese pariccajati, nibbāne ca pakkhandati, tathābhūto ca nibbattanavasena🔽kilese na ādiyati, nāpi adosadassitāvasena saṅkhatārammaṇaṃ, tena vuttaṃ “paṭinissajjati,🔽no ādiyatī”ti. Idānissa tāhi anupassanāhi yesaṃ dhammānaṃ pahānaṃ hoti, taṃ dassetuṃ
analyzed: bhikkhu vutta nayena kilese pariccajati nibbāne ca pakkhandati tathābhūtaḥ ca nibbattana vasena  kilese na ādiyati na api adosa dassi tā vasena saṅkhata ārammaṇam tena vuttam paṭinissajjati  no ādiyati iti idāni sa tāhi anupassanāhi yesam dhammānam pahānam hoti tam dassetuṃ
translated: So the bhikkhu who possesses this contemplation surrenders defilements and penetrates Nibbāna in the way already described. And being so,🔽he does not take up defilements in the way already described, nor does he take up formed things as object by seeing them as free from defilements. Hence it was said: “He surrenders, he does not take up” .

original: “aniccato anupassanto niccasaññaṃ pajahatī”tiādi vuttaṃ. Tattha niccasaññanti “saṅkhārā
analyzed: aniccataḥ anupassantaḥ nicca saññam pajahati itiādi vuttam tattha nicca saññanti saṅkhārāḥ
translated: Now, in order to show the states that are given up by means of these contemplations, it was said: “Contemplating as impermanent, he abandons the perception of permanence” , and so on. Herein, the perception of permanence is the perception of formed things as permanent.

original: niccā”ti evaṃ pavattaṃ viparītasaññaṃ. Diṭṭhicittavipallāsappahānamukheneva saññāvipallāsappahānanti
analyzed: nicca ati evam pavattam viparīta saññam diṭṭhi citta vipallāsa pahāna mukhena iva saññā vipallāsa ppahānam ti
translated: and the perception that occurs thus is the perverted perception.

original: saññāggahaṇaṃ, saññāsīsena vā tesampi gahaṇaṃ daṭṭhabbaṃ. Nandinti sappītikataṇhaṃ.
analyzed: saññā ggahaṇam saññā sīsena vā tesam pi gahaṇam daṭṭhabbam nandinti
translated: The grasping of perception should be understood as the grasping of the perversion of view and the perversion of cognizance, or as the grasping of the perversion of perception by the head.🔽Craving is craving with happiness.

original: Sesaṃ vuttanayameva.
analyzed: sesam vutta nayam eva
translated: The rest is as already stated.🔽By the word “lives” the kind of living of one possessed of contemplation of the body is stated.

original: “Viharatī”ti iminā kāyānupassanāsamaṅgino iriyāpathavihāro vuttoti āha “iriyatī”ti,
analyzed: viharati iti iminā kāya anupassanā samaṅginaḥ iriyāpatha vihāro vutto ti āha iriyati iti
translated: The meaning is that he sets going the postures.

original: iriyāpathaṃ pavattetīti attho. Ārammaṇakaraṇavasena abhibyāpanato “tīsu bhavesū”ti
analyzed: iriyāpatham pavatteti iti attho ārammaṇa karaṇa vasena abhibyāpanato tīsu bhavesu uti
translated: Because of the manifestation by making them objects, it is said “in the three kinds of becoming” .🔽But as regards their occurrence, the defilements are only of the limited sphere.

original: vuttaṃ, uppajjanavasena pana kilesā parittabhūmakā evāti. Yadipi kilesānaṃ pahānaṃ🔽ātāpananti taṃ sammādiṭṭhiādīnampi attheva, ātappa-saddo viya pana ātāpasaddo vīriyeyeva
analyzed: vuttam uppajjana vasena pana kilesāḥ paritta bhūmakāḥ evā iti yadi api kilesānam pahānam  ātāpanam ti tam sammādiṭṭhi ādīnam pi atthā iva ātappa saddaḥ viya pana ātāpa saddaḥ vīriyeya iva
translated: Although the abandoning of defilements is🔽heat, still the word “heat” is established only in the sense of energy,🔽like the word “heat” . That is why it is said “This is a name for energy” .

original: niruḷhoti vuttaṃ “vīriyassetaṃ nāma”nti. Atha vā paṭipakkhappahāne sampayuttadhammānaṃ
analyzed: niruḷhaḥ ti vuttam vīriyassa etam nāman ti atha vā paṭipakkha ppahāne sampayutta dhammānam
translated: Or alternatively, in the abandoning of the opposite, the associated states

original: abbhussahanavasena pavattamānassa vīriyassa sātisayaṃ tadātāpananti vīriyameva tathā
analyzed: abbhussahana vasena pavattamānassa vīriyassa sa atisayam vīriyam eva tathā
translated: and since it occurs as a surpassing of that burning by energy which is occurring as arousing, it is energy that is called “burning” in this way, not other states.🔽And this particle “-i” is a particle of praise or of surpassing.

original: vuccati, na aññe dhammā. Ātāpīti cāyamīkāro pasaṃsāya, atisayassa vā dīpakoti ātāpīgahaṇena
analyzed: vuccati na aññe dhammā ātāpī iti pasaṃsāya atisayassa vā dīpako ti ātāpī gahaṇena
translated: So by the word “burning” he shows that he possesses right endeavour.

original: sammappadhānasamaṅgitaṃ dasseti. Sammā, samantato, sāmañca pajānanto sampajāno, asammissato🔽vavatthāne aññadhammānupassitābhāvena sammā aviparītaṃ, sabbākārapajānanena samantato,
analyzed: sammappadhāna samaṅgi tam dasseti sammā samantataḥ sāmañca pajānantaḥ sampajānaḥ a sammissataḥ  vavatthāne añña dhamma anupassita abhāvena sammā aviparītam sabba ākāra pajānanena samantataḥ
translated: He is “fully aware” (sampajāna) because he knows (pajānāti) rightly (sammā), all round (samantato), and in conformity (sāmañca). The meaning is that he knows rightly because he is unconfused,🔽all round because he knows in all aspects, and in conformity because he knows with the occurrence of what is progressively superior.

original: uparūpari visesāvahabhāvena pavattiyā sāmaṃ pajānantoti attho. Yadi paññāya anupassati,
analyzed: upari upari visesa āvaha bhāvena pavattiyā sāmam pajānanto ti atthaḥ yadi paññāya anupassati
translated: If he contemplates with understanding,🔽how is it the establishment of mindfulness? He says “not without” , etc.

original: kathaṃ satipaṭṭhānatāti āha “na hī”tiādi. Sabbatthikanti sabbattha bhavaṃ sabbattha
analyzed: katham satipaṭṭhāna tā ti āha na hi itiādi sabbatthikam ti sabbattha bhavam sabbattha
translated: “For all” : for all states of being everywhere,🔽because it is necessary to want to do so with regard to the mind that is slack or excited everywhere.

original: līne, uddhate ca citte icchitabbattā. Sabbe vā līne, uddhate ca bhāvetabbā bojjhaṅgā
analyzed: līne uddhate ca citte icchitabba ttā sabbe vā līne uddhate ca bhāvetabbāḥ bojjhaṅgā
translated: Or alternatively, the factors of enlightenment that are necessary for all slack and excited states to be developed are “for all” .

original: atthikā etāyāti sabbatthikā. Satiyā laddhupakārāya eva paññāya ettha yathāvutte kāye
analyzed: atthikā etāya ati sabbatthikā satiyā laddha upakārāya eva paññāya ettha yathā vutte kāye
translated: This understanding, which is a condition for the acquisition of mindfulness, is “here” in the way stated, in the body,

original: kammaṭṭhāniko bhikkhu kāyānupassī viharati. Anto saṅkhepo antoolīyano, kosajjanti
analyzed: kammaṭṭhānikaḥ bhikkhu kāya anupassī viharati antaḥ saṅkhepaḥ
translated: A meditator is a bhikkhu who is a meditator on a meditation subject. “One who is inwardly heedless” : the inwardness is the contraction, the shrinking, the slothfulness, in him.

original: attho. Upāyapariggaheti ettha sīlavisodhanādi, gaṇanādi, uggahakosallādi ca upāyo,🔽tabbipariyāyato anupāyo veditabbo. Yasmā ca upaṭṭhitassati yathāvuttaṃ upāyaṃ na
analyzed: upāya pariggahe ti ettha sīla visodhana ādi gaṇanā ādi uggaha kosalla ādi ca upāyaḥ  tad vipariyāyataḥ anupāyaḥ veditabbaḥ yasmā ca upaṭṭhitaḥ sati yathā vuttam upāyam na
translated: “The right means” : here virtue- purification, etc., counting, etc., and skill in the devices are the right means.🔽The opposite of that should be understood as the wrong means.

original: pariccajati, anupāyañca na upādiyati, tasmā vuttaṃ “muṭṭhassatī …pe… asamattho hotī”ti.
analyzed: pariccajati anupāyam ca na upādiyati tasmā vuttam muṭṭha satī pe asamatthaḥ hoti iti
translated: And because one who is mindful does not abandon the right means described in the way beginning, “He trains thus: ‘I shall breathe in … shall breathe out experiencing happiness’ ” , nor does he take up the wrong means, it is said, “One who is mindful is able to do this and that” .🔽“By that” : by the inability to take up the right means and to avoid the wrong means, to abandon the former and not to take up the latter.

original: Tenāti upāyānupāyānaṃ pariggahaparivajjanesu, pariccāgāpariggahesu ca asamatthabhāvena. Assa yogino.🔽Yasmā satiyevettha satipaṭṭhānaṃ vuttaṃ, tasmāssa sampayuttadhammā vīriyādayo aṅganti
analyzed: tena ati upāya an upāyānam pariggaha parivajjanesu pariccāga apariggahesu ca asamattha bhāvena assa yoginaḥ  yasmā satiyā iva ittha sati paṭṭhānam vuttam tasmā assa sampayutta dhammāḥ vīriya ādayaḥ aṅganti
translated: “The meditator” : the yogi.🔽Since only mindfulness is mentioned here, the associated states such as energy, etc., are its “factors” .

original: āha “sampayogaṅgañcassa dassetvā”ti. Aṅga-saddo cettha kāraṇapariyāyo daṭṭhabbo.
analyzed: āha dassetvā iti aṅga saddaḥ ca ittha kāraṇa pariyāyaḥ daṭṭhabbo
translated: Therefore it is said, “Having shown the associated factors” . And here the word “factor” should be understood in the sense of cause.

original: Satiggahaṇeneva cettha samādhissāpi gahaṇaṃ daṭṭhabbaṃ tassā samādhikkhandhe saṅgahitattā.
analyzed: sati gahaṇena iva ca ittha samādhissa api gahaṇam daṭṭhabbam tassā samādhi kkhandhe saṅgahita ttā
translated: And by the mention of mindfulness, concentration should be understood too, because it is included in the concentration aggregate.

original: Yasmā vā satisīsenāyaṃ desanā. Na hi kevalāya satiyā kilesappahānaṃ sambhavati, nibbānādhigamo🔽vā, nāpi kevalā sati pavattati, tasmāssa jhānadesanāyaṃ savitakkādivacanassa viya
analyzed: yasmā vā sati sīsena ayam desanā na hi kevalāya satiyā kilesa pahānam sambhavati nibbāna adhigamaḥ  vā nā api kevalā sati pavattati tasmā assa jhāna desanā ayam sa vitakka ādi vacanassa
translated: Or alternatively, the teaching is by way of the spear of mindfulness. For it is not possible to abandon defilements or to reach Nibbāna by means of mindfulness alone,🔽nor does mindfulness occur alone. Therefore, just as the words “accompanied by thought” , etc.,

original: sampayogaṅgadassanatāti aṅga-saddassa avayavapariyāyatā daṭṭhabbā. Pahānaṅganti “vivicceva🔽kāmehī”tiādīsu viya pahātabbaṅgaṃ dassetuṃ. Yasmā ettha lokiyamaggo adhippeto, na
analyzed: sampayoga aṅga dassana tā ti aṅga saddassa avayava pariyāya tā daṭṭhabbā pahāna aṅgam ti vivicca iva  kāmehi iti ādīsu viya pahātabba aṅgam dassetum yasmai ettha lokiya maggaḥ adhippetaḥ na
translated: are used in the teaching of the jhānas, so too here the word “factor” should be regarded as denoting a concomitant. The “factor of abandoning” is mentioned in order to show the factor to be abandoned, as in the passage beginning, “Quite secluded from sense desires, secluded from unprofitable things” .🔽Since the mundane path is intended here, not the supramundane path,

original: lokuttaramaggo, tasmā pubbabhāgiyameva vinayaṃ dassento “tadaṅgavinayena vā vikkhambhanavinayena
analyzed: lokuttara maggo tasmai pubbabhāgiyam eva vinayam dassento tad aṅga vinayena vā vikkhambhana vinayena
translated: he said, “by means of the disciplinary act that is a means of abandoning or by means of the disciplinary act that is a means of suppressing” , showing the disciplinary act that pertains to the preliminary stage.

original: vā”ti āha. Tesaṃ dhammānanti vedanādidhammānaṃ. Tesañhi tattha anadhippetattā “atthuddhāranayenetaṃ
analyzed: vā ti āha tesam dhammānam ti vedanā ādi dhammānam tesam hi tattha an adhippeta ttā attha uddhāra nayena itam
translated: The “those states” are the states of feeling, etc. For since they are not intended here, it is said: “This is said by way of the method of the meaning of the words.”

original: vutta”nti vuttaṃ. Tatthāti vibhaṅge. Etthāti “loke”ti etasmiṃ pade.
analyzed: vuttam iti vuttam tattha ati vibhaṅge ettha ati loke iti etasmin pade
translated: “There” is in the Vibhaṅga. “Here” is in the passage beginning, “In the world” .

original: Avisesena dvīhipi nīvaraṇappahānaṃ vuttanti katvā puna ekekena vuttaṃ pahānavisesaṃ
analyzed: avisesena dvīhi pi nīvaraṇa pahānam vuttan ti katvā punar ekekena vuttam pahāna visesam
translated: Since the abandoning of the hindrances is stated by both in a general way, the abandoning of the hindrances by the first is stated again in particular by the second.

original: dassetuṃ “visesenā”ti āha. Atha vā “vineyya nīvaraṇānī”ti avatvā abhijjhādomanassavinayavacanassa🔽payojanaṃ dassento “visesenā”tiādimāha. Kāyānupassanābhāvanāya hi ujuvipaccanīkānaṃ
analyzed: dassetum visesena ati āha atha vā vineyya nīvaraṇāni iti avatvā abhijjhā domanassa vinaya vacanassa  payojanam dassentaḥ visesena ati ādim āha kāya anupassanā bhāvanāya hi uju vipaccanīkānam
translated: He says “in particular” in order to show. Or else, without saying “having removed the hindrances,” he says “in particular” in order to show the purpose of the words “having removed greed and grief” .🔽For the purpose of this meditation is the seeing of the abandoning of the hindrances, which are the opposites of the enlightenment factors, and of the abandoning of the likes and dislikes, which are the opposites of equanimity.

original: anurodhavirodhādīnaṃ pahānadassanaṃ etassa payojananti. Kāyasampattimūlakassāti rūpabalayobbanārogyādisarīrasampadānimittassa.
analyzed: anurodha virodha ādīnam pahāna dassanam etassa payojanam ti kāya sampatti mūlakassa ati rūpa bala yobbana ārogya ādi sarīra sampadā nimittassa
translated: “The root of the body’s excellence”: the cause of the excellence of the body consisting in beauty, strength, youth, health, and so on.🔽The opposite of this should be understood as the root of the body’s deficiency.

original: Vuttavipariyāyato kāyavipattimūlako virodho veditabbo. Kāyabhāvanāyāti kāyānupassanābhāvanāya.
analyzed: vutta vipariyāyataḥ kāya vipatti mūlakaḥ virodhaḥ veditabbaḥ kāya bhāvanāya ati kāya anupassanā bhāvanāya
translated: “The body’s development”: the development of the contemplation of the body.🔽For that is intended here as the body’s development.

original: Sā hi idha kāyabhāvanāti adhippetā. Subhasukhabhāvādīnanti ādi-saddena manuññaniccatādisaṅgaho🔽daṭṭhabbo. Asubhāsukhabhāvādīnanti ettha pana ādi-saddena amanuññaaniccatādīnaṃ.
analyzed: sā hi idha kāya bhāvanā ati adhippetā ādi saddena manuñña nicca tā ādi saṅgaho  daṭṭhabbaḥ asubha asukha bhāva ādīnam ti ettha pana ādi saddena amanuñña anicca tā ādīnam
translated: The word “and so on” in the phrase “the state of beauty, pleasure, and so on” should be understood to include the states of lovability, eternity, and so on.🔽But in the phrase “the state of ugliness, pain, and so on” the word “and so on” should be understood to include the states of unlovability, impermanence, and so on.

original: Tenāti anurodhādippahānavacanena. “Yogānubhāvo hī”tiādi vuttassevatthassa pākaṭakaraṇaṃ.
analyzed: tena ati anurodha ādi ppahāna vacanena yoga anubhāvaḥ hi itiādi pākaṭa karaṇam
translated: “The power of concentration”: the purpose of the words “having removed the hindrances” is to show that the abandoning of the likes and dislikes is due to the power of concentration.

original: Yogānubhāvo hi bhāvanānubhāvo. Yogasamatthoti yogamanuyuñjituṃ samattho. Purimena
analyzed: yoga anubhāvaḥ hi bhāvanā anubhāvaḥ yoga samatthaḥ iti yogam anuyuñjitum samatthaḥ purimena
translated: For the power of the yogi is the power of development. “Able to undertake the yogi’s task” means able to undertake the development of insight.

original: hi “anurodhavirodhavippamutto”tiādivacanena bhāvanaṃ anuyuttassa ānisaṃso vutto,
analyzed: hi anurodha virodha vippamuttaḥ ti ādi vacanena bhāvanam anuyuttassa ānisaṃsaḥ vutto
translated: For by the first phrase the benefit of one who is devoted to development is stated,

original: dutiyena bhāvanaṃ anuyuñjantassa paṭipatti. Na hi anurodhavirodhādīhi upaddutassa bhāvanā ijjhati.🔽Anupassīti etthāti “anupassī”ti etasmiṃ pade labbhamānāya anupassanāya anupassanājotanāya
analyzed: dutiyena bhāvanam anuyuñjantassa paṭipatti na hi anurodha virodha ādīhi upaddutassa bhāvanā ijjhati  anupassī iti ettha ati anupassī iti etasmin pade labbhamānāya anupassanāya anupassana ājotanāya
translated: and by the second, the practice of one who undertakes development. For development does not succeed in one who is troubled by approval and opposition, etc.

original: kammaṭṭhānaṃ vuttanti evamattho daṭṭhabbo, aññathā “anupassanāyā”ti karaṇavacanaṃ
analyzed: kammaṭṭhānam vuttanti evamatthaḥ daṭṭhabbaḥ aññathā anupassanāya āti karaṇa vacanam
translated: “Contemplating”: the meaning should be regarded thus: “The meditation subject is stated by the word ‘contemplating’ which is a term for insight that is possible in the word ‘contemplating.’ Otherwise the instrumental case in ‘contemplating’

original: na yujjeyya. Anupassanā eva hi kammaṭṭhānaṃ, na ettha ārammaṇaṃ adhippetaṃ, yujjati🔽vā. Kāyapariharaṇaṃ vuttanti sambandho. Kammaṭṭhānapariharaṇassa cettha atthasiddhattā
analyzed: na yujjeyya anupassanā eva hi kammaṭṭhānam na ettha ārammaṇam adhippetam yujjati  vā kāya pariharaṇam vuttan ti sambandhaḥ kammaṭṭhāna pariharaṇassa ca ittha attha siddha tā
translated: would not be appropriate. For it is insight itself that is the meditation subject, and the object is not intended here.🔽The construction is: “The meditation subject is stated as ‘the keeping in being of the body.’“ But since the meaning of the meditation subject is established here by the words “the keeping in being of the body,”

original: “kāyapariharaṇa”ntveva vuttaṃ. Kammaṭṭhānikassa hi kāyapariharaṇaṃ yāvadeva kammaṭṭhānaṃ
analyzed: kāya pariharaṇam tu eva vuttam kammaṭṭhānikassa hi kāya pariharaṇam yāvat eva kammaṭṭhānam
translated: it is said only as “the keeping in being of the body.” For the keeping in being of the body of one who has a meditation subject is only the meditation subject.

original: pariharaṇatthanti. Kammaṭṭhānapariharaṇassa vā “ātāpī”tiādinā vuccamānattā “kāyapariharaṇa”ntveva
analyzed: pariharaṇa atthanti kammaṭṭhāna pariharaṇassa vā ātāpī iti ādinā vuccamāna ttā kāya pariharaṇam tu eva
translated: “For the purpose of keeping it in being”: or alternatively, since it is said in the way beginning, “He is ardent”, it is called “keeping the body in being”.

original: vuttaṃ. Kāyaggahaṇena vā nāmakāyassāpi gahaṇaṃ, na rūpakāyasseva, teneva kammaṭṭhānapariharaṇampi🔽saṅgahitaṃ hoti, evañca katvā “viharatīti ettha vuttavihārenā”ti etthaggahaṇañca🔽samatthitaṃ hoti “kāyānupassī viharatī”ti vihārassa visesetvā vuttattā. “Ātāpī”tiādi
analyzed: vuttam kāya ggahaṇena vā nāma kāyassa api gahaṇam na rūpa kāyassa iva tena iva kammaṭṭhāna pariharaṇam pi  saṅgahitam hoti evam ca katvā viharati iti ettha vutta vihārena ati etthak gahaṇam ca  samatthitam hoti kāya anupassī viharati iti vihārassa visesetvā vutta ttā ātāpi itiādi
translated: Or by the word “body” the mental body is included as well as the material body, not only the material body. That is why the keeping in being of the meditation subject is included too.🔽And when it is put thus, the inclusion of the word “body” in the phrase “he breathes in … he breathes out … he trains thus ‘I shall breathe out’” is justified.

original: pana saṅkhepato vuttassa kammaṭṭhānapariharaṇassa saha sādhanena vitthāretvā dassanaṃ.
analyzed: pana saṅkhepataḥ vuttassa kammaṭṭhāna pariharaṇassa saha sādhanena vitthāretvā dassanam
translated: And the phrase “he trains thus ‘contemplating relinquishment I shall breathe out’” is justified by the words “he trains thus ‘I shall breathe out contemplating the body’” because the word “body” is used in the sense of the meditation subject.🔽“Ardent” is said with reference to the ardour. So too with “having clear comprehension” and so on.

original: Ātāpenāti ātāpaggahaṇena. “Satisampajaññenā”tiādīsupi eseva nayo. Sabbatthakakammaṭṭhānanti
analyzed: ātāpena ati ātāpa gahaṇena sati sampajaññena ati ādīsu pi esa iva nayaḥ sabbatthaka kammaṭṭhānam ti
translated: “The meditation subject in all aspects”:

original: buddhānussati, mettā, maraṇassati, asubhabhāvanā ca. Idañhi catukkaṃ yoginā parihariyamānaṃ
analyzed: buddha anussati mettā maraṇa ssati asubha bhāvanā ca idam hi catukkam yoginā parihariyamānam
translated: the recollection of the Buddha, loving-kindness, mindfulness of death, and foulness. For when this tetrad is kept in being by a meditator,

original: “sabbatthakakammaṭṭhāna”nti vuccati, sabbattha kammaṭṭhānānuyogassārakkhabhūtattā🔽satisampajaññabalena avicchinnassa pariharitabbattā satisampajaññaggahaṇena tassa
analyzed: sabbatthaka kammaṭṭhānan ti vuccati sabbattha kammaṭṭhāna anuyoga sārakkha bhūta ttā  sati sampajañña balena avicchinnassa pariharitabba ttā sati sampajañña ggahaṇena tassa
translated: It is called “a meditation subject for all” because it is a protection for the pursuit of meditation subjects in all instances.🔽And it is called “mentioned by the word mindfulness and full awareness” because it has to be borne in mind without break by means of the power of mindfulness and full awareness.

original: vuttatā vuttā. Satiyā vā samatho vutto tassā samādhikkhandhena saṅgahitattā.🔽Vibhaṅge pana attho vuttoti yojanā. Tenāti saddatthaṃ anādiyitvā bhāvatthasseva vibhajanavasena
analyzed: vutta tā vuttā satiyāḥ vā samathaḥ vuttaḥ tassā samādhi kkhandhena saṅgahita ttā  vibhaṅge pana atthaḥ vuttaḥ iti yojanā tena ati saddattham an ādiyitvā bhāva tthassa iva vibhajana vasena
translated: Or alternatively, “calm” is mentioned by the word mindfulness because it is included in the concentration aggregate.🔽But the meaning is stated in the Vibhaṅga, is the construction. “By that” means by the text of the Vibhaṅga, which is a commentary on the meaning of the word, since it is stated by analysis of the meaning of being, not by taking the meaning of the word.

original: pavattena vibhaṅgapāṭhena saha. Aṭṭhakathānayoti saddatthassāpi vivaraṇavasena yathārahaṃ
analyzed: pavattena vibhaṅga pāṭhena saha aṭṭhakathā nayo ti saddatthassa api vivaraṇa vasena yathāraham
translated: “By the commentaries” means by the method of explaining the meaning stated as appropriate by way of the elucidation of the meaning of the word.

original: vutto atthasaṃvaṇṇanānayo. Yathā saṃsandatīti yathā atthato, adhippāyato ca avilomento🔽aññadatthu saṃsandati sameti, evaṃ veditabbo.
analyzed: vuttaḥ attha saṃvaṇṇanā nayaḥ yathā saṃsandati iti yathā atthataḥ adhippāyato ca  aññadatthu saṃsandati sameti evam veditabbaḥ
translated: “How it is relevant” means how it is relevant without confusion of meaning and intention, how it is relevant in the sense of being consistent.

original: Vedanādīnaṃ puna vacaneti ettha nissayapaccayabhāvavasena cittadhammānaṃ vedanāsannissitattā,
analyzed: vedanā ādīnam puna vacanā iti ettha nissaya paccaya bhāva vasena citta dhammānam vedanā sannissita ttā
translated: As to the restatement of feeling, etc., the mental states of consciousness are dependent on feeling

original: pañcavokārabhave arūpadhammānaṃ rūpapaṭibaddhavuttito ca vedanāya kāyādianupassanāppasaṅgepi
analyzed: pañcavokāra bhave arūpa dhammānam rūpa paṭibaddha vuttito ca vedanāya kāya ādi anupassanā appasaṅge pi
translated: And in the five-constituent becoming, because of the occurrence of the immaterial states bound up with materiality, the contemplation of feeling as in the body might be misconstrued.

original: āpanne tato asammissato vavatthānaṃ dassanatthaṃ, ghanavinibbhogādidassanatthañca🔽dutiyaṃ vedanāggahaṇaṃ, tena na vedanāyaṃ kāyānupassī, cittadhammānupassī vā, atha
analyzed: āpanne tatas a sammissataḥ vavatthānam dassana attham ghana vinibbhoga ādi dassana attham ca  dutiyam vedanā ggahaṇam tena na vedanā ayam kāya anupassī citta dhamma anupassī vā atha
translated: So a second mention of feeling is given in order to show their delimitation as unmixed, and in order to show the dissolution of compactness, etc.,

original: kho vedanānupassī evāti vedanāsaṅkhāte vatthusmiṃ vedanānupassanākārasseva dassanena🔽asammissato vavatthānaṃ dassitaṃ hoti. Tathā “yasmiṃ samaye sukhā vedanā, na tasmiṃ🔽samaye dukkhā, adukkhamasukhā vā vedanā, yasmiṃ vā pana samaye dukkhā, adukkhamasukhā
analyzed: kho vedanā anupassī eva ati vedanā saṅkhāte vatthusmim vedanā anupassanā ākārassa iva dassanena  a sammissataḥ vavatthānam dassitam hoti tathā yasmin samaye sukhā vedanā na tasmin  samaye dukkhā adukkhamasukhā vā vedanā yasmin vā pana samaye dukkhā adukkhamasukhā
translated: by which the contemplation of feeling is shown as the only one in the case of the materiality called “feeling.”🔽So by showing the contemplation of feeling as the only one in the case of the materiality called “feeling,”

original: vā vedanā, na tasmiṃ samaye itarā vedanā”ti vedanābhāvasāmaññe avatvā taṃ taṃ vedanaṃ🔽vinibbhujjitvā dassanena ghanavinibbhogo dhuvabhāvaviveko dassito hoti, tena tāsaṃ
analyzed: vā vedanā na tasmin samaye itarā vedanā ati vedanā bhāva sāmaññe avatvā tam tam vedanam 🔽vinibbhujjitvā dassanena ghana vinibbhogaḥ dhuva bhāva vivekaḥ dassitaḥ hoti tena tāsam
translated: their delimitation as unmixed is shown. And likewise the dissolution of compactness and the separation of what is compact is shown by the way in which the three kinds of feeling are shown by distinguishing each one from the other, without any reference to the common characteristic of being felt, in the way beginning, “When there is pleasant feeling, then there is none that is painful or neither-painful-nor-pleasant” .

original: khaṇamattāvaṭṭhānadassanena aniccatāya, tato eva dukkhatāya, anattatāya ca dassanaṃ
analyzed: khaṇa matta avaṭṭhāna dassanena anicca tāya tatas eva dukkha tāya anatta tāya ca dassanaṃ
translated: By seeing the state of the object as momentary, the seeing of impermanence, and then of suffering and not-self,

original: vibhāvitaṃ hoti. Ghanavinibbhogādīti ādi-saddena ayampi attho veditabbo. Ayañhi vedanāyaṃ
analyzed: vibhāvitam hoti ghana vinibbhoga ādi iti ādi saddena ayam pi atthaḥ veditabbaḥ ayam hi vedanā ayam
translated: is made clear. “By the analysis of the compact, etc.”: by the word “etc.” is meant this meaning. For this meditator

original: vedanānupassī eva, na aññadhammānupassī. Kiṃ vuttaṃ hoti – yathā nāma bālo amaṇisabhāvepi
analyzed: vedanā anupassī eva na añña dhamma anupassī kim vuttam hoti yathā nāma bālaḥ a maṇi sabhāve pi
translated: is only a contemplator of feeling, not a contemplator of other states. What is meant? Just as a fool, when looking at a water bubble,

original: udakapubbuḷake maṇiākārānupassī hoti, na evaṃ ayaṃ ṭhitiramaṇīyepi vedayite, pageva🔽itarasmiṃ manuññākārānupassī, atha kho khaṇapabhaṅguratāya, avasavattitāya kilesāsucipaggharaṇatāya
analyzed: udaka pubbuḷake maṇi ākāra anupassī hoti na evam ayam ṭhiti ramaṇīye api vedayite pagā iva  itarasmim manuñña ākāra anupassī atha kho khaṇa pabhaṅgura tāya avasavatti tāya kilesa asuci paggharaṇa tāya
translated: sees it as a gem, so this meditator does not see the feeling, whether pleasant or painful, as something desirable,🔽but rather sees it as impermanent because of its momentary dissolution, as not-self because of its lack of self-control, and as foul because of its secretion of impure substances.

original: ca aniccaanattaasubhākārānupassī, vipariṇāmadukkhatāya, saṅkhāradukkhatāya ca visesato
analyzed: ca anicca anatta asubha ākāra anupassī vipariṇāma dukkha tāya saṅkhāra dukkha tāya ca visesataḥ
translated: And he sees it as suffering in particular by way of the suffering of change and the suffering of formations.

original: dukkhānupassī yevāti. Evaṃ citta dhammesupi yathārahaṃ punavacane payojanaṃ vattabbaṃ.
analyzed: dukkha anupassī yeva āti evam citta dhammesu pi yathāraham punavacane payojanam vattabbam
translated: Thus, in the case of consciousness and mental objects, the purpose of the repetition should be stated in the appropriate way.

original: Lokiyā eva sammasanacārassa adhippetattā. “Kevalaṃ panidhā”tiādinā “idha ettakaṃ🔽veditabba”nti veditabbaparicchedaṃ dasseti. “Esa nayo”ti iminā yathā cittaṃ, dhammā🔽ca anupassitabbā, tathā tāni anupassanto citte cittānupassī, dhammesu dhammānupassīti🔽veditabboti imamatthaṃ atidisati. Dukkhatoti dukkhasabhāvato, dukkhanti anupassitabbāti
analyzed: lokiyāḥ eva sammasana cārassa adhippeta ttā kevalam panidhā ti ādinā idha ettakam  veditabbam ti veditabba paricchedam dasseti esa nayo ti iminā yathā cittam dhammā  ca anupassitabbā tathā tāni anupassantaḥ citte citta anupassī dhammesu dhamma anupassī iti  veditabbaḥ ti imam attham atidisati dukkhataḥ ti dukkha sabhāvataḥ dukkhanti anupassitabbā ti
translated: Because only mundane insight is intended here. “But only the mere establishment of the sign” shows the delimitation of what is to be known thus: “Herein, this much is to be known.” “The same method applies to the other two” shows that the meaning of “contemplating mind as mind” and “contemplating ideas as ideas” should be understood thus: he contemplates mind as mind, he contemplates ideas as ideas, by way of contemplation of rise and fall, by way of contemplation of dissolution, by way of contemplation of destruction, by way of contemplation of fall, by way of contemplation of change, by way of contemplation of the signless, by way of contemplation of voidness, by way of contemplation of the inconstant, by way of contemplation of the non-self, by way of contemplation of danger, by way of contemplation of disenchantment, by way of contemplation of the turn away, by way of contemplation of fading away, by way of contemplation of cessation, by way of contemplation of relinquishment. “As painful” : as having the nature of pain. “He should contemplate it as painful” :

original: attho. Sesapadadvayepi eseva nayo.🔽Yo sukhaṃ dukkhato addāti yo bhikkhu sukhaṃ vedanaṃ vipariṇāmadukkhatāya “dukkhā”ti🔽paññācakkhunā addakkhi. Dukkhaṃ addakkhi sallatoti dukkhaṃ vedanaṃ pīḷājananato,
analyzed: attho sesa pada dvaye pi esa iva nayo  yaḥ sukham dukkhataḥ addāti yaḥ bhikkhu sukham vedanam vipariṇāma dukkha tāya dukkhāti  paññācakkhunā addakkhi dukkham addakkhi sallataḥ ti dukkham vedanam pīḷā jananato
translated: Because only mundane insight is intended here. “But only the mere establishment of the mind” : this shows the delimitation of what is to be known thus, “Herein, this much is to be known.” “The same method applies to the rest” : by this he shows the meaning of “one contemplating mind in mind” and “one contemplating mental objects in mental objects” thus: he contemplates those things in such a way that they are to be known in this way. “As impermanent” : as having the nature of impermanence. The meaning is: he should contemplate them as “impermanent.” The same method applies to the other two terms.🔽“One who sees pleasure as pain”: a bhikkhu who sees pleasant feeling by the eye of wisdom as pain because of the suffering inherent in change.🔽“One who sees pain as a dart”: he sees painful feeling as a dart because it generates suffering, because it pierces to the quick, and because it is hard to extract.

original: antotudanato, dunnīharaṇato ca sallato addakkhi passi. Adukkhamasukhanti upekkhāvedanaṃ.
analyzed: antotudanataḥ dunnīharaṇataḥ ca sallataḥ addakkhi passi adukkham asukhanti upekkhā vedanaṃ
translated: “One who sees neither pleasure nor pain”: he sees neither-painful-nor-pleasant feeling as neither pleasure nor pain.

original: Santanti sukhadukkhāni viya anoḷārikatāya, paccayavasena vūpasantasabhāvatāya ca
analyzed: santanti sukha dukkhāni viya anoḷārika tāya paccaya vasena vūpasanta sabhāva tāya ca
translated: “Peaceful” : because of being unmixed, like pleasure and pain, and because of being by nature calmed down by way of conditions.

original: santaṃ. Aniccatoti hutvāabhāvato, udayavayavantato, tāvakālikato, niccapaṭipakkhato
analyzed: santam aniccato ti hutvā abhāvataḥ udaya vaya antataḥ tāvakālikataḥ nicca paṭipakkhato
translated: “Impermanent” : he saw as “impermanent” in the sense of non-existence after having come to be, in the sense of having rise and fall, in the sense of being for a short time, and in the sense of being the opposite of permanence.

original: ca “anicca”nti yo addakkhi. Sa ve sammaddaso bhikkhu ekaṃsena, paribyattaṃ vā vedanāya
analyzed: ca aniccanti yaḥ addakkhi sa ve sammaddasaḥ bhikkhu ekaṃsena paribyattam vā vedanāya
translated: He, the monk who saw thus, is the one who saw rightly, one-sidedly, or in a complete manner, in regard to feeling.

original: sammāpassanakoti attho.🔽Dukkhātipīti saṅkhāradukkhatāya dukkhā itipi. Taṃ dukkhasminti sabbaṃ taṃ vedayitaṃ
analyzed: sammāpassanakaḥ ti attho  dukkha atipi iti saṅkhāra dukkha tāya dukkhā tam dukkhasmin ti sabbam tam vedayitam
translated: The meaning is: he who sees rightly.🔽“Painful” : painful in the sense of the suffering inherent in formations.🔽“I say that all that is included in, and falls within, suffering” : I say that all that is felt

original: dukkhasmiṃ antogadhaṃ pariyāpannaṃ vadāmi saṅkhāradukkhatānativattanato. Sukhadukkhatopi
analyzed: dukkhasmin antogadham pariyāpannam vadāmi saṅkhāra dukkha tā an ativattanataḥ sukha dukkhataḥ pi
translated: is included in, and falls within, suffering, because of not going beyond the suffering inherent in formations.

original: cāti sukhādīnaṃ ṭhitivipariṇāmañāṇasukhatāya, vipariṇāmaṭhitiaññāṇadukkhatāya ca
analyzed: ca ati sukha ādīnam ṭhiti vipariṇāma ñāṇa sukha tāya vipariṇāma ṭhiti aññāṇa dukkha tāya ca
translated: “From the point of view of pleasure and pain” : because of the pleasure of the knowledge of the change-of-lineage of pleasure, etc., and because of the pain of the ignorance of the change-of-lineage of pleasure, etc.,

original: vuttattā tissopi ca sukhato, tissopi ca dukkhato anupassitabbāti attho. Satta anupassanā
analyzed: vutta ttā tissaḥ api ca sukhataḥ tissaḥ api ca dukkhataḥ anupassitabbā ti atthaḥ satta anupassanā
translated: it is said. The meaning is: one should contemplate as pleasure and as pain, respectively.

original: heṭṭhā pakāsitā eva. Sesanti yathāvuttaṃ sukhādivibhāgato sesaṃ sāmisanirāmisādibhedaṃ
analyzed: heṭṭhā pakāsitāḥ eva sesanti yathā vuttam sukha ādi vibhāgato sesam sāmisa nirāmisa ādi bhedam
translated: are as already described. The rest are the rest of the kinds of feeling classed as pleasant, etc., as already described, which are mixed with greed, etc.,

original: vedanānupassanāyaṃ vattabbaṃ.
analyzed: vedanā anupassanā ayam vattabbam
translated: and which are to be spoken of in the contemplation of feeling.

original: Ārammaṇa…pe… bhedānanti rūpādiārammaṇanānattassa nīlāditabbhedassa, chandādiadhipatinānattassa
analyzed: ārammaṇa pe bheda ananti rūpa ādi ārammaṇa nānattassa nīla ādi tad bhedassa chanda ādi adhipati nānattassa
translated: As to object, etc.: as to the variety of objects consisting of visible data, etc., as to the variety of aspects consisting of blue, etc., as to the variety of predominance consisting of will, etc.,

original: hīnāditabbhedassa, ñāṇajhānādisahajātanānattassa sasaṅkhārikāsaṅkhārikasavitakkāditabbhedassa,
analyzed: hīna ādi tad bhedassa ñāṇa jhāna ādi sahajāta nānattassa sa saṅkhārika asaṅkhārika sa vitakka ādi tad bhedassa
translated: as to the variety of co-nascence with knowledge, jhāna, etc., as to the variety of presence or absence of applied thought, etc.,

original: kāmāvacarādibhūminānattassa ukkaṭṭhamajjhimāditabbhedassa, kusalādikammanānattassa
analyzed: kāmāvacara ādi bhūmi nānattassa ukkaṭṭha majjhima ādi tad bhedassa kusala ādi kamma nānattassa
translated: as to the variety of plane consisting of the sense sphere, and so on, as to the variety of aspect consisting of the fine-material sphere, and so on, as to the variety of profitable, etc., kamma,

original: devagatisaṃvattaniyatāditabbhedassa, kaṇhasukkavipākanānattassa diṭṭhadhammavedanīyatāditabbhedassa,
analyzed: deva gati saṃvatta niyata ādi tad bhedassa kaṇha sukka vipāka nānattassa diṭṭha dhamma vedanīya tā ādi tad bhedassa
translated: as to the variety of destiny consisting of the destiny of the gods, and so on, as to the variety of ripening consisting of the black and white kinds, as to the variety of ripening consisting of ripening in this life, and so on,

original: parittabhūmakādikiriyānānattassa tihetukāditabbhedassa vasena anupassitabbanti yojanā.
analyzed: paritta bhūmaka ādi kiriyā nānattassa ti hetuka ādi tad bhedassa vasena anupassitabbanti yojanā
translated: as to the variety of function consisting of the function of the limited sphere, and so on, as to the variety of root consisting of the triple root, and so on. “He should contemplate them as impermanent, and so on”: he should contemplate them as impermanent, and so on, in the various ways already described.

original: Ādi-saddena savatthukāvatthukādinānattassa puggalattayasādhāraṇāditabbhedassa ca
analyzed: ādi saddena savatthuka avatthuka ādi nānattassa ca
translated: The word “etc.” includes the variety of presence or absence of a visible form, etc., as to the variety of aspect consisting of what is common to the three kinds of persons, and so on.

original: saṅgaho daṭṭhabbo. Salakkhaṇasāmaññalakkhaṇānanti phusanāditaṃtaṃlakkhaṇānañceva
analyzed: saṅgahaḥ daṭṭhabbo sa lakkhaṇa sāmañña lakkhaṇānam ti phusana ādi tad tad lakkhaṇānam ca eva
translated: and the aggregates should be seen as the field of their occurrence.🔽As to the characteristic, etc., and the general characteristic: the construction is as follows: as to the individual characteristic of each of the states beginning with feeling, and as to the general characteristic of impermanence, etc.,

original: aniccatādisāmaññalakkhaṇānañca vasenāti yojanā. Suññatadhammassāti anattatāsaṅkhātasuññatāsabhāvassa.
analyzed: anicca tā ādi sāmañña lakkhaṇānam ca vasena ati yojanā suññata dhammassa āti anatta tā saṅkhāta suñña tā sabhāvassa
translated: As to the state of voidness: as to the state of voidness called “non-self.”

original: Yaṃ vibhāvetuṃ abhidhamme“tasmiṃ kho pana samaye dhammā honti, khandhā hontī”tiādinā
analyzed: yam vibhāvetum abhidhamma itasmin kho pana samaye dhammāḥ honti khandhāḥ honti itiādinā
translated: In order to illustrate that, the teaching of the exposition of voidness occurs in the Abhidhamma as follows: “At that time there are ideas, there are aggregates” ,

original: suññatāvāradesanā pavattā, taṃ pahīnameva pubbe pahīnattā, tasmā tassa tassa puna
analyzed: suñña tā vāra desanā pavattā tam pahīnam eva pubbe pahīna ttā tasmā tassa tassa puna
translated: and so on. That has already been given up previously, and so it need not be mentioned again as something to be given up.

original: pahānaṃ na vattabbaṃ. Na hi kilesā pahīyamānā ārammaṇavibhāgena pahīyanti anāgatānaṃyeva🔽uppajjanārahānaṃ pahātabbattā, tasmā abhijjhādīnaṃ ekattha pahānaṃ vatvā itarattha
analyzed: pahānam na vattabbam na hi kilesāḥ pahīyamānāḥ ārammaṇa vibhāgena pahīyanti anāgatānam yeva  uppajjana arahānam pahātabba ttā tasmai abhijjhā ādīnam ekattha pahānam vatvā itarattha
translated: For defilements are not given up by the abandoning of their object, because what is to be given up is only that which is capable of arising in the future.🔽Therefore, after the lust, etc., have been mentioned as given up in one place, it need not be mentioned again in another place.

original: na vattabbaṃ evāti imamatthaṃ dasseti “kāmañcetthā”tiādinā. Atha vā maggacittakkhaṇe
analyzed: na vattabbam eva ati imam attham dasseti kāmañca itthā iti ādinā atha vā magga citta kkhaṇe
translated: This is the meaning he shows by the words “If it be asked, etc.”

original: ekattha pahīnaṃ sabbattha pahīnameva hotīti visuṃ visuṃ pahānaṃ na vattabbaṃ. Maggena
analyzed: ekattha pahīnam sabbattha pahīnam eva hoti iti visum visum pahānam na vattabbam maggena
translated: Or alternatively, when they are given up in one place they are given up everywhere at the moment of the path consciousness, and so they need not be mentioned as given up separately.

original: hi pahīnāti vattabbataṃ arahanti. Tattha purimāya codanāya nānāpuggalaparihāro, na
analyzed: hi pahīnā ati vattabba tam arahanti tattha purimāya codanāya nānā puggala parihāraḥ na
translated: “It is to be said that it is abandoned in the former case, and that it is suppressed in the latter case. Herein, the former question is answered by the individual,

original: hi ekassa pahīnaṃ tato aññassa pahīnaṃ nāma hoti. Pacchimāya nānācittakkhaṇikaparihāro.
analyzed: hi ekassa pahīnam tatas aññassa pahīnam nāma hoti pacchimāya nānā citta kkhaṇika parihāro
translated: for what is abandoned by one is not necessarily abandoned by another. The latter question is answered by the moment of consciousness.

original: Nānācittakkhaṇeti hi lokiyamaggacittakkhaṇeti adhippāyo. Pubbabhāgamaggo hi idhādhippeto.🔽Lokiyabhāvanāya ca kāye pahīnaṃ na vedanādīsu vikkhambhitaṃ hoti. Yadipi nappavatteyya,
analyzed: nānā cittakkhaṇā iti hi lokiya magga cittakkhaṇā iti adhippāyaḥ pubbabhāga maggaḥ hi idha adhippeto  lokiya bhāvanāya ca kāye pahīnam na vedanā ādīsu vikkhambhitam hoti yadi pi
translated: For the moment of consciousness is the moment of the path of any one of the three planes.🔽And what is abandoned in the body by development of the mundane path is not suppressed in feeling, etc., even though it does not occur there.

original: paṭipakkhabhāvanāya suppahīnattā tattha sā “abhijjhādomanassassa appavattī”ti na
analyzed: paṭipakkha bhāvanāya su pahīna ttā tattha sā abhijjhā domanassassa appavattī iti na
translated: And although it does not occur there, it is not to be said that it has “ceased to occur in relation to covetousness and grief” because it has been well abandoned by the development of the opposition.

original: vattabbā, tasmā punapi tappahānaṃ vattabbameva. Ekattha pahīnaṃ sesesupi pahīnaṃ
analyzed: vattabbā tasmā puna api tad pahānam vattabbam eva ekattha pahīnam sesesu pi pahīnam
translated: Therefore its abandonment must be stated again. What is abandoned in one place is abandoned in the rest.

original: hotīti lokuttarasatipaṭṭhānabhāvanaṃ, lokiyabhāvanāya vā sabbattha appavattimattaṃ
analyzed: hoti iti lokuttara sati paṭṭhāna bhāvanam lokiya bhāvanāya vā sabbattha appavattimattam
translated: This is said with reference to the development of the supramundane foundations of mindfulness, or else with reference to the mere non-occurrence of the mundane development in the rest.

original: sandhāya vuttaṃ. “Pañcapi khandhā upādānakkhandhā loko”ti hi vibhaṅgecatūsupi ṭhānesu vuttanti.
analyzed: sandhāya vuttam pañca api khandhāḥ upādānakkhandhāḥ loko ti hi vibhaṅge catūsu pi ṭhānesu vuttan ti
translated: For in the Vibhaṅga the four foundations of mindfulness are said to be included in the five aggregates subject to clinging, which are the world: “The five aggregates subject to clinging are the world. In what sense world? In the sense of burning, in the sense of turbulence, in the sense of change, in the sense of variety” .

original: Uddesavāravaṇṇanāya līnatthappakāsanā.
translated: The exposition of the “rehearsal” is the demonstration of the meaning of the “rehearsal” .

original: Kāyānupassanā
analyzed: kāya anupassanā
translated: Contemplation of the body

original: Ānāpānapabbavaṇṇanā🔽374. Ārammaṇavasenāti anupassitabbakāyādiārammaṇavasena. Catudhā bhinditvāti uddesavasena
analyzed: āna apāna pabba vaṇṇanā  ārammaṇa vasena ati anupassitabba kāya ādi ārammaṇa vasena catudhā bhinditvā ati uddesa vasena
translated: The exposition of the “breathless state”🔽“By way of object”: by way of the object of contemplation, namely, the body, etc.🔽“Having divided it up into four”: having divided it up into four by way of the “rehearsal” .

original: catudhā bhinditvā. Tato catubbidhasatipaṭṭhānato ekekaṃ satipaṭṭhānaṃ gahetvā kāyaṃ
analyzed: catudhā bhinditvā tatas catubbidha sati paṭṭhānataḥ ekekam sati paṭṭhānam gahetvā kāyam
translated: Then, taking each of the four foundations of mindfulness, he “analyzes the body” , etc.,

original: vibhajantoti pāṭhaseso.
analyzed: vibhajantaḥ iti pāṭha sesaḥ
translated: is the remainder of the text.

original: Kathañcāti ettha kathanti pakārapucchā, tena niddisiyamāne kāyānupassanāpakāre pucchati.
analyzed: katham ca ati ettha katham ti pakāra pucchā tena niddisiyamāne kāya anupassanā pakāre pucchati
translated: “How?” Here “how” is a mode of questioning; he asks by this how-question about the mode of contemplation of the body.

original: Ca-saddo byatireko, tena uddesavārena apākaṭaṃ niddesavārena vibhāviyamānaṃ visesaṃ
analyzed: casaddaḥ byatirekaḥ tena uddesa vārena apākaṭam niddesa vārena vibhāviyamānam visesam
translated: The word “also” indicates the distinction that is not clear in the “rehearsal” but is made clear in the “exposition.”

original: joteti. Bāhirakesupi ito ekadesassa sambhavato sabbappakāraggahaṇaṃ kataṃ “sabbappakārakāyānupassanānibbattakassā”ti,
analyzed: jotā iti bāhirakesu pi itas eka desassa sambhavataḥ sabba ppakāra ggahaṇam katam sabba ppakāra kāya anupassanā nibbattakassa ati
translated: “Having originated from all manner of body-contemplation” : all manner of body-contemplation is mentioned because a part of it is found among the external disciples.

original: tena ye ime ānāpānapabbādivasena āgatā cuddasappakārā, tadantogadhā ca ajjhattādianupassanāppakārā,
analyzed: tena ye ime āna apāna pabba ādi vasena āgatā cuddasa ppakārā tad anta gadhā ca ajjhatta ādi anupassanā appakārā
translated: The fourteen manners of contemplation beginning with the “breathless state” and the manners of contemplation of the internal, etc., included in them,

original: tathā kāyagatāsatisutte vuttā kesādivaṇṇasaṇṭhānakasiṇārammaṇacatukkajjhānappakārā,🔽lokiyādippakārā ca, te sabbepi anavasesato saṅgaṇhāti. Ime ca pakārā imasmiṃyeva
analyzed: tathā kāyagatāsatisutte vuttā kesa ādi vaṇṇa saṇṭhāna kasiṇa ārammaṇa catukka jjhāna ppakārā  ca te sabbe pi anavasesataḥ saṅgaṇhāti ime ca pakārāḥ imasmin yeva
translated: Likewise the kasiṇas consisting of the colours of the head hairs, etc., which are the object of the four jhānas stated in the Kāyagatāsati Sutta ,

original: sāsane, na ito bahiddhāti vuttaṃ “sabbappakāra…pe… paṭisedhano cā”ti. Tattha tathābhāvapaṭisedhanoti🔽sabbappakārakāyānupassanānibbattakassa puggalassa aññasāsanassa nissayabhāvapaṭisedhano,🔽etena idha bhikkhaveti ettha idha-saddo antogadhaevasaddatthoti dasseti. Santi hi
analyzed: sāsane na itas bahiddhā iti vuttam ca ati tattha tathābhāva paṭisedhano ti  sabba ppakāra kāya anupassanā nibbattakassa puggalassa añña sāsanassa nissaya bhāva paṭisedhano  etena idha bhikkhave ti ettha idha saddaḥ dasseti santi hi
translated: and the kinds of jhāna classed as mundane, etc., are all included without exception. And these kinds of jhānas are found only in this dispensation, not outside it, thus it is said: “all kinds of … are refuted here” . Herein, the refutation of the state of being is the refutation of the state of being a recluse in anyone who is not a recluse in the true sense of the word.🔽This shows that the word here in the passage, “Here, bhikkhus” , has the meaning of “only.” For there are words of limitation in a single clause,

original: ekapadānipi avadhāraṇāni yathā “vāyubhakkho”ti. Tenāha “idheva bhikkhave samaṇo”tiādi.
analyzed: eka padāni api avadhāraṇāni yathā tena āha idha iva bhikkhave samaṇa uti ādi
translated: as in the passage, “One who has wind for his food” . That is why he said, “Here, bhikkhus, only a recluse” ,

original: Paripuṇṇasamaṇappakaraṇadhammo hi so puggalo, yo sabbappakārakāyānupassanānibbattako.
analyzed: paripuṇṇa samaṇa ppakaraṇa dhammaḥ hi so puggalaḥ yaḥ sabba ppakāra kāya anupassanā nibbattakaḥ
translated: for that person who is a recluse in the true sense of the word is one who has attained to the jhāna called “recollection of stilling” .

original: Parappavādāti paresaṃ aññatitthiyānaṃ nānappakārā vādā titthāyatanāni.
analyzed: para ppavādā ti paresam añña titthiyānam nāna ppakārāḥ vādāḥ tittha āyatanāni
translated: Other doctrines: the various doctrines, the various theories, the various views, the various persuasions, the various inclinations, the various preferences, the various creeds, the various ways of regarding things, of other sectarians, of the teachers of other schools, of the ascetics, brahmans, and wanderers.

original: Araññādikasseva bhāvanānurūpasenāsanataṃ dassetuṃ “imassahī”tiādi vuttaṃ. Duddamo🔽damathaṃ anupagato goṇo kūṭagoṇo. Dohanakāle yathā thanehi anavasesato khīraṃ na🔽paggharati, evaṃ dohapaṭibandhinī kūṭadhenu. Rūpa-saddādike paṭicca uppajjanakaassādo🔽rūpārammaṇādiraso. Pubbe āciṇṇārammaṇanti pabbajjato pubbe, anādimati vā saṃsāre
analyzed: arañña ādikassa iva bhāvanā anurūpa senāsana tam dassetum imassa hi itiādi vuttam duddamo  damatham an upagataḥ goṇaḥ kūṭa goṇaḥ dohana kāle yathā khīram na  paggharati evam doha paṭibandhinī kūṭa dhenu rūpa sadda ādike paṭicca uppajjanaka assādaḥ  rūpa ārammaṇa ādi rasaḥ pubbe āciṇṇa ārammaṇanti pabbajjataḥ pubbe anādimati vā saṃsāre
translated: “This one” is said in order to show that the lodging is suitable for the development of the forest-dweller’s practice.🔽A bull that is not yet tamed, that has not yet been brought under control, is a wild bull.🔽Just as milk does not flow out completely from the udder at the time of milking,🔽so the wild cow is a hindrance to the flow of milk.🔽The taste that arises in dependence on visible forms, sounds, etc., is the taste of visible forms, etc.🔽The object that was experienced in the past, either before going forth or in the beginningless process of cyclic existence,

original: paricitārammaṇaṃ. Nibandheyyāti bandheyya. Satiyāti sammadeva kammaṭṭhānassa sallakkhaṇavasena🔽pavattāya satiyā. Ārammaṇeti kammaṭṭhānārammaṇe. Daḷhanti thiraṃ, yathā satokārissa🔽upacārappanābhedo samādhi ijjhati, tathā thāmagataṃ katvāti attho.🔽Visesādhigamadiṭṭhadhammasukhavihārapadaṭṭhānanti sabbesaṃ buddhānaṃ, ekaccānaṃ paccekabuddhānaṃ,
analyzed: paricita ārammaṇam nibandheyya ati bandheyya satiyā ati sammat eva kammaṭṭhānassa sat lakkhaṇa vasena 🔽pavattāya satiyā ārammaṇe iti kammaṭṭhāna ārammaṇe daḷhanti thiram yathā satokārissa 🔽upacāra ppanā bhedaḥ samādhi ijjhati tathā thāma gatam katvā iti attho 🔽visesa adhigama diṭṭha dhamma sukha vihāra padaṭṭhānanti sabbesam buddhānam ekaccānam paccekabuddhānam
translated: The words “and so on” are said in order to show that the lodging is suitable for development of concentration in one who has gone to the forest, etc. A bull that is difficult to tame is a wild bull. A wild cow is one that obstructs the flow of milk, just as a cow does when the calf is being milked, by not allowing the milk to flow out completely. The taste that arises in dependence on visible forms, sounds, etc., is the taste of the object of the visible-form element, etc. The object formerly experienced is an object that has been experienced before going forth or in the beginningless round of rebirths. He should bind his mind to that object: he should bind it to the object of meditation. By means of mindfulness: by means of the mindfulness that occurs by way of proper reflection on the meditation subject. To the object: to the object of meditation. Firmly: firmly established, in such a way that the concentration consisting in access and absorption succeeds in one of strong desire. The words “the basis for the attainment of distinction” mean the basis for the attainment of the bliss of the vision of nibbāna.

original: buddhasāvakānañca visesādhigamassa aññena kammaṭṭhānena adhigatavisesānaṃ diṭṭhadhammasukhavihārassa padaṭṭhānabhūtaṃ.
analyzed: buddha sāvakānaṃ ca visesa adhigamassa aññena kammaṭṭhānena adhigata visesānam diṭṭhadhamma sukha vihārassa padaṭṭhāna bhūtam
translated: and it is the footing for the special attainment of the Buddhas’ disciples, and for the abiding in bliss here and now of those who have attained special attainments by some other meditation subject.🔽The Blessed One is like a teacher of the science of ground because he advises meditators as to a suitable place to stay.

original: Vatthuvijjācariyo viya bhagavā yogīnaṃ anurūpanivāsaṭṭhānupadisanato. Bhikkhu dīpisadiso🔽araññe ekako viharitvā paṭipakkhanimmathanavasena icchitatthasādhanato phalamuttamanti
analyzed: vatthuvijjā cariyaḥ viya bhagavā yogīnam anurūpa nivāsa ṭṭhāna upadisanataḥ bhikkhu dīpi sadisaḥ  araññe ekakaḥ viharitvā paṭipakkha nimmathana vasena icchita attha sādhanataḥ phalam uttamanti
translated: The bhikkhu is like a deer🔽because, after living alone in the forest, he achieves his desired aim by the exertion of the return.🔽The word “fruit” is used in the sense of the fruit of asceticism.

original: sāmaññaphalaṃ sandhāya vadati. Parakkamajavayoggabhūminti bhāvanussāhajavassa yoggakaraṇabhūmibhūtaṃ.

translated: he defines them by way of the immaterial, being intent on serenity. The physical basis is the body of physical heart since it is the site of the occurrence of consciousness and its concomitants.

original: Añño satto vā puggalo vā natthīti visuddhidiṭṭhi “tayidaṃ dhammamattaṃ, na ahetukaṃ,
analyzed: aññaḥ sattaḥ vā puggalo vā natthi iti visuddhi diṭṭhi tayidam dhamma mattam na ahetukam

analyzed: vitiṇṇa kaṅkhaḥ yam kiñci bhikkhu rūpan ti ādinā nayena kalāpa sammasana vasena ti lakkhaṇam

original: āropetvā. Udayavayānupassanādivasena vipassanaṃ vaḍḍhento. Anukkamena maggapaṭipāṭiyā.
analyzed: āropetvā udaya vaya anupassana ādi vasena vipassanam vaḍḍhentaḥ anukkamena magga paṭipāṭiyā
translated: and having done so, he develops insight by means of the contemplation of rise and fall, etc., and in due course he reaches the direct path.

original: “Parassa vā assāsapassāsakāye”ti idaṃ sammasanavāravasenāyaṃ pāḷi pavattāti katvā
analyzed: parassa vā assāsa passāsakāya iti idam sammasana vāra vasena ayam pāḷi pavattā ati katvā
translated: “In another’s in-breath and out-breath” is said because this text occurs in the section dealing with the exercise of reviewing.

original: vuttaṃ, samathavasena pana parassa assāsapassāsakāye appanānimittuppatti eva natthi.🔽Aṭṭhapetvāti antarantarā na ṭhapetvā. Aparāparaṃ sañcaraṇakāloti ajjhattabahiddhādhammesupi🔽nirantaraṃ vā bhāvanāya pavattanakālo kathito. Ekasmiṃ kāle panidaṃ ubhayaṃ na labbhatīti
analyzed: vuttam samatha vasena pana parassa assāsa passāsa kāye appanā nimitta uppatti eva natthi  a aṭṭhapetvā ti antar antarā na ṭhapetvā apara aparam sañcaraṇa kālo ti ajjhatta bahiddhā dhammesu pi  nirantaram vā bhāvanāya pavattana kālo kathito ekasmin kāle pana idam ubhayam na labbhati iti
translated: But in the case of serenity, there is no arising of the sign as object in another’s in-breath and out-breath.🔽“Without distinguishing” means without making a distinction. The “time of passing to and fro” is said to be the time of uninterrupted occurrence of development in the case of the sign of in-breaths and out-breaths as an internal or external object.🔽But this pair is not found at one time.

original: “ajjhattaṃ, bahiddhā”ti ca vuttaṃ idaṃ dhammadvayaṃ ghaṭitaṃ ekasmiṃ kāle ekato ārammaṇabhāvena
analyzed: ajjhattam bahiddhā ti ca vuttam idam dhamma dvayam ghaṭitam ekasmim kāle ekatas ārammaṇa bhāvena
translated: The pair of states called “in oneself” and “in another” is not found at one time as object in the way of being combined into one.

original: na labbhati, ekajjhaṃ ālambituṃ na sakkāti attho.
analyzed: na labbhati ekajjham ālambitum na sakkā iti attho
translated: The meaning is that it cannot be taken as a single object.

original: Samudeti etasmāti samudayo, so eva kāraṇaṭṭhena dhammoti samudayadhammo. Assāsapassāsānaṃ
analyzed: samudeti etasmā ati samudayo saḥ eva kāraṇa ṭṭhena dhammo ti samudaya dhammo assāsa passāsānam
translated: The origin is that from which it originates. The state of origin is the state that is the cause of that.

original: uppattihetu karajakāyādi, tassa anupassanasīlo samudayadhammānupassī, taṃ pana samudayadhammaṃ🔽upamāya dassento “yathā nāmā”tiādimāha. Tattha bhastanti ruttiṃ. Pakativācī vā🔽dhamma-saddo “jātidhammāna”ntiādīsu viyāti kāyassa paccayasamavāye uppajjanakapakatikāyānupassī
analyzed: uppatti hetu karaja kāya ādi tassa anupassana sīlaḥ samudaya dhamma anupassī tam pana samudaya dhammaṃ  upamāya dassentaḥ yathā nāma ati ādim āha tattha bhastam ti ruttim gaggara nāḷim ti ukkāpa nāḷim  tā iti karaja kāya ādike yathā assāsa passāsa kāyaḥ karaja kāya ādi sambandhī tad nimitta tāya  evam karaja kāya ādayaḥ api assāsa passāsa kāya sambandhinaḥ tad nimitta bhāvena ati samudaya dhammā  kāyasmin ti vattabbatam labhanti iti vuttam samudaya pe vuccati iti pakati vācī vā  dhamma saddaḥ jāti dhamma ananti ādīsu viyāti kāyassa paccaya samavāye uppajjanaka pakatikāya anupassī
translated: The origin-cause is the body of in-breath and out-breath, etc., and the one who has the habit of contemplating that is contemplating as having origination.🔽But that which has origination is shown by a simile in the words beginning with “Just as, etc.,” Herein, bhaṃ means sound. Gaggaranaḷi means a bamboo tube.🔽Te means the body of in-breath and out-breath, etc. Just as the body of in-breath and out-breath is related to the body of in-breath and out-breath, etc., by being their sign,🔽so too the body of in-breath and out-breath, etc., are related to the body of in-breath and out-breath by being its sign. That is why it is said that they “are called origination in the body” .🔽Or the word dhamma in the phrase “origin-dhamma” is a verbal noun formed from the verb pacati .🔽It is used in the sense of origination in the way in which it is used in such passages as “of origination- dhammas” . So the meaning is that he contemplates the body that originates in the concurrence of conditions for the body.🔽

analyzed: paṭhama vikappa vasena attha vibhāvanā dutiya vikappa vasena upacārena vinā iva atthaḥ veditabbo  ajjhatta bahiddhā anupassanā viya bhinna vatthu visaya tāya samudaya vaya dhamma anupassanā api

Thus the non-existence of the body of consciousness, etc., is said to be the cause of the destruction of the body of in-breaths and out-breaths by way of a simile. Hence he said: “As in the case of the bellows” . This, in the first place, is the exposition of the meaning of contemplation of destruction by way of the first method of exposition. By way of the second method of exposition the meaning should be understood as follows:
