analyzed: eka kāle na labbhati iti āha kālena samudayam kālena vayam anupassanto ti atthi kāyo ti  eva saddaḥ lutta niddiṭṭhaḥ ti kāyaḥ iva atthi iti vatvā avadhāraṇena nivattitam dassento
translated: Contemplation of arising and contemplation of destruction are not possible at one time, like the contemplation of the internal and the contemplation of the external, because they have different objects. Therefore he said: “Contemplating arising at one time and destruction at another time” . The word “only” is a term of exclusion.🔽The meaning is: there is only the body, not a being.🔽The word “only” is a term of exclusion.

original: “na satto”tiādimāha. Tassattho – yo rūpādīsu sattavisattatāya, paresañca sajjāpanaṭṭhena,
analyzed: na satta iti ādim āha tassa atthaḥ yaḥ rūpa ādīsu satta visattatāya paresam ca sajjāpana ṭṭhena
translated: The meaning is: there is only the body, not a being.

original: satvaguṇayogato vā “satto”ti parehi parikappito, tassa sattanikāyassa pūraṇato ca🔽cavanupapajjanadhammatāya galanato ca “puggalo”ti, thīyati saṃhaññati ettha gabbhoti
analyzed: satva guṇa yogataḥ vā satto ti parehi parikappito tassa satta nikāyassa pūraṇato ca  cavan upapajjana dhamma tāya galanataḥ ca puggalaḥ ti thīyati saṃhaññati ettha gabbho ti
translated: Or else, “being” is so called because it is imagined by others as a combination of the qualities of being, and because it fills the gap between the past and future existences of the being.🔽“Person” is so called because of the nature of dying and being reborn again and again, and because of the passing away of the person.🔽“Woman” is so called because the embryo is kept and formed there.

original: “itthī”ti, puri pure bhāge seti pavattatīti “puriso”ti, āhito ahaṃ māno etthāti “attā”ti,
analyzed: itthī iti puri pure bhāge saḥ iti pavattati iti purisaḥ iti āhitaḥ aham mānaḥ ettha ati attā ati
translated: “Man” is so called because it lies in the earlier and earlier stages of the embryo.🔽“Self” is so called because the conceit “I am” is based there.🔽“One’s own” is so called because it is one’s own property.

original: attano santakabhāvena “attaniya”nti, paro na hotīti katvā “aha”nti, mama santakanti
analyzed: attano santaka bhāvena attaniyanti paraḥ na hoti iti katvā ahanti mama santakanti
translated: “Another” is so called because it is not another’s.🔽“Someone” is so called because it is different from the one described above.

original: katvā “mamā”ti, vuttappakāravinimutto aññoti katvā “kocī”ti, tassa santakabhāvena
analyzed: katvā mama ati vutta ppakāra vinimuttaḥ aññaḥ ti katvā koci iti tassa santaka bhāvena
translated: “Someone else’s” is so called because it is the property of another.

original: “kassacī”ti, vikappetabbo koci natthi, kevalaṃ “kāyo eva atthī”ti. Dasahipi padehi🔽attattaniyasuññatameva kāyassa vibhāveti. Evanti “kāyova atthī”tiādinā vuttappakārena.
analyzed: kassaci iti vikappetabbaḥ koci na atthi kevalam kāyaḥ eva atthi iti dasahi api padehi  kāyassa vibhāveti evam ti kāyaḥ uva atthi iti ādinā vutta ppakārena
translated: “There is no one to be found who can be designated,” because there is no one to be found of the kind described above.🔽“Only the body exists” is so called because it is the mere body.

original: Ñāṇapamāṇatthāyāti kāyānupassanāñāṇaṃ paraṃ pamāṇaṃ pāpanatthāya. Satipamāṇatthāyāti
analyzed: ñāṇa pamāṇa atthāya ati kāya anupassanā ñāṇam param pamāṇam pāpana tthāya sati pamāṇa atthāya ati
translated: “For the purpose of knowing the measure of knowledge” is for the purpose of making the knowledge of contemplation of the body the highest measure. “For the purpose of knowing the measure of mindfulness” is for the purpose of making mindfulness of the body the highest measure.

original: kāyapariggāhikaṃ satiṃ pavattanasatiṃ paraṃ pamāṇaṃ pāpanatthāya. Imassa hi vuttanayena
analyzed: kāya pariggāhikam satim pavattana satim param pamāṇam pāpana tthāya imassa hi vutta nayena
translated: and mindfulness that is a bodily resort, mindfulness that is directed mindfulness, to the highest degree, for the purpose of attaining the measureless. For this

original: “atthi kāyo”ti aparāparuppattivasena paccupaṭṭhitā sati bhiyyoso mattāya tattha ñāṇassa,
analyzed: atthi kāyo ti apara apara uppatti vasena paccupaṭṭhitā sati bhiyyosaḥ mattāya tattha ñāṇassa
translated: He develops mindfulness that is concerned with the body, mindfulness that is directed to the body, for the purpose of surmounting the measureless. For this mindfulness that is established by the occurrence of the body as “there is the body” is a condition for the knowledge of the measureless body.

original: satiyā ca paribrūhanāya hoti. Tenāha “satisampajaññānaṃ vuḍḍhatthāyā”ti. Imissā bhāvanāya
analyzed: satiyā ca paribrūhanāya hoti tena āha sati sampajaññānam vuḍḍhatthāya ati imissā bhāvanāya
translated: And it is a condition for the increase of mindfulness. Therefore it is said: “for the increase of mindfulness and full awareness.”

original: taṇhādiṭṭhiggāhānaṃ ujupaṭipakkhattā vuttaṃ “taṇhā…pe… viharatī”ti. Tathābhūto ca
analyzed: taṇhā diṭṭhi ggāhānam uju paṭipakkha ttā vuttam taṇhā pe viharati iti tathābhūtaḥ ca
translated: In this development, since craving and views are the direct opponents of the path, it is said: “he abides contemplating arising and vanishing in the body.”

original: loke kiñcipi “aha”nti vā “mama”nti vā gahetabbaṃ na passati, kuto gaṇheyyāti āha🔽“na ca kiñcī”tiādi. Evampīti ettha pi-saddo heṭṭhā niddiṭṭhassa tādisassa atthassa
analyzed: loke kiñcipi ahanti vā mamanti vā gahetabbam na passati kutas gaṇheyya ati āha  na ca kiñci itiādi evam pi iti ettha pi saddaḥ heṭṭhā niddiṭṭhassa tādisassa atthassa
translated: One who is such does not see anything in the world that could be clung to as “I” or “mine.” How could he cling? Therefore it is said:🔽“and he does not grasp at anything in the world.” The word “also” in the phrase “he also abides independent” shows that the meaning of the compound is inclusive.🔽“He also abides independent” means that he abides independent of the world.🔽“He also abides unattached” means that he abides unattached to the world.

original: abhāvato avuttasamuccayatthoti dassento “upari atthaṃ upādāyā”ti āha yathā “antamaso🔽tiracchānagatāyapi, ayampi pārājiko hotī”ti. evanti pana niddiṭṭhākārassa paccāmasanaṃ
analyzed: abhāvataḥ a vutta samuccaya tthaḥ ti dassentaḥ upari attham upādāya ati āha yathā antamaso 🔽ayam pi pārājikaḥ hoti iti evam ti pana niddiṭṭha ākārassa paccāmasanam
translated: “He also abides secluded” means that he abides secluded from the world.🔽“He also abides with a mind that is free from evil states” means that he abides with a mind that is free from the defilements of the world.🔽“He also abides with a mind that is free from worldly states” means that he abides with a mind that is free from the world’s states of greed, etc.🔽“He also abides with a mind that is free from defilements” means that he abides with a mind that is free from the defilements of the world.🔽“He also abides with a mind that is free from worldly states” means that he abides with a mind that is free from the world’s states of greed, etc.

original: nigamanavasena katanti āha “iminā pana…pe… dassetī”ti.
analyzed: nigamana vasena katanti āha iminā pana pe dasseti iti
translated: He shows this by the words “But by this method … he shows the four truths.”

original: Pubbabhāgasatipaṭṭhānassa idha adhippetattā vuttaṃ “sati dukkhasacca”nti. Sā pana
analyzed: pubbabhāga sati paṭṭhānassa idha adhippeta ttā vuttam sati dukkha saccanti sā pana
translated: Since the foundations of mindfulness in the prior stage are intended here, he says “Mindfulness is the truth of suffering.”

original: sati yasmiṃ attabhāve, tassa samuṭṭhāpikā taṇhā, tassāpi samuṭṭhāpikā eva nāma hoti
analyzed: sati yasmin attabhāve tassa samuṭṭhāpikā taṇhā tassa api samuṭṭhāpikā eva nāma hoti
translated: But that mindfulness is the craving that generates the selfhood in which it occurs, and that craving is the craving that generates that craving.

original: tadabhāve abhāvatoti āha “tassā samuṭṭhāpikā purimataṇhā”ti, yathā “saṅkhārapaccayā”ti.
analyzed: tad abhāve abhāvato ti āha tassā samuṭṭhāpikā purima taṇhā āti yathā saṅkhāra paccayā ti
translated: Since there is no occurrence of the latter without the former, he says “The prior craving generates that.” As in the case of the words “With formations as condition.”

original: Taṃviññāṇabījataṃsantatisambhūto sabbopi lokiyo viññāṇappabandho “saṅkhārapaccayā🔽viññāṇaṃ” tveva vuccati suttantanayena. Appavattīti appavattinimittaṃ, ubhinnaṃ appavattiyā
analyzed: tad viññāṇa bīja tad santati sambhūto sabbaḥ api lokiyaḥ viññāṇa ppabandho saṅkhāra paccayā  viññāṇam tu eva vuccati suttanta nayena appavattī iti appavatti nimittam ubhinnam appavattiyā
translated: All the occurrence of consciousness in the world, which is generated by the seed of that consciousness, is called “With formations as condition, consciousness” in the way of the texts.

original: nimittabhūtoti attho. Na pavattati etthāti vā appavatti. “Dukkhaparijānano”tiādi
analyzed: nimitta bhūtaḥ ti atthaḥ na pavattati ettha ati vā appavatti dukkha parijānanaḥ tiādi
translated: “The sign of non-occurrence” is the sign of non-occurrence of both. The meaning is that it is the sign of the non-occurrence of both. Or “non-occurrence” is “non-occurrence here.”

original: ekantato catukiccasādhanavaseneva ariyamaggassa pavattīti dassetuṃ vuttaṃ. Avuttasiddho
translated: The words “The understanding of suffering” and so on are said in order to show that the noble path occurs only as the accomplishment of the fourfold task.

original: hi tassa bhāvanāpaṭivedho. Catusaccavasenāti catusaccakammaṭṭhānavasena. Ussakkitvāti
analyzed: hi tassa bhāvanā paṭivedhaḥ catu sacca vasena āti catu sacca kammaṭṭhāna vasena ussakkitvā ati
translated: for that is the penetration of development. By means of the four foundations of mindfulness: by means of the meditation subject consisting in the four foundations of mindfulness. He should make sure:

original: visuddhiparamparāya āruhitvā, bhāvanaṃ upari netvāti attho. Niyyānamukhanti vaṭṭadukkhato nissaraṇūpāyo.
analyzed: visuddhi paramparāya āruhitvā bhāvanam upari netvā ti attho niyyāna mukhanti vaṭṭa dukkhataḥ nissaraṇa upāyaḥ
translated: he should make sure by mounting the successive stages of purification and by bringing development to fulfilment, is the meaning. Outlet: means of escape from the suffering of the round of rebirths.

original: Ānāpānapabbavaṇṇanā niṭṭhitā.🔽Iriyāpathapabbavaṇṇanā
analyzed: āna apāna pabba vaṇṇanā niṭṭhitā  iriyāpatha pabba vaṇṇanā
translated: The description of the Ānāpānasati is ended.

original: 375. Iriyāpathavasenāti iriyanaṃ iriyā, kiriyā, idha pana kāyikapayogo veditabbo.
analyzed: iriyāpatha vasena ati iriyanam iriyā kiriyā idha pana kāyika payogaḥ veditabbo
translated: By means of the postures: iriyanaṃ iriyā, kiriyā, here it should be understood as bodily activity.

original: Iriyānaṃ patho pavattimaggoti iriyāpatho, gamanādivasena pavattā sarīrāvatthā. Gacchanto
analyzed: iriyānam patho pavatti maggo ti iriyāpathaḥ gamana ādi vasena pavattā sarīra avatthāḥ gacchanto
translated: The path of the postures is the iriyāpatho, the state of the body occurring by means of going, etc. For a being, while going,

original: vā hi satto kāyena kātabbakiriyaṃ karoti ṭhito vā nisinno vā nipanno vāti, tesaṃ
analyzed: vā hi sattaḥ kāyena kātabba kiriyam karoti ṭhitaḥ vā nisinnaḥ vā nipannaḥ vā ati tesam
translated: or standing, or sitting, or lying down, performs the function that has to be done by the body.🔽By means of those postures, by the analysis of the postures, is the meaning.

original: iriyāpathānaṃ vasena, iriyāpathavibhāgenāti attho. Puna caparanti puna ca aparaṃ,
analyzed: iriyāpathānam vasena iriyāpatha vibhāgena ati puna ca paranti puna ca aparam
translated: And again: and again, further,

original: yathāvuttaānāpānakammaṭṭhānato bhiyyopi aññaṃ kāyānupassanākammaṭṭhānaṃ kathemi,
analyzed: yathā vutta ānāpāna kammaṭṭhānataḥ bhiyyas api aññam kāya anupassanā kammaṭṭhānam kathemi
translated: after the meditation subject consisting in mindfulness of breathing already described, there is another meditation subject of contemplation of the body, which is as follows.

original: suṇāthāti vā adhippāyo. “Gacchanto vā”tiādi gamanādimattajānanassa, gamanādigatavisesajānanassa
analyzed: suṇātha ati vā adhippāyaḥ gacchantaḥ vā atiādi gamana ādi matta jānanassa gamana ādi gata visesa jānanassa
translated: or the meaning intended is “Listen!”🔽The words “going, etc.” are said in common for one who knows merely going, etc., and for one who knows the specific state of going, etc.

original: ca sādhāraṇavacanaṃ, tattha gamanādimattajānanaṃ na idha nādhippetaṃ, gamanādigatavisesajānanaṃ
analyzed: ca sādhāraṇa vacanam tattha gamana ādimatta jānanam na idha na adhippetam gamana ādi gata visesa jānanam
translated: Herein, knowing merely going, etc., is not intended here; but knowing the specific state of going, etc.,

original: pana adhippetanti taṃ vibhajitvā dassetuṃ “tattha kāma”ntiādi vuttaṃ. Sattūpaladdhinti
analyzed: pana adhippetanti tam vibhajitvā dassetum tattha kāma nti ādi vuttam sattu upaladdhinti
translated: is intended. In order to show that, after analyzing it, it is said, “Herein, what is the world?”🔽The “apprehension of a being” is the grasping of a being, the apprehension that “a being exists.”

original: “satto atthī”ti upaladdhiṃ sattaggāhaṃ. Na pajahati na pariccajati “ahaṃ gacchāmi,
analyzed: sattaḥ atthi iti upaladdhim sattaggāham na pajahati na pariccajati aham gacchāmi
translated: He does not abandon, does not relinquish, the grasping “I go,🔽my going.” Consequently,

original: mama gamana”nti gāhasabbhāvato. Tato eva attasaññaṃ “atthi attā kārako vedako”ti
analyzed: mama gamanam ti gāha sabbhāvato tatas eva atta saññam atthi attā kārakaḥ vedako ti
translated: he does not remove, does not do away with, the notion of self, the notion that occurs thus “There is a self, an agent, an experiencer.”

original: evaṃ pavattaṃ viparītasaññaṃ na ugghāṭeti nāpaneti appaṭipakkhabhāvato, ananubrūhanato
analyzed: evam pavattam viparīta saññam na ugghāṭeti na apaneti appaṭipakkha bhāvataḥ an anubrūhanato
translated: Because it is not opposed to that, or because it does not increase it.

original: vā. Evaṃ bhūtassa cassa kuto kammaṭṭhānādibhāvoti āha “kammaṭṭhānaṃ vā satipaṭṭhānabhāvanā
analyzed: vā evam bhūtassa ca ssa kutas kammaṭṭhāna ādi bhāvaḥ ti āha kammaṭṭhānam vā sati paṭṭhāna bhāvanā
translated: How can one who is such have a meditation subject, etc.? Therefore it is said, “A meditation subject, the development of the foundations of mindfulness,

original: vā na hotī”ti. “Imassa panā”tiādi sukkapakkho, tassa vuttavipariyāyena attho veditabbo.
analyzed: vā na hoti iti imassa pana atiādi sukkapakkhaḥ tassa vutta vipariyāyena atthaḥ veditabbaḥ
translated: “But is there any such case?” The bright side is the opposite of the dark side.

original: Tameva hi atthaṃ vivarituṃ “idañhī”tiādi vuttaṃ.
analyzed: tam eva hi attham vivaritum idam hi itiādi vuttam
translated: “But is there no going in the case of this?” is the bright side. Its meaning should be understood in the opposite sense to the above.

original: Tattha ko gacchatīti sādhanaṃ, kiriyañca avinibbhuttaṃ katvā gamanakiriyāya kattupucchā,🔽sā kattubhāvavisiṭṭhaattapaṭikkhepatthā dhammamattasseva gamanasiddhidassanato. Kassa
analyzed: tattha kaḥ gacchati iti sādhanam kiriyam ca avinibbhuttam katvā gamana kiriyāya kattu pucchā  sā kattu bhāva visiṭṭha atta paṭikkhepa atthā dhamma mattassa iva gamana siddhi dassanato kassa
translated: “Herein, what goes?” is a question about the doing of the act of going, the means and the action being not distinguished.🔽It is stated in order to show that the mere idea of an entity is established as going, since the self is denied as the doer.

original: gamananti tamevatthaṃ pariyāyantarena vadati sādhanaṃ, kiriyañca vinibbhuttaṃ katvā
analyzed: gamanam ti tam evattham vadati sādhanam kiriyam ca vinibbhuttam katvā
translated: “Whose going?” is a question about the means and the action being distinguished,

original: gamanakiriyāya akattusambandhībhāvavibhāvanato. Paṭikkhepatthañhi antonītaṃ katvā
analyzed: gamana kiriyāya a kattu sambandhībhāva vibhāvanataḥ paṭikkhepa attham hi antonītam katvā
translated: since it is stated in order to make clear the relationship of the non-doer to the act of going.🔽For the word “what” is used in both cases after the denial has been made.

original: ubhayatthaṃ kiṃ-saddo pavatto. Kiṃ kāraṇāti pana paṭikkhittakattukāya gamanakiriyāya
analyzed: ubhayattham kiṃsaddaḥ pavattaḥ kim kāraṇā ati pana paṭikkhitta kattukāya gamana kiriyāya
translated: “Why does it go?” is a question about the reason that is not opposed to the act of going, which has been denied as a doing.

original: aviparītakāraṇapucchā. Idañhi gamanaṃ nāma attā manasā saṃyujjati, mano indriyehi,
analyzed: aviparīta kāraṇa pucchā idam hi gamanam nāma attā manasā saṃyujjati manaḥ indriyehi
translated: For this going is said to be the self’s being conjoined with the mind, the mind with the faculties,

original: indriyāni attehīti evamādi micchākāraṇavinimuttaanurūpapaccayahetuko dhammānaṃ pavattiākāraviseso.
analyzed: indriyāni attehi iti evamādi micchā kāraṇa vinimutta anurūpa paccaya hetukaḥ dhammānam pavatti ākāra visesaḥ
translated: “The faculties are the self’s goer” and so on are the various ways in which dhammas occur, free from wrong reasons, and due to appropriate conditions and causes.

original: Tenāha “tatthā”tiādi.
analyzed: tena āha tattha atiādi
translated: Hence he said “Herein” and so on.

original: Na koci satto vā puggalo vā gacchati dhammamattasseva gamanasiddhito, tabbinimuttassa
analyzed: na koci sattaḥ vā puggalaḥ vā gacchati dhamma mattassa iva gamana siddhitaḥ tad vinimuttassa
translated: No being or person goes, because going is established only as a dhamma, and because there is no one apart from that.

original: ca kassaci abhāvato. Idāni dhammamattasseva gamanasiddhiṃ dassetuṃ “cittakiriyāvāyodhātuvipphārenā”tiādi
analyzed: ca kassaci abhāvataḥ idāni dhamma mattassa iva gamana siddhim dassetum citta kiriyā vāyaḥ dhātu vipphārena atiādi
translated: Now, in order to show that going is established only as a dhamma, he said “by the diffusion of the air element that is the action of consciousness” and so on.

original: vuttaṃ. Tattha cittakiriyā ca sā, vāyodhātuyā vipphāro vipphandanañcāti cittakiriyāvāyodhātuvipphāro,
analyzed: vuttam tattha citta kiriyā ca sā vāyodhātuyā vipphāraḥ vipphandanam ca ati citta kiriyā vāyodhātu vipphāro
translated: Herein, it is the action of consciousness, and it is the diffusion of the air element, the spreading out of the air element, thus it is the diffusion of the air element that is the action of consciousness.

original: tena. Ettha ca cittakiriyaggahaṇena anindriyabaddhavāyodhātuvipphāraṃ nivatteti,
analyzed: tena ettha ca citta kiriya ggahaṇena anindriya baddha vāyodhātu vipphāram nivatteti
translated: By that. And here, by mentioning the action of consciousness, he excludes the diffusion of the air element not bound up with faculties;

original: vāyodhātuvipphāraggahaṇena cetanāvacīviññattibhedaṃ cittakiriyaṃ nivatteti, ubhayena
analyzed: vāyo dhātu vipphāra ggahaṇena cetanā avacī viññatti bhedam citta kiriyam nivatteti ubhayena
translated: by mentioning the diffusion of the air element, he excludes the action of consciousness classed as volition and intimation;🔽but by both he distinguishes bodily intimation.

original: pana kāyaviññattiṃ vibhāveti. “Gacchatī”ti vatvā yathā pavattamāne kāye “gacchatī”ti
analyzed: pana kāya viññattim vibhāveti gacchati iti vatvā yathā pavattamāne kāye gacchati iti
translated: Having said “goes,” he shows how the body that is occurring goes.

original: vohāro hoti, taṃ dassetuṃ “tasmā”tiādi vuttaṃ. Tanti gantukāmatāvasena pavattacittaṃ.
analyzed: vohāraḥ hoti tam dassetum tasmā tiādi vuttam tanti gantu kāma tā vasena pavatta cittam
translated: In order to show this, the following is said: “Therefore, etc.” T = the mind that occurs as desire to go.

original: Vāyaṃ janetīti vāyodhātuadhikaṃ rūpakalāpaṃ uppādeti, adhikatā cettha sāmatthiyato,
analyzed: vāyam janeti iti vāyodhātu adhikam rūpa kalāpam uppādeti adhika tā ca ittha sāmatthiyato
translated: Vāyo janetīti = generates the configuration of materiality that is predominant in the air element. The predominance here is by way of capability,

original: na pamāṇato. Gamanacittasamuṭṭhitaṃ sahajātarūpakāyassa thambhanasandhāraṇacalanānaṃ🔽paccayabhūtena ākāravisesena pavattamānaṃ vāyodhātuṃ sandhāyāha “vāyo viññattiṃ janetī”ti.
analyzed: na pamāṇataḥ gamana citta samuṭṭhitam sahajāta rūpa kāyassa thambhana sandhāraṇa calanānam  paccaya bhūtena ākāra visesena pavattamānam vāyodhātum sandhāya āha vāyo viññattim janeti iti
translated: not by way of magnitude. The air element that occurs in the mode of a condition for the stiffening, supporting, and moving of the body that is generated by the mind of going,🔽is referred to by the words “vāyo viññattiṃ janetī” .

original: Adhippāyasahabhāvī hi vikāro viññatti. Yathāvuttaadhikabhāveneva ca vāyogahaṇaṃ,
analyzed: adhippāya sahabhāvī hi vikāraḥ yathā vutta adhika bhāvena iva ca vāyo gahaṇam
translated: For the modification that is conascent with the intention is the intimation. And the air element is the cause of the intimation only by way of the aforesaid predominance,

original: na vāyodhātuyā eva janakabhāvato, aññathā viññattiyā upādāyarūpabhāvo durupapādo
analyzed: na vāyo dhātuyāḥ eva janaka bhāvataḥ aññathā viññattiyāḥ upādāyarūpa bhāvaḥ durupapādaḥ
translated: not by way of the mere fact of its being the generator of the intimation. Otherwise, it would be difficult to establish that the intimation is a derived materiality.

original: siyā. Purato abhinīhāro puratobhāgena kāyassa pavattanaṃ, yo “abhikkamo”ti vuccati.
analyzed: siyā puratas abhinīhāraḥ puratobhāgena kāyassa pavattanam yaḥ abhikkamo ti vuccati
translated: Purato abhinīhāro = the projection forward, the movement of the body in the direction of the front, which is called “abhikkamo” .

original: “Eseva nayo”ti atidesena saṅkhepato vatvā tamatthaṃ vivarituṃ “tatrāpi hī”tiādi vuttaṃ. Koṭito paṭṭhāyāti heṭṭhimakoṭito paṭṭhāya pādatalato paṭṭhāya. Ussitabhāvoti ubbiddhabhāvo.
analyzed: esā iva nayo ti atidesena saṅkhepataḥ vatvā tam attham vivaritum tatra api hi itiādi vuttam koṭitaḥ paṭṭhāya ati heṭṭhima koṭitaḥ paṭṭhāya pāda talataḥ paṭṭhāya ussita bhāvo ti ubbiddha bhāvaḥ
translated: “The state of being raised” : the state of being lifted up.

original: Evaṃ pajānatoti evaṃ cittakiriyavāyodhātuvipphāreneva gamanādi hotīti pajānato. Tassa🔽evaṃ pajānanāya nicchayagamanatthaṃ “evaṃ hotī”ti vicāraṇā vuccati loke yathābhūtaṃ
analyzed: evam pajānato ti evam citta kiriya vāyodhātu vipphārena iva gamana ādi hoti iti pajānato tassa  evam pajānanāya nicchaya gamana attham evam hoti iti vicāraṇā vuccati loke yathābhūtam
translated: “One who understands in this way” : one who understands thus: “Going, etc., occur only through the diffusion of the air element that is the function of the mind.”

original: ajānantehi micchābhinivesavasena, lokavohāravasena vā. Atthi panāti attano evaṃ vīmaṃsanavasena
analyzed: a jānantehi micchā abhinivesa vasena loka vohāra vasena vā atthi pana ati attanaḥ evam vīmaṃsana vasena
translated: “The consideration ‘it is thus’ ” is said in the world by those who do not know the truth as it is, either through wrong adherence or through worldly convention, for the purpose of determining the going, etc., of that person who understands in this way.🔽“But is there” : this is a question expressing his own doubt.

original: pucchāvacanaṃ. Natthīti nicchayavasena sattassa paṭikkhepavacanaṃ. “Yathā panā”tiādi
analyzed: pucchā vacanam natthi iti nicchaya vasena sattassa paṭikkhepa vacanam yathā pana atiādi
translated: “There is not” : this is a reply expressing his own determination that there is no being.

original: tasseva atthassa upamāya vibhāvanaṃ, taṃ suviññeyyameva.
analyzed: tassa iva atthassa upamāya vibhāvanam tam su viññeyyam eva
translated: “But just as” : this is an elucidation of the same meaning by way of a simile, which is easy to understand.

original: Nāvā mālutavegenāti yathā acetanā nāvā vātavegena desantaraṃ yāti, yathā ca acetano
analyzed: nāvā māluta vegena ati yathā acetanā nāvā vāta vegena desantaram yāti yathā ca acetanā
translated: “The boat by the force of the wind” : just as an unconscious boat goes to another place by the force of the wind, and just as an unconscious

original: tejanaṃ kaṇḍo jiyāvegena desantaraṃ yāti, tathā acetano kāyo vātāhato yathāvuttavāyunā🔽nīto desantaraṃ yātīti evaṃ upamāsaṃsandanaṃ veditabbaṃ. Sace pana koci vadeyya “yathā🔽nāvātejanānaṃ pellakassa purisassa vasena desantaragamanaṃ, evaṃ kāyassāpī”ti, hotu,
analyzed: tejanam kaṇḍaḥ desantaram yāti tathā acetanaḥ kāyaḥ vāta āhataḥ yathā vutta vāyunā  nītaḥ desantaram yāti iti evam upamā saṃsandanam veditabbam sace pana koci vadeyya yathā  nāvā tejanānam pellakassa purisassa vasena desa antara gamanam evam kāyassa api iti hotu
translated: The fan moves to another place by the force of the wind’s motion, and so the mindless body is carried to another place by the wind as already described.🔽This is how the similes should be construed. But if anyone should say: “Just as the fan and the boat move to another place by the power of the man, so too the body,” let it be so;

original: evaṃ icchito vāyamattho yathā hi nāvātejanānaṃ saṃhatalakkhaṇasseva purisassa vasena🔽gamanaṃ, na asaṃhatalakkhaṇassa, evaṃ kāyassāpīti. Kā no hāni, bhiyyopi dhammamattatāva
analyzed: evam icchitaḥ vā ayam atthaḥ yathā hi nāvā tejanānam saṃhata lakkhaṇassa iva purisassa vasena  gamanam na asaṃhata lakkhaṇassa evam kāyassa api iti kā no hāni bhiyyas pi dhamma matta tā ava
translated: for the meaning intended is this: Just as the boat and the fan move by the power of the man who possesses the characteristic of being combined with them, not by the power of one who possesses the characteristic of being uncombined with them, so too the body.

original: patiṭṭhaṃ labhati, na purisavādo. Tenāha “yantasuttavasenā”tiādi.🔽Tattha payuttanti heṭṭhā vuttanayena gamanādikiriyāvasena paccayehi payojitaṃ. Ṭhātīti
analyzed: patiṭṭham labhati na purisavādaḥ tena āha yanta sutta vasena atiādi  tattha payuttam ti heṭṭhā vutta nayena gamana ādi kiriyā vasena paccayehi payojitam ṭhāti iti
translated: What is the loss to us? The mere fact that the doctrine of a person is established is all that we want, not the doctrine of a person who possesses the characteristic of being combined with the aggregates. That is why he said “by the method of the Yantā sutta” .

original: tiṭṭhati. Etthāti imasmiṃ loke. Vinā hetupaccayeti gantukāmatācittataṃsamuṭṭhānavāyodhātuādihetupaccayehi
analyzed: tiṭṭhati ettha ati imasmin loke vinā hetu paccaye iti gantu kāma tā citta taṃ samuṭṭhāna vāyodhātu ādi hetu paccayehi
translated: Herein, it is “engaged” in the sense of being employed by conditions in the way stated above, namely, as the doer of the act of going, etc., “It stands” means it is present. “Here” means in this world. “Without cause and condition” means without the air element, etc., which originate the consciousness of the desire to go.

original: vinā. Tiṭṭheti tiṭṭheyya. Vajeti vajeyya gaccheyya ko nāmāti sambandho. Paṭikkhepattho🔽cettha kiṃ-saddoti hetupaccayavirahena ṭhānagamanapaṭikkhepamukhena sabbāyapi dhammappavattiyā
analyzed: vinā tiṭṭha iti tiṭṭheyya vaja iti vajeyya gaccheyya kaḥ nāma ati sambandhaḥ paṭikkhepa attho  ca ittha kim saddaḥ ti hetu paccaya virahena ṭhāna gamana paṭikkhepa mukhena sabbāya api dhamma ppavattiyā
translated: ‘Without’ means without a cause. ‘Would stand’ means would stand. ‘Would go’ means would go. The construction is: ‘What is the name of the one who would stand or go without a cause?’🔽Herein, the word ‘what’ has the meaning of a prohibition.

original: paccayādhīnavuttitāvibhāvanena attasuññatā viya aniccadukkhatāpi vibhāvitāti daṭṭhabbā.
analyzed: paccaya adhīna vutti tā vibhāvanena atta suñña tā viya anicca dukkha tā api vibhāvitā ati daṭṭhabbā
translated: Therefore it should be regarded as showing the voidness of self in all the occurrences of dhammas by the method of prohibiting standing and going without a cause and condition, and by the method of showing that their occurrence is dependent on conditions, just as the voidness of self is shown by the method of prohibiting standing and going without a cause and condition.

original: Paṇihitoti yathā yathā paccayehi pakārehi nihito ṭhapito. Sabbasaṅgāhikavacananti🔽sabbesampi catunnaṃ iriyāpathānaṃ ekajjhaṃ saṅgaṇhanavacanaṃ, pubbe visuṃ visuṃ iriyāpathānaṃ
analyzed: paṇihitaḥ ti yathā yathā paccayehi pakārehi nihitaḥ ṭhapitaḥ sabba saṅgāhika vacananti  sabbesam pi catunnam iriyāpathānam ekajjham saṅgaṇhana vacanam pubbe visum visum iriyāpathānam
translated: ‘Directed’: directed, placed, by conditions in such and such a way. ‘A comprehensive expression’:🔽a term that includes all four postures together. The meaning is this: since the postures were previously stated separately, this is a statement that includes them together.

original: vuttattā idaṃ nesaṃ ekajjhaṃ gahetvā vacananti attho. Purimanayo vā iriyāpathappadhāno
analyzed: vutta ttā idam nesam ekajjham gahetvā vacanan ti attho purima nayaḥ vā iriyāpatha padhāno
translated: Or alternatively, since the method of postures was stated in the first part of the sutta,

original: vuttoti tattha kāyo appadhāno anunipphādīti idha kāyaṃ padhānaṃ, apadhānañca iriyāpathaṃ
analyzed: vuttaḥ ti tattha kāyaḥ appadhānaḥ anunipphādi iti idha kāyam padhānam apadhānam ca iriyāpatham
translated: here the body is the method, and the postures are the application of the method.

original: anunipphādiṃ katvā dassetuṃ dutiyanayo vuttoti evampettha dvinnaṃ nayānaṃ viseso
analyzed: anu nipphādim katvā dassetum dutiya nayaḥ vuttaḥ ti evam pa ittha dvinnam nayānam visesaḥ
translated: The second method is stated in order to show the arising by way of the immediately preceding condition. This is how the difference between the two methods should be understood here.

original: veditabbo. Ṭhitoti pavatto.
analyzed: veditabbaḥ ṭhitaḥ ti pavattaḥ
translated: “Is present” means has occurred.

original: Iriyāpathapariggaṇhanampi iriyāpathavato kāyasseva pariggaṇhanaṃ tassa avatthāvisesabhāvatoti🔽vuttaṃ “iriyāpathapariggaṇhanena kāye kāyānupassī viharatī”ti. Tenevettha rūpakkhandhavaseneva
analyzed: iriyāpatha pariggaṇhanam pi iriyāpathavato kāyassa iva pariggaṇhanam tassa avattha avisesa bhāvato ti  vuttam iriyāpatha pariggaṇhanena kāye kāya anupassī viharati iti tena iva itthā rūpa kkhandha vasena iva
translated: The “observation of the postures” is the observation of the body itself by way of the postures, because the postures are a particular state of the body.🔽Therefore it is said: “By observing the postures, he remains focused on the body in and of itself.” Thus the origination, etc., of the materiality aggregate is pointed out here by way of the materiality aggregate itself.

original: samudayādayo uddhaṭā. Esa nayo sesavāresupi. Ādināti ettha ādi-saddena yathā “taṇhāsamudayā🔽kammasamudayā āhārasamudayā”ti nibbattilakkhaṇaṃ passantopi rūpakkhandhassa udayaṃ🔽passatīti ime cattāro ākārā saṅgayhanti, evaṃ “avijjānirodhā”ti ādayopi pañca ākārā
analyzed: samudaya ādayaḥ uddhaṭāḥ ādinā ati ettha ādi saddena yathā taṇhā samudayā  kamma samudayā āhāra samudayā ti nibbatti lakkhaṇam passantaḥ api rūpakkhandhassa udayam  passati iti ime cattāro ākārā saṅgayhanti evam avijjā nirodhā ati ādayaḥ pi pañca ākārā
translated: The same method applies to the rest of the sections.

original: saṅgahitāti daṭṭhabbā. Sesaṃ vuttanayameva.
analyzed: saṅgahitā ti daṭṭhabbā sesam vutta nayam eva

The rest is as already explained.

original: Iriyāpathapabbavaṇṇanā niṭṭhitā.

original: Catusampajaññapabbavaṇṇanā

analyzed: adhippetaḥ ti āha rūpa kkhandhassa iva samudayaḥ ca vayaḥ ca nīharitabbaḥ iti rūpa dhammānaṃ yeva

translated: “By means of the arousing of the ideation of the elements”: by means of the kind of attention given to the four elements beginning with the earth element that occurs in the development of the meditation subject called “the defining of the four elements.”

original: catudhātuvavatthānavasenāti attho. Dhātumanasikāro, dhātukammaṭṭhānaṃ, catudhātuvavatthānanti🔽hi atthato ekaṃ. Goghātakoti jīvikatthāya gunnaṃ ghātako. Antevāsikoti kammakaraṇavasena

original: tassa samīpavāsī taṃ nissāya jīvanako. Vinivijjhitvāti ekasmiṃ ṭhāne aññamaññaṃ vinivijjhitvā.

original: Mahāpathānaṃ vemajjhaṭṭhānasaṅkhāteti catunnaṃ mahāpathānaṃ tāya eva vinivijjhanaṭṭhānatāya🔽vemajjhasaṅkhāte. Yasmā te cattāro mahāpathā catūhi disāhi āgantvā tattha samohitā

translated: For it is as though the four great highways meet there,🔽and so that place is called a crossroads.

original: viya honti, tasmā taṃ ṭhānaṃ catumahāpathaṃ, tasmiṃ catumahāpathe. Ṭhita-saddo “ṭhito🔽vā”tiādīsu ṭhānasaṅkhātairiyāpathasamaṅgitāya, ṭhā-saddassa vā gatinivattiatthatāya
analyzed: viya honti tasmā tam ṭhānam catu mahāpatham tasmin catu mahāpathe ṭhita saddaḥ ṭhitaḥ  vāti ādīsu ṭhāna saṅkhāta eriyā patha samaṅgi tāya ṭhā saddassa vā gati nivatti atthatāya
translated: The word “standing” in the phrase “standing in the crossroads” is used in the sense of a posture in such passages as “Standing, the bhikkhu should attend to this” .🔽Or the word “standing” is used in the sense of the stopping of going, as in the passage “Standing, he does not stand” .

original: aññattha ṭhapetvā gamanaṃ sesairiyāpathasamaṅgitāya bodhako, idha pana yathā tathā🔽rūpakāyassa pavattiākārabodhako adhippetoti āha “catunnaṃ iriyāpathānaṃ yena kenaci
analyzed: aññattha ṭhapetvā gamanam idha pana yathā tathā  rūpa kāyassa pavatti ākāra bodhakaḥ adhippetaḥ ti āha catunnam iriyāpathānam yena kenacid
translated: But in the present context the word “standing” is intended to convey the idea of the occurrence of the material body in some posture or other.🔽Thus the commentator says: “Standing in whatever posture among the four postures” .

original: ākārena ṭhitattā yathā ṭhita”nti. Tattha ākārenāti ṭhānādinā rūpakāyassa pavattiākārena.
analyzed: ākārena ṭhita ttā yathā ṭhitanti tattha ākārena ati ṭhāna ādinā rūpa kāyassa pavatti ākārena
translated: Herein, “in some posture” means in the occurrence of the material body in some posture or other, such as standing, etc.

original: Ṭhānādayo hi iriyāpathasaṅkhātāya kiriyāya patho pavattimaggoti “iriyāpatho”ti vuccantīti
analyzed: ṭhāna ādayaḥ hi iriyāpatha saṅkhātāya kiriyāya patho pavatti maggo ti iriyāpatho ti vuccanti iti
translated: For standing, etc., are called postures because they are the paths for the occurrence of the action called deportment.

original: vutto vāyamattho. Yathāṭhitanti yathāpavattaṃ, yathāvuttaṃ ṭhānamevettha paṇidhānanti
analyzed: vuttaḥ vā ayam atthaḥ yathāṭhitanti yathāpavattam yathā vuttam ṭhānam eva ittha paṇidhānanti
translated: The meaning is stated. “As it occurs” means as it is occurring, as it is said to be. The “as it is” here is the designation of the posture.

original: adhippetanti āha “yathā ṭhitattā ca yathāpaṇihita”nti. “Ṭhita”nti vā kāyassa ṭhānasaṅkhātairiyāpathasamāyogaparidīpanaṃ,
analyzed: adhippetanti āha yathā ṭhita ttā ca yathā paṇihitanti ṭhitanti vā kāyassa ṭhāna saṅkhāta eriyā patha samāyoga paridīpanam
translated: “As it is placed” means as it is placed, as it is designated. “As it is” is the designation of the combination of the body with the posture called “standing,”

original: “paṇihita”nti tadaññairiyāpathasamāyogaparidīpanaṃ. “Ṭhita”nti vā kāyasaṅkhātānaṃ🔽rūpadhammānaṃ tasmiṃ tasmiṃ khaṇe sakiccavasena avaṭṭhānaparidīpanaṃ, paṇihitanti
analyzed: paṇihitanti tad añña eriyāpatha samāyoga paridīpanam ṭhitanti vā  rūpa dhammānam tasmim tasmim khaṇe sa kicca vasena avaṭṭhāna paridīpanam paṇihitanti
translated: “As it is placed” is the designation of the combination of the body with other postures.

original: paccayavasena tehi tehi paccayehi pakārato nihitaṃ paṇihitanti evampettha attho veditabbo.
analyzed: paccaya vasena tehi tehi paccayehi pakārataḥ nihitam paṇihitan ti evam pi ittha atthaḥ veditabbo
translated: “As it is” is the designation of the non-cessation of the material phenomena called “body” in each moment by way of their own function. “As it is placed” is the designation of the placing of them by way of conditions, by way of the various conditions. This is how the meaning should be understood here.

original: Paccavekkhatīti pati pati avekkhati, ñāṇacakkhunā vinibbhujjitvā visuṃ visuṃ passati.
analyzed: paccavekkhati iti pati pati avekkhati ñāṇa cakkhunā vinibbhujjitvā visum visum passati
translated: “He looks on”: he looks again and again; he sees by way of analysis with the eye of knowledge.

original: Idāni vuttamevatthaṃ bhāvatthavibhāvanavasena dassetuṃ “yathā goghātakassā”tiādi
analyzed: idāni vuttam evattham bhāva ttha vibhāvana vasena dassetum yathā go ghātakassa ati ādi
translated: Now, in order to show by way of the exposition of the meaning of existence the matter that has been stated, he gives the simile of the butcher’s son.

original: vuttaṃ. Tattha posentassāti maṃsūpacayaparibrūhanāya kuṇḍakabhattakappāsaṭṭhiādīhi🔽saṃvaḍḍhentassa. Vadhitaṃ matanti hiṃsitaṃ hutvā mataṃ. Matanti ca matamattaṃ. Tenevāha
analyzed: vuttam tattha posentassa iti maṃsu upacaya paribrūhanāya kuṇḍaka bhatta kappāsa ṭṭhi ādīhi  saṃvaḍḍhentassa vadhitam matanti hiṃsitam hutvā matam matanti ca mata mattam tena iva āha
translated: “Feeding” means nourishing by means of the food of the five factors of sense pleasure, such as the food of visible forms, etc., for the purpose of increasing the flesh and blood.🔽“Killed” means killed after being struck. “Dead” means merely dead. Hence it is said:🔽

original: “tāvadevā”ti. Gāvīti saññā na antaradhāyatīti yāni aṅgapaccaṅgāni yathāsanniviṭṭhāni🔽upādāya gāvīsamaññā matamattāyapi gāviyā tesaṃ taṃsannivesassa avinaṭṭhattā. Vilīyanti

translated: “He is nourishing it” means he is increasing it by means of the food of morsels, of contact, of mental volition, and of consciousness, for the purpose of increasing the flesh. “Killed” means killed and dead. “Dead” means merely dead. original: bhijjanti vibhujjantīti bīlā, bhāgā va-kārassa ba-kāraṃ, ikārassa ca īkāraṃ katvā.🔽Bīlasoti bīlaṃ bīlaṃ katvā. Vibhajitvāti aṭṭhisaṅghātato maṃsaṃ vivecetvā, tato vā
analyzed: bhijjanti vibhujjanti iti bīlāḥ bhāgāḥ vakārassa bakāram ikārassa ca īkāram katvā  bīlaso ti bīlam bīlam katvā vibhajitvā ati aṭṭhi saṅghātataḥ maṃsam vivecetvā tatas vā
