original: vivecitaṃ maṃsaṃ bhāgaso katvā. Tenevāha “maṃsasaññā pavattatī”ti. Pabbajitassāpi
analyzed: vivecitam maṃsam bhāgasaḥ katvā tena iva āha maṃsa saññā pavattati iti pabbajitassa api
translated: “They are broken up” means they are broken into pieces. “They are divided” means the flesh is separated from the skeleton, or the flesh that is separated is divided into parts. Hence he said “the perception of flesh occurs.”🔽Even for one who has gone forth into homelessness,

original: apariggahitakammaṭṭhānassa. Ghanavinibbhoganti santatisamūhakiccaghanānaṃ vinibbhujjanaṃ
analyzed: a pariggahita kammaṭṭhānassa ghana vinibbhogam ti santati samūha kicca ghanānam vinibbhujjanam
translated: “The compact is broken up” means the breaking up of the continuity, the mass, and the function.

original: vivecanaṃ. Dhātuso paccavekkhatoti ghanavinibbhogakaraṇena dhātuṃ dhātuṃ pathavīādidhātuṃ🔽visuṃ visuṃ katvā paccavekkhantassa. Sattasaññāti attānudiṭṭhivasena pavattā sattasaññāti
analyzed: vivecanam dhātuso paccavekkhato ti ghana vinibbhoga karaṇena dhātum dhātum pathavī ādi dhātum  visum visum katvā paccavekkhantassa satta saññā ati atta anudiṭṭhi vasena pavattā satta saññā ati
translated: “Contemplation of elements” is the contemplation of each element, earth, water, fire, and air, by way of the resolution of the compact .

original: vadanti, vohāravasena pavattasattasaññāyapi tadā antaradhānaṃ yuttameva yāthāvato
analyzed: vadanti vohāra vasena tadā antaradhānam yuttam eva yāthāvato
translated: “Perception of a being” is the perception of a being that occurs by way of the view of self, they say. But the disappearance of the perception of a being that occurs by way of conventional usage is also appropriate,

original: ghanavinibbhogassa sampādanato. Evañhi sati yathāvuttaopammatthena upameyyattho aññadatthu
analyzed: ghana vinibbhogassa sampādanato evam hi sati yathā vutta opamma tthena upameyya tthaḥ
translated: because the resolution of the compact is accomplished. For in that case the meaning of the simile, which is the object of the simile as stated,🔽is indeed connected and corresponds. Therefore it is said: “The mind becomes steadied in the mode of elements” .

original: saṃsandati sameti. Tenevāha “dhātuvaseneva cittaṃ santiṭṭhatī”ti. Dakkhoti cheko
analyzed: saṃsandati sameti tena iva āha dhātu vasena iva cittam santiṭṭhati iti dakkho ti cheko
translated: “Skilled” means clever,

original: taṃtaṃsamaññāya kusalo “yathājāte sūnasmiṃ naṅguṭṭhakhuravisāṇādivante aṭṭhimaṃsādiavayavasamudāye
analyzed: taṃ taṃsam aññāya kusalaḥ yathā jāte sūnasmim naṅguṭṭha khura visāṇa ādivante aṭṭhim aṃsa ādi avayava samudāye
translated: knowing thus: “In a newly born calf, in which the dewlap, the tail, the horns, etc., are not yet developed, and in which the various parts such as the bones, flesh, etc., are not yet distinguished,

original: avibhatte gāvīsamaññā, na vibhatte. Vibhatte pana aṭṭhimaṃsādiavayavasamaññā”ti jānanato.
analyzed: a vibhatte gāvī samaññā na vibhatte vibhatte pana aṭṭhi maṃsa ādi avayava samaññā ti jānanato
translated: there is the conception of a cow, but not the conception of bones, flesh, etc. But when the various parts such as bones, flesh, etc., are distinguished, there is the conception of bones, flesh, etc.”

original: Catumahāpatho viya catuiriyāpathoti gāviyā ṭhitacatumahāpatho viya kāyassa pavattimaggabhūto🔽catubbidho iriyāpatho yasmā visuddhimagge vitthāritā, tasmā tattha, taṃsaṃvaṇṇanāyañca
analyzed: catu mahā pathaḥ viya catu iriyāpatho ti gāviyā ṭhita catu mahā pathaḥ viya kāyassa pavatti magga bhūto  catubbidhaḥ iriyāpathaḥ yasmā visuddhi magge vitthāritā tasmā tattha tad saṃvaṇṇanāyan ca
translated: The four postures are of four kinds, being the path of occurrence of the body, like the crossroad where four roads meet.

original: vuttanayena veditabbo. Sesaṃ vuttanayameva.
analyzed: vutta nayena veditabbaḥ sesam vutta nayam eva
translated: Since they are dealt with in detail in the Visuddhimagga, they should be understood by the method given in the description of that. The rest is as already stated.

original: Dhātumanasikārapabbavaṇṇanā niṭṭhitā.
analyzed: dhātu manasikāra pabba vaṇṇanā niṭṭhitā
translated: The exposition of the element of contemplation of the foul is ended.

original: Navasivathikapabbavaṇṇanā🔽379. Sivathikāya apaviddhauddhumātakādipaṭisaṃyuttānaṃ odhiso pavattānaṃ kathānaṃ,
analyzed: nava sivathika pabba vaṇṇanā  sivathikāya apaviddha auddhumātaka ādi paṭisaṃyuttānam odhisaḥ pavattānam kathānam
translated: Exposition of the element of the charnel ground

original: tadabhidheyyānañca uddhumātakādiasubhabhāgānaṃ sivathikapabbānīti saṅgītikārehi gahitasamaññā.
analyzed: tad abhidheyyānam ca uddhumātaka ādi asubha bhāgānam sivathika pabbāni iti saṅgīti kārehi gahita samaññā
translated: The charnel ground is the name given by compilers to the stories that occur specifically about the bloated and so on, which are connected with the bloated and so on, and to the bloated and so on, which are parts of the foulness of the bloated and so on.🔽Hence it is said: “The charnel ground should be defined.”

original: Tenāha “sivathikapabbehi vibhajitu”nti. Maritvā ekāhātikkantaṃ ekāhamataṃ. Uddhaṃ
analyzed: tena āha sivathika pabbehi vibhajitum ti maritvā ekāha atikkantam ekāha matam uddham
translated: One day dead: one day after death.🔽After the end of life: after the end of life, after death.

original: jīvitapariyādānāti jīvitakkhayato upari maraṇato paraṃ. Samuggatenāti samuṭṭhitena.
analyzed: jīvita pariyādānā ati jīvita khayataḥ upari maraṇataḥ param samuggatena ati samuṭṭhitena
translated: Risen up: arisen.

original: Uddhumātattāti uddhaṃ uddhaṃ dhumātattā sūnattā. Setarattehi viparibhinnaṃ vimissitaṃ🔽nīlaṃ vinīlaṃ, purimavaṇṇavipariṇāmabhūtaṃ vā nīlaṃ vinīlaṃ. Vinīlameva vinīlakanti🔽ka-kārena padavaḍḍhanaṃ anatthantarato yathā “pītakaṃ lohitaka”nti. Paṭikkūlattāti🔽jigucchanīyattā. Kucchitaṃ vinīlanti vinīlakanti kucchanattho vā ayaṃ ka-kāroti dassetuṃ🔽vuttaṃ yathā “pāpako kittisaddo abbhuggacchatī”ti. paribhinnaṭṭhānehi kākakaṅkādīhi.
analyzed: uddhumātattā ati uddham uddham dhumātattā sūnattā seta rattehi viparibhinnam vimissitam  nīlam vinīlam purima vaṇṇa vipariṇāma bhūtam vā nīlam vinīlam vinīlam eva vinīlakanti  kakārena pada vaḍḍhanam an atthantarataḥ yathā pītakam lohitakam ti paṭikkūla ttā ati  jigucchanīya tā kucchitam vinīlanti vinīlakanti kucchana atthaḥ vai ayam kakāraḥ iti dassetum  vuttam yathā pāpakaḥ kitti saddaḥ abbhuggacchati iti paribhinna ṭhānehi kāka kaṅka ādīhi
translated: “Swollen” : it is “swollen” because it is “blown up” , because it is “empty” .🔽“Blue-black” : it is “blue-black” because it is “blue” and “black” , because it is “mixed” and “intermingled” ,🔽or because it is “blue” and has “changed” from its former colour. “Blue-black” is just “black” .🔽The affix -ka is added to show the meaning of “black” , just as in the words “yellow” and “red” .🔽“Repulsive” : because it is “disgusting” .🔽“Rotten” : the affix -ka is added to show the meaning of “rotten” ,🔽just as in the words “evil report” . “Blue-black” is “blue-black” because it is “mixed” with the places that have changed.

original: Vissandamānapubbanti vissavantapubbaṃ, tahaṃ tahaṃ paggharantapubbanti attho. Tathābhāvanti🔽vissandamānapubbabhāvaṃ.🔽So bhikkhūti yo “passeyya sarīraṃ sivathikāya chaḍḍita”nti vutto, so bhikkhu. Upasaṃharati
analyzed: vissandamāna pubbam ti vissavanta pubbam taham taham paggharanta pubbam ti attho tathābhāvanti 🔽vissandamāna pubba bhāvam 🔽so bhikkhu iti yaḥ passeyya sarīram sivathikāya chaḍḍitanti vuttaḥ saḥ bhikkhu upasaṃharati
translated: Rotting: swollen, hollow, and putrid. Black and blue: discoloured and mixed up with the black and blue of the corpse’s original complexion. Or alternatively, black and blue is just a word formed by reduplication for the purpose of euphony, like “yellow-red” . Repulsive: because of its loathsomeness. Rotten and stinking: the word ka-kāra is used to show that the meaning of ka is “stinking” . As it is said: “A bad report goes round” . By crows, vultures, etc., in the place where it is dismembered. With the entrails protruding: with the entrails oozing out, the meaning is, with the entrails trickling here and there. In that state: in the state of having entrails oozing out. That bhikkhu: the bhikkhu who is said to “see a corpse thrown aside in a charnel ground” . He should bring to mind:

original: sadisataṃ. “Ayampi kho”tiādi upasaṃharaṇākāradassanaṃ. Āyūti rūpajīvitindriyaṃ, arūpajīvitindriyaṃ
analyzed: ayam pi kho ti ādi upasaṃharaṇa ākāra dassanam āyūti rūpa jīvita indriyam a rūpa jīvita indriyam
translated: “This too” is shown as the mode of summing up. “Life” is the material life faculty and the immaterial life faculty.

original: panettha viññāṇagatikameva. Usmāti kammajatejo. Evaṃ pūtikasabhāvoyevāti evaṃ ativiya
analyzed: pana ittha viññāṇa gatikam eva kamma ja tejaḥ evam evam
translated: Herein, the latter is only the life faculty of the consciousness element. “Heat” is the kamma-born fire element.🔽Thus, “putrid” is the same as “putrefied.”

original: duggandhajegucchapaṭikkūlapūbhikasabhāvo eva, na āyuādīnaṃ avigame viya mattasoti
analyzed: eva na a vigame
translated: The intention is that it is not like the life faculty, etc., which are not absent in one who is dead.

original: adhippāyo. Ediso bhavissatīti evaṃbhāvīti āha “evaṃ uddhumātādibhedo bhavissatī”ti.
analyzed: adhippāyaḥ edisaḥ bhavissati iti evaṃbhāvī iti āha evam uddhumāta ādi bhedaḥ bhavissati iti
translated: “Will be like this” is the same as “will be of this kind.” He said, “Will be of the kind called bloated, etc.”

original: Luñcitvā luñcitvāti uppāṭetvā uppāṭetvā. Sāvasesamaṃsalohitayuttanti sabbaso akhāditattā
analyzed: luñcitvā luñcitvā ati uppāṭetvā uppāṭetvā sa avasesa maṃsa lohita yuttam ti sabbaso a khādita ttā
translated: “Having pulled off” means having torn off.

original: tahaṃ tahaṃ sesena appāvasesena maṃsalohitena yuttaṃ. “Aññena hatthaṭṭhika”nti avisesena
analyzed: taham taham sesena appa avasesena maṃsa lohitena yuttam aññena hatthaṭṭhikanti avisesena
translated: “With flesh and blood smeared over” means smeared here and there with a little flesh and blood that remain because it has not been completely eaten.🔽“With bones of the hands, etc.” is said without distinction to show the scattered state of the bones of the hands, etc.

original: hatthaṭṭhikānaṃ vippakiṇṇatā jotitāti anavasesato tesaṃ vippakiṇṇataṃ dassento “catusaṭṭhibhedampī”tiādimāha.
analyzed: hattha ṭṭhikānam vippakiṇṇa tā jotitā ti anavasesataḥ tesam vippakiṇṇa tam dassento catu aṭṭhi bhedam pi itiādim āha
translated: Showing their scattered state without remainder, he said, “Scattered in sixty parts.”

original: Terovassikānīti tirovassaṃ gatāni, tāni pana saṃvaccharaṃ vītivattāni hontīti āha
analyzed: terovassikāni iti tirovassam gatāni tāni pana saṃvaccharam vītivattāni honti iti āha
translated: Three years old: three years have gone by. But they are a year past, he says,

original: “atikkantasaṃvaccharānī”ti. Purāṇatāya ghanabhāvavigamena vicuṇṇatā idha pūtibhāvoti
analyzed: atikkanta saṃvat śarāni iti purāṇa tāya ghana bhāva vigamena vicuṇṇa tā idha
translated: because they have been there for a year. Here the state of being rotten is the state of being broken up by the loss of compactness due to age.

original: so yathā hoti, taṃ dassento “abbhokāse”tiādimāha. Terovassikānevāti saṃvaccharamattātikkantāni🔽eva. Khajjamānatādivasena dutiyasivathikapabbādīnaṃ vavatthāpitattā vuttaṃ “khajjamānatādīnaṃ
analyzed: saḥ yathā hoti tam dassentaḥ abbhokāsa itiādim āha terovassikān eva ati saṃvacchara matta atikkantāni  eva khajjamāna tā ādi vasena dutiya sivathika pabba ādīnam vavatthāpita ttā vuttam khajjamāna tā ādīnam
translated: So, showing what that is like, he said, “in the open air,” etc. Three years old: just a year has gone by.

original: vasena yojanā kātabbā”ti.
analyzed: vasena yojanā kātabbā ati
translated: Because the second charnel ground, etc., are defined by the presence of gnawing, etc., it is said, “The application should be made by way of gnawing, etc.”

original: Navasivathikapabbavaṇṇanā niṭṭhitā.🔽Imāneva dveti avadhāraṇena appanākammaṭṭhānaṃ tattha niyameti aññapabbesu tadabhāvato.
analyzed: nava sivathika pabba vaṇṇanā niṭṭhitā  imān eva dve ti avadhāraṇena appanā kammaṭṭhānam tattha niyame ti añña pabbesu tad abhāvato
translated: The description of the nine-year-old skeleton is ended.🔽By the particle “only” in the words “these two” he restricts the subject to the kasiṇa meditation object, because the other charnel grounds are not that.

original: Yato hi eva-kāro, tato aññattha niyameti, tena pabbadvayassa vipassanākammaṭṭhānatāpi
analyzed: yatas hi evakāraḥ tatas aññattha niyame ti tena pabba dvayassa vipassanā kammaṭṭhāna tā api
translated: For the word “only” restricts the subject to that, and so it should be understood that the two charnel grounds are also meditation objects for insight,

original: appaṭisiddhā daṭṭhabbā aniccatādidassanato. Saṅkhāresu ādīnavavibhāvanāni sivathikapabbānīti
analyzed: appaṭisiddhāḥ daṭṭhabbāḥ anicca tā ādi dassanato saṅkhāresu ādīnava vibhāvanāni sivathikapabbāni iti
translated: because they are not contradicted by the seeing of impermanence, etc. The two charnel grounds of the skeleton and the nine-year-old skeleton are called “the defining of danger in formations.”

original: āha “sivathikānaṃ ādīnavānupassanāvasena vuttattā”ti. Iriyāpathapabbādīnaṃ appanāvahatā
analyzed: āha sivathikānam ādīnava anupassanā vasena vutta ttā ti iriyāpatha pabba ādīnam
translated: He says: “because it is stated as the contemplation of danger in the case of the charnel-ground contemplations.”🔽The other twelve are obvious as being conducive to absorption in the case of the postures, etc.,

original: pākaṭā evāti “sesāni dvādasapī”ti vuttaṃ. Yaṃ panettha atthato avibhattaṃ. Taṃ suviññeyyameva.
analyzed: pākaṭāḥ evā ti sesāni dvādasa api iti vuttam yam pana ittha atthataḥ avibhattam tam su viññeyyam eva
translated: so it is said: “The other twelve are obvious” . But what is not commented on here is quite clear in meaning.

original: Kāyānupassanāvaṇṇanā niṭṭhitā.
analyzed: kāya anupassanā vaṇṇanā niṭṭhitā
translated: The Description of the Contemplation of the Body is ended.

original: Vedanānupassanāvaṇṇanā🔽380. Sukhaṃ vedananti ettha sukhayatīti sukhā. Sampayuttadhamme, kāyañca laddhassāde
analyzed: vedanā anupassanā vaṇṇanā  sukham vedanan ti ettha sukhayati iti sukhā sampayutta dhamme kāyaṃ ca
translated: The Description of the Contemplation of Feeling

original: karotīti attho. Suṭṭhu vā khādati, khanati vā kāyikaṃ, cetasikañcābādhanti sukhā.
analyzed: karoti iti attho suṭṭhu vā khādati khanati vā kāyikam cetasikam ca ābādhanti sukhā
translated: Pleasant feeling: it delights , thus it is pleasant . The meaning is that it makes associated states and the body acquire delight. Or alternatively, it is very much a feeder , thus it is pleasant ; it is very much a stabber , thus it is pleasant , in the sense of “it stabs the body and the mind with bodily and mental discomfort” .

original: “Sukaraṃ okāsadānaṃ etissāti sukhā”ti apare. Vedayati ārammaṇarasaṃ anubhavatīti
analyzed: sukaram okāsa dānam etissa ati apare vedayati ārammaṇa rasam anubhavati iti
translated: Or alternatively, it is pleasant because it is easy to experience, since it is the condition for the occurrence of delight.🔽Feeling is what is felt .🔽The experiencing is the experiencing of that.

original: vedanā. Vedayamānoti anubhavamāno. “Kāma”ntiādīsu yaṃ vattabbaṃ, taṃ iriyāpathapabbe
analyzed: vedanāḥ vedayamāno ti anubhavamāno kāmanti ādīsu yat vattabbam tat iriyāpatha pabbe
translated: In the case of “sense-desire” , etc., what should be said has already been said in the Description of the Postures .

original: vuttanayameva. Sampajānassa vediyanaṃ sampajānavediyanaṃ.
analyzed: vutta nayam eva sampajānassa vediyanam sampajāna vediyanam
translated: The experiencing of one who is fully aware is full awareness of experiencing.

original: Vatthuārammaṇāti rūpādiārammaṇā. Rūpādiārammaṇañhettha vedanāya pavattiṭṭhānatāya🔽“vatthū”ti adhippetaṃ. Assāti bhaveyya. Dhammavinimuttassa kattu abhāvato dhammasseva🔽kattubhāvaṃ dassento “vedanāva vedayatī”ti āha. “Vohāramattaṃ hotī”ti etena “sukhaṃ
analyzed: vatthu ārammaṇā ati rūpa ādi ārammaṇā rūpa ādi ārammaṇam ha ittha vedanāya pavatti ṭṭhāna tāya  vatthu uti adhippetam assa ati bhaveyya dhamma vinimuttassa kattu abhāvataḥ dhammassa iva  kattu bhāvam dassentaḥ vedanā ava vedayati iti āha vohāra mattam hoti iti etena sukham
translated: “The object as physical basis” is the object consisting of visible data, etc. For the occurrence of feeling is called “physical basis” here in the sense of a footing for it.🔽“It would be” : it would be so. “Feeling feels” : he shows that only a state, not an agent, is implied, since there is no being that is the doer.

original: vedanaṃ vedayamāno sukhaṃ vedanaṃ vedayāmī”ti idaṃ vohāramattanti dasseti.
analyzed: vedanam vedayamānaḥ sukham vedanam vedayāmi iti idam vohāra mattanti dasseti
translated: “It is mere designation” : by this he shows that the designation “I am experiencing a pleasant feeling” is mere words.

original: Nitthunantoti balavato vedanāvegassa nirodhane ādīnavaṃ disvā tassa avasaradānavasena
analyzed: nitthunanto ti balavataḥ vedanā vegassa nirodhane ādīnavam disvā tassa avasara dāna vasena
translated: “He is not able to endure”: seeing danger in the stopping of the strong current of feeling, he is not able to endure it by not giving it an opportunity.

original: nitthunanto. Vegasandhāraṇe hi atimahantaṃ dukkhaṃ uppajjatīti aññampi vikāraṃ uppādeyya,🔽tena thero aparāparaṃ parivattati. Vīriyasamathaṃ yojetvāti adhivāsanavīriyassa adhimattattā
analyzed: nitthunantaḥ vega sandhāraṇe hi ati mahantam dukkham uppajjati iti aññam pi vikāram uppādeyya  tena theraḥ apara aparam parivattati vīriya samatham yojetvā ati adhivāsana vīriyassa adhimatta ttā
translated: For if he were to hold the current, he would arouse some other affliction because of the great pain that would arise.🔽That is why the Elder went round and round.🔽“Having yoked the taming of energy”: because of the excess of energy in endurance, he yoked the taming of energy by producing a state of balance in it through concentration, that is, by reducing it.

original: tassa hāpanavasena samādhinā samarasatāpādanena vīriyasamathaṃ yojetvā. Saha paṭisambhidāhīti
analyzed: tassa hāpana vasena samādhinā samarasa tā āpādanena vīriya samatham yojetvā saha
translated: “Together with the discriminations”:

original: lokuttarapaṭisambhidāhi saha. Ariyamaggakkhaṇe hi paṭisambhidānaṃ asammohavasena
analyzed: lokuttara paṭisambhidāhi saha ariya magga kkhaṇe hi paṭisambhidānam asammoha vasena
translated: and the supramundane kinds of analytical knowledge. For at the moment of the noble path the analytical knowledges are reached by way of non-delusion,

original: adhigamo, atthapaṭisambhidāya pana ārammaṇakaraṇavasenapi. Lokiyānampi vā sati uppattikāle🔽tattha samatthataṃ sandhāyāha “saha paṭisambhidāhī”ti. Samasīsīti vārasamasīsī hutvā,
analyzed: adhigamaḥ attha paṭisambhidāya pana ārammaṇa karaṇa vasena api lokiyānam pi vā sati uppatti kāle  tattha samatthatam sandhāya āha saha samasīsī iti vārasamasīsī hutvā
translated: but the analytical knowledge of meaning is also reached by way of making it the object. Or alternatively, the words “together with the analytical knowledges” may be taken to refer to the time of the arising of mundane analytical knowledge.

original: paccavekkhaṇavārassa anantaravāre parinibbāyīti attho.🔽Yathā ca sukhaṃ, evaṃ dukkhanti yathā “sukhaṃ ko vedayatī”tiādinā sampajānavediyanaṃ🔽sandhāya vuttaṃ, evaṃ dukkhampi. Tattha dukkhayatīti dukkhā, sampayuttadhamme, kāyañca🔽pīḷeti vibādhatīti attho. Duṭṭhuṃ vā khādati, khanati kāyikaṃ, cetasikañca sātanti
analyzed: paccavekkhaṇa vārassa anantara vāre parinibbāyi iti attho  yathā ca sukham evam dukkhanti yathā sukham kaḥ vedayati iti ādinā sampajāna vedi yanam  sandhāya vuttam evam dukkham pi tattha dukkhayati iti dukkhā sampayutta dhamme kāyaṃ ca  pīḷeti vibādhati iti atthaḥ duṭṭhum vā khādati khanati kāyikam cetasikam ca
translated: “Together with” means “with the same summit,” that is, he attained final Nibbāna in the next-to-last existence.🔽And just as with pleasure, so also with pain: just as the words “he feels pleasure, he feels pain” were said with reference to clear comprehension of feeling pleasure and pain,

original: dukkhā. “Dukkaraṃ okāsadānaṃ etissāti dukkhā”ti apare. Arūpakammaṭṭhānanti arūpapariggahaṃ,
analyzed: dukkhā dukkaram okāsa dānam etissa ati dukkhā ati apare arūpa kammaṭṭhānam arūpa pariggaham
translated: so also the words “he feels pain” were said with reference to that. Herein, it oppresses , thus it is pain ; it oppresses associated states and the body, is the meaning. Or alternatively, it is eaten badly , is dug out badly , it digs out bodily and mental pleasure, thus it is pain . “It is pain because it is hard to give an opportunity ,” say others. The immaterial as object: the immaterial is the four immaterial aggregates.

original: arūpadhammamukhena vipassanābhinivesananti attho. Na pākaṭaṃ hoti phassassa, cittassa
analyzed: arūpa dhamma mukhena vipassanā abhinivesananti attho na pākaṭam hoti phassassa cittassa
translated: The meaning is that he is devoted to insight by way of immaterial states.

original: ca avibhūtākārattā. Tenāha “andhakāraṃ viya khāyatī”ti. “Na pākaṭaṃ hotī”ti ca idaṃ
analyzed: ca a vibhūta ākāra ttā tena āha andhakāram khāyati iti na ca idam
translated: It is not obvious to him because the form of contact and consciousness is not evident. Hence it is said, “It appears as if in darkness.” And this is said

original: tādise puggale sandhāya vuttaṃ, tesaṃ ādito vedanāva vibhūtatarā hutvā upaṭṭhāti.
analyzed: tādise puggale sandhāya vuttam tesam āditas vedanā va vibhūtatarā hutvā upaṭṭhāti
translated: with reference to a person of that kind. For in his case feeling is evident from the very beginning.

original: Evañhi yaṃ vuttaṃ sakkapañhavaṇṇanā dīsu “phasso pākaṭo hoti, viññāṇaṃ pākaṭaṃ hotī”ti,
analyzed: evam hi yam vuttam sakkapañhavaṇṇanā dīsu phassaḥ pākaṭaḥ hoti viññāṇam pākaṭam hoti iti
translated: For this is how the statement in the commentary to the Sakkapañha Sutta, “Contact is evident, consciousness is evident,”

original: taṃ avirodhitaṃ hoti. Vedanāvasena kathiyamānaṃ kammaṭṭhānaṃ pākaṭaṃ hotīti yojanā.
analyzed: tam a virodhitam hoti vedanā vasena kathiyamānam kammaṭṭhānam pākaṭam hoti iti yojanā
translated: is not contradicted. The meaning is that the meditation subject is evident when it is explained in terms of feeling.

original: “Vedanānaṃ uppattipākaṭatāyā”ti ca idaṃ sukhadukkhavedanānaṃ vasena vuttaṃ. Tāsañhi
analyzed: vedanānam uppatti pākaṭa tāya ati ca idam sukha dukkha vedanānam vasena vuttam tāsam hi
translated: And the words “because of the evident occurrence of feelings” are said with reference to pleasant and painful feelings. For the occurrence of these

original: pavatti oḷārikā, na itarāya. Tadubhayaggahaṇamukhena vā gahetabbattā itarāyapi pavatti
analyzed: pavatti oḷārikā na itarāya tad ubhaya ggahaṇa mukhena vā pavatti
translated: is gross, not that of the other. Or alternatively, the occurrence of the other can be understood by the method of comprehending both,

original: viññūnaṃ pākaṭā evāti “vedanāna”nti avisesaggahaṇaṃ daṭṭhabbaṃ. Sakkapañhe vuttanayeneva
analyzed: viññūnam pākaṭāḥ evā ti vedanānam ti avisesa ggahaṇam daṭṭhabbam sakka pañhe vutta nayena iva
translated: so the words “of feelings” should be regarded as a non-specific use of a specific expression.

original: veditabbo, tasmā tattha vattabbo atthaviseso tattha līnatthappakāsaniyaṃ vuttanayeneva gahetabbo.🔽Pubbe “vatthuṃ ārammaṇaṃ katvā vedanāva vedayatī”ti vedanāya ārammaṇādhīnavuttitāya
analyzed: veditabbaḥ tasmā tattha vattabbaḥ attha visesaḥ tattha līna attha ppakāsaniyam vutta nayena iva gahetabbaḥ  pubbe vatthum ārammaṇam katvā vedanā ava vedayati iti vedanāya ārammaṇa adhīna vutti tāya
translated: and it should be understood that the difference in meaning here should be taken in the way stated in the explanation of the meaning of “sluggish” .

original: ca anattatāya ca pajānanaṃ vuttaṃ, idāni tassā aniccatādipajānanaṃ dassento “ayaṃ🔽aparopi pajānanapariyāyo”ti āha. Yathā ekasmiṃ khaṇe cittadvayassa asambhavo ekajjhaṃ🔽anekantapaccayābhāvato, evaṃ vedanādvayassa visiṭṭhārammaṇavuttito cāti āha “sukhavedanākkhaṇe
analyzed: ca anatta tāya ca pajānanam vuttam idāni tassāḥ anicca tā ādi pajānanam dassentaḥ ayam  aparaḥ api pajānana pariyāyaḥ iti āha yathā ekasmin khaṇe citta dvayassa asambhavaḥ ekajjham  aneka anta paccaya abhāvataḥ evam vedanā dvayassa visiṭṭha ārammaṇa vuttito ca ati āha sukha vedanā khaṇe
translated: In the earlier part of this chapter, it was said that feeling feels, making the physical basis its object, and that it should be understood as not self because of its dependence on a physical basis and because of its impermanence. Now, in order to show the understanding of its impermanence, etc., he said, “This is another way in which it can be understood.”🔽Just as two consciousnesses do not occur simultaneously because of the absence of several conditions for a single object, so also two feelings do not occur simultaneously because of the occurrence of a distinguished object.

original: dukkhāya vedanāya abhāvato”ti. Nidassanamattañcetaṃ tadā upekkhāvedanāyapi abhāvato,
analyzed: dukkhāya vedanāya abhāvato ti tadā abhāvato
translated: Therefore he said, “because at the moment of pleasant feeling there is no unpleasant feeling.” But this is merely an illustration, because at that moment there is also no neutral feeling.

original: tena sukhavedanākkhaṇe bhūtapubbānaṃ itaravedanānaṃ hutvāabhāvapajānanena sukhavedanāyapi
analyzed: tena sukha vedanā khaṇe bhūta pubbānam itara vedanānam hutvā abhāva pajānanena
translated: Therefore, by understanding that the other feelings, which have been experienced in the past, do not exist at the moment of pleasant feeling,

original: hutvā abhāvo ñāto eva hotīti tassā pākaṭabhāvameva dassento “imissā ca sukhāya vedanāya
analyzed: hutvā abhāvaḥ ñātaḥ eva hoti iti tassā pākaṭa bhāvam eva dassento imissā ca sukhāya vedanāya
translated: and the fact of its non-existence after having been is known.🔽🔽Showing only the manifest state of that, he said: “And with regard to this pleasant feeling,

original: ito paṭhamaṃ abhāvato”ti āha, eteneva ca tāsampi vedanānaṃ pākaṭabhāvo dassitoti
analyzed: itas paṭhamam abhāvato ti āha etena iva ca tāsam pi vedanānam pākaṭa bhāvaḥ dassito ti
translated: and the fact that it is non-existent after having been is known. So he said: “And before this pleasant feeling’s appearance” in order to show its manifestness. And by this the manifestness of the other two feelings is also shown.

original: daṭṭhabbaṃ. Tenāha “vedanā nāma aniccā adhuvā vipariṇāmadhammā”ti. Aniccaggahaṇena
analyzed: daṭṭhabbam tena āha vedanā nāma aniccā adhuvā vipariṇāma dhammā ti anicca ggahaṇena
translated: That is why he said: “Feeling is impermanent, unstable, a mere becoming and a mere fading away” .

original: hi vedanānaṃ viddhaṃsanabhāvo dassito viddhaste aniccatāya suviññeyyattā. Adhuvaggahaṇena
analyzed: hi vedanānam viddhaṃsana bhāvaḥ dassitaḥ viddhaḥ te anicca tāya su viññeyya ttā adhuva ggahaṇena
translated: For by the word “impermanent” the state of being destroyed is shown, because that is easily understood by the impermanence of the feeling.🔽By the word “unstable” its manifestness is shown, because it is not always manifest.

original: pākaṭabhāvo tassa asadābhāvitādibhāvanato. Vipariṇāmaggahaṇena dukkhabhāvo tassa
analyzed: pākaṭa bhāvaḥ tassa asadābhāvita ādi bhāvanataḥ vipariṇāma ggahaṇena dukkha bhāvaḥ tassa
translated: By the word “mere becoming and a mere fading away” its state of suffering is shown, because that is indicated by the change.

original: aññathattadīpanato, tena sukhāpi vedanā dukkhā, pageva itarāti tissannampi vedanānaṃ🔽dukkhatā dassitā hoti. Iti “yadaniccaṃ dukkhaṃ, taṃ ekantato anattā”ti tīsupi vedanāsu
analyzed: aññathatta dīpanato tena sukhā api vedanā dukkhā pagā iva itarā ti tissannam pi vedanānaṃ  dukkha tā dassitā hoti iti yat aniccam dukkham tam ekantataḥ anattā ati tīsu pi vedanāsu
translated: Thus it is shown that even pleasant feeling is suffering, to say nothing of the other two. So the state of suffering in the three kinds of feeling is shown.

original: lakkhaṇattayapajānanā jotitāti daṭṭhabbaṃ. Tenāha “itiha tattha sampajāno hotī”ti.
analyzed: lakkhaṇa ttaya pajānanā jotitā iti daṭṭhabbam tena āha iti ha tattha sampajānaḥ hoti iti
translated: And so it should be regarded as showing the discerning of the three characteristics in the three kinds of feeling, since what is impermanent is of the nature of suffering and what is of the nature of suffering is not-self. That is why he said: “Thus he is one who is fully aware of it there” .

original: Idāni tamatthaṃ suttena sādhetuṃ “vuttampi ceta”ntiādimāha. Tattha neva tasmiṃ samaye
analyzed: idāni tam attham suttena sādhetum vuttam pi cetanti ādim āha tattha na iva tasmin samaye
translated: Now, in order to establish that meaning by means of a sutta, he says, “And it is said” . Herein, at that time

original: dukkhaṃ vedanaṃ vedetīti tasmiṃ sukhavedanāsamaṅgisamaye neva dukkhaṃ vedanaṃ vedeti
analyzed: dukkham vedanam vedeti iti tasmin sukha vedanā samaṅgi samaye na iva dukkham vedanam vedeti
translated: Now, in order to establish that meaning by way of the scriptures, he says, “And it is said,” etc. Herein, he does not feel painful feeling at that time: at the time of the presence of pleasant feeling he does not feel painful feeling,

original: niruddhattā, anuppannattā ca yathākkamaṃ atītānāgatānaṃ. Paccuppannāya pana asambhavo🔽vutto eva. Sakiccakkhaṇamattāvaṭṭhānato aniccā. Samecca sambhuyya paccayehi katattā
analyzed: niruddha ttā anuppanna ttā ca yathākkamam atīta anāgatānam paccuppannāya pana asambhavaḥ  vuttaḥ eva sa kicca khaṇa matta avaṭṭhānataḥ aniccā samecca sambhuyya paccayehi kata ttā
translated: because it has ceased and has not yet arisen, respectively, in the past and future. But the impossibility of its arising in the present is already stated.🔽It is impermanent because it lasts only for the moment of its own occurrence.🔽It is conditioned because it is made by conditions that meet and combine.

original: saṅkhatā. Vatthārammaṇādipaccayaṃ paṭicca uppannattā paṭiccasamuppannā. Khayavayapalujjananirujjhanapakatitāya
analyzed: saṅkhatā vattha ārammaṇa ādi paccayam paṭicca uppanna ttā paṭiccasamuppannā khaya vaya palujjana nirujjhana pakati tāya
translated: It is dependently arisen because it arises in dependence on conditions such as the physical basis and the object.

original: khayadhammā vayadhammā virāgadhammā nirodhadhammāti daṭṭhabbā.
analyzed: khaya dhammāḥ vaya dhammāḥ virāga dhammāḥ nirodha dhammā ti daṭṭhabbā
translated: It should be seen as subject to destruction, subject to vanishing, subject to fading away, and subject to cessation because of the manifest nature of destruction, vanishing, fading away, and cessation.

original: Kilesehi āmasitabbato āmisaṃ nāma, pañca kāmaguṇā, ārammaṇakaraṇavasena saha āmisehīti sāmisaṃ. Tenāha “pañcakāmaguṇāmisanissitā”ti.
analyzed: kilesehi āmasitabbataḥ āmisam nāma pañca kāmaguṇāḥ ārammaṇa karaṇa vasena saha āmisehi iti sa āmisam tena āha pañca kāmaguṇa āmisa nissitā ti
translated: The five strands of sense pleasure are called “sensual” because they are to be sensed by being met with. They are “with sensual desires” in the sense of being associated with sensual desires. Thus he says, “Dependent on the sensual desires of the five strands.”

original: Ito paranti “atthi vedanā”ti evamādi pāḷiṃ sandhāyāha “kāyānupassanāyaṃ vuttanayamevā”ti.
analyzed: itas paranti atthi vedanā ti evamādi pāḷim sandhāya āha kāya anupassanā ayam vutta nayam eva ti
translated: From here on, he says, “The method is the same as in the contemplation of the body,” referring to the text beginning, “There is feeling” .

original: Vedanānupassanāvaṇṇanā niṭṭhitā.
analyzed: vedanā anupassanā vaṇṇanā niṭṭhitā
translated: The description of the contemplation of feeling is ended.

original: Cittānupassanāvaṇṇanā
analyzed: citta anupassanā vaṇṇanā
translated: Contemplation of consciousness

original: 381. Sampayogavasena pavattamānena saha rāgenāti sarāgaṃ. Tenāha “lobhasahagata”nti.🔽Vītarāganti ettha kāmaṃ sarāgapadapaṭiyoginā vītarāgapadena bhavitabbaṃ, sammasanacārassa
analyzed: sampayoga vasena pavattamānena saha rāgena ati sa rāgam tena āha lobha sahagatam iti  vīta rāgam ti ettha kāmam sa rāga pada paṭiyoginā vīta rāga padena bhavitabbam sammasana cārassa
translated: With lust means associated with lust. Hence he says, “accompanied by greed.”

original: pana adhippetattā tebhūmakasseva gahaṇanti “lokiyakusalābyākata”nti vatvā “idaṃ panā”tiādinā
analyzed: pana adhippeta ttā tebhūmakassa iva gahaṇanti vatvā idam pana ati ādinā
translated: Without lust means that the expression “without lust” should be the opposite of “with lust.” But because the practice of serenity is intended here, only the three planes are included. Hence he says, “mundane profitable and indeterminate” and then, with the words “But this,” etc.,

original: tameva adhippāyaṃ vivarati. Sesāni dve dosamūlāni, dve mohamūlānīti cattāri akusalacittāni.
analyzed: tam eva adhippāyam vivarati sesāni dve dosa mūlāni dve moha mūlāni iti cattāri akusala cittāni
translated: he explains the intention. The remaining four kinds of consciousness are the two rooted in hate and the two rooted in delusion.

original: Tesañhi rāgena sampayogābhāvato nattheva sarāgatā, taṃnimittakatāya pana siyā taṃsahitakāle
analyzed: tesam hi rāgena sampayoga abhāvataḥ nattha iva sa rāga tā tad nimittaka tāya pana siyā tad sahita kāle
translated: For these have no association with lust, and so they are not “with lust.” But since they are caused by lust, they may be called “with lust” at the time when they are associated with lust.

original: soti nattheva vītarāgatāpīti dukkhavinimuttatā evettha labbhatīti āha “neva purimapadaṃ
analyzed: sā ti nattha iva vīta rāga tā api iti dukkha vinimutta tā eva ittha labbhati iti āha na iva purima padam
translated: So they are not “without lust” either. Thus only “free from suffering” is appropriate here. Hence he says, “The expression ‘without lust’ does not exclude the profitable and indeterminate consciousnesses rooted in hate and delusion, which are free from greed, and it does not include the consciousness with lust, which is not free from suffering. So the expression ‘without lust’ is inappropriate here. Therefore the words ‘free from suffering’ should be understood as said with reference to the escape from suffering, that is, to Nibbāna.”

original: na pacchimapadaṃ bhajantī”ti. Yadi evaṃ padesikaṃ pajānanaṃ āpajjatīti? Nāpajjati,🔽dukantarapariyāpannattā tesaṃ. Ye pana “paṭipakkhabhāve agayhamāne sampayogābhāvo
analyzed: na pacchima padam bhajanti iti yadi evam padesikam pajānanam āpajjati iti na āpajjati  duka antara pariyāpanna ttā tesam ye pana paṭipakkha bhāve a gayhamāne sampayoga abhāvaḥ
translated: If that is so, then it follows that the knowledge is partial? It does not follow,🔽because they are included in the middle term. But those who maintain that🔽“the measure here is the absence of association, as in the case of some of the🔽indeterminate states, when they are not associated with their opposites”

original: evettha pamāṇaṃ ekaccaabyākatānaṃ viyā”ti icchanti, tesaṃ matena sesākusalacittānampi
analyzed: eva ittha pamāṇam ekacca abyākatānam viyāti icchanti tesam matena sesa akusala cittānam pi
translated: maintain that the inclusion of the rest of the unprofitable consciousnesses🔽should be understood in the second term. The meaning should be understood

original: dutiyapadasaṅgaho veditabbo. Dutiyadukepi vuttanayena attho veditabbo. Akusalamūlesu
analyzed: dutiya pada saṅgahaḥ veditabbaḥ dutiya duke pi vutta nayena atthaḥ veditabbaḥ akusala mūlesu
translated: in the second dyad in the same way as above. It occurs together with delusion🔽in the unprofitable roots, thus it “occurs with delusion” . That is why he said,

original: saha moheneva vattatīti samohanti āha “vicikicchāsahagatañceva uddhaccasahagatañcā”ti.
analyzed: saha mohena iva vattati iti āha vicikicchā sahagatañca iva uddhacca sahagatañca ati
translated: “accompanied by delusion and by uncertainty and by agitation.”🔽But since the specification “together with delusion” is also possible here in

original: Yasmā cettha “saheva mohenāti samoha”nti purimapadāvadhāraṇampi labbhatiyeva, tasmā
analyzed: ca itthā sahā iva mohena ati tasmā
translated: the way beginning, “together with delusion only,”🔽that is why he said, “But since it is said,” etc.

original: vuttaṃ “yasmā panā”tiādi. Yathā pana atimūḷhatāya pāṭipuggalikanayena savisesamohavantatāya
analyzed: vuttam yasmā pana atiādi yathā pana ati mūḷha tāya pāṭipuggalika nayena sa visesa mohavanta tāya
translated: But since it is the one that is most deluded, it should be called “deluded consciousness” in the way beginning, “The unprofitable consciousnesses are🔽of two kinds, being deluded and undeluded” .🔽That is why the two kinds accompanied by uncertainty and agitation are

original: “momūhacitta”nti vattabbato vicikicchāuddhaccasahagatadvayaṃ visesato “samoha”nti
analyzed: momūha cittam ti vattabbataḥ vicikicchā uddhacca sahagata dvayam visesataḥ samohanti
translated: specified as “with delusion” in the way beginning, “The unprofitable consciousnesses are of two kinds, being deluded and undeluded” .

original: vuccati, na tathā sesākusalacittānīti “vaṭṭantiyevā”ti sāsaṅkaṃ vadati. Sampayogavasena
analyzed: vuccati na tathā sesa akusala cittāni iti vaṭṭantiyā iva ati sa āsaṅkam vadati sampayoga vasena
translated: but not so the other unprofitable consciousnesses. So he says “it is possible” with some doubt.

original: thinamiddhena anupatitaṃ anugatanti thinamiddhānupatitaṃ, pañcavidhaṃsasaṅkhārikākusalacittaṃ
analyzed: thinamiddhena anupatitam thinamiddha anupatitam pañcavidham sasaṅkhārika akusala cittam
translated: It is accompanied by stiffness and torpor, thus it is accompanied by stiffness and torpor. The five-door adverting consciousness is accompanied by stiffness and torpor.

original: saṅkucitacittaṃ, saṅkucitacittaṃ nāma ārammaṇe saṅkocanavasena pavattanato. Paccayavisesavasena🔽thāmajātena uddhaccena sahagataṃ saṃsaṭṭhanti uddhaccasahagataṃ, aññathā sabbampi🔽akusalacittaṃ uddhaccasahagatamevāti. Pasaṭacittaṃ nāma ārammaṇe savisesaṃ vikkhepavasena
analyzed: saṅkucita cittam saṅkucita cittam nāma ārammaṇe saṅkocana vasena pavattanato paccaya visesa vasena  thāma jātena uddhaccena sahagatam saṃsaṭṭhanti uddhacca sahagatam aññathā sabbam pi  akusala cittam uddhacca sahagatam eva ati pasaṭa cittam nāma ārammaṇe sa visesam vikkhepa vasena
translated: The contracted consciousness is so called because it occurs with contraction upon the object.🔽It is associated with, mixed up with, restlessness born of a special condition, thus it is associated with restlessness. Otherwise all unprofitable consciousness would be associated with restlessness.

original: visaṭabhāvena pavattanato.🔽Kilesavikkhambhanasamatthatāya vipulaphalatāya ca dīghasantānatāya ca mahantabhāvaṃ
analyzed: visaṭa bhāvena pavattanataḥ  kilesa vikkhambhana samattha tāya vipula phala tāya ca dīgha santāna tāya ca mahanta bhāvam
translated: The distracted consciousness is so called because it occurs with distraction, with a state of being scattered, over the object.

original: gataṃ, mahantehi vā uḷāracchandādīhi gataṃ paṭipannanti mahaggataṃ, taṃ pana rūpārūpabhūmigataṃ
analyzed: gatam mahantehi vā uḷāracchanda ādīhi gatam paṭipannanti mahaggatam tam pana rūpa arūpa bhūmi gatam
translated: It has gone to greatness, thus it is exalted . It has gone to greatness owing to the greatness of its fruit, owing to its long continuity, and owing to its ability to suppress defilements. Or it has gone to the great, to the sublime, owing to the great, sublime desire for enlightenment, etc., that have gone into it. It is of the fine-material and immaterial-sphere kinds.

original: tato mahantassa loke abhāvato. Tenāha “rūpārūpāvacara”nti. Tassa cettha paṭiyogī
analyzed: tatas mahantassa loke abhāvato tena āha rūpa arūpa avacaranti tassa ca ittha paṭiyogī
translated: and because of the absence of any greater one in the world. That is why he said “in the fine-material and immaterial kinds of becoming.”🔽The opposite of that is the limited,🔽and that is why he said “in the sense-desire kind of becoming.”

original: parittaṃ evāti āha “amahaggatanti kāmāvacara”nti. Attānaṃ uttarituṃ samatthehi saha
analyzed: parittam eva iti āha a mahaggatam ti kāma avacaranti attānam uttaritum samatthehi saha
translated: With those that are able to cross over themselves,🔽it is associated, and that is why he said “with a higher” .🔽The opposite of that is without a higher, and that is why he said “without a higher.”

original: uttarehīti sauttaraṃ. Tappaṭipakkhena anuttaraṃ. Tadubhayaṃ upādāyupādāya veditabbanti🔽āha “sauttaranti kāmāvacarantiādi. Paṭipakkhavikkhambhanasamatthena samādhinā sammadeva
analyzed: uttarehi iti sauttaram tad paṭipakkhena anuttaram tat ubhayam upādāya upādāya veditabbanti  āha sauttara nti kāmāvacara ntiādi paṭipakkha vikkhambhana samatthena samādhinā sammat eva
translated: It should be understood that both these terms are used according to the sense in which they are intended.🔽That is why he said “with a higher” and so on.

original: āhitaṃ samāhitaṃ. Tenāha “yassā”tiādi. Yassāti yassa cittassa. Yathāvuttena samādhinā
analyzed: āhitam samāhitam tena āha yassa atiādi yassa ati yassa cittassa yathā vuttena samādhinā
translated: The word “its” refers to the kind of consciousness.🔽It is not associated with the aforesaid concentration, and that is why he said “unconcentrated.”

original: na samāhitanti asamāhitaṃ. Tenāha “ubhayasamādhirahita”nti. Tadaṅgavimuttiyā vimuttaṃ,
analyzed: na samāhitam iti asamāhitam tena āha ubhaya samādhi rahitam ti tad aṅga vimuttiyāḥ vimuttam
translated: That is why he said “devoid of both kinds of concentration.”🔽The sense-desire-sphere profitable consciousness is liberated by the liberation of the faculties,

original: kāmāvacarakusalacittaṃ, vikkhambhanavimuttiyā vimuttaṃ, mahaggatacittanti tadubhayaṃ
analyzed: kāmāvacara kusala cittam vikkhambhana vimuttiyā vimuttam mahaggata cittan ti tat ubhayam
translated: and the fine-material-sphere consciousness is liberated by the liberation of suppression.🔽That is why he said “liberated by the liberation of the faculties and by the liberation of suppression.”

original: sandhāyāha “tadaṅgavikkhambhanavimuttīhi vimutta”nti. Yattha tadubhayavimutti natthi,
analyzed: sandhāya āha tad aṅga vikkhambhana vimuttīhi vimuttanti yattha tad ubhaya vimutti natthi
translated: Where there is no liberation of either kind,

original: taṃ ubhayavimuttirahitanti gayhamāne lokuttaracittepi siyāsaṅkāti taṃ nivattanatthaṃ
analyzed: tam ubhaya vimutti rahitanti gayhamāne lokuttara citte api siyā āsaṅkā ati tam nivattana attham
translated: If it were accepted that it is devoid of both kinds of deliverance, then it might be supposed that the supramundane consciousness is so too. So in order to refute that,🔽

original: “samuccheda…pe… okāsova natthī”ti āha. Okāsabhāvo ca sammasanacārassa adhippetattā
analyzed: samuccheda pe okāsaḥ uva natthi iti āha okāsa bhāvaḥ ca sammasana cārassa adhippeta ttā
translated: If it were to be admitted that it is devoid of both kinds of deliverance, then it might be suspected that it is supramundane consciousness. So he said ‘There is no opportunity for it’ in order to refute that. And the state of opportunity is intended here as the state of object of the jhāna that occurs in the way beginning with contemplation of the elements.

original: veditabbo. Yaṃ panettha atthato avibhattaṃ, taṃ heṭṭhā vuttanayattā uttānameva.
analyzed: veditabbaḥ yam pana ittha atthataḥ avibhattam tam heṭṭhā vutta naya ttā uttānam eva
translated: So it should be understood. But what is not analysed here as to meaning is obvious since it is given in the way already stated.

original: Cittānupassanāvaṇṇanā niṭṭhitā.
analyzed: citta anupassanā vaṇṇanā niṭṭhitā
translated: Contemplation of consciousness is finished.

original: Dhammānupassanā🔽Nīvaraṇapabbavaṇṇanā
analyzed: dhamma anupassanā  nīvaraṇa pabba vaṇṇanā
translated: Contemplation of ideas🔽The exposition of the hindrances, etc.,

original: 382. Pahātabbādidhammavibhāgadassanavasena pañcadhā dhammānupassanā niddiṭṭhāti ayamattho
analyzed: pahātabba ādi dhamma vibhāga dassana vasena pañcadhā dhamma anupassanā niddiṭṭhā ti ayam attho
translated: The meaning of the fivefold contemplation of ideas as shown in the way beginning with “What ideas are to be abandoned”

original: pāḷito eva viññāyatīti tamatthaṃ ulliṅgento “pañcavidhena dhammānupassanaṃ kathetu”nti🔽āha. Yadi evaṃ kasmā nīvaraṇādivaseneva niddiṭṭhanti? Vineyyajjhāsayato. Yesañhi
analyzed: pāḷitaḥ eva viññāyati iti tam attham ulliṅgentaḥ pañcavidhena dhamma anupassanam kathetun ti  āha yadi evam kasmai nīvaraṇa ādi vasena iva niddiṭṭhanti yesan hi
translated: can be understood from the text itself. So, alluding to that meaning, he said “I shall explain the fivefold contemplation of ideas.”

original: veneyyānaṃ pahātabbadhammesu paṭhamaṃ nīvaraṇāni vibhāgena vattabbāni, tesaṃ vasenettha
analyzed: veneyyānam pahātabba dhammesu paṭhamam nīvaraṇāni vibhāgena vattabbāni tesam vasena ittha
translated: But if that is so, why is it shown only in the way of the hindrances, and so on? Because of the inclination of those who need training. For the hindrances should be stated by analysis first of all among the ideas to be abandoned, and so

original: bhagavatā paṭhamaṃ nīvaraṇesu dhammānupassanā kathitā. Tathā hi kāyānupassanāpi samathapubbaṅgamā
analyzed: bhagavatā paṭhamam nīvaraṇesu dhamma anupassanā kathitā tathā hi kāya anupassanā api samatha pubbaṅgamā
translated: And so too the contemplation of the body has been taught as having serenity as its forerunner.

original: desitā, tato pariññeyyesu khandhesu, āyatanesu ca bhāvetabbesu bojjhaṅgesu, pariññeyyādivibhāgesu
analyzed: desitā tatas pariññeyyesu khandhesu āyatanesu ca bhāvetabbesu bojjhaṅgesu pariññeyya ādi vibhāgesu
translated: And then the further teaching in the following sections is about the aggregates, bases, and elements that are to be fully understood, and about the enlightenment factors that are to be developed, and about the truths that are to be fully understood, and so on.

original: saccesu ca uttarā desanā, tasmā cettha samathabhāvanāpi yāvadeva vipassanatthā icchitā.🔽Vipassanāpadhānā, vipassanābahulā ca satipaṭṭhānadesanāti tassā vipassanābhinivesavibhāgena🔽desitabhāvaṃ vibhāvento “apicā”tiādimāha. Tattha khandhāyatanadukkhasaccavasena missakapariggahakathanaṃ
analyzed: saccesu ca uttarā desanā tasmā ca ittha samatha bhāvanā api yāvat eva vipassana tthā icchitā  vipassanā apadhānā vipassanā bahulā ca sati paṭṭhāna desanā ati tassāḥ vipassanā abhinivesa vibhāgena  desita bhāvam vibhāventaḥ api ca iti ādim āha tattha khandha āyatana dukkha sacca vasena missaka pariggaha kathanam
translated: So here the development of serenity is accepted only as far as it is a prerequisite for insight.🔽And the teaching of the foundations of mindfulness, etc., is mainly concerned with insight.🔽So, in order to show how it is taught by the analysis of the insistence on insight, he said: “Besides, in the first of the first in the first triad in the first pair in the first section in the first pair of divisions in the first chapter of the Path of Purification, the Blessed One taught the contemplation of ideas as a meditation subject in the first tetrad of the first pair of jhānas in the first pair of dyads in the first triad in the first pair in the first section in the first pair of divisions in the first chapter of the Path of Purification.”

original: daṭṭhabbaṃ. Saññāsaṅkhārakkhandhapariggahampīti pi-saddena sakalapañcupādānakkhandhapariggahaṃ
analyzed: daṭṭhabbam saññā saṅkhāra kkhandha pariggaham pi iti pi saddena sakala pañca upādāna kkhandha pariggaham
translated: Herein, the explanation of the mixed discernment should be understood as the discernment of the aggregates, bases, and truth of suffering.🔽And by the word “too” he includes the discernment of the formations and perception aggregates,

original: sampiṇḍeti itaresaṃ tadantogadhattā.
analyzed: sampiṇḍā iti
translated: since the rest are included in those.

original: “Kaṇhasukkadhammānaṃ yuganandhatā natthī”ti pajānanakāle abhāvā “abhiṇhasamudācāravasenā”ti🔽vuttaṃ. Saṃvijjamānanti attano santāne upalabbhamānaṃ. Yathāti yenākārena, so pana🔽“kāmacchandassa uppādo hotī”ti vuttattā kāmacchandassa kāraṇākārova, atthato kāraṇamevāti
analyzed: kaṇha sukka dhammānam yuga nandha tā natthi iti pajānana kāle abhāvāḥ abhiṇha samudācāra vasena ati  vuttam saṃvijjamānam ti attanaḥ santāne upalabbhamānam yathā ati yena ākārena saḥ pana  kāmacchandassa uppādaḥ hoti iti vutta ttā kāmacchandassa kāraṇa ākāraḥ uva atthataḥ kāraṇam eva ati
translated: “There is no such thing as the simultaneous presence of the dark and bright states” means that it is not present at the time of understanding.🔽“By its frequent occurrence” is said.🔽“Existing” means being found in one’s own continuum.🔽“In such a way” means in what way. But since it is said “the arising of sensual desire occurs,” it is the way of the cause of sensual desire. In fact, it is the cause itself.

original: āha “yena kāraṇenā”ti. Ca-saddo vakkhamānatthasamuccayattho.🔽Tatthāti “yathā cā”tiādinā vuttapade. Subhampīti kāmacchandopi. So hi attano gahaṇākārena
analyzed: āha yena kāraṇena ati ca saddaḥ vakkhamāna attha samuccaya tthaḥ  tattha ati yathā ca ati ādinā vutta pade kāmacchandaḥ api saḥ hi attanaḥ gahaṇa ākārena
translated: “There is no such thing as the simultaneous presence of both the dark and bright states” means that, at the time of understanding, there is no such thing as the simultaneous presence of both lust and non-lust. “By way of frequent occurrence” is said. “Existing” means being found in one’s own continuum. “As” means by what mode. But since it is said “the arising of lust occurs,” it is the mode of the cause of lust. In the sense of the cause, it is said “by what cause.” The word “ca” has the meaning of including what is to be said.

original: “subha”nti vutto, tenākārena pavattanakassa aññassa kāmacchandassa nimittattā “nimitta”nti🔽ca. Iṭṭhaṃ, iṭṭhākārena vā gayhamānaṃ rūpādi subhārammaṇaṃ. Ākaṅkhitassa hitasukhassa
analyzed: subham ti vuttaḥ tena ākārena pavattanakassa aññassa kāmacchandassa nimitta ttā nimittanti  ca iṭṭham iṭṭha ākārena vā gayhamānam rūpa ādi subha ārammaṇam ākaṅkhitassa hita sukhassa
translated: “There” means in the words beginning with “yathā ca.” “Subhampi” means lust also. For that is said to be “subha” by the mode of its own grasping. By that mode, it is the sign of another lust that occurs. Therefore it is “nimitta.”

original: pattiyā anupāyabhūto manasikāro anupāyamanasikāro. Tanti ayonisomanasikāraṃ. Tatthāti
analyzed: pattiyā an upāya bhūtaḥ manasikāraḥ an upāya manasikāro a yoniso manasikāram tattha ati
translated: A desirable object such as form, etc., is “subha” when it is desirable or when it is grasped in a desirable way. The attention that is not a means to the attainment of the desired benefit and happiness is “anupāyamanasikāra.” “Tā” means improper attention. “Tattha” means

original: tasmiṃ sabhāgahetubhūte, ārammaṇabhūte ca duvidhe subhanimitte. Āhāroti paccayo attano
analyzed: tasmin sa bhāga hetu bhūte ārammaṇa bhūte ca duvidhe subha nimitte āhāro ti paccayaḥ attano
translated: In the two kinds of beautiful objects, which are the like-kind cause and the object condition for the jhāna.

original: phalaṃ āharatīti katvā.🔽Asubhanti asubhajjhānaṃ uttarapadalopena, taṃ pana dasasu aviññāṇakaasubhesu ca kesādīsu
analyzed: phalam āharati iti katvā  asubhan ti asubha jjhānam uttara pada lopena tam pana dasasu aviññāṇaka asubhesu ca kesa ādīsu
translated: The nutriment is a condition for its fruit by bringing it, thus it is a nutriment condition.🔽The foul: the foulness jhāna is meant here, with the elision of the middle term. But that should be regarded as occurring in the ten kinds of foulness that are without consciousness and in the ten kinds that are with consciousness.

original: saviññāṇakaasubhesu ca pavattaṃ daṭṭhabbaṃ. Kesādīsu hi saññā “asubhasaññā”ti girimānandasutte
analyzed: sa viññāṇaka asubhesu ca pavattam daṭṭhabbam kesa ādīsu hi saññā asubha saññā iti girima ānanda sutte
translated: For in the case of the ten kinds of foulness that are without consciousness, beginning with the bloated, perception is called “perception of foulness” in the Girimānanda Sutta:🔽“Bhikkhus, any kind of perception of foulness is a state favourable to concentration. Any kind of perception of beauty is a state unfavourable to concentration” .

original: vuttā. Ettha ca catubbidhassa ayonisomanasikārassa, yonisomanasikārassa ca gahaṇaṃ
analyzed: vuttāḥ ettha ca catubbidhassa a yonisoma nasikārassa yonisoma nasikārassa ca gahaṇam
translated: And here the inclusion of the four kinds of unwise attention and the one kind of wise attention should be understood as stated without reserve.

original: niravasesadassanatthaṃ katanti daṭṭhabbaṃ, tesu pana asubhesu “subha”nti, “asubha”nti🔽ca manasikāro idhādhippeto, tadanukūlattā pana itare pīti.
analyzed: niravasesa dassana attham katanti daṭṭhabbam tesu pana asubhesu subhanti asubhanti  ca manasikāraḥ idha adhippetaḥ tad anukūla ttā pana itare pi iti
translated: But attention to the foulness and to the beauty in the ten kinds of foulness is intended here. The happiness is included by its being favourable to that attention.

original: Ekādasasu asubhesu paṭikkūlākārassa uggaṇhanaṃ, yathā vā tattha uggahanimittaṃ uppajjati,
analyzed: ekādasasu asubhesu paṭikkūla ākārassa uggaṇhanam yathā vā tattha uggaha nimittam uppajjati
translated: The learning of the repulsive aspect in the eleven kinds of foulness, or the practice in the way stated for the learning sign to arise,

original: tathā paṭipatti asubhanimittassa uggaho. Upacārappanāvahāya asubhabhāvanāya anuyuñjanā
analyzed: tathā paṭipatti asubha nimittassa uggahaḥ upacāra ppanā vahāya asubha bhāvanāya anuyuñjanā
translated: is the learning of the sign of foulness. The pursuit of foulness meditation by practice in access and absorption is

original: asubhabhāvanānuyogo. “Bhojane mattaññuno mitāhārassa thinamiddhābhibhavābhāvā otāraṃ
analyzed: asubha bhāvanā anuyogaḥ bhojane mattaññunaḥ mita āhārassa thina middha abhibhava abhāvāḥ otāram
translated: the development of foulness. “One who is moderate in eating, who consumes food with full awareness of what he is doing, will not be overcome by sloth and torpor.

original: alabhamāno kāmacchando pahīyatī”ti vadanti, ayameva ca attho niddesepi vuccati. Yo🔽pana bhojanassa paṭikkūlataṃ, tabbipariṇāmassa tadādhārassa tassa ca upanissayabhūtassa🔽ativiya jegucchataṃ, kāyassa ca āhāraṭṭhitikattaṃ sammadeva jānāti, so sabbaso bhojane
analyzed: a labhamānaḥ kāmacchandaḥ pahīyati iti vadanti ayam eva ca atthaḥ niddese pi vuccati yaḥ  pana bhojanassa paṭikkūla tam tad vipariṇāmassa tad ādhārassa tassa ca upanissaya bhūtassa  ativiya jegucchatam kāyassa ca āhāra ṭṭhitikattam sammat eva jānāti saḥ sabbaso bhojane
translated: and the contemplation of foulness. “One who is moderate in eating, who eats his food considering it as necessary for his bodily existence, is not overcome by sloth and torpor. The lust for sensual desires is abandoned in him because he does not find an opportunity to indulge in it,” they say. And this is the meaning stated in the Niddesa as well.🔽But one who truly knows the repulsiveness of food, the repulsiveness of the process of digestion that is based on it, and the repulsiveness of the body that is nourished by it, and who knows as well the fact that the body is a mere condition for the existence of the nutriment, is called “one who knows the measure in eating” in the sense that he knows the measure of food.

original: pamāṇassa jānanena bhojanemattaññū nāma. Tādisassa hi kāmacchando pahīyateva.
analyzed: pamāṇassa jānanena bhojanemattaññū nāma tādisassa hi kāmacchandaḥ pahīyateva
translated: For the lust for sensual desires is abandoned in one of this sort.🔽The Elder Tissa, the maker of the contemplation of foulness, was one who had seen the bones of his own teeth.

original: Asubhakammikatissatthero dantaṭṭhidassāvī. Pahīnassāti vikkhambhanavasena pahīnassa.
analyzed: asubha kammika tissa theraḥ danta ṭṭhi dassāvī pahīnassa ati vikkhambhana vasena pahīnassa
translated: “Abandoned by him”: abandoned by him through suppression.🔽The same method applies to the other instances in this section.

original: Ito paresupi evarūpesu ṭhānesu eseva nayo. Abhidhammapariyāyena sabbopi lobho kāmacchandanīvaraṇanti
analyzed: itas paresu pi evarūpesu ṭhānesu esa iva nayaḥ abhidhamma pariyāyena sabbaḥ api lobho kāmacchanda nīvaraṇanti
translated: According to the Abhidhamma, all greed is the hindrance of sensual desire.

original: āha “arahattamaggenā”ti.
analyzed: āha arahatta maggena ati
translated: Therefore it is said: “by the path of arahatship.”

original: Paṭighampi purimuppannaṃ paṭighanimittaṃ parato uppajjanakassa paṭighassa kāraṇanti katvā.🔽Mejjati siniyhatīti mitto, hitesī puggalo, tasmiṃ mitte bhavā, mittassa vā esāti
analyzed: paṭigham pi purima uppannam paṭigha nimittam paratas uppajjanakassa paṭighassa kāraṇam ti katvā  mejjati siniyhati iti mittaḥ hitesī puggalo tasmin mitte bhavā mittassa va
translated: and the sign of resentment is a condition for the later resentment in the way already stated.

original: mettā, hitesitā, tassā mettāya. Appanāpi upacāropi vaṭṭati sādhāraṇavacanabhāvato.
analyzed: mettā hita isitā tassā mettāya appanā api upacāraḥ api vaṭṭati sādhāraṇavacana bhāvato
translated: A friend is one who is friendly, who is helpful. The state of being a friend is mittatā. Or it is a friend’s state, a friend’s condition, thus it is mittatā.🔽It is both absorption and access, because the word is used in the way beginning, “The same bhikkhu … is virtuous, … has a sense of moral shame … is well conducted according to the Teacher’s instructions … is a good exhorter … is one who brings people together and is a good talker” .

original: “Cetovimuttī”ti vutte appanāva vaṭṭati appanaṃ appattāya paṭipakkhato suṭṭhu muccanassa
analyzed: cetaḥ vimutti iti vutte appanā ava vaṭṭati appanam appattāya paṭipakkhato suṭṭhu muccanassa
translated: But when “liberation of mind” is mentioned, only absorption is intended, because there is no complete liberation from opposition until absorption is reached.🔽Tanti yonisomanasikāraṃ: Tanti is a demonstrative pronoun.

original: abhāvato. Tanti yonisomanasikāraṃ. Tatthāti mettāya. Bahulaṃ pavattayatoti bahulīkāravato.🔽Sattesu mettāyanassa hitūpasaṃhārassa uppādanaṃ pavattanaṃ mettānimittassa uggaho,🔽paṭhamuppanno mettāmanasikāro parato uppajjanakassa kāraṇabhāvato mettāmanasikārova🔽mettānimittaṃ. Kammameva sakaṃ etesanti kammassakā, sattā, tabbhāvo kammassakatā,
analyzed: abhāvataḥ yoniso manasikāram tattha ati mettāya bahulam pavattayato ti bahulīkāravato 🔽sattesu mettāyanassa hitu upasaṃhārassa uppādanam pavattanam mettā nimittassa uggaho 🔽paṭhama uppannaḥ mettā manasikāro paratas uppajjanakassa kāraṇa bhāvataḥ mettā manasikāraḥ uva 🔽mettā nimittam kammam eva sakam etesanti kammassakā sattā tad bhāvaḥ kammassaka tā
translated: Bahulaṃ pavattayato: Bahulaṃ pavattayato is an instrumental in the sense of cause.

original: kammadāyādatā. Dosamettāsu yāthāvato ādīnavānisaṃsānaṃ paṭisaṅkhānaṃ vīmaṃsā idha
analyzed: kamma dāyāda tā dosa mettāsu yāthāvataḥ ādīnava a nisaṃsānam paṭisaṅkhānam vīmaṃsā idha
translated: and the kamma-resultant. The investigation of the danger and the benefit in hate and in loving-kindness is the investigation here.

original: paṭisaṅkhānaṃ. Mettāvihārikalyāṇamittavantatā idha kalyāṇamittatā. Odissakaanodissakadisāpharaṇānanti
analyzed: paṭisaṅkhānam mettā vihāri kalyāṇa mittavanta tā idha kalyāṇa mitta tā odissaka anodissaka disā pharaṇa ananti
translated: The presence of a good friend who is a dweller in loving-kindness is the good-friendship here. The pervasion of the directions as limited and unlimited is

original: (odhisakaanodhisakadisāpharaṇānaṃ ma. ni. aṭṭha. 1.115) attaatipiyasahāyamajjhattaverivasena
analyzed: odhisaka anodhisaka disāpharaṇānam ma ni aṭṭha atta atipiya sahāya majjhatta veri vasena
translated: (the pervasion of the directions as limited and unlimited is treated in detail in the Paṭisambhidā, Paṭis I 8).🔽The limited is the limited by the self, by the dear one, by the neutral one, and by the hostile one.

original: odissakatā, sīmāsambhede kate anodissakatā. Ekādidisāpharaṇavasena disāpharaṇatā🔽mettāya uggahaṇe veditabbā. Vihāraracchāgāmādivasena vā odissakadisāpharaṇaṃ. Vihārādiuddesarahitaṃ🔽puratthimādidisāvasena anodissakadisāpharaṇanti evaṃ dvidhā uggahaṇaṃ sandhāya “odissakaanodissakadisāpharaṇāna”nti
analyzed: odissaka tā sīmā sambhede kate anodissaka tā eka ādi disā pharaṇa vasena disā pharaṇa tā  mettāya uggahaṇe veditabbā vihāra racchā gāma ādi vasena vā odissaka disā pharaṇam vihāra ādi uddesa rahitam  puratthima ādi disā vasena anodissaka disā pharaṇam ti evam dvidhā uggahaṇam sandhāya odissaka anodissaka disā pharaṇa ananti
translated: The unlimited is the unlimited when the limited has been defined. The pervasion of the directions is to be known by the pervasion of the directions as one, etc.🔽Or else, the limited is the pervasion of the directions as limited by a monastery, a village, etc.; the unlimited is the pervasion of the directions as unlimited by the eastern direction, etc. Thus the limited and the unlimited are stated with reference to the twofold learning.

original: vuttaṃ. Uggahoti ca yāva upacārā daṭṭhabbo. Uggahitāya āsevanā bhāvanā. Tattha sabbe
analyzed: vuttam uggahaḥ ti ca yāva upacārāḥ daṭṭhabbo uggahitāya āsevanā bhāvanā tattha sabbe
translated: The learning is to be regarded as far as the periphery. The development is the repetition of the learning. Herein, all beings are of two kinds, that is to say, as animals and as non-animals.

original: sattā, pāṇā, bhūtā, puggalā, attabhāvapariyāpannāti etesaṃ vasena pañcavidhā, ekekasmiṃ
analyzed: sattā pāṇāḥ bhūtāḥ puggalāḥ etesam vasena pañcavidhāḥ ekekasmin
translated: It is fivefold according to beings classed as “living beings,” “breathing things,” “persons,” “individuals,” and “those included in the selfhood.”🔽It is twentyfold according to the fourfold occurrence of each of these five kinds: “Let them be free from enmity, free from oppression, free from trouble, and may they live happily.”

original: averā hontu, abyāpajjhā, anīghā, sukhī attānaṃ pariharantūti catudhā pavattito vīsatividhā🔽anodissakapharaṇā mettā. Sabbā itthiyo, purisā, ariyā, anariyā, devā, manussā, vinipātikāti🔽sattodhikaraṇavasena pavattā sattavidhā, aṭṭhavīsati vidhā vā, dasahi disāhi disodhikaraṇavasena
analyzed: averāḥ hontu a byāpajjhāḥ anīghāḥ sukhī attānam pariharantu uti catudhā pavattitaḥ vīsatividhā  anodissaka pharaṇā mettā sabbāḥ itthiyaḥ purisāḥ ariyāḥ anariyāḥ devāḥ manussāḥ vinipātikā ati  pavattā sattavidhā aṭṭhavīsati vidhā vā dasahi disāhi disa udhikaraṇa vasena
translated: This is loving-kindness that radiates impartially.🔽It is sevenfold according to the occurrence of each of these four kinds in the case of women, men, Noble Ones, and ordinary people, gods, and human beings, and those in states of loss. Or it is twenty-eightfold.🔽It is tenfold according to the occurrence of each of these four kinds in the case of the ten directions.

original: pavattā dasavidhā, ekekāya vā disāya sattādiitthādiaverādibhedena asītādhikacatusatappabhedā
analyzed: pavattā dasavidhā ekekāya vā disāya
translated: Or it is a hundred and twenty-eight fold according to the occurrence of each of these ten kinds in the case of women, men, Noble Ones, and ordinary people, gods, and human beings, and those in states of loss.

original: ca odhiso pharaṇā veditabbā.
analyzed: ca odhiso pharaṇā veditabbā
translated: This is loving-kindness that radiates selectively.

original: Yena ayonisomanasikārena aratiādikāni uppajjanti, so aratiādīsu ayonisomanasikāro.
analyzed: yena a yonisoma nasikārena arati ādikāni uppajjanti saḥ arati ādīsu ayonisomanasikāraḥ
translated: “Inappropriate attention” is the kind of attention that gives rise to disliking, etc.

original: Tena nipphādetabbe hi idaṃ bhummaṃ. Esa nayo ito paresupi. Ukkaṇṭhitā pantasenāsanesu,
analyzed: tena nipphādetabbe hi idam bhummam esa nayaḥ itas paresu pi ukkaṇṭhi tā
translated: The locative case is used here in the sense of the ablative. The same method applies to the rest. “Discontent” is dissatisfaction with the dwelling place, etc.

original: adhikusaladhammesu ca uppajjanabhāvariñcanā. Kāyavinamanāti karajakāyassa virūpenākārena
analyzed: adhi kusala dhammesu ca uppajjana bhāva riñcanā kāya vinamanā ati karaja kāyassa virūpena ākārena
translated: He bends his body: he bends his physical body in an unseemly way.

original: namanā. Līnākāroti saṅkocāpatti.
analyzed: saṅkoca āpatti
translated: In a contracted way: in a cramped way.

original: Kusaladhammapaṭipattiyā paṭṭhapanasabhāvatāya, tappaṭipakkhānaṃ visosanasabhāvatāya
analyzed: kusala dhamma paṭipattiyāḥ paṭṭhapana sabhāva tāya tad paṭipakkhānam visosana sabhāva tāya
translated: Because it is the state of being the foundation for the practice of profitable states and the state of being the cleanser of their opposites,

original: ca ārambhadhātuādito pavattavīriyanti āha “paṭhamārambhavīriya”nti. Yasmā paṭhamārambhamattassa
analyzed: ca ārambha dhātu āditaḥ pavatta vīriyanti āha paṭhama ārambha vīriyanti yasmā paṭhama ārambha mattassa
translated: energy that occurs from the first as the element of instigation is called “the energy of first instigation.”🔽Since there is no shaking off of indolence and no coming to the fore of the energy of first instigation,

original: kosajjavidhamanaṃ, thāmagamanañca natthi, tasmā vuttaṃ “kosajjato nikkhantatāya tato🔽balavatara”nti. Yasmā pana aparāparuppattiyā laddhāsevanaṃ uparūpari visesaṃ āvahantaṃ
analyzed: kosajja vidhamanam thāma gamanam ca na atthi tasmā vuttam kosajjataḥ nikkhanta tāya tatas  yasmā pana apara apara uppattiyā laddha āsevanam upari upari visesam āvahantam
translated: it is said to be “weaker than that which comes from the shaking off of indolence.”🔽But since that which has reached repetition by the occurrence of the next stage and which brings about the next higher distinction is very much more come to the fore,

original: ativiya thāmagatameva hoti, tasmā vuttaṃ “paraṃ paraṃ ṭhānaṃ akkamanato tatopi balavatara”nti.
analyzed: ativiya thāma gatam eva hoti tasmā vuttam param param ṭhānam akkamanataḥ tatas pi
translated: it is said to be “stronger than that which comes from the shaking off of indolence.”

original: Atibhojane nimittaggāhoti atibhojane thinamiddhassa nimittaggāho, ettake bhutte taṃ
analyzed: atibhojane nimitta ggāho ti atibhojane thinamiddhassa nimitta ggāho ettake bhutte taṃ
translated: In over-eating the seizing of the sign: in over-eating the seizing of the sign of torpor and drowsiness.

original: bhojanaṃ thinamiddhassa kāraṇaṃ hoti, ettake na hotīti thinamiddhassa kāraṇākāraṇagāho🔽hotīti attho. Byatirekavasena cetaṃ vuttaṃ, tasmā “ettake bhutte taṃ bhojanaṃ thinamiddhassa
analyzed: bhojanam thinamiddhassa kāraṇam hoti ettake na hoti iti thinamiddhassa kāraṇa akāraṇa gāho  hoti iti atthaḥ byatireka vasena ca itam vuttam tasmai ettake bhutte tam bhojanam thinamiddhassa
translated: Food is a cause of sluggishness and drowsiness. There is no such cause in the amount that is not a cause of sluggishness and drowsiness.

original: kāraṇaṃ na hotī”ti bhojane mattaññutā ca atthato dassitāti daṭṭhabbaṃ. Tenāha “catupañca…pe…
analyzed: kāraṇam na hoti iti bhojane mattaññu tā ca atthataḥ dassitā iti daṭṭhabbam tena āha catu pañcape
translated: The meaning is that there is no such cause. This is said by way of excess. Therefore it should be regarded as showing moderation in eating in the sense that “in the amount of food eaten that is not a cause of sluggishness and drowsiness, that food is not a cause of sluggishness and drowsiness.” Hence it is said: “four or five mouthfuls … is not a cause of sluggishness and drowsiness.”

original: na hotī”ti. Divā sūriyālokanti divā gahitanimittaṃ sūriyālokaṃ rattiyaṃ manasi karontassāpīti
analyzed: na hoti iti divā divā gahita nimittam sūriya ālokam rattiyam manasi karontassa api iti
translated: The light of the sun by day: the light of the sun by day is the sign apprehended by day.🔽The meaning should be understood in this way.

original: evamettha attho veditabbo. Dhutaṅgānaṃ vīriyanissitattā vuttaṃ “dhutaṅganissitasappāyakathāyapī”ti.
analyzed: evam ettha atthaḥ veditabbaḥ dhutaṅgānam vīriya nissita ttā vuttam dhutaṅga nissita sappāya kathāya api iti
translated: Since the ascetic practices are dependent on energy, it is said: “in the proper conversation dependent on the ascetic practices.”

original: Kukkuccampi katākatānusocanavasena pavattamānaṃ cetaso avūpasamāvahatāya uddhaccena samānalakkhaṇamevāti “avūpasamo nāma avūpasantākāro, uddhaccakukkuccamevetaṃ atthato”ti vuttaṃ.
analyzed: kukkuccam pi kata akata anusocana vasena pavattamānam cetasaḥ a vūpasamāvahatāya uddhaccena samāna lakkhaṇam eva ati avūpasamaḥ nāma a vūpasanta ākāraḥ uddhacca kukkuccam eva etam atthato ti vuttam
translated: Since worry also occurs as a form of mental unease consisting in anxiety about what has been done and what has not been done, it has the same characteristic as agitation. Therefore it is said: “unease is a state of unease; in fact it is agitation and worry.”

original: Bahussutassa ganthato, atthato ca suttādīni vicārentassa tabbahulavihārino atthavedādipaṭilābhasabbhāvato
analyzed: bahu ssutassa ganthataḥ atthataḥ ca sutta ādīni vicārentassa tad bahula vihārinaḥ attha veda ādi paṭilābha sabbhāvato
translated: When one who is learned, who is occupied with the investigation of the suttas, etc., as to their meaning and as to the texts, and who is habituated to that, has attained the understanding of the meaning, etc.,

original: vikkhepo na hotīti, yathāvidhipaṭipattiyā, yathānurūpapatikārappavattiyā ca katākatānusocanañca
analyzed: vikkhepaḥ na hoti iti yathāvidhi paṭipattiyā yathā anurūpa patikāra ppavattiyā ca kata akata anusocanam ca
translated: there is no distraction. And there is no regret for what has been done or not done because of the practice of the right way and the practice of the right kind of attention.

original: na hotīti “bāhusaccenapi…pe… uddhaccakukkuccaṃ pahīyatī”ti āha. Yadaggena bāhusaccena🔽uddhaccakukkuccaṃ pahīyati, tadaggena paripucchakatāvinayapakataññutāhipi taṃ pahīyatīti
analyzed: na hoti iti uddhacca kukkuccam pahīyati iti āha yadaggena bāhusaccena  uddhacca kukkuccam pahīyati tad aggena tam pahīyati iti
translated: So it was said: “By the development of learning … agitation and worry are abandoned” .🔽It should be regarded as said of the abandonment of agitation and worry by the development of learning, etc., that it is by the development of questioning, etc., that it is abandoned.

original: daṭṭhabbaṃ. Vuddhasevitā ca vuddhasīlitaṃ āvahatīti cetovūpasamakarattā uddhaccakukkuccappahānakārī🔽vuttā. Vuddhattaṃ pana anapekkhitvā kukkuccavinodakā vinayadharā kalyāṇamittā vuttāti
analyzed: daṭṭhabbam vuddha sevitā ca vuddha sīlitam āvahati iti cetaḥ vūpasama karattā uddhacca kukkucca ppahāna kārī  vuttā vuddha ttam pana an apekkhitvā kukkucca vinodakā vinaya dharā kalyāṇa mittā vuttā ati
translated: And the frequenting of elders brings about the state of virtue of elders. So it is said to bring about the abandonment of agitation and worry because it causes the mind to be tranquil.🔽But it should be regarded as said because of good friends who are bearers of the tradition and who remove worry, without regard to the state of being an elder.

original: daṭṭhabbā. Vikkhepo ca pabbajitānaṃ yebhuyyena kukkuccahetuko hotīti “kappiyākappiyaparipucchābahulassā”tiādinā
analyzed: daṭṭhabbāḥ vikkhepaḥ ca pabbajitānam yebhuyyena kukkucca hetuko hoti iti kappiya akappiya paripucchā bahulassa ati ādinā
translated: And distraction is usually the cause of worry in those gone forth. So it was said: “By the frequent questioning of what is and what is not proper” ,

original: vinayanayeneva paripucchakatādayo niddiṭṭhā. Pahīne uddhaccakukkucceti niddhāraṇe
analyzed: vinaya nayena iva paripucchaka tā ādayaḥ niddiṭṭhā pahīne uddhacca kukkucca iti niddhāraṇe
translated: The words “When agitation and worry are abandoned in him” are the locative case.

original: bhummaṃ. Kukkuccassa domanassasahagatattā anāgāmimaggena āyatiṃ anuppādo vutto.
analyzed: bhummam kukkuccassa domanassa sahagata ttā anāgāmi maggena āyatim anuppādaḥ vutto
translated: And since worry is associated with grief, its non-arising in the future is stated by the non-return path.🔽The words “the source of doubt” are analyzed as follows: “It stands in it” , thus it is a source ;

original: Tiṭṭhati pavattati etthāti ṭhānīyā vicikicchāya ṭhānīyā vicikicchāṭhānīyā, vicikicchāya🔽kāraṇabhūtā dhammā, tiṭṭhatīti vā ṭhānīyā, vicikicchā ṭhānīyā etissāti vicikicchāṭhānīyā,
analyzed: tiṭṭhati pavattati ettha ati ṭhānīyā vicikicchāya ṭhānīyā vicikicchā aṭhānīyā vicikicchāya  kāraṇa bhūtāḥ dhammā tiṭṭhati iti vā ṭhānīyā vicikicchā ṭhānīyā etissa ati vicikicchā ṭhānīyā
translated: doubt is a source , thus it is the source of doubt.

original: atthato vicikicchā eva. Sā hi purimuppannā parato uppajjanakavicikicchāya sabhāgahetutāya
analyzed: atthataḥ vicikicchā eva sā hi purima uppannā paratas uppajjanaka vicikicchāya sa bhāga hetu tāya
translated: In the sense of the specific characteristic , it is doubt itself. For that is a condition for the doubt that arises later as a similar kind of condition.

original: asādhāraṇaṃ kāraṇaṃ.🔽Kusalākusalāti kosallasambhūtaṭṭhena kusalā, tappaṭipakkhato akusalā. Ye akusalā,
analyzed: asādhāraṇam kāraṇam  kusala akusalā ti kosalla sambhūta ṭṭhena kusalā tad paṭipakkhato akusalāḥ ye akusalā
translated: It is a special condition.🔽The words “profitable and unprofitable” are analyzed as follows: “They are profitable because they originate from skill” , and “they are unprofitable because they are the opposites of that” .

original: te sāvajjā, asevitabbā, hīnā ca. Ye kusalā, te anavajjā, sevitabbā, paṇītā ca. Kusalā
analyzed: te sāvajjāḥ a sevitabbāḥ hīnā ca ye kusalā te anavajjā sevitabbā paṇītā ca kusalā
translated: Those that are unprofitable are “blameworthy” and “should not be developed” and “inferior” . Those that are profitable are “blameless” and “should be developed” and “superior” .
