analyzed: āha sati pana sabbattha balavatī vaṭṭati iti sabbattha ati līn uddhacca pakkhikesu pañcasu
translated: In all: in the five faculties beginning with mindfulness and ending with equanimity.

original: indriyesu. Uddhaccapakkhikekadese gaṇhanto “saddhāvīriyapaññāna”nti āha. Aññathā
analyzed: indriyesu uddhacca pakkhika ikadese gaṇhanto saddhā vīriya paññānan ti āha aññathā
translated: Taking the side of agitation, he says “faith, energy, and understanding” .🔽Otherwise,🔽happiness would have to be included too. For it is said simply “by concentration on idleness” ,

original: pīti ca gahetabbā siyā. Tathā hi “kosajjapakkhikena samādhinā” icceva vuttaṃ, na
analyzed: pi iti ca gahetabbā siyā tathā hi kosajja pakkhikena samādhinā icca iva vuttam na
translated: not “by the happiness, concentration, and equanimity” .

original: “passaddhisamādhiupekkhāhī”ti. Sāti sati. Sabbesu rājakammesu niyutto sabbakammiko.
analyzed: passaddhi samādhi upekkhāhi iti sā ati sati sabbesu rāja kammesu niyuttaḥ sabbakammiko
translated: “Sati” is mindfulness. “Sabbakammiko” is one who is occupied with all the king’s duties.

original: Tenāti tena sabbattha icchitabbaṭṭhena kāraṇena. Āha aṭṭhakathāyaṃ. Sabbattha niyuttā🔽sabbatthikā sabbattha līne, uddhate ca citte icchitabbattā, sabbe vā līne, uddhate
analyzed: tena ati tena sabbattha icchitabba ṭṭhena kāraṇena āha aṭṭhakathā ayam sabbattha niyuttā  sabbatthikā sabbattha līne uddhate ca citte sabbe vā līne uddhate
translated: “For that reason” is the reason why it is to be desired everywhere. The commentary says:

original: ca citte bhāvetabbā bojjhaṅgā atthikā etāyāti sabbatthikā. Cittanti kusalaṃ cittaṃ.
analyzed: ca citte bhāvetabbā bojjhaṅgā atthikā etāya ati sabbatthikā cittanti kusalam cittam
translated: “They are ‘for everywhere’ because they are to be desired in all states of consciousness, whether slack or excited. Or alternatively, the factors of enlightenment are to be developed for all slack and excited states of consciousness, thus they are ‘for everywhere.’ ‘Consciousness’ is profitable consciousness.

original: Tassa hi sati paṭisaraṇaṃ parāyaṇaṃ appattassa pattiyā anadhigatassa adhigamāya.
analyzed: tassa hi sati paṭisaraṇam parāyaṇam appattassa pattiyā anadhigatassa adhigamāya
translated: For mindfulness is the refuge and support for the attainment of what has not been attained and the realization of what has not been realized.

original: Tenāha “ārakkhapaccupaṭṭhānā”tiādi.
analyzed: tena āha ārakkha paccupaṭṭhāna atiādi
translated: That is why it is said that it ‘functions as protection.’

original: Khandhādibhede anogāḷhapaññānanti pariyattibāhusaccavasenapi khandhāyatanādīsu appatiṭṭhitabuddhīnaṃ.
analyzed: khandha ādi bhede pariyatti bāhu sacca vasena api khandha āyatana ādīsu appatiṭṭhita buddhīnam
translated: ‘Whose understanding is not yet keen in the classification of the aggregates, etc.’: whose understanding is not yet firmly established in the aggregates, sense bases, etc., even by much learning.

original: Bahussutasevanā hi sutamayañāṇāvahā. Taruṇavipassanāsamaṅgīpi bhāvanāmayañāṇe ṭhitattā
analyzed: bahu ssuta sevanā hi suta maya ñāṇa āvahā taruṇa vipassanā samaṅgī api bhāvanā maya ñāṇe ṭhita ttā
translated: For much learning leads to knowledge consisting in what is heard. But one who possesses tender insight is called ‘wise in the sense of being established in knowledge consisting in development’

original: ekaṃsato paññavā eva nāma hotīti āha “samapaññāsa lakkhaṇapariggāhikāya udayabbayapaññāya
analyzed: ekaṃsataḥ paññavā eva nāma hoti iti āha sama paññāsa lakkhaṇa pariggāhikāya udaya bbaya paññāya
translated: because he is established in knowledge consisting in development. Therefore it is said: ‘One who has reached absorption and possesses insight that discerns the rise and fall of the fifty mental factors’ .

original: samannāgatapuggalasevanā”ti. Ñeyyadhammassa gambhīrabhāvavasena tapparicchedakañāṇassa
analyzed: samannāgata puggala sevanā ti ñeyya dhammassa gambhīra bhāva vasena tad paricchedaka ñāṇassa
translated: “The cultivation of friendship with a person who possesses these qualities.”🔽The penetration of the knowable is deep, and therefore the knowledge that penetrates it is called “deep.”

original: gambhīrabhāvaggahaṇanti āha “gambhīresu khandhādīsu pavattāya gambhīrapaññāyā”ti.
analyzed: gambhīra bhāva ggahaṇam ti āha gambhīresu khandha ādīsu pavattāya gambhīra paññāya ati
translated: The penetration of the knowable is deep, and therefore the knowledge that penetrates it is called “deep.”

original: Tañhi ñeyyaṃ tādisāya paññāya caritabbato gambhīrañāṇacariyaṃ, tassā vā paññāya tattha
analyzed: tat hi ñeyyam tādisāya paññāya caritabbataḥ gambhīra ñāṇa cariyam tassā vā paññāya tattha
translated: This is the deep practice of knowledge, for the knowable is to be penetrated by such knowledge. Or the practice of the deep knowledge is the penetration of the knowable,

original: pabhedato pavatti gambhīrañāṇacariyā, tassā paccavekkhaṇāti āha “gambhīrapaññāya🔽pabhedapaccavekkhaṇā”ti. Yathā sativepullappatto nāma arahā eva, evaṃ paññāvepullappattotipi
analyzed: pabhedataḥ pavatti gambhīra ñāṇa cariyā tassā paccavekkhaṇā ti āha gambhīra paññāya  pabheda paccavekkhaṇā ti yathā sati vepullappattaḥ nāma arahā eva evam paññā vepulla ppatto ti pi
translated: which occurs in the various aspects of the knowable. The contemplation of that is called “the contemplation of the deep knowledge.”🔽Just as one who has reached the fullness of mindfulness is an arahant, so one who has reached the fullness of wisdom is also an arahant.

original: so evāti āha “arahattamaggena bhāvanāpāripūrī hotī”ti. Vīriyādīsupi eseva nayo.🔽“Tattaṃ ayokhilaṃ hatthe gamentī”tiādinā vuttapañcavidhabandhanakammakāraṇā niraye
analyzed: saḥ eva ati āha arahatta maggena bhāvanā pāripūrī hoti iti vīriya ādīsu pi esā iva nayo  tat tam ayaḥ khilam hatthe gamenti iti ādinā vutta pañcavidha bandhana kamma kāraṇā niraye
translated: The fulfillment of development is by means of the path of arahantship.🔽The five kinds of work of a fetter-smith mentioned in the passage beginning, “The red-hot iron ball, glowing and flaming” , are done by the being reborn in hell, for the most part, first of all.

original: nibbattasattassa yebhuyyena sabbapaṭhamaṃ karontīti, devadūtasuttādīsu tassa ādito
analyzed: nibbatta sattassa yebhuyyena sabba paṭhamam karonti iti deva dūta sutta ādīsu tassa āditaḥ
translated: In the Devaduta Sutta, etc., it is said that the fetters are made first of all.

original: vuttattā ca āha “pañcavidhabandhanakammakāraṇato paṭṭhāyā”ti. Sakaṭavahanādikāleti
analyzed: vutta ttā ca āha pañcavidha bandhana kamma kāraṇataḥ paṭṭhāyāti sakaṭa vahana ādi kāla iti
translated: And because it is said, he says, “from the time of the fivefold bondage and the work of the executioner.”🔽The word “etc.” in “cart-driving, etc.”🔽includes the time when they are hindered by other human beings and by animals.

original: ādi-saddena tadaññamanussehi, tiracchānehi ca vibādhiyamānakālaṃ saṅgaṇhāti. “Ekaṃ
analyzed: ādi saddena tad añña manussehi tiracchānehi ca vibādhiyamāna kālam saṅgaṇhāti ekam
translated: “One

original: buddhantara”nti idaṃ aparāparaṃ petesu eva uppajjanakasattavasena vuttaṃ, ekaccānaṃ
analyzed: buddhantaram ti idam apara aparam petesu eva uppajjanaka satta vasena vuttam ekaccānam
translated: Buddha-interval” is said with reference to a being who is reborn only among ghosts, or it is said thus because some ghosts

original: vā petānaṃ ekaccatiracchānānaṃ viya tathā dīghāyukatāpi siyāti tathā vuttaṃ. Tathā
analyzed: vā petānam ekacca tiracchānānam viya tathā dīgha āyuka tā api siyā ti tathā vuttam tathā
translated: have a life-duration as long as that of some animals.

original: hi “kālo nāgarājā catunnaṃ buddhānaṃ sammukhībhāvaṃ labhitvā ṭhito metteyyassapi
analyzed: hi kālaḥ nāga rājā catunnam buddhānam sammukhībhāvam labhitvā ṭhitaḥ metteyyassa api
translated: For they say that the dragon-king Kāla, who has waited for the appearance of four Buddhas, will obtain the appearance of the

original: bhagavato sammukhībhāvaṃ labhissatī”ti vadanti, yaṃ tassa kappāyukatā vuttā.🔽Ānisaṃsadassāvinoti “vīriyāyatto eva sabbo lokuttaro, lokiyo ca visesādhigamo”ti
analyzed: bhagavataḥ sammukhībhāvam labhissati iti vadanti yam tassa kappa āyuka tā vuttā  ānisaṃsa dassāvino ti vīriya āyattaḥ eva sabbaḥ lokuttaro lokiyaḥ ca visesa adhigamo ti
translated: Blessed Metteyya, and it is said that his life-duration is an aeon.🔽“Seeing the benefits” : of one who is so by seeing the benefits in energy in the way stated thus, “The whole supramundane and the mundane distinction of attainment is dependent on energy” .

original: evaṃ vīriye ānisaṃsadassanasīlassa. Gamanavīthinti sapubbabhāgaṃ nibbānagāminiṃ paṭipadaṃ,
analyzed: evam vīriye ānisaṃsa dassana sīlassa gamana vīthim ti sa pubbabhāgam nibbāna gāminim paṭipadam
translated: “The way to travel” : the way leading to Nibbāna together with its prerequisite.

original: saha vipassanāya ariyamaggapaṭipāṭi, sattavisuddhiparamparā vā. Sā hi bhikkhuno vaṭṭaniyyānāya
analyzed: saha vipassanāya ariya magga paṭipāṭi satta visuddhi paramparā vā sā hi bhikkhuno vaṭṭa niyyānāya
translated: Or else it is the Noble Path with insight, or the seven purifications. For that is the way to be gone by a bhikkhu for the purpose of turning away from the round of rebirths.

original: gantabbā paṭipadāti katvā gamanavīthi nāma. Kāyadaḷhībahuloti yathā tathā kāyassa🔽daḷhīkammappasuto. Piṇḍanti raṭṭhapiṇḍaṃ. Paccayadāyakānaṃ attani kārassa attano
analyzed: gantabbā paṭipadā ati katvā gamanavīthi nāma kāya daḷhī bahulo ti yathā tathā kāyassa  daḷhīkamma ppasutaḥ piṇḍanti raṭṭha piṇḍam paccaya dāyakānam attani kārassa attano
translated: So it is called the “way to be gone.” “One who is devoted to physical exercise”: one who is devoted to the physical exercise of the body in one way or another.

original: sammāpaṭipattiyā mahapphalabhāvassa karaṇena piṇḍassa bhikkhāya paṭipūjanā piṇḍāpacāyanaṃ.🔽Nīharantoti pattathavikato nīharanto. Taṃ saddaṃ sutvāti taṃ upāsikāya vacanaṃ attano
analyzed: sammā paṭipattiyāḥ mahat phala bhāvassa karaṇena piṇḍassa bhikkhāya paṭipūjanā piṇḍa apacāyanaṃ  nīharantaḥ ti patta thavikataḥ nīharantaḥ tam saddam sutvā iti tam upāsikāya vacanam attano
translated: “The alms food”: the alms food of the country. “The honouring of the alms food”: the honouring of the alms food by the bhikkhu through his own right practice, which makes it fruitful for the givers of requisites, by making himself a fit vessel for it.

original: vasanapaṇṇasāladvāre ṭhitova pañcābhiññatāya dibbasotena sutvā. Manussasampatti,
analyzed: vasana paṇṇa sāla dvāre ṭhitaḥ uva pañcābhiññatāya dibba sotena sutvā manussa sampatti
translated: “Taking it out”: taking it out of the bowl. “Having heard the sound”: having heard the lay devotee’s words with his deva-ear, which is purified and surpasses the human, while standing at the door of his leaf hut.

original: dibbasampatti, nibbānasampattīti imā tisso sampattiyo. Dātuṃ sakkhissasīti “tayi
analyzed: dibba sampatti nibbāna sampatti iti imāḥ tissaḥ sampattiyaḥ dātum sakkhissasi iti tayi
translated: The three kinds of excellence are the excellence of men, the excellence of devas, and the excellence of nibbana.

original: katena dānamayena, veyyāvaccamayena ca puññakammena khettavisesabhāvūpagamanena aparāparaṃ
analyzed: katena dāna mayena veyyāvacca mayena ca puñña kammena khetta visesa bhāva upagamanena apara aparam
translated: “You will be able to give”: “By means of the meritorious deeds consisting in giving and in refraining, which you will have done in me, a field of merit, you will be able to attain successively the excellence of men, the excellence of devas, and the excellence of nibbana.”

original: devamanussasampattiyo, ante nibbānasampattiñca dātuṃ sakkhissasī”ti thero attānaṃ
analyzed: deva manussa sampattiyaḥ ante nibbāna sampattiñca dātum sakkhissasi iti theraḥ attānam
translated: and the perfections of the gods and men, and finally the perfection of Nibbāna.”🔽The Elder thought: “I have crossed over the round of rebirths without difficulty.”

original: pucchati. Sitaṃ karonto vāti “akiccheneva mayā vaṭṭadukkhaṃ samatikkanta”nti paccavekkhaṇāvasāne🔽sañjātapāmojjavasena sitaṃ karonto eva.🔽Vippaṭipannanti jātidhammakuladhammādilaṅghanena asammāpaṭipannaṃ. Evaṃ yathā asammāpaṭipanno
analyzed: pucchati sitam karontaḥ vāti a kicchena iva mayā vaṭṭa dukkham samatikkantanti paccavekkhaṇa avasāne  sañjāta pāmojja vasena sitam karontaḥ eva  vippaṭipannanti jāti dhamma kula dhamma ādi laṅghanena asammāpaṭipannam evam yathā asammāpaṭipannaḥ
translated: He smiled as he looked back, and he smiled as he looked forward.

original: putto tāya eva asammāpaṭipattiyā kulasantānato bāhiro hutvā pitu santikā dāyajjassa🔽na bhāgī, evaṃ. Kusītopi tena kusītabhāvena asammāpaṭipanno satthu santikā laddhabbaariyadhanadāyajjassa
analyzed: putto tāya eva asammāpaṭipattiyā kula santānataḥ bāhiraḥ hutvā pitu santikā dāyajjassa  na bhāgī evam kusītaḥ api tena kusīta bhāvena asammāpaṭipannaḥ satthu santikā laddhabba ariya dhana dāyajjassa
translated: “Gone astray”: gone astray by transgressing the family traditions and customs handed down by one’s ancestors. Just as a son who has gone astray in this way is excluded from the family line and is not entitled to his share of the estate from his father,🔽so too the lazy man, because of his laziness, has gone astray and is not entitled to the spiritual inheritance of the ariyan state which he might receive from the Teacher.

original: na bhāgī. Āraddhavīriyova labhati sammāpaṭipajjanato. Uppajjati vīriyasambojjhaṅgoti🔽yojanā, evaṃ sabbattha.
analyzed: na bhāgī āraddha vīriyaḥ uva labhati sammāpaṭipajjanataḥ uppajjati vīriya sambojjhaṅgaḥ ti 🔽yojanā evam sabbattha
translated: Only the energetic man who practices rightly is entitled to it. The meaning of the expression “the enlightenment factor of energy arises” is to be interpreted in the same way as the meaning of the expression “the enlightenment factor of investigation of states arises.”

original: Mahāti sīlādīhi guṇehi mahanto vipulo anaññasādhāraṇo. Taṃ panassa guṇamahattaṃ dasasahassilokadhātukampanena loke pākaṭanti dassento “satthuno hī”tiādimāha.
analyzed: mahā ti sīla ādīhi guṇehi mahantaḥ vipulaḥ anañña sādhāraṇaḥ tam panassa guṇa mahattam dasa sahassi lokadhātu kampanena loke pākaṭanti dassentaḥ satthuno hi iti ādim āha
translated: And showing that his greatness in special qualities is evident in the world by the quaking of the ten-thousand world-element, he said, “When the Teacher.”

original: Yasmā satthusāsane pabbajitassa pabbajjūpagamena sakyaputtassabhāvo sampajāyati, tasmā buddhaputtabhāvaṃ dassento “asambhinnāyā”tiādimāha.🔽Alasānaṃ bhāvanāya nāmamattampi ajānantānaṃ kāyadaḷhībahulānaṃ yāvadatthaṃ bhuñjitvā
analyzed: satthu sāsane pabbajitassa pabbajju upagamena sakya putta ssabhāvaḥ sampajāyati tasmai buddha putta bhāvam dassentaḥ asambhinnāya iti ādim āha  alasānam bhāvanāya a jānantānam kāya daḷhī bahulānam yāvadattham bhuñjitvā
translated: Since the state of being a Sakyan sage’s son becomes evident to one who has gone forth in the dispensation of the Teacher, he said, “When the Teacher’s son,” showing his state as the Buddha’s son.🔽Avoiding from afar those who are lazy, who do not know the meaning of “meditation on the unattractive” and are ignorant of even its name, who are full of physical strength, who eat as much as they can to satisfy their craving,

original: seyyasukhādianuyuñjanakānaṃ tiracchānakathikānaṃ puggalānaṃ dūrato vajjanā kusītapuggalaparivajjanā.
analyzed: seyya sukha ādi anuyuñjanakānam tiracchāna kathikānam puggalānam dūratas vajjanā kusīta puggala parivajjanā
translated: who indulge in the pleasures of lying down, sleeping, and so on, and who talk like animals.

original: “Divasaṃ caṅkamena nisajjāyā”tiādinā bhāvanāraddhavasena āraddhavīriyānaṃ daḷhaparakkamānaṃ
analyzed: divasam caṅkamena nisajja āyāti ādinā bhāvanā raddha vasena āraddha vīriyānam daḷha parakkamānam
translated: “By walking and sitting in the day time,” etc., he said, showing that he associates with those who are energetic, who are strong in their efforts, and who have begun the development of meditation.

original: kālena kālaṃ upasaṅkamanā āraddhavīriyapuggalasevanā. Tenāha “kucchiṃ pūretvā”tiādi.
analyzed: kālena kālam upasaṅkamanā āraddha vīriya puggala sevanā tena āha kucchim pūretvā itiādi
translated: He associates with those who are energetic by visiting them from time to time. Therefore he said, “I filled my belly,” etc.

original: Visuddhimagge pana jātimahattapaccavekkhaṇā, sabrahmacārīmahattapaccavekkhaṇāti idaṃ
analyzed: visuddhi magge pana jāti mahatta paccavekkhaṇā sabrahmacārī mahatta paccavekkhaṇā ati idam
translated: But in the Visuddhimagga the two, namely, the reflection on the greatness of the birth and the reflection on the greatness of the fellow-brahmin,

original: dvayaṃ na gahitaṃ, thinamiddhavinodanatā, sammappadhānapaccavekkhaṇatāti idaṃ dvayaṃ
analyzed: dvayam na gahitam thinam iddha vinodana tā sammappadhāna paccavekkhaṇa tā ti idam dvayam
translated: are not taken, and the two, namely, the removal of sloth and torpor and the reflection on the right endeavour, are taken.

original: gahitaṃ. Tattha ānisaṃsadassāvitāya eva sammappadhānapaccavekkhaṇā gahitā hoti lokiyalokuttaravisesādhigamassa
analyzed: gahitam tattha eva sammappadhāna paccavekkhaṇā gahitā hoti lokiya lokuttara visesa adhigamassa
translated: Therein, the reflection on the right endeavour is taken because of the seeing of the benefit, for the attainment of the distinction of the mundane and supramundane is

original: vīriyāyattatādassanabhāvato. Thinamiddhavinodanaṃ tadadhimuttatāya eva gahitaṃ hoti,
analyzed: vīriya āyatta tā dassana bhāvataḥ thinam iddha vinodanam tad adhimutta tāye eva gahitam hoti
translated: due to the dependence on energy. The removal of sloth and torpor is taken because of the inclination towards it,🔽for the removal of sloth and torpor is the very success in the exertion of one who is engaged in the production of energy. Therein, the reflection on the fear of the unhappy destination, etc.,

original: vīriyuppādane yuttappayuttassa thinamiddhavinodanaṃ atthasiddhameva. Tattha thinamiddhavinodanakusītapuggalaparivajjanaāraddhavīriyapuggalasevana-
analyzed: vīriya uppādane yutta ppayuttassa thinam iddha vinodanam attha siddham eva tattha thinam iddha vinodana kusīta puggala parivajjana āraddha vīriya puggala sevana
translated: should be seen as the producers of the enlightenment factor of energy by way of the avoidance of the lazy person who removes sloth and torpor, by way of the association with the energetic person who is inclined towards it,

original: tadadhimuttatāpaṭipakkhavidhamanapaccayūpasaṃhāravasena, apāyabhayapaccavekkhaṇādayo🔽samuttejanavasena vīriyasambojjhaṅgassa uppādakā daṭṭhabbā.
analyzed: tad adhimutta tā paṭipakkha vidhamana paccayu upasaṃhāra vasena apāya bhaya paccavekkhaṇa ādayaḥ 🔽samuttejana vasena vīriya sambojjhaṅgassa uppādakā daṭṭhabbā
translated: by way of the removal of the opposite of the inclination, and by way of the accumulation of the conditions, and by way of the stimulation.

original: Purimuppannā pīti parato uppajjanakapītiyā visesakāraṇasabhāgahetubhāvato “pītiyeva
analyzed: purima uppannā pīti paratas uppajjanaka pītiyāḥ visesa kāraṇa sa bhāga hetu bhāvataḥ pītiyā iva
translated: Happiness is called the “basis for the enlightenment factor of happiness” because it is the cause for the arising of the later happiness that is a condition for the enlightenment factor of happiness.

original: pītisambojjhaṅgaṭṭhānīyā dhammā”ti vuttā, tassā pana bahuso pavattiyā puthuttaṃ upādāya
analyzed: pīti sambojjhaṅga ṭṭhānīyāḥ dhammā ti vuttā tassā pana bahusas pavattiyā puthuttam upādāya
translated: The plural form “the dhammas that are the basis for the enlightenment factor of happiness” is used because of the multiplicity of its occurrences.

original: bahuvacananiddeso. Yathā sā uppajjati, evaṃ paṭipatti tassā uppādakamanasikāro.
analyzed: bahuvacana niddesaḥ yathā sā uppajjati evam paṭipatti tassāḥ uppādaka manasikāro
translated: The attention that causes its arising is the way in which it arises.

original: “Buddhānussatī”tiādīsu vattabbaṃ visuddhimagge vuttanayeneva veditabbaṃ.
analyzed: buddha anussati iti ādīsu vattabbam visuddhi magge vutta nayena iva veditabbam
translated: The explanation of the recollection of the Buddha, etc., should be understood in the way given in the Path of Purity .

original: Buddhānussatiyā upacārasamādhiniṭṭhattā vuttaṃ “yāva upacārā”ti. Sakalasarīraṃ pharamānoti🔽pītisamuṭṭhānehi paṇītarūpehi sakalasarīraṃ pharamāno. Dhammaguṇe anussarantassāpi🔽yāva upacārā sakalasarīraṃ pharamāno pītisambojjhaṅgo uppajjatīti yojanā, evaṃ sesaanussatīsu.
analyzed: buddha anussatiyāḥ upacāra samādhi niṭṭha ttā vuttam yāva sakala sarīram pharamānaḥ ti  pīti samuṭṭhānehi paṇīta rūpehi sakala sarīram pharamānaḥ dhamma guṇe anussarantassa api  yāva sakala sarīram pharamānaḥ pīti sambojjhaṅgaḥ uppajjati iti yojanā evam sesa anussatīsu
translated: Since the recollection of the Buddha culminates in access concentration, it is said that it “goes as far as access.”🔽The pervasion of the whole body: the pleasant feeling that arises from the happiness that is the cause for the arising of the enlightenment factor of happiness pervades the whole body.🔽The recollection of the Dhamma and the recollection of the Sangha should be understood in the same way.

original: Pasādanīyasuttantapaccavekkhaṇāyañca yojetabbaṃ tassāpi vimuttāyatanabhāvena taggatikattā.
analyzed: yojetabbam tassa api vimutta āyatana bhāvena taggatika ttā
translated: The recollection of virtue should be understood as the reviewing of the discourses that are inspiring. It too goes as far as access concentration, because it leads to the base of neither-perception-nor-non-perception.

original: Saṅkhārānaṃ sappadesavūpasamepi nippadesavūpasame viya tathā paññāya pavattito bhāvanāmanasikāro🔽kilesavikkhambhanasamattho hutvā upacārasamādhiṃ āvahanto tathārūpapītisomanassasamannāgato
analyzed: saṅkhārānam sappadesa vūpasame api nippadesa vūpasame viya tathā paññāya pavattitaḥ bhāvanā manasikāro  kilesa vikkhambhana samatthaḥ hutvā upacāra samādhim āvahantaḥ tathārūpa pīti somanassa samannāgataḥ
translated: And the attention given to development is the occurrence of understanding in this way, even when there is mere subsidence of defilements in a limited field, as if there were subsidence in an unlimited field.🔽It is accompanied by the happiness and rapture that are in conformity with it.

original: pītisambojjhaṅgassa uppādāya hotīti āha “samāpattiyā…pe… paccavekkhantassāpī”ti.
analyzed: pīti sambojjhaṅgassa uppādāya hoti iti āha samāpattiyā āpe paccavekkhantassa api iti
translated: It is the cause for the arising of the enlightenment factor of rapture.

original: Tattha “vikkhambhitā kilesā”ti pāṭho. Te hi na samudācarantīti. Iti-saddo kāraṇattho,
analyzed: tattha vikkhambhitāḥ kilesā ati pāṭhaḥ te hi na samudācaranti iti iti saddaḥ kāraṇa atthaḥ
translated: Herein, the reading is “the defilements are suppressed” . For they do not occur. The word iti has the meaning of a causal particle.

original: yasmā na samudācaranti, tasmā taṃ nesaṃ asamudācāraṃ paccavekkhantassāti yojanā.
analyzed: yasmai na samudācaranti tasmai tam a samudācāram paccavekkhantassa ati yojanā
translated: The construction is: “because they do not occur, he looks on at their non-occurrence.”

original: Na hi kilese paccavekkhantassa bojjhaṅguppatti yuttā. Pasādanīyesu ṭhānesu pasādasinehābhāvena
analyzed: na hi kilese paccavekkhantassa bojjhaṅgu patti yuttā pasādanīyesu ṭhānesu pasāda sineha abhāvena
translated: For it is not proper that the enlightenment factors should arise in one who looks on at defilements.🔽The “harshness” is the lack of confidence and lack of affection for the objects that inspire confidence.

original: thūsasamahadayatā lūkhatā, sā tattha ādaragāravākaraṇena viññāyatīti āha “asakkaccakiriyāya🔽saṃsūcitalūkhabhāve”ti.
analyzed: thūsa sama hadaya tā lūkha tā sā tattha ādara gārava akaraṇena viññāyati iti āha asakkacca kiriyāya 🔽saṃsūcita lūkha bhāva iti
translated: It is known by the performance of duties without respect.

original: Kāyacittadarathavūpasamalakkhaṇā passaddhi eva yathāvuttabodhiaṅgabhūto passaddhisambojjhaṅgo, tassa passaddhisambojjhaṅgassa evaṃ uppādo hotīti yojanā.🔽Paṇītabhojanasevanatāti paṇītasappāyabhojanaseva natā. Utuiriyāpathasukhaggahaṇena
analyzed: kāya citta daratha vūpasama lakkhaṇā passaddhi eva yathā vutta bodhi aṅga bhūto passaddhi sambojjhaṅgo tassa passaddhi sambojjhaṅgassa evam uppādaḥ hoti iti yojanā  paṇīta bhojana sevana tā ati paṇīta sappāya bhojana seva na tā utu iriyāpatha sukha ggahaṇena
translated: Serenity is the characteristic of the stilling of the disquiet of body and mind. The enlightenment factor of serenity is the serenity described in the way just stated. The enlightenment factor of concentration is the concentration described in the way just stated. The enlightenment factor of equanimity is the equanimity described in the way just stated. The meaning is that the arising of that serenity, that concentration, and that equanimity as enlightenment factors is due to the development of serenity, concentration, and equanimity.

original: sappāyautuiriyāpathaggahaṇaṃ daṭṭhabbaṃ. Tañhi tividhampi sappāyaṃ seviyamānaṃ kāyassa
analyzed: daṭṭhabbam tat hi tividham pi sappāyam seviyamānam kāyassa
translated: By using superior food: by using superior kinds of requisites consisting in boiled rice, etc.,🔽and by using superior weather and posture.

original: kallatāpādanavasena cittassa kallataṃ āvahantaṃ duvidhāyapi passaddhiyā kāraṇaṃ hoti.
analyzed: kalla tā āpādana vasena cittassa kalla tam āvahantam duvidhāya api passaddhiyā kāraṇam hoti
translated: For that is a triple kind of requisites that, when used, is a cause for the two kinds of serenity by arousing fitness in the mind through producing fitness in the body.

original: Ahetukaṃ sattesu labbhamānaṃ sukhadukkhanti ayameko anto, issarādivisamahetukanti
analyzed: ahetukam sattesu labbhamānam sukha dukkhan ti ayam ekaḥ antaḥ issara ādi visama hetukanti
translated: The extreme of pleasure is the pleasure that is found in beings without cause or with an unequal cause such as God.🔽The extreme of pain is the pain that is found in beings with an unequal cause.

original: pana ayaṃ dutiyo. Ete ubho ante anupagamma yathāsakaṃ kammunā hotīti ayaṃ majjhimā
analyzed: pana ayam dutiyaḥ ete ubho ante an upagamma yathāsakam kammunā hoti iti ayam majjhimā
translated: The middle way is the occurrence of pleasure and pain according to each one’s kamma.

original: paṭipatti. Majjhatto payogo yassa so majjhattapayogo, tassa bhāvo majjhattapayogatā.
analyzed: paṭipatti majjhattaḥ payogaḥ yassa so majjhatta payogo tassa bhāvaḥ majjhatta payoga tā
translated: The middle practice is that of one who has the middle way.

original: Ayañhi pahāya sāraddhakāyataṃ passaddhakāyatāya kāraṇaṃ hontī passaddhidvayaṃ āvahati,
analyzed: ayan hi pahāya sāraddha kāyatam passaddha kāyatāya kāraṇam hontī passaddhi dvayam āvahati
translated: For this is the reason why he has abandoned bodily disturbance and has bodily tranquillity, namely, the two kinds of tranquillity that he brings about.

original: eteneva sāraddhakāyapuggalaparivajjanapassaddhakāyapuggalasevanānaṃ tadāvahanatā
analyzed: etena iva sāraddha kāya puggala parivajjana passaddha kāya puggala sevanānam tad āvahana tā
translated: And it is because of this that the avoidance of a person of disturbed body and the cultivation of a person of tranquil body bring about those two kinds of tranquillity.

original: saṃvaṇṇitāti daṭṭhabbaṃ.
analyzed: saṃvaṇṇitā iti daṭṭhabbam
translated: So it should be regarded as “praised.”

original: Yathāsamāhitākārasallakkhaṇavasena gayhamāno purimuppanno samatho eva samathanimittaṃ.
analyzed: yathā samāhita ākāra sat lakkhaṇa vasena gayhamānaḥ purima uppannaḥ samathaḥ eva samatha nimittam
translated: The sign of serenity is the serenity arisen earlier that is apprehended by characterizing it as “contemplated in this way” .

original: Nānārammaṇe paribbhamanena vividhaṃ aggaṃ etassāti byaggo, vikkhepo. Tathā hi so
analyzed: nānā ārammaṇe paribbhamanena vividham aggam etassa ati byaggaḥ vikkhepaḥ tathā hi so
translated: It is called “distraction” because it is scattered in various ways by wandering among the various objects of consciousness.

original: anavaṭṭhānaraso, bhantatāpaccupaṭṭhāno ca vutto, ekaggatābhāvato byaggapaṭipakkhoti🔽abyaggo, samādhi. So eva nimittanti pubbe viya vattabbaṃ. Tenāha “avikkhepaṭṭhena
analyzed: anavaṭṭhāna rasaḥ bhanta tā paccupaṭṭhāno ca vuttaḥ ekagga tā bhāvataḥ byagga paṭipakkho ti  abyaggaḥ samādhi saḥ eva nimittan ti pubbe viya vattabbam tena āha avikkhepa ṭṭhena
translated: For it is said to have the nature of non-steadiness and to be manifested as agitation and perturbation. It is the opposite of unification.

original: ca abyagganimitta”nti.
analyzed: ca abyagga nimittam ti
translated: “Non-distraction” is concentration. It is called “sign of non-distraction” in the way already stated. Hence it is said: “In the sense of non-distraction it is the sign of non-distraction.”

original: Vatthuvisadakiriyā, indriyasamattapaṭipādanā ca paññāvahā vuttā, samādhānāvahāpi tā honti samādhānāvahabhāveneva paññāvahabhāvatoti vuttaṃ “vatthuvisada…pe… veditabbā”ti.🔽Karaṇabhāvanākosallānaṃ avinābhāvato, rakkhanakosallassa ca taṃmūlakattā “nimittakusalatā
analyzed: vatthu visada kiriyā indriya samatta paṭipādanā ca paññā āvahā vuttā samādhāna āvahā api tāḥ honti samādhāna āvaha bhāvena iva paññā āvaha bhāvato ti vuttam vatthu visada pe veditabbā ati  karaṇa bhāvanā kosallānam avinābhāvataḥ rakkhana kosallassa ca nimitta kusala tā
translated: The words “purification of the object” and “adjustment of the faculties” are said to be conducive to insight because they are the cause for the arising of insight. But they are also conducive to concentration because they are the cause for the arising of concentration. That is why it is said: “The purification of the object and the adjustment of the faculties should be understood as being conducive to concentration in the sense of being its cause.”🔽Because skill in the means of development is inseparable from it, and because guarding is rooted in it, skill in the sign is said to be skill in the means of development.🔽The words “skill in the sign” should be understood as skill in apprehending the sign of a kasiṇa.

original: nāma kasiṇanimittassa uggahaṇakusalatā” icceva vuttaṃ. Kasiṇanimittassāti ca nidassanamattaṃ🔽daṭṭhabbaṃ. Asubhanimittassāpi hi yassa kassaci jhānuppattinimittassa uggahaṇakosallaṃ
analyzed: nāma kasiṇa nimittassa uggahaṇa kusala tā iccā iva vuttam kasiṇa nimittassa ati ca nidassana mattam  daṭṭhabbam asubha nimittassa api hi yassa kassaci jhāna uppatti nimittassa uggahaṇa kosallam
translated: And the words “sign of a kasiṇa” should be understood as a mere indication.🔽For skill in apprehending the sign of any object that has arisen in one who is attaining jhāna is skill in the sign.

original: nimittakusalatā evāti. Atisithilavīriyatādīhīti ādi-saddena paññāpayogamandataṃ,
analyzed: nimitta kusala tā eva iti ādi saddena paññā apayoga manda tam
translated: “Excessive slackness of energy” is mentioned in order to include excessive slackness of the other aids to enlightenment as well,🔽and “lack of desire to see” in order to include lack of desire to see the other aids to enlightenment.

original: pamodavekallañca saṅgaṇhāti. Tassa paggaṇhananti tassa līnassa cittassa dhammavicayasambojjhaṅgādisamuṭṭhāpanena🔽layāpattito samuddharaṇaṃ. Vuttañhetaṃ bhagavatā –
analyzed: pamoda vekallañca saṅgaṇhāti tassa paggaṇhanan ti tassa līnassa cittassa dhammavicaya sambojjhaṅga ādi samuṭṭhāpanena 🔽laya āpattitaḥ samuddharaṇam vuttam ha etam bhagavatā
translated: “The arousing of it” is the lifting of the slack mind out of its depression by arousing the enlightenment factors of discrimination of states, energy, and happiness.

original: “Yasmiñca kho, bhikkhave, samaye līnaṃ cittaṃ hoti, kālo tasmiṃ samaye dhammavicayasambojjhaṅgassa
analyzed: yasmin ca kho bhikkhave samaye līnam cittam hoti kālo tasmin samaye dhammavicaya sambojjhaṅgassa
translated: “Bhikkhus, when the mind is slack, that is the time for developing the enlightenment factor of discrimination of states,

original: bhāvanāya, kālo vīriyasambojjhaṅgassa bhāvanāya, kālo pītisambojjhaṅgassa bhāvanāya.
analyzed: bhāvanāya kālaḥ vīriya sambojjhaṅgassa bhāvanāya kālaḥ pīti sambojjhaṅgassa bhāvanāya
translated: the enlightenment factor of energy, and the enlightenment factor of rapture.

original: Taṃ kissa hetu? Līnaṃ, bhikkhave, cittaṃ taṃ etehi dhammehi susamuṭṭhāpayaṃ hoti.🔽Seyyathāpi, bhikkhave, puriso parittaṃ aggiṃ ujjālitukāmo assa, so tattha sukkhāni🔽ceva tiṇāni pakkhipeyya, sukkhāni gomayāni pakkhipeyya, sukkhāni kaṭṭhāni pakkhipeyya,
analyzed: tat kissa hetu līnam bhikkhave cittam tam etehi dhammehi su samuṭṭhāpayam hoti  seyyathā api bhikkhave purisaḥ parittam aggim ujjālitu kāmaḥ assa saḥ tattha sukkhāni  ca iva tiṇāni pakkhipeyya sukkhāni gomayāni pakkhipeyya sukkhāni kaṭṭhāni pakkhipeyya
translated: Why is that? Because a slack mind is easily aroused by these states.

original: mukhavātañca dadeyya, na ca paṃsukena okireyya, bhabbo nu kho so puriso parittaṃ
analyzed: mukha vātañca dadeyya na ca paṃsukena okireyya bhabbaḥ nu kho so purisaḥ parittam
translated: Suppose a man wanted to make a small fire blaze up. He would put dry grass on it, put dry cow-dung on it, put dry sticks on it, blow on it with his mouth, and not scatter soil over it. Would he be able to make that small fire blaze up?”

original: aggiṃ ujjālitunti. Evaṃ bhante”ti.
analyzed: aggim ujjālitum ti evam bhanta iti
translated: “Yes, venerable sir.”

original: Ettha ca yathāsakaṃ āhāravasena dhammavicayasambojjhaṅgādīnaṃ bhāvanāsamuṭṭhāpanāti
analyzed: ettha ca yathāsakam āhāra vasena dhammavicaya sambojjhaṅga ādīnam bhāvanā samuṭṭhāpanā ati
translated: And here the arousing of the development of the enlightenment factors of discrimination of states, etc., should be understood as the nutriment for each one respectively.

original: veditabbā, sā anantaraṃ vibhāvitā eva. Āraddhavīriyatādīhīti ādi-saddena paññāpayogabalavataṃ,
analyzed: veditabbā sā anantaram vibhāvitā eva āraddha vīriya tā ādīhi iti ādi saddena
translated: should be understood, and that has been explained immediately above.🔽The words “one who has aroused energy, etc.” include one who has the energy, the method, and the strength of understanding.

original: pamodubbilāvanañca saṅgaṇhāti. Tassa niggaṇhananti tassa uddhatassa cittassa samādhisambojjhaṅgādisamuṭṭhāpanena
analyzed: saṅgaṇhāti tassa niggaṇhanan ti tassa uddhatassa cittassa samādhi sambojjhaṅga ādi samuṭṭhāpanena
translated: “The restraining of that” is the prevention of the occurrence of agitation by arousing the concentration factor of complete awakening, etc.

original: uddhatāpattito nisedhanaṃ. Vuttampi cetaṃ bhagavatā –🔽“Yasmiñca kho, bhikkhave, samaye uddhataṃ cittaṃ hoti, kālo tasmiṃ samaye passaddhisambojjhaṅgassa
analyzed: uddhata āpattitaḥ nisedhanam vuttam api ca itam bhagavatā  yasmin ca kho bhikkhave samaye uddhatam cittam hoti kālo tasmin samaye passaddhi sambojjhaṅgassa
translated: And this is said by the Blessed One:

original: bhāvanāya, kālo samādhisambojjhaṅgassa bhāvanāya, kālo upekkhāsambojjhaṅgassa bhāvanāya.
analyzed: bhāvanāya kālo samādhi sambojjhaṅgassa bhāvanāya kālo upekkhā sambojjhaṅgassa bhāvanāya
translated: “Bhikkhus, when the mind is agitated, that is the wrong time to develop the serenity enlightenment factor, the concentration enlightenment factor, and the equanimity enlightenment factor.

original: Taṃ kissa hetu? Uddhataṃ, bhikkhave, cittaṃ taṃ etehi dhammehi suvūpasamayaṃ hoti.
analyzed: tat kissa hetu uddhatam bhikkhave cittam tam etehi dhammehi su vūpasamayam hoti
translated: Why is that? Because an agitated mind cannot well be quieted by those states.🔽Suppose a man wanted to extinguish a large bonfire.

original: Seyyathāpi, bhikkhave, puriso mahantaṃ aggikkhandhaṃ nibbāpetukāmo assa, so tattha
analyzed: seyyathā api bhikkhave purisaḥ mahantam aggi kkhandham nibbāpetu kāmaḥ assa saḥ tattha
translated: If he threw dry grass, dry cow-dung, and dry timber into it,

original: allāni ceva tiṇāni…pe… paṃsukena ca okireyya, bhabbo nu kho so puriso mahantaṃ aggikkhandhaṃ
analyzed: allāni ca iva tiṇānipe paṃsukena ca okireyya bhabbaḥ nu kho so purisaḥ mahantam aggi kkhandham
translated: and he were to scatter dry grass, cow-dung, and cow-dung pellets on it, would he be able to🔽🔽

original: nibbāpetunti. Evaṃ bhante”ti.
analyzed: nibbāpetunti evam bhante iti
translated: and he were to scatter dry grass, cow-dung, and dust on it, would he be able to extinguish that great mass of fire? ’ ‘Yes, venerable sir.’

original: Etthāpi yathāsakaṃ āhāravasena passaddhisambojjhaṅgādīnaṃ bhāvanāsamuṭṭhāpanāti veditabbā,
analyzed: ettha api yathāsakam āhāra vasena passaddhi sambojjhaṅga ādīnam bhāvanā samuṭṭhāpanā ati veditabbā
translated: Herein, the arousing of the development of the tranquillity enlightenment factor, etc., should be understood as nutriment in each instance according to the way of development stated.🔽Herein, the development of the tranquillity enlightenment factor has already been stated.

original: tattha passaddhisambojjhaṅgassa bhāvanā vuttā eva. Samādhisambojjhaṅgassa anantaraṃ🔽vakkhati. Paññāpayogamandatāyāti paññābyāpārassa appabhāvena. Yathā hi dānaṃ alobhapadhānaṃ,
analyzed: tattha passaddhi sambojjhaṅgassa bhāvanā vuttā eva samādhi sambojjhaṅgassa anantaram  vakkhati paññā apayoga manda tāya ati paññā byāpārassa appabhāvena yathā hi dānam a lobha padhānam
translated: The development of the concentration enlightenment factor is next to that of the tranquillity enlightenment factor.🔽By the weakness of the function of understanding: by the weakness of the operation of understanding.🔽For just as giving is pre-eminent in non-greed, virtue in non-hate, and development in non-delusion,🔽so understanding is pre-eminent in development.

original: sīlaṃ adosapadhānaṃ, evaṃ bhāvanā amohapadhānā. Tattha yadā paññā na balavatī hoti,🔽tadā bhāvanā pubbenāparaṃ visesāvahā na hoti, anabhisaṅkhato viya āhāro purisassa
analyzed: sīlam adosa padhānam evam bhāvanā amoha padhānā tattha yadā paññā na balavatī hoti  tadā bhāvanā pubbena aparam visesa āvahā na hoti anabhisaṅkhataḥ viya āhāraḥ purisassa
translated: When understanding is not strong,🔽development does not lead to distinction as it does when understanding is strong. Then, like nutriment that is not properly assimilated, it does not give satisfaction to the mind of the meditator,

original: yogino cittassa abhiruciṃ na janeti, tena taṃ nirassādaṃ hoti, tathā bhāvanāya sammadeva
analyzed: yogino cittassa abhirucim na janeti tena tam nirassādam hoti tathā bhāvanāya sammad eva
translated: and so development is unsatisfying. And when it is unsatisfying,

original: avīthipaṭipattiyā upasamasukhaṃ na vindati, tenāpi cittaṃ nirassādaṃ hoti. Tena vuttaṃ
analyzed: a vīthi paṭipattiyā upasama sukham na vindati tena api cittam nirassādam hoti tena vuttam
translated: He does not find the bliss of peace through the practice of the path. Therefore his mind is dispirited. Hence it was said:🔽“The practice of wisdom is a condition for the arising of dispiritedness.”

original: “paññāpayoga…pe… nirassādaṃ hotī”ti. Tassa saṃveguppādanaṃ, pasāduppādanañca tikicchananti🔽taṃ dassento “aṭṭha saṃvegavatthūnī”tiādimāha. Tattha jātijarābyādhimaraṇāni yathārahaṃ🔽sugatiyaṃ, duggatiyañca hontīti tadaññameva pañcavidhabandhanādikhuppipāsādi aññamaññaṃ
analyzed: nirassādam hoti iti tassa saṃvega uppādanam pasāda uppādanam ca tikicchanan ti  tam dassentaḥ aṭṭha saṃvega vatthūni iti ādim āha tattha jāti jarā byādhi maraṇāni yathāraham  sugatiyam duggatiyam ca honti iti tad aññam eva pañcavidha bandhana ādi khuppipāsā ādi aññam aññam
translated: The treatment of this is the arousing of a sense of urgency and the arousing of confidence.🔽In order to show this, he said: “The eight grounds for a sense of urgency” and so on. Herein, birth, aging, sickness, and death are to be seen as the suffering of the round in the happy destinies and the unhappy destinies, respectively. The other five kinds of suffering, beginning with being bound in captivity, are the suffering of the unhappy destinies, which is due to the causes of mutual oppression, etc.

original: vibādhanādihetukaṃ apāyadukkhaṃ daṭṭhabbaṃ, tayidaṃ sabbaṃ tesaṃ tesaṃ sattānaṃ paccuppannabhavanissitaṃ🔽gahitanti atīte anāgate ca kāle vaṭṭamūlakadukkhāni visuṃ gahitāni. Ye pana sattā
analyzed: vibādhana ādi hetukam apāya dukkham daṭṭhabbam tayidam sabbam tesam tesam sattānam paccuppanna bhava nissitam  gahitanti atīte anāgate ca kāle vaṭṭa mūlaka dukkhāni visum gahitāni ye pana sattā
translated: All this is included in the present life of beings.🔽The suffering of the round in the past and future is included separately as the suffering rooted in the round.

original: āhārūpajīvino, tattha ca uṭṭhānaphalūpajīvino, tesaṃ aññehi asādhāraṇaṃ jīvikādukkhaṃ
analyzed: āhāra upajīvino tattha ca uṭṭhāna phala upajīvino tesam aññehi asādhāraṇam jīvikā dukkham
translated: But the suffering of livelihood, which is not shared by all beings, is the suffering of those beings who subsist on food and who subsist on the fruits of effort.

original: aṭṭhamaṃ saṃvegavatthu gahitanti daṭṭhabbaṃ. Ayaṃ vuccati samaye sampahaṃsanāti ayaṃ🔽bhāvanācittassa sampahaṃsitabbasamaye vuttanayena saṃvegajananavasena ceva pasāduppādanavasena
analyzed: aṭṭhamam saṃvega vatthu gahitanti daṭṭhabbam ayam vuccati samaye sampahaṃsanā ati ayam  bhāvanā cittassa sampahaṃsitabba samaye vutta nayena saṃvega janana vasena ca iva pasāda uppādana vasena
translated: This is called “encouragement at the proper time” .🔽At the time of encouraging the development of consciousness, in the way stated, it is the right encouragement by arousing a sense of urgency and by arousing confidence.

original: ca sammadeva pahaṃsanā, saṃvegajananapubbakapasāduppādanena tosanāti attho.
analyzed: ca sammad eva pahaṃsanā saṃvega janana pubbaka pasāda uppādanena tosanā ti attho
translated: The meaning is: by arousing confidence after arousing a sense of urgency.

original: Sammāpaṭipattiṃ āgammāti līnuddhaccavirahena, samathavīthipaṭipattiyā ca sammā avisamaṃ🔽sammadeva bhāvanāpaṭipattiṃ āgamma. “Alīna”ntiādīsu kosajjapakkhikānaṃ dhammānaṃ🔽anadhimattatāya alīnaṃ, uddhaccapakkhikānaṃ anadhimattatāya anuddhataṃ, paññāpayogasampattiyā,
analyzed: sammā paṭipattim āgamma ati līn uddhacca virahena samatha vīthi paṭipattiyā ca sammā avisamam  sammat eva bhāvanā paṭipattim āgamma alīna nti ādīsu kosajja pakkhikānam dhammānam  an adhimatta tāya alīnam uddhacca pakkhikānam an adhimatta tāya anuddhatam paññā apayoga sampattiyā
translated: “Having come to the right way”: having come to the right development of consciousness by the right way, without slackness or agitation, by the way of the middle, the way of evenness.

original: upasamasukhādhigamena ca anirassādaṃ, tato eva ārammaṇe samappavattaṃ samathavīthipaṭipannaṃ.
analyzed: upasama sukha adhigamena ca a nirassādam tatas eva ārammaṇe sama ppavattam samatha vīthi paṭipannam
translated: In the passage beginning “not slack” , it is not slack because of the absence of the predominance of states on the side of indolence; it is not excited because of the absence of the predominance of states on the side of agitation; it is not dispirited because of the excellence of the application of wisdom and because of the attainment of the bliss of peace; and therefore it is even, it has come to the way of evenness, occurring evenly in the object.

original: Tattha alīnatāya paggahe, anuddhatatāya niggahe, anirassādatāya sampahaṃsane na byāpāraṃ🔽āpajjati. Alīnānuddhatatā hi ārammaṇe samappavattaṃ, anirassādatāya samathavīthipaṭipannaṃ,
analyzed: tattha a līna tāya paggahe an uddhata tāya niggahe a nirassāda tāya sampahaṃsane na byāpāram  āpajjati alīna anuddhata tā hi ārammaṇe sama ppavattam a nirassāda tāya samatha vīthi paṭipannam
translated: Herein, he does not make effort to stimulate it when it is not over-energetic, to restrain it when it is over-energetic, or to encourage it when it is not over-sluggish.🔽For non-sluggishness and non-agitation are the opposite of over-sluggishness and over-agitation.

original: samappavattiyā vā alīnaṃ anuddhataṃ. Samathavīthipaṭipattiyā anirassādanti daṭṭhabbaṃ.🔽Ayaṃ vuccati samaye ajjhupekkhanatāti ayaṃ ajjhupekkhitabbasamaye bhāvanācittassa🔽paggahaniggahasampahaṃsanesu abyāvaṭatāsaṅkhātaṃ paṭipakkhaṃ abhibhuyya pekkhanā
analyzed: sama ppavattiyā vā alīnam anuddhatam samatha vīthi paṭipattiyā a nirassādanti daṭṭhabbam  ayam vuccati samaye ajjhupekkhana tā ati ayam ajjhupekkhitabba samaye bhāvanā cittassa  paggaha niggaha sampahaṃsanesu a byāvaṭa tā saṅkhātam paṭipakkham abhibhuyya pekkhanā
translated: Or alternatively, non-sluggishness is the opposite of over-sluggishness, and non-agitation is the opposite of over-agitation.🔽This is called equanimity about proper occasion: the looking on, called non-preoccupation, in the proper occasion for looking on, which is the occasion for abandoning the opposite, called preoccupation, in the development of consciousness in the sense of stimulating, restraining, and encouraging.

original: vuccati. Paṭipakkhavikkhambhanato, vipassanāya adhiṭṭhānabhāvūpagamanato ca upacārajjhānampi
analyzed: vuccati paṭipakkha vikkhambhanataḥ vipassanāya adhiṭṭhāna bhāva upagamanataḥ ca upacāra jhānam pi
translated: This is said because access concentration and absorption concentration are called “equanimity about proper occasion” since they are the looking on that abandons the opposite, called preoccupation, in the development of consciousness in the sense of stimulating, restraining, and encouraging.🔽And because it suppresses the opposite and because it is the means to the attainment of the state of absorption,

original: samādhāna kiccanipphattiyā puggalassa samāhitabhāvasādhanaṃ evāti tattha samadhurabhāvenāha🔽“upacāraṃ vā appanaṃ vā”ti.
analyzed: 🔽upacāram vā appanam vā ati
translated: access concentration is also called “equanimity about proper occasion” since it is the means to the establishment of a person’s state of composure by the fulfilment of the function of concentration.🔽So he said “access or absorption” in order to show the state of composure by the words “equanimity about proper occasion.”

original: Upekkhāsambojjhaṅgaṭṭhānīyā dhammāti ettha yaṃ vattabbaṃ, taṃ heṭṭhā vuttanayānusārena
analyzed: upekkhā sambojjhaṅga ṭṭhānīyāḥ dhammā ti ettha yat vattabbam tat heṭṭhā vutta naya anusārena
translated: The words “things that are a basis for the enlightenment factor of equanimity” should be understood in the way already stated .

original: veditabbaṃ. Anurodhavirodhavippahānavasena majjhattabhāvo upekkhāsambojjhaṅgassa🔽kāraṇaṃ tasmiṃ sati sijjhanato, asati ca asijjhanato. So ca majjhattabhāvo visayavasena
analyzed: veditabbam anurodha virodha vippahāna vasena majjhatta bhāvaḥ upekkhā sambojjhaṅgassa  kāraṇam tasmin sati sijjhanataḥ asati ca so ca majjhatta bhāvaḥ visaya vasena
translated: The cause of the enlightenment factor of equanimity is the state of neutrality consisting in the abandoning of approval and resistance,

original: duvidhoti āha “sattamajjhattatā saṅkhāramajjhattatā”ti. Tadubhaye ca virujjhanaṃ
analyzed: duvidhā iti āha satta majjhattatā saṅkhāra majjhattatā iti tad ubhaye ca virujjhanam
translated: because when that exists the enlightenment factor is successful and when not, not. And that neutrality is twofold as concerned with creatures and with ideas.

original: passaddhisambojjhaṅgabhāvanāya eva dūrīkatanti anurujjhanasseva pahānavidhiṃ dassetuṃ
analyzed: passaddhi sambojjhaṅga bhāvanāya eva dūrīkatanti anurujjhanassa iva pahāna vidhim dassetum
translated: The abandoning of both kinds of resistance is effected by the development of the tranquillity enlightenment factor,

original: “sattamajjhattatā”tiādi vuttaṃ. Tenāha “sattasaṅkhārakelāyanapuggalaparivajjanatā”ti.
analyzed: satta majjhatta tā iti ādi vuttam tena āha satta saṅkhāra kelāyana puggala parivajjana tā ti
translated: so the method of abandoning resistance is shown by the words “neutrality towards creatures” and so on. Hence he said “avoidance of persons who are addicted to the jhāna-made ideas of creatures” .

original: Upekkhāya hi visesato rāgo paṭipakkho. Tathā cāha “upekkhā rāgabahulassa visuddhimaggo”ti.
analyzed: upekkhāya hi visesataḥ rāgaḥ paṭipakkhaḥ tathā ca āha upekkhā rāga bahulassa visuddhi maggo ti
translated: For equanimity has as its opposite greed, which is why it is said, “Equanimity is the path to purity for one abundant in greed” .

original: Dvīhākārehīti kammassakatāpaccavekkhaṇaṃ, attasuññatāpaccavekkhaṇanti imehi dvīhi
analyzed: dvīhākārehi iti kammassaka tā paccavekkhaṇam attasuñña tā paccavekkhaṇam ti imehi dvīhi
translated: By the two kinds of neutrality: by the two kinds consisting in the reflection on the fact that kamma is one’s own and the reflection on the voidness of self.

original: kāraṇehi. Dvīhevāti avadhāraṇaṃ saṅkhyāsamānatādassanatthaṃ. Saṅkhyā evettha samānā,
analyzed: kāraṇehi dvīhā iva ati avadhāraṇam saṅkhyā samāna tā dassana ttham saṅkhyā eva ittha samānā
translated: Here the number is the same,

original: na saṅkhyeyyaṃ sabbathā samānanti. Assāmikabhāvo anattaniyatā. Sati hi attani tassa
analyzed: na saṅkhyeyyam sabbathā samāna nti a ssāmika bhāvaḥ an attaniya tā sati hi attani tassa
translated: but the things numbered are not all the same. The state of having no owner is the unownedness determined by non-self. For if there were a self,

original: kiñcanabhāvena cīvaraṃ, aññaṃ vā kiñci attaniyaṃ nāma siyā, so pana koci natthevāti
analyzed: kiñcana bhāvena cīvaram aññam vā kiñci attaniyam nāma siyā so pana koci nattha iva ati
translated: then the robe would be owned by it as its property, or something else would be owned by it. But there is no such thing.

original: adhippāyo. Anaddhaniyanti na addhānakkhamaṃ na ciraṭṭhāyi, ittaraṃ aniccanti attho.
analyzed: adhippāyaḥ na addhāna khamam na cira ṭṭhāyi ittaram aniccanti attho
translated: This is the intention. The state of having no property is not property-enduring, not lasting long. The meaning is that it is short-lived and impermanent.

original: Tāvakālikanti tasseva vevacanaṃ.
analyzed: tāvakālikanti tassa iva vevacanam
translated: The state of having no duration is a synonym for that.

original: Mamāyatīti mamattaṃ karoti “mamā”ti taṇhāya pariggayha tiṭṭhati.
analyzed: mamāyati iti mamattam karoti mamāti taṇhāya pariggayha tiṭṭhati
translated: It is “mine” because it makes “mine” , because it stands possessed by craving as “mine.”

original: Mamāyantāti mānaṃ dabbaṃ karontā.
analyzed: mamāyantā ati mānam dabbam karontā
translated: It is “mine-ish” because it makes “mine” a conceit.

original: Ayaṃ satipaṭṭhānadesanā pubbabhāgamaggavasena desitāti pubbabhāgiyabojjhaṅge sandhāyāha “bojjhaṅgapariggāhikā sati dukkhasacca”nti. Sesaṃ vuttanayattā suviññeyyameva.
analyzed: ayam sati paṭṭhāna desanā pubbabhāga magga vasena desitā iti pubbabhāgiya bojjhaṅge sandhāya āha bojjhaṅga pariggāhikā sati dukkha saccanti sesam vutta naya ttā su viññeyyam eva
translated: This teaching of the foundations of mindfulness is given as a prior-to-path-development. So the meaning is that the mindfulness that is the condition for the enlightenment factors is the truth of suffering. The rest is easily intelligible since its meaning has already been given.

original: Bojjhaṅgapabbavaṇṇanā niṭṭhitā.
analyzed: bojjhaṅga pabba vaṇṇanā niṭṭhitā
translated: The description of the enlightenment factors is ended.

original: Paṭhamabhāṇavāravaṇṇanā niṭṭhitā.
analyzed: paṭhama bhāṇa vāra vaṇṇanā niṭṭhitā
translated: The first recitation section is finished.

original: Catusaccapabbavaṇṇanā
translated: The four noble truths

original: 386. Yathāsabhāvatoti aviparītasabhāvato. Bādhanakkhaṇato yo yo vā sabhāvo yathāsabhāvo,
analyzed: yathā sabhāvataḥ ti aviparīta sabhāvataḥ bādhana kkhaṇataḥ yaḥ yaḥ vā sabhāvaḥ yathā sabhāvaḥ
translated: As to individual essence: as to non-erroneous individual essence. As to the mode of oppression: or else, as to the individual essence of each one,🔽the meaning being as to the individual essence of materiality, etc., as hardness, etc.

original: tato, ruppanādi kakkhaḷādisabhāvatoti attho. Janikaṃ samuṭṭhāpikanti pavattalakkhaṇassa
analyzed: tatas ruppana ādi kakkhaḷa ādi sabhāvato ti atthaḥ janikam samuṭṭhāpikam ti pavatta lakkhaṇassa
translated: As to the cause of arising: as to the cause of the arising of the mode of appearance,

original: dukkhassa janikaṃ nimittalakkhaṇassa samuṭṭhāpikaṃ. Purimataṇhanti yathāpariggahitassa
analyzed: dukkhassa janikam nimitta lakkhaṇassa samuṭṭhāpikam purima taṇhanti yathā pariggahitassa
translated: which is suffering, and of the mode of sign, which is the cause. As to the prior craving: as to the craving that is accomplished prior to the arising of the suffering that has been discerned.

original: dukkhassa nibbattito puretaraṃ siddhaṃ taṇhaṃ. Siddhe hi kāraṇe tassa phaluppatti.
analyzed: dukkhassa nibbattitaḥ puretaram siddham taṇham siddhe hi kāraṇe tassa phala uppatti
translated: For when the cause is accomplished, the occurrence of its fruit follows.

original: Ayaṃ dukkhasamudayoti pajānātīti yojanā. Ayaṃ dukkhanirodhoti etthāpi eseva nayo.
analyzed: ayam dukkha samudayo ti pajānāti iti yojanā ayam dukkha nirodho ti ettha api esā iva nayo
translated: The construction should be understood thus: “This is the origin of suffering” .

original: Ubhinnaṃ appavattinti dukkhaṃ, samudayo cāti dvinnaṃ appavattinimittaṃ, tadubhayaṃ
analyzed: ubhinnam appavatti dukkham samudayaḥ ca ati dvinnam appavatti nimittam tat ubhayam
translated: As to the cessation of both: as to the cause of the non-occurrence of both suffering and origin.🔽That is to say, the cessation of both is not the occurrence of both.

original: na pavatti etāyāti appavatti, asaṅkhatā dhātu. Dukkhaṃ dukkhasaccaṃ parijānāti pariññābhisamayavasena
analyzed: na etāya ati appavatti asaṅkhatā dhātu dukkham dukkha saccam parijānāti pariññā abhisamaya vasena
translated: The unformed element is the non-occurrence. The truth of suffering he fully understands by the penetration of full understanding.

original: paricchindatīti dukkhaparijānano, ariyamaggo, taṃ dukkhaparijānanaṃ. Sesapadadvayepi
analyzed: paricchindati iti dukkha parijānanaḥ ariya maggo tam dukkha parijānanam sesa pada dvaye pi
translated: He defines it, thus it is the full-understanding of suffering. The Noble Path is the full-understanding of suffering. In the case of the other two terms

original: iminā nayena attho veditabbo.
analyzed: iminā nayena atthaḥ veditabbo
translated: “He defines” is the noble path, which is the full-understanding of suffering. The meaning should be understood in the same way in the case of the other two terms.

original: Dukkhasaccaniddesavaṇṇanā
analyzed: dukkha sacca niddesa vaṇṇanā
translated: The exposition of the truth of suffering is ended.

original: 388. Evaṃ vuttāti evaṃ uddesavasena vuttā. Sabbasattānaṃ pariyādānavacanaṃ byāpanicchāvasena
analyzed: evam vuttā iti evam uddesa vasena vuttā sabba sattānam pariyādāna vacanam byāpana icchā vasena
translated: “Thus stated”: thus stated in the mode of expression by way of the headings. The words “of all beings” are stated by way of the desire to include.

original: āmeḍitaniddesabhāvato. Sattanikāyeti sattānaṃ nikāye, sattaghaṭe sattasamūheti attho.🔽Devamanussādibhedāsu hi gatīsu bhummadevādikhattiyādihatthiādikhuppipāsikāditaṃtaṃjātivisiṭṭho
analyzed: āmeḍita niddesa bhāvato satta nikāya iti sattānam nikāye satta ghaṭe satta samūhe iti attho  deva manussa ādi bhedāsu hi gatīsu bhummadeva ādi khattiya ādi hatthi ādi khuppipāsika ādi taṃ taṃ jāti visiṭṭhaḥ
translated: The “classes of beings” are the groups of beings, the categories of beings, the collections of beings.🔽For in the destinies such as the gods’ and human worlds, the collection of beings distinguished by such and such a birth, such as the gods of the earth plane, the nobles, etc., the elephants, etc., the hungry ghosts, etc., is a class of beings.

original: sattasamūho sattanikāyo. Nippariyāyato khandhānaṃ paṭhamābhinibbatti jātīti katvā
analyzed: satta samūhaḥ satta nikāyaḥ nippariyāyataḥ khandhānam paṭhama abhinibbatti jātī iti katvā
translated: In the ultimate sense, the first generation of the aggregates is birth.

original: “jananaṃ jātī”ti vatvā svāyaṃ uppādavikāro aparinipphanno yesu khandhesu icchitabbo,
analyzed: jananam jātī iti vatvā svāyam uppāda vikāraḥ a parinipphannaḥ yesu khandhesu icchitabbo
translated: Having stated “birth is generation,” this generation, which is the manifestation of what has not come to be, is to be desired together with the aggregates in which it occurs.

original: te teneva saddhiṃ dassetuṃ “savikārāna”ntiādi vuttaṃ. Savikārānanti uppādasaṅkhātena
analyzed: te tena iva saddhim dassetum sa vikāra ananti ādi vuttam sa vikāra ananti uppāda saṅkhātena
translated: In order to show this, it is said, “together with the manifestation” and so forth. “Together with the manifestation” means together with the manifestation called arising.

original: vikārena savikārānaṃ. Jātiādīni hi tīṇi lakkhaṇāni dhammānaṃ vikāravisesāti. “Upasaggamaṇḍitavevacana”nti
analyzed: vikārena sa vikārānam jāti ādīni hi tīṇi lakkhaṇāni dhammānam vikāra visesā ati upasagga maṇḍita vevacananti
translated: By alteration, of those that are altered. For the three characteristics of birth, etc., are the alteration and the distinction of states.

original: iminā kevalaṃ upasaggena padavaḍḍhanaṃ katanti dasseti. Anupaviṭṭhākārenāti aṇḍakosaṃ,
analyzed: iminā kevalam upasaggena pada vaḍḍhanam katam ti dasseti an upaviṭṭha ākārena ati aṇḍa kosam
translated: By the word “only” he shows that the word is extended by the prefix alone.🔽By the mode of not being obstructed: by the mode of entering the egg-shell and the membrane.

original: vatthikosañca ogāhanākārena. Nibbattisaṅkhātenāti āyatanānaṃ pāripūrisaṃsiddhisaṅkhātena.
analyzed: vatthi kosam ca ogāhana ākārena nibbatti saṅkhātena ati āyatanānam pāripūri saṃsiddhi saṅkhātena
translated: By what is called “birth”: by what is called “the completion and fulfilment of the sense bases.”

original: Atha vā jananaṃ jātīti aparipuṇṇāyatanaṃ jātimāha. Sañjātīti sampuṇṇāyatanaṃ. Sampuṇṇā🔽hi jāti sañjāti. Okkamanaṭṭhena okkantīti aṇḍajajalābujavasena jāti. Te hi aṇḍakosaṃ,🔽vatthikosañca okkamantā pavisantā viya paṭisandhiṃ gaṇhanti. Abhinibbattanaṭṭhena
analyzed: atha vā jananam jātī iti a paripuṇṇa āyatanam jātim āha sañjāti iti sampuṇṇa āyatanam sampuṇṇā  hi jāti sañjāti okkamana ṭṭhena okkanti iti aṇḍa ja jalābu ja vasena jāti te hi aṇḍa kosam  vatthi kosam ca okkamantā pavisantā viya paṭisandhim gaṇhanti abhinibbattana ṭṭhena
translated: Or alternatively, by “birth” he refers to birth in an incomplete sense base, and by “rebirth” he refers to birth in a complete sense base. For “rebirth” is complete birth.🔽By the mode of descending: by the mode of birth by the egg-born and womb-born methods. For those who are born by these two methods take rebirth-linking as if descending into the egg-shell and the membrane.

original: abhinibbattīti saṃsedajaopapātikavasena. Te hi pākaṭā eva hutvā nibbattanti. Abhibyattā
analyzed: abhinibbattī iti saṃseda ja opapātika vasena te hi pākaṭāḥ eva hutvā nibbattanti abhibyattā
translated: By the mode of arising: by the mode of birth by the moisture-born and spontaneous methods. For these are born in a manifest way.

original: nibbatti abhinibbatti. “Jananaṃ jātī”tiādi āyatanavasena, yonivasena ca dvīhi dvīhi🔽padehi sabbasatte pariyādiyitvā jātiṃ dassetuṃ vuttaṃ. “Tesaṃ tesaṃ sattānaṃ…pe…🔽abhinibbattī”ti sattavasena vuttattā sammutikathā. Pātubhāvoti ettha iti-saddo ādiattho,🔽pakārattho vā, tena “āyatanānaṃ paṭilābho”ti imassa padassa saṅgaho daṭṭhabbo. Ayampi
analyzed: nibbatti abhinibbatti jananam jāti itiādi āyatana vasena yoni vasena ca dvīhi dvīhi  padehi sabba satte pariyādiyitvā jātim dassetum vuttam tesam tesam sattānam pe  abhinibbattī iti satta vasena vutta ttā sammuti kathā pātubhāvaḥ ti ettha iti saddaḥ ādi atthaḥ  pakāra atthaḥ vā tena āyatanānam paṭilābhaḥ ti imassa padassa saṅgahaḥ daṭṭhabbaḥ ayam pi
translated: “Rebirth” is rebirth-linking. “Birth” and so on are stated with the two terms each in order to show birth by way of the bases and by way of the wombs. “The appearance of beings” and so on are stated by way of the seven kinds of beings.🔽Therefore this is conventional discourse. “Manifestation” : here the word iti has the meaning of “beginning” or🔽the meaning of “manifestation.” Therefore the inclusion of the term “the obtaining of the bases” should be understood. This is also🔽

original: hi paramatthakathāti. Ekavokārabhavādīsūti ekacatupañcavokārabhavesu. Tasmiṃ khandhānaṃ🔽pātubhāve sati. analyzed: hi paramattha kathā ati ekavokāra bhava ādīsu iti eka catu pañcavokāra bhavesu tasmim khandhānam 🔽pātubhāve sati eka catuvokāra bhavesu dvinnam dvinnam āyatanānam 🔽vasena sesesu rūpadhātuyam paṭisandhi khaṇe uppajjamānānam pañcannam kāmadhātuyam 🔽vasena sattannam navannam dasannam punadasannam ekādasannam ca

original: vā. Jīraṇameva jīraṇatā, jīrantassa vā ākāro tā-saddena vuttoti āha “ākārabhāvaniddeso”ti.🔽Khaṇḍitadantā khaṇḍitā nāma uttarapadalopena. Yassa vikārassa vasena satto “khaṇḍito”ti

translated: “Ageing” is the state of being aged, or the mode of being aged is expressed by the word “ageing.”🔽“With broken teeth” : the word “broken” is omitted in the second term. The “brokenness” is that by means of which a person is called “broken.”

original: vuccati, taṃ khaṇḍiccaṃ. Tathā palitāni assa santīti “palito”ti vuccati, taṃ pāliccaṃ.

analyzed: valittacatāya vā vali tacaḥ assa ati valittacaḥ

original: Phalūpacārenāti phalavohārena.

translated: “With wrinkles” : by the word “wrinkles” the “state of being wrinkled” is expressed.

original: 390. Cavanameva cavanatā, cavantassa vā ākāro tā-saddena vutto. Khandhā bhijjantīti

translated: The state of that very one’s having passed away or the aspect of his passing away is what is called death by the word ‘ta’ . The aggregates break up.

original: ekabhavapariyāpannassa khandhasantānassa pariyosānabhūtā khandhā bhijjanti, teneva🔽bhedena nirodhanaṃ adassanaṃ gacchanti, tasmā bhedo antaradhānaṃ maraṇaṃ. translated: The aggregates that are the end of the continuity of aggregates included in a single becoming break up.

original: maraṇakālo, anatikkamanīyattā visesena “kālo”ti vuttoti tassa kiriyā, atthato cutikhandhānaṃ🔽bhedappattiyeva, kālassa vā antakassa kiriyāti yā loke vuccati, sā cuti, maraṇanti
analyzed: maraṇa kālaḥ an atikkamanīya ttā visesena kālo ti vutto ti tassa kiriyā atthato cuti khandhānam 🔽bheda ppattiyā iva kālassa vā antakassa kiriyā ati yā loke vuccati sā cuti maraṇanti
translated: By that very breaking up they go to cessation without being seen, thus it is breaking up, disappearance, death. Death as destruction is death that is the severing of the life faculty included in a single becoming called destruction. Hence it is said, ‘not momentary death’ . Without making the compound ‘death as destruction’ , the meaning of the compound ‘death as destruction’ is not inappropriate as a separate construction thus: ‘The breaking up called destruction and the giving up of life called death are called death’ . The time of death is called ‘death’ because it is not to be transgressed; it is the occurrence of that, in the sense of the breaking up of the aggregates included in death, or the occurrence of the end called ‘death’ in the world, is death.
