original: Vakkhamānatthasampiṇḍanattho pi-saddoti āha “upari sesāni upādāya pi-kāro”ti. Yanti
analyzed: vakkhamāna attha sampiṇḍana atthaḥ pi saddo ti āha upari sesāni upādāya pi kāro ti yanti
translated: The word “pi” has the meaning of “and” and the meaning of “including.” Thus he said “The syllable ‘pi’ includes the rest.” “This”:

original: hetuatthe karaṇe paccattavacananti āha “yenapi dhammenā”ti. Hetuattho hi ayaṃ dhamma-saddo,
analyzed: hetu atthe karaṇe paccatta vacananti āha yena api dhammena ati hetu atthaḥ hi ayam dhamma saddaḥ
translated: The word “dhamma” is in the instrumental case in the sense of cause, and in the sense of instrument.

original: alabbhaneyyabhāvo ettha hetu veditabbo. Tanti vā icchitassa vatthuno alabbhanaṃ,
analyzed: alabbhaneyya bhāvaḥ ettha hetu veditabbo tanti vā icchitassa vatthuno alabbhanaṃ
translated: The cause here is the fact that it is not to be obtained. Or else, “that” is the non-obtaining of the desired object.

original: evamettha “yampīti yenapī”ti vibhattivipallāsena attho vutto. Yadā pana yaṃ-saddo🔽“iccha”nti etaṃ apekkhati, tadā alābhavisiṭṭhā icchā vuttā hoti. Yadā pana “na labhatī”ti
analyzed: evam ettha yam pi iti yena pi iti vibhatti vipallāsena atthaḥ vuttaḥ yadā pana yaṃsaddaḥ  icchanti etam apekkhati tadā alābha visiṭṭhā icchā vuttā hoti yadā pana na labhati iti
translated: Thus the meaning is stated here by a reversal of the case-endings in “yampi” and “yenapi.”🔽But when the word “yaṃ” is related to “icchā,” then the non-obtaining is stated as qualified by the desire.

original: etaṃ apekkhati, tadā icchāvisiṭṭho alābho vutto hoti, so pana atthato añño dhammo🔽natthi, tathāpi alabbhaneyyavatthugatā icchāva vuttā hoti. Sabbatthāti “jarādhammāna”ntiādinā
analyzed: etam apekkhati tadā icchā visiṭṭhaḥ alābhaḥ vuttaḥ hoti saḥ pana atthataḥ aññaḥ dhammo  natthi tathā api alabbhaneyya vatthu gatā icchā va vuttā hoti sabbattha āti jarā dhamma ananti ādinā
translated: But when it is related to “na labhati,” then the desire is stated as qualified by the non-obtaining. But in fact there is no other state than that.🔽Nevertheless, the desire itself is stated as the object that is not to be obtained.

original: āgatesu sabbavāresu.
analyzed: āgatesu sabba vāresu
translated: “Everywhere” refers to all the passages beginning with “subject to ageing” .

original: Samudayasaccaniddesavaṇṇanā
translated: The explanation of the Description of the Truth of Origination

original: 400. Punabbhavakaraṇaṃ punobbhavo uttarapadalopaṃ katvā mano-saddassa viya purimapadassa
analyzed: punabbhava karaṇam punobbhavaḥ uttara pada lopam katvā manaḥ saddassa viya purima padassa
translated: The “re-arising” is the re-arising of renewed existence, as in the case of the word “mind” , by the omission of the middle term.

original: o-kārantatā daṭṭhabbā. Atha vā sīlanaṭṭhena ika-saddena gamitatthattā kiriyāvācakassa
analyzed: okāra anta tā daṭṭhabbā atha vā sīlana ṭṭhena ika saddena gamita ttha ttā kiriyā vācakassa
translated: and the -i- ending should be regarded as a mere nominal base. Or else, since the meaning is conveyed by the word -i- in the sense of “the state of being,” the absence of a word expressing a verb should be regarded,

original: saddassa adassanaṃ daṭṭhabbaṃ yathā “asūpabhakkhanasīlo asūpiko”ti. Sammohavinodaniyaṃ
analyzed: saddassa a dassanam daṭṭhabbam yathā a sūpa bhakkhana sīlaḥ a sūpikaḥ ti sammoha vinodaniyam
translated: like the expression “one who has the habit of eating without sauce,” as “one who is without sauce.”

original: pana “punabbhavaṃ deti, punabbhavāya saṃvattati, punappunaṃ bhave nibbattetīti ponobbhavikā”ti
analyzed: pana punabbhavam deti punabbhavāya saṃvattati punappunam bhave nibbatteti iti ponobbhavikā ati
translated: But in the Sammohavinodani the meaning is given as follows: “It gives a renewed existence, it leads to a renewed existence, it causes rebirth again and again, thus it is renewed existence” .

original: attho vutto so “taddhitā” iti bahuvacananiddesato, vicittattā vā taddhitavuttiyā,
analyzed: atthaḥ vuttaḥ saḥ taddhitāḥ iti bahuvacana niddesataḥ vā taddhita vuttiyā
translated: This is said as if it were a bahuvrīhi compound, or else because the formation of bahuvrīhis is various,

original: abhidhānalakkhaṇattā vā taddhitānaṃ tesupi atthesu ponobbhavikasaddasiddhi sambhaveyyāti🔽katvā vutto. Tattha kammunā sahajātā punabbhavaṃ deti, asahajātā kammasahāyabhūtā
analyzed: abhidhāna lakkhaṇa ttā vā taddhitānam tesu pi atthesu sambhaveyya ati  katvā vuttaḥ tattha kammunā sahajātā punabbhavam deti asahajātā kamma sahāya bhūtā
translated: or else because bahuvrīhis are characterized by the fact that they express something else.

original: punabbhavāya saṃvattati, duvidhāpi punappunaṃ bhave nibbattetīti daṭṭhabbā. Nandanaṭṭhena,
analyzed: punabbhavāya saṃvattati duvidhā api punappunam bhave nibbatteti iti daṭṭhabbā nandana ṭṭhena
translated: So it is said as if it were possible to derive the word ponobbhavika from the meaning of those words. Herein, that which is conascent with kamma gives a renewed existence; that which is not conascent but is a condition for kamma as its associate gives a renewed existence. Both should be regarded as causing rebirth again and again in renewed existences.

original: rañjanaṭṭhena ca nandīrāgo, yo ca nandīrāgo, yā ca taṇhāyanaṭṭhena taṇhā, ubhayametaṃ
analyzed: rañjana ṭṭhena ca nandī rāgaḥ yā ca nandī rāgaḥ yā ca taṇhāyana ṭṭhena taṇhā ubhayam etam
translated: Delight is both delight and greed in the sense of delighting and in the sense of gladdening. And that delight and greed is craving in the sense of the way of flowing.

original: ekatthaṃ, byañjanameva nānanti taṇhā “nandīrāgena saddhiṃ atthato ekattameva gatā”ti
analyzed: ekattham byañjanam eva nānanti taṇhā nandī rāgena saddhim atthataḥ ekattam eva gatā ati
translated: “In one way” means that craving has gone to the same meaning as delight and greed.🔽The word “together” here has the meaning of “with,” as in the passage “visible objects, etc.”

original: vuttā. Tabbhāvattho hettha saha-saddo “sanidassanā dhammā”tiādīsu viya. Tasmā nandīrāgasahagatāti
analyzed: vuttā tad bhāva atthaḥ ha ittha saha saddaḥ sa nidassanā dhammā ti ādīsu viya tasmā nandī rāga sahagatā ati
translated: Therefore “accompanied by delight and greed” means

original: nandīrāgabhāvaṃ gatā sabbāsupi avatthāsu nandīrāgabhāvassa apaccakkhāya vattanatoti
analyzed: nandī rāga bhāvam gatā sabbāsu pi avatthāsu nandī rāga bhāvassa a paccakkhāya vattanato ti
translated: that they have gone to the state of delight and greed, since they occur without ever abandoning the state of delight and greed in all their modes.

original: attho. Rāgasambandhena uppannassāti vuttaṃ. Rūpārūpabhavarāgassa visuṃ vuccamānattā
analyzed: atthaḥ rāga sambandhena uppannassa ati vuttam rūpa arūpa bhava rāgassa visum vuccamāna ttā
translated: This is what is said. “Arisen through the bond of greed” means: since greed for the fine-material and immaterial is mentioned separately,

original: kāmabhave eva bhavapatthanuppatti vuttāti veditabbā.
analyzed: kāma bhave eva bhava patthanuppatti vuttā iti veditabbā
translated: it should be understood that the arising of the wish for existence is stated only in the sense-desire realm.

original: Tasmiṃ tasmiṃ piyarūpe paṭhamuppattivasena “uppajjatī”ti vuttaṃ, punappunaṃ pavattivasena
analyzed: tasmin tasmin piya rūpe paṭhama uppatti vasena uppajjati iti vuttam punappunam pavatti vasena
translated: “Arises” is said with reference to the first arising in the form of what is dear in this or that case. “Enters upon” is said with reference to the occurrence of that again and again.

original: “nivisatī”ti. Pariyuṭṭhānānusayavasena vā uppattinivesā yojetabbā. Sampattiyanti
analyzed: nivisati iti pariyuṭṭhāna anusaya vasena vā uppatti nivesā yojetabbā sampattiyanti
translated: Or alternatively, “arises” and “enters upon” can be construed as “arising” and “entering upon” through the means of the latent tendency to adhere.

original: manussasobhagge, devatte ca. Attano cakkhunti savatthukaṃ cakkhuṃ vadati, sapasādaṃ
analyzed: manussa sobhagge devatte ca attano cakkhunti sa vatthukam cakkhum vadati sa pasādam
translated: “In the case of prosperity” means in the case of human beauty and divine beauty. “One’s own eye” refers to the eye with its physical basis, with its clear appearance.

original: vā maṃsapiṇḍaṃ. Vippasannaṃ pañcapasādanti parisuddhasuppasannanīlapītalohitakaṇhaodātavaṇṇavantaṃ.
analyzed: vā maṃsa piṇḍam vippasannam pañca pasādanti parisuddha su pasanna nīla pīta lohita kaṇha odāta vaṇṇavantam
translated: or a lump of meat. Clear: pure, very pure, possessing the colour blue, yellow, red, white, etc.

original: Rajatapanāḷikaṃ viya chiddaṃ abbhantare odātattā. Pāmaṅgasuttaṃ viya ālambakaṇṇabaddhaṃ.🔽Tuṅgā uccā dīghā nāsikā tuṅganāsā, evaṃ laddhavohāraṃ attano ghānaṃ. “Laddhavohārā”ti
analyzed: rajata panāḷikam viya chiddam abbhantare odāta tā pāmaṅga suttam viya ālamba kaṇṇa baddham  tuṅgā uccā dīghā nāsikā tuṅga nāsā evam laddha vohāram attanaḥ ghānam laddha vohārā ati
translated: Like a silver cup, with an opening inside because of its hollowness. Like a piece of string, with a fastening for the ear because of its length.🔽High: high-bridged, tall, long. The nose is the organ of smell, which has acquired the name “high-bridged” in this way.

original: vā pāṭho, tasmiṃ sati tuṅgā nāsā yesaṃ te tuṅganāsā, evaṃ laddhavohārā sattā attano🔽ghānanti yojanā kātabbā. Jivhaṃ…pe… maññanti vaṇṇasaṇṭhānato, kiccato ca. Kāyaṃ…pe…
analyzed: tasmin sati tuṅgāḥ nāsāḥ yesam te tuṅga nāsāḥ evam laddha vohārāḥ sattā  yojanā kātabbā jivhaṃpe maññanti vaṇṇa saṇṭhānato kiccato ca kāyaṃpe
translated: Or the reading is “high-bridged noses” . If that is so, then the construction should be: “They are high-bridged noses, and beings who have acquired the name ‘high-bridged’ in this way are their noses.”🔽The tongue …🔽The body …🔽The mind …

original: maññanti ārohapariṇāhasampattiyā. Manaṃ…pe… maññanti atītādiatthacintanasamatthaṃ.🔽Attanā paṭiladdhāni ajjhattañca sarīragandhādīni, bahiddhā ca vilepanagandhādīni.
analyzed: maññanti āroha pariṇāha sampattiyā manaṃpe maññanti atīta ādi attha cintana samattham  attanā paṭiladdhāni ajjhattañca sarīra gandha ādīni bahiddhā ca vilepana gandha ādīni
translated: One’s own internal smells such as the smell of the body, etc., and external smells such as the smell of ointments, etc.

original: Uppajjamānā uppajjatīti yadā uppajjamānā hoti, tadā ettha uppajjatīti sāmaññena gahitā
analyzed: uppajjamānā uppajjati iti yadā uppajjamānā hoti tadā ettha uppajjati iti sāmaññena gahitā
translated: Arising: when it is arising, it is included in the general sense of “arising” here.

original: uppādakiriyā lakkhaṇabhāvena vuttā, visayavisiṭṭhā ca lakkhitabbabhāvena. Na hi sāmaññavisesehi🔽nānattavohāro na hotīti. Uppajjamānāti vā anicchito uppādo hetubhāvena vutto, uppajjatīti
analyzed: uppāda kiriyā lakkhaṇa bhāvena vuttā visaya visiṭṭhā ca lakkhitabba bhāvena na hi sāmañña visesehi  nānatta vohāraḥ na hoti iti uppajjamāna ati vā anicchitaḥ uppādaḥ hetu bhāvena vuttaḥ uppajjati iti
translated: and the characteristic of arising is stated as the act of arising, and the object is stated as the act of being characterized. For there is no difference in the denotation of the general and particular terms.🔽Or alternatively, the unprompted arising is stated as the cause, and the prompted arising is stated as the effect. If it is arising, it is prompted.

original: nicchito phalabhāvena yadi uppajjamānā hoti, ettha uppajjatīti.
analyzed: nicchitaḥ phala bhāvena yadi uppajjamānā hoti ettha uppajjati iti
translated: Herein, “arising” is the effect.

original: Nirodhasaccaniddesavaṇṇanā🔽401. “Sabbāni nibbānavevacanānevā”ti vatvā tamatthaṃ pākaṭataraṃ kātuṃ “nibbānañhī”tiādi
analyzed: sabbāni nibbāna vevacanāni eva iti vatvā tam attham pākaṭataram kātum nibbānam hi itiādi
translated: The explanation of the description of the truth of suffering is ended.

original: āraddhaṃ. Tattha āgammāti nimittaṃ katvā. Nibbānahetuko hi taṇhāya asesavirāganirodho.
analyzed: āraddham tattha āgamma iti nimittam katvā nibbāna hetukaḥ hi taṇhāya asesa virāga nirodhaḥ
translated: Having said that all these are mere synonyms for Nibbāna, he has given the reason for that in order to make the meaning clear, with the words “For Nibbāna is the destruction of lust, etc.” Herein, “having come to” means having made it the object. For the cessation of craving with the remainder of clinging is due to Nibbāna.

original: Khayagamanavasena virajjati. Appavattigamanavasena nirujjhati. Anapekkhatāya cajanavasena,🔽hānivasena vā cajīyati. Puna yathā nappavattati, tathā dūra khipanavasena paṭinissajjīyati.
analyzed: khaya gamana vasena virajjati appavatti gamana vasena nirujjhati anapekkhatāya cajana vasena 🔽hāni vasena vā puna yathā na ppavattati tathā dūra khipana vasena paṭinissajjīyati
translated: He becomes dispassionate through going to the destruction of the defilements. He ceases through going to the non-occurrence of the aggregates. He abandons through going to non-regard.🔽Or alternatively, he abandons through going to the destruction of the defilements. He relinquishes through going to the non-occurrence of the aggregates.

original: Bandhanabhūtāya mocanavasena muccati. Asaṃkilesavasena na allīyati. Kasmā panetaṃ
analyzed: bandhana bhūtāya mocana vasena muccati asaṃkilesa vasena na kasmai
translated: He is freed by way of deliverance from what has become a bondage. He does not stick by way of non-defilement.

original: nibbānaṃ ekameva samānaṃ nānānāmehi vuccatīti? Paṭipakkhanānatāyāti dassento “ekameva
analyzed: nibbānam ekam eva samānam nānā nāmehi vuccati iti paṭipakkha nānatāya ati dassento ekam eva
translated: But why is this Nibbāna, which is the same, called by various names? Showing the diversity of opposites, he says: “For although Nibbāna is one only,” etc.

original: hī”tiādimāha. Saṅkhatadhammavidhurasabhāvattā nibbānassa nāmānipi guṇanemittikattā
analyzed: hi iti ādim āha saṅkhata dhamma vidhura sabhāva ttā nibbānassa nāmāni api guṇa nemittika ttā
translated: Because Nibbāna is of the nature of being devoid of formed dhammas, its names too are devoid of formed dhammas, being merely the cause for the qualities .

original: saṅkhatadhammavidhurāneva hontīti vuttaṃ “sabbasaṅkhatānaṃ nāmapaṭipakkhavasenā”ti.
analyzed: saṅkhata dhamma vidhurān eva honti iti vuttam sabba saṅkhatānam nāma paṭipakkha vasena ati
translated: That is why it is said: “By way of the opposite of all formed dhammas.”

original: Asesaṃ virajjati taṇhā etthāti asesavirāgoti. Esa nayo sesesupi. Ayaṃ pana viseso
analyzed: asesam virajjati taṇhā ettha ati asesa virāgaḥ iti esa nayaḥ sesesu pi ayam pana viseso
translated: “Asesavirāga” means: “here craving comes to an end without remainder.” The same method applies to the rest. But there is this difference:

original: – natthi etassa uppādo, na vā etasmiṃ adhigate puggalassa uppādoti anuppādo, asaṅkhatadhammo.
analyzed: na atthi etassa uppādaḥ na vā etasmin adhigate puggalassa uppādaḥ ti anuppādaḥ asaṅkhata dhammo
translated: “Anuppāda” means: “there is no arising of this” or “when this is attained there is no arising of a person.” It is the unformed dhamma.🔽The meaning of “appavatta” , etc., should be understood in the same way.

original: “Appavatta”ntiādīsupi iminā nayena attho veditabbo. Āyūhanaṃ samudayo, tappaṭipakkhavasena anāyūhanaṃ.
analyzed: appavatta nti ādīsu pi iminā nayena atthaḥ veditabbaḥ āyūhanam samudayaḥ tad paṭipakkha vasena anāyūhanam
translated: “Āyūhana” is origination; the opposite of that is “anāyūhana.”

original: Taṇhā appahīne sati yattha uppajjati, pahāne pana sati tattha tatthevassā abhāvo
analyzed: taṇhā appahīne sati yattha uppajjati pahāne pana sati tattha abhāvo
translated: When craving is unabandoned, it arises wherever there is a basis for it. But when it is abandoned, there is no arising of it here and there.

original: sudassitoti āha “tattheva abhāvaṃ dassetu”nti. Apaññattinti apaññāpanaṃ, “titta alābu
analyzed: su dassitaḥ ti āha tattha eva abhāvam dassetunti apaññattinti apaññāpanam
translated: “To show non-existence there” means to show non-existence right there. “Non-designation” means non-designation. “Enough, gourd!”

original: atthī”ti vohārābhāvaṃ vā. Tittaalābuvalliyā appavattiṃ icchanto puriso viya ariyamaggo,🔽tassa tassā appavattininnacittassa mūlacchedanaṃ viya maggassa nibbānārammaṇassa
analyzed: atthi iti vohāra abhāvam vā titta alābu valliyāḥ appavattim icchantaḥ purisaḥ viya ariya maggo  tassa tassāḥ appavatti ninna cittassa mūla chedanam viya maggassa nibbāna ārammaṇassa
translated: He says “to show non-existence there” . “ Non-described” : non-description; or non-occurrence of the expression “There is a gourd in the water” . The noble path is like the man who wishes to stop the growth of the gourd vine.

original: taṇhāya pahānaṃ, tadappavatti viya taṇhāya appavattibhūtaṃ nibbānaṃ daṭṭhabbaṃ.
analyzed: taṇhāya pahānam tad appavatti viya taṇhāya appavatti bhūtam nibbānam daṭṭhabbaṃ
translated: The abandoning of craving for Nibbāna, the object of the path, is like the cutting of the root of the vine. Nibbāna, which is the non-occurrence of craving, should be seen as like the non-occurrence of the vine.

original: Dutiyaupamāyaṃ dakkhiṇadvāraṃ viya nibbānaṃ, coraghātakā viya maggo. Dakkhiṇadvāre🔽ghātitāpi corā pacchā “aṭaviyaṃ corā ghātitā”ti vuccanti, evaṃ nibbānaṃ āgamma niruddhāpi
analyzed: dutiya aupamāyam dakkhiṇa dvāram viya nibbānam cora ghātakāḥ viya maggaḥ dakkhiṇa dvāre  ghātitā api corā pacchā aṭaviyam corāḥ ghātitā iti vuccanti evam nibbānam āgamma niruddhā api
translated: In the second simile, Nibbāna is like the southern gate, and the path is like the executioners.

original: taṇhā “cakkhādīsu niruddhā”ti vuccati tattha kiccakaraṇābhāvatoti daṭṭhabbaṃ. Purimā
analyzed: taṇhā cakkha ādīsu niruddhā ati vuccati tattha kicca karaṇa abhāvato ti daṭṭhabbam purimā
translated: Even though the thieves are executed at the southern gate, they are afterwards said to be executed in the forest. So too, craving, which has ceased by reaching Nibbāna, is said to have ceased in the eye, etc., because there is no function there.

original: vā upamā maggena niruddhāya “piyarūpasātarūpesu niruddhā”ti vattabbatādassanatthaṃ
analyzed: vā upamā maggena niruddhāya piya rūpa sāta rūpesu niruddhā iti vattabba tā dassana attham
translated: Or the first simile is given to show that craving, which has ceased by means of the path, should be said to have ceased in what is dear and agreeable, etc.

original: vuttā, pacchimā nibbānaṃ āgamma niruddhāya “piyarūpasātarūpesu niruddhā”ti vattabbatādassanatthaṃ
analyzed: vuttā pacchimā nibbānam āgamma niruddhāya piya rūpa sātarūpesu niruddhā iti vattabba tā dassana attham
translated: “The first is said for the purpose of showing that the first is ceased in the sense of the cessation of the five aggregates of clinging, and the last is said for the purpose of showing that the last is ceased in the sense of Nibbāna, which is the cessation of what is dear and pleasant.”

original: vuttāti ayaṃ etāsaṃ viseso.🔽Maggasaccaniddesavaṇṇanā
analyzed: vuttā ati ayam etāsam visesaḥ
translated: This is the difference between them.🔽The explanation of the exposition of the truth of the path.

original: 402. Aññamaggapaṭikkhepanatthanti titthiyehi parikappitassa maggassa dukkhanirodhagāminipaṭipadābhāvapaṭikkhepanatthaṃ,
analyzed: añña magga paṭikkhepana attham titthiyehi parikappitassa maggassa dukkha nirodha gāmini paṭipadā abhāva paṭikkhepana attham
translated: “For the purpose of rejecting other paths”: for the purpose of rejecting the non-path of the path that is imagined by sectarians,

original: aññassa vā maggabhāvapaṭikkhepo aññamaggapaṭikkhepo, tadatthaṃ. “Aya”nti pana attano,
analyzed: aññassa vā magga bhāva paṭikkhepaḥ añña magga paṭikkhepaḥ tad attham ayanti pana attanaḥ
translated: or the rejection of the state of being a path of what is not a path is the rejection of other paths, for that purpose. “This” is one’s own.

original: tesu ca bhikkhūsu ekaccānaṃ paccakkhabhāvato āsannapaccakkhavacanaṃ. Ārakattāti niruttinayena🔽ariyasaddasiddhimāha. Ariyabhāvakarattāti ariyakaraṇo ariyoti uttarapadalopena, puggalassa
analyzed: tesu ca bhikkhūsu ekaccānam paccakkha bhāvataḥ āsanna paccakkha vacanam ārakattā iti nirutti nayena  ariya sadda siddhim āha ariya bhāva karattā ati ariya karaṇaḥ ariyaḥ iti uttara pada lopena puggalassa
translated: And because some of those bhikkhus were witnesses, the expression “near witness” is used. “Far witness” by way of cessation🔽signifies the success of the noble word. “For the purpose of making one noble” means for the purpose of making a person noble by the omission of the latter part of the compound,

original: ariyabhāvakarattā ariyaṃ karotīti vā ariyo, ariyaphalapaṭilābhakarattā vā ariyaṃ
analyzed: ariya bhāva karattā ariyam karoti iti vā ariyaḥ ariya phala paṭilābha karattā vā ariyam
translated: or “noble” means for the purpose of attaining the noble fruit by the omission of the latter part of the compound,

original: phalaṃ labhāpeti janetīti ariyo. Purimena cettha attano kiccavasena, pacchimena phalavasena
analyzed: phalam labhāpeti janeti iti ariyaḥ purimena ca ittha attano kicca vasena pacchimena phala vasena
translated: He causes the fruit to be obtained, he generates it, thus he is Noble. Herein, the first is stated according to his own function, and the second according to the fruit.

original: ariyanāmalābho vuttoti daṭṭhabbo. Catusaccapaṭivedhāvahaṃ kammaṭṭhānaṃ catusaccakammaṭṭhānaṃ,
analyzed: ariya nāma lābho vutto ti daṭṭhabbo catu sacca paṭivedha āvaham kammaṭṭhānam catu sacca kammaṭṭhānam
translated: So it should be regarded as the Noble One’s acquisition of the stainless. The meditation subject that brings about the penetration of the four noble truths is the four noble truths as a meditation subject.

original: catusaccaṃ vā uddissa pavattaṃ bhāvanākammaṃ yogino sukhavisesānaṃ ṭhānabhūtanti
analyzed: catu accam vā uddissa pavattam bhāvanā kammam yoginaḥ sukha visesānam ṭhāna bhūtan ti
translated: Or alternatively, the meditation subject consisting in the four noble truths is a state that is a basis for the special kinds of knowledge in a meditator.

original: catusaccakammaṭṭhānaṃ. Purimāni dve saccāni vaṭṭaṃ pavattihetubhāvato. Pacchimāni
analyzed: catu sacca kammaṭṭhānam purimāni dve saccāni pavatti hetu bhāvato pacchimāni
translated: The first two truths are the round of rebirths because they are the cause of its occurrence. The last two

original: vivaṭṭaṃ nivattitadadhigamupāyabhāvato. Vaṭṭe kammaṭṭhānābhiniveso sarūpato pariggahasabbhāvato.
analyzed: vivaṭṭam nivatti tad adhigama upāya bhāvataḥ vaṭṭe kammaṭṭhāna abhiniveso sarūpataḥ pariggaha sabbhāvato
translated: are the unravelling because they are the means to its cessation. The meditation subject in the round of rebirths is in the true sense the discernment of the three contemplations.🔽In the unravelling it is not, because it is not the province of the latter. And the province of the latter is not because it is useless.

original: Vivaṭṭe natthi avisayattā, visayatte ca payojanābhāvato. Purimāni dve saccāni uggaṇhitvāti
analyzed: vivaṭṭe natthi avisaya ttā visaya tte ca payojana abhāvato purimāni dve saccāni uggaṇhitvā ati
translated: Having learned the first two truths,

original: sambandho. Kammaṭṭhānapāḷiyā hi tadatthasallakkhaṇena vācuggatakaraṇaṃ uggaho. Tenāha
analyzed: sambandho kammaṭṭhāna pāḷiyā hi tad attha sat lakkhaṇena vāc uggata karaṇam uggahaḥ tena āha
translated: is the construction. For learning is the making of the truths one’s own by learning the text of the meditation subject and by discerning its meaning. Hence it is said:

original: “vācāya punappunaṃ parivattento”ti. Iṭṭhaṃ kantanti nirodhamaggesu ninnabhāvaṃ dasseti,
analyzed: vācāya punappunam parivattento ti iṭṭham kantanti nirodha maggesu ninna bhāvam dasseti
translated: “By speech, by turning over again and again.” He shows the state of being “bent on” the state of cessation and the path by the words “dear” and “agreeable.”

original: na abhinandanaṃ, tanninnabhāvoyeva ca tattha kammakaraṇaṃ daṭṭhabbaṃ.
analyzed: na abhinandanam ca tattha kamma karaṇam daṭṭhabbam
translated: But he does not show the state of being “bent on” delighting in them. And the state of being “bent on” them should be regarded as the act of seeing them.

original: Ekapaṭivedhenevāti ekañāṇeneva paṭivijjhanena. Paṭivedho paṭighātābhāvena visaye
analyzed: eka paṭivedhena iva ati eka ñāṇena iva paṭivijjhanena paṭivedhaḥ paṭighāta abhāvena visaye
translated: By penetration of a single kind: by penetration by a single kind of knowledge. Penetration is the act of penetrating by way of the absence of resistance.

original: nissaṅgacārasaṅkhātaṃ nibbijjhanaṃ. Abhisamayo avirajjhitvā visayassa adhigamasaṅkhāto
analyzed: nissaṅga cāra saṅkhātam nibbijjhanam abhisamayaḥ a virajjhitvā visayassa adhigama saṅkhātaḥ
translated: Realization is the act of realizing by way of the mode of non-clinging.

original: avabodho. “Idaṃ dukkhaṃ, ettakaṃ dukkhaṃ, na ito bhiyyo”ti paricchinditvā jānanameva
analyzed: avabodhaḥ idam dukkham ettakam dukkham na itas bhiyyas ti paricchinditvā jānanam eva
translated: The act of knowing by delimiting thus, “This is suffering, this is the extent of suffering, there is no suffering beyond this,”

original: vuttanayena paṭivedhoti pariññāpaṭivedho, tena. Idañca yathā tasmiṃ ñāṇe pavatte🔽pacchā dukkhassa sarūpādiparicchede sammoho na hoti, tathā pavattiṃ gahetvā vuttaṃ,
analyzed: vutta nayena paṭivedhaḥ ti pariññā paṭivedho tena idam ca yathā tasmim ñāṇe pavatte  pacchā dukkhassa sarūpa ādi paricchede sammohaḥ na hoti tathā pavattim gahetvā vuttam
translated: is penetration by delimitation, according to the method stated.🔽This is said by taking the mode of occurrence of the knowledge in such wise that later on there is no confusion about the specific nature, etc., of suffering.

original: na pana maggañāṇassa “idaṃ dukkha”ntiādinā pavattanato. Pahīnassa puna appahātabbatāya
analyzed: na pana magga ñāṇassa idam dukkham ti ādinā pavattanataḥ pahīnassa puna a pahātabba tāya
translated: But it is not said because the path knowledge occurs thus, “This is suffering,” etc.🔽For what has been abandoned is not to be abandoned again.

original: pakaṭṭhaṃ hānaṃ cajanaṃ samucchindanaṃ, pahānameva vuttanayena paṭivedhoti pahānapaṭivedho,🔽tena. Ayampi yasmiṃ kilese appahīyamāne maggabhāvanāya na bhavitabbaṃ, asati ca maggabhāvanāya🔽yo uppajjeyya, tassa kilesassa paṭighātaṃ karontassa anuppattidhammataṃ āpādentassa
analyzed: pakaṭṭham hānam cajanam samucchindanam pahānam eva vutta nayena paṭivedhaḥ ti pahāna paṭivedho  tena ayam pi yasmin kilese a pahīyamāne magga bhāvanāya na bhavitabbam asati ca magga bhāvanāya  yaḥ uppajjeyya tassa kilesassa paṭighātam karontassa anuppatti dhamma tam āpādentassa
translated: Abandoning is the casting out, the giving up, the relinquishing, of the gross defilements in the way already stated. Penetration is the same as the abandoning.🔽This is said of the knowledge that prevents the arising of the defilement that would arise if the path were not developed, and that brings it about that it has no more arising.

original: ñāṇassa tathāpavattiyaṃ paṭighātābhāvena nissaṅgacāraṃ upādāya evaṃ vutto. Sacchikiriyā🔽paccakkhakaraṇaṃ anussavākāraparivitakkādike muñcitvā sarūpato ārammaṇakaraṇaṃ “idaṃ
analyzed: ñāṇassa tathā pavattiyam paṭighāta abhāvena nissaṅga cāram upādāya evam vuttaḥ sacchikiriyā  paccakkha karaṇam anussava ākāra parivitakka ādike muñcitvā sarūpataḥ ārammaṇa karaṇaṃ idam
translated: It is said of the knowledge that prevents the arising of the defilement in this way, since it occurs without clinging because of the absence of any object to be prevented. Realization

original: ta”nti yathāsabhāvato gahaṇaṃ, sā eva vuttanayena paṭivedhoti sacchikiriyāpaṭivedho,
analyzed: tatti yathā sabhāvataḥ gahaṇam sā eva vutta nayena paṭivedho ti sacchikiriyā paṭivedho
translated: Realization is the making of one’s own the act of seeing by oneself, by one’s own direct-knowledge, without the intervention of mere hearsay. It is the same as the abandoning.

original: tena. Ayaṃ panassa āvaraṇassa asamucchindanato ñāṇaṃ nirodhaṃ ālambituṃ na sakkoti,🔽tassa samucchindanato taṃ sarūpato vibhāventameva pavattatīti evaṃ vutto. Bhāvanā
analyzed: tena ayam pana assa āvaraṇassa a samucchindanataḥ ñāṇam nirodham ālambitum na sakkoti 🔽tassa samucchindanataḥ tam sarūpataḥ vibhāventam eva pavattati iti evam vuttaḥ bhāvanā
translated: This is said of the knowledge that is unable to take cessation as its object because it does not cut off the obstruction,🔽and of the knowledge that occurs only by penetrating cessation itself because it does cut off the obstruction. Development

original: uppādanā, vaḍḍhanā ca. Tattha paṭhamamagge uppādanaṭṭhena, dutiyādīsu vaḍḍhanaṭṭhena,🔽ubhayatthāpi vā ubhayathāpi veditabbaṃ. Paṭhamamaggepi hi yathārahaṃ vuṭṭhānagāminiyaṃ
analyzed: uppādanā vaḍḍhanā ca tattha paṭhama magge uppādana ṭṭhena dutiya ādīsu vaḍḍhana ṭṭhena  ubhayatthā api vā ubhayathā api veditabbam paṭhama magge pi hi yathāraham vuṭṭhāna gāminiyam
translated: and the development of what has been aroused. Herein, in the first path it is in the sense of arousing, and in the second and the rest it is in the sense of developing.

original: pavattaṃ parijānanādiṃ vaḍḍhento pavattoti vaḍḍhanaṭṭhena bhāvanā sakkā viññātuṃ.
analyzed: pavattam parijānana ādim vaḍḍhento pavatto ti vaḍḍhana ṭṭhena bhāvanā sakkā viññātum
translated: Or it can be understood in both senses in both instances. For in the first path too it is possible to understand development in the sense of developing what has been aroused, which is the act of reviewing, etc., that occurs in the path leading to emergence.

original: Dutiyādīsupi appahīnakilesappahānato, puggalantarabhāvasādhanato ca uppādanaṭṭhena
analyzed: dutiya ādīsu pi appahīna kilesa ppahānato puggala antara bhāva sādhanato ca uppādana ṭṭhena
translated: And in the second and the rest it is possible to understand development in the sense of arousing, since defilements not previously abandoned are abandoned and a different kind of person is constituted.

original: bhāvanā sakkā viññātuṃ, sā eva vuttanayena paṭivedhoti bhāvanāpaṭivedho, tena. Ayampi
analyzed: bhāvanā sakkā viññātum sā eva vutta nayena paṭivedho ti bhāvanā paṭivedho tena ayam pi
translated: That same penetration is development in the sense of penetration of development.

original: hi yathā ñāṇe pavatte pacchā maggadhammānaṃ sarūpaparicchede sammoho na hoti, tathā🔽pavattimeva gahetvā vutto.
analyzed: hi yathā ñāṇe pavatte pacchā magga dhammānam sarūpa paricchede sammohaḥ na hoti tathā  pavattim eva gahetvā vuttaḥ
translated: For just as, when knowledge occurs, there is no confusion about the specific and general characteristics of the states of the path, so too🔽it is said to occur in the same way as regards the states of fruition that occur in the way stated.

original: Tiṭṭhantu tāva yathādhigatā maggadhammā, yathāpavattesu phaladhammesupi ayaṃ yathādhigatasaccadhammesu
analyzed: tiṭṭhantu tāva yathā adhigatāḥ magga dhammāḥ yathā pavattesu phala dhammesu pi ayam yathā adhigata sacca dhammesu
translated: Let alone the states of the path as they are known,

original: viya vigatasammohova hoti. Tenevāha “diṭṭhadhammo pattadhammo viditadhammo pariyogāḷhadhammo”ti🔽yato sacassa dhammatāsañcoditā yathādhigatasaccadhammālambaniyo maggavīthito parato
analyzed: viya vigata sammohaḥ uva hoti tena iva āha diṭṭha dhammo patta dhammo vidita dhammo pariyogāḷha dhammo ti  yatas sacassa dhamma tā sañcoditā yathā adhigata sacca dhamma ālambaniyaḥ magga vīthitaḥ paratas
translated: and he is as if free from doubt. Hence it is said: “He has seen the state, attained the state, been fully enlightened about the state, understood the state, and penetrated the state” .🔽When he has been urged by the truth of the Dhamma, then after the path he reviews the Nibbāna element that is without trace left, which is the remainderless fading away and cessation of the five aggregates that he has already penetrated.

original: maggaphalapahīnāvasiṭṭhakilesanibbānānaṃ paccavekkhaṇā pavattanti, dukkhasaccammopi
analyzed: magga phala pahīna avasiṭṭha kilesa nibbānānam paccavekkhaṇāḥ pavattanti
translated: And he reviews the truth of suffering too,

original: sakkāyadiṭṭhiādayo. Ayañca atthavaṇṇanā “pariññābhisamayenā”tiādīsupi vibhāvetabbā.
analyzed: sakkāya diṭṭhi ādayaḥ ayam ca attha vaṇṇanā vibhāvetabbā
translated: and the wrong views of individuality, etc., that are abandoned in the path. And this commentary should be understood as applicable also to the passages beginning, “With the direct-knowledge of full-understanding … ” .

original: Ekābhisamayena abhisametīti etthāha vitaṇḍavādī “ariyamaggañāṇaṃ catūsu saccesu nānābhisamayavasena
analyzed: eka abhisamayena abhisameti iti ettha āha vitaṇḍa vādī ariya magga ñāṇam catūsu saccesu nānā abhisamaya vasena
translated: As regards the words, “He penetrates with a single penetration” , the disputant says: “The knowledge of the noble path is effective in the four truths by way of a separate penetration for each truth.

original: kiccakara”nti, so abhidhamme odhisokathāya saññāpetabbo. Idāni tameva ekābhisamayaṃ
analyzed: so abhidhamme odhi sokathāya saññāpetabbaḥ idāni tam eva eka abhisamayam
translated: ” He should be made to agree that this is a discussion in the Abhidhamma, and now in order to elaborate that very single penetration

original: vitthāravasena vibhāvetuṃ “evamassā”tiādi vuttaṃ. “Pubbabhāge…pe… paṭivedho hotī”ti
analyzed: vitthāra vasena vibhāvetum evam assa atiādi vuttam pubba bhāga īpe paṭivedhaḥ hoti iti
translated: it is said: “Thus in the earlier stage … penetration comes about” .

original: kasmā vuttaṃ, nanu paṭivedho pubbabhāgiyo na hotīti? Saccametaṃ nippariyāyato, idha
analyzed: kasmā vuttam nanu paṭivedhaḥ pubbabhāgiyaḥ na hoti iti saccam etam nippariyāyataḥ idha
translated: Why is it said? Hasn’t penetration no place in the earlier stage? That is so in the absolute sense , but here it is said

original: pana uggahādivasena pavatto avabodho pariyāyato tathā vutto. Paṭivedhanimittattā
analyzed: pana uggaha ādi vasena pavattaḥ avabodhaḥ pariyāyataḥ tathā vuttaḥ paṭivedha nimitta ttā
translated: But the understanding that occurs by way of learning, etc., is so called figuratively.🔽Or alternatively, the knowledge that occurs in the earlier stages about suffering, etc., by way of learning, etc., is called “penetration” because it is the sign of penetration,

original: vā uggahādivasena pavattaṃ dukkhādīsu pubbabhāge ñāṇaṃ “paṭivedho”ti vuttaṃ, na paṭivijjhanasabhāvaṃ.
analyzed: vā uggaha ādi vasena pavattam dukkha ādīsu pubba bhāge ñāṇam paṭivedhaḥ ti vuttam na paṭivijjhana sabhāvam
translated: not because it has the nature of penetration.

original: Kiccatoti pubbabhāgehi dukkhādiñāṇehi kātabbakiccassa idha nipphattito, imasseva
analyzed: kiccato ti pubba bhāgehi dukkha ādi ñāṇehi kātabba kiccassa idha nipphattitaḥ imassa eva
translated: “By what is to be done”: because the fruit of what is to be done by the knowledge of suffering, etc., in the earlier stages is accomplished here;

original: vā ñāṇassa dukkhādippakāsanakiccato, pariññāditoti attho. Ārammaṇapaṭivedhoti sacchikiriyāpaṭivedhamāha.
analyzed: vā ñāṇassa dukkha ādi ppakāsana kiccataḥ pariññā āditaḥ ti atthaḥ ārammaṇa paṭivedhaḥ iti sacchikiriyā paṭivedham āha
translated: or because the function of this knowledge is to show suffering, etc., the meaning is, “by full understanding, etc.” “Penetration of the object” refers to the penetration of realization.

original: Sāti paccavekkhaṇā. Idhāti imasmiṃ ṭhāne. Uggahādīsu vuccamānesu na vuttā anavasarattā.
analyzed: sā ati paccavekkhaṇā idha āti imasmin ṭhāne uggaha ādīsu vuccamānesu na vuttā anavasara ttā
translated: “S” is reviewing. “Here” is in this context. “Not mentioned” means not mentioned because there is no opportunity for them.

original: Adhigame hi sati tassā siyā avasaro.
analyzed: adhigame hi sati tassā siyā avasaraḥ
translated: For when there is acquisition, there is opportunity for them.🔽“And this” is said in order to show that very lack of opportunity.

original: Taṃyeva hi anavasaraṃ dassetuṃ “imassa cā”tiādi vuttaṃ. Pubbe pariggahatoti kammaṭṭhānapariggahato
analyzed: tam yeva hi anavasaram dassetum imassa ca atiādi vuttam pubbe pariggahato ti kammaṭṭhāna pariggahato
translated: “Previously, by discerning”: previously, by discerning the meditation subject.

original: pubbe. Uggahādivasena saccānaṃ pariggaṇhanañhi pariggaho. Tathā tāni pariggaṇhanato
analyzed: pubbe uggaha ādi vasena saccānam pariggaṇhanan hi pariggahaḥ tathā tāni pariggaṇhanato
translated: For discerning the truths by way of learning, etc., is discerning. And because he discerns them in that way,

original: manasikāradaḷhatāya pubbabhāgiyā dukkhapariññādayo honti yevāti āha “pariggahato🔽paṭṭhāya hotī”ti. Aparabhāgeti maggakkhaṇe. Duddasattāti attano pavattikkhaṇavasena
analyzed: manasikāra daḷha tāya pubbabhāgiyāḥ dukkha pariññā ādayaḥ honti yeva āti āha pariggahato  paṭṭhāya hoti iti aparabhāge iti magga kkhaṇe duddasa ttā ati attano pavatti kkhaṇa vasena
translated: The full understanding of suffering, etc., in the prior stage is due to the strength of attention. Hence he said: “It is from the time of discerning.”

original: pākaṭānipi pakatiñāṇena sabhāvarasato daṭṭhuṃ asakkuṇeyyattā. Gambhīreneva ca bhāvanāñāṇena,🔽tathāpi matthakappattena ariyamaggañāṇeneva yāthāvato passitabbattā gambhīrāni. Tenāha
analyzed: pākaṭāni api pakati ñāṇena sabhāva rasataḥ daṭṭhum gambhīrena iva ca bhāvanā ñāṇena  tathā api matthaka ppattena ariya magga ñāṇena iva yāthāvataḥ passitabba ttā gambhīrāni tena āha
translated: The later stage is the path moment. They are hard to see: they are not evident to ordinary men’s knowledge of the specific nature because they cannot be seen by that knowledge as to individual essence, even though they are evident by way of their occurrence moment.🔽  They are profound only by means of the knowledge of development,

original: “lakkhaṇapaṭivedhato pana ubhayampi gambhīra”nti. Itarāni asaṃkiliṭṭhaasaṃkilesikatāya
analyzed: lakkhaṇa paṭivedhato pana ubhayam pi gambhīranti itarāni asaṃkiliṭṭha asaṃkilesika tāya
translated: and they are seen as they are only by means of the noble path knowledge that has reached its culmination. Hence he said: “But from the time of penetration of the characteristics both are profound.”

original: accantasukhappattāya anuppattibhavatāya, anuppannapubbatāya ca pavattivasena apākaṭattā🔽ca paramagambhīrattā, tathā paramagambhīrañāṇeneva passitabbatāya pakatiñāṇena daṭṭhuṃ
analyzed: accanta sukha ppattāya anuppatti bhavatāya anuppanna pubbatāya ca pavatti vasena apākaṭa ttā  ca parama gambhīra ttā tathā parama gambhīra ñāṇena iva passitabba tāya pakati ñāṇena daṭṭhum
translated: The others are hard to see because they are not evident by way of occurrence as unadulterated and unadulterated by defilements, as having reached the utmost happiness, as having no arising, and as having not arisen before.

original: na sakkuṇeyyānīti duddasāni. Tenāha “itaresaṃ panā”tiādi. Payogoti kiriyā, vāyāmo
analyzed: na sakkuṇeyyāni iti tena āha itaresam kiriyā
translated: And they are hard to see because they are extremely profound and because they can be seen only by means of extremely profound knowledge. Hence he said: “But the others are hard to see” and so on.🔽  The practice is the action, the effort,

original: vā. Tassa mahantatarassa icchitabbataṃ, dukkarataratañca upamāhi dasseti “bhavaggaggahaṇattha”ntiādinā.
analyzed: vā tassa mahantatarassa icchitabba tam dukkaratara tam ca upamāhi dasseti bhavagga ggahaṇa ttha nti ādinā
translated: He shows the desirability of the greater and the greater difficulty of it by means of the similes beginning with “If he were to wish” .

original: Paṭivedhakkhaṇeti ariyassa maggassa catusaccasampaṭivedhakkhaṇe. Ekameva taṃ ñāṇanti
analyzed: paṭivedha kkhaṇe ti ariyassa maggassa catu sacca sampaṭivedha kkhaṇe ekam eva tam ñāṇam ti
translated: At the moment of penetration: at the moment of the Noble Path’s penetration of the four truths.

original: dukkhādīsu pariññādikiccasādhanavasena ekameva taṃ maggañāṇaṃ hoti.
analyzed: dukkha ādīsu pariññā ādi kicca sādhana vasena ekam eva tam magga ñāṇam hoti
translated: That is one knowledge: that path knowledge is one only, in the sense of accomplishing the functions of full-understanding, etc., in regard to suffering, and so on.

original: Imesu tīsu ṭhānesūti imesu viramitabbatāvasena jotitesu tīsu kāmabyāpādavihiṃsāvitakkavatthūsu.
analyzed: imesu tīsu ṭhānesu uti imesu viramitabba tā vasena jotitesu tīsu kāma byāpāda vihiṃsā vitakka vatthūsu
translated: In these three instances: in these three instances of the object of sensual-desire, ill will, and cruelty, which are stated by the words “he abstains” .

original: Visuṃ visuṃ uppannassa tividhaakusalasaṅkappassa. Padapacchedatoti ettha gatamaggo
analyzed: visum visum uppannassa tividha akusala saṅkappassa pada pacchedato ti ettha gata maggo
translated: Of the three kinds of unprofitable thinking that arise separately.🔽By the cutting off of the tracks: here the path gone is called a “track” .

original: “pada”nti vuccati, yena ca upāyena kāraṇena kāmavitakko uppajjati, so tassa gatamaggoti
analyzed: padam ti vuccati yena ca upāyena kāraṇena kāma vitakko uppajjati so tassa gata maggo ti
translated: And the way, the reason, by which sensual-desire thinking arises is the track gone by that .🔽The cutting off, the destruction, of that is the cutting off of the tracks.

original: tassa pacchedo ghāto padapacchedo, tato padapacchedato. Anuppattidhammatāpādanaṃ
analyzed: tassa pacchedaḥ ghāto pada pacchedo tatas pada pacchedataḥ anuppatti dhamma tā āpādanam
translated: By the cutting off of the tracks.

original: anuppattisādhanaṃ, tassa vasena. Maggakiccasādhanena maggaṅgaṃ pūrayamāno ekova tividhakiccasādhano
analyzed: anuppatti sādhanam tassa vasena magga kicca sādhanena maggaṅgam pūrayamānaḥ ekaḥ iva tividha kicca sādhanaḥ
translated: and the accomplishment of its arising is by means of that. The profitable thought that accomplishes the function of the path by fulfilling a path factor arises as the single accomplishment of the three functions.

original: kusalasaṅkappo uppajjati. Tividhākusalasaṅkappasamucchedanameva hettha tividhakiccasādhanaṃ
analyzed: kusala saṅkappaḥ uppajjati tividha akusala saṅkappa samucchedanam eva ha itthā tividha kicca sādhanam
translated: The accomplishment of the three functions here should be regarded as the cutting off of the three kinds of unprofitable thinking.

original: daṭṭhabbaṃ. Iminā nayena “imesu catūsu ṭhānesū”tiādīsupi attho veditabbo.
analyzed: daṭṭhabbam iminā nayena imesu catūsu ṭhānesu uti ādīsu pi atthaḥ veditabbo
translated: The meaning should be understood in this way also in the case of the other three terms beginning with “in these four instances.”

original: Musāvādāveramaṇiādayoti ettha yasmā sikkhāpadavibhaṅge viraticetanā, sabbe sampayuttadhammā🔽ca sikkhāpadānīti āgatānīti tattha padhānānaṃ viraticetanānaṃ vasena “viratiyopi
analyzed: ettha yasmā sikkhāpada vibhaṅge virati cetanā sabbe sampayutta dhammā  ca sikkhāpadāni iti āgatāni iti tattha padhānānam virati cetanānam vasena
translated: As to “abstinences from false speech, etc.,” since in the description of the training precepts the volition of abstinence and all associated states🔽are said to be the training precepts,🔽it was said in the Vibhaṅga in order to remove confusion, “They are abstinences and they are volitions too” .

original: honti cetanāyopī”ti sammohavinodaniyaṃ vuttaṃ, tasmā keci “ādi-saddena na kevalaṃ
analyzed: honti cetanāya upi iti sammoha vinodaniyam vuttam tasmā keci ādi saddena na kevalam
translated: So some say that the word “etc.” includes not only the abstinences from malicious speech, etc.,

original: pisuṇavācā veramaṇiādīnaṃyeva saṅgaho, atha kho tādisānaṃ cetanānampi saṅgaho”ti
analyzed: pisuṇa vācā saṅgahaḥ atha kho saṅgahaḥ iti
translated: but also the volitions of that kind.

original: vadanti, taṃ pubbabhāgavasena vuccamānattā yujjeyya, musāvādādīhi viramaṇakāle vā
analyzed: vadanti tam pubba bhāga vasena vuccamāna ttā yujjeyya musāvāda ādīhi viramaṇa kāle vā
translated: That is correct if it is said with reference to the prior stage. Or else it is correct if it is said at the time of abstaining from false speech, etc.,

original: viratiyo, subhāsitādivācābhāsanādikāle ca cetanāyo yojetabbā, maggakkhaṇe pana viratiyova🔽icchitabbā cetanānaṃ amaggaṅgattā. Ekassa ñāṇassa dukkhādiñāṇatā viya, ekāya viratiyā
analyzed: viratiyaḥ su bhāsita ādi vācā bhāsana ādi kāle ca cetanāyaḥ yojetabbā magga kkhaṇe pana viratiyaḥ uva  icchitabbā cetanānaṃ a magga aṅga ttā ekassa ñāṇassa dukkha ādi ñāṇa tā viya ekāya viratiyā
translated: And the abstinences should be construed at the time of speaking rightly, etc., and the volition at the time of the manifestation of the right speech, and so on. But at the moment of the path only the abstinences are required,🔽because volition is not a factor of the path, just as the knowledge of suffering, etc., is not the knowledge of the first path, and the abstinence from false speech, etc., is not the right speech, and so on.

original: musāvādādiviratibhāvo viya ca ekāya cetanāya sammāvācādikiccattayasādhanasabhāvābhāvā
analyzed: musāvāda ādi virati bhāvaḥ ca ekāya cetanāya
translated: And because the single volition cannot have the nature of accomplishing the three functions of right speech, and so on,

original: sammāvācādibhāvāsiddhito, taṃsiddhiyaṃ aṅgattayatāsiddhito ca.
analyzed: sammā vācā ādi bhāva asiddhitaḥ ca
translated: because it is not established as right speech, and so on, and because it is established as the three factors if it is established as right speech, and so on.

original: Bhikkhussa ājīvahetukaṃ kāyavacīduccaritaṃ nāma ayoniso āhārapariyesanahetukameva
analyzed: bhikkhussa ājīva hetukam kāyavacī duccaritam nāma ayonisas āhāra pariyesana hetukam eva
translated: The bhikkhu’s bodily and verbal misconduct due to livelihood is called “misconduct due to wrong search for food,”

original: siyāti āha “khādanīya…pe… duccarita”nti. Kāyavacīduccaritaggahaṇañca kāyavacīdvāreyeva
analyzed: āha khādanīya pe duccaritanti kāya vacī duccarita ggahaṇam ca
translated: and so he said “misconduct due to wrong search for food, etc.” The inclusion of bodily and verbal misconduct is for the purpose of showing that the disturbance of livelihood is only in the bodily and verbal doors,

original: ājīvapakopo, na manodvāreti dassanatthaṃ. Tenāha “imesuyeva sattasu ṭhānesū”ti.
analyzed: ājīva pakopaḥ na manaḥ dvāra iti dassana ttham tena āha imesu yeva sattasu ṭhānesu iti
translated: not in the mental door. Hence he said “in these seven instances.”

original: Anuppannānanti asamudācāravasena vā ananubhūtārammaṇavasena vā anuppannānaṃ. Aññathā
analyzed: anuppannānam ti asamudācāra vasena vā ananubhūta ārammaṇa vasena vā anuppannānam aññathā
translated: As to “unoriginated” : either as to non-occurrence or as to unperceived object.

original: hi anamatagge saṃsāre anuppannā pāpakā akusalā dhammā nāma na santi. Tenāha “ekasmiṃ🔽bhave”tiādi. Yasmiṃ bhave ayaṃ imaṃ vīriyaṃ ārabhati, tasmiṃ ekasmiṃ bhave. Janetīti
analyzed: hi anamatagge saṃsāre anuppannāḥ pāpakāḥ akusalāḥ dhammāḥ nāma na santi tena āha ekasmin  bhava iti ādi yasmin bhave ayam imam vīriyam ārabhati tasmin ekasmin bhave janeti iti
translated: For in the beginningless round of rebirths there are no bad unwholesome states that have not arisen before. Hence he said “in any one becoming” .

original: uppādeti. Tādisaṃ chandaṃ kurumāno evaṃ chandaṃ janeti nāma. Vāyāmaṃ karotīti payogaṃ🔽parakkamaṃ karoti. Vīriyaṃ pavattetīti kāyikacetasikavīriyaṃ pakārato vatteti. Vīriyena🔽cittaṃ paggahitaṃ karotīti teneva sahajātavīriyena cittaṃ ukkhipento kosajjapātato
analyzed: uppāda iti tādisam chandam kurumānaḥ evam chandam jana iti nāma vā āyāmam karoti iti  parakkamam karoti vīriyam pavatteti iti kāyika cetasika vīriyam pakārataḥ vatteti vīriyena  cittam paggahitam karoti iti tena iva sahajāta vīriyena cittam ukkhipentaḥ kosajja pātato
translated: In any one becoming: in the one becoming in which he makes this effort. He generates: he produces. He who makes such zeal is said to generate zeal. He makes an exertion: he makes an effort, makes an endeavour. He exerts energy: he exerts bodily and mentally in the sense of repeatedly exerting.🔽He makes his mind steady: he makes his mind steady by lifting it up with that energy that is conascent with it, by preventing it from falling into the sloth of torpor.

original: nisedhanena paggahitaṃ karoti. Padahanaṃ pavattetīti padhānaṃ vīriyaṃ karoti. Paṭipāṭiyā
analyzed: nisedhanena paggahitam karoti padahanam pavatteti iti padhānam vīriyam karoti paṭipāṭiyā
translated: He causes his mind to be concentrated: he causes his mind to be concentrated by preventing it from falling into the sloth of torpor. He makes his mind one-pointed: he makes his mind one-pointed by preventing it from falling into the sloth of torpor.

original: panetāni cattāri padāni āsevanābhāvanābahulīkammasātaccakiriyāhi yojetabbāni.
analyzed: pana itāni cattāri padāni āsevanā bhāvanā bahulīkamma sātacca kiriyāhi yojetabbāni
translated: But these four terms should be construed with the four terms “repeated practice,” “development,” “making much of,” “steadfastness,” and “habituality.”

original: Uppannapubbānanti sadisavohārena vuttaṃ. Bhavati hi taṃsadisesu tabbohāro yathā “sā
analyzed: uppanna pubbānam ti sadisa vohārena vuttam bhavati hi tad sadisesu tad bohāraḥ yathā sā
translated: Arisen before: this is said by way of a like expression. For there is a like expression in the case of what is similar, as in the case of “the same” .

original: eva tittiri, tāni eva osadhānī”ti. Tenāha “idāni tādise”ti. Uppannānanti “anuppannā”ti
analyzed: eva tittiri tāni eva osadhāni iti tena āha idāni tādisā iti uppannā nanti anuppannā iti
translated: “Arisen” : they have come to be such that they cannot be said to be “unrisen.”🔽“For the abandoning” : for the purpose of abandoning.

original: avattabbataṃ āpannānaṃ. Pahānāyāti pajahanatthāya. Anuppannānaṃ kusalānanti ettha
analyzed: avattabba tam āpannānam pahānāya ati pajahana atthāya anuppannānam kusalānam ti ettha
translated: “Unarisen profitable” : here

original: kusalāti uttarimanussadhammā adhippetā, tesañca uppādo nāma adhigamo paṭilābho, tappaṭikkhepena🔽anuppādo appaṭilābhoti āha “appaṭiladdhānaṃ paṭhamajjhānādīna”nti. “Ṭhitiyā vīriyaṃ
analyzed: kusalā ati uttari manussa dhammā adhippetā tesam ca uppādaḥ nāma adhigamaḥ paṭilābhaḥ tad paṭikkhepena  anuppādaḥ appaṭilābhaḥ ti āha a paṭiladdhānam paṭhama jhāna ādīnam ti ṭhitiyā vīriyam
translated: “profitable” stands for supramundane states. And their “arising” is their attainment, their acquisition. By the word “unrisen”🔽their non-attainment, their non-acquisition, is meant. Hence he said “for the non-arising” of the first jhāna, etc.

original: ārabhatī”ti vutte na khaṇaṭhiti adhippetā tadatthaṃ vīriyārabbhena payojanābhāvato,
analyzed: ārabhati iti vutte na khaṇaṭhiti adhippetā tad attham vīriya ārabbhena payojana abhāvato
translated: “He makes a choice in the sense of establishing” : when it is said that “he makes a choice for the establishing of presence” , what is meant by “establishing” is not momentary establishing, because there is no purpose in making an effort of will for that purpose,

original: atha kho pabandhaṭhiti adhippetāti āha “punappunaṃ uppattipabandhavasena ṭhitattha”nti.🔽Sammussanaṃ paṭipakkhadhammavasena adassanamupagamananti tappaṭikkhepena asammussanaṃ
analyzed: atha kho pabandha ṭhiti adhippetā iti āha punappunam uppatti pabandha vasena ṭhita ttham ti  sammussanam paṭipakkha dhamma vasena adassanam upagamanan ti tad paṭikkhepena asammussanam
translated: but rather continuity-establishing. Hence he said “in the sense of establishing by the means of a continuity of arising again and again.”

original: asammosoti āha “asammosāyāti avināsanattha”nti. Bhiyyobhāvo punappunaṃ bhavanaṃ,
analyzed: asammoso ti āha asammosāya ati avināsana attham ti bhiyyobhāvaḥ punappunam bhavanam
translated: “For the non-remorse” : non-remorse is the non-seeing of the opposite state as a fault. Hence he said “for the purpose of non-loss.”🔽“For increase” : for repeated development.

original: so pana uparūpari uppattīti āha “uparibhāvāyā”ti. Vepullaṃ abhiṇhappavattiyā paguṇabalavabhāvāpattīti
analyzed: saḥ pana uparūpari uppatti iti āha upari bhāvāya ati vepullam abhiṇha pavattiyā paguṇa balava bhāva āpatti iti
translated: and that is the arising of the jhāna in a higher and higher stage, so he said “for the purpose of surmounting” .🔽The word “surmounting” is a synonym for “passing beyond” .🔽The word “surmounting” is a synonym for “passing beyond” .

original: vuttaṃ “vepullāyāti vipulabhāvāyā”ti, mahantabhāvāyāti attho. Bhāvanāya paripūraṇatthanti
analyzed: vuttam vepullāya ati vipula bhāvāya ati mahanta bhāvāya ati atthaḥ bhāvanāya paripūraṇa atthanti
translated: The word “surmounting” is a synonym for “passing beyond” .

original: jhānādibhāvanāparibrūhanatthaṃ.
analyzed: jhāna ādi bhāvanā paribrūhana attham

original: Catūsu ṭhānesūti anuppannākusalānuppādanādīsu catūsu ṭhānesu. Kiccasādhanavasenāti catubbidhassapi kiccassa ekajjhaṃ nipphādanavasena.
analyzed: catūsu ṭhānesu iti anuppanna akusala anuppādana ādīsu catūsu ṭhānesu kicca sādhana vasena ati catubbidhassa api kiccassa ekajjham nipphādana vasena

original: Jhānāni pubbabhāgepi maggakkhaṇepi nānāti yadipi samādhiupakārakehi abhiniropanānumajjanasampiyāyanabrūhanasantasukhasabhāvehi
analyzed: jhānāni pubbabhāge pi magga kkhaṇe pi yadi pi samādhi upakārakehi abhiniropana anumajjana sampiyāyana brūhana santa sukha sabhāvehi

analyzed: vitakka ādīhi sampayoga bhedataḥ bhāvanā atisaya ppavattānam catunnam jhānānam vasena sammāsamādhi
translated: The word “surmounting” is a synonym for “passing beyond” .🔽The word “surmounting” is a synonym for “passing beyond” .🔽The word “surmounting” is a synonym for “passing beyond” .

original: vibhatto, tathāpi vāyāmo viya anuppannākusalānuppādanādicatuvāyāmakiccaṃ, sati viya
analyzed: vibhatto tathā api vāyāmaḥ viya anuppanna akusala anuppādana ādi catu vāyāma kiccam sati viya
translated: The word

original: ca asubhāsukhāniccānattesu kāyādīsu subhādisaññāppahānacatusatikiccaṃ, eko samādhi🔽catujhānasamādhikiccaṃ na sādhetīti pubbabhāgepi paṭhamajjhānasamādhi eva maggakkhaṇepi,🔽tathā pubbabhāgepi catutthajjhānasamādhi eva maggakkhaṇe pīti attho. Nānāmaggavasenāti🔽paṭhamamaggādinānāmaggavasena jhānāni nānā. Dutiyādayopi maggā dutiyādīnaṃ jhānānaṃ.

translated: and the function of the fourfold insight into foulness, pain, impermanence, and not-self in the body, etc., is not accomplished by the single concentration.🔽So the first-jhāna concentration is the same in the earlier stage and at the moment of the path.🔽And so too the fourth-jhāna concentration is the same in the earlier stage and at the moment of the path.🔽The meaning of “joy” is the same.🔽By means of the different paths: the jhānas are different because of the difference of the different paths, that is to say, the first path, and so on. And the second, third, and fourth paths are the second, third, and fourth jhānas.

original: idha pana sammasitajjhānapuggalajjhāsayavādanivattanato pādakajjhānaniyamo vutto.
analyzed: idha pana sammasita jjhāna puggala jhā saya vāda nivattanato pādaka jjhāna niyamaḥ vutto
translated: But here the restriction to the basic jhāna is stated in order to prevent the view that the person who has attained the jhāna of reviewing and the person who has attained the jhāna of aspiration are alike.

original: Vipassanāniyamo pana sādhāraṇattā idhāpi na paṭikkhittoti daṭṭhabbo. Aññe ca ācariyavādā
analyzed: vipassanā niyamo pana sādhāraṇa ttā idha api na paṭikkhittaḥ ti daṭṭhabbo aññe ca ācariya vādā
translated: But the restriction to insight should be understood as not being stated here because it is common to all.

original: parato vakkhamānā vibhajitabbāti yathāvuttameva tāva pādakajjhānaniyamaṃ vibhajanto
analyzed: paratas vakkhamānā vibhajitabbā ti yathā vuttam eva tāva pādaka jjhāna niyamam vibhajanto
translated: And other teachers’ views will be analysed later on.

original: āha “pādakajjhānaniyamena tāvā”ti. Paṭhamajjhāniko hoti, yasmā āsannapadese vuṭṭhitasamāpatti
analyzed: āha pādaka jhāna niyamena tāvā ti paṭhamajjhānikaḥ hoti yasmai āsanna padese vuṭṭhita samāpatti
translated: So, in order to analyse the restriction to the basic jhāna as stated, he said, “As regards the restriction to the basic jhāna, etc.” The first jhāna is the basic jhāna for the path of stream-entry.

original: maggassa attano sadisabhāvaṃ karoti bhūmivaṇṇo viya godhāvaṇṇassa. Paripuṇṇāneva
analyzed: maggassa attano sadisa bhāvam karoti bhūmi vaṇṇaḥ viya godhā vaṇṇassa
translated: Because the attainment that arises in the adjacent stage makes the path like itself, like the colour of the soil does the colour of the cow.🔽They are complete: the meaning is that they are eight or seven.

original: hontīti aṭṭha satta ca hontīti attho. Satta honti sammāsaṅkappassa abhāvato. Cha🔽honti pītisambojjhaṅgassa abhāvato. Maggaṅgabojjhaṅgānaṃ sattachabhāvaṃ atidisati
analyzed: honti iti aṭṭha satta ca honti iti attho satta honti sammāsaṅkappassa abhāvato cha  honti pīti sambojjhaṅgassa abhāvataḥ maggaṅga bojjhaṅgānam satta cha bhāvam atidisati
translated: They are seven because there is no right thought.🔽They are six because there is no joy factor of complete awakening.🔽He shows that the factors of the path and the factors of complete awakening are seven and six respectively.

original: “esa nayo”ti. Arūpe catukkapañcakajjhānaṃ…pe… vuttaṃ aṭṭhasāliniyanti adhippāyo.
analyzed: esa nayo ti arūpe vuttam aṭṭhasāliniyan ti adhippāyo

original: Nanu tattha “arūpe tikacatukkajjhānaṃ uppajjatī”ti vuttaṃ, na “catukkapañcakajjhāna”nti?🔽Saccametaṃ, yesu pana saṃsayo atthi, tesaṃ uppattidassanena, tena atthato “catukkapañcakajjhānaṃ
analyzed: nanu tattha arūpe tika catukka jjhānam uppajjati iti vuttam na catukka pañcaka jjhānam ti  saccam etam yesu pana saṃsayaḥ atthi tesam uppatti dassanena tena atthato catukka pañcaka jjhānam
translated: Has it not been said there that the immaterial jhānas arise in three and four?

original: uppajjatī”ti vuttameva hotīti evamāhāti veditabbaṃ. Samudāyañca apekkhitvā “tañca
analyzed: uppajjati iti vuttam eva hoti iti evam āha ati veditabbam samudāyañca apekkhitvā tañca

analyzed: catuttha jhānam eva hi tattha lokiyam uppajjati na catukkam pañcakam vā ati ettha

original: kathanti pādakajjhānassa abhāvā kathaṃ daṭṭhabbanti attho. Taṃjhānikāvassa tattha🔽tayo maggā uppajjanti, tajjhānikaṃpaṭhamaphalādiṃ pādakaṃ katvā uparimaggabhāvanāyāti

original: adhippāyo. Tikacatukkajjhānikaṃ pana maggaṃ bhāvetvā tattha uppannassa arūpacatutthajjhānaṃ,

analyzed: sa santati pariyāpannaḥ viya hoti iti katvā vuttam attanaḥ vā cattāri saccāni iti parassa 🔽vāti ettha api esā iva nayaḥ tena āha bhagavā imasmiṃya iva byāma matte kaḷevare sa saññimhi

analyzed: samanake lokañca paññāpemi loka samudayañca paññāpemi loka nirodhañca paññāpemi
translated: I describe the world, I describe the origin of the world, I describe the cessation of the world,

original: lokanirodhagāminipaṭipadañca paññāpemī”ti kathaṃ pana ādikammiko nirodhamaggasaccāni🔽pariggaṇhātīti? Anussavādisiddhamākāraṃ pariggaṇhāti. Evañca katvā lokuttarabojjhaṅge🔽uddissāpi pariggaho na virujjhati. Yathāsambhavatoti sambhavānurūpaṃ, ṭhapetvā nirodhasaccaṃ
analyzed: loka nirodha gāmini paṭipadam ca paññāpemi iti katham pana ādikammikaḥ nirodha magga saccāni  pariggaṇhāti iti anussava ādi siddham ākāram pariggaṇhāti evam ca katvā lokuttara bojjhaṅge  uddissa api pariggahaḥ na virujjhati yathā sambhavataḥ ti sambhava anurūpam ṭhapetvā nirodha saccam
translated: I describe the way leading to the cessation of the world.” But how does one who is a beginner discern the truths of cessation and the path?🔽He discerns the aspect that is established by the tradition. And when he does so in this way, the discernment of the supramundane enlightenment factors is not contradicted.

original: sesasaccavasena samudayavayāti veditabbāti attho.
analyzed: sesa sacca vasena samudaya vayā ati veditabbā ti attho
translated: According to what is possible: according to what is possible, according to what is appropriate. The meaning is that, except for the truth of cessation, the rest of the truths are to be understood as “arising” and “vanishing.”

original: Catusaccapabbavaṇṇanā niṭṭhitā.
analyzed: catusaccapabba vaṇṇanā niṭṭhitā
translated: The description of the four noble truths is ended.

original: Dhammānupassanāvaṇṇanā niṭṭhitā.🔽404. “Aṭṭhikasaṅkhalikaṃ samaṃsa”ntiādikā satta sivathikā aṭṭhikakammaṭṭhānatāya
analyzed: dhamma anupassanā vaṇṇanā niṭṭhitā  aṭṭhika saṅkhalikam samaṃsanti ādikā satta sivathikā aṭṭhika kammaṭṭhāna tāya
translated: The description of the contemplation of ideas is ended.🔽The seven charnel grounds beginning with “a skeleton with flesh and blood, connected by sinews” are a meditation subject for one who wants to develop the meditation subject of a bloated corpse, etc.,

original: itarāsaṃ uddhumātakādīnaṃ sabhāvenevāti navannaṃ sivathikānaṃ appanākammaṭṭhānatā
analyzed: itarāsam uddhumātaka ādīnam sabhāvena iva ati navannam sivathikānam appanā kammaṭṭhāna tā
translated: because of their nature as a skeleton. So the nine charnel grounds are meditation subjects for absorption.

original: vuttā. Dveyevāti ānāpānaṃ, dvattiṃsākāroti imāni dveyeva. Abhinivesoti vipassanābhiniveso,
analyzed: vuttā dveyeva ati āna apānam dvattiṃsa ākāro ti imāni dveyeva abhiniveso ti vipassanā abhiniveso
translated: “Two” is inbreath and outbreath. “Thirty-two aspects” is the thirty-two aspects of the meditation subject. “Adherence” is adherence to insight.

original: so pana sammasaniyadhammapariggaho. Iriyāpathā, ālokitādayo ca rūpadhammānaṃ avatthāvisesamattatāya🔽na sammasanupagā viññattiādayo viya. Nīvaraṇabojjhaṅgā ādito na pariggahetabbāti
analyzed: so pana sammasa niya dhamma pariggaho iriyāpathāḥ ālokita ādayo ca rūpa dhammānam avatthā visesa matta tāya  na sammasa upagāḥ viññatti ādayaḥ viya nīvaraṇa bojjhaṅgāḥ āditaḥ na pariggahetabbā ti
translated: But that is the apprehending of the things to be comprehended. The postures and looking straight on, etc., are merely different states of material phenomena,🔽and so they are not suitable for comprehension like intimation, etc. The hindrances and enlightenment factors are not to be apprehended at the beginning.

original: vuttaṃ “iriyāpatha…pe… na jāyatī”ti. Kesādiapadesena tadupādānadhammā viya iriyāpathādiapadesena
analyzed: vuttam na jāyati iti kesa ādi apadesena tad upādāna dhammāḥ viya iriyāpatha ādi apadesena
translated: So it is said that “the postures, etc., do not arise” . The material phenomena that are the states of the postures, etc., are apprehended by means of the postures, etc.,

original: tadavatthā rūpadhammā pariggayhanti, nīvaraṇādimukhena ca taṃsampayuttā, taṃnissayadhammāti🔽adhippāyena mahāsivatthero ca iriyāpathādīsupi “abhiniveso jāyatī”ti avoca. “Atthi
analyzed: tad avatthāḥ rūpa dhammā pariggayhanti nīvaraṇa ādi mukhena ca tad sampayuttā tad nissaya dhammā ti  adhippāyena mahāsiva thero ca iriyāpatha ādīsu pi abhinivesaḥ jāyati iti avoca atthi
translated: just as the phenomena that are the materiality of the faculties are apprehended by means of the faculties. And the associated and the phenomena that are the support for the hindrances, etc., are apprehended by means of the hindrances, etc.,🔽according to the intention of the Elder Maha Siva, who said that “adherence arises in the postures, etc., too.” “Is there” , etc., is said in order to show that the postures, etc., are not intended by the words “the postures, etc.,”

original: nu kho me”tiādi pana sabhāvato iriyāpathādīnaṃ ādikammikassa anicchitabhāvadassanaṃ.
analyzed: nu kho mā itiādi pana sabhāvataḥ iriyāpatha ādīnam ādikammikassa anicchita bhāva dassanam
translated: for a beginner does not discern them as they are in reality.

original: Apariññāpubbikā hi pariññāti.
analyzed: a pariññā pubbikā hi pariññā ati
translated: For full understanding comes after prior comprehension.

original: Kāmaṃ “idha bhikkhave bhikkhū”tiādinā uddesaniddesesu tattha tattha bhikkhuggahaṇaṃ
analyzed: kāmam idha bhikkhave bhikkhu iti ādinā uddesa niddesesu tattha tattha bhikkhu ggahaṇam
translated: Although the words “here, bhikkhus, a bhikkhu” are used in the exposition and the demonstration,

analyzed: katam taṃ paṭipattiyā bhikkhu bhāva dassana attham desanā pana sabba sādhāraṇā iti dassetuṃ
translated: the purpose of the words “a bhikkhu” is to show that the practice is for a bhikkhu. But the teaching is common to all. In order to show this,

original: “yo hi koci bhikkhave” icceva vuttaṃ, na bhikkhu yevāti dassento “yo hi koci bhikkhu
analyzed: yaḥ hi koci bhikkhave icca iva vuttam na bhikkhu yā iva ati dassento yaḥ hi koci bhikkhu
translated: he said “Yo hi koci bhikkhave” and not “bhikkhu yevā” . In order to show that he said “yo hi koci bhikkhu vā” .

original: vā”tiādimāha. Dassanamaggena ñātamariyādaṃ anatikkamitvā jānantī sikhāppattā aggamaggapaññā
analyzed: vā ti ādim āha dassana maggena ñāta mariyādam an atikkamitvā jānantī sikhā appattā agga magga paññā
translated: The knowledge called “knowing” is the supramundane understanding that has reached its culmination, which knows without overstepping the noble actuality that has been known by the path of seeing.

original: aññā nāma, tassa phalabhāvato aggaphalaṃ pīti āha “aññāti arahatta”nti.
analyzed: aññā nāma tassa phala bhāvataḥ agga phalam pi iti āha aññā iti arahattam ti
translated: The supreme fruit is called “joy” because it is the state of fruition of that knowledge.

original: Appatarepi kāle sāsanassa niyyānikabhāvaṃ dassentoti yojanā. Niyyātentoti nigamento.
analyzed: appatare pi kāle sāsanassa niyyānika bhāvam dassento ti yojanā niyyātento ti nigamento
translated: The construction is: showing the state of being a refuge for the Dispensation even in a lesser time.

original: Mahāsatipaṭṭhānasuttavaṇṇanāya līnatthappakāsanā.
translated: The explanation of the Mahāsatipaṭṭhāna Sutta has shown the meaning of the condensed .

original: 10. Pāyāsirājaññasuttavaṇṇanā
translated: The Commentary on the Pāyāsi Sutta

original: 406. Bhagavatā evaṃ gahitanāmattāti yojanā. Yasmā rājaputtā loke “kumāro”ti voharīyanti. Ayañca rañño kittimaputto, tasmā āha “rañño…pe… sañjāniṃsū”ti.
analyzed: bhagavatā evam gahita nāma ttā iti yojanā yasmai rāja puttāḥ loke kumāraḥ iti ayam ca rañño kittima putto tasmai āha sañjāniṃsu iti
translated: The king’s son is called a “prince” in the world. And since this one was the son of King Kitti, it is said, “The king’s son, the prince, was thus addressed by the king.”🔽“Assa” is the elder monk.

original: Assāti therassa. Puññāni karonto kappasatasahassaṃ devesu ceva manussesu ca uppajjitvā
analyzed: assa ati therassa puññāni karontaḥ kappa sata sahassam devesu ca iva manussesu ca uppajjitvā
translated: Making merit, he was reborn for a hundred thousand eons among the gods and humans,

original: visesaṃ nibbattetuṃ nāsakkhi indriyānaṃ aparipakkattā. Tatiyadivaseti pabbataṃ āruḷhadivasato tatiye divase.
analyzed: visesam nibbattetum na asakkhi indriyānam a paripakka ttā tatiya divase ti pabbatam āruḷha divasataḥ tatiye divase
translated: but he was unable to produce a distinction because his faculties were unripe. On the third day means on the third day after the day he climbed the mountain.

original: Tesaṃ sāvakabodhiyā niyatatāya, puññasambhārassa ca sātisayattā vinipātaṃ agantvā ekaṃ buddhantaraṃ…pe… anubhavantānaṃ. Devatāyāti pubbe sahadhammacāriniyā suddhāvāsadevatāya.
analyzed: tesam sāvaka bodhiyāḥ niyata tāya puñña sambhārassa ca sa atisaya ttā vinipātam a gantvā ekam buddha antaraṃpe anubhavantānam devatāya ati pubbe saha dhammacāriniyā suddhāvāsa devatāya
translated: Because they were destined for discipleship and because their accumulation of merit was excessive, they did not go to an unhappy destination. For one Buddha-interval … experiencing … the god’s means the god of the Pure Abodes who was a companion in the same practice in the past.

original: “Kuladārikāya kucchimhi uppanno”ti vatvā taṃ evassa uppannabhāvaṃ mūlato paṭṭhāya
analyzed: kula dārikāya kucchimhi uppannaḥ ti vatvā tam eva assa uppanna bhāvam mūlataḥ paṭṭhāya
